Title: Trump's Speech on Afghanistan Disappoints "America First" Base

President Donald Trump's speech on Afghanistan on Monday night was met with disappointment from his "America First" base, who had expected a more isolationist approach to foreign policy. Instead, Trump announced plans to increase the number of troops in the 16-year-war, a move that many saw as a betrayal of his campaign promises.

Trump's speech was criticized by conservative commentators, including Ann Coulter, who tweeted that "it doesn't matter who you vote for, the military-industrial complex wins." Trump himself acknowledged that he had flip-flopped on his foreign policy, saying that his original instinct was to pull out of Afghanistan, but that he had been convinced otherwise.

Fox News commentators were divided in their reaction, with some praising the speech and others expressing disappointment. Todd Starnes, a Fox News Radio host, accused Trump of changing his campaign promise from "America First" to "Afghanistan First." Other right-wing commentators, such as Kyle Feldscher and Justin Raimondo, noted the contrast between Trump's rhetoric on the campaign trail and his actual policy.

Radio host Stefan Molyneux contrasted Trump's speech with his previous statements on Twitter, while filmmaker and author Mike Cernovich sarcastically congratulated "President McMaster" and "General Jared," referring to Trump's national security adviser and senior adviser respectively. Moderate conservatives, including Washington Post reporter Robert Costa, struggled to drum up enthusiasm for Trump's policy.

Costa noted the contrast between Trump's rhetoric and the plan itself, tweeting that Trump was echoing points made by former Chief Strategist Steve Bannon behind the scenes, but had ultimately gone along with a version of the plan proposed by National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster and Defense Secretary James Mattis.

Title: Trump's Immigration Position Remains Unclear Amid Contradictory Statements

The Trump campaign's stance on immigration has become increasingly unclear, with the Republican nominee making contradictory statements and failing to provide a clear policy outline. Trump's initial position, which emphasized building a wall and being "tough" on immigration, has been criticized for its lack of detail and potential humanitarian consequences. While some analysts suggest Trump is "softening" on the issue, his recent statements have been contradictory, with him expressing openness to a "touch back" policy while his campaign manager rules it out.

Trump's campaign has not provided a clear explanation for his shifting stance, leaving experts and voters alike confused. Policy experts are calling for clarity on his immigration policies, with some questioning whether it's even possible for Trump to recover from his anti-immigrant rhetoric. Trump's supporters, however, may be more forgiving, with some expressing sympathy for undocumented immigrants already in the country but supporting the construction of a wall to prevent new immigrants from entering.

The upcoming speech in Arizona is expected to provide more insight into Trump's immigration policy, but experts are skeptical that it will bring much clarity. Regardless, Trump's muddling of his stance has left many unconvinced that he is moderating his views, and some are calling for a more detailed and coherent policy outline.

Title: House Speaker Boehner Threatens to Ignore Senate Bills if Democrats Abuse Filibusters

House Speaker John Boehner joined Senate Republicans in their opposition to Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's plan to limit filibusters, threatening to ignore any bills sent to the House if Democrats abuse the parliamentary delay tactic. The move represents an escalation of a bitter partisan fight that has been brewing in the Senate for weeks.

Reid's plan, which could be implemented in January, would allow Democrats to limit filibusters without Republican support, a move that has infuriated Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell and other Republicans. The plan would require filibustering senators to be present on the Senate floor, a practice that has been abandoned in recent years.

Boehner accused Reid of trying to "marginalize Senate Republicans and their constituents" and said any bill that reaches the House based on the Democrats' "heavy-handed power play" would be "dead on arrival." He also suggested that the move could "poison the atmosphere" and hinder cooperation on Capitol Hill, particularly during the current negotiations over deficit-cutting measures.

The dispute has led to sharp exchanges on the Senate floor between Reid and McConnell, with neither side ruling out the possibility of negotiating a solution. The battle is a reflection of the ongoing partisan divide in Washington, with Republicans seeking to retain power and Democrats looking to advance their legislative agenda.

Statistics show that minority Republicans have increasingly used filibusters in recent years, with Democrats arguing that they are abusing the tactic. Republicans, on the other hand, claim that Reid blocks them from presenting amendments and that they are using filibusters to slow or kill legislation.

Title: Trump's Election Win Brings Repeal of Obamacare into Focus

The recent presidential election has sparked a renewed discussion about the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. Despite initial skepticism from some commentators, Donald Trump's victory has brought the possibility of repeal to the forefront. According to a post-election voter survey, 74% of Republicans want to repeal the Affordable Care Act, while 51% of Americans overall support repealing the law, as reported by Gallup and Rasmussen polls.

The desire to repeal Obamacare is not limited to Republicans, as a majority of Americans want to see changes or its outright repeal. The law's supporters, including those advocating for government-run single-payer healthcare, lost the election, and the President-elect and Congress will begin working together to repeal the law after January 20, 2017.

The media has responded with a propaganda campaign, warning that repealing Obamacare will be difficult or impossible. However, this stance is based on the assumption that the GOP does not have a filibuster-proof majority in the Senate. However, vulnerable Democratic Senators from red states may be willing to cooperate with Republicans to break a filibuster.

Even if a filibuster is maintained, the GOP leadership can use budget maneuvers, such as reconciliation, to repeal certain aspects of the law. The 2015 bill H.R.3762, which eliminated individual and employer mandates, taxes, and phased out subsidies, is an example of this approach.

The media has accused Trump of "waffling" on his promise to repeal Obamacare, citing an interview with the Wall Street Journal. However, this is a misrepresentation, as Trump has always supported the pre-existing conditions provision of the law.

The article concludes that the media's focus on the repeal of Obamacare has been on the potential obstacles and challenges, rather than the actual provisions supported by Trump's voters. The exit polls suggest that voters who feel the law went too far are breaking decisively for Trump, with 80% supporting his stance.

Title: Obama and Congressional Republicans Diverge on Key Issues Ahead of Election Year

The White House and congressional Republicans have taken different approaches to the upcoming election year, with President Obama focusing on his economic and income-equality agenda and the GOP concentrating on the health-care reform law and its consequences across the country.

In his weekly address, President Obama emphasized the need to raise the minimum wage from $7.25 to $10.10 for all Americans, highlighting his recent executive action to increase pay for federal contractors. He emphasized that this increase would benefit approximately 28 million Americans, lifting millions out of poverty and helping others work their way out of poverty without requiring new taxes or spending. The president urged Americans to ask their representatives where they stand on this issue.

On the other hand, Representative Tom Rooney, a Florida Republican, delivered the GOP weekly address, focusing entirely on the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) and its problems. He shared stories of constituents struggling to find primary care physicians and specialists, citing examples of seniors in Florida's heartland having to travel long distances to see a doctor. Rooney called on colleagues and citizens to work together to repeal the law, despite previous failed attempts.

The minimum wage increase is a key component of President Obama's "opportunity agenda," which requires Congressional approval. The president's push for a higher minimum wage has sparked debate, with some arguing it would benefit millions of Americans and others opposing it as a potential job killer. The issue of growing income inequality between the rich and poor in America is also expected to be a major topic heading into the fall election.

Title: Senate Gridlock: Obama's Nominees Face Resistance from Republicans

Article:

The United States Senate is facing a critical test of its democratic processes as President Barack Obama's nominees for key positions face increasing resistance from Republican lawmakers. The nominees in question include those for Secretary of Labor, Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Consumer Financial Protection Bureau director, and National Labor Relations Board members. The battles over these nominations are expected to continue, with some reaching the Senate floor as early as July.

The standoff has raised concerns about the Senate's ability to fulfill its constitutional duty to provide advice and consent on presidential nominations. If Republicans continue to block votes on these nominees, the majority may be forced to revisit Senate rules and reform them to prevent further obstruction.

One notable example is Richard Cordray, the nominee to lead the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. The agency was created as part of the Wall Street reform law to protect consumers from financial products. Republicans have refused to confirm Cordray, citing concerns about the agency's ability to function. However, critics argue that this is a transparent attempt to protect special interests and undermine the agency's purpose.

Similarly, the Senate has seen obstinate resistance to Obama's nominees for the National Labor Relations Board. A recent hearing on these nominees showed no signs of a thaw in this stance. As a result, some nominees have been named through recess appointments, which have been challenged by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The court has blocked Wall Street reforms, undermined labor rights, and rolled back environmental protections, sparking concerns about the court's impartiality.

The D.C. Circuit Court has three vacancies, and Republicans are trying to prevent the president from filling them, which would restore balance to the court. This move is seen as an attempt to eliminate the remaining vacant judgeships and prevent Obama from exercising his constitutional obligation. The situation highlights the ongoing struggle between the executive and legislative branches over the balance of power and the ability of the Senate to fulfill its constitutional duties.

Title: Trump Transition Team Deploys "Landing Parties" to Federal Agencies, Offers First Big Appointment

The Trump transition team has accelerated its activity, deploying "landing parties" to federal agencies responsible for national security and reportedly offering the next administration's first big appointment. According to a senior Trump official speaking on condition of anonymity, President-elect Donald Trump has offered the post of White House national security adviser to retired Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn, a former Defense Intelligence Agency chief. It is unclear whether Flynn has accepted the offer.

The transition team has been criticized for its slow pace of progress since the election. However, Trump officials dispute these claims, citing the complexity of the transition process. The team is working to lay the groundwork for the handover in January, with visits to the National Security Council and departments of Defense, Justice, and State.

The landing-party members are huddling in conference rooms at the agencies, receiving thick binders and detailed presentations that include organization charts, budget forecasts, and parking space assignments. This process is typical of previous transitions, with both sides working together to achieve a smooth handover.

The transition team will tackle federal agencies in three waves: national security, economic, and domestic. The next wave will focus on economic agencies, including the Treasury, Commerce Department, U.S. Trade Representative's office, Small Business Administration, and Social Security Administration. The final wave will fan out across domestic agencies, including the departments of Interior, Agriculture, Homeland Security, Energy, Labor, Transportation, Education, and Health and Human Services.

Trump's meeting schedule in New York included diplomatic legend Henry Kissinger, South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley, retired Army Gen. Jack Keane, and Family Research Council leader Ken Blackwell. The most unexpected meeting was reportedly set for this weekend with Mitt Romney, the 2012 presidential nominee who was a vocal critic of Trump during the race. Trump planned to move the transition meetings to the private Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, New Jersey, about 35 miles west of Manhattan.

The Trump-Romney meeting likely will take place there because the president-elect plans to stay in Bedminster until Sunday night, transition team officials said. Sen. Jeff Sessions of Alabama, a transition team member who is a potential pick for U.S. attorney general, said it's good that Trump is meeting with people like Romney, as there are many talented people he needs good relationships with.

Title: White House Welcomes Boehner's Lawsuit, Sees It as a Political Gift

The White House has been quick to respond to John Boehner's lawsuit against Barack Obama's use of unilateral executive authority, with the President himself poking fun at the move, saying "You're going to sue me for doing my job?" The administration has even encouraged reporters to write about the lawsuit, and Democrats have been buzzing about the possibility of impeachment. However, the White House's enthusiasm for the lawsuit may seem counterintuitive, as it is unlikely to succeed in court.

According to Andrew Prokop, the odds of the House GOP prevailing in court are minuscule. But the White House sees the lawsuit as a way to shift the focus away from its own struggles to advance its agenda and onto the Republican Party's perceived obstructionism. Since Republicans took control of the House in 2010, Obama's biggest political challenge has been that average American voters have a poor understanding of the US constitutional order. People expect the government to take action to improve their lives, and when that doesn't happen, they become frustrated with the President.

To address this issue, Obama has tried to highlight his executive actions, branding them under the banner "We Can't Wait." However, these initiatives have struggled to attract significant public attention due to their relatively small scope. The lawsuit against the President's use of executive authority provides a welcome distraction from this issue, allowing him to emphasize his leadership and the Republican Party's opposition to his agenda.

In a statement, White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest criticized the lawsuit, saying that at a time when Washington should be working to expand economic opportunities for the middle class, Republican leaders in Congress are playing politics instead of working with the President. The implication is that the lawsuit is a political stunt rather than a genuine attempt to address the President's use of executive authority.

The real-world alternative to litigation is simply doing nothing, as the parties do not agree and no amount of posturing or grandstanding will change that. However, the American public prefers the idea of compromise, collaboration, and action. The current partisan debate is often described as a stalemate, but it is better captured by the chess term "zugzwang," where the optimal move would be to pass and force the other player to make a move, except that passing is against the rules.

In this situation, the best move for House Republicans would be to do nothing, as Obama's approval rating is underwater and the GOP is poised to pick up seats in the midterms. However, conservative activists will not tolerate a pass strategy, and the lawsuit provides a way for Boehner to express his opposition to the President.

Title: Trump Cancels Secret Meeting with Taliban After Deadly Kabul Bombing

President Donald Trump announced on Monday that peace negotiations with the Taliban are "dead as far as I'm concerned" after the terrorist group claimed responsibility for a bombing in Afghanistan that killed an American service member. The bombing occurred on Sunday, just days before the 18th anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

The president called off a secret meeting with Taliban leaders and representatives of the Afghanistan government, which had been planned for Sunday at Camp David. Critics had expressed concerns about the meeting, citing the timing as disrespectful.

Trump stated that he personally decided to cancel the meeting after learning about the bombing, which killed 12 people, including the American service member. He denied reports that he had overruled his national-security adviser, John Bolton, and the vice president to schedule the meeting in the first place.

The president also expressed frustration with the prolonged U.S. presence in Afghanistan, recalling his campaign promise to bring home the approximately 14,000 American troops currently stationed in the war-torn country. He stated that the U.S. has been serving as policemen in Afghanistan, which was not the intended purpose of the troops.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo echoed Trump's sentiments, saying that the U.S. will not reward the Taliban for their violent behavior. "We're going to walk away from a deal if others try to use violence to achieve better ends in the negotiations," Pompeo said. "It's not right. It's not appropriate. It killed an American. And it made no sense for the Taliban to be rewarded for that kind of bad behavior."

Title: Media's Shift in Attention: From Physical Violence to Rhetorical Battles

The media's focus has shifted from reporting on physical violence to covering rhetorical battles between political opponents. In the past, violent incidents, such as the assassination attempt on Congressman Steve Scalise and his colleagues, received widespread media attention. However, the media's attention has now shifted to the verbal sparring matches between left-wing and right-wing individuals, often played out on cable television.

The article highlights the left's recent threats to advertisers, which led some corporate titans to temporarily bow to their demands. However, when the threats proved hollow, the advertisers returned. The article also mentions the left's past targeting of conservative media personalities, such as Rush Limbaugh, and its current focus on Sean Hannity and Laura Ingraham.

The article also touches on the rise of Fox News, led by Rupert Murdoch, as a champion of free speech and a challenge to the left's media monopoly. The author notes that the media's shift in attention has led to a decline in the popularity of traditional newspapers, which have struggled to maintain a balanced perspective.

Overall, the article presents a neutral and factual account of the media's shift in attention and the ongoing battles between political opponents, without taking a stance or expressing personal opinions.

Title: Secretary of State Tillerson Urges International Community to Take Action Against North Korea's Nuclear Threat

Article:

United States Secretary of State Rex Tillerson addressed the United Nations Security Council on Friday, emphasizing the need for international cooperation to address the escalating threat posed by North Korea's nuclear program. Tillerson called on member countries to fully implement UN sanctions and suspend or downgrade diplomatic ties with Pyongyang, citing the real threat of a North Korean attack on Seoul or Tokyo.

Tillerson emphasized that the international community must take concrete steps to prevent North Korea from making good on its threats, stating that "business as usual is not an option." He urged nations to downgrade their diplomatic relations with North Korea and warned that the US would not hesitate to sanction third-party countries that fail to comply with UN sanctions.

UN Secretary-General António Guterres also spoke at the meeting, condemning North Korea's record of violations of UN resolutions on nuclear and missile testing and development. He expressed alarm at the risk of a military escalation in the region, including the possibility of miscalculation or misunderstanding.

China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi also attended the meeting, pledging that Beijing would fully implement all UN sanctions on North Korea. Wang stated that China agrees with the international community to step up efforts on non-proliferation due to North Korea's recent efforts to accelerate missile and nuclear development.

The US Secretary of State's comments come as President Trump indicated that direct conflict with North Korea is possible. Trump told Reuters that there is a chance that the US could end up having a major, major conflict with North Korea. This statement came on the same day that Pyongyang released a propaganda video simulating an attack on the White House.

Title: Supreme Court to Consider Stay on Same-Sex Marriage Ruling

The United States Supreme Court is set to review a request to stay a federal judge's decision legalizing same-sex marriage in Utah, following a ruling by Judge Robert J. Shelby of the Federal District Court in Salt Lake City. The two-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in Denver has also declined to stay the decision, although it has called for "expedited consideration" of the appeal.

The state of Utah has requested that the Supreme Court block Judge Shelby's ruling while appeals proceed, which will initially be directed to Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the member of the court responsible for overseeing the Tenth Circuit. It is likely that the matter will be referred to the full court, with a decision expected within several days.

The Supreme Court will face a difficult calculation in deciding whether to grant a stay, as it did not have to confront similar issues in reviewing decisions from federal courts in California striking down Proposition 8, the state's ban on same-sex marriage. In that case, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit stayed both the trial judge's ruling and its own as appeals went ahead.

Professor Eric Dorf, a constitutional law expert, believes that there are probably not five votes on the Supreme Court to block Judge Shelby's ruling, citing the "strictly legal argument" that it is hard to justify granting a stay. However, he notes that the lower courts should have done so, partly due to the potential cruelty of voiding the new marriages and partly because the Supreme Court is difficult to predict.

Regardless of the Supreme Court's decision on a stay, it is unclear how it could hear the larger issue in the case in the current term. However, a decision in the court's next term, culminating in a decision in June 2015, is entirely possible.

Title: John Kasich Suspends Presidential Campaign, Leaving Donald Trump as Presumptive Republican Nominee

Article:

Ohio Governor John Kasich suspended his presidential campaign on Wednesday, leaving Donald Trump as the presumptive Republican nominee. Trump expressed conciliatory sentiments, stating that Kasich might be helpful in the general election and that he would consider him as a potential vice presidential running mate. Kasich's supporters lamented the loss of what they saw as the last source of civility in the race, as he was one of the few candidates who did not engage in personal attacks and innuendo.

Kasich's decision to withdraw was seen as a strategic move, as he had finally reached his goal of a one-on-one match-up with Trump, only to decide to exit the race. Some argued that he could have rallied anti-Trump forces and shown that Trumpism had not conquered the entire Republican Party. However, with Trump likely to accumulate a winning majority of delegates by the end of the primary season, Kasich felt he had no choice but to withdraw.

Kasich's campaign struggled to gain traction, winning only his home state of Ohio and failing to reach 20% in national polls. He finished the 2016 election in fourth place, with Trump, Senator Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio winning more delegates. Kasich's decision to stay in the race for as long as he did was seen as surprising, given his limited success in the early primaries and caucuses.

Trump has expressed interest in Kasich as a potential running mate, citing his experience and message as a potential asset to the ticket. Kasich, who described himself as the "Prince of Light and Hope," might see a VP slot as a way to validate his campaign and cap his long and varied political career. However, he would be joining a candidate who has shown little enthusiasm for either of those characteristics.

Title: Trump Criticizes School Resource Officer's Response to Florida School Shooting

Article:

US President Donald Trump has criticized the school resource officer who failed to confront the gunman during the recent shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. The officer, Scot Peterson, resigned after an investigation found he did not enter the building during the attack, which killed 17 people. Trump described Peterson as possibly being a "coward" who "did not react properly under pressure."

The President's comments came during a speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in Maryland, where he also reiterated his support for arming teachers as a solution to school safety. Trump proposed giving teachers a bonus for carrying guns, an idea that has been championed by the National Rifle Association (NRA) gun lobby.

However, Randi Weingarten, president of the American Federation of Teachers union, disagreed with the idea, stating that anyone who wants guns in schools "has no understanding of what goes on inside them - or worse, doesn't care."

The Broward County Sheriff's Office has released footage showing Peterson arriving at the building where the shooting occurred about 90 seconds after the first shots were fired and remaining outside for about four minutes. The attack lasted six minutes. Sheriff Scott Israel said that Peterson should have gone inside and addressed the killer.

It is unclear whether Peterson will face charges. The suspect, Nikolas Cruz, used a semi-automatic AR-15 rifle and escaped the scene before being captured later. The investigation is ongoing.

Florida Governor Rick Scott has called for law enforcement officers to be placed in every public school in the state and has proposed raising the minimum age for buying guns to 21 years old. He also plans to make it "virtually impossible for anyone who has mental health issues to use guns."

Title: North Korea's Loyalty to Kim Jong Un: A Frightening Reality

The threat of war between North Korea and the United States remains a pressing concern, with President Donald Trump warning of "fire and fury" and "total destruction" if Pyongyang continues to threaten the US or its allies. However, a decorated former South Korean general, Lt. Gen. In-Bum Chun, has shed light on the loyalty North Korean soldiers would show to their leader, Kim Jong Un, in the event of an invasion.

Chun, who spent nearly 40 years in the South Korean military, including a stint leading the country's special forces, believes that North Korean troops would fight with "nearly religious zeal" to defend their leader. He attributes this loyalty to the country's indoctrination system, where citizens are taught to revere the Kim family as gods. The current leader, Kim Jong Un, has made efforts to emulate his grandfather, Kim Il Sung, who was revered as the "Great Leader" and the "Eternal President."

Chun's comments are based on his firsthand experience and knowledge of North Korean society. He has spoken to defected North Korean soldiers who still hold an innate belief in the system, despite their own defection. The retired general also highlighted the country's militarized society, where pilots would likely use their planes in kamikaze-style attacks, and citizens receive extensive training in weapons use from a young age.

The crux of Chun's argument is that North Korean troops and citizens would remain loyal to Kim Jong Un, even in the face of an invasion, due to the country's system of surveillance and punishment for any dissent. Those who speak out against the regime could face imprisonment or even death in the country's gulags, which have been compared to Nazi camps.

While a war with North Korea is still unlikely, it is essential to understand the potential consequences of such a conflict. The reopening of a military crisis hotline between North and South Korea and Pyongyang's agreement to send athletes to the Olympics in South Korea next month suggest that diplomatic efforts are underway to reduce tensions.

In conclusion, Lt. Gen. In-Bum Chun's insights provide a chilling perspective on the loyalty North Korean soldiers would show to their leader in the event of an invasion. The importance of understanding this loyalty lies in the potential consequences of a war, which could be devastating for both sides.

Title: Florida Governor Rick Scott Claims Victory in Senate Race, Accuses Opponent of Fraud

Florida Governor Rick Scott has declared victory in the closely contested Senate race against Democratic Senator Bill Nelson, alleging that his opponent is committing fraud to steal the election. Scott made the claims during an appearance on "Fox News Sunday," stating that Nelson is trying to commit fraud to win the race.

The Florida Senate race is one of three statewide contests headed to an automatic recount, with Scott's lead over Nelson narrowing since election night. The recount was ordered after the unofficial deadline for counties to report results passed at noon on Saturday. Scott's lead has shrunk to just over 12,000 votes, with Democrat-rich counties like Broward County continuing to report additional numbers.

Scott repeated his allegations of fraud without providing evidence, echoing claims made by President Donald Trump that Democrats are trying to "steal" the election. The governor's comments concern two issues that surfaced after Election Day: the Palm Beach County election canvassing board's decision to cancel a ballot cast by a non-citizen, and Nelson's lawyers' request to allow all absentee ballots to count, including those where the signature on the mail-in envelope doesn't match the voter's file signature.

Nelson's legal team has insisted that the increase in votes for the incumbent is simply due to the fact that more votes are being counted. The Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the Secretary of State's office, both agencies overseen by Scott, have previously stated that there is no evidence of fraud.

As the recount begins, Scott has said he believes he has already won the race twice and intends to head to Washington to be sworn in as the state's junior senator. Senator Nelson was invited to appear on the show but declined. The Senate currently stands at 51 Republicans to 46 Democrats, with races in Arizona and Mississippi still to be resolved.

Title: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell Uncertain About Repealing Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

Article:

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell has expressed uncertainty about the likelihood of repealing the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA), also known as Obamacare, in the aftermath of the Supreme Court's ruling upholding the law's constitutionality. According to WHAS-TV, McConnell stated that it is difficult to repeal the 2,700-page health care law, as it is harder to undo something than it is to stop it in the first place. He made these comments during a visit to Hardin Memorial Hospital in Elizabethtown, Kentucky, where he discussed the law's future with about 50 people.

The Supreme Court's decision, led by Chief Justice John Roberts, upheld the law's crucial mandate that individuals buy health insurance or face a penalty. While this ruling technically handed a political victory to President Barack Obama, it also invigorated Republicans eager to cast the law as a new tax.

McConnell has stated that he would support using budget reconciliation rules to repeal the law if the Republicans gain control of the Senate next year. This would allow them to bypass a Senate filibuster and pass the repeal with only 51 votes.

However, some argue that the surest way to repeal Obamacare is to elect new members of Congress and a new president. Recent polls suggest that Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican nominee, is in a strong position to defeat President Obama in the November election. If Romney wins, Republicans would have a good chance of retaking the Senate, which would make it easier to repeal the law.

It is worth noting that Chief Justice Roberts' decision to uphold the law on the thinnest of grounds may actually make it easier for lawmakers to repeal it. While the constitutionality of the mandate has been resolved, millions of Americans will still be uninsured, and health care costs will remain high.

Title: Justice Department Seeks Tips on George Zimmerman Case, Weighs Possible Federal Civil Rights Case

The United States Department of Justice has set up a public email address to gather tips and information regarding the case of George Zimmerman, the former neighborhood watch volunteer acquitted of murdering Trayvon Martin. This move comes amid pressure from the NAACP and several Democratic lawmakers to pursue a federal civil rights case against Zimmerman. Attorney General Eric Holder stated that the department will "consider all available information" before deciding whether to move forward.

The Justice Department held a conference call with civil rights leaders on Monday, which included DOJ officials, FBI representatives, and federal prosecutors. The call was convened by Tom Perez, assistant attorney general for the Civil Rights Division. A Justice official noted that the conference call and email address are standard procedure when dealing with high-profile investigations.

Some attorneys and analysts have expressed skepticism about the likelihood of a successful civil rights case against Zimmerman, citing the lack of evidence or claims of racial bias in the investigation. However, lawmakers such as Rep. Corrine Brown (D-Fla.) have already made up their minds, stating that "Mr. Martin's civil rights have been violated."

In a separate development, Attorney General Holder also criticized "stand-your-ground" laws, which allow individuals to use lethal force when they believe their lives are in danger. The National Rifle Association (NRA) responded by stating that self-defense is a "fundamental human right." Holder also shared his own experiences with racial profiling during his address to the NAACP.

Title: US Withdrawal from Syria: A Decision Criticized for Jeopardizing ISIS Defeat and Hurting US Credibility

The United States has withdrawn its troops from northern Syria, a decision announced by President Donald Trump on Sunday evening. The move has been met with widespread criticism from both sides, with concerns that it will lead to a resurgence of the Islamic State (ISIS) and undermine the US's credibility as a reliable ally.

The decision to withdraw support from the Kurdish-led forces in the region, who have been instrumental in defeating ISIS, has been seen as a betrayal by many. The Kurds, who have lost thousands of lives in the fight against ISIS, are now left to face a potential invasion by Turkey, a NATO ally. The move has also raised questions about the US's commitment to its allies and its ability to maintain stability in the region.

Critics argue that the decision will not only jeopardize the defeat of ISIS but also undermine the US's credibility as a reliable partner. The withdrawal of US troops from Syria has been seen as a blow to the Kurdish-led forces, who have been instrumental in defeating ISIS. The move has also raised concerns about the potential for a resurgence of the terrorist group.

The decision has also been criticized for being a betrayal of the Kurds, who have been a key partner in the fight against ISIS. The US has been accused of abandoning its allies and leaving them to face a potential invasion by Turkey, a NATO ally.

The decision has also been seen as a blow to the US's credibility as a reliable partner. The US has been accused of abandoning its allies and leaving them to face a potential invasion by Turkey, a NATO ally.

The withdrawal of US troops from Syria has been met with widespread criticism from both sides, with concerns that it will lead to a resurgence of ISIS and undermine the US's credibility as a reliable ally. The decision has been seen as a betrayal of the Kurds, who have been a key partner in the fight against ISIS, and has raised questions about the US's commitment to its allies and its ability to maintain stability in the region.

Title: Clinton Emphasizes Bipartisanship, Urges Focus on Shared Goals

Former US President Bill Clinton delivered a bipartisan-themed address at the University of Kansas, accepting the 2015 Dole Leadership Prize. Clinton, the 42nd President of the United States, highlighted the importance of bipartisanship in achieving common goals, citing his decades-long interactions with former Republican Senator Bob Dole as an example.

Clinton emphasized that the current era is the most "interdependent" in human history, where forces both positive and negative are colliding. He urged Americans and the world to focus on shared goals instead of differences, stating that polarization is present not just in Washington but in American life.

Clinton referenced his autobiography, recalling his admiration for Dole's ability to fight for what he believed in while still being open to compromise. He noted that something happened to Dole during his time in the hospital recovering from World War II that allowed him to identify with others, a quality that is essential in today's world.

Clinton also discussed the importance of diverse groups making better decisions by reaching across lines. He cited examples of efforts initiated during his presidency, including the Families of Freedom Fund, which has awarded $118 million to survivors of the 9/11 attacks, regardless of citizenship.

The Dole Institute of Politics, named after former Senator Bob Dole, aims to foster civil dialogue about political and economic issues in a balanced and bipartisan environment. Clinton was selected for the prize for his work balancing the budget and practicing bipartisanship while in office. The prize comes with a $25,000 award, which Clinton has chosen to donate back to the Dole Institute to seed its new Women and Leadership Lecture Series.

Title: Republican Operatives Shift Strategy to Support Establishment Candidates with Unlimited Cash

Article:

A significant shift in Republican Party strategy is underway, as operatives are establishing super PACs to support establishment candidates in the 2014 and 2016 elections. This move marks a departure from previous efforts, where well-funded conservative groups like Karl Rove's Crossroads network and the Koch-linked Americans for Prosperity largely stayed out of primary fights, allowing tea party-associated groups to unseat more moderate Republicans.

The new strategy aims to help incumbent Republicans fend off tea party challenges with unlimited cash. Consultants and attorneys, including Charlie Spies, co-founder of the pro-Mitt Romney super PAC, are laying the groundwork or have already filed paperwork for dozens of super PACs organized to support individual candidates. The effort is the biggest reevaluation of the Republican Party's outside money strategy since the dawn of the super PAC era.

The prime targets for this strategy are incumbents who expect a primary election challenge. Even if candidates trust organizations like American Crossroads, American Action Network, or Congressional Leadership Fund to support them in Senate or House races, they are more likely to focus resources on general election races than get involved in primary contests.

Super PACs, unlike congressional campaigns, are permitted to raise and spend unlimited funds. However, the downside is that the campaign and the PAC are forbidden from coordinating. The Federal Election Commission requires a strict firewall between a campaign and a super PAC, meaning that a trusted aide usually needs to helm the outside effort.

The strategy shift reflects the growing internecine warfare between Republicans, which will likely characterize the 2014 and 2016 campaigns. The Senate Conservatives Fund, founded by former Sen. Jim DeMint, has vowed to attack GOP candidates deemed insufficiently conservative. Establishment Republicans say previous efforts to sack moderates only served to boost unelectable candidates like Delaware's Christine O'Donnell or Missouri's Todd Akin, who blew the GOP's chances in winnable general elections.

Single-candidate super PACs are also a sign that party leaders believe donors are unhappy with the results of big money groups in recent years and are willing to take their checkbooks elsewhere. Rove's Crossroads groups budgeted more than $300 million on a plan to defeat President Barack Obama and flip the Senate to the GOP in 2012, but failed. The perceived stumbles of Crossroads in 2012 led to recriminations within the conservative movement about Rove's dominance of the outside money apparatus.

In the special Massachusetts Senate election to replace John Kerry in 2013, a single donor bankrolled the deceptively-named Americans for Progressive Action on behalf of GOP senate candidate Gabriel Gomez, even as major GOP groups like Crossroads and Americans for Prosperity took a pass on the race.

Title: Polling Data Suggests Tighter Presidential Race as Election Day Approaches

As the United States approaches Election Day, polling data has revealed a tightening race between Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton and Republican nominee Donald Trump. Despite Clinton's consistent lead in polling aggregators and election prediction markets, recent developments have sparked concerns about the accuracy of predictions.

FBI Director James Comey's decision to alert Congress to the renewal of an investigation into new emails potentially related to Clinton's use of a private server as Secretary of State has thrown the race into chaos. The Mexican peso plummeted, and Wall Street began pricing in the rising possibility of a Trump win. The media has responded by hyperventilating over new polls showing the race tightening.

According to FiveThirtyEight, Trump trails Clinton by just 3.3 points in a polls-only forecast, with a margin of error. Even if the electoral college seems to place Clinton ahead by wider margins in certain states, national polls can be off by 2.7 points, which could flip states like Wisconsin and Minnesota into Trump's column.

Polling aggregators and data scientists have varying opinions on the race. HuffPost Pollster gives Clinton a 97.9% chance of victory, while Nate Silver's model gives her a 68.1% chance, accounting for increased volatility. Neuroscientist Sam Wang, who out-predicted Silver in 2012, notes that while some individual polls may place Clinton narrowly ahead, Trump's rise shouldn't be confused with momentum.

Wang observes that voter opinion has become entrenched, with a "regression to the mean" phenomenon occurring, where voter opinion tends to move back to a midpoint. Clinton is currently at the low end of her polling range, but if this trend holds, she may see a slight movement back to her average.

As the final weekend approaches, the race remains unpredictable, with many factors at play. While some polls suggest a Clinton lead, others indicate a tightening race. Ultimately, the outcome will depend on various assumptions and factors, making it difficult to accurately predict the winner.

Title: Democratic Debate Highlights: Biden Faces Challenges, Harris and Buttigieg Shine

The second round of the Democratic debates saw California Sen. Kamala Harris and South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg emerge as dominant forces, driving the conversation and challenging the frontrunner, Joe Biden. The debates expanded the possibilities of the Democratic contest, as Biden's performance left some of his supporters concerned and Harris's strong showing made her a top trending topic on Google.

Harris and Buttigieg were praised for their crisp and commanding performances, with Harris displaying her prosecutor's skills and Buttigieg showing a low-key and thoughtful approach to addressing a fatal police shooting in South Bend. Harris's decision to raise her hand in support of eliminating private health insurance as part of Medicare-for-All could complicate her appeal to moderate Democrats in the primaries and make her a target for Republicans in the general election.

Biden, who has generally ranked second in national and state polls, was criticized for failing to articulate a clear vision about what he would do as president. He was also challenged by Harris over his comments on segregationists and his stance on busing, which she said was "personal" and "hurtful." Biden accused her of mischaracterizing his comments and his position on busing.

The debates also saw a boost for some candidates, including former Housing Secretary Julian Castro and New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker, who both had strong appearances. The debates highlighted the unprecedented diversity of the Democratic field, with six women, two African Americans, a Latino, and an openly gay man participating.

The debates are just the beginning of the Democratic contest, with 11 more debates scheduled and the Iowa caucuses still more than seven months away. While Biden remains the leader in the field, his performance and Harris's strong showing have opened up new possibilities for the contest.

Title: Obama's Limited Role in Midterm Campaign Highlights Democratic Party's Shift

The article reports on the limited involvement of President Barack Obama in the current midterm campaign, a stark contrast to his prominent role in the 2010 election. In 2010, Obama rallied Democratic supporters with his "Are you fired up? Are you ready to go?" chant, but this year, he has only appeared at a few low-key events, including a fundraiser at actress Gwyneth Paltrow's home. The article notes that Obama's approval ratings have dropped, and Democratic candidates are distancing themselves from him, with some even refusing to acknowledge their support for him.

According to the article, Obama has headlined no public campaign events this election cycle and has only appeared in person with two candidates, both in Democratic states. In contrast, four years ago, he had led three rallies and appeared with five candidates. The article quotes Democratic strategist Steve Israel as saying that the party would love to see more of Obama's involvement, but it seems unlikely.

The article also notes that the White House has not announced any campaign events with Democratic Senate candidates, and some campaigns are hesitant to invite Obama due to concerns that it would shift the focus to national issues. A recent poll found that an endorsement from Obama would actually leave a more negative view of a congressional or Senate candidate.

Despite the limited role, Obama has maintained a busy fundraising schedule, headlining 58 events this year, comparable to his 2010 schedule. The article concludes that the White House has a long-term interest in demonstrating that Obama still has some political capital, and his limited involvement in the midterm campaign may be a strategic decision to avoid further damaging his reputation.

Title: Study Reveals Political Polarization Caused Americans to Spend Less Time with Family on Thanksgiving

A recent study published in Science has shed light on the impact of political polarization on family gatherings during the 2016 US presidential election. The research found that families with mixed political views spent 20 to 50 minutes less time together at the dinner table compared to families with like-minded political views. The study also revealed that Republicans left the table earlier than Democrats, with some Republicans leaving by more than an hour. Additionally, the study found that areas with heavy political advertising saw a threefold increase in the effect.

The study's authors, Keith Chen and Ryne Rohla, used communication and location technology to track the movements of over 10 million smartphones on Thanksgiving Day in 2016. They overlaid this data with voting tallies by precinct to determine the political leanings of the individuals. The researchers then analyzed the data to see if families with mixed political views spent less time together at the dinner table.

The study found that families with mixed political views spent an average of 73.6 million person-hours less time together on Thanksgiving, with Republicans leaving the table earlier than Democrats. The study also found that areas with heavy political advertising saw a threefold increase in the effect.

The study's findings suggest that political polarization has a significant impact on family gatherings, even on holidays like Thanksgiving. The researchers hope that their study will help to highlight the importance of finding common ground and bridging the political divide.

In conclusion, the study provides new insights into the impact of political polarization on family gatherings during the 2016 US presidential election. The findings suggest that political polarization has a significant impact on family relationships and highlights the importance of finding common ground and bridging the political divide.

Title: US Customs and Border Protection Clarifies Policy on Hurricane Dorian Refugees, Contradicted by President Trump

Article:

In the aftermath of Hurricane Dorian, confusion arose over whether people fleeing the Bahamas would be allowed to seek refuge in the United States. Over the weekend, a video surfaced showing an official announcing that those traveling from the Bahamas to the US needed a visa to travel, prompting concerns about the feasibility of evacuation. However, Acting Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection, Mark Morgan, clarified the situation, stating that storm refugees are welcome, regardless of whether they have travel documentation.

Morgan emphasized that the US will accept anyone on humanitarian grounds who needs to come to the country, saying, "If your life is in jeopardy and you're in the Bahamas and you want to get to the United States, you're going to be allowed to come to the United States, whether you have travel documents or not." The statement came as tens of thousands of people remain homeless in the Bahamas following the devastating storm.

However, President Donald Trump quickly contradicted Morgan's statement, emphasizing the need for "totally proper documentation" for those fleeing the Bahamas. Trump cited concerns about "very bad people and some very bad gang members and some very, very bad drug dealers" entering the US. He stated, "We have to be very careful. Everybody needs totally proper documentation because, look, the Bahamas had some tremendous problems with people going to the Bahamas that weren't supposed to be there."

The Washington Post notes that existing US policy allows Bahamians to enter the country without a visa by providing a passport and proof of no criminal record, as well as undergoing pre-screening conducted by CBP in Freeport and Nassau. The situation highlights the ongoing challenges faced by those affected by Hurricane Dorian, as well as the complexities of humanitarian crises and border control.

Title: Georgia Authorities to Review Fatal Shooting of Ahmaud Arbery, Family Demands Justice

The case of Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man who was fatally shot in February, is gaining widespread attention after a graphic video of the incident was released this week. The video shows Arbery being pursued by two armed white men, Gregory McMichael and his son Travis, who claimed they were trying to stop him for being involved in recent burglaries. However, Arbery's family maintains he was simply out for a jog at the time.

The incident has sparked outrage among lawmakers, with Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., tweeting, "Ahmaud Arbery was murdered for being Black. His White assailants were allowed to roam free for months after lynching him. They faced no charges, no arrests. Police had video of Ahmaud's murder the day it happened. His family deserves justice. Our country deserves answers."

The Georgia Bureau of Investigation is assisting the prosecutor in the case, and a grand jury will review the incident. Georgia Attorney General Chris Carr expressed concern over the events surrounding the shooting, stating, "I am deeply concerned with the events surrounding the shooting of Ahmaud Arbery."

Several politicians, including Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-Calif., and former Rep. Trey Gowdy, R-S.C., have weighed in on the case, calling for justice and an investigation. Former Georgia gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams, a potential running mate for Joe Biden, said, "I believe that there should be an immediate investigation of charges. It looks like murder. It looks like vigilante behavior that should be charged and criminalized."

Biden himself tweeted, "The video is clear: Ahmaud Arbery was killed in cold blood. My heart goes out to his family, who deserve justice and deserve it now. It is time for a swift, full, and transparent investigation into his murder."

The case has also prompted calls for the McMichaels to be detained until trial, as they have not been charged. The investigation is ongoing, with a grand jury review scheduled for June 13, pending Georgia's orders to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

Title: Common Core Standards Criticized by Celebrities and Parents, Sparking Pop Culture Debate

The Common Core academic standards, once hailed as a bipartisan success story, have become a topic of heated debate in recent months. Celebrities like Louis C.K. and Chuck Norris have joined parents in criticizing the standards, citing concerns over the stress and confusion they cause for students. The debate has spilled over into pop culture, with comedians like Stephen Colbert and late-night TV shows using the topic as a punchline.

The controversy surrounds the Common Core's emphasis on standardized testing and the perceived difficulty of the math problems. Louis C.K. took to Twitter to express his concerns, sharing pictures of third-grade math problems he deemed incomprehensible or "dumb." His tweets were quickly retweeted over 7,000 times, sparking a wider conversation about the impact of the standards on students.

While some critics argue that the Common Core is a necessary step towards raising academic standards and preparing students for the global economy, others claim that the focus on standardized testing has led to an overemphasis on rote memorization and a lack of creativity in the classroom. The debate has also raised concerns about the stress and anxiety caused by high-stakes testing, with some students reportedly vomiting from test-day jitters.

The controversy has also led to a wider discussion about the role of education in American society. Some argue that the Common Core is a symptom of a broader problem with the education system, while others see it as a necessary step towards improving academic standards.

The debate is not limited to social media, with comedians like Stephen Colbert and late-night TV shows using the topic as a punchline. Authors like Judy Blume, Maya Angelou, and Matt Damon have also weighed in with critiques of standardized testing.

While some critics argue that the Common Core is a necessary step towards raising academic standards, others claim that the focus on standardized testing has led to an overemphasis on rote memorization and a lack of creativity in the classroom. The debate has also raised concerns about the stress and anxiety caused by high-stakes testing, with some students reportedly vomiting from test-day jitters.

In conclusion, the Common Core standards have become a topic of heated debate in recent months, with celebrities, parents, and educators weighing in on the pros and cons. While some see the standards as a necessary step towards improving academic standards, others claim that the focus on standardized testing has led to an overemphasis on rote memorization and a lack of creativity in the classroom. The debate is likely to continue, with implications for the future of American education.

Title: Trump Arrives in Saudi Arabia for First Foreign Trip as President

President Donald Trump arrived at the Royal Court Palace in Saudi Arabia, marking the start of his first foreign trip as president. The president was greeted by King Salman and honored with an elaborate red carpet ceremony, accompanied by his wife Melania Trump. The White House staff, including Ivanka Trump, Jared Kushner, and other officials, also shook hands with the president and the king.

During the ceremony, Trump was presented with the Collar of Abdulaziz Al Saud, the Saudi nation's highest honor. The president and King Salman then spoke briefly, discussing topics such as Syria, with the king noting that the war-torn country used to be an advanced nation and pondering how quickly a country can be destroyed.

The Trumps arrived in Riyadh on Air Force One, landing at King Khalid International Airport around 9:45 a.m. local time. The president and first lady were greeted by King Salman, who joined them for a walk down a red carpet, with the Saudi Royal Guard lined up at attention along either side with trumpets playing. The first lady wore an ankle-length dress, while the president wore a suit.

The president and first lady then walked into the terminal, where a coffee reception with King Salman was held. The pair spoke through an interpreter inside the terminal, according to The Associated Press.

The high-profile welcome stands in stark contrast to the low-key reception Obama received in the kingdom last year, when the governor of Riyadh was the highest-ranking official to greet the president. The Saudis offered Trump an elaborate welcome, with billboards featuring his image lining the highways of Riyadh and lights bathing his luxury hotel in red, white, and blue.

Trump tweeted photos of himself in Riyadh, writing, "Great to be in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Looking forward to the afternoon and evening ahead. #POTUSAbroad." The trip marks the first time a U.S. president has made Saudi Arabia, a Muslim-majority country, his first stop.

Title: Justice Department Inspector General Criticizes FBI for Failures in Russia Probe

The Justice Department Inspector General, Michael Horowitz, testified before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee on Wednesday, rebuking the FBI for its failures during the initial phase of the Russia probe. Horowitz's report found 17 inaccuracies and omissions in the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrant applications for former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page, including a doctored email and the failure to include exculpatory information about Page.

During his testimony, Horowitz emphasized that the FBI's handling of the Carter Page applications was "antithetical" to the heightened duty of candor, and that the frequency of unsupported or contradicted representations made by FBI personnel raised concerns about the reliability of information contained in other FBI applications.

Horowitz did not reach any conclusions regarding intent, but he did not necessarily accept the reasons given by FBI officials for their actions. He stated that the FBI should have provided complete and accurate information to Justice Department attorneys and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, but instead, the information provided was incomplete and inaccurate.

The hearing also saw senators questioning the FBI's handling of the Russia probe, with Senator Josh Hawley asking whether the FBI was simply incompetent or whether there was a more sinister motive behind the failures. Horowitz replied that he did not find any evidence of intentional misconduct, but he did not credit the explanations given by FBI officials for their actions.

The hearing also touched on the issue of political bias, with Senator Rand Paul questioning whether the lack of a determination of political bias meant that there had not been any bias. Horowitz replied that just because they did not find evidence of bias did not mean it did not exist, and that there could have been 15 people involved whose bias influenced their decisions.

The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) also criticized the FBI in a rare public order, referencing Horowitz's findings and stating that the FBI's handling of the Carter Page applications was "antithetical" to the heightened duty of candor.

Overall, the hearing highlighted the FBI's failures during the Russia probe and the need for greater transparency and accountability in the handling of FISA applications.

Title: Republican Bill Weld Challenges President Trump in 2020 Presidential Election

Article:

Former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld has become the first Republican to challenge President Donald Trump in the 2020 presidential election. Weld, 73, released a campaign video highlighting his differences with the current president and touting his cross-party credentials. The video contrasts Weld's record with clips of Trump's provocative statements and ends with the slogan "A Better America Starts Here."

Weld, who served as governor of Massachusetts from 1991-1997 and was a running mate on the Libertarian ticket in the 2016 presidential election, believes that six more years of Trump's presidency would be a "political tragedy." He stated, "I would be ashamed of myself if I didn't raise my hand and run."

However, Weld faces an uphill battle to take over the Republican Party, which has been refashioned in Trump's image. The Republican National Committee promptly rejected his campaign, stating that any effort to challenge Trump's nomination would "go absolutely nowhere." According to a recent Gallup poll, 89% of Republican voters approve of Trump.

Trump's campaign has already raised over $30 million in the first quarter of this year, far surpassing the political war chests of individual Democratic candidates. Other potential Republican challengers to Trump include former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, former Ohio Governor John Kasich, and Maryland Governor Larry Hogan.

The 2020 presidential election will feature primaries for both the Republican and Democratic parties, where voters will choose their respective party's standard bearer for the November election. Sitting presidents rarely face internal challengers, and only a few have been denied renomination by their party.

Title: Texas Governor Rick Perry to be Booked on Public Corruption Charges

Texas Governor Rick Perry will be booked on public corruption charges at the Travis County criminal courthouse in Austin today, according to his lawyer, Tony Buzbee. Perry's defense lawyers have rejected the grand jury's indictment, calling it an attempt to criminalize politics and damage his prospects as a potential presidential candidate in 2016.

Perry's legal team includes high-powered attorneys with a strong track record in big cases. His lead attorney, Tony Buzbee, won millions of dollars for clients who sued BP over a refinery explosion in 2005. Another attorney, Bobby Burchfield, argued before the U.S. Supreme Court and won changes to campaign finance laws. George W. Bush's former lawyer, Ben Ginsburg, also joined the team, having co-chaired President Barack Obama's bipartisan committee on election administration.

The legal team is still unclear about which lawyers will be paid by the state of Texas and which will be paid by other funds, such as a defense fund. Perry did not attend the unveiling of his new defense team at an upscale Austin hotel, but they promised to publicize when Perry will complete the booking process.

Perry is facing charges of coercion and official oppression, which carry a maximum sentence of 109 years in prison, for carrying out a threat to veto funding for the state's public integrity unit last summer. The governor has emphatically stood by his veto and denied all wrongdoing. The judge overseeing the case, Republican Bert Richardson, decided against issuing an arrest warrant and instead granted a simple legal summons, which means a booking is still in Perry's future.

A summons has been issued for Perry to be arraigned on Friday, although Michael McCrum, the San Antonio-based special prosecutor presenting the case against Perry, said the governor may waive his arraignment altogether. Perry's spokesman, Felix Browne, said the governor would not need to appear personally.

The case has sparked controversy, with some Democrats calling the indictment a political witch hunt, while others see it as a necessary step to hold the governor accountable for his actions. The grand jury in Austin indicted Perry for carrying out a threat to veto $7.5 million in funding for the state's public integrity unit after Travis County District Attorney Rosemary Lehmberg, a Democrat, refused to resign following a drunken driving arrest. The ethics unit is housed under Lehmberg's office.

Regardless of the outcome, Perry's legal team is confident that he will be vindicated, with Burchfield stating that the prosecution is "outrageous and inexplicable."

Title: White House Denies Editing Intelligence Community's Talking Points on Benghazi Attack

The White House has denied allegations that it intentionally omitted information about terrorist involvement in the 9/11/12 Benghazi attack from the talking points circulated to administration officials. The claims were made after David Petraeus's closed-door testimony suggested that the intelligence community initially identified the possibility of terrorist involvement, but that this information was later removed from the talking points.

In response, the White House stated that it only made minor adjustments to the talking points, changing the term "consulate" to "diplomatic facility" since the Benghazi facility was not officially a consulate. The White House emphasized that it worked off the points provided by the intelligence community and made no other edits.

Senator John McCain has criticized the Obama administration's handling of the Benghazi attack, suggesting that the president's narrative that al-Qaida is diminishing in the Middle East is at odds with the reality of the group's resurgence. Chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Dianne Feinstein, expressed confidence that the White House was not involved in pushing a wedge between the intelligence and talking points, but acknowledged that Congress will continue to investigate the matter to determine what happened.

Title: Attacks on Individuals Wearing Trump-Related Items Spark Concerns Over Political Violence

Article:

A recent string of violent attacks on individuals wearing items related to President-elect Donald Trump has raised concerns over political violence and the potential for hate crimes. The incidents, which have been captured on video, involve individuals being beaten, choked, and subjected to racial and anti-Trump slurs.

In one incident, a mentally disabled man in Chicago was bound, gagged, and beaten while his captors yelled racial and anti-Trump slurs. In another incident, a 15-year-old student in Maryland was beaten up by several people while wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat during a student walkout to protest Trump's election.

A New York City man was also attacked on the subway after a man asked him if he supported the president-elect. The victim reported that he was choked and shoved against a wall by his attackers.

Some of the attackers have been heard using phrases such as "You voted Trump?" and "Don't vote Trump!" during the assaults. A survey found that at least 2,000 educators around the country reported hearing racial slurs and other derogatory remarks being used against white students in the days following Trump's victory.

While it is unclear if all the victims were Trump supporters, the common thread is the attackers' hatred of Trump. The incidents have drawn little media attention, but far more press has been given to alleged crimes committed by supposed Trump supporters, many of which have later been proven to be hoaxes.

One notable example is a black man in Mississippi who was arrested for spray-painting his own church with a "vote Trump" tag and lighting the house of worship on fire. Muslim women in Louisiana and New York have also lied about assaults by alleged pro-Trump aggressors.

The incidents have sparked concerns over political violence and the potential for hate crimes. The attacks have also highlighted the need for greater understanding and tolerance in the face of political differences.

Title: Constitutional Scholars Debate Legality of President's Airstrike Campaign Against ISIS

The legality of President Obama's sustained and targeted airstrike campaign against ISIS forces in Iraq is a topic of contention among constitutional scholars. While some experts argue that any targeted military operation lasting no longer than a few days passes constitutional muster, others disagree, citing the War Powers Act and the president's obligation to report to Congress within 48 hours of the airstrikes commencing.

According to Louis Fisher, a scholar at the Constitutional Law Project, any conflict lasting a few days could be justified, but President Obama's campaign against ISIS is expected to last longer. Under the War Powers Act, Obama is required to report to Congress within 48 hours of the airstrikes commencing, and he has 60 days to convince Congress to get on board or pull out the troops. However, Obama has not done so, and the situation becomes more convoluted when legal experts deliberate on the nature of the attacks.

Some experts argue that the airstrikes were initially deemed lawful because they were launched outside the city of Erbil, with the explicit purpose of protecting American citizens. However, recent airstrikes are being launched solely to protect the ethnic minority population in northern Iraq, which raises legal implications. Obama has defended the airstrikes against ISIS near Mt. Sinjar as a "humanitarian effort" necessary to prevent genocide, but some experts argue that the president has no constitutional authority to use American forces in combat to defend foreigners.

Not all constitutional scholars agree on this point, with Robert F. Turner, a national security professor at the University of Virginia, defending Obama's actions in Iraq. Turner believes that Obama can continue ordering airstrikes against ISIS because they are not a foreign state, just a terrorist group. "What he's doing, it's not an act of war," Turner said. "He's essentially coming to the defense of Iraq. Nobody recognizes ISIS as a state. They're not set up as a government, they're just a band of terrorists."

Regardless of the debate, the president has pursued targeted airstrike campaigns in the past without Congress' approval, and against the wishes of his top legal advisors. If he does this again, it's safe to say cries of executive overreach will only grow louder, even if his actions are warranted and well-intentioned.

Title: Mario Lopez Apologizes for Comments on Parenting Transgender Children

Article:

Mario Lopez, a television host and actor, has apologized for his recent comments on parenting transgender children. In an interview with conservative commentator Candace Owens, Lopez expressed his confusion and concern about the trend of celebrities allowing their children to choose their gender. He stated that he believes it is "dangerous" for parents to make decisions about their child's gender at a young age, citing his own experience as a parent.

Lopez's comments sparked widespread criticism on social media, with many users accusing him of being "cancelled" and ignorant about transgender issues. The LGBTQ organization PFLAG even offered to provide him with education on the differences between gender, sex, and sexual orientation.

In a statement, Lopez apologized for his comments, saying they were "ignorant and insensitive" and that he will strive to be more informed and thoughtful in the future. He also expressed his support for the LGBTQ community.

The controversy surrounding Lopez's comments highlights the ongoing debate about gender identity and the importance of education and understanding. While some argue that allowing children to choose their gender is a form of self-expression and acceptance, others believe it is a trend that may have long-term consequences for the children involved.

It is essential to approach this topic with sensitivity and respect for all individuals, regardless of their gender identity. As Lopez's apology demonstrates, it is crucial to be open to learning and growing, and to recognize the importance of understanding and acceptance.

**Google News Search Results Found to Have Left-Leaning Bias, Study Concludes**

A recent report by AllSides, a group specializing in identifying media bias, has concluded that Google News search results have a bias towards the left end of the political spectrum. However, the report also suggests that this bias may be a reflection of the general bias of popular online news sources and not intentional manipulation by Google.

According to the study, Google's search results are influenced by its popularity algorithm, which favors viewpoints that are more widely consumed online. As a result, viewpoints that are outside the majority may not appear as high up in search results. The study analyzed 123 different measurements of Google News and Google News search results over 14 days and found that the overall bias of Google News is 65% left, 20% center, and 16% right.

The study also found that the average position of the first result from left, center, or right sources is telling. Left-leaning sources tend to appear in the top two results, while right-leaning sources are often below the fold, requiring users to scroll down to find them.

The findings are consistent with past research and observations by AllSides, which has often struggled to find perspectives from the right when using Google News. The study does not suggest intentional favoritism for left-leaning media sources, but rather a natural and unintended consequence of Google's algorithms and the fact that most news outlets and journalists lean left.

The full report, available online, provides more detail on the methodology and findings.

Title: House Republicans Plan Vote on Debt Ceiling Bill, Posing Test for Obama's Second Term

Article:

House Republicans are set to vote on a debt ceiling bill this week, marking the first legislative battle of President Obama's second term. The bill, unveiled on Monday, would allow the government to continue borrowing through May 18, but it also includes a provision that would withhold lawmakers' pay if their chamber fails to pass a budget by April 15. The "no budget, no pay" provision has raised questions about its constitutionality, with some critics citing the 27th Amendment, which states that no law altering congressional compensation can take effect until after an election.

House Republican leaders are defending the plan, arguing that it would not violate the 27th Amendment because it would temporarily withhold pay, rather than reducing it. However, Representative Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., has expressed concerns that the plan appears to be unconstitutional.

The debt ceiling provision does not set a specific limit, but would automatically increase the limit by the amount required to fund U.S. government obligations through May 18. White House Press Secretary Jay Carney has stated that President Obama would not block the bill if it passes.

Democrats in Congress have reacted coolly to the three-month extension, which would still leave other fiscal challenges in place, including sharp spending cuts and the possibility of a partial government shutdown. However, failing to meet those deadlines would have less severe consequences than defaulting on U.S. obligations.

The debt-ceiling bill stands as the first legislative test of Obama's second term, and the president has vowed not to negotiate over the debt limit. If the debt cap is not raised, the government would default on its obligations by as early as February 15, according to the Treasury Department.

The debt ceiling, automatic spending cuts, and the expiration of the current budget are immediate domestic challenges facing the administration and Congress, which also present opportunities to tackle the country's bloated deficit.

Title: Sen. Jeff Sessions to Defend Reputation Against Assault on Character at Senate Hearing

Article:

Sen. Jeff Sessions, the nominee for Attorney General, will face a Senate hearing on Tuesday to defend his reputation against accusations of being a racist, sexist, and homophobe. As the first Cabinet nominee to face scrutiny, Sessions will insist that his lifetime commitment to law and order includes the protection of the rights of every American.

In his prepared opening remarks, Sessions will acknowledge the history of civil rights and the impact of discrimination on African-American communities. He will also express understanding of the demands for justice and fairness made by the LGBT community and the lifelong scars born by women who are victims of assault and abuse.

Sessions will emphasize his commitment to upholding the law fairly and equitably, denying any allegations of racial insensitivity or bias. He will outline his goals for battling gun crimes, illegal immigration, drug-trafficking cartels, and other criminal gangs, as well as protecting voting rights, supporting local law enforcement agencies, and building mutual respect between police and minority communities.

As the chief target of liberal groups hoping to derail President-elect Donald Trump's agenda, Sessions will face intense scrutiny from activists and Senate Democrats. However, he will try to present himself as someone qualified for the job and reverent of the responsibilities of serving as the country's top law enforcement officer.

In his statement, Sessions will acknowledge the weight of the responsibility and commit to being worthy of the office and the special trust that comes with it.
