He will emphasize his commitment to upholding the Constitution and the rule of law, as well as his belief in fairness, impartiality, and equal justice under the law.

The hearing will be a critical moment for Sessions, as he faces accusations of improper prosecution of black voting rights activists and making racially insensitive comments during his time as U.S. attorney in Alabama in the 1980s. He has vehemently denied these allegations and pledged to uphold the law fairly and equitably.

Title: Senate Approves Historic Gay Rights Bill, But Faces Uncertain Future in House

The United States Senate has approved a landmark bill aimed at banning workplace discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity. The legislation, known as the Employer Non-Discrimination Act (ENDA), passed with a vote of 64-32, with 54 Democrats and 10 Republicans supporting the measure.

The bill, which applies to workplaces with more than 15 employees, exempts religious organizations and the U.S. military. This stipulation helped win over some Republican support, although the bill still faces an uncertain future in the GOP-controlled House.

House Speaker John Boehner's office has announced that he does not plan to allow a vote on the bill, citing concerns that it will lead to "frivolous" litigation and harm small businesses. House Majority Leader Eric Cantor's office also stated that there is no vote scheduled.

Despite this setback, President Obama has urged House leaders to bring the bill to the floor, saying that "one party in one house of Congress should not stand in the way of millions of Americans who want to go to work each day and simply be judged by the job they do."

The bill has been introduced in nearly every Congress since 1994, but this is the first time it has received a full Senate vote. Twenty-two states and Washington, D.C. have already enacted laws prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation, and a June 2013 Pew Research survey found that 21% of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender adults reported being treated unfairly at work because of their sexual orientation.

The legislation is seen as a major step forward for LGBTQ+ rights, but its fate remains uncertain in the House.

Title: House of Representatives Passes Legislation for Republicans to Proceed with 'Budget Reconciliation' to End Key Provisions of Obama's Signature Healthcare Law

The House of Representatives has passed a preliminary measure that will allow Republicans to dismantle key provisions of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, by using a procedure known as "budget reconciliation." The legislation passed with a vote of 227-198, with nine Republicans joining Democrats in voting against the measure.

The move allows Republicans to use the reconciliation process to repeal key provisions of the law, which was signed into effect by former President Barack Obama in 2010. Republican leaders have said they intend to "repeal" and "replace" Obamacare, but they have yet to agree on a replacement plan.

The legislation passed in the House and Senate, with the Senate voting in favor of the measure in the early hours of Thursday morning. The move sets the stage for the repeal of the Affordable Care Act, which covers an estimated 20 million Americans.

Democrats have expressed concerns about repealing the law without first agreeing on an alternative, with House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi stating that Republicans have had six years to propose an alternative but have yet to do so. Republicans, on the other hand, argue that the healthcare law is "collapsing" and that they need to "rescue" Americans from soaring premiums and increasing deductibles.

The repeal of the Affordable Care Act is a long-standing goal for Republicans, who have been trying to repeal the law since its passage in 2010. With both chambers of Congress and the White House now in Republican control, they have the opportunity to do so. However, passing a replacement plan will be a challenging task, as Republicans will need to craft a proposal that unites their party and wins over some Democrats.

The process of drafting the legislation to replace the bill will begin in various committees, a lengthy and exhaustive process that will take place across four committees. The outcome of this process remains uncertain, as Democrats have shown no desire to rescue Republicans over their replacement plan.

Title: Supreme Court Hears Oral Arguments on President's Business Practices

The Supreme Court heard oral arguments on Tuesday via teleconference regarding the power to investigate President Donald Trump's business practices. The case revolves around the president's refusal to comply with subpoenas for his tax returns and financial records, which are part of a criminal investigation into his hush money payments to adult film star Stormy Daniels. The House of Representatives is also seeking to investigate potential conflicts of interest related to the president's business dealings.

Trump's lawyers have argued that a president should not be subject to investigation while in office, citing "temporary presidential immunity." However, the court's justices seemed skeptical of this claim, with some expressing sympathy for the White House's arguments against the House's demands for documents.

The justices are expected to deliver a decision in the cases, Trump v. Mazars, Trump v. Deutsche Bank, and Trump v. Vance, this summer.

Title: Right-Wing Media's Denial of Racism Provides Cover for Intolerance

Article:

Recent incidents involving rancher Cliven Bundy and LA Clippers owner Donald Sterling have brought to light the notion that racism and bigotry are over, a notion perpetuated by right-wing media. This dangerous fiction has also surfaced in recent Supreme Court decisions, providing cover for modern racists and policies that harm minority communities.

Fox News hosts and contributors have echoed this sentiment, with Eric Bolling stating, "Is there racism? I don't believe there's racism." Charles Krauthammer has argued that policies protecting against racial discrimination are no longer necessary because they're about giving "advantages to people who 50 years ago" were disadvantaged. Andrea Tantaros has claimed that civil rights laws are no longer needed "because there is equality." Bill O'Reilly has stated that racism is "an individual problem, not a country problem," and that America's sad history of discrimination is "all in the past."

This denial of racism provides cover for intolerance on the fringe. The recent Supreme Court decision in Schuette v. BAMN, which overturned decades of civil rights precedent and gutted a core component of equal protection law, is a prime example. The conservative majority took the position of "blame-shifting," suggesting that the debate over affirmative action should and could take place in a "genteel, controversy-free zone."

The decision has had damaging impacts on civil rights and minority communities, particularly in states like Michigan where white Americans are the overwhelming majority. The enrollment of African-American students in Michigan has seen a dramatic decrease, and racist incidents and racial tensions on campuses around the country are on the rise.

The Supreme Court's recent decision is reminiscent of its June 2013 blow to voting rights, which also made on the premise that racism no longer exists in America. States wasted no time after the decision pushing highly restrictive voting laws that history has shown serve to make it harder for minorities to cast a vote.

In conclusion, the denial of racism by right-wing media and the Supreme Court has far-reaching consequences, perpetuating discrimination and intolerance. It is essential to recognize the ongoing struggles of minority communities and the importance of protecting their rights.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch's Judicial Philosophy: A Focus on Interpreting the Law

Article:

Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch, who serves on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Denver, has shared his judicial philosophy in his book "Of Lions and Bears, Judges and Legislators, and the Legacy of Justice Scalia." In the book, Gorsuch emphasizes the importance of interpreting the law as it is written, rather than making decisions based on personal convictions or policy preferences.

Gorsuch believes that judges should focus on applying the law as it is, rather than trying to shape it to fit their own moral or political views. He advocates for a traditional approach to judicial interpretation, which involves considering the text, structure, and history of the law to determine what a reasonable reader at the time of the events in question would have understood the law to be.

Gorsuch also emphasizes the importance of judges issuing judgments with which they may disagree as a matter of policy, as long as they believe it is what the law fairly demands. He believes that this approach will help to maintain the integrity of the judicial system and ensure that judges remain impartial and unbiased.

Gorsuch's views on judicial philosophy are heavily influenced by those of the late Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, whom he has praised for his commitment to interpreting the law as written. Gorsuch has stated that he believes Scalia's approach will endure, despite criticism from some who argue that judges should be more proactive in shaping the law to address social and economic issues.

Overall, Gorsuch's judicial philosophy emphasizes the importance of interpreting the law as it is written, rather than trying to shape it to fit personal or political agendas. His approach is rooted in a commitment to traditional judicial principles and a desire to maintain the integrity of the judicial system.

Title: House Approves Budget Resolution to Dismantle Affordable Care Act

The House of Representatives has begun the process of dismantling the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, by approving a budget resolution on a mostly party-line vote. The Senate passed the measure earlier this week, allowing Republicans to use a process known as "budget reconciliation" to roll back major parts of the healthcare law.

Nine Republicans voted against the measure, with some expressing concerns about the lack of a clear plan to replace Obamacare. Representative Charlie Dent, a moderate Republican from Pennsylvania, cautioned that the decision could further send insurance markets into a spiral, emphasizing the need for a clear plan before moving forward.

Representatives Justin Amash, a libertarian Republican from Michigan, opposed the measure due to broader concerns about government spending. The vote also formally approved budget guidelines for the current fiscal year, which adds more than $9 trillion to the debt over the next decade.

The focus of the debate has been on Obamacare, which is set to dominate much of the time in Washington in the coming months. House Majority Whip Steve Scalise stated that the vote shows Republicans are serious about repealing and replacing the law, while House Speaker Paul Ryan described the move as a "rescue mission" to fix the massive healthcare law.

Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who led the passage of the law in 2009 and 2010, accused Republicans of attempting to "cut and run" on people with health insurance and argued that their replacement plan would cut Medicare benefits.

The vote will clear the decks for Republicans to begin working on a repeal of the law, but the larger debate has exposed rifts within the Republican Party. Some conservative Republicans are concerned about the timeline to replace Obamacare, while more moderate members are worried about moving forward with repeal without more detailed replace plans.

Title: Trump's Fundraising Lead Eroded as Democratic Primary Field Surpasses His 2019 Haul

The 2020 Democratic presidential primary debate, co-hosted by CNN and the Des Moines Register, took place on January 14, 2020, at the Drake University campus in Des Moines, Iowa. The event featured Democratic presidential hopefuls Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren (D), former Vice President Joe Biden (D), and Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders (I).

In a significant development, President Donald Trump's fundraising lead in his 2020 reelection bid has been eroded by the crowded Democratic primary field. According to an analysis of Federal Election Commission filings and campaign statements, the Democratic primary field has more than tripled Trump's 2019 cash haul. This marks an unprecedented feat, as no incumbent president this century has been outraised by a field of challengers in the year before a reelection contest.

The main Republican challengers to President Barack Obama in 2012 barely took in more than the incumbent in 2011, while President George W. Bush narrowly topped his challengers in fundraising in 2003, the year before he won reelection in 2004.

Sarah Bryner, director of research and strategy at the Center for Responsive Politics, noted that the cash edge reflects a Democratic voter base energized and motivated since Trump's 2016 election. She added that the pace of donations could reflect a dislike of Trump more than a fondness for any particular candidate – although Democratic contender and prolific fundraiser Senator Bernie Sanders has a famously devoted following.

Trump's campaign still had a fundraising advantage over any of his potential challengers entering 2020, raising $46 million in the fourth quarter, higher than Sanders' $34.5 million, the biggest haul in the Democratic field. The Trump campaign had accumulated cash while rivals in the jammed Democratic primary compete for donors, with more than $100 million in the bank at the end of 2019. Most Democratic campaigns will not announce cash-on-hand numbers until the end of the month.

The fundraising figures for Trump, his two predecessors, and their challengers in the year prior to their reelection bids are listed and visualized below. Total receipts, which include transfers from other campaign committees, and contributions from individuals are listed separately.

**Democratic Presidential Debate Set to Take Place in Des Moines, Iowa**

The first Democratic presidential debate of 2020 is scheduled to take place in Des Moines, Iowa, just three weeks before the Iowa caucuses. The debate will feature a slim cast of six hopefuls, including Sens. Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, and Amy Klobuchar, former Vice President Joe Biden, Pete Buttigieg, and billionaire Tom Steyer.

The debate is expected to be a battle for heads, not hearts, as the candidates face off in a tight race. The rift between Sens. Sanders and Warren has grown, with both candidates realizing that they may split the progressive vote and hand a victory to Biden if they don't consolidate a solid base.

The debate comes as the election is now underway, with the Democratic hopefuls now foes and rivals rather than friends. The debate will be hosted by CNN and will be the largest gathering of liberals since Woodstock, according to Ross Baker, a political science professor at Rutgers University.

**Texas Governor Awards Medal of Courage**

Texas Governor Greg Abbott has awarded the Governor's Medal of Courage to Jack Wilson, a former reserve deputy sheriff who took out a shooter who opened fire in a Fort Worth church in late December. Wilson, 71, heads up the church's volunteer security squad and took out the gunman with a single round within six seconds after the shooting began.

**President Trump to Hold Rally in Milwaukee**

President Trump will hold a rally in Milwaukee on Tuesday, part of a long sequence of campaign rallies that make up his successful voter outreach. The rally will take place in the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Panther Arena, which has caused consternation among students who deemed the event a "hate" rally. University Chancellor Mark Mone has explained that the campus has naming rights for the venue but does not own the site or control who appears there.

**Media Coverage of President Trump**

A Media Research Center analysis has found that almost all broadcast coverage of President Trump has been negative in recent months. The analysis evaluated 1,053 comments about Trump that aired on ABC, CBS, and NBC from September 24 to January 1 and found that the Big Three evening newscasts have battered the President with 93% negative coverage and promoted impeachment at the expense of nearly all other Trump news.

**Public Opinion on Economic Inequality**

A Pew Research Center poll of 6,878 U.S. adults found that 66% of Americans believe the federal government should have a lot of responsibility in reducing economic inequality in the U.S., while 44% of Republicans and 75% of Democrats agree. The poll also found that 62% of Americans believe large business and corporations should have responsibility, 52% believe state governments should have responsibility, and 46% believe wealthy individuals should have responsibility.

Title: Obama Discusses Baltimore Riots, Emphasizes Need for Long-Term Solutions

President Barack Obama addressed the recent Baltimore riots, offering six points on the issue during a news conference with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The president's remarks focused on the need for a long-term approach to address the underlying issues driving the unrest, rather than just reacting to immediate crises.

Obama emphasized that the problem of racial tensions and police-community relations is a "slow-rolling crisis" that has been ongoing for a long time. He acknowledged that the recent riots are a symptom of a broader issue, and that simply sending police to contain the problem will not solve it. The president also expressed sympathy for the families of Freddie Gray, who died in police custody, as well as the injured police officers and their families.

Obama highlighted the need to focus on the peaceful protests and the efforts of those working to defuse the violence, rather than just the violent acts themselves. He also pointed out that his administration has taken steps to address the issue, including the creation of a task force on policing and efforts to work with local communities to implement police reforms.

The president also emphasized the need for society as a whole to take responsibility for the well-being of children in disadvantaged communities, particularly those who are black. He noted that solving the problem will require a sustained effort and attention, as well as a recognition that these issues are not just a law-and-order issue, but a broader social issue.

Obama's remarks were seen as a departure from his previous comments on race, which have sometimes been criticized for being too vague or too focused on individual incidents. However, his aides say that the president's thinking on the issue has not changed much over his time in office, and that his recent comments were an effort to provide a more comprehensive view of the problem.

Title: Lawmakers Criticize President's Decision to Swap Bergdahl for Taliban Prisoners

The recent decision by President Barack Obama to swap long-missing Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for five Taliban prisoners held at Guantanamo Bay has sparked intense criticism from lawmakers, who have labeled the move as both reckless and lawless. The controversy has raised questions about the administration's decision-making process and its compliance with federal law.

The White House has faced scrutiny over its failure to notify Congress about the prisoner swap before it occurred, as required by law. The administration has argued that it had briefed Congress on the outlines of the possible swap, but lawmakers have expressed concerns about the lack of formal notification.

The controversy has also raised questions about the motivations behind the swap and the potential implications for future prisoner exchanges. Some lawmakers have expressed concerns that the deal sets a dangerous precedent for future negotiations with terrorist organizations.

The president has defended his administration's efforts to rescue Bergdahl from captivity, stating that "regardless of the circumstances, whatever those circumstances may turn out to be, we still get an American soldier back if he's held in captivity. Period. Full stop. We don't condition that."

However, the controversy is unlikely to subside anytime soon, with lawmakers on both sides of the aisle expressing their concerns and calling for further investigation. The future of Sgt. Bergdahl remains uncertain, and the debate over the prisoner swap is likely to continue in the coming weeks and months.

Title: Celebrities' Anti-Semitic Remarks and the Perpetuation of Racism

The recent surge in anti-Semitic tweets and posts from sports and entertainment celebrities has raised concerns about the future of the Black Lives Matter movement. However, the muted response to these incidents is equally troubling, as it perpetuates a culture of apathy towards social justice. The lack of outrage and condemnation from prominent figures in the entertainment industry and sports world is a stark contrast to the expected passionate public outcry.

Ice Cube, DeSean Jackson, and others have made statements that imply Jews are responsible for the oppression of blacks, citing conspiracy theories and stereotypes. These remarks would be laughable if not for the harm they cause and the platform they provide for hate groups. Former NBA player Stephen Jackson, a self-proclaimed activist, has also been criticized for agreeing with DeSean Jackson on social media and sharing anti-Semitic messages.

Chelsea Handler, a Jewish performer, has posted videos of Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan to her 3.9 million followers, potentially spreading a subliminal message that some Jews condone anti-Semitism. The Trump campaign has also been accused of exploiting anti-Semitic biases, despite having a Jewish son-in-law and daughter.

These incidents are not isolated and are part of a larger pattern of scapegoating and prejudice. The logic of blaming one group for the problems of another is a dangerous game that perpetuates racism and hate. The lack of condemnation and outrage from celebrities and influencers emboldens racists and hate groups, making it harder to combat social injustice.

The apologies offered by some of these celebrities have been inadequate, with some attempting to deflect blame and others showing a lack of understanding of the harm caused by their words. Celebrities have a responsibility to get their words right, as they have a significant platform and influence. The actual deeds and words have a real impact, and in this case, it has been destructive.

The struggle against racism and hate is ongoing, and it requires everyone to be outraged by injustice, regardless of who is affected. As Martin Luther King Jr. said, "Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere." It is time for celebrities and influencers to take responsibility for their words and actions, and to use their platform to promote understanding, empathy, and social justice.

Title: Obama: Accountability Expected for Veterans Affairs Problems

Article:

President Barack Obama has condemned the reported widespread problems at the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), stating that anyone found to have manipulated or falsified records will be held accountable. During a news conference on Wednesday, Obama emphasized the importance of accountability, saying that if the reported behavior is proven true, it is "dishonorable" and "disgraceful." He also noted that some employees have already been placed on administrative leave.

The president met with White House deputy chief of staff Rob Nabors, who has been detailed to work with the VA, and emphasized the need for improvement. Obama stated that his administration will continue to work on bringing the VA "into the 21st century," which he acknowledged is a challenging task.

The VA is currently facing two main challenges: an influx of new veterans from recent U.S. military conflicts and an aging population of Baby Boomer veterans. Obama noted that there are 85 million appointments scheduled over a year, highlighting the complexity of the issue.

The president also defended Secretary of Veterans Affairs Eric Shinseki, stating that "no one cares more about our veterans." However, Obama emphasized that he expects accountability and improvement in the full report on the VA's problems. Shinseki has previously stated that he will take swift and appropriate action if reports of manipulated statistics are substantiated.

The VA is currently under investigation by the inspector general and is undergoing a broader audit ordered by Shinseki. The findings of both inquiries are expected to be released this summer.

Title: Obama's Call to Action: Honest Conversations on Race

Article:

In the aftermath of the George Zimmerman acquittal, the topic of race has dominated the national conversation. However, according to Simon, a prominent political columnist, this discussion has been exhausting and draining, and it's time to move on. Simon argues that Americans, particularly white Americans, tend to avoid discussing race unless it's a crisis, and even then, it's often a reluctant conversation.

In a recent speech, President Barack Obama spoke movingly and personally about race, acknowledging the pain and frustration felt by the African-American community. He emphasized that race is a topic that doesn't go away, and that it's essential to recognize the experiences and history of African-Americans. Obama also highlighted the importance of self-reflection and personal responsibility, encouraging individuals to examine their own biases and prejudices.

While some may argue that politicians should lead the conversation on race, Obama believes that it's more effective to have these discussions in personal settings, such as families, churches, and workplaces. He emphasized the need for individuals to take ownership of their own biases and work towards creating a more inclusive society.

The article concludes that Obama's call to action is a reminder that conversations about race require impetus, leadership, and discipline to avoid simply shouting past each other. With the President's focus shifting to economic issues, the topic of race has been "checked off" the national agenda, and it's time to move on.

Title: Stress in America: 2020 Presidential Election, Healthcare Costs, and Mass Shootings Top Concerns

The American Psychological Association (APA) has released its annual "Stress in America" survey, which reveals that sociocultural issues are now the most significant sources of stress for American citizens. The survey, conducted between August 1 and September 3, polled 3,617 adults across the United States.

According to the survey, 56% of adults said the 2020 presidential election is already a significant stressor, a year out from Election Day. This is an increase from the 52% who said the 2016 presidential election was stressful. The election is proving to be a more stressful topic for survey respondents identifying as Democrats, versus those identifying as Republicans, by almost 25%.

Other significant stressors include healthcare costs, with 69% of adults citing it as a notable point of stress. Mass shootings were also a major concern, with 71% of adults pointing to it as a stressful topic, a rise of almost 10% from the APA's 2018 survey.

The survey also found that 63% of people of color said that discrimination has kept them from having a fully productive life, while 64% of LGBT adults said the same thing. Stress levels decreased significantly across respondents categorized by age group, with members of the baby boomer generation and "older adults" reporting lower average stress levels compared to younger generations.

The APA's chief executive officer, Arthur C. Evans Jr., emphasized the need for more open conversations about the impact of stress and stress management, especially among groups experiencing high levels of stress. The organization recommends getting a good amount of sleep every night, exercising regularly, and maintaining a healthy network of social support to manage stress.

The survey's findings highlight the importance of addressing sociocultural issues and providing emotional support to those affected by stress.

Title: Stocks Rise as Tech and Energy Shares Climb, Dollar Falls

Stocks rose on Wednesday, with major US equity benchmarks finishing near session lows, as tech and energy shares led the gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended flat, while the small-cap Russell 2000 Index climbed 1.3 percent to pace the gains. The Nasdaq 100 Index wiped out nearly half of its decline from Tuesday.

Energy was the strongest group in the S&P 500 Index, with WTI crude rebounding from a one-year low to leap back above $54 a barrel. Apple Inc. surrendered an earlier gain to close down for a third straight day, bringing its loss this week to 8.6 percent.

The FANGs, a group of high-flying tech stocks, were a key driver of the rally, with companies like Foot Locker Inc. and CBS Corp. seeing significant gains. Foot Locker jumped 15 percent, the most since May, after posting strong third-quarter earnings. CBS Corp. rose amid speculation of a coming merger with Viacom Inc., which also saw its stock climb.

The dollar weakened after reports that the Federal Reserve may soften its stance on raising interest rates, with the US dollar index falling 0.3 percent. The 10-year Treasury yield was little changed at 3.0609 percent.

Investors are weighing industry data that showed US crude inventories unexpectedly fell last week against doubts about OPEC's plans to cut output. The market is also reacting to the Trump Administration's trade war and the president's calls on the Federal Reserve to back off from raising rates.

Despite the volatility, some investors remain optimistic about the market's direction. "The market is really trading on technicals, a lot of the tech names are very overvalued," said Rahul Shah, CEO of Ideal Asset Management. "For a name like Apple, you could argue that some buyers are coming in at this level. But overall, today's action might be an oversold bounce. I wouldn't read it as a shift in the tenor of the market."

The S&P 500 rose 0.3 percent to 2,649.93, while the Nasdaq 100 gained 0.8 percent. The Japanese yen declined 0.3 percent to 113.07 per dollar. The MSCI Emerging Markets Currency Index rose 0.1 percent to the highest since August.

Title: President Obama Believes National Dialogue on Race Relations is "Healthy" for the US

President Barack Obama believes the ongoing national dialogue about race relations, particularly the interactions between minority communities and law enforcement, is a "healthy" development for the United States. In an interview with NPR, the president stated that the nation is not more racially divided than it was six years ago, and that recent protests in cities like New York and Ferguson, Missouri, are a sign that the issue is finally being addressed.

According to Obama, the issue of mistrust between police and communities of color is not new, but it has only recently come to the forefront due to increased awareness and the ability to record and share events with the wider public. The president believes that this increased attention can lead to long-term solutions.

The president has spoken out on the issue multiple times in recent months, including after grand jury decisions not to charge white police officers in connection with the deaths of black men. He has also condemned violence, including the assassination of two NYPD officers, which was motivated by a desire to retaliate against law enforcement for its treatment of the black community.

Obama also noted that many white Americans may hold certain beliefs on racially tinged issues due to a lack of information or social awareness, rather than racism. For example, he pointed out that white Americans may not understand that African-Americans are more likely to be pulled over by police, simply because it is not something they experience themselves.

Title: Ted Cruz: I Can Win Over Donald Trump's Supporters Even If I Don't Win Him Over

Senator Ted Cruz believes he can win over Donald Trump's supporters even if he doesn't win over the front-runner himself. In an interview with Mark Halperin and John Heilemann for Bloomberg Television's With All Due Respect, Cruz emphasized the importance of keeping Trump's supporters energized and engaged, especially in the event of a contested convention.

Cruz attributed his ability to compete effectively with Trump to his focus on issues that resonate with Trump's base, such as illegal immigration, securing the border, and bringing jobs back to America. He believes that if he earns a majority of the delegates in Cleveland, he will be able to unite Trump supporters and get them to vote in November.

Although Trump has dominated among voters without a college education, Cruz won those voters in the recent Wisconsin primary. Trump has warned of "riots" and suggested his supporters will abandon the GOP if he's blocked from the nomination at the July convention. Cruz acknowledged that divisions in the party are a natural concern at a contested convention.

Cruz also pointed to an "encouraging" sign for his ability to bring together Republicans, citing the endorsements he has received from five other Republican candidates, including Rick Perry, Lindsey Graham, Jeb Bush, Scott Walker, and Carly Fiorina. He also mentioned that his campaign is examining potential vice presidential nominees, citing the original GOP field as evidence of an "abundance of good choices" for the position.

When asked about Bruce Springsteen's decision to cancel a concert in North Carolina due to the state's "bathroom law," Cruz declined to take a stance, stating that both Springsteen and the people of North Carolina have the right to express their opinions. He also noted that many in Hollywood and the entertainment industry are liberal and tend to latch onto what is "politically correct" at the moment.

The full interview will air on Bloomberg TV's With All Due Respect on Friday at 5:00 p.m. Eastern time.

Title: Georgia's Sixth Congressional District Special Election Ends in Runoff between Jon Ossoff and Karen Handel

The special election in Georgia's Sixth Congressional District has failed to produce an outright winner, forcing a June 20 runoff between Democrat Jon Ossoff and Republican Karen Handel. Ossoff garnered 48% of the vote, falling short of the majority threshold required in the so-called "jungle primary." Handel, a former Georgia Secretary of State, received 20% of the vote, finishing ahead of technology executive Bob Gray, who received 11%, and former State Senators Judson Hill and Dan Moody, who each received 9%.

The winner of the runoff will succeed Tom Price, who resigned to become Trump's health and human services secretary. Ossoff, a 30-year-old documentary filmmaker and former congressional aide, had sought to capitalize on opposition to President Donald Trump, attracting over $8 million in donations, mostly from outside the state.

Republicans nationally and in Georgia had predicted Ossoff would top the slate of 11 Republicans, five Democrats, and two independents on the primary ballot. The GOP launched a barrage of ads attacking Ossoff for living outside the district and portraying him as a conservative's nightmare who would increase taxes and take away guns. The Republican National Committee released a statement criticizing Ossoff for receiving 97% of his donations from outside the district and consistently lying about his resume.

Ossoff acknowledged that he lives just south of the district, in Atlanta, so his girlfriend can be close to her work at Emory University's medical complex. Republican groups ran ads tying Ossoff to House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., and a political action committee backed by House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., spent over $2 million on attacks. Trump himself posted several messages on Twitter encouraging Republicans to vote in the special election and recorded a get-out-the-vote call.

The special election drew national attention, with Trump posting another tweet early Wednesday saying, "Despite major outside money, FAKE media support, and 11 Republican candidates, BIG 'R' win with runoff in Georgia. Glad to be of help!" National attention intensified after last week's closer-than-expected GOP victory in a Kansas special House election. Handel has maintained her distance from Trump, rarely discussing him unless asked.

Polling day took an unusual turn in the district when key electronic voting logs were stolen from a Cobb County poll worker's pickup truck. However, there were no reports of voting irregularities at Cobb County polling places on Tuesday.

Title: Climate Change: A Consensus Among Scientists, a Divide Among Americans

The overwhelming majority of scientists agree that human activities are causing climate change, with a staggering 97% consensus among experts. However, a significant portion of the American public remains skeptical, with only 42% having a great deal of confidence in the scientific community. This lack of trust is partly due to the fact that many Americans are not familiar with living scientists, with some relying on fictional characters like Dr. Sheldon Cooper from the TV show "The Big Bang Theory" as their only exposure to science.

According to Anthony Leiserowitz, director of the Yale Project on Climate Change Communication, there are six distinct categories of public responses to climate change. The "Alarmed" group, comprising 16% of the public, believes climate change is an urgent problem but lacks a clear understanding of how to address it. The "Concerned" group (27%) believes climate change is a problem but views it as primarily affecting polar bears and tiny islands rather than their own lives. The "Cautious" group (23%) is undecided, while the "Disengaged" group (5%) lacks knowledge about climate change. The "Doubtful" group (12%) does not believe climate change is man-made and thinks it poses no long-term risk.

The most problematic group, however, is the "Dismissives" (15%), who believe climate change is a hoax and that scientists are fabricating data. This group is well-organized and vocal, thanks in part to media coverage and political support. Conservative politicians like Rick Santorum and Ted Cruz have publicly denied the existence of climate change, while the fossil fuel industry has invested heavily in climate denial.

A recent study by Drexel University found that conservative foundations and others have bankrolled climate denial to the tune of $558 million between 2003 and 2010. This funding has given climate deniers a powerful megaphone in the public square.

On the other hand, extreme weather events are forcing people to take notice of climate change's direct impact on their lives. Many religious leaders, including evangelicals, are now advocating for environmental protection, recognizing the moral obligation to save the planet. Even the Pope may soon weigh in on the issue, with the Vatican press office announcing that Pope Francis is working on a draft text on ecology.

As the scientific consensus on climate change continues to grow, it is essential to address the public's lack of trust in scientists and the well-organized minority that denies the reality of climate change.

Title: U.S. Military Officials Provide Varying Explanations for Potential Airstrikes Against Islamic State in Syria

U.S. military officials have given conflicting and sometimes confusing explanations about what would trigger airstrikes against Islamic State (ISIS) targets in Syria. The Joint Chiefs chairman, Gen. Martin Dempsey, appeared to tone down his earlier comments about the growing threat posed by ISIS, stating that the group is not currently plotting or planning attacks against the U.S. or Europe. However, his spokesman, Col. Ed Thomas, clarified that Dempsey believes ISIS will soon become a threat to the U.S. and Europe.

A senior U.S. Defense spokesman said that any threats against U.S. personnel and interests could drive action against ISIS in Syria. The official emphasized that the U.S. and its allies need a "long-term strategy" to separate ISIS from the population, and that if a plot against the homeland is discovered, the U.S. will take action.

The White House Press Secretary, Josh Earnest, reiterated that there is no active plot by ISIS militants in Syria to attack the U.S. Pentagon spokesman, Rear Adm. John Kirby, stated that there has been no direction from the White House to tone down the language about ISIS.

The U.S. has conducted airstrikes and provided military aid to Kurdish Peshmerga fighters in Iraq, which has served as a check on ISIS's advance. Dempsey emphasized that the U.S. will not recommend airstrikes in Syria until ISIS becomes a direct threat to the U.S. or Europe. He believes that key allies in the region, including Jordan, Turkey, and Saudi Arabia, will join the U.S. in quashing the Islamic State group.

The Obama administration has authorized airstrikes within Iraq to protect U.S. personnel and facilities and to help Iraqi and Kurdish forces assist refugees driven from their homes by ISIS. Senior U.S. leaders have said the key to success in Iraq is the formation of an inclusive government that will include disenfranchised Sunnis. Any additional military assistance from the U.S. to Iraq is contingent on those political and diplomatic steps by the government.

Title: Senate Republicans Unwavering on Sequester Cuts, Democrats Propose Alternative

Article:

Senate Republicans, led by Senator John Barrasso, are adamant that the sequester's massive spending cuts will go into effect on March 1, despite Democratic proposals to delay or replace them. The across-the-board cuts, aimed at reducing the deficit by $1.2 trillion over the next decade, were initially set to begin at the start of the year but were postponed by two months in the fiscal cliff bill.

With less than two weeks to go, lawmakers are facing another countdown before the cuts are scheduled to begin. Senate Democrats proposed a $110 billion measure to delay the cuts, which Pentagon officials say will have drastic effects on the military. The proposal would replace the budget cuts with a combination of increased tax revenue from millionaires through the closing of loopholes, ending agriculture subsidies, and reducing defense spending after the war in Afghanistan ends.

However, Senator Barrasso and other Republicans in the Senate are not pleased with the proposal, particularly the provision dealing with tax revenue. "Taxes are off the table," Barrasso told CNN's Candy Crowley. "The American people need to know tax cuts are off the table and the Republican Party is not in any way going to trade spending cuts for a tax increase."

Senator Barrasso did not specify alternative proposals, but emphasized that there are "much better ways to do these budget cuts." President Barack Obama had vowed during his re-election campaign that the sequester would not happen, and his chief of staff, Denis McDonough, expressed uncertainty about the cuts' prevention. "I sure hope it doesn't happen," McDonough said on NBC's "Meet the Press."

Democratic Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, on the other hand, sounded optimistic about the issue. "I think that Democrats have the high ground both substantively and politically and we will win on this issue," he said on "State of the Union." He argued that Republicans have no choice but to "come on board" and that their arguments are "untenable" and "don't meet the favor of hardly anyone other than themselves and the few whose special interests they're protecting."

Title: Trump's Protectionist Trade Policies Likely to Continue Guiding Federal Policy

The 2020 presidential election may be a crucial factor in determining the future of American trade policy. President Donald Trump's protectionist views on trade and skepticism about the benefits of foreign trade are likely to continue guiding federal policy for the foreseeable future. Despite this, leading Democratic presidential candidates are more likely to pander to the victims of Trump's trade war – farmers and manufacturing workers – rather than calling for a reversal of the policies causing the problems.

During the recent Democratic debate, candidates largely agreed with Trump's approach to trade policy, even if they disagreed with some of his methods. Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) described the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) as a "modest improvement" over the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). However, this assessment is misleading, as the new deal includes higher barriers to duty-free trade for automobiles and car parts, new labor standards that increase the cost of manufacturing in Mexico, and a 16-year sunset clause that increases long-term uncertainty.

Warren and other Democratic candidates, such as Senators Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) and Pete Buttigieg, have expressed support for the USMCA, while former Vice President Joe Biden offered a generally positive review of the deal. The only notable dissent came from Senator Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), who broke with his Senate colleagues and promised to vote against the USMCA, citing concerns about the outsourcing of American jobs and the lack of strong environmental and labor standards.

The disagreement between Warren and Sanders on trade is largely cosmetic, as both want to see less free trade than what is currently in place. Warren is willing to accept Trump's protectionism as a stepping stone to her own version of trade wars, which prioritizes American environmental and labor standards over the benefits of free trade. Sanders, on the other hand, wants to see more protectionist measures, including an end to the outsourcing of American jobs and stronger environmental and labor standards.

The only candidate who has shown a willingness to challenge Trump's trade policies is Joe Biden, who has acknowledged the importance of exports to American economic growth. However, even Biden seems to be getting pulled towards the "no new trade deals" view espoused by Warren, although without attaching as many conditions as she does.

In the end, Trump's shifting of American trade policy is likely to continue, and this is bad news for many. The winner in all of this is Trump, who has effectively neutered the pro-trade voices within the Republican Party and handed the Democrats a rewritten NAFTA that fulfills many of their wishlist items.

Title: Americans' Views on Trump: A Complex Picture

The Pew Research Center's findings on Americans' attitudes towards President Trump's statements are stark: 76% are concerned, 70% are confused, 69% are embarrassed, 65% are angry, 62% are insulted, and 56% are frightened. These numbers might suggest a bleak outlook for Trump's re-election prospects. However, there are three reasons why this might not be the case.

Firstly, a significant majority of Americans (76%) rate the current economic conditions positively, a significant increase from 48% at the time of Trump's election. Secondly, the progressive left's values may be increasingly at odds with mainstream American values, as seen in the recent controversy surrounding J.K. Rowling's defense of a woman fired for her views on transgenderism. Thirdly, the more the left criticizes Trump and predicts catastrophic consequences, the more it appears out of touch when those predictions do not materialize.

As a result, Trump's average approval ratings have steadily increased since October. Many Americans view the president as flawed but not as bad as his critics claim. In a contest between Trump and his critics, the president might emerge victorious.

A key point to consider is that Trump's critics may be overpromising a significant overhaul of the economy, which shows no signs of needing such a drastic change. There are, however, several long-term risks to American prosperity, including a declining birth rate, a national debt exceeding $23 trillion, the erosion of the global free-trade consensus, threats to the Federal Reserve's independence, and the growing popularity of unorthodox economic theories like Modern Monetary Theory.

Title: Nationwide Protests Continue After Grand Jury Decision in Ferguson Shooting

Across the United States, protests and demonstrations took place for the second consecutive night in response to the grand jury's decision not to indict Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson in the shooting death of 18-year-old Michael Brown in August. While some protests remained peaceful, others turned violent, with reports of vandalism, property damage, and arrests.

In Ferguson, Missouri, the scene of the original protests, demonstrations quieted down into early Wednesday evening, with 45 people arrested, mostly for failure to disperse. Outside the Ferguson Police Department, a woman was taken into custody after protesters hurled objects at a line of officers. Several others were arrested for defying police instructions to leave the street or move out of the way of police vehicles.

In other cities, protests turned violent. In Oakland, California, protesters vandalized police cars, smashed windows at businesses, and set fires in the middle of city streets. In Minneapolis, a car struck a protester and drove through a group of others. In Portland, Oregon, police used pepper spray and made arrests after about 300 people disrupted bus and light rail traffic by walking across a bridge.

Protesters also shut down two major freeways, with police eventually forcing them to disperse. In Los Angeles, protesters blocked lanes on the U.S. 101 freeway, with one protester managing to toss a barricade onto the freeway. Thousands of people marched in Manhattan, gathering in Union Square and holding up traffic on several bridges and tunnels.

NYPD Commissioner William Bratton stated that police were giving protesters "breathing room" as long as they remained nonviolent and did not engage in vandalism. A car struck a pedestrian during a rally in Cleveland, but the driver called the police immediately after the incident, and the woman suffered minor injuries.

Protests also took place in other cities, including St. Louis, where riot police arrested several demonstrators on Interstate 44 near the Edward Jones Dome. In Atlanta, hundreds of students from historically black colleges held peaceful demonstrations, but some groups later tried to block a freeway and police reported broken windows.

Overall, the protests remained largely peaceful, with many demonstrators calling for justice and an end to police brutality. As one protester, 17-year-old Naesha Pierce, said, "The system wasn't made to protect us. To get justice, the people themselves have to be justice."

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Call for Impeachment of President Trump Over Foreign Interference Comments

Article:

Several Democratic presidential candidates have joined the chorus of calls for impeachment proceedings against President Trump, citing his recent comments on accepting foreign interference in the 2020 election. The latest to join the chorus is Beto O'Rourke, who stated on CNN's "State of the Union" that Trump's admission that he would take help from a foreign government going forward is reason enough to see him ousted from office.

O'Rourke's call comes after Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio also expressed support for impeachment proceedings. Klobuchar emphasized that it is illegal to take something of value from a foreign country to use in a campaign, and Trump's actions are sending out signals similar to those he displayed in 2016, when he publicly urged Russia to find and publish Hillary Clinton's emails.

De Blasio described Trump's comments as "openly treasonous" and called for Congress to begin impeachment hearings. He stated that the nation can no longer accept the notion of a president who openly invites interference in the election.

While the idea of impeachment is popular among Democratic base voters, polls indicate that it is not yet supported by a majority of the general public. The recent comments from Democratic presidential candidates raise questions about how willing they are to keep bending norms of governmental behavior, such as the usually bright line between politics and federal prosecutions, that Trump has shattered.

Title: Justice Department and North Carolina Engage in Dueling Lawsuits Over Controversial "Bathroom" Law

The United States Department of Justice and the state of North Carolina have filed dueling lawsuits over the state's controversial "bathroom" law, which requires transgender individuals to use bathrooms that correspond with the sex on their birth certificate. The Justice Department filed a lawsuit in U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina, alleging a "pattern or practice of employment discrimination on the basis of sex" against the state.

The lawsuit was filed after North Carolina Governor Pat McCrory, a Republican, accused the administration of a "baseless and blatant overreach" in trying to get the policy scrapped. McCrory's lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in the Eastern District of North Carolina, claims that the administration is attempting to unilaterally rewrite long-established federal civil rights laws.

The Justice Department's lawsuit alleges that the law violates federal civil rights laws and discriminates against transgender individuals. Attorney General Loretta Lynch stated that the state has created "state-sponsored discrimination against transgender individuals." The lawsuit seeks to have the law declared unconstitutional and to require the state to take steps to prevent discrimination against transgender individuals.

McCrory has argued that the law is necessary to protect public safety and privacy, and that the federal government is overstepping its authority. He has urged the court to intervene in the dispute and has called on Congress to clarify federal anti-discrimination provisions.

The controversy surrounding the law has sparked widespread criticism and backlash, with many businesses and organizations expressing opposition to the law. The law has also been criticized by gay rights groups and has led to several high-profile cancellations of events and performances in the state.

The Justice Department has given the state until the close of business Monday to respond to its demand that the law be repealed or face legal action and risk losing federal funds. The state has refused to comply, and the Justice Department has stated that it will continue to take action to protect the rights of transgender individuals.

The controversy surrounding the law is likely to continue, with the Justice Department expected to take further action to ensure that transgender student rights are fully protected under federal law.

Title: Allegations Against Trump Erode Support Among Female Voters and Independents

The presidential campaign has been marked by allegations against Republican candidate Donald Trump regarding his comments about women and sexual misconduct. This has led to a decline in his support among female voters and independents, according to Republican pollsters. However, Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton's support has not seen a significant increase, suggesting that many Republicans still do not view Trump's behavior as morally unacceptable.

Some college students have expressed shock that Trump still enjoys strong support despite his comments and allegations. However, many voters have already made up their minds and are unlikely to switch sides solely based on this issue. According to Alex Abbott, a senior at Hampden-Sydney College, the responses to Trump's behavior from men are either "I would never do anything like that" or "Every guy does that, and it's not out of the ordinary."

While voters are primarily concerned about the economy and terrorism, the negative attention on Trump's sexual behavior is hurting him with female voters and independents. However, support for Clinton has not increased significantly, indicating that many Republicans still do not view Trump's behavior as morally unacceptable.

According to Alan Abramowitz, a political science professor at Emory University, this is an example of "negative partisanship," where voters vote against the opposing party rather than for their own. This phenomenon is particularly evident this year, with Republicans showing strong support for Trump despite his controversies.

The ill will towards Trump is also evident among Democrats, including playwright Jon Robin Baitz, whose latest work explores a tailor's relationship with a Trump-like candidate. Baitz expressed his disappointment, stating that "there is, to me, a kind of fundamental American decency, and it's just been lost in the prurient shallowness of the discourse."

Title: The Clash Between Real Rights and the Invented Right of Same-Sex Marriage

The article discusses the growing conflict between the concept of same-sex marriage as a "right" and the traditional understanding of freedom of religion, speech, and association. The author argues that same-sex marriage is not a "right" but a "preference" and that it is being imposed on others through liberal judges and activists. The article also highlights the intolerance and intimidation tactics used by some gay activists against those who dissent from their views.

The author claims that laws can and do legislate morality, and that the question is not whether we can legislate morality, but "Whose morality will we legislate?" They argue that while religions may teach moral rights, these rights do not need to be justified by God to be supported.

The article also quotes Andrew Sullivan, a homosexual author, who expressed revulsion at the intolerance shown to former Mozilla CEO Brandon Eich, who was forced to resign after being criticized for his views on same-sex marriage. The author notes that Sullivan's words are a rare example of a gay activist acknowledging the intolerance of some in the gay community.

The article concludes that there is no middle ground between celebrating same-sex marriage and opposing it, and that the real rights of freedom of religion, speech, and association must give way to the invented right of same-sex marriage. The author argues that this is not tolerance, but totalitarianism, and that Christians must stand firm in their beliefs and not be swayed by the pressure to conform.

Title: Sanders' Momentum Grows as Democratic Primary Enters Crucial Stages

As the Democratic primary season reaches its peak, Senator Bernie Sanders is gaining momentum, with a sweep of the Nevada caucuses and popular vote victories in Iowa and New Hampshire. The crucial battles in South Carolina and Super Tuesday on March 3 are looming, and Sanders has the enthusiasm and momentum to continue his triumphant march to the nomination in Milwaukee.

Several factors could potentially interrupt Sanders' progress, including attacks on his socialist ideology and concerns about his ability to win in November. However, Sanders has consistently shown himself capable of defending his positions, and such attacks may only expose his opponents' desperation.

Another potential obstacle is the anticipated endorsement of former Vice President Joe Biden by Representative Jim Clyburn, the most influential black politician in South Carolina. Clyburn warns that nominating a socialist like Sanders could lead to electoral disaster, particularly in states with significant African American populations. If Biden cannot win in his firewall state, where does he win?

Biden faces another challenge from billionaire Tom Steyer, who has pumped millions into South Carolina and pledged to support reparations for slavery. Polls show Steyer gaining support among black voters who might otherwise have stood by Biden.

The question remains: Who can beat Sanders? With Biden, Buttigieg, Warren, Steyer, and Klobuchar all competing in South Carolina and Super Tuesday, it is unclear who will emerge victorious. Bloomberg can likely buy enough votes to win some states, but would the other candidates stand aside to yield the field to the billionaire?

The Democratic establishment worries that if the "moderates" in the race do not start dropping out and joining behind a single candidate to challenge Sanders, they will lose the nomination to him and the election to Trump.

Sanders' chances of becoming president are slim, but his odds of winning the nomination and reshaping the party are good and have been improving weekly. His vision for the Democratic Party includes Medicare for All, abolition of private health insurance, a war on Wall Street, the Green New Deal, free college tuition, forgiveness of student debt, open borders, and welfare for undocumented migrants.

As Winston Churchill once said, "Some regard private enterprise as if it were a predatory tiger to be shot. Others look upon it as a cow that they can milk. Only a handful see it for what it really is — the strong horse that pulls the whole cart." Sanders sees free market capitalism as a fat goose that lays golden eggs and can be hectored, squeezed, and beaten into producing more. Those most receptive to his message are the young.

Welcome to the Party of JFK as reconceived by Bernie Sanders.

Title: NSA's XKeyscore Program Revealed: Widespread Surveillance of Internet Activity

The National Security Agency (NSA) has been revealed to have a secret surveillance program called XKeyscore, which allows analysts to search through vast databases of emails, chats, and browsing histories from millions of people without prior authorization. The program, detailed in training manuals leaked by Edward Snowden, enables the NSA to mine enormous databases by filling out a simple on-screen form, without requiring court review or clearance from higher-ranking officials.

According to the documents, XKeyscore can cover "nearly everything a typical user does on the Internet" and even monitor online activity in real-time. The program allows analysts to access the content of emails and chats, and can search by name, telephone number, IP address, and keywords. Additionally, XKeyscore can monitor activity on social media platforms, including Facebook, by inputting a user name and date range into a search.

The NSA claims that XKeyscore has been successful in capturing 200 terrorists by 2008, and one slide indicates that the program can search HTTP activity with a keyword, allowing the NSA to monitor "nearly everything a typical user does on the Internet."

The revelation of XKeyscore comes as senior intelligence officials met with Senate members to release classified documents about the collection of phone records and the FISA court. The Guardian published the documents on the same day, providing further insight into the NSA's surveillance capabilities.

Title: Trump's Veterans Charity Fundraiser Falls Short of Promised Amounts

The Trump campaign's January fundraiser, held on the eve of the Iowa caucuses, aimed to raise $6 million for veterans' charities. However, a recent survey by The Wall Street Journal found that most of the 22 organizations listed as recipients have received less than half of that amount. According to the report, 19 organizations have received a total of $2.4 million from Trump's foundation or associates.

The Journal surveyed the 22 groups listed by Trump's campaign as prospective recipients and found that 19 organizations had obtained a total of $2.4 million. Three other charities declined to disclose how much they had received, one said it needed to submit more paperwork before receiving any money, and the third did not respond to questions.

The fundraiser was held in lieu of Trump's attendance at a GOP debate hosted by ███. The real estate mogul had declined to appear at the debate, claiming he had not been treated fairly by the network. All 19 groups that confirmed receiving money from the Trump event received checks in the mail, with 16 charities seeing donations arrive in late February in increments of $50,000 or $100,000. The other three reported smaller donations in March, averaging between $5,000 and $15,000.

Keith David of the Task Force Dagger Foundation expressed confusion about a $50,000 check from Trump associate Stewart Rahr's foundation, stating it looked like it was from a separate organization. Hope Hicks, a spokeswoman for the Trump campaign, claimed that Trump has given to the 22 groups originally announced and many others, but did not provide information on how much money raised at the event had been distributed or how much each group has received.

The Trump Foundation's tax returns show that it has given just $180,000 to veterans' charities over the past decade, with Hicks stating that this amount does not include personal donations by the candidate. At least one prominent charity, Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America (IAVA), declined to receive any money from the January fundraiser, calling it a "political stunt."

Title: Romney Declines to Commit to Reversing Obama's Immigration Order

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, declined to say whether he would reverse President Barack Obama's recent order to stop deporting some illegal immigrants, during an interview on CBS's "Face the Nation" on Sunday. The order, which allows work permits and prevents deportation for up to 1.4 million undocumented immigrants brought to the United States as children, was seen as a move to address the issue of immigration reform.

Romney, who had previously stated that he would veto the Dream Act, which would provide a path to citizenship for some illegal immigrants, was more equivocal about Obama's order. He stated that there needs to be a long-term solution for the children brought to the country by their parents through no fault of their own, but did not commit to reversing the president's decision.

Romney also accused Obama of making a purely political move by issuing the order and bypassing Congress. He stated that if the president felt strongly about the issue, he should have taken action when he had a Democratic House and Senate, but did not.

The president's move was seen as an attempt to address the concerns of Hispanic voters, who have been critical of Obama's immigration policies, which have focused on deportations. Romney's campaign had been working on a platform that would include immigration policies, and he is expected to unveil them on Thursday when he speaks to the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials in Florida.

Romney also discussed the European economic crisis, stating that the United States should not send checks to Europe or bail out European banks. He emphasized the need to strengthen the US economy and blamed the president for policies that have made it harder for the economy to recover.

On another topic, Romney expressed skepticism about another round of monetary stimulus, known as QE3, from the Federal Reserve, which is expected to be discussed at the Fed's meeting this week. He reiterated his economic proposals, including lowering tax rates and cutting government spending from 25% of the economy to 20%, which he believes will "ignite growth."

Title: Obama Administration's Handling of Benghazi Attack Raises Questions

The Obama administration's handling of the 2012 Benghazi attack has been shrouded in controversy, with allegations of dishonesty and deception surrounding the events that unfolded. The administration initially claimed that the attack was a spontaneous protest that escalated into chaos, but this narrative has been discredited by evidence and testimony.

According to reports, the highest-ranking American diplomat on the scene in Libya told Secretary of State Hillary Clinton that the attack was a terrorist attack, and the CIA also confirmed this assessment. However, the administration's talking points, which were drafted in the days following the attack, showed that intelligence agencies had initially identified the attack as a terrorist attack, but this information was omitted from the final version.

The article suggests that the administration's reluctance to acknowledge the attack as a terrorist attack was motivated by political concerns, particularly in the context of the 2012 presidential election. The author argues that the administration's narrative about a spontaneous protest was a calculated lie designed to downplay the threat posed by terrorist groups and avoid admitting that the attack was a sign of their continued activity.

The article also highlights the case of Gregory Hicks, a State Department foreign service officer who was in Libya during the attack and knew the truth. Despite his efforts to speak out about the attack, Hicks was subjected to negative job evaluations and was demoted to a desk job in Washington.

The article concludes that the Obama administration's handling of the Benghazi attack raises questions about the administration's honesty and willingness to deceive the American public. While the exact details of the attack and the administration's response remain unclear, the article suggests that the truth is slowly emerging, and further investigations are needed to uncover the full extent of the administration's actions.

Title: The Rise of a Conservative Voice: The Story of Kayleigh McEnany

Article:

Kayleigh McEnany, a young and ambitious individual, has made a name for herself in the world of politics and media. Her journey began during her time at Oxford, where she developed a strong foundation in her faith and beliefs. She was particularly influenced by the late Christian pastor Ravi Zacharias, who she admired for his ability to provide intellectual arguments for her faith.

McEnany's interest in elite universities led her to an internship on Fox News, where she caught the attention of Alan Colmes, a liberal commentator. Colmes became her mentor, and she went on to work as a producer for former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee's show. During this time, she maintained a blog, where she shared her conservative views and reading recommendations.

As she continued to build her career, McEnany faced opposition from liberal critics, including Elie Mystal, a writer at The Nation. Despite their disagreements, Mystal acknowledged that McEnany was a true believer in her arguments, not simply doing it for show or money. Her authenticity and core beliefs earned her a position at Above the Law, a prominent legal blog.

Throughout her journey, McEnany has demonstrated a strong commitment to her faith and her conservative values. She has also shown an ability to engage in fierce debates and arguments, which has helped her ascend the ranks of cable news. Her story serves as a testament to the power of perseverance and dedication in achieving one's goals.

Title: Trump's Data-Driven Strategy: A Lesson for His Opponents

The article discusses Donald Trump's unconventional approach to politics, which has allowed him to defy expectations and remain a strong contender in the presidential race. Trump's use of social media and provocative language has generated a vast amount of data that his opponents can analyze to understand what people like and dislike about him. The article argues that instead of condemning Trump's tactics, his opponents should focus on understanding the data he's generating and using it to their advantage.

The article highlights Trump's use of social media platforms, such as Instagram and Twitter, to deliver provocative messages and short videos, which has garnered a significant following. It also notes that Trump's opponents should learn from his strategy and invest in the infrastructure needed to analyze and organize the data he's generating.

The article references Barack Obama's successful use of data analysis in his 2012 re-election campaign, where he used big data to identify undecided voters and persuade them to vote for him. Jim Messina, Obama's campaign manager, emphasized the importance of big data in their strategy.

The article concludes that Trump's opponents should focus on understanding the data he's generating and using it to their advantage, rather than condemning his tactics. By analyzing the data and learning what people like and dislike about him, opponents can identify areas to target and potentially win over Trump's supporters.

Title: Renewable Energy Outpaces Fossil Fuels in Tax Preferences Over the Past Decade

The past decade has seen a significant shift in the U.S. tax code, with renewable energy receiving more tax preferences than fossil fuels. According to Congressional Budget Office (CBO) figures, renewable energy received $10.9 billion in tax preferences in 2016, compared to $4.6 billion for fossil fuels. This trend has been ongoing since the early days of the Obama administration, when the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act and increased production in the wind and solar power sectors shifted tax preferences toward renewable energy.

The CBO figures show that in 2008, fossil fuels received $8.2 billion in tax preferences, while renewables received $5.3 billion. By 2016, the gap had narrowed, with renewables receiving $10.9 billion and fossil fuels receiving $4.6 billion. This shift is attributed to the increased production of renewable energy, rather than the establishment of new government policies favoring a given source.

The wind production tax credit, for example, was first enacted in 1992, and has been extended several times since then. The tax credit has become more valuable in terms of dollar amounts simply because of the wind industry's expansion and significant increases in production. The tax preferences for solar power and other renewable sources accounted for more than $6 billion in tax preferences last year, according to CBO numbers.

The shift in tax preferences has been driven by the growth of the renewable energy industry, rather than changes in government policies. The wind production tax credit, for example, was first enacted in 1992, and has been extended several times since then. The tax preferences for solar power and other renewable sources accounted for more than $6 billion in tax preferences last year, according to CBO numbers.

The CBO figures also highlight the complexity of the tax code, with many tax preferences for fossil fuels having been in place for decades. The sector received $1.8 billion in tax preferences in 2016 for the "expensing of exploration and development costs for oil and natural gas," as well as billions of dollars in benefits for the depreciation of gas distribution lines and "geological and geophysical expenditures" related to exploration and other activities.

The debate over tax reform is ongoing, with President Trump and his Republican allies in Congress seeking to rewrite the tax code and eliminate many of the energy carve-outs that have been implemented over the past decade. However, specialists say it will be difficult to strip away these preferences, as they have become entrenched and have the support of lawmakers from states with significant renewable energy industries.

**Pope Francis: A Humble Leader with a Focus on the Poor**

Pope Francis, the 266th pontiff of the Catholic Church, has taken the reins of the global Catholic community, marking a significant shift in the church's leadership. The Argentinian-born Jesuit priest is the first from outside Europe to lead the 1.2 billion-strong Catholic community.

Pope Francis has chosen to honor St. Francis of Assisi, a 13th-century Italian friar known for his devotion to the poor and his love for nature. Like his namesake, Pope Francis has a reputation for humility and simplicity. He has been known to take public transportation and cook his own meals, breaking with the tradition of luxurious living quarters and chauffeured limousines.

In his first public act as pontiff, Pope Francis asked the crowd to pray for him, rather than blessing them first, a departure from the traditional papal protocol. He also refused to use a platform to elevate himself above the cardinals standing with him, instead meeting each of them on their own level.

Pope Francis has been criticized for his stance on same-sex marriage and abortion, which aligns with the socially conservative views of the Catholic Church. However, during his time as a priest in Argentina, he clashed with the government over his opposition to gay marriage and free distribution of contraceptives.

The new pope has also faced criticism for his alleged involvement in the 1976 kidnapping of two liberal Jesuit priests during the Dirty War in Argentina. However, he has denied the charges, and Amnesty International has not investigated any individual for their specific involvement.

As Pope Francis takes the helm of the Catholic Church, he faces significant challenges, including the decline of the church's membership and the need to address issues such as sex abuse by priests and corruption within the hierarchy. He will also need to navigate the shifting viewpoints among Catholics, particularly in the United States, where 90% of Catholics use contraception and 82% believe it is morally permissible.

Despite these challenges, Pope Francis's humility and commitment to serving the poor and marginalized have inspired hope and optimism among many Catholics and non-Catholics alike.

Title: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell Defends Debt-Ceiling Vote Amid Criticism

Article:

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Republican from Kentucky, defended his decision to join Democrats in voting to raise the debt ceiling, saying his job is to protect the country and lead when necessary. McConnell was one of 12 Republican senators who voted to end debate on the debt-ceiling bill, which will extend the federal debt limit for a year. The bill was signed into law by President Obama on Saturday.

McConnell's decision has been criticized by some of his Republican colleagues, including Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, who threatened to filibuster the vote. Cruz said that every Senate Republican should have stood together against the bill, calling it a "blank check" for President Obama. Matt Bevin, a tea party conservative challenging McConnell in the Kentucky GOP primary in May, also criticized the senator's decision, saying it was "financially reckless behavior."

McConnell defended his vote, saying his preference is for a debt ceiling to carry additional legislation that addresses the debt. He noted that he negotiated the Budget Control Act with Vice President Biden in 2011, which led to a deficit-reduction package that reduced government spending for two years in a row. McConnell said the House's inability to come together on a different version of the bill left him with no choice but to vote in favor of passing a clean debt-ceiling bill.

The senator also defended his record as a legislator who averts crises, saying he has consistently stepped up to solve problems, including the fiscal cliff deal in 2012 and the government shutdown in October.

Title: Democrats' Convention Revives Spirits, Bill Clinton's Speech Adds Strength

The Democratic National Convention has concluded, with a rousing two nights of speeches and events that have revitalized party spirits. The convention has set the stage for President Barack Obama's speech on Thursday, which is crucial for the party's chances of breaking open the presidential race.
