In fact, Shapiro himself acknowledges the importance of strong male role models in his column, stating that young men need to learn from men who treat women well and act as protectors rather than victimizers. This is exactly what the Gillette ad is calling on men to do.

The controversy surrounding the ad highlights the ongoing debate about masculinity and what it means to be a man. While some may see the ad as an attack on traditional masculinity, others may view it as a necessary step towards creating a more respectful and compassionate society. Ultimately, people are free to associate with whatever brand they choose, but it would be a shame if the right started boycotting companies for taking the position that hurting people is bad.

Title: Study Reveals Surprising Link Between News Consumption and Mental Health

A recent study by Alison Holman and her colleagues from the University of California, Irvine, has shed light on the profound impact of news coverage on mental health. The study began as a routine examination of mental wellbeing across the United States, but it took an unexpected turn when the Boston Marathon bombings occurred in 2013. The researchers found that individuals who had not been physically present at the bombings but had consumed six or more hours of news coverage in the week following the event showed higher levels of acute stress than those who had been directly affected by the tragedy.

The study's findings suggest that news coverage can have a significant impact on mental health, even for those who were not directly involved in the event. This is a stark contrast to the assumption that only those who were physically present at the incident would be affected. The researchers found that knowing someone who had been injured or died, or being in the vicinity when the bombs went off, was not as predictive of high acute stress as consuming large amounts of news coverage.

The study's lead author, Alison Holman, notes that people often underestimate the impact of news on their lives. The research highlights the importance of considering the emotional fallout of news coverage, which can lead to increased risk of developing post-traumatic stress, anxiety, and depression. Moreover, the study suggests that even a few hours of news consumption per day can have a significant impact on mental health, far beyond what might be expected.

The study's findings have significant implications for our understanding of the role of news in shaping our lives. It is clear that news coverage can have a profound impact on our mental wellbeing, and it is essential to consider the emotional fallout of news consumption.

Title: Red-State Democrats Express Frustration with GOP on Tax-Cut Bill

Article:

A group of red-state Democrats, who face re-election battles next year in states won by President Trump in 2016, expressed frustration with the Republican Party's approach to the recent tax-cut bill. While some of these Democrats acknowledged the bill's benefits, they argued that it favored corporations over individuals and failed to address their constituents' concerns.

Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia, who has repeatedly tried to find common ground with Republicans, said he couldn't support the bill due to its permanent corporate tax cuts and the planned expiration of individual rate reductions. Manchin stated that while there are some positive aspects to the bill, it is too skewed towards business.

Other red-state Democrats, such as Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri, framed their opposition to the bill as a disappointment that it prioritized corporations over individuals. McCaskill argued that the bill deviated from President Trump's original proposals and failed to benefit the people.

Some voters, however, expressed confusion over the Democrats' stance. Dennis Hugo, a 32-year-old Libertarian from Missouri, said he couldn't understand why McCaskill opposed the bill and hoped she would explain her reasoning.

Indiana Senator Joe Donnelly, another Democrat, claimed to have met with President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence to discuss the tax bill. Donnelly stated that he was willing to partner with Republicans, but the final bill produced by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Speaker Paul Ryan was not what he had discussed with the administration.

North Dakota Senator Heidi Heitkamp, who initially expressed openness to voting for the bill, ultimately voted against it due to concerns over the $1.5 trillion in additional deficits generated by the tax cuts. However, some voters in her state do not see her opposition as reasonable.

The bill's impact on farmers was also a point of contention. The doubling of the estate tax exemption to $11 million was seen as a benefit by some, while others argued it would only help large corporations and not benefit farmers as claimed by Republicans. Daryl Lies, president of the North Dakota Farm Bureau, stated that the increased deduction for equipment purchases would be a tangible benefit for local farmers.

Title: Republican Senators Investigate Hunter Biden's Business Dealings in Ukraine and China

Article:

Two Republican senators, Chuck Grassley and Ron Johnson, have sent a letter to the Secret Service Director James Murray requesting information about Hunter Biden's business dealings in Ukraine and China. The senators are seeking clarification on whether Hunter Biden used government-sponsored travel to conduct private business and details of his travel records. This move comes after President Donald Trump was acquitted by the Senate on articles of impeachment for his own conduct in Ukraine.

The senators are investigating potential conflicts of interest related to Hunter Biden's business dealings in Ukraine and China. They claim that Hunter Biden's business interests in Ukraine may have influenced his father's foreign policy decisions during his time as Vice President. However, there is no evidence to support this claim.

The investigation is part of a broader effort by Republicans to shift the focus away from Trump's actions in Ukraine and onto Hunter Biden's business dealings. The senators are seeking information about Hunter Biden's travel records and whether he used government-sponsored travel to conduct private business.

In a separate development, Senator Lindsey Graham, Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, has also announced plans to investigate the Bidens. Graham has stated that he intends to call witnesses, including Hunter Biden, to testify about the matter in the coming weeks.

Hunter Biden has dismissed all allegations as conspiracy theories and acknowledged that his role created a "bad image." The former Vice President, Joe Biden, has also denied any wrongdoing and stated that his son's business dealings did not influence his foreign policy decisions.

The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen what information will be uncovered.

Title: USCIS Director Francis Cissna Resigns at President Trump's Request

The Director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), Francis Cissna, resigned from his post on Friday at the request of President Donald Trump. Cissna will be replaced by former Virginia attorney general Ken Cuccinelli, according to a person familiar with the situation.

In his resignation letter, Cissna emphasized his commitment to enforcing the rule of law and laying the groundwork for effective immigration reform. He stated, "We are the government servants charged with lawfully, efficiently, and fairly adjudicating requests for immigration benefits, while protecting Americans, securing the homeland, and honoring our nation's values."

Cissna's departure has been in the works for weeks, as Trump sought to shake up his immigration officials. Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen and Ronald Vitiello, who was acting director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, also left their posts last month. Republican lawmakers had urged the president to keep Cissna on board, but White House adviser Stephen Miller had sought to boot him weeks ago.

Cuccinelli's selection to a top immigration post raised eyebrows earlier this week. Cuccinelli led the charge among the Republican National Convention to back Sen. Ted Cruz's nomination in 2016. However, members of Trump's inner circle told reporters earlier this week that the president had gotten over their bitter past and has come to admire Cuccinelli.

USCIS oversees legal immigration and has traditionally defended it. However, under the Trump administration and Cissna's leadership, the agency has been a key element in the hardline crackdown on immigration. Cissna oversaw the dramatic shrinking of the country's refugee program, the creation of a "denaturalization task force" charged with stripping citizenship from those who committed fraud, and a change in policy to make it easier for visas to be denied.

In an interview with magazine in September, Cissna stated that he was not driven by anti-immigrant sentiment but rather a "strong commitment to the law, and to the rule of law."

Title: Congressional Leaders Criticize President Obama's Plan to Review Surveillance Programs

Article:

Congressional leaders have criticized President Obama's plan to review and potentially alter government surveillance programs, which he announced at a news conference last Friday. However, the backlash is not specifically directed at the proposed changes themselves, but rather at the White House's handling of the national security versus privacy debate.

According to Rep. Michael T. McCaul, chairman of the House Committee on Homeland Security, the president's plan is an attempt to "window dress" the programs, which are lawful and have saved lives and stopped terrorist plots. McCaul stated that the president has failed to explain the programs and has been "backtracking" since National Security Agency leaker Edward Snowden revealed their existence.

The president's remarks were meant to appease critics who say the federal government is eroding Americans' Fourth Amendment rights. He proposed reviewing portions of the Patriot Act, allowing privacy advocates to argue against the government's case for search warrants, and increasing transparency around the programs.

However, critics argue that the administration has been slow to react to the Snowden leaks and the public pressure that followed. Rep. Peter T. King, a New York Republican, stated that the president has been "silent for the last two months" and has allowed Snowden to dominate the media narrative.

Lawmakers' voices have grown louder in recent weeks, with some Republicans and Democrats alike expressing concerns about the government's surveillance programs. Rep. James E. Clyburn, a South Carolina Democrat, voted to defund NSA surveillance programs, citing the need for Congress to be more involved in the process.

The proposed changes have also drawn criticism from outside Washington, including from Edward Snowden's father, Lon. He stated that the president's press conference was "much political theater" and that the proposed changes are "superficial."

The debate surrounding the government's surveillance programs has highlighted a deeper problem in American society, with some lawmakers saying that there is a need to restore public confidence in elected leaders. Sen. John McCain, an Arizona Republican, stated that there is a "careful balance" between preserving national security and protecting privacy, and that efforts must focus on restoring public trust in government.

**US-China Trade Conflict Escalates: Tariffs on $200 Billion of Chinese Products Imminent**

The United States is poised to impose 10% tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese-made products, including clothing, television parts, and refrigerators, by August 30. This move is part of a broader trade conflict between the two nations, with China vowing to retaliate against the tariffs. The US has already imposed tariffs on $50 billion of Chinese goods, and the new levies are expected to raise import prices on almost half of everything the US buys from China.

The tariffs are part of a broader effort by the Trump administration to address what it sees as unfair trade practices and intellectual property theft by China. The US has accused China of engaging in "unfair" trade practices, including forced technology transfers and intellectual property theft, and is demanding that China make significant changes to its trade practices.

China has responded by imposing retaliatory duties on US goods, including soybeans and bourbon, and has vowed to respond "blow-for-blow" to the US tariffs. The Chinese Commerce Ministry has called the US tariffs "totally unacceptable" and has threatened to retaliate against them.

The trade conflict has sparked concerns about the potential impact on global trade and the economy. Economists warn that a full-blown trade war could derail the strongest economic upswing in years, while investors are bracing for the potential fallout.

The US-China trade conflict is also taking a toll on consumer goods, with some tariffs applying to popular items such as handbags, cameras, and mobile phones. The tariffs could raise prices for these goods, which could have a significant impact on consumers.

The trade conflict is also taking a toll on politicians, with some Republicans expressing concerns about the impact of the tariffs on farmers and businesses. Senator Chuck Grassley, a Republican from Iowa, has expressed "great concern" about the trade spat with China and the level of uncertainty it's creating among farmers and businesses in his state.

The trade conflict is also a major concern for China, as it poses a significant threat to the country's economic growth and stability. China's slowing economy, which is heavily dependent on trade, could be severely impacted by a sustained attack from the US.

The US-China trade conflict is a complex and multifaceted issue, with both sides refusing to back down. The outcome of the conflict remains uncertain, but one thing is clear: the stakes are high, and the impact on global trade and the economy could be significant.

Title: House Speaker Boehner Highlights GOP Budget as Solution for Middle-Class Families and Small Businesses

The House of Representatives has passed a budget that aims to create new opportunities for middle-class families and small businesses, according to House Speaker John Boehner. In a column for the Cleveland Plain Dealer, Boehner emphasized that the pro-growth, balanced budget addresses the problem of spending under President Barack Obama, paves the way for job creation, and institutes a simpler and fairer tax code.

The budget, passed by the House this week, aims to reduce spending, cut taxes, and reform entitlement programs. Boehner argued that middle-class families and small businesses are seeking real solutions to create growth and new opportunities, but President Obama's budget does not deliver. Instead, Obama's budget includes a 65% increase in spending over 10 years, more than $2 trillion in new taxes on working families, and $8.5 trillion in new debt for future generations.

Boehner highlighted that many middle-class families are struggling under Obama's presidency, with stagnant wages, high energy prices, and a difficult jobs market. He emphasized that bold new reforms are needed to unleash the potential of the American people and expand opportunities for everyone.

The Republican budget, according to Boehner, addresses the problem of spending head-on while protecting programs like Medicare and Social Security. The House also voted to replace Medicare's Sustainable Growth Rate (SGR) formula with a system that rewards quality and innovation. This permanent SGR solution is seen as a big win for the American people, ensuring seniors have access to their doctors and providing hundreds of billions of dollars in durable savings for taxpayers over the long term.

Boehner concluded by stating that the House of Representatives has had a strong first 100 days of 2015 and will continue to listen to the American people and do what is right for the country, not what is easy.

Title: German Authorities Launch Manhunt for Suspect in Deadly Berlin Christmas Market Attack

German authorities have launched a manhunt for Anis Amri, a 23-year-old Tunisian national, in connection with the deadly truck attack on a Berlin Christmas market on Monday. The suspect's residence permit was found in the cab of the lorry, and he is believed to be armed and dangerous.

According to reports, Amri had been under surveillance earlier this year for suspicion of seeking to buy guns. The German authorities are offering a reward of up to €100,000 for information leading to his arrest.

The attack, which claimed 12 lives and injured 49 people, occurred when a lorry was driven into crowds at the Breitscheidplatz Christmas market. The driver, Lukasz Urban, was found murdered in the cab with gunshot and stab wounds. The only confirmed death is that of Urban, a Polish citizen.

The investigation is ongoing, with police searching a migrant shelter in the Emmerich area of North Rhine-Westphalia, where the suspect's permit was issued. The German cabinet has approved plans to increase video surveillance in public places in response to the attack.

Amri's family has denied his involvement in the attack, with his brother telling AFP news agency that he is "in shock" and "can't believe it's him who committed this crime." However, judicial sources say the suspect was monitored in Berlin between March and September on suspicion of planning a robbery to fund automatic weapons for an attack.

The investigation is ongoing, with police examining DNA traces from the cab of the truck and acting on hundreds of tips from the public. The Islamic State group has claimed responsibility for the attack, but provided no evidence.

**Job Market Slumps in December, Adding Only 74,000 Jobs**

The US job market experienced a significant slowdown in December, with the economy adding only 74,000 jobs, according to the government. This marks the weakest month for job growth since January 2011 and comes as a surprise to economists, who had predicted an addition of 193,000 jobs.

Despite the weak job gains, the unemployment rate fell to 6.7% in December, mainly due to workers leaving the labor force. The labor force participation rate, which measures the percentage of the adult population actively working or looking for work, dropped to 62.8%, the lowest level since 1978.

Some economists believe the weak job gains in December could be a one-time anomaly, and the government may revise the numbers higher in the coming months. However, others are concerned that the job market's growth may be slower than expected, with some experts predicting it could take until the end of 2016 to reach a 5.5% unemployment rate.

The construction industry was particularly hard hit in December, losing 16,000 jobs, which could be attributed to unusually cold weather in some parts of the country. The sector has been slow to recover since the recession, with many jobs still not returning.

The job market's struggles are also reflected in the experiences of individuals who have been unemployed for an extended period. Jamie May, a former senior manager, has been looking for a job for over a year, and has been met with rejections and concerns about her willingness to stay with a company. Fred Royal, an administrative assistant, has also been struggling to find a job, with many employers expressing concerns about his job security.

The ongoing debate in Washington over budget cuts and aid to the economy highlights the ongoing tension between policymakers. While the Federal Reserve has been pumping trillions of dollars into the economy, the government has cut 98,000 jobs over the past three years, not including the Postal Service.

**Typhoon Mangkhut Makes Landfall in China, Brings Destruction and Flooding to Hong Kong and Philippines**

Typhoon Mangkhut, considered the strongest to hit the region this year, made landfall in China's Guangdong province on Sunday, bringing heavy rain and strong winds to the area. The storm, packing winds of over 200 kph (125 mph), caused widespread destruction and flooding in Hong Kong and the Philippines, with potentially more than 50 people killed in the latter.

In Hong Kong, the typhoon's eye skirted 100 kilometers (62 miles) south of the city, but the former British colony was still affected by the storm's outer bands of rain and gale-force winds. The city raised its highest typhoon signal, No. 10, as ferocious winds uprooted trees and smashed windows in office and residential buildings. Residents reported feeling dizzy as buildings swayed in the gusts.

In the Philippines, the storm caused landslides in or near mountainous areas of the Cordillera region, with at least 33 people killed and 56 missing. The head of the military's Northern Luzon Command reported at least 19 more deaths in landslides in Benguet province, with many feared trapped in an old mining bunkhouse that collapsed under rubble.

In Macau, which halted casino gambling late on Saturday, serious flooding of up to 2.5 meters (8.2 feet) occurred, with some people rescued from homes on rubber dinghies. The city's power grid was also affected, with over 20,000 households experiencing a blackout.

In Guangdong, China's most populous province, with a population of over 100 million, two people were killed as of 8:00 p.m. local time, and more than 2.45 million people were relocated. Over 48,000 fishing boats were called back to port, and work at more than 29,000 construction sites was suspended.

The storm has also affected sugar production in Guangdong, with China sugar futures rising last week due to concerns about the cane crop. The typhoon is expected to continue on its northwesterly track, bringing heavy rain and winds to the autonomous region of Guangxi early on Monday, before weakening into a tropical depression in southwestern Yunnan province on Tuesday.

Title: Physician Advocates for Legalization of Marijuana, Critiques CNN Op-Ed

Article:

David Nathan, a clinical psychiatrist, has written an op-ed piece criticizing David Frum's stance on marijuana policy, which argues that the drug should remain illegal. Nathan agrees with Frum that young people should avoid marijuana, but believes that it should be legal for adults and sold like alcohol, with education on the risks. Nathan argues that the negative legal consequences of marijuana use are far worse than the medical consequences and that making it illegal has elevated its status to that of a forbidden fruit.

Nathan points out that drugs like cocaine, painkillers, and alcohol are more commonly used and potentially habit-forming than marijuana, yet only marijuana is illegal. He notes that the dangers of marijuana are far surpassed by the perils of alcohol, which is associated with a range of health problems, including pancreatitis, gastritis, cirrhosis, and permanent dementia.

Nathan also highlights the potential benefits of legalizing and regulating marijuana, including reducing the illegal drug trade and the proliferation of dangerous synthetic cannabinoids. He notes that the Federal Bureau of Narcotics banned cannabis in 1937, citing bad science and fabricated stories of violence, and that the ban has led to a thriving illegal market.

Nathan concludes that the only rational approach to cannabis is to legalize, regulate, and tax it, and that those who believe it should remain illegal must logically support the criminalization of alcohol and tobacco.

Title: Donald Trump Enters 2016 Presidential Race, Bringing High National Name Recognition

Article:

Donald Trump, a billionaire real estate developer and TV celebrity, has joined the 2016 presidential race, making him the most prominent candidate in the field. Trump, 69, has high national name recognition due to his successful business ventures and reality TV shows. He has made previous attempts at national politics, including a 1999 bid for the Reform Party nomination and vocal criticisms of President Obama's policies in 2008 and 2012.

Trump's business career began with his father, a developer of middle-class housing in Queens and other outer boroughs of New York. He then went on to attend the New York Military Academy and later the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of finance. Trump has been involved in various business ventures, including real estate development, golf resorts, and casinos.

According to Forbes magazine, Trump's net worth is estimated to be $4.1 billion, ranking him 133rd among American billionaires and 388th globally. He is expected to release a summary of his assets, which total $9 billion, including valuations on his real estate.

Trump has also gained fame through his TV shows, including "The Apprentice" and "The Celebrity Apprentice," where he schools ambitious young people. He has also been a frequent guest on TV talk shows, including "The Late Show With David Letterman."

Trump's business breakthrough came when he was 34, when he obtained an option to buy the old Commodore Hotel near Manhattan's Grand Central Station. He redesigned the hotel as the Grand Hyatt, a major success after the restoration of Grand Central itself. He later bought and renovated the iconic Plaza Hotel at the southeast corner of Central Park and the Barbizon at the southwest corner.

Trump has been married three times and has five children, with his three children from his first marriage now involved in the Trump Organization businesses.

Title: Aging Water Infrastructure Puts Communities at Risk of Lead Contamination

The water crisis in Flint, Michigan, serves as a stark reminder that the country's aging water infrastructure is deeply flawed, putting millions of people at risk of lead contamination. The city's switch to the Flint River in 2014, intended as a cost-saving measure, led to devastating consequences, including exposure to poisonous levels of lead. This crisis is not an isolated incident, as many of the 150,000 public water systems serving over 300 million people are based on outdated and leaky pipes.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) established an action level for lead in public drinking water at 15 micrograms per liter in 1991, requiring water supplies to regularly test household tap water for lead levels. However, the consequences of lead exposure are well-documented, with no safe level of exposure deemed acceptable. Lead can cause irreversible damage to the brain, particularly in young or unborn children, leading to low IQ, cognitive delays, and learning disabilities.

The Flint crisis highlights the need for immediate action to address the country's aging water infrastructure. The Obama administration's plan to appoint Dr. Nicole Lurie as a "czar" to fix the crisis in Flint is a step in the right direction, but it is crucial to extend this effort to other areas of the country where communities are most susceptible to similar disasters. The government's failure to protect the city of Flint is a stark reminder of the need for swift action to prevent similar tragedies from occurring elsewhere.

Title: Professor Accuses Virginia Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax of Sexual Assault, Denies Consensual Interaction

A professor, Vanessa Tyson, has publicly accused Virginia Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax (D) of sexual assault, stating that what began as consensual kissing turned into a sexual assault in 2004 at the Democratic National Convention in Boston. Tyson, a professor from California, claimed that Fairfax forced her to perform oral sex on him.

In a statement, Tyson said, "What began as consensual kissing quickly turned into a sexual assault. Mr. Fairfax forced me to perform oral sex on him." She also stated that she did not want to engage in oral sex with Fairfax and never gave any form of consent.

Fairfax has denied the accusation, stating that his interaction with Tyson was consensual. He claimed that Tyson never expressed discomfort or concern about their interactions during or after the encounter, and that she stayed in touch with him for months following it. However, Tyson contradicted Fairfax's denial, saying that she did not want to engage in oral sex with him and never gave any form of consent.

Tyson is a professor of politics at Scripps College in California and is currently on fellowship at Stanford University. She is an advocate for sexual assault awareness and prevention. She stated that the allegations are not politically motivated and that she is a "proud Democrat."

The allegations against Fairfax surfaced after a photo was released of Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam's (D) medical school yearbook page, which pictured a man dressed in blackface and another dressed in Ku Klux Klan robes. Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring (D) also admitted to using blackface as a teenager, deepening the leadership crisis in the Commonwealth.

Title: Trump's Rise to Power: A Shift in the Political Landscape

The article presents a scathing critique of the Republican Party, claiming that it is led by "delusional and incompetent politicians" who have failed to deliver on their promises. The author argues that the party's track record is marked by a 15-year war, significant funding, and thousands of American lives lost, with little to show for it. The article also criticizes politicians who promised to "shake up" Washington, D.C., but failed to deliver.

The article highlights Donald Trump's rise to power, stating that he has single-handedly destroyed the Jeb Bush campaign and is on a clear path to winning the Republican nomination. The author notes that Trump has exposed the GOP for what it is and has made politicians "quiver in their shallow shoes."

While the article presents a critical view of the Republican Party, it does not provide specific examples or evidence to support its claims. The article also does not provide a balanced perspective, as it does not offer any counterarguments or criticisms of Trump's policies or actions.

In conclusion, the article presents a one-sided view of the Republican Party and Donald Trump, highlighting their perceived failures and shortcomings. However, it does not provide a comprehensive or balanced analysis of the political landscape.

Title: House Democrats to Examine Legislative Path to Obtain Trump's Tax Returns

The House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Oversight will hold a hearing on Thursday to discuss legislative proposals and laws governing the process of obtaining President Donald Trump's personal tax returns. The hearing will feature testimony from a panel of experts on tax law, including a 1924 measure that allows the chairman of the exclusive tax-writing panel to privately examine anyone's tax returns. A majority vote from the committee would be required to publicly release the returns, if obtained.

The call for Trump to make his tax returns public dates back to the early days of the 2016 presidential campaign, when he initially signaled he would release the documents. However, he later backed off, citing ongoing IRS audits that would complicate any attempt to make them public. Some progressive Democratic lawmakers have clamored for the release of Trump's tax returns, while others, like House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, have taken a more cautious approach, stating that it is "appropriate" to hold a hearing before acting to obtain the documents.

House Republicans, led by Rep. Kevin Brady, have expressed concerns about "protecting the rights of every private taxpayer" and the potential for "abuse of power" if the tax code is used for political purposes. Rep. Bill Pascrell, a senior member of the Ways and Means committee, emphasized the importance of a "checks and balances government" and the need to proceed methodically.

Five witnesses are expected to testify at the hearing: Joseph J. Thorndike, director of the Tax History Project; George K. Yin, the Edwin S. Cohen Distinguished Professor of Law and Taxation at the University of Virginia School of Law; Noah Bookbinder, executive director at the Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington; Steven M. Rosenthal, senior fellow at the Urban-Brookings Tax Policy Center; and Ken Kies, managing director of the Federal Policy Group.

Title: Supreme Court Strikes Down Most of Arizona's Immigration Law, Upholds Police Authority to Question Immigration Status

The Supreme Court has struck down most of Arizona's tough immigration law, ruling that it is an unlawful infringement on federal power. However, the court upheld the most important plank of the law, which allows police to stop and question the immigration status of those they suspect are in the country illegally.

The decision comes as President Barack Obama announced his administration would stop deporting most young adult illegal immigrants, marking a seismic shift in the national immigration debate. The ruling is a significant blow to Arizona's Governor Jan Brewer, who signed the law in 2010, saying her state needed to act because the federal government wasn't doing its job.

The court's 5-3 ruling stated that while Arizona police can continue to question the legal status of those they stop, the state cannot impose its own criminal penalties for immigration violations. The majority opinion, written by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, said that states cannot try to act in an area in which the Constitution specifically grants powers to Congress.

The decision has sparked debate among legal experts and politicians, with some arguing that the ruling will lead to racial profiling and others seeing it as a victory for the rule of law. Arizona Governor Jan Brewer said she will move forward with the new authorities for police, saying they are prepared to enforce it fairly.

The law, known as SB 1070, required police to check the immigration status of those they encountered whom they had reasonable suspicion were in the country illegally, and required that they contact federal immigration authorities to give them a chance to put the individuals in deportation proceedings. The law also imposed state penalties on illegal immigrants who applied for jobs.

The Obama administration sued to stop the law, and lower courts stayed both parts of the law. The Supreme Court's decision upholds the authority of police to question the immigration status of those they stop, but strikes down the parts of the law that sought to impose state penalties for immigration violations.

The ruling has implications for the national immigration debate, with some seeing it as a victory for the federal government's authority over immigration policy and others arguing that it will lead to racial profiling. The decision is likely to be challenged in the future, with some critics already preparing new litigation tactics.

Title: The Zimmerman Verdict: A Reflection on the Ongoing Struggle with Racism in American Society

The acquittal of George Zimmerman in the Trayvon Martin case has sparked widespread debate and outrage, with many questioning the justice system's handling of the case. However, the issue goes beyond the specifics of the case and the law. It highlights the deeper problem of racism in American society, which has evolved from overt, biological-based discrimination to a more subtle form of racial exclusion.

According to Harvard sociologist Lawrence Bobo's theory, this subtle racism is based on the notion that African Americans and their cultural norms are to blame for their social and economic position in American life. This mentality is often expressed through phrases like "they don't work hard enough" or "they don't have the right values." Chief Justice John Roberts' quote, "The way to stop discrimination on the basis of race is to stop discriminating on the basis of race," highlights the need to address the lingering effects of racism.

The case of Trayvon Martin's death is not an isolated incident. It is part of a broader cultural phenomenon that treats all black youths as potential suspects, drug dealers, or gang members, often based on little more than the way they dress or the music they listen to. This culture denies young blacks opportunities to succeed and then blames them for their failure.

Statistics from various institutions, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Justice Statistics, show that African Americans do not commit crimes at a higher rate than whites. However, rates of robbery and serious property offenses among black youth are at their lowest rates in 40 years, and rates of violent crime and victimization are also declining.

The problem is not that the law is racist, but that the cultural norms and societal structures perpetuate racial disparities. The justice system is not designed to address these issues, and many people deny that race played a role in the Zimmerman verdict, despite the obvious inequality in outcomes.

The Atlantic's Ta-Nehisi Coates argues that the injustice in the Trayvon Martin case was not a result of a weak case, but rather a result of a country that has historically created a "pariah class." The killing of Trayvon Martin by George Zimmerman is not an error in programming, but the correct result of forces we have set in motion years ago and have done little to address.

The author of the article acknowledges that they are still learning about the problem of racism in society and are unsure of what to do next. However, they recognize that men are not an oppressed group and that understanding the experiences of those who suffer from injustice is the first step towards change.

Title: 9th Circuit Court Affirms Ruling Against Trump's Revised Travel Ban

The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled against President Trump's revised travel ban, dealing another blow to the administration as it awaits a potential Supreme Court decision. The court affirmed the Hawaii District Court's ruling, which blocked parts of the order and suspended the entry of refugees and reduced the cap on refugee admissions.

The three-judge panel found that Trump's revised order does not provide a sufficient justification to suspend the entry of over 180 million people based on nationality. The judges noted that the Immigration and Nationality Act gives the president broad powers to control the entry of foreigners, but these powers are subject to certain statutory and constitutional restraints.

The court also cited Trump's tweets in defending their finding that the order does not provide a reason why permitting entry of nationals from the six designated countries under current protocols would be detrimental to the interests of the United States. The judges wrote that Trump's tweets "confirm his assessment that it is the 'countries' that are inherently dangerous, rather than the 180 million individual nationals of those countries who are barred from entry under the President's 'travel ban'."

The court vacated the Hawaii District Court's injunction against the government's ability to conduct interagency reviews of its vetting procedures, but ordered the court to issue a new order that blocks the temporary ban but allows the government to proceed with its review. The court also called the government's argument that the District Court erred in issuing an injunction that runs against the president himself "well taken."

This decision marks the second time the 9th Circuit has ruled against Trump, following a February ruling that refused to reinstate his first travel ban. The administration has already asked the Supreme Court to intervene, and the Department of Justice filed emergency applications on June 1 asking the court to block the 4th Circuit and Hawaii District Court rulings blocking the ban.

Title: The Democratic Party's Decline During the Obama Presidency: A Legacy of Loss

The Democratic Party has faced significant losses during the Obama presidency, with the party losing hundreds of positions in the House, Senate, state legislatures, and governorships. According to the article, the party has lost more seats than under any other president, with the number of Democratic senators decreasing from 60 to 46 and the number of House seats held by Democrats shrinking from 257 to 188.

The article attributes this decline to a combination of factors, including the Republican Party's ability to turn out their voters in midterm elections, the Democrats' lack of focus on state legislative races, and the clustering of Democratic voters in urban areas. The article also notes that the Democratic Party has not put enough effort and resources into state legislative races, unlike the Republicans, who make these races a top priority.

The article also highlights the impact of gerrymandering, citing the example of Pennsylvania, where the Republican takeover of the governor's mansion and legislature led to a significant shift in congressional districts. The article quotes former Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell, who notes that the state went from having 13 Democratic congressmen to five after the 2010 redistricting.

The article concludes that the stakes for Democrats are high this November, with the party facing the possibility of being "truly out in the cold" if they do not win the White House and maintain control of other branches of government.

Title: ICE Council President Criticizes Gang of 8's Handling of Immigration Reform

The Immigration and Customs Enforcement Council President, Chris Crane, expressed frustration with the Gang of 8's handling of the new illegal immigration overhaul, stating that lawmakers have failed to include law enforcement input in the development of the legislation. Crane, who represents law enforcement officers working within the nation's broken immigration system, believes that American citizens are being excluded from the process and their concerns are being ignored.

Crane and a group of law enforcement agents, including border sheriffs, interior sheriffs, deputies, and immigration agents, met with lawmakers to discuss their concerns, but none of the Gang of 8 members attended the meetings. During a recent Gang of 8 press conference, Crane was even escorted out by police when he asked a question.

Crane has previously stated that the Gang of 8 plan does not address the criminal alien and cartel element running rampant in the United States, and that it falls short in allowing ICE agents to enforce current immigration laws on the border and in the interior of the country. He believes that the plan prioritizes politics over fixing the problems in the broken immigration system and prioritizing public safety.

Crane emphasized that the discussion about criminal elements and cartels operating within the United States is absent from the public conversation, and that this lack of attention to the issue is a major concern. He believes that the Gang of 8's approach is not focused on providing a solution to the nation's immigration problems, but rather on advancing a political agenda.

Title: Trump's Criticism of Khan Family Sparks Republican Backlash

The Republican presidential nominee, Donald Trump, has continued to face criticism from fellow Republicans and the public after his sustained attacks on Khizr and Ghazala Khan, the parents of an Army captain killed in Iraq. The Khans gained national attention after delivering a powerful speech criticizing Trump at the Democratic National Convention, where they spoke out against his proposal to temporarily ban all Muslim immigrants from the United States.

Trump's criticism of the Khans has sparked widespread condemnation, with Arizona Senator John McCain issuing a 700-word statement denouncing Trump's comments. McCain emphasized that Trump's remarks do not represent the views of the Republican Party or its candidates. He also expressed his disagreement with Trump's statement, saying that the fallen soldier's parents should not be disrespected.

Other Republicans, including House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, have also distanced themselves from Trump's attacks on the Muslim immigrants. However, Trump continued to tweet criticism of the Khans on Monday morning, despite a statement from his running mate, Indiana Governor Mike Pence, that sought to paint a more conciliatory picture.

Khizr Khan, in an appearance on the Today Show, called Trump's response "amazing" and "ignorant," saying that Trump can malign entire nations, religions, and communities, but cannot say what he feels about a private citizen. Khan also reiterated that his experience at the Democratic National Convention was positive, with people showing support for his message and wanting to take pictures.

The controversy has highlighted the growing discomfort among some Republicans with Trump's behavior and rhetoric, particularly his attacks on minority groups and individuals.

Title: US Administration Proposes Rule Change to Detain Immigrant Families Together Longer

The Trump administration has announced a proposal to effectively end a decades-old legal settlement that bars the detention of immigrant children for more than 20 days when families are arrested for trying to enter the US illegally. The Department of Homeland Security and Health and Human Services officials want to circumvent the so-called Flores agreement, a 1997 court settlement that prevents authorities from detaining children for more than 20 days.

The proposed rule change, published in the Federal Register, aims to allow families, most of whom are seeking asylum, to be detained together throughout the duration of their lengthy immigration proceedings. Officials claim it would offer protections similar to those outlined in the Flores settlement.

The proposal is likely to face legal challenges, as the administration was previously denied a request to detain families together beyond the 20-day limit. Immigration authorities have struggled to adhere to the Flores settlement's terms while trying to impose a zero-tolerance policy that aims to prosecute all adults who cross the southern border illegally.

The proposal would allow families to be detained together throughout their immigration proceedings, which could take months or even years. The rule would also create an alternative to the existing licensed program requirement for family residential centers, allowing Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) to use appropriate facilities to detain family units together during their immigration proceedings.

The proposal is scheduled to be published in the Federal Register on Friday, and the public will have 60 days to comment. The administration's move is likely to spark controversy, with immigration advocates and others condemning the proposal as an attempt to jail more children for longer.

The Trump administration's zero-tolerance policy, which resulted in the separation of children from their families who were arrested at the border, sparked widespread outrage earlier this year. The government has reunited nearly 2,000 once-separated children but is still trying to reconnect almost 500 children whose parents have been deported.

The proposal is part of the administration's efforts to crack down on illegal border-crossers and enforce immigration laws as passed by Congress. Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen said the rule change would address "one of the primary pull factors for illegal immigration" and allow the federal government to enforce immigration laws as passed by Congress.

The proposal is likely to face opposition from lawmakers and advocacy groups, who argue that it would violate the Flores settlement and put children at risk. The administration's practice of separating children from their parents had sparked rare, forceful pushback from Republicans on Capitol Hill, with House Speaker Paul Ryan saying that "we should not be separating people at the border."

Title: Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein Defends Justice Department's Handling of Mueller Report

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein has defended the Justice Department's handling of the special counsel's still-secret report, stating that Attorney General William Barr is "being as forthcoming as he can" about his process for redacting and releasing the roughly 400-page document. Rosenstein's comments come amid concerns from Democrats that Barr is trying to mislead the public by releasing only a four-page summary of Robert Mueller's investigation.

Rosenstein emphasized that Barr is providing the public with the "top-line conclusions" of the report, which found that President Trump and his campaign did not conspire with Russian interference in the 2016 election, but reached no conclusion about whether the president obstructed justice. The report is expected to be released, likely next week, after blacking out portions for sensitive information.

Rosenstein's comments come as Barr is under intense pressure to quickly produce the edited report, with Democrats demanding access to the full report and concerns from some investigators on Mueller's team that the report is more critical of Trump on the obstruction issue than Barr indicated in his summary. Rosenstein would not comment on why Mueller rendered no conclusion on the obstruction question.

Rosenstein, who is set to leave his position soon, stated that he has tremendous confidence in Barr and his process for reviewing the report. He also declined to comment on Barr's review of the origins of the 2016 counterintelligence investigation, which Barr has characterized as "spying" on people associated with the Trump campaign.

Title: President Trump Threatens to Use Military Power to Stop Migrant Caravan

President Donald Trump has taken to Twitter to express his concerns about a caravan of thousands of migrants traveling towards the United States' southern border. In a series of tweets, Trump stated that he will do everything in his power to stop the caravan, including using military power, if Mexico does not take action.

According to Trump, the caravan is an "assault on our country" led by Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador, which he claims are doing little to stop the flow of people, including many criminals, from entering Mexico and the U.S. He also blamed the Democratic Party for the situation, stating that they want open borders and weak laws.

Trump threatened to withhold aid from Honduras if the country fails to stop the caravan and also called on Mexico to take action to stop the flow of people at its northern border. He stated that the situation at the southern border is more important to him than trade or the USMCA.

The caravan, which consists of over 4,000 people, is traveling from Honduras towards the U.S. border. Trump's tweets come as a response to the situation, and his administration has previously threatened to withhold aid from Honduras if the country fails to take action to stop the caravan.

Title: The New York Times Publishes Op-Ed by Sen. Tom Cotton, Sparking Backlash and Debate

The New York Times published an op-ed piece by Senator Tom Cotton (R-AR) on June 4, 2020, urging President Trump to deploy the military to quell the violent riots that erupted in Minneapolis following the police killing of George Floyd. The article sparked a heated debate, with some critics accusing the newspaper of giving a platform to a politician who they believe promotes violence and oppression.

Senator Cotton responded to the backlash, stating that he sees no reason for the New York Times to apologize and believes the editors should be commended for printing his piece. He argued that the newspaper stood up to the "woke progressive mob" in their own newsroom by publishing his opinion, which he believes is a testament to the importance of free speech and the diversity of voices in the media.

The New York Times editorial page editor, James Bennet, explained the decision to publish the op-ed, stating that the newspaper's editorial board has consistently defended the protests as patriotic and criticized the use of force against protesters, journalists, and bystanders. Bennet emphasized that the Times owes it to its readers to provide counterarguments, particularly from those in positions of power, and believes that Senator Cotton's argument requires public scrutiny and debate.

The reaction from high-profile figures and readers was mixed, with some expressing exhaustion and frustration with the newspaper's decision to publish the op-ed. Others praised the Times for standing up to the "woke progressive mob" and providing a platform for diverse voices.

The article highlights the ongoing debate about the role of the media in providing a platform for diverse opinions and perspectives, as well as the challenges of navigating the complexities of free speech and social justice.

Title: President Obama to Launch Economic Tour, Push for Congressional Action

Article:

President Barack Obama will embark on a several-weeks-long campaign to urge Congress to work with him to boost the economy, starting with a major address at Knox College in western Illinois on Wednesday. The president will lay out his vision for how Washington and the private sector can stimulate economic growth, which has been improving only in fits and starts.

According to White House senior adviser Dan Pfeiffer, Obama believes that Washington has lost focus on the most critical issue facing the country, and that Congress is more focused on scoring political points and fighting old battles rather than addressing the needs of the middle class. The president will address specific topics related to the economy, including job security, education, and healthcare, in the coming weeks.

The president's push will begin in Galesburg, Illinois, a small town that holds a special place in his heart. Obama has a long history with the community, dating back to his early days on the national political scene. He chose Galesburg as the starting point for his economic tour, citing its struggles and resilience.

In his speeches, Obama will likely emphasize the importance of bipartisan cooperation and the need for Congress to pass legislation that benefits the middle class. He may also touch on the topic of immigration reform, which has been a sticking point in Congress. The Senate has passed a comprehensive immigration bill, but the House has shown reluctance to take it up.

The president's economic tour will also take him to rural Warrensburg, Missouri, and Jacksonville, Florida, where he will deliver remarks. It remains to be seen how much emphasis he will place on immigration reform, but his goal is to use his bully pulpit to push Congress to take action on the economy and other key issues.

Title: Online Learning Platforms See Surge in Enrolments Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

As the world grinds to a halt due to the COVID-19 pandemic, many people are finding solace in online learning platforms. Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) on platforms like edX, FutureLearn, and Coursera have seen a significant surge in enrolments, with some courses experiencing an eightfold increase in sign-ups since the start of the pandemic.

Coursera's Chief Product Officer, Shravan Goli, notes that the company has seen an unprecedented increase in enrolments for social science, personal development, and arts and humanities courses. The Science of Well-being course, in particular, saw 500,000 new enrolments in a single weekend.

Devoting some of our quarantine time to self-education makes sense. Not only can it help bolster one's career during economic uncertainty, but learning a new skill can also provide a sense of control and help cope with anxiety engendered by the pandemic.

While some may be tempted to sign up for courses with prestigious instructors, James Murphy, an associate lecturer at the Open University, advises against it. Instead, he suggests trying out a course and seeing if it's engaging. Many platforms offer user reviews, which can help gauge the course's quality.

When choosing a course, it's essential to consider the difficulty level, as well as the length and format. Some courses may be too easy or too challenging, which can lead to frustration. James Wallman, author of "Time and How to Spend It," suggests finding a course that's just beyond one's comfort zone, which can lead to a sense of accomplishment and flow.

To stay motivated, it's crucial to set a schedule and treat the course like a physical class. Bianca Barratt, a writer and regular MOOC user, recommends setting a routine and showing up when you say you will. Anant Agarwal, founder and CEO of edX, suggests finding a study buddy or joining a larger learning group to stay accountable and motivated.

For some, this may be just the start of their learning journey, while others may find that completing a single course is enough. Whatever the goal, online learning platforms offer a unique opportunity to connect with others, learn new skills, and transform this period of self-isolation into a time of enlightenment and self-discovery.

Title: Baltimore Riots: A Look Back at the 1968 Unrest and Its Lasting Implications

The recent riots in Baltimore have sparked concerns about the potential for a repeat of the civil unrest that swept the city and 125 others in 1968, following the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. The 1968 riots lasted almost four days, resulting in six deaths, 700 injuries, and the destruction of 1,000 businesses. While the current riots are not of the same magnitude, they have raised questions about the city's response and the potential for a "long, hot summer" of urban unrest.

The 1968 riots had significant political implications, including the reaction of then-Maryland Governor Spiro Agnew, a moderate Republican who summoned 100 black leaders to his office for a tongue-lashing. Agnew accused the leaders of refusing to criticize black militants, such as Stokely Carmichael, who had visited Baltimore three days before the riots.

The riots also had a profound impact on the political careers of several individuals, including Baltimore Mayor Tommy D'Alessandro, who lost his job as a result of the unrest. The riots also led to the elevation of Agnew to Vice President, a position he held until his resignation in 1973.

Some scholars believe the Baltimore riots helped trigger the law-and-order backlash of the 1970s and 1980s and a national criminal justice policy that put thousands of black men behind bars. Others argue that the huge investments in welfare and anti-poverty programs that flowed into urban neighborhoods after the riots helped undermine minority family structure and breed increased violence.

In the current crisis, Baltimore Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake has faced criticism for her handling of the situation, with some accusing her of giving too much space to those who wished to destroy property. However, it is clear that the city's response to the riots will be closely watched and studied, with the hope that lessons can be learned and employed in other tense cities.

Title: Pentagon Warns of National Security Risks from Automatic Spending Cuts, But Public Support Remains Divided

The Pentagon has warned that the automatic spending cuts set to take effect next week will damage U.S. national security, with Defense Secretary Leon Panetta stating that the cuts will put the military on a "hollow force" path. However, the warnings do not appear to be moving the needle with lawmakers or the American public.

The automatic spending cuts, also known as the sequester, are set to reduce the Pentagon's budget by $500 billion over the next decade. The cuts are a result of a 2011 agreement between Congress and the White House to address the national debt. The cuts are expected to have a significant impact on the military, with the Navy already deciding not to send one of its aircraft carriers on a scheduled deployment to the Persian Gulf.

Some Republicans, such as House Speaker John Boehner, have expressed alarm over the cuts, calling them "devastating." However, Congressional expert Sarah Binder of the Brookings Institution notes that the GOP is no longer united on protecting the Pentagon. "There's a defense wing of defense hawks, and they've been pretty vocal about the impact on the Defense Department and national security, generally," she said.

The White House is trying to enlist the public's help in opposing the cuts, with President Obama doing a series of local TV interviews and planning to visit a military community outside Washington, D.C. next week. However, the public remains divided on the issue, with some polls showing that nearly two-thirds of Americans support reducing defense spending.

A recent survey by the Stimson Center found that 63% of respondents opted for defense cuts as a way to address the federal deficit. The survey also found that both Republicans and Democrats were comfortable reducing the defense budget. Other polls by Gallup, Harris, and the Pew Research Center have produced similar findings.

The survey's findings suggest that the public is willing to consider reducing defense spending as a way to address the national debt, but it does not necessarily mean they are comfortable with the indiscriminate cuts set to take effect next week. The cuts are a result of the 2011 agreement and were intended to be a temporary measure to address the debt. However, the gridlock in Congress has prevented lawmakers from finding an alternative solution, and the cuts are now set to take effect.

The debate over the sequester highlights the complexity of the issue and the difficulty in finding a solution. While some argue that the cuts will damage national security, others see them as a necessary step to address the national debt. The public remains divided, and it is unclear what the outcome will be.

Title: The Luxury Beliefs of the Upper Class: How Elite Ideas Contribute to Social Inequality

The concept of monogamy has been deemed "outdated" by some members of the upper class, according to a recent conversation with a former classmate from Yale. This individual, who comes from an affluent family and works at a well-known technology company, believes that marriage should not be a societal expectation. However, they still plan to have a monogamous marriage themselves.

The idea that monogamy is outdated is just one example of a "luxury belief" held by the upper class. These beliefs are ideas and opinions that confer status on the rich at very little cost, while taking a toll on the lower class. The upper class has found a way to display their social status through luxury beliefs, rather than luxury goods.

Research suggests that people care deeply about social status, and that respect and admiration from peers are even more important than money for our sense of well-being. As a result, the upper class has found ways to display their status through beliefs that are not only unattainable for the lower class but also perpetuate social inequality.

One example of a luxury belief is the idea that all family structures are equal. This is not supported by evidence, as families with two married parents are the most beneficial for young children. Despite this, affluent, educated people raised by two married parents are more likely to believe that monogamy is outdated.

The erosion of the family has contributed to the decline in marriage rates among the working class and poor. Out-of-wedlock birthrates have increased significantly among these groups, with rates more than 10 times higher than they were in 1960. In contrast, affluent people are less likely to have children out of wedlock.

Other luxury beliefs held by the upper class include the idea that religion is irrational or harmful, and that individual decisions don't matter compared to random social forces, including luck. These beliefs can have negative consequences for the lower class, as they can lead to a lack of motivation and a sense of powerlessness.

White privilege is another luxury belief that can have devastating effects on disadvantaged communities. The idea that racial disparities stem from inherent advantages held by whites is a myth that perpetuates inequality. Affluent whites are more likely to claim white privilege, yet they are less likely to incur any costs for promoting this belief.

In conclusion, the luxury beliefs of the upper class can have real and tangible consequences for disadvantaged people, further widening the social divide. As these beliefs are passed down to the working class and poor, they can perpetuate social inequality and undermine the social fabric of communities.

Title: Former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty Backs Jeb Bush for Republican Presidential Nomination

Article:

Former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty has expressed his support for former Florida Governor Jeb Bush to win the Republican presidential nomination in 2016. Pawlenty, who ended his own presidential campaign in 2011, believes Bush can overcome the notion that conservatives won't elect an "establishment" candidate. He pointed to the party's standard bearers in the past two presidential cycles, John McCain and Mitt Romney, as examples of successful candidates who defied expectations.

Pawlenty stated on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" that Bush has a compelling personal story and a strong campaign infrastructure, similar to McCain and Romney. However, he acknowledged that Bush's last name could be a liability, citing a recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll that found 69% of respondents agreed with Barbara Bush's statement that "there are more than two or three families who should run for high office in America." The poll also showed that 21% of respondents view Bush positively, while 32% have a negative view.

Compared to a year ago, Americans view Bush less favorably, with 26% having a positive view and 23% having a negative view. The poll of 1,000 adults had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

Title: Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Dunford: Military Option for North Korea Not "Unimaginable"

Article:

Marine General Joseph Dunford, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, emphasized the importance of preparing for the possibility of a military confrontation with North Korea during an interview at the Aspen Security Forum in Aspen, Colorado. Dunford stated that while a military option should not be ruled out, it would be a "horrific" and "loss of life unlike any we have experienced in our lifetimes" if a conflict were to occur on the Korean Peninsula.

Dunford's comments came in the wake of North Korea's recent testing of an inter-continental ballistic missile, which has raised concerns about the country's rapid advancement in its weapons systems. The Chairman stressed that the United States is already prepared to defend itself and its allies against North Korea's current capability of carrying out a more limited missile attack.

Dunford also touched on the importance of applying continued economic and diplomatic pressure to persuade North Korea to give up its nuclear arms program. He emphasized the need to develop military options to prevent a nuclear weapon from landing in Denver, Colorado, which he deemed "unimaginable."

The Chairman also discussed the importance of properly resourcing the State Department, stating that the Department of Defense is in support of the State Department's efforts. Dunford expressed his support for Secretary of State Rex Tillerson's work in tackling a range of crises, including corralling more international support to pressure North Korea and repairing a diplomatic rift between Qatar and a group of other countries led by Saudi Arabia.

In a lighter moment, Dunford joked about his relationship with President Donald Trump, saying, "He loves me! At least I think so."

Title: Trump Administration Blocks Congress from Seeing Unredacted Emails on Census Citizenship Question

The Trump administration has refused to release unredacted emails and memos related to the addition of a citizenship question to the 2020 census, citing privileges and exemptions. The documents, which were part of lawsuits over the question's addition, revealed that Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross pressured Commerce staff to add the question for reasons deemed "mysterious" by a federal judge in Maryland.

The Justice Department, representing the administration in the lawsuits, has cited privileges, including those preventing attorney-client communications and certain decision-making discussions between government officials from becoming public. The lawsuits' plaintiffs have attempted to lift some of these protections, but courts have generally sided with the administration.

Lawmakers on the House Oversight and Reform Committee have been battling for months to obtain the full release of these emails and memos, as well as other unreleased documents, as part of their congressional investigation into the administration's motivations for adding the citizenship question. This week, President Trump claimed executive privilege over the requested documents, shortly before the committee's Democrats and Rep. Justin Amash, a Republican from Michigan, voted to hold Ross and U.S. Attorney General William Barr in contempt of Congress for refusing to comply with subpoenas for the documents.

Some of the emails that could spark another court battle over the citizenship question include:

* An email sent to Ross by Commerce Department official Earl Comstock on May 2, 2017
* An email sent to Ross's then-chief of staff, Wendy Teramoto, by Ross on May 2, 2017
* An email sent to Comstock by Ross on August 8, 2017
* An email sent to Comstock by Ross on August 10, 2017
* An email sent to Ross by Comstock on August 11, 2017 (The House oversight committee has asked the administration to release the memo attached to this unredacted email)
* An email sent to Comstock by Ross on September 1, 2017
* An email sent to Comstock by Ross on September 1, 2017
* An email sent to then-Commerce Department attorney James Uthmeier on September 7, 2017
* An email sent to then-White House official John Zadrozny on December 20, 2017
* An email sent to then-Commerce Department attorney Michael Walsh by Uthmeier on February 26, 2018

Title: Former Bank Executive Testifies in Paul Manafort's Fraud Trial

A former executive of Federal Savings Bank, Dennis Raico, testified on Friday in Paul Manafort's fraud trial that the bank's CEO, Steve Calk, was directly involved in approving $16 million in loans to Manafort. Raico, who was granted immunity, stated that Calk took a "personal interest" in Manafort's loan applications and expedited them. One loan was approved just a day after a July 27, 2016, call in which Calk expressed his interest in a role in the Trump administration.

According to Raico, Calk wanted to be considered for positions such as Treasury Secretary or Housing and Urban Development Secretary. However, he did not receive any post in the administration. Raico testified that the involvement of Calk in the Manafort loans was unusual and made him uncomfortable, as he had never seen loans approved so quickly at the bank.

The trial resumed after an unexpected recess that lasted into the afternoon, with prosecutors planning to call two more witnesses on Monday. The jury was instructed to put the trial out of their minds until Monday and not to discuss the case with anyone.

Title: Obama Administration Finalizes Rule to Expand Overtime Eligibility

The United States Department of Labor has finalized a rule that will make millions of American workers eligible for overtime pay. The new regulation, set to take effect on December 1, states that anyone earning less than $47,476 per year will be entitled to time-and-a-half pay for hours worked beyond 40 hours a week. This change is expected to benefit approximately 4.2 million salaried workers who were previously not eligible for overtime pay.

The rule is part of the Obama administration's efforts to boost slow-growing incomes and strengthen the middle class. Labor Secretary Tom Perez emphasized that the goal is to ensure middle-class jobs pay middle-class wages. The rule change is authorized under the Fair Labor Standards Act, which was enacted during the New Deal era.

Prior to this rule, only about 7% of salaried workers were eligible for overtime pay. In 1975, more than 60% of salaried workers were eligible, but inflation and regulatory changes under the George W. Bush administration eroded this protection. The new rule will cover about 35% of salaried workers, with managers at many retail stores and fast food restaurants being among those who will benefit.

Some employers have welcomed the change, while others have expressed concerns that it will increase labor costs. Critics are urging Congress to block the new rule, but any such push would face a certain veto by President Obama. The Labor Department has emphasized that employers have various ways to comply with the new rule, including increasing employee wages, providing more time off, or reclassifying certain employees as exempt.

The rule has been in the making for over two years, with the Labor Department initially proposing an even higher income threshold of more than $50,000 before scaling it back in response to concerns about pay scales in low-wage areas. Vice President Joe Biden will meet with an employer who supports the change on Wednesday.

Title: Trump Weighs in on Franken, Avoids Comment on Moore Allegations

Article:

President Donald Trump has spoken out about the allegations against Democratic Senator Al Franken, calling a photo of Franken appearing to grab a woman's breast while she was asleep "The Al Frankenstien picture is really bad, speaks a thousand words. Where do his hands go in pictures 2, 3, 4, 5 & 6 while she sleeps?" Trump wrote on Twitter. Franken has apologized for his behavior and welcomed an ethics probe into his conduct.

Trump's comments on Franken come as he has declined to weigh in forcefully on the allegations against Alabama Senate Republican candidate Roy Moore, who has been accused of sexual misconduct by multiple women. The President's decision not to comment on the Moore controversy is reportedly due in part to his own history of facing sexual misconduct allegations, with a Republican close to the White House telling CNN that Trump is worried about being dragged into the topic of sexual assault or harassment if he weighs in.

The White House has said that Trump believes Moore should step aside if the allegations against him are true, but the President himself has declined to comment further on the matter. White House press secretary Sarah Sanders has said that the decision on whether Moore should drop out of the race is up to the people of Alabama, not the President.

In contrast, Trump has weighed in on the allegations against Franken, calling the photo "really bad" and referencing a 1995 New York magazine article in which Franken joked about drugging and raping journalist Lesley Stahl. Franken has apologized for his behavior and welcomed an ethics probe into his conduct.

The White House has also said that a Senate investigation into the allegations against Franken is an "appropriate action."

Title: Senate Begins Debate on Immigration Reform, Path to Citizenship for DREAMers Unclear

The United States Senate has started a free-wheeling debate on immigration reform, with lawmakers seeking a bipartisan compromise that can garner at least 60 votes to pass. The goal is to provide legal protection for undocumented immigrants who came to the country as children, while also bolstering immigration enforcement. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell described the process as an opportunity for "a thousand flowers to bloom."

The debate began with a shell bill proposed by McConnell, which will be amended and debated over the coming days and weeks. Senators voted 97-1 to start the debate, with only Texas Republican Senator Ted Cruz voting against it. The bill aims to provide a path to citizenship for up to 1.8 million DREAMers, in exchange for $25 billion for a border wall and at least a 25% cut in legal immigration. The Secure and Succeed Act mirrors the White House's outlined proposal.

While the bill's chances in the Senate are unclear, with most Democrats opposing the cuts to legal immigration and some conservatives questioning the path to citizenship for such a large group. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer described the bill as a "narrow" solution, stating that it is not the time to reform the entire legal immigration system.

The debate is ongoing, with the "gang of six" – a bipartisan group of six senators working to find a solution – still deciding whether to introduce their proposal as an amendment. The White House has rejected the "gang of six" plan, which outlined a more moderate approach to address the four areas the White House said it would like to see addressed: legal protections for DREAMers, money for border security and a wall, changes to family-based or "chain" migration, and an end to the diversity visa lottery program.

The outcome of the debate remains uncertain, with Senator Dick Durbin stating that he does not know if they will have 60 votes or if they can get 11 Republicans to join all the Democrats. The debate is expected to continue, with the fate of the DREAMers and the future of immigration reform hanging in the balance.

Title: US Reports Over a Million Coronavirus Cases Due to Testing Efforts, Says President Trump

The United States has reported over a million coronavirus cases, according to President Donald Trump, who attributed the high number to the country's testing efforts. Trump took to Twitter to hail the country's testing as "much better than any other country in the world." The US has the world's largest number of confirmed cases, with over 1 million reported, and total deaths exceeding 58,000 as of late Tuesday.

According to a tally, the US has reported more than 3.1 million cases worldwide, with over 216,000 deaths. The rise in cases has put pressure on efforts to boost testing capacity, with health officials flagging the challenge of getting tests to those who need them most.

Dr. Anthony Fauci, head of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said that every American in need of a virus test should be able to get one by the end of May or the beginning of June. Fauci emphasized the importance of identifying, isolating, and tracing contacts to keep the country safe and healthy.

The virus has taken an unprecedented toll on the US economy, with a likely contraction in the first quarter at its sharpest pace since the Great Recession. The number of Americans seeking jobless benefits has soared to 26.5 million, or nearly one in six US workers, and the Trump administration has forecast an April unemployment rate exceeding 16%.

Title: Naval Air Station-Corpus Christi Closed Following Active Shooter Threat

The Naval Air Station-Corpus Christi in Texas was closed on May 21, 2020, after an active shooter threat was reported. The facility was placed on lockdown, and the entrances were closed. According to officials, the shooter was "neutralized," but few details about the incident have been released.

The shooting occurred at around 6:15 a.m. when the gunman attempted to speed through a security gate at the naval air station, opening fire and wounding a sailor, a member of base security. The sailor was able to roll over and hit the switch that raised a barrier, preventing the gunman from entering the base.

The FBI has taken the lead on the investigation, which is being treated as "terrorism-related." The agency has not released any information about the shooter's motive or whether a second person of interest is at large.
