The FBI Supervisory Senior Resident Agent Leah Greeves stated that investigators are working to determine whether the shooting was related to terrorism, but did not provide further details.

The injured sailor was discharged from the hospital after being treated for minor injuries. The air station was on lockdown for about five hours before it was lifted, and the main gate was reopened, although the gate where the incident occurred remained shut down.

The FBI's Houston field office is leading the investigation, and neither investigators nor the Navy have provided details on the shooter or a possible motive. The incident comes months after a similar shooting at a Navy base in Pensacola, Florida, which was also deemed an act of terrorism.

Title: White House Broadens Obamacare Exemptions, Offers Alternative Plans to Those Whose Coverage Was Cancelled

The White House has announced a new policy that will exempt millions of Americans who had their health plans cancelled from the Affordable Care Act's individual mandate. This move comes just before the deadline to sign up for coverage starting January 1. The administration has also made a catastrophic health plan available to those who had their plans cancelled, which has more limited benefits than other Obamacare health plans.

The new policy has been met with criticism from Republicans, who argue that it will cause instability in the marketplaces and further confuse consumers. The insurance industry has also expressed concerns that the change will disrupt coverage and lead to tumult in the new marketplaces.

The administration has stated that fewer than half a million people who had their plans cancelled have not yet found new coverage. The new rules will allow those who are seeking coverage to get a "hardship exemption" if their new alternatives are too expensive. The catastrophic plan is an option for people under 30 and those who qualify for specific exemptions, such as affordability.

Administration officials have noted that some people who lost plans were able to get subsidized ones in the new exchanges. The catastrophic plan is an option for people who had their plans cancelled, and they will have to provide proof of a canceled policy to qualify for the exemption.

The administration does not expect many people to take up the new option, but wants to ensure that catastrophic coverage is available to those who had plans cancelled. However, making catastrophic health plans more broadly available also poses problems for insurers, as it could disrupt the insurance pools and further depress enrollment.

Title: US Citizenship Data Reveals Dominant Countries and States of Origin

The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services has released data on the 779,929 immigrants who became naturalized citizens in 2013. The data shows that people from all over the world are still coming to the United States, with a few countries dominating the list. According to the data, Mexico is the leading country of origin, followed by India, the Philippines, the Dominican Republic, China, and Cuba.

The data also reveals that the new citizens have already lived in the United States for at least five years, with some having lived here longer. A notable group is the 2,807 individuals listed as having been born in the former Soviet Union, which may indicate that they have been in the United States since before the end of the Cold War.

The data also shows that the new citizens are concentrated in a handful of states, with California, New York, and Florida being the top three. However, every state has at least some new citizens, with Wyoming having the fewest at 242.

A unique aspect of the data is the labeling of states based on the country of origin that produced the closest number of new citizens. For example, Wyoming, with 242 new citizens, is labeled as Austria, which had 248 new citizens. Kentucky, with 3,341 new citizens, is labeled as Turkey, which had 3,390 new citizens.

Notably, California stands out as having the largest number of new citizens, with 164,792 individuals naturalized in 2013. No single country had as many people naturalized as US citizens in the same year.

Title: Analysis of RAISE Act's Economic Impact Raises Questions

The RAISE Act, a bill aimed at reducing legal immigration levels by half over a decade, has been met with criticism from some media outlets, including CNN, which warned of the bill's supposedly harmful economic effects. However, a closer examination of the Wharton School of Business's analysis, cited by CNN, reveals a more nuanced picture.

According to the study, the American economy would lose more than 4 million jobs and be 2 percent smaller by 2040 under the RAISE Act compared to current immigration levels. While this may seem alarming, Steve Camarota, director of research at the Center for Immigration Studies, argues that CNN is misinterpreting the study's findings.

Camarota points out that the study's projections are based on a smaller population with fewer workers, not a reduction in the native-born population's employment rate. In fact, the study suggests that the employment rate for native-born Americans could increase under the RAISE Act.

Jason Richwine, a fellow at the Center for Immigration Studies, notes that the domestic worker participation rate would not increase enough to fill the jobs that immigrants would have filled, meaning the job market would become more favorable for native-born Americans.

The media's focus on gross domestic product (GDP) is also misleading, according to Camarota. He argues that adding people to the United States does not necessarily raise the standard of living, and that GDP per capita is a more accurate measure of economic well-being. The Wharton analysis does address GDP per capita, finding a negligible effect from reduced immigration under the RAISE Act, with per capita GDP expected to be 0.02 percent higher in 2027 compared to current policy.

Overall, while the RAISE Act's economic impact is a topic of ongoing debate, a closer examination of the Wharton analysis suggests that the bill may not have the devastating effects claimed by some media outlets.

Title: Iowa Freedom Summit to Host Top Republican Contenders

The Iowa Freedom Summit, co-hosted by Citizens United and Rep. Steve King, will take place this weekend in Des Moines, Iowa. The event is considered a significant gathering for the 2016 Republican presidential race, with nearly 10 potential candidates set to speak. The list includes New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas, Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, former Texas Gov. Rick Perry, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee, renowned neurosurgeon Ben Carson, former Sen. Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, and former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina.

Notably, top contenders Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney will not be attending the event, citing scheduling conflicts. Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky and Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida will also skip the Iowa gathering, with Paul opting to speak at an event in Palm Springs, California, hosted by a group backed by the Koch Brothers.

Christie, considered a moderate and pragmatic candidate, is expected to be a highlight of the summit. He has taken a stance on social issues, focusing on enhancing drug rehabilitation programs in his state, particularly for non-violent criminals with drug convictions. His views on immigration reform remain unclear, and political observers will be watching to see what candidates say about the issue in Iowa this week.

Other topics expected to be discussed at the summit include same-sex marriage and abortion, with the Supreme Court set to take up the issue of same-sex marriage this year. The House recently passed a measure banning taxpayer money for abortions, and the 42nd anniversary of the Roe v. Wade decision was marked by anti-abortion rights activists.

Several potential candidates will stay in Iowa longer, with Huckabee and Perry planning book signings and Santorum staying until Tuesday for multiple events throughout the state. The Iowa Freedom Summit provides a platform for candidates to roll out their message to core caucus-goers and build a winning coalition.

Title: Trump's Re-Election Campaign Threatens to Sue CNN Over Alleged Biased Reporting

The re-election campaign of President Donald Trump has threatened to sue CNN over what they claim is biased reporting, a move that opponents have denounced as an attempt to intimidate the media. The campaign's lawyers, led by Charles Harder, sent a letter to CNN alleging that the network has engaged in "unfair, unfounded, unethical, and unlawful attacks" against the President.

CNN responded by calling the threat a "desperate PR stunt" and refusing to comment further. Legal analysts have pointed out that the threatened lawsuit would likely be unsuccessful, as it would not be a libel suit and would not meet the legal requirements for a Lanham Act violation.

The dispute is the latest salvo in the ongoing feud between Trump and the news media, particularly CNN. Trump has frequently attacked the network and its employees, calling them "fake news" and claiming they are biased against him. CNN has defended its reporting, stating that it is committed to providing accurate and unbiased information to the public.

The Trump campaign's letter to CNN cites reports from a conservative group that obtained tapes of CNN employees discussing coverage of the President. However, legal analysts have pointed out that the tapes do not provide evidence of any wrongdoing by CNN and are likely a PR stunt designed to appeal to Trump's base.

The dispute highlights the ongoing tensions between the Trump administration and the news media, with both sides accusing each other of bias and misinformation.

Title: London Mosque Attack: Man Arrested After Van Hits Muslims, Leaving 11 Injured

The Metropolitan Police have arrested a 47-year-old man, Darren Osborne, on suspicion of attempted murder and alleged terror offenses after a van struck a group of Muslims near a London mosque. The incident occurred shortly after midnight near the Finsbury Park Mosque, with 11 people injured, including nine taken to hospital and two treated at the scene. The driver of the van was detained by bystanders before police arrived.

The Metropolitan Police Chief, Cressida Dick, described the incident as "quite clearly an attack on Muslims" and announced that the community will see more police, including armed officers, in the area, particularly around religious establishments.

The family of the arrested man, Darren Osborne, released a statement expressing their shock and devastation, saying they are still trying to process the events. They also extended their condolences to those injured.

The attack has sparked widespread condemnation, with Prime Minister Theresa May calling it "every bit as sickening" as previous terror attacks in the UK. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn also visited the area, stating that an attack on a mosque, synagogue, or church is an attack on all of us.

The incident has also raised concerns about the potential for retaliation and the impact on community relations. Locals described the area as proudly multicultural, where the biggest rivalry is between football teams, Arsenal and Tottenham. Residents are now left feeling shocked and fearful, with some expressing concerns about the safety of their children.

The driver of the van was reportedly heard saying "you deserve it" and "I did my bit" to those holding him, according to Toufik Kacimi, chief executive of Muslim Welfare House. The incident has been condemned by faith leaders and community members, who are calling for unity and solidarity in the face of terrorism.

Title: North and South Korean Leaders Meet, Kim Jong-un Promises End to Missile Tests

Article:

North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in met at the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) on Friday, marking a historic moment in inter-Korean relations. The meeting was characterized by a convivial atmosphere, with the two leaders chatting and laughing as they walked to the House of Peace. Kim Jong-un even extended an unscripted invitation to Moon to visit the North, and the two leaders exchanged smiles and handshakes as they began their talks.

During their meeting, Kim Jong-un reportedly promised Moon that there would be no more nuclear missile tests, stating that he wanted to ensure Moon's morning sleep would not be disturbed again. This pledge is a repeat of one made earlier this year, but its implementation remains to be seen.

Kim's sister, Kim Yo-jong, was present throughout the formalities, handing him a pen to sign a guestbook and taking flowers from schoolchildren. The meeting was notable for being the first time Kim's speaking voice has been heard in conversation, with Bloomberg journalist Kyung Bok-cho describing his accent as minimal and him sounding like he could fit in seamlessly in Seoul.

Despite the optimistic tone of the meeting, experts remain skeptical about the implications for peace on the peninsula. Robert Kelly of Pusan National University warned that Pyongyang has not made meaningful concessions and that significant strategic and political divisions remain between the North and South, as well as between the North and the US. Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull also expressed caution, noting that the Korean peninsula has seen false dawns before. The meeting did not touch on the proposed summit between Kim and US President Donald Trump, which remains uncertain.

Title: US Ambassador to UN Spends $53,000 on Customized Curtains Amid Budget Cuts

The United States Ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki Haley, has faced criticism over the purchase of customized and mechanized curtains for her official residence in New York City. The curtains, which cost $52,701, were approved in 2016 under the Obama administration, but were installed last year.

The curtains themselves cost nearly $30,000, with the additional $22,801 spent on the hardware needed to operate them. The purchase has raised eyebrows, particularly given the State Department's recent budget cuts and freezes on hiring and diplomatic staff.

Critics, including former White House official Brett Bruen, have questioned the priorities of the spending. "How can you, on the one hand, tell diplomats that basic needs can't be met and, on the other hand, spend more than $50,000 on a customized curtain system for the ambassador to the U.N.?" Bruen asked.

Andrew Stroehlein, Human Rights Watch's European Media Director, also took to Twitter to express his disapproval, writing, "When @nikkihaley's not busy rejecting the idea of universal human rights, she's busy spending $52,701 of US taxpayer money on curtains for her residence. Milk the people, screw the world. Fine priorities you got there."

Defending the spending, Patrick Kennedy, the top management official at the State Department during the Obama administration, stated that the curtains will be used by future officials and cited security and entertainment purposes. "All she's got is a part-time maid, and the ability to open and close the curtains quickly is important," Kennedy said.

The State Department, under former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, had previously frozen hiring, reduced diplomatic staff, and proposed cutting the department's budget by 31 percent.

Title: Roberts Edges Wolf in Kansas Senate Primary, Party Support Key Factor

Article:

In the Kansas Senate primary, incumbent Senator Pat Roberts secured a narrower-than-expected win over challenger Milton Wolf, a radiologist and distant cousin of President Barack Obama. The Republican establishment's efforts to support Roberts played a significant role in his victory, with the National Republican Senatorial Committee (NRSC) sending resources to the Kansas City area to boost his campaign.

Roberts won the election with 48% of the vote, while Wolf received 41%, and two minor candidates combined for the remaining 11%. The NRSC's efforts, led by Kansas Senator Jerry Moran, who chairs the committee, focused on turning out supporters in Wolf's home base in Johnson County, where he lives and works. The committee sent six workers to the area for the final 10 days, knocking on over 10,000 doors and making over 40,000 phone calls.

Roberts' campaign reached over 200,000 GOP households in the state through live telephone calls and door knocks, most multiple times, over the final three weeks. The NRSC's regional political director, Brittany Belt, was also sent to Kansas for the final three weeks, focusing on the early vote and working with the campaign on messaging.

Senator Roberts' victory speech highlighted his campaign's efforts, stating that he has served as a "diligent check on Democrats' push for ever-expansive government and is a true conservative voice for our state." Moran, the NRSC chair, celebrated Roberts' win, saying he is a "true conservative voice for our state."

The election saw a closer margin than expected, with recent polls showing Roberts crushing Wolf. Wolf's campaign focused on portraying Roberts as a Washington insider, questioning whether he truly resides in the state or merely parachuted in to fight for reelection. Roberts, the son of an Eisenhower-era Republican National Committee chairman, was a longtime Hill aide before winning election to Congress in 1980.

Wolf, a second cousin once removed of Obama, presented himself as a hard-line conservative and built his bid around an effort to undo Obamacare. His challenge to Roberts was his first run for office, and he won the backing of some conservative groups that have tried, but so far failed, to oust Senate incumbents.

In his post-election speech, Roberts urged Republicans to refrain from similar infighting in future elections, stating, "The truth is, Republicans in Kansas and nationally can not afford the kind of intraparty fratricide we have seen recently. Friends, we can not afford to waste scarce resources and energy tearing ourselves apart. We can not afford a fractured party. The stakes are too high."

Title: Reporters Challenge New Restrictions on Coverage of Senate Impeachment Trial

The Senate's new restrictions on reporters covering the impeachment trial have sparked controversy among news organizations and journalists. The measures, negotiated with Republican leadership, limit reporters' access to senators and restrict their movements within the Capitol complex. Reporters are now confined to small, cordoned-off areas and are no longer allowed to walk with senators to continue conversations, even when the senator is willing to participate. Additionally, reporters are prohibited from approaching senators for interviews in the halls surrounding the Senate chamber.

The new rules effectively prevent journalists from reaching many senators, limiting their ability to gather information and cover the trial. The restrictions are seen as unusually strict, even compared to those in place for the annual State of the Union address.

The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, along with nearly 60 news organizations, has urged Senate leaders to relax the restrictions, citing the importance of preserving the public's right to know. The committee argues that reporters must have the ability to respond quickly to rapid developments and need reasonable access to lawmakers who wish to speak to the press.

The Society of Professional Journalists and the National Press Club Journalism Institute have also spoken out against the restrictions, citing the importance of the press in holding the government accountable and providing the public with information. The restrictions, they argue, could chill reporters' ability to cover big events or even normal business in the Capitol in the future.

News organizations are continuing to negotiate with the Senate sergeant-at-arms and Capitol Police to establish ground rules for coverage of the trial.

Title: House Democrats Vow to Pass $2 Trillion Coronavirus Relief Bill Despite Last-Minute Hurdles

The House of Representatives is expected to pass a massive $2 trillion coronavirus relief bill on Friday, despite last-minute efforts by a conservative member to force a roll-call vote. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said, "We're going to pass it today," as she entered the Capitol building shortly before 9 a.m.

House leaders had initially sought to pass the stimulus package without having to call the full chamber back to Washington, using a voice vote procedure that would allow some members to debate the legislation without the full House reconvening. However, Rep. Thomas Massie (R-Ky.) has threatened to force a roll-call vote, prompting leaders in both parties to weigh contingency plans for moving the package to President Trump's desk.

House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) has been working with House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) to find a quick path forward. Hoyer said that if Massie were to force a roll-call vote, party leaders expect to have enough lawmakers on the floor to form a quorum, allowing the House to approve the measure on Friday.

The House opened the floor at 9 a.m. to begin debate, which was initially expected to run for two hours but has been extended to three. Pelosi said the debate will respect congressional traditions and will allow for a longer discussion. The outcome of the vote remains uncertain, with Rep. Kevin Brady (R-Texas) stating that while there is a better-than-even chance the bill will pass, some members may still call for a roll-call vote.

Title: Trump Open to Delaying Funding for Border Wall, Clearing Way for Government Funding Deal

The White House announced on Monday that President Donald Trump is willing to wait until later this year to secure funding for a wall along the US-Mexico border, a potential breakthrough that could help avoid a government shutdown on Saturday. This shift in stance could clear the way for lawmakers to strike a deal on a five-month spending bill.

The president had previously indicated that he wanted to include funding for the wall in the bill to keep the government running after its current funding expires at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday, which marks his 100th day in office. However, the administration's flexibility on the wall's funding could remove one of the last remaining hurdles facing congressional Democrats and Republicans as they work to pass the spending bill.

The House GOP debate over a health-care bill is likely to be pushed to the back burner to help avert a shutdown, according to Republican lawmakers and aides. Without the debate over the border wall, lawmakers may be able to come to an agreement on the spending bill relatively quickly. Both Democrats and Republicans had signaled they were willing to increase money for the military and broader border security before administration officials indicated that Mr. Trump would press for money to begin building the wall.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said in a statement that it's "good for the country" that President Trump is taking the wall off the table in these negotiations, allowing bipartisan and bicameral negotiators to continue working on outstanding issues. Democratic votes will be needed, as Republicans hold just 52 seats in the Senate, where spending bills need 60 votes to clear procedural hurdles.

Many Republicans had indicated they would be satisfied with a spending bill that included money to strengthen security along the border in ways other than building a wall. "Border security's the main issue—whether that includes a wall or technology, drones, or repairing what we have," said Sen. Shelley Moore Capito (R., W. Va.). Other Republicans echoed that their top priority was making sure they crafted a spending bill that could clear both chambers before the government runs out of money.

One issue that remains unresolved is whether the five-month spending bill under negotiation would include payments to health insurers known as "cost-sharing reductions," as requested by Democrats. The payments support Affordable Care Act insurance plans by helping insurers lower costs for low-income consumers. An abrupt withdrawal of the payments would pose an immediate threat to health-insurance markets, potentially triggering the collapse of health plans midyear.

Title: Syrian Refugees Bring Economic Skills to Britain, Despite Challenges

Article:

In a heartwarming tale of resilience and determination, Syrian refugees Mohammed Rahimeh and Majeda Khoury have found success in the UK, leveraging their skills to start their own businesses. Rahimeh, who fled Syria in 2015 to avoid conscription, developed his cooking skills while waiting for his asylum claim to be processed. He now runs a popular pop-up restaurant, Mo's Eggs, serving a Syrian brunch. Khoury, a human-rights activist, learned to cook through a charity called Migrateful and prepares dishes associated with different Syrian cities.

Both Rahimeh and Khoury benefited from training by the Entrepreneurial Refugee Network (TERN), a charity aiming to launch 1,000 refugee-led businesses in the UK by 2025. Their stories highlight the valuable contributions refugees can make to the economy, echoing the experiences of immigrants throughout history, such as the Flemish weavers who came to England in the 14th century and the millions of Europeans who emigrated to America in the late 19th century.

However, many refugees face significant challenges in starting their own businesses. Paul Hutchings, co-founder of Refugee Support, a charity, has been working to help those stuck in camps. He established a shop in the camps, allowing residents to buy their own necessities, promoting dignity and independence. Dina Nayeri, a former refugee, emphasizes the importance of dignity, as many refugees struggle with trauma, shame, and feelings of inferiority.

Refugee Support has also set up a sewing co-operative, where refugees make bags, cushion covers, and aprons, selling them online at Refumade.org. The charity provides materials, machines, and electricity, and each item comes with a message about the person who made it. The sewing workers are mostly women, while men have access to a bicycle-sharing scheme in Cyprus to help them find work outside the camps.

The refugees' determination to rebuild their lives is truly striking, and their work ethic is something any company or country should value. Their stories serve as a reminder of the importance of providing opportunities for refugees to contribute to the economy and society, promoting dignity and independence.

Title: House GOP Leaders Propose Revenue Increases, Spending Cuts in Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

House Speaker John Boehner and other Republican leaders have presented a proposal to address the fiscal cliff, which includes $2.2 trillion in deficit savings over the next decade. The plan promises $800 billion from tax reform, $600 billion from Medicare reforms, and $600 billion in other spending cuts. The proposal also includes $200 billion in savings by revising the consumer price index, a measure of inflation.

The plan was quickly dismissed by the Obama administration, which called it a "step backward" and not worthy of a counteroffer because it is not serious enough. White House spokesman Dan Pfeiffer criticized the plan for not meeting the "test of balance" and not providing enough specifics on which deductions would be eliminated, which loopholes would be closed, or which Medicare savings would be achieved.

The Republican proposal is an attempt to address the fiscal cliff, which is the result of a two-year stalemate over deficit reduction. The plan is based on a framework proposed last year by Erskine Bowles, a Democrat and former White House chief of staff. However, Bowles denied any direct connection to the GOP proposal, saying it reflected his view of a middle-ground approach a year ago but "circumstances have changed since then."

The proposal has been met with skepticism by the Obama administration, which has called for a more balanced approach that includes increasing tax revenue by almost $1 trillion over 10 years. The plan would also close loopholes, limit deductions, raise the estate tax rate to 2009 levels, and increase tax rates on capital gains and dividends.

The fiscal cliff has been a contentious issue for two years, with both sides refusing to budge. The non-partisan Tax Policy Center estimates that middle-class families would pay about $2,000 a year more in taxes without action. A recent CNN/ORC International Poll found that 56% of respondents said higher taxes were a fair tradeoff if it helps lower-income people, while 36% said taxes should be kept low to create jobs.

The outcome of the fiscal cliff negotiations remains uncertain, with both sides continuing to negotiate and no new offers officially on the table.

Title: White House Hopeful Beto O'Rourke Reveals Ancestral Ties to Slavery, Calls for National Conversation on Racial Injustice

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke recently revealed that he and his wife, Amy, are descended from slave owners. In a Medium post, O'Rourke shared documents showing that his paternal great-great-great-grandfather listed two enslaved women, Rose and Eliza, as his possessions. He acknowledged that his ancestors profited from the transatlantic slave trade and the subsequent forms of institutionalized racism, which had long-term repercussions for the enslaved and their descendants.

O'Rourke emphasized that he benefits from a system that his ancestors built to favor themselves at the expense of others and that he has a responsibility to change the country. He outlined several policy promises aimed at addressing the legacy of slavery, including addressing underfunding for minority-majority public schools, giving federal capital to minority- and women-owned businesses, universal healthcare, and criminal justice reform.

The White House hopeful also reiterated his support for reparations for the descendants of slaves, stating that it is essential to have a national conversation on slavery and racial injustice. This debate has gained momentum in recent months, with the House Judiciary Committee holding its first hearing on the issue in a decade in June. A bill sponsored by Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D-Texas) to form a commission to study whether black Americans should receive reparations has been gaining steam in the House, with many 2020 hopefuls endorsing the move.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has opposed the initiative, citing concerns about the constitutionality of reparations. In response, McConnell noted that he and former President Obama are in the same camp, both being descendants of slaveholders.

Title: Trump Administration's Visitor Log Policy Draws Criticism from Transparency Advocates

The Trump administration's decision to restrict public access to White House visitor logs has been met with criticism from transparency advocates, who argue that it is a step backward in government openness. The policy, which effectively means that none of the logs will be available for at least five years, has been condemned by Tom Blanton, the director of the National Security Archive, as a "falsehood" because the Obama-era policy already made exceptions.

The National Security Archive, along with two other organizations, sued the government this week for visitor logs from the White House, Mar-a-Lago estate, and Trump Tower. Blanton stated that the government's action was "just looking for a way to hide the logs" and that his organization had anticipated this move.

The Trump administration's policy is a return to the one followed by presidents who preceded Obama, during which government transparency groups began filing lawsuits demanding information about specific visitors to the White House, only to be stonewalled by the president's lawyers. The issue had not been resolved by the time Obama took office, but his administration adopted the position that visitor logs would be released with certain exceptions, in line with those recognized under the Freedom of Information Act.

Although a federal court ruled in 2011 that visitor logs could be kept secret, the Obama administration continued to provide them, with lawyers exercising what they maintained was a right to omit some entries, including in cases of highly sensitive meetings, such as interviews for prospective Supreme Court candidates and those dealing with national security or intelligence matters. The Obamas also routinely left out the names of celebrities and top donors who came to personal events at the White House, such as star-studded birthday celebrations for the president and his wife, drawing criticism for doing so.

The Trump policy has recently gained intense attention after the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Devin Nunes, confirmed that he was on the White House grounds when he received what he described as evidence that Trump or his closest associates might have been "incidentally" swept up in foreign surveillance by American spy agencies. Logs recording Nunes' visit on March 21 have not been released to the public.

The visitor records, maintained by the Secret Service, list the names of those entering along with which member of the White House staff obtained permission for them to enter, and the name of the person they are to meet.

**Trump and Kim Arrive in Singapore for Historic Summit**

US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un have arrived in Singapore ahead of their highly anticipated summit on the resort island of Sentosa. The two leaders are staying in separate hotels, not far from each other, and are preparing for their meeting on Tuesday.

The summit marks a significant shift in the relationship between the two leaders, who have had an up-and-down relationship over the past 18 months, trading insults and threatening war before abruptly changing tack and moving towards a face-to-face meeting.

The US hopes the summit will kick-start a process that eventually sees Kim give up his nuclear weapons. The US wants North Korea to get rid of its nuclear weapons in an irreversible manner that can be verified internationally. In return, the US is offering relief from UN sanctions.

The summit is seen as a significant step towards denuclearization, but analysts are skeptical about the chances of success. Kim has already gained a victory by winning the prestige of a meeting with the world's most powerful leader, and it is unclear what concessions he is willing to make.

The US president has described the summit as a "one-time shot" at peace and has said that if things go well, Kim could receive an invitation to the White House. However, if things go badly, Trump has said he will walk out of the meeting.

The summit is a significant development in the relationship between the two leaders, who have had a tumultuous past. Trump has referred to Kim as "little rocket man" and "dotard," while Kim has called Trump "mentally deranged." Despite the animosity, the two leaders have agreed to meet and discuss the possibility of denuclearization.

The summit is a complex and sensitive issue, with many factors at play. The US wants North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons, while North Korea wants sanctions relief and international investment. The outcome of the summit is uncertain, but it is a significant step towards a potential breakthrough in the region.

Title: Insurers to Send Customers $500 Million in Rebates this Summer

The White House is highlighting a provision in the Affordable Care Act, which requires health insurance providers to refund customers when they spend less than 80% of premiums on medical care. This provision will result in 8.5 million Americans receiving $500 million in rebates later this summer, with an average rebate of $100 per family. The Department of Health and Human Services estimates that this year's rebates will be lower than those in 2011, with 4.1 million people receiving about $152 per family, or a total of $1.1 billion.

The rebates are a tangible benefit of the health care law, which is facing deadlines to establish health care exchanges in all 50 states by October 1. The law's opponents, including Republican lawmakers, argue that the law is causing premium increases and that the rebates are not enough to offset the costs. However, the White House maintains that the law is providing peace of mind and security for individuals and their families.

The president will use a speech at the White House to tout the benefits of the law, highlighting the medical loss ratio provision and the rebates it will provide. The speech will also feature Americans who have received refunds from their insurance companies. The White House has invited these individuals to join the president on stage to share their experiences and demonstrate the law's impact on their lives.

Title: Supreme Court Allows Trump Administration to Implement Refugee Ban

The United States Supreme Court has granted the Trump administration's request to block a federal appeals court decision that would have allowed up to 24,000 additional refugees to enter the country. The decision gives President Donald Trump a partial victory as the high court prepares for a key October hearing on the constitutionality of his controversial executive order.

The March 6 executive order suspended travel for people from six Muslim-majority countries and limited refugee admissions for 90 and 120 days, respectively. The order aimed to prevent terrorist attacks and allow the government to put in place more stringent vetting procedures. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals had previously ruled that grandparents, aunts, uncles, and cousins of legal U.S. residents were exempt from the travel ban. The Justice Department opted not to appeal this part of the decision.

However, the 9th Circuit also ruled that Trump's refugee policy was too broad, allowing entry to refugees from around the world if they had a formal offer from a resettlement agency. The Justice Department appealed this decision, and the full Supreme Court sided with the administration in a one-sentence order.

Naureen Shah, Amnesty International USA's senior director of campaigns, criticized the decision, stating that the refugee ban is "inherently cruel" and that vulnerable people are being subjected to "unimaginable violence and fear" while their lives remain in limbo.

The state of Hawaii, which challenged the policy, argued that the U.S. government could still "bar tens of thousands of refugees from entering the country." Hawaii Attorney General Doug Chin expressed respect for the Supreme Court's decision and is preparing for the hearing on October 10.

Title: Rand Paul's Shift on Military Intervention Sparks Debate Among Republicans

Article: Senator Rand Paul, a likely presidential candidate, has been criticized for his skepticism towards military intervention overseas. In a Republican Party often defined by military muscularity, Paul has taken a more dovish stance, hoping to connect with a war-weary public. However, his recent comments on the Islamic State (ISIS) have sparked a debate among Republicans, with some accusing him of flip-flopping.

Paul has been vocal about his concerns over military intervention, stating that arming Islamic rebels in Syria created a haven for ISIS and that the Obama administration's decision not to intervene in Syria was a wise one. However, in a recent statement, he said that if he were president, he would call a joint session of Congress to discuss the reasoning behind ISIS's threat to national security and seek congressional authorization to destroy the group militarily.

This shift in rhetoric has drawn criticism from some Republicans, who argue that Paul is soft on ISIS. Mitt Romney, a former presidential candidate, wrote an op-ed in the Washington Post stating that the US should not slash its military spending in the face of threats from Russia, China, and Iran. The tone of the political argument is shifting, with some Republicans questioning Paul's commitment to his anti-interventionist views.

Paul has a paper trail of his views on military intervention, including an earlier op-ed in which he argued that the US should not choose sides in Iraq's civil war and that the Obama administration's decision not to intervene was correct. He has also criticized his own party for being too hawkish, stating that some Republicans advocated for striking down Assad's regime in Syria, which would have made the current situation worse.

The debate highlights the complexities of the issue, with some arguing that the US must take a strong stance against ISIS, while others believe that military intervention can have unintended consequences. Paul's shift in rhetoric has triggered criticism from some on the right, with conservative blogger Jennifer Rubin stating that Paul lacks the strength of his convictions. However, others argue that it is possible to believe that the US was too quick to make war in the Middle East and that ISIS is a threat that needs to be addressed.

Title: Trump Signs Budget Deal, Fox News Host Jesse Watters Criticizes Lack of Border Wall Funding

The President signed a budget deal on Friday, which has been met with criticism from some quarters, including Fox News host Jesse Watters. Watters expressed disappointment and frustration with the deal, stating that it was a "huge defeat" for the President on a "signature issue."

According to Watters, the deal does not provide sufficient funding for the border wall, with only $1.6 billion allocated for its construction. He noted that the wall is only supposed to be built for 93 miles, while the border stretches for 3,000 miles, and that the funding is insufficient to complete the project.

Watters also criticized the deal for prioritizing military spending over other areas, stating that the President sacrificed "everything else" to get the military funding. He also expressed frustration with the lack of funding for other important issues, such as the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), which he said is at a "historic high."

Watters also referenced comments made by Senator Rand Paul, who stated that there is an "unholy alliance" between Republicans and Democrats in Congress, which Watters believes is responsible for the lack of progress on the border wall.

The President had initially considered vetoing the budget deal, but ultimately decided to sign it. The deal has been met with criticism from some of the President's allies, including Laura Ingraham and Ann Coulter, who have suggested that the President could be impeached over the deal.

Title: Obama Proposes Free Preschool for Low-Income Families, Raises Questions on Cost and Effectiveness

The President's plan to provide free, high-quality preschool for low-income families has garnered a mixed response, with some praising the initiative as a way to help disadvantaged children, while others question the cost and effectiveness of the program.

During his State of the Union address, President Obama emphasized the importance of early childhood education, citing studies that show the benefits of early learning. He noted that less than 30% of 4-year-olds are enrolled in high-quality preschool programs and that poor children, who need help the most, are often at a disadvantage due to lack of access to such education.

The plan, which would match state funds to create high-quality preschool programs for 4-year-olds from low- and moderate-income families, would also provide extra federal money to states that expand their public preschool programs to middle-class families. The cost of the program remains unclear, but the President argues that investing in early education will save Americans by increasing graduation rates and reducing teen pregnancy and violent crime.

Critics, however, point to the country's $16 trillion debt and a Department of Health and Human Services study that shows limited benefits after third grade for those enrolled in preschools under the $7 billion Head Start program. Some argue that the program is not a proven solution and that the benefits are not as significant as claimed.

The Center for American Progress estimates the Obama plan would cost roughly $98 billion over 10 years. The liberal-leaning think tank also cited several studies that support the benefits of preschool education and noted that families making less than $1,500 a month must spend about 53% of their income on care for their children 4 years old and younger.

While some Republicans, such as Georgia Senator Johnny Isakson, have expressed skepticism about the plan, others, like Oklahoma and Georgia, have implemented successful preschool programs that have shown positive results. The debate highlights the complexity of the issue and the need for further discussion and analysis before a decision is made.

Title: US Rejects Iraqi Request to Withdraw Troops Amid Escalating Tensions with Iran

The United States has refused an Iraqi request to prepare for the withdrawal of its troops from the country, amid heightened tensions between Washington and Tehran following the US killing of an Iranian commander in Baghdad. The US has instead explored the possibility of expanding NATO's presence in Iraq.

The request was made by Iraqi Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi in a phone call with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Thursday, following a vote in Iraq's parliament last week. Mahdi asked Pompeo to send delegates to prepare for the withdrawal of US troops, citing the fact that the forces used in the killing had entered Iraq or used its airspace without permission.

The US State Department responded that any US delegation would not discuss the withdrawal of US troops, as their presence in Iraq is "appropriate." Instead, the department emphasized the need for a conversation between the US and Iraqi governments on security, as well as financial, economic, and diplomatic partnerships.

President Donald Trump said in an interview with Fox News that if Iraq wanted the US to leave, he would tell them, "You have to pay us for the money we put in." He claimed that the US has $35 billion of Iraq's money "sitting in an account" and that he believes Iraq will agree to pay it back.

Meanwhile, the US has imposed more sanctions on Iran in response to an attack on US troops in Iraq launched by Tehran in retaliation for the death of General Qassem Soleimani. The sanctions are aimed at tightening pressure on Iran and its leadership.

Iraq is caught in the middle of the escalating tensions between the US and Iran, with its leaders caught between their two main allies. The country has suffered decades of war, sanctions, and sectarian conflict, including the US-led invasion of 2003.

In the aftermath of Soleimani's killing, Tehran has stepped up its calls for US forces to leave Iraq, which like Iran is a mainly Shia Muslim nation. Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei has said the retaliatory strikes were not enough and that ending the US military presence in the region is Tehran's main goal.

However, Pompeo said on Friday that Washington has specific information about an imminent Iranian threat, including to US embassies, and that "American lives were at risk."

Title: US and North Korea Disagree on Progress in Nuclear Disarmament Talks

The United States and North Korea have presented differing accounts of a recent round of high-level talks, with North Korea accusing the US of using "gangster-like" tactics to push for nuclear disarmament. The North Korean foreign ministry released a statement, carried by the official KCNA news agency, claiming that the US attitude during the meeting was "extremely troubling" and that the country's resolve for denuclearization may falter.

According to the statement, the US had failed to bring a "constructive idea" to the table, instead imposing unilateral pressure on North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons. The statement warned that the US is "fatally mistaken" if it believes North Korea will be compelled to accept its demands.

In contrast, US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said that progress was made during his two-day visit to Pyongyang, but did not provide specific details. He stated that the US and North Korea discussed a timeline for disarmament, including the destruction of a missile engine testing facility, and that some progress was made on central issues.

The differing accounts come as the US and North Korea continue to negotiate on the details of a denuclearization agreement. The US has been pushing for North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program, while North Korea has been seeking security guarantees and economic benefits in return.

The meeting between Pompeo and Kim Yong-chol, a key aide to North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, did not result in a breakthrough, but the two sides did discuss the key issues of disarmament and security assurances. The US has also been seeking the return of remains of US service personnel from the Korean War.

Pompeo's visit marked the first time he had visited North Korea since the historic summit between US President Donald Trump and Kim Jong-un in Singapore. The meeting ended with a promise from Kim to work towards denuclearization, but details on how this will be achieved remain thin.

Title: Hong Kong Protests Continue for 17th Week, Tensions Remain High

Hong Kong's political crisis has entered its 17th week, with protests continuing to escalate and tensions remaining high. The unrest began over an extradition bill that was withdrawn by Chief Executive Carrie Lam, but the protests have "ruptured" trust between Hong Kong residents and the city's institutions, with much of the anger directed at Lam.

On Sunday, an unsanctioned rally turned violent, with protesters setting objects on fire and smashing windows at a train station, according to Bloomberg. In response, hundreds of pro-China supporters held a counter-protest. The previous day, hundreds of thousands of people took part in a sanctioned rally commemorating the 5th anniversary of the 2014 Umbrella Movement, which also saw protests against the Chinese government. Police used tear gas and water cannon to disperse the crowds.

The protests have been marked by clashes between protesters and police, with the latter firing over 3,000 canisters of tear gas and hundreds of rubber bullets in an effort to quell the demonstrations. This is a significant increase from 2014, when police fired 87 canisters of tear gas during the Umbrella Movement.

The protests are not only a response to Beijing's perceived overreach, but also a reflection of seismic changes in Hong Kong's identity. According to new research and opinion polling, being Hong Konger and being Chinese, once complementary, have come to feel exclusive. The 2014 Umbrella Movement was sparked by Beijing's proposal to limit Hong Kong's democracy and prevent the city from voting for its own leader.

The situation remains volatile, with Hong Kong residents threatening to stage a counter-rally during a celebration for the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Votes to Reform Patriot Act, Limit NSA's Phone-Snooping Powers

The House Judiciary Committee has taken a significant step towards limiting the National Security Agency's (NSA) phone-snooping program, voting 25-2 in favor of major reforms to the Patriot Act. The bipartisan majority's decision sends the USA Freedom Act to the full House floor for a vote, which could potentially scrap the NSA's program to collect and store Americans' data.

The reform bill, designed to rewrite Section 215 of the Patriot Act, would prevent the federal government from indiscriminately collecting and storing Americans' data, and impose more transparency on the secret court that oversees intelligence collection. The bill also raises prison sentences for those convicted of providing material support to terrorists.

The NSA's program, revealed by former government contractor Edward Snowden, has been widely criticized for its scope and lack of transparency. The program collects and stores five years' worth of records of phone calls made within the U.S., with the NSA insisting it only probes the records when it believes a number is associated with a terrorism investigation.

The reform bill has been in the works for two years, with efforts to rein in the collection of data ongoing. The bill is similar to one that passed the full House overwhelmingly last year, also with bipartisan support.

Senate Republicans, led by Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, have been pushing for a full renewal of the Patriot Act, citing the need for the government to keep the country safe. However, Senate Democrats are generally opposed to the bill, and even some Senate Republicans are torn, with civil libertarians like presidential candidate Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky fiercely opposing it.

The issue appears to be trending away from McConnell, with the House bill gaining momentum. The biggest threat to the bill came not from hawks but from the other side, where Republicans and Democrats teamed up to try to further limit government searches under Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The amendment failed, but only after some lawmakers expressed concerns about upsetting the carefully crafted consensus.

The two "no" votes on the bill came from Rep. Ted Poe, Texas Republican, and Rep. Jim Jordan, Ohio Republican. The bill's author, Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Wisconsin Republican, said the bill ends bulk collection, secret laws, and increases transparency of the intelligence community.

Title: Trump Criticizes Special Counsel Mueller's Investigators, Alleging Conflicts of Interest

President Donald Trump launched a series of tweets on Friday, criticizing Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigators and suggesting that their conflicts of interest should be included in the final report. Trump's tweets come ahead of major filings in the Russia probe and congressional testimony by former FBI Director James Comey.

Trump alleged that Mueller and Comey have a close relationship and that there are many conflicts of interest within the investigation. He also mentioned that the woman in charge of prosecuting Jerome Corsi, an ally of GOP political operative Roger Stone, is likely Jeannie Rhee, a federal prosecutor on Mueller's team. Rhee is a former partner at WilmerHale, the law firm where Mueller worked prior to taking on the special counsel role.

Trump also mentioned that Andrew Weissmann, a prosecutor on Mueller's team, has a history of controversial prosecutions and that Rod Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, is "totally conflicted" due to his role in appointing Mueller and signing the FISA warrant.

The president's tweets come as Mueller faces a court-imposed deadline to file briefs concerning the prosecutions of former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and former personal attorney Michael Cohen. The filings are expected to reveal more information about the extent of Manafort's cooperation with the government and how Cohen should be punished for lying to Congress.

Meanwhile, Comey is set to testify behind closed doors before the House Judiciary and Oversight committees on Friday, with a focus on his decision to write the July 2016 statement recommending against filing criminal charges in the Hillary Clinton email probe and the apparent political bias demonstrated in a slew of text messages and leaks by top FBI officials.

The president's tweets are the latest in a series of attacks on the Russia investigation, which he has repeatedly described as a "witch hunt."

Title: House Democrats to File Resolution to Block Trump's National Emergency Declaration, Setting Up Clash Over Presidential Powers and Immigration

Article:

House Democrats are set to file a resolution on Friday aimed at blocking the national emergency declaration issued by President Donald Trump to help finance his wall along the southwest border. This move is likely to set up a clash over billions of dollars, immigration policy, and the constitution's separation of powers.

The resolution, which is expected to be introduced by the full House, will likely pass with the support of Democratic lawmakers. It will then move to the Republican-controlled Senate, where it may face opposition from some GOP senators. The law that governs emergency declarations requires the Senate to address the issue, but there are procedural uncertainties surrounding the process.

The move is seen as a way for Democrats to take a defiant stance against Trump and please liberal voters. It will also put some Republicans from swing districts and states in a difficult position. The resolution is unlikely to garner the two-thirds majority needed to override a potential Trump veto.

The debate is centered around Trump's declaration of a national emergency to access billions of dollars beyond what Congress has authorized to start building a border wall. The move is seen as a way for Trump to circumvent Congress and get the funding he wants. Democrats argue that there is no emergency at the border and that Trump is improperly declaring one to work around Congress's rejection of higher amounts.

The resolution will likely be assigned to a committee, which will have 15 calendar days to send it to the full chamber. The House will then have three calendar days to vote on it, and the same procedure will be repeated in the Senate. The law requires these timetables unless either chamber votes to do otherwise.

The move has sparked debate among lawmakers, with some Republicans expressing concerns that Trump's declaration sets a precedent for future Democratic presidents to declare emergencies to address their own favored issues. Moderate Senator Susan Collins of Maine has publicly stated her support for the resolution, making her the first Republican to do so.

Title: Facebook's Quest for "Trusted" News Sources Raises Questions About Definition of Trust

Facebook, the social media giant, has announced plans to prioritize "trusted" news sources in its news feed, citing a survey that asks users if they are familiar with a news source and whether they trust it. The move aims to combat the spread of misinformation and propaganda on the platform. However, experts argue that the concept of trust is complex and difficult to define, making it challenging to determine what constitutes a "trusted" news source.

Facebook's approach relies on a poll that asks users to rate their familiarity and trust in news outlets, with options ranging from "entirely" to "not at all." The company hopes that this data will inform its ranking of news sources in its news feed. However, critics argue that this approach oversimplifies the complex issue of trust and may not accurately reflect users' perceptions of news sources.

The relationship between Facebook and the news media is complicated, with the social network generating significant ad revenue from news outlets and influencing the way people consume news. Facebook's efforts to combat misinformation and propaganda are well-intentioned, but the company's approach to trust is problematic.

The concept of trust is messy and difficult to define, as noted by political scientist Russell Hardin in his book "Trust and Trustworthiness." Trust is a three-part relationship between a person or institution, the action they are trusted to perform, and the outcome. Facebook's approach focuses on user familiarity and trust, but this may not accurately capture the nuances of trust.

Ultimately, the question is not whether Facebook can determine what news organizations people trust, but whether that is the right question to ask. The complexity of trust and the difficulty in defining it make it challenging to determine what constitutes a "trusted" news source.

Title: Holder Reflects on Legacy as He Prepares to Leave Office

Attorney General Eric Holder recently announced his resignation, and in a visit to Scranton, Pennsylvania, he reflected on his nearly 40-year career as a public corruption prosecutor, which began with a big trial win in the same city. Holder, who became the first African-American attorney general in 2009, has reached nearly every goal he set for himself, including becoming the U.S. attorney in Washington, D.C., and deputy attorney general in the Clinton administration.

During his tenure, Holder has been involved in several significant events, including the review of the death penalty, which he personally opposes. He has authorized several executions over the past five years, but his review will also examine the effectiveness of the death penalty as a deterrent and its impact on violent crime rates.

Holder also expressed regret over the lack of progress on gun safety measures following a visit to a crime scene in Newtown, Connecticut, where a gunman killed 20 children almost two years ago. He hopes to continue working on criminal justice and civil rights issues after his government service ends.

As he prepares to leave office, Holder has been reflecting on his legacy and the impact he has had on the country. He has been the head of the Justice Department for nearly five years, making him the third-longest-serving attorney general in U.S. history. Despite his impending departure, Holder is committed to continuing his work on criminal justice and civil rights issues, and hopes to find a way to bridge the gap between communities of color and law enforcement.

Title: Republican Presidential Field Takes Shape as Conservatives Eye 2016 Election

The 2016 presidential election cycle has begun, and with it, the excitement and speculation about the Republican candidates vying for the nomination. Matt Latimer, a former speechwriter for President George W. Bush, notes that this is a time when every Republican candidate promises to be the next Ronald Reagan, only to eventually dissolve into Gerald Ford. The Washington establishment often projects their own views onto the conservative grassroots, failing to understand the diverse opinions and preferences of Republican voters across America.

Conservatives have one thing to be thankful for: Hillary Clinton's 2008 defeat taught her valuable lessons, which she is repeating this time around. Her campaign is characterized by overconfidence, safe speeches, and a bloated staff that is already leaking to the press.

The Republican field is crowded, with 18-20 potential candidates considering a run. While some are people of quality and worth, others are running to build their brand and score book deals. The GOP field is so crowded that its first debate may have to be held on an aircraft carrier.

The article also pokes fun at the D.C. pundit class and their confident delusions about the Republican race. The author notes that no one has performed a better comeback in terms of public esteem than Mitt Romney, who is considering running for president again. However, the author believes that Romney's chances of winning are slim due to his past failures and the risks involved in running again.

The article concludes that there is no clear frontrunner in the GOP race, and that most D.C. reporters and pundits are mistaken in their predictions. The author suggests that the 2016 election may be a replay of the 1992 election, with Jeb Bush and Hillary Clinton facing off against each other once again.

Title: House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi Discusses Trump Impeachment and Special Counsel Mueller's Investigation

Article:

House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, in an interview on NBC's "Today" show, expressed her thoughts on the ongoing investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller and the possibility of President Trump being indicted. When asked if Mueller should honor and observe the Department of Justice's guidance that a sitting president cannot be indicted, Pelosi replied, "I do not think that that is conclusive. No, I do not."

Pelosi also emphasized the importance of lawmakers focusing on getting results for the American people, stating that "everything indicates that a president can be indicted after he is no longer president of the U.S." Her comments come as Mueller's investigation into Russia's interference in the 2016 presidential election and possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Moscow continues into 2019.

The investigation has led to scrutiny around the Justice Department's guidelines on indicting a sitting president. In December, Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen was sentenced to 36 months in prison for a series of crimes he committed while working as Trump's personal attorney. Prior to Cohen's sentencing, federal prosecutors in New York said in a memo that Trump directed Cohen to make illegal payments to two women, marking the first time prosecutors made those accusations against the president.

A recent poll found that a majority of Americans believe a sitting president should be subject to indictment. Seventy-one percent of respondents, including 49 percent of Republicans, said sitting presidents should be subject to indictment, while 21 percent said they shouldn't.

Title: Supreme Court Deadlocks on Obama's Immigration Policies, Leaving Programs in Limbo

The Supreme Court has dealt a significant blow to President Obama's immigration policies, issuing a 4-4 tie that leaves in place a lower court ruling blocking two controversial programs. The tied vote means that a program allowing undocumented immigrants who are parents of U.S. citizens or lawful permanent residents to remain in the United States for three years and apply for work permits remains blocked. Additionally, the administration's efforts to expand the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, issued by Obama in 2012, are also stalled.

The decision does not affect the original DACA program, which allows certain children who entered or stayed in the United States illegally to remain in the country and apply for work permits. However, it does prevent the administration from implementing new programs aimed at shielding more than 4 million undocumented immigrants from deportation and granting them work permits.

The Supreme Court's decision is the most prominent case to stall in a 4-4 tie, and it raises the stakes further in this fall's presidential election. The White House and Democrats in Congress have criticized the Senate's decision not to hold a hearing on President Obama's nomination of Merrick Garland to the Supreme Court, which has left the court with only eight justices.

In a statement, President Obama expressed disappointment over the lack of a decision, saying it "takes us further back from the country we want to be." Senator Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) blasted the GOP Senate majority for failing to consider Garland's nomination, saying it is "clear evidence we need nine justices on the court."

The decision does not affect the original DACA program, which allows certain children who entered or stayed in the United States illegally to remain in the country and apply for work permits. However, it does prevent the administration from implementing new programs aimed at shielding more than 4 million undocumented immigrants from deportation and granting them work permits.

The actual lawsuit filed by 26 Republican-led states is still working its way through the court system. The states claimed they would be burdened by having to spend more on public services like healthcare, law enforcement, and education if undocumented parents of both American citizens and legal permanent residents were allowed to stay in the country.

The Supreme Court's decision is the latest development in a long-standing debate over immigration policy, with President Obama's executive actions aimed at providing a path to citizenship for millions of people living in the country illegally. Immigrant rights activists have criticized Obama's record on deportations, while supporters argue that his actions are necessary to address the country's broken immigration system.

Title: US Designates Specific Groups and Individuals as Terrorists in Connection with 2012 Benghazi Attack

The US State Department has designated Ansar al-Sharia in Benghazi, Ansar al-Sharia in Darnah, and Ansar al-Sharia in Tunisia as terrorist organizations, citing their involvement in the 2012 Benghazi attack that killed four Americans. The department also labeled Sufian bin Qumu, head of the Darnah branch, and Ahmed Abu Khattalah, head of the Benghazi branch, as terrorists.

According to the State Department, Ansar al-Sharia in Benghazi and Ansar al-Sharia in Darnah have been involved in terrorist attacks against civilian targets, frequent assassinations, and attempted assassinations of security officials and political actors in eastern Libya. The department also cited the September 11, 2012 attacks against the US Special Mission and Annex in Benghazi, Libya.

The new designation bars anyone from providing or trying to provide material support or resources to these organizations and individuals, and freezes any assets they have in the US. The State Department has also updated its Rewards for Justice website to include a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the arrest or conviction of anyone involved in the Benghazi attack.

The designations come as the US government continues to investigate the 2012 attack, which was initially described as a spontaneous response to protests over an anti-Islam film. However, many lawmakers have disputed this explanation, claiming the attack was planned by terrorists. The State Department has since backed off the initial explanation, but has not ruled out the possibility that the film played some role in the attack.

The designations are seen as a significant step in holding those responsible for the attack accountable, and in disrupting the activities of these terrorist organizations.

Title: Fox News Analyst Says Hunter Biden's Work Overseas "Looks Bad" but Not Criminal

Article:

Fox News senior judicial analyst Andrew Napolitano has weighed in on the controversy surrounding Hunter Biden's work with a Chinese company, stating that while it "looks bad," it is not criminal. Napolitano made his comments on "Fox & Friends" early Tuesday.

According to Napolitano, the Chinese company's investment in an entity managed by Hunter Biden is a common business practice, similar to how the Chinese operate. He noted that the company did not put a billion dollars in Biden's pocket, but rather invested in the entity he was managing.

Hunter Biden, the son of former Vice President Joe Biden, announced earlier this week that he would be stepping down from the board of the Chinese company. He also stated that he would not engage in any foreign work if his father is elected president in 2020.

In an interview with ABC News, Hunter Biden acknowledged that he made a mistake by getting involved with foreign companies, which allowed critics to attack his father over alleged conflicts of interest. He took responsibility for his actions, stating that he gave a "hook" to unethical people to act illegally and harm his father.

Joe Biden, the Democratic presidential candidate, has denied any wrongdoing and has not conducted any sit-down interviews with national broadcast media outlets since President Trump began attacking the Bidens last month. There is no evidence of any criminal wrongdoing by either the Bidens.

The controversy surrounding Hunter Biden's work has been fueled by Trump and Republicans, who have accused him of profiting off his father's office and claiming the former vice president is corrupt. The House Democrats launched an impeachment inquiry into Trump last month after revelations emerged that he pressured Ukraine's president to investigate the Bidens.

Title: Fox News' Role in the Immigration Debate: A Wild Card Factor

Fox News Channel is poised to play a crucial role in the ongoing debate over a path to citizenship for the nation's 11 million undocumented immigrants. As the most-watched cable news network, Fox's stance on the issue could significantly impact the national conversation. Rupert Murdoch, the chairman and CEO of News Corp, Fox's parent company, has become an outspoken advocate for immigration reform and mass legalization. However, his personal views may not necessarily trickle down to the network's programming.

Fox News has been a crucial platform for critics of the proposed comprehensive reform plan, with some attributing the network's influence to the failure of a similar legislative push in 2006 and 2007. However, immigrant advocates believe Fox could emerge as a potential ally in the battle for public opinion on immigration. Some notable Fox personalities, such as Sean Hannity, Bill O'Reilly, and Charles Krauthammer, have expressed support for immigration reform.

Rupert Murdoch's personal views on the issue may not necessarily dictate the network's stance, as he has stated that Fox is a platform for all views, not just his own. However, his influence as a businessman may also play a role in shaping the network's coverage. The network's primetime viewership has been declining in recent months, but it remains a highly-profitable network with a large news audience.

While some critics believe Fox's influence could be decisive in the immigration debate, others argue that the network's role is overstated and that the diversity and bipartisanship of advocates for a reform plan will ultimately prevail. The National Immigration Forum's executive director, Ali Noorani, notes that Fox having a range of conservative speakers on the issue, such as Sen. Marco Rubio, can help move the country forward with a broad immigration reform.

Title: Florida's Intensive-Care Units Reach Capacity as Coronavirus Cases Surge Across the State

Florida's intensive-care units (ICUs) are at capacity, with at least 56 hospitals reporting they have run out of beds for coronavirus patients, and 35 more warning that their bed availability has dropped to 10% or lower. This comes as the state recorded over 7,300 new coronavirus cases, 380 new hospitalizations, and 63 more deaths from the infection.

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis stated that the death rate in the state has begun to taper off, noting that most of the new cases are among younger patients. He emphasized that the state is prepared to handle the surge in cases, citing a decrease in hospitalizations from nursing homes, which is a positive sign.

Other states have also seen a surge in coronavirus cases after reopening their economies. Georgia surpassed 100,000 positive cases on Tuesday, making it the ninth state to reach this milestone. California recorded a record daily increase of over 10,200 new cases, along with a record 6,000 hospitalized patients. Some Texas counties have warned that their hospital ICUs will run out of beds over the next two weeks.

Dr. Anthony Fauci, chief medical adviser for the Trump administration's coronavirus task force, noted that the death rate from the virus has decreased, but warned against "false complacency" as the pathogen continues to spread. He emphasized that while the death rate is lower due to younger patients being infected, it does not mean that people cannot get seriously ill.

The United States has recorded over three million positive cases of coronavirus, and 131,200 people have died after being infected.

Title: US Judge Rules Trump Exceeded Authority in Reversing Offshore Drilling Bans

A US District Court judge has ruled that President Trump exceeded his authority when he reversed bans on offshore drilling in the Arctic Ocean and Atlantic Ocean, restoring the Obama-era restrictions. Judge Sharon Gleason, who was nominated by President Obama, stated that the wording of the 2015 and 2016 withdrawals indicates that they were intended to extend indefinitely and can only be revoked by an act of Congress.

The ruling comes after the Trump administration's executive order in 2017 reversed the drilling bans, which were put in place by President Obama to protect polar bears, walruses, ice seals, and Alaska Native villages that depend on these animals. The bans also aimed to preserve the Arctic Ocean and Atlantic Ocean's ecosystems, including marine mammals, deep-water corals, and valuable fish populations.

The American Petroleum Institute, a defendant in the case, disagreed with the ruling, stating that developing offshore resources can provide billions in government revenue, create thousands of jobs, and strengthen national security. However, environmental groups, represented by Earthjustice, welcomed the ruling, saying it shows that the president cannot "trample on the Constitution" to benefit the fossil fuel industry at the expense of the oceans, wildlife, and climate.

The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, written in 1953, was at the center of the case. Acting Assistant U.S. Attorney General Jeffrey Wood argued during a hearing that environmental groups were misinterpreting the intent of the law, which is meant to be flexible and sensible, and not intended to bind one president with decisions made by another.

In 2015, Obama halted exploration in coastal areas of the Beaufort and Chukchi seas and the Hanna Shoal, an important area for walruses. In late 2016, he withdrew most other potential Arctic Ocean lease areas, about 98% of the Arctic outer continental shelf. The bans were intended to protect polar bears, walruses, ice seals, and Alaska Native villages that depend on these animals.

Title: Merkel to Meet Obama at White House Amid Ukraine Crisis and NSA Spying Concerns

German Chancellor Angela Merkel will visit the White House on Friday for lunch and several hours of talks with President Barack Obama, amidst ongoing tensions over the Ukraine crisis and lingering concerns about the National Security Agency's (NSA) spying on German leaders, including Merkel herself.

The crisis in Ukraine, which has been a major point of contention between the US and Russia, is expected to dominate the agenda of the meeting. Merkel, who has a close personal relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin and has strong economic ties to Russia, is likely to advocate for a cautious and step-by-step approach to Russian aggression in Ukraine. However, she may also encourage Obama to prioritize transatlantic unity and coordination over unilateral action.

The meeting comes as the US and Europe are seeking to address the crisis in Ukraine, which has led to the annexation of Crimea and a campaign of destabilization in eastern Ukraine. The two leaders will also discuss the upcoming national elections in Ukraine, scheduled for May 25, and the need to ensure a legitimate and authoritative national government.

In addition to the Ukraine crisis, the meeting will also touch on the issue of NSA spying on German leaders, including Merkel. While Merkel has expressed disappointment and frustration over the revelations, she is not expected to demand a "no-spy" accord with the US, as some had speculated. Instead, she will likely focus on rebuilding trust and cooperation with the US.

The meeting is seen as an opportunity for Obama to enlist Germany's support in addressing the Ukraine crisis and to demonstrate the strength of the transatlantic partnership. German experts note that Merkel's firm stance on the crisis has been a surprise to some, and her leadership role in Europe makes her words carry significant weight in the region.

Title: Holder's Education Agenda: A Threat to the Education of Poor and Minority Children
