The article discusses the alleged attempts by Attorney General Eric Holder to suppress charter schools in Louisiana and his nationwide threats of legal action against schools that discipline more black students than he believes they should. The author argues that these actions are part of a broader pattern of prioritizing the interests of teachers' unions over the education of poor and minority children.

The article highlights the success of charter schools, particularly those that serve minority students, and notes that these schools are often targeted by the educational establishment and teachers' unions. The author cites the example of the American Indian Model Schools in Oakland, California, which were shut down despite being ranked among the top schools in the nation.

The article also criticizes Holder's threats of legal action against schools that discipline more black students, arguing that these actions are based on racial statistics rather than a nuanced understanding of the complex issues involved. The author notes that relying on racial statistics can be misleading and ignores the individual experiences of students and teachers.

The article concludes by suggesting that Holder's actions are motivated by political considerations, specifically the desire to energize the black vote for Democrats. The author argues that sacrificing the education of children, particularly those from low-income backgrounds, is a new low and a betrayal of the trust placed in Holder as Attorney General.

Overall, the article presents a critical view of Holder's education agenda and its potential impact on the education of poor and minority children.

Title: Media Feud Erupts Over Unverified Allegations Against Trump

The recent publication of unverified allegations against President-elect Donald Trump by BuzzFeed and CNN has sparked a heated debate about the role of journalism in the digital age. The controversy began when BuzzFeed published a report claiming that Russian operatives had compromising information about Trump, which was allegedly shared with President-elect Trump and President Barack Obama. The report was based on a 35-page dossier compiled by a former British intelligence officer, which contained unverified claims about Trump's alleged ties to Russia.

The publication of the report has been widely criticized by Trump and his team, who have called it "fake news" and "garbage." Trump himself has accused BuzzFeed of being a "failing piece of garbage" and vowed to "suffer the consequences" of its actions. The White House has also denied the allegations, with Press Secretary Sean Spicer calling the report "frankly outrageous" and "highly irresponsible."

BuzzFeed's Editor-in-Chief Ben Smith has defended the publication, stating that it is the media's job to report on allegations, even if they are unverified. However, many journalists and media outlets have criticized BuzzFeed for publishing the report without verifying the claims, which they say is a departure from traditional journalistic standards.

The controversy has also highlighted the challenges of reporting on unverified information in the digital age. With the rise of social media and 24-hour news cycles, the pressure to break news and be the first to report on a story can sometimes lead to a rush to publish without proper verification. This can result in the spread of misinformation and the erosion of trust between the public and the media.

In the end, the controversy serves as a reminder of the importance of responsible journalism and the need for media outlets to prioritize accuracy and verification in their reporting.

Title: Former House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert Indicted for Alleged Currency Law Violations and Lying to the FBI

A federal grand jury has indicted former House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert on charges of attempting to circumvent currency laws and lying to the FBI. The indictment alleges that Hastert, 73, agreed to pay $3.5 million to "compensate for and conceal" his past behavior against an individual identified as "Individual A," who knew Hastert from his time as a high school coach and teacher.

According to the indictment, Hastert and Individual A met at prearranged times and locations every six weeks, with Hastert turning over $50,000 each time. However, when investigators became involved, Hastert began making smaller withdrawals of less than $10,000, which is banned by federal currency transparency laws. The indictment states that Hastert lied to the FBI about the withdrawals, claiming he was keeping the cash.

The investigation found that Hastert withdrew approximately $1.7 million in cash from various bank accounts and provided it to Individual A between 2010 and 2014. The indictment also alleges that Hastert structured his cash withdrawals in increments of less than $10,000 to evade the filing of Currency Transaction Reports.

Hastert served as House Speaker from 1999 to 2007, notching the longest tenure of any Republican speaker in history. He resigned from his position as head of the lobbying arm of Dickstein Shapiro LLP on Thursday. Hastert has not responded to an email request for comment.

The indictment does not specify the nature of Hastert's alleged misconduct against Individual A, but the document suggests that the two knew each other from Hastert's time as a high school teacher and wrestling coach in Yorkville, Illinois. The indictment states that Individual A is a resident of the same town and has known Hastert most of his life.

Hastert's case was pursued by the FBI and the IRS Criminal Investigation Division. He has turned over about $1.7 million of the $3.5 million he agreed to pay to Individual A, with $952,000 taken out in increments of less than $10,000, which investigators said was done in violation of the currency law.

Title: DOJ Investigates Intentional Discrimination in College Admissions

The Department of Justice (DOJ) has launched an investigation into intentional race-based discrimination in college and university admissions, as reported by The New York Times. The investigation aims to enforce the law and protect the rights of all students, regardless of their race or ethnicity.

The investigation follows complaints filed by Asian-American groups against elite American colleges, alleging discrimination and quotas in the admissions process. The complaints presented evidence of a stunning level of race-based discrimination, with Asian-American students facing higher academic standards and lower acceptance rates compared to other racial groups.

For example, the complaints showed that Asian-American students had to score 140 points higher than white students, 270 points higher than Hispanic students, and 450 points higher than black students to gain admission to college. This discrimination has caused harm to Asian-American students, including stress, mental health issues, and a lack of trust in American institutions.

The investigation also highlights the need to address the legacy of discrimination against Asian-American students, who have faced discrimination and quotas in the past. The 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color, and national origin in federally funded educational institutions.

The investigation is a step in the right direction to ensure that all students have equal access to higher education, regardless of their race or ethnicity. It is essential to enforce the law and protect the rights of all students, including Asian-American students who have faced discrimination and quotas in the past.

Title: Mueller Rejects Claim That Flynn Was Tricked into Lying to FBI

Article:

Robert Mueller, the special counsel, has rejected the notion that former Trump administration national security adviser Michael Flynn was tricked into lying to the FBI during an interview in January 2017. The interview, which took place just days after President Donald Trump's inauguration, was voluntary and lacked any indicia of coercion, according to court documents.

Flynn's attorneys had suggested earlier this week that the FBI duped the former national security adviser by not warning him about the criminal consequences of lying to agents during the interview. However, Mueller's prosecutors countered that Flynn, as a sitting national security adviser, former head of an intelligence agency, retired lieutenant general, and 33-year veteran of the armed forces, knew he should not lie to federal agents.

The new filings come ahead of Flynn's December 18 sentencing, where prosecutors have recommended no prison time for the former Trump administration official, citing his substantial cooperation in the ongoing Russia investigation. Flynn's attorneys have also asked that he be spared prison time.

The FBI interview was arranged by then-Deputy FBI Director Andrew McCabe, who was subsequently fired for unauthorized disclosures to reporters. The primary interviewing agent was Peter Strzok, a senior counterintelligence official who was later dismissed for making disparaging comments about candidate Donald Trump in text messages exchanged with an FBI lawyer who was Strzok's girlfriend.

According to court documents, Flynn did not back away from accepting responsibility for his actions, even when circumstances later came to light that prompted extensive public debate about the investigation. Mueller's prosecutors noted that Flynn had lied about his discussions with Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak to reporters, Vice President Mike Pence, and members of the president's transition team in the weeks before the FBI interview.

During the interview, Flynn appeared "unguarded and clearly saw the FBI agents as allies," according to FBI notes. Flynn was so talkative that Strzok wondered if the national security adviser had more important things to do than have a relaxed, non-pertinent discussion with them. Throughout the interview, Flynn had a "very sure" demeanor and did not give any indicators of deception, according to Strzok's recollection.

Despite questions raised about FBI tactics, prosecutors continued to support leniency for the former administration officer, who will be the first former White House official to be sentenced in Mueller's continuing inquiry.

Title: US to Deliver F-16 Fighter Jets to Egypt Amid Concerns Over New President's Allegiances

The United States is set to deliver four F-16 fighter jets to Egypt's air force, with the first batch expected to arrive on January 22. The $213 million deal was signed in 2010, during the presidency of Hosni Mubarak, but has raised concerns on Capitol Hill due to the uncertain allegiances of Egypt's new leader, Mohamed Morsi.

Morsi, who is backed by the Muslim Brotherhood, has been criticized for attempting to seize dictatorial powers and allegedly using thugs and rapists to intimidate protesters. Florida Representative Vern Buchanan has called for ending foreign aid to Egypt altogether, stating that American tax dollars should not be used to aid a dictatorial regime.

Representative Mac Thornberry, vice chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, expressed caution about the delivery, saying that the US should be careful about the arms it provides to Egypt, given the uncertainty surrounding its direction. Thornberry noted that Egypt is a "wild card" under Morsi's leadership.

The F-16s are part of a larger package of military aid approved by lawmakers in Washington. The planes are considered a significant upgrade for Egypt's air force, which already has over 200 F-16s. The jets are equipped with advanced electronics and have a range of over 500 miles, making them a valuable asset for Egypt's military.

A Pentagon spokesman emphasized the importance of the US-Egypt defense relationship, stating that the transfer of the F-16s reflects the US commitment to supporting Egypt's military modernization efforts. The delivery is expected to increase interoperability between the two militaries and enhance Egypt's capacity to contribute to regional mission sets.

However, some analysts have raised concerns about the potential risks of the deal. Malou Innocent, a foreign policy analyst at the Cato Institute, warned that Egypt's murky intentions could lead to a scenario where the US finds itself supplying military hardware to both Egypt and Israel in the event of a conflict. Given the US's fiscal woes, Innocent believes that American taxpayers should no longer be Egypt's major arms supplier.

**BBC's Former Director General Mark Thompson Explains Knowledge of Jimmy Savile Abuse Allegations**

Mark Thompson, the former director general of the BBC, has written a letter to a British lawmaker attempting to clarify what he knew about a journalistic investigation into claims of abuse by Jimmy Savile, a late children's TV presenter. The letter comes as the BBC faces intense scrutiny over its handling of allegations against Savile, a household name in Britain.

Thompson, who was director general of the BBC at the time of the "Newsnight" investigation, initially stated that he was not notified or briefed about the investigation and was not involved in the decision to drop it. However, an account published in The New York Times quoted Thompson as saying that a BBC reporter told him about the investigation at a party in December.

In his letter, Thompson explained that he learned of the investigation but not its details and was satisfied when he inquired to his senior management and was told that it had been dropped for journalistic reasons. He stated that he was never formally notified about the "Newsnight" investigation and was not briefed about the allegations they were examining.

The scandal has sparked widespread criticism and questions about who knew what and when about the alleged abuse of young teenage girls. The BBC has faced intense scrutiny over its handling of the allegations, with many questioning why the "Newsnight" investigation was dropped.

The scandal has also raised questions about the culture of the BBC during Savile's time, with some suggesting that a culture of sexism and abuse may have contributed to the allegations. The BBC has launched an internal investigation into the matter, and the Metropolitan Police have launched a criminal investigation into claims of child sexual abuse by Savile and others.

Thompson is set to take over as the incoming chief executive of The New York Times, but the scandal has raised questions about his integrity and decision-making. The public editor of The New York Times, Margaret Sullivan, has written that the scandal is a concern for the company and that it is worth considering whether Thompson is the right person for the job.

Title: Colin Kaepernick Announces Memoir and Publishing Company, Discusses Activism and NFL Career

Colin Kaepernick, the former San Francisco 49ers quarterback, has given a rare interview to USA Today and announced the release of his memoir under his own publishing company, Kaepernick Publishing, in partnership with Amazon-owned Audible. The still-untitled book is described as "part political awakening and part memoir," detailing the life experiences that led him to protest police brutality and social injustice by kneeling during the national anthem at NFL games.

In the interview, Kaepernick discussed his decision to share his story and give insight into his experiences. He stated, "I've had a lot of questions surrounding what got me to the point of protesting, which led me to wanting to share that story and give insight." He also emphasized the importance of controlling the narrative and giving power to marginalized voices, stating, "I learned early on that in fighting against systematic oppression, dehumanization, and colonization, who controls the narrative shapes the reality of how the world views society."

Kaepernick Publishing aims to promote writers of color and offer unprecedented ownership options to collaborators, bringing greater diversity and representation to literature and spoken word. The company's mission is to empower black and brown voices globally and give them control over their stories.

Kaepernick's activism extends beyond his football career, as he has created the Know Your Rights Camp, which hosts camps to raise awareness on higher education, self-empowerment, and instructions on how to properly interact with law enforcement. He has also signed an endorsement contract with Nike and released a viral commercial and the "True to 7" Kaepernick-branded version of the Air Force 1 sneaker.

Despite being unemployed and unsigned by any NFL team since 2017, Kaepernick still trains five days a week and is ready to return to the field. He expressed his desire to play football again, stating, "My desire to play football is still there. I'm ready to go, I'm ready for a phone call, tryout, workout at any point in time."

Title: Louisville Police Officer Fired for Role in Breonna Taylor's Death

The Louisville Metro Police Department has terminated Officer Brett Hankison, one of the officers involved in the March shooting death of 26-year-old emergency medical worker Breonna Taylor. In a letter to Hankison, Police Chief Robert Schroeder described his conduct as a "shock to the conscience" and stated that he had violated two standard operating procedures: obedience to rules and regulations and use of deadly force.

According to the letter, Hankison fired 10 rounds into Taylor's apartment, creating a substantial danger of death and serious injury to Taylor and the three occupants of the apartment next door. Schroeder noted that Hankison's actions were not justified, as there was no immediate threat or danger posed by Taylor or her boyfriend, Kenneth Walker, who was a licensed gun owner.

The letter also stated that three of the rounds fired by Hankison entered the apartment next door, endangering the lives of three people. Schroeder concluded that Hankison's conduct was extreme and unacceptable, bringing discredit to himself and the department. He deemed Hankison's actions to be a "shock to the conscience" and stated that he could not tolerate such conduct from any member of the Louisville Metro Police Department.

The three officers involved in the shooting, including Hankison, Jon Mattingly, and Myles Cosgrove, had been placed on administrative reassignment throughout the investigation. Despite widespread protests and calls for arrests, none of the officers have been charged in connection with Taylor's death.

Title: Fact-Checking Efforts in the Election Cycle: A Growing Industry with Limited Impact

The fact-checking process has become a crucial aspect of the election cycle, with experts and reporters working tirelessly to verify the accuracy of political claims. However, despite the efforts of fact-checkers, it appears that politicians continue to stretch the truth and fabricate facts with little consequence. The question remains: why is there no penalty for lying in politics?

One of the primary challenges faced by fact-checkers is the public's general distrust of politicians and government. Since the 1970s, trust in government has steadily declined, and the public has become accustomed to politicians not telling the truth. This skepticism makes it difficult for fact-checkers to gain traction and make a significant impact.

Another hurdle is the increasingly partisan media environment. The weakening of norms of objectivity in many news outlets and the rise of openly partisan reporting have led to a situation where Americans often rely on sources that confirm their existing beliefs. This makes it challenging for objective fact-checkers to break through the noise and be heard.

The proliferation of partisan fact-checkers has also created confusion among the public. Political parties and organizations have established their own fact-checking operations, which often serve to attack their opponents' credibility. This has led to a situation where it is difficult for people to distinguish between partisan and genuine fact-checkers.

The fact-checking process has become a crucial aspect of the election cycle, with experts and reporters working tirelessly to verify the accuracy of political claims. However, despite these efforts, it appears that politicians continue to stretch the truth and fabricate facts with little consequence. The question remains: why is there no penalty for lying in politics?

Title: House Committee Votes to Subpoena Former Trump Official Over Security Clearance Concerns

The House Committee on Oversight and Reform has voted to subpoena Carl Kline, the former personnel security director for the Trump administration, to discuss how the White House granted security clearances to individuals despite issues with their background checks. The move comes after a whistleblower, Tricia Newbold, testified that she and colleagues denied security clearances to about 25 applicants, but saw those decisions overturned by higher-ups in the Trump administration.

The subpoena is based on Newbold's testimony, which revealed that some applicants had ties to foreign influence, conflicts of interest, questionable or criminal conduct, financial problems, and drug abuse. The 25 applicants may include President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner, who was granted a top-secret security clearance despite concerns from officials.

The White House has rejected requests for information about clearances for Kushner, his spouse Ivanka Trump, and national security adviser John Bolton, citing privacy and saying Congress does not have the authority to see these documents. The administration has also refused to provide information about the clearance process, sparking concerns about the potential risks to national security.

The House Committee on Oversight and Reform is seeking information about the clearance process and the individuals granted access to sensitive information. The committee has not identified the 25 applicants recommended for rejection, but has asked the White House to provide information about clearances for Kushner, Ivanka Trump, and Bolton.

The White House has rejected the document requests, citing privacy and saying Congress does not have the authority to see these documents. The administration has also indicated it may fight subpoenas.

The House Committee on Oversight and Reform is one of several committees investigating the Trump administration. The House Judiciary Committee is planning to authorize a subpoena for special counsel Robert Mueller's full report and the evidence his investigators gathered, setting up what could be a historic legal clash with the Justice Department.

Title: Dozens of U.S. Diplomats Call for Military Pressure on Syria's Assad Regime

A group of over 50 U.S. State Department officials have signed an internal memo calling for a change in the U.S. approach to Syria, specifically advocating for military pressure on the Bashar Assad regime to push it towards negotiations. The diplomats expressed their opposition to the current U.S. policy through a cable on the State Department's dissent channel, which is designed for officials to share their dissenting views on foreign policy issues.

According to reports, the cable calls for targeted military strikes against the Assad regime, a move that would put the U.S. on a collision course with Russia, which is backing the regime. However, the diplomats argue that a credible military threat is necessary to pressure Assad to negotiate and end the humanitarian crisis in Syria.

The American Foreign Service Association, which represents active and retired Foreign Service members, praised the diplomats for their "intellectual courage" in expressing their dissent. The organization emphasized the importance of a professional environment that values candor and debate, even when the stakes are high.

The dissent channel, established in 1971, allows State Department officials to share their dissenting views directly with the top of the chain of command. While it is unusual for so many officials to sign on to a single cable, the channel has been used by diplomats to express their concerns on various issues, including the war in Iraq in 2004.

The cable's authors argue that the moral rationale for taking action to end the suffering in Syria is evident and unquestionable, and that the status quo will continue to present dire humanitarian, diplomatic, and terrorism-related challenges. The U.S. Secretary of State, John Kerry, has stated that he respects the process and will study the views expressed in the cable.

Title: Trump's Pardons Raise Concerns About Corruption and Abuse of Power

The recent pardons granted by President Trump to several individuals with personal connections to him have raised concerns about the potential impact on efforts to combat corruption and the abuse of power. The pardons, which included those for former Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich, financier Michael Milken, and former New York City Police Commissioner Bernard Kerik, have been criticized for being "whimsical" and "self-serving" rather than based on a principled exercise of the pardon power.

The pardons have been seen as a way for Trump to reward his supporters and score political points, rather than being used to promote justice and fairness. The fact that all of the individuals granted clemency have some personal connection to the President has raised concerns about the potential for corruption and the erosion of the rule of law.

Trump's exercise of the pardon power has been criticized for being "transactional," with some arguing that it is being used to reward friends and supporters rather than being based on a principled consideration of the facts and circumstances of each case. This has raised concerns about the potential for abuse of power and the erosion of the rule of law.

In contrast, Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi has been praised for her ability to whip up votes in her caucus and discipline dissenters, as well as her ability to offer incentives and punishments to get Democratic members of Congress to do what she wants them to do. Her recent speech ripping up the State of the Union address has been seen as a ploy designed to get attention and has worked, with many people talking about her rather than the President.

Overall, the pardons granted by President Trump have raised concerns about the potential for corruption and abuse of power, and have been seen as a way for him to reward his supporters and score political points rather than being used to promote justice and fairness.

Title: Millennials Flock to Libertarian Candidate Gary Johnson, Leaving Hillary Clinton Underperforming

Article:

A recent series of polls has revealed that Libertarian presidential nominee Gary Johnson is gaining significant support among millennials, while Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton is underperforming with the same demographic that helped President Obama build winning coalitions in 2008 and 2012. According to a New York Times/CBS poll, 26% of voters under the age of 29 support Johnson, with 10% backing Green presidential nominee Jill Stein. A Quinnipiac poll shows Johnson at 29% among young voters, with Stein at 15%. In the same poll, Clinton barely edges out Johnson among young voters, receiving 31% support.

The results have sparked concern among older liberals, who feel that the vote of millennials belongs to them. However, many millennials are embracing Johnson's libertarian views, which align with their own beliefs on limited government and personal freedom. A 2014 poll found that 66% of millennials believed government was wasteful and inefficient, yet many still planned to vote Democrat.

The decline in support for Democrats is unsurprising, given that the party's rhetoric does not match the reality on the ground. Many millennials are skeptical of authority and give the government the "side eye," making it difficult for Clinton to connect with them. The option of a third-party vote is also being skewered online, mostly by establishment liberals who have come to represent poor policy-making and a lack of accountability.

Johnson's refusal to play political games and his willingness to take a stand on issues, even if it means being mocked by the media establishment, likely ingratiates him to millennials who see both Trump and Clinton as products of a corrupt political system. The Libertarian Party's decision to nominate socially tolerant and fiscally responsible candidates aligns with the values of many millennials, who are used to disrupting industries and driving change.

The persistence of never-Trump Republicans and the refusal of Obama and Clinton to smear the principles of limited government, freedom, and Constitutionalism with Trumpism means that millennials have the chance to catapult the Libertarian party into major party status, if not through this election cycle alone, almost certainly in cycles to come. As the old establishment partisan order slowly but surely comes to an end, both millennials and Libertarians can expect smears and attacks to become more vociferous and detached from reality.

Title: Presidential Candidates Take Different Approaches to Addressing Unrest and Police Violence

The ongoing protests and demonstrations across the United States, sparked by the killing of George Floyd, have become a central issue in the upcoming presidential election. The two candidates, President Donald Trump and presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden, have taken distinct approaches to addressing the unrest and police violence.

President Trump has repeatedly called for authorities to "dominate" demonstrators, suggesting the deployment of the U.S. military in American cities. He has also emphasized his commitment to "law and order," echoing the message of his predecessor, Richard Nixon, who won the 1968 election amidst widespread unrest and chaos. Trump's approach has been met with skepticism by some analysts, who argue that his own presidency has contributed to the divisions and chaos he is now trying to capitalize on.

In contrast, Biden has taken a more unifying tone, speaking out about the need to address "systemic racism" in the country. He has visited protests in several cities and met privately with Floyd's family, emphasizing the need for empathy and understanding. Biden's approach has been praised by some as a more effective way to address the complex issues of police violence and racial inequality.

The 1968 election, which took place during a tumultuous period in American history, saw Nixon's emphasis on "law and order" help him win the presidency. Trump's campaign is attempting to capitalize on this message, drawing attention away from the administration's response to the coronavirus pandemic, which voters largely see as a failure. However, some analysts argue that Trump's own presidency has made it difficult for him to effectively make the case for a return to normalcy.

It remains to be seen how the ongoing unrest will affect voters come November, but early polling suggests that Trump's response is hurting, rather than helping. The debate over police violence and civil unrest is likely to continue, with both candidates taking different approaches to address the complex issues.

Title: Trump's Speechwriting Team Aims for a More Inclusive Tone

The White House is preparing for a speech by President Trump, with officials describing it as "optimistic" and aiming for a more inclusive tone. The speech is being written by a team led by speechwriters, including Jason Miller, Vince Haley, and Rob Porter, who are coordinating input from various government departments. The goal is to present a positive message that can resonate with a wide range of Americans.

According to Newt Gingrich, a former Republican House speaker who has advised Trump, the president is shifting his approach, focusing on promoting the economy and his tax plan without using combative language that might detract from his message. "They're moving a little bit from 'Trump the fighter' to 'Trump the winner,'" Gingrich said.

While some of Trump's advisors may prefer a darker and more strident tone, White House officials are aiming for a more inclusive speech in tone, if not in substance. The speech is expected to be judged on whether Trump can deliver a coherent and on-message speech, resisting the urge to respond to perceived slights or settle scores.

The president's speechwriting team is aware of Trump's tendency to deviate from his script and insert divisive comments, and is working to ensure that he stays on track. The goal is to present a positive message that can appeal to a broad audience, including those who may not be part of Trump's base.

The speech is seen as important for Trump's political future, with the midterm elections in November and his own re-election bid in 2020. Corey Stewart, a Tea Party Trump supporter and Senate candidate from Virginia, believes that Trump will need to expand his appeal beyond his base to win over new voters.

Title: Historical Insights into Political Polarization in the United States

Article:

The United States has a long history of political polarization, with divisions and intense feelings of distrust between opposing parties. This phenomenon is not new, dating back to the country's founding and even the American Revolution. In the 1790s, the Federalists and Democratic-Republicans clashed over the French Revolution and domestic policy, with some fearing the country might not survive into the 19th century.

During the American Revolution, the colonists were divided over independence, with some supporting the cause and others remaining loyal to Britain. The war was not only a struggle against Britain but also a civil war, dividing colonists who supported independence from those who did not. This division led to the execution of Moses Dunbar, a Connecticut farmer who was accused of being a loyalist and executed in 1777.

Dunbar's story serves as a vivid example of how fear and suspicion can lead people to question the motives of their adversaries and even contemplate violence against them. His case also highlights the dangers of extreme partisanship, which can drive people to question the motives of their opponents and even contemplate violence against them.

After the war, many loyalists fled the United States, but many more stayed, including those who had been mischaracterized by their opponents. Dunbar's descendants remained in the new nation, and some continued to live among the very people who had harassed and betrayed him. Although they never recorded their reasons for doing so, former adversaries likely made a decision to cease making enemies of their neighbors, focusing instead on what they had in common.

The story of Moses Dunbar serves as a reminder that political polarization is not a new phenomenon in the United States, and that even in the most trying times, there is always a chance for healing and reconciliation.

Title: Obama Vows to Pursue Closure of Guantanamo Bay Detention Facility

President Barack Obama has reiterated his commitment to closing the Guantanamo Bay detention facility in Cuba, a promise he made during his 2008 campaign. Despite facing opposition on Capitol Hill, Obama expressed his determination to fulfill this goal during his remaining two years in office.

In an interview with CNN's Candy Crowley, Obama stated, "I'm going to be doing everything I can to close it." He emphasized that the facility's continued operation is contrary to American values and inspires jihadists and extremists worldwide. The President has already transferred many detainees to other countries and plans to continue doing so, as Congress has prohibited him from transferring them to federal Supermax facilities within the United States.

However, Obama acknowledged that dealing with "really hard cases" remains a significant challenge. These cases involve individuals who have been deemed dangerous and have committed wrongdoing. Despite this hurdle, Obama remains committed to shutting down the facility, citing the financial burden and inconsistency with American values.

The President's comments come after a flurry of executive actions, including an overhaul of U.S. immigration rules and new regulations aimed at reducing environmentally-harmful emissions. His recent deal with Cuba represents the biggest steps towards thawing the economic freeze between the two nations in decades.

Title: The Annoying Voice in Our Heads: Navigating Gender Expectations in the Workplace

The article discusses the challenges women face in the workplace, particularly when it comes to balancing their ambition and femininity. The author shares their personal experience of having an inner critical voice that constantly criticizes their behavior, telling them they are either too feminine or not feminine enough. This voice is impossible to satisfy, and the author has learned to live with it.

The article highlights the dilemma women face when trying to be ambitious and successful, as these traits are not traditionally associated with femininity. The author notes that embracing traditional gender roles can lead to being perceived as lacking leadership skills and strength, while embracing ambition and power can lead to being seen as unlikable and unrelatable.

The article also references Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign as an example of a world where women no longer have to navigate these gender expectations. The author notes that Clinton's campaign has inspired ridiculous gendered demands and critiques, which can be exhausting and demoralizing.

The article also critiques a recent column by Maureen Dowd in The New York Times, which criticized Hillary Clinton for not being feminine enough. The author argues that Dowd's column is ridiculous and absurd, as it suggests that Clinton needs to find a "more authentic way to campaign as a woman" and that she is too masculine or too feminine.

The article concludes by noting that this system is rigged and that there is no way to win, especially for those who have never been spoofed on late-night television. The author suggests that having a handy retort to the annoying voice in our heads can be a relief, and that if Hillary Clinton is what failure looks like, then sign them up.

Title: Supreme Court's Decision on Healthcare Subsidies May Hinge on John Roberts' Political Calculations

The Supreme Court's upcoming decision on subsidies for health plans on federally facilitated health insurance exchanges has sparked concerns about the potential consequences of a ruling against the government. According to Supreme Court columnist Linda Greenhouse, rejecting the government's defense of the law would require the conservative justices to suspend their own approach to statutory interpretation and their views on Congress's relationship with states. If they were to do so, they would have to explain their decision to history.

The decision likely rests with Chief Justice John Roberts, who has a history of considering political implications in his decisions. In 2012, he upheld the individual mandate, but only on the grounds of taxation and not the Commerce Clause, which was seen as a compromise. This time around, Roberts may be weighing the potential consequences of a ruling against the government, including the potential chaos it could cause in the country's healthcare system.

The White House is aware of Roberts' concerns and is likely to emphasize the potential consequences of a ruling against the government. Republicans, on the other hand, are pushing for a ruling that would eliminate subsidies for insurance plans bought on federally facilitated exchanges, which could be seen as a way to gut the Affordable Care Act.

During a recent Senate Finance Committee hearing, Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Mathews Burwell was pressed for details on the administration's backup plan in the event of a ruling against the government. Burwell dodged the question, saying her focus is on meeting targets for the open enrollment period. Some former Bush administration officials have suggested that the administration is keeping its plans close to the chest to avoid signaling "weakness" to Roberts.

The GOP, meanwhile, is pushing for an "alternative" to Obamacare, which could be seen as a way to show Roberts that they have a plan in place. While it's impossible to predict how Roberts will decide, it's clear that the political implications of the case will play a significant role in his decision-making process.

Title: Obama's Hiroshima Visit Highlights Nuclear Proliferation Concerns in Asia

President Barack Obama's upcoming trip to Asia will include a stop in Hiroshima, where he will focus on the city's dark nuclear past. However, his visit comes at a time when U.S. and Asian officials are concerned about the region entering a newly dangerous atomic future. North Korea is expanding its nuclear arsenal and upgrading its ballistic missiles, while China is growing and modernizing its stockpile. Japan and South Korea are also considering developing their own nuclear arms, driven by concerns about the reliability of the U.S. nuclear umbrella.

The visit is a stark contrast to the views of President Donald Trump, who recently questioned Japan's nuclear-weapons-free policy. Trump suggested that Japan and South Korea might need to develop their own nuclear weapons to counter the threat from North Korea. This has sparked concerns among Japanese leaders and experts that the U.S. may no longer be a reliable ally.

Obama's visit aims to promote a message of nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation, which is part of his broader goal of limiting nuclear proliferation. However, his efforts have been met with mixed results, as North Korea continues to develop its nuclear program and other countries in the region consider their own nuclear options.

The situation is particularly concerning in Japan, where the government has traditionally maintained a policy of pacifism and has not developed its own nuclear weapons. However, some officials and analysts are re-evaluating this stance, citing concerns about China's growing military presence in the region and the potential for a nuclear arms race.

The U.S. alliance with Japan and South Korea is seen as a key factor in maintaining regional stability, and any perceived weakening of this alliance could lead to a nuclear arms race. Obama's visit to Hiroshima is an opportunity to emphasize the importance of preventing the spread of nuclear weapons and promoting a world without them.

Title: The Complexities of Health Insurance: Balancing Quality, Cost, and Coverage

The healthcare industry is subject to various regulations, such as the licensing of medical professionals, to ensure the quality of care provided to patients. Similarly, the Food and Drug Administration oversees the safety and effectiveness of pharmaceuticals. However, healthcare spending can be unpredictable and expensive, making it challenging for individuals to budget for their medical expenses.

Health insurance helps alleviate this issue by pooling risks among the population, reducing financial uncertainty. However, this also creates another problem: insured consumers tend to overconsume healthcare services. When insurance covers the costs, individuals have less incentive to be cost-conscious, leading to unnecessary doctor visits and tests. To mitigate this, insurers implement co-pays, deductibles, and rules limiting access to services. While these measures reduce overconsumption, they also decrease the ability of insurance to pool risk and create conflicts between insurers and customers.

Another challenge facing insurance markets is adverse selection, where customers with known health differences, such as chronic diseases, may choose not to purchase insurance. This can lead to the "death spiral," where insurance companies must raise prices to cover the costs of sicker customers, causing healthier individuals to drop their coverage, and the cycle continues. As this process unfolds, the insurance market may collapse.

These complexities highlight the need for a balanced approach to healthcare and insurance, striking a delicate balance between quality, cost, and coverage.

Title: Egyptian Government Backtracks on Appointment of Mohamed ElBaradei as Prime Minister

The office of Egypt's interim president has reportedly reversed its decision to appoint Mohamed ElBaradei as prime minister, citing opposition from the second-largest Islamist party, Salfi el-Nour. The news of ElBaradei's appointment was initially reported by several news organizations, including Reuters, Al Jazeera, and the BBC, citing "presidential" sources.

According to ElBaradei's spokeswoman, he was set to be sworn in as prime minister on Saturday afternoon. However, just before 1:30 p.m. ET, his spokesman told NPR that the appointment was no longer happening.

The news comes after the ousting of President Mohammed Morsi, Egypt's first democratically elected president, who was removed from office on Wednesday. The military installed Adly Mansour, chief justice of Egypt's Supreme Constitutional Court, as interim president, who is expected to serve until elections can be held.

Mohamed ElBaradei, a former head of the International Atomic Energy Agency and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has a long history of public service. He served as special assistant to the Egyptian foreign minister in 1978 and was part of the negotiating team at the historic Camp David peace talks that led to Egypt's peace treaty and diplomatic relations with Israel. He began his UN career in 1980 and was sent to Iraq in the wake of the 1991 Gulf War to dismantle Saddam's nuclear program.

The development is the latest in a series of events following the removal of President Morsi, who was in office for just one year. The military's decision was met with widespread protests and unrest across the country, fueled by discontent over Egypt's economic problems and the Muslim Brotherhood Party.

Title: China's Response to the Outbreak: A Call for Transparency and Cooperation

The novel coronavirus, which has spread globally, has sparked concerns about its origin and China's role in the pandemic. While it is essential to acknowledge that China's system and deceptions made the situation worse, it is crucial to separate fact from fiction and focus on the facts.

Studies suggest that the virus likely went through natural selection, evolving from animals or after making the leap to humans. The genetic material in the current virus shows an 82% match with the earlier SARS virus and an 89% match with a coronavirus found in bats. Some early victims had visited a Wuhan seafood market where live animals were sold, a so-called wet market.

A more troubling explanation is that the coronavirus was inadvertently spread from the Wuhan Institute of Virology, which had conducted research on bat coronaviruses and possessed a biosafety level 4 facility. While most experts agree that there is no evidence of China deliberately engineering the virus as a weapon, it is essential to investigate the circumstances surrounding the outbreak.

China's initial response to the outbreak was marred by a lack of transparency and deception. When unusual cases of illness began to accumulate in Wuhan in December, the system broke down, and local officials attempted to clamp down on information. When eight doctors in the city expressed concern about the new sickness, they were reprimanded for spreading rumors. One of them, Li Wenliang, a 34-year-old ophthalmologist, later died of the virus.

The Wuhan Health Commission issued public statements claiming no new cases were detected during the critical early weeks of January, while President Xi Jinping was aware of the virus spread as early as January 7. A confidential memo from the National Health Commission revealed a grim assessment of the situation, stating that the risk of transmission and spread was high, and all localities must prepare for and respond to a pandemic.

However, the system opted for deception at the expense of public health, with the National Health Commission issuing a 63-page document on response procedures, labeled "internal" and "not to be spread on the Internet" or "publicly disclosed." It was not until January 20 that Xi warned the public.

China's official death toll was initially too low, and anecdotal evidence described many more deaths. On Friday, China revised the Wuhan death toll upward by 50%, to 3,869, based on a reexamination. This is a welcome step towards transparency and a necessary attitude for the country to adopt.

China has launched a campaign to portray Xi as the hero who vanquished the virus, but this is problematic. Some Chinese officials have even claimed that the United States created the virus, a conspiracy theory as ugly as those heard in Washington. The part of China's campaign that is most troubling is the claim that its system should be emulated. Global Times, a nationalist daily, declared that China's model is the only "successful" one to extinguish the virus.

It is crucial for the United States and China to cooperate to deal with the pandemic and its aftermath. China is critical in the global supply chain for drugs and personal protective equipment, and is an economic superpower. China and the rest of the world must also confront infectious disease together, not use it to score points. However, no one should conclude that China's authoritarian model is one to be emulated. The model – deception, cover-up, and rewriting history – is part of the problem, not the solution.

**Jobless Claims in the United States Reach Record High**

The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits has reached a record high, with over 3.8 million new claims in the past week. This brings the total number of jobless claims to over 22 million, surpassing the previous record set during the Great Recession. The national unemployment rate is estimated to be between 15 and 20 percent, significantly higher than during the Great Recession.

Economists predict that the national unemployment rate will continue to rise, with some estimating it could peak at 25 percent. The job losses are widespread, with industries such as hotels, restaurants, and airlines being particularly hard hit. Even businesses that were not directly affected by the pandemic, such as news organizations and tech companies, are suffering from reduced ad revenue and paid subscriptions.

Consumer spending, which was the driving force behind the longest economic expansion in U.S. history, has come to a near standstill. Many businesses are operating with skeleton staffs and facing months of dismal revenue. The White House and Congress have attempted to intervene with new funding for small businesses, but it has been met with limited success.

The job losses have not been evenly distributed across the country, with some states such as Michigan, Hawaii, and Kentucky experiencing significantly higher rates of unemployment. In Michigan, plant shutdowns and furloughs have ravaged the manufacturing economy, which had only recently recovered from the Great Recession.

Employers are also unlikely to be hiring at pre-pandemic levels, with job postings on Indeed down 34 percent compared to last year. The job losses have left many Americans struggling to make ends meet, with some low-income veterans and Social Security recipients still waiting for stimulus checks.

Title: GOP Debate: Trump's Dominance and Fiorina's Strength

The Republican presidential debate at the Reagan Library in Simi Valley, California, saw Donald Trump's dominance continue, with some questioning whether his act is starting to wear thin. Trump's opponents, including Carly Fiorina, Ben Carson, Jeb Bush, and Scott Walker, struggled to make their mark, with Fiorina emerging as the standout performer.

The debate focused on Trump's bombastic style, with some critics arguing that the moderators are catering to his antics to boost ratings. Trump's opponents faced challenges in getting their messages heard, with many questions centered around his comments and actions. Fiorina, a former Hewlett-Packard executive, shone in her responses, showcasing her depth and concision on defense strategy and her ability to handle Trump's jabs with dignity.

Fiorina's performance was marked by her clear and concise answers, particularly on defense strategy and her willingness to take on Hillary Clinton. She also stood out for not pandering to the question about a new face on the $10 bill, instead using it as an opportunity to promote women's equality.

Trump's performance was marked by his continued dominance, with some flat moments, including his swipe at Rand Paul's hair and his refusal to apologize to Columba Bush. His ideas cupboard remains lightly stocked, leaving many wondering if he can sustain his momentum.

The debate also highlighted the challenges faced by the other candidates, including Bush's struggles to show his passion and wit, and Walker's stalled campaign. The debate format, with Trump at its center, has been criticized for creating an uneven playing field, with some questioning whether the moderators are prioritizing Trump's antics over the other candidates' messages.

Overall, the debate showed that while Trump may be a ratings draw, his act may be starting to wear thin, and Fiorina's strength and clarity may be a sign of things to come.

Title: Trump Acknowledges Pain Caused by Comments, Regrets Some Remarks

In a rare move, Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump acknowledged that his caustic comments may have caused people pain, stating that he regrets some of what he has said "in the heat of debate." This admission came as Trump's campaign struggles to recover from a series of self-created distractions and controversies.

Trump's remarks, delivered at a rally in Charlotte, North Carolina, marked a departure from his usual tone, as he attempted to appeal directly to non-white voters and express regret for his past comments. "Sometimes in the heat of debate and speaking on a multitude of issues, you don't choose the right words or you say the wrong thing," Trump said, reading from prepared text. "And believe it or not, I regret it – and I do regret it – particularly where it may have caused personal pain."

Trump's comments came as his campaign faces significant challenges, including a recent announcement of a campaign shake-up and a trail in the polls. The Republican nominee also announced a new chief executive and campaign manager, a move seen by some as an attempt to double down on his divisive rhetoric.

Despite the change in tone, Trump's campaign still faces skepticism from critics, who argue that his apology rings hollow without concrete actions to back it up. "Donald Trump literally started his campaign by insulting people," said Clinton campaign spokeswoman Christina Reynolds. "He has continued to do so through each of the 428 days from then until now, without shame or regret."

It remains to be seen whether Trump's reboot will be enough to turn the tide of the election, as he trails Clinton in preference polls of key battleground states.

Title: Britain Votes to Leave European Union, Trump Cheers Decision and Draws Parallels to His Own Presidential Bid

Article:

In a historic vote, the United Kingdom has decided to leave the European Union, sending shockwaves across the American political landscape. The decision has sparked reactions from both sides of the political aisle, with President Barack Obama and presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton expressing respect for the British people's decision, while presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump has hailed the outcome as a victory for "taking their country back."

Trump, who was in Scotland touring his golf resorts at the time of the vote, drew parallels between the sentiments driving the "Leave" campaign and those driving his own presidential bid. He pointed to anger over high immigration levels and the desire for greater control over borders as key factors in the British decision.

"We're going to have this more and more, and I think it's happening in the United States," Trump said during a press conference. "I think you're going to see it in other countries, and I think it's a big parallel."

Trump also criticized President Obama for his efforts to persuade the British to remain in the EU, saying that his actions may have contributed to the outcome. "He shouldn't have done it, and I actually think that his recommendation perhaps caused it to fail," Trump said.

Meanwhile, Clinton released a statement acknowledging the uncertainty created by the vote and emphasizing the need for calm, steady leadership to protect American jobs and interests. "Our first task has to be to make sure that the economic uncertainty created by these events does not hurt working families here in America," she said.

The vote has sent shockwaves through the global economy, with the Dow tumbling in response. Vice President Joe Biden, who was in Ireland at the time of the vote, acknowledged that the administration had hoped for a different outcome but stressed that the U.S. will respect the British people's decision.

The outcome of the vote has significant implications for the future of the Western alliance and the global economy, with the potential for a domino effect of similar votes across Europe. The U.S. and the U.K. will need to navigate the complexities of their future relationship, with Trump promising that the U.K. will be "at the front of the line" for trade deals if he is elected.

Title: Trump Holds Campaign Rally in Pennsylvania, Criticizes Democrats and Media

Article:

President Donald Trump held a campaign rally in Moon Township, Pennsylvania, on Saturday, where he delivered a 73-minute speech that was characterized by taunts, insults, and vulgarity. The event was aimed at supporting congressional candidate Rick Saccone, who is running in a special election on Tuesday. The stakes are high for the Republican Party, as Saccone is barely ahead of Democratic candidate Conor Lamb in a district that Trump won by 20 points in the 2016 election.

Trump's speech touched on various topics, including his support for Saccone, his criticism of Democrats, and his attacks on the media. He referred to Democratic leaders Nancy Pelosi and Maxine Waters as "low-IQ individuals" and claimed that Democrats want to "stop us from doing things." He also mentioned his new slogan for the 2020 campaign, "Keep America Great!"

Trump also discussed foreign policy issues, including his dealings with Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto and North Korea. He threatened to fight a trade war with the European Union over tariffs on steel and aluminum and reiterated his stance on drug dealers and sanctuary cities.

As is typical at Trump rallies, he also re-litigated the 2016 election, getting key facts wrong. He claimed to have gotten 52% of the women's vote, which is only true if excluding non-white voters. Exit polls show that Trump won only 25% of Hispanic women and 4% of black women.

Trump also took aim at the media, calling CNN "fake as hell" and claiming that their ratings are "lousy" compared to Fox News. He also referred to Meet the Press host Chuck Todd as a "sleeping son of a bitch."

The event was a vehicle for Trump to talk about himself, with him saying that his casual, seat-of-the-pants speaking style got him elected. He also revealed his new slogan for the 2020 campaign, "Keep America Great!"

Title: Senate Leaders Clash Over Proposed Rules on Political Spending by Non-Profit Groups

The Senate Majority Leader, Harry Reid, has accused the Koch brothers, influential conservatives, of trying to "buy the country" through their political activities. This comes as the Obama administration is proposing new rules to limit the political activities of non-profit groups organized around "social welfare" purposes.

Reid's comments were in response to Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell's criticism of the administration's proposed rules, which he claims are an attack on free speech. McConnell argued that the rules would stifle the political speech of outside groups and compared them to the Internal Revenue Service's targeting of outside groups.

Reid, however, accused the Koch brothers of masquerading as social welfare groups and criticized McConnell's efforts to help them. He stated that the Koch brothers are trying to buy the country due to a United States Supreme Court decision called Citizens United, which allowed for unlimited political spending by corporations and individuals.

The proposed rules would limit the ability of non-profit groups organized around "social welfare" purposes to engage in political activities. These groups, also known as 501(c)(4) nonprofits, have become an integral part of the campaign finance landscape in recent years. Democratic operatives and Republicans have used these groups to shield donors from public scrutiny while still participating in elections.

The Treasury Department is currently considering new rules that would curtail some 501(c)(4) political activity. Reid acknowledged that the Koch-backed groups' spending poses a threat to Democrats, who are fighting to keep the Senate and preserve some control of Congress during Obama's last two years in office.

The Koch brothers, major conservative financiers, have previously given to Democrats, including Senate Democrats, in the past. In 2010, they gave nearly $200,000 to Democratic candidates, including a $30,000 donation to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

Title: Democrats' Shift to the Left Raises Concerns About Political Viability

The Democratic Party is facing a dilemma as it moves further to the left, potentially alienating moderate voters and independents who are crucial to their electoral success. The party's recent stance on immigration and border control has sparked controversy, with some Democratic senators calling for the abolition or replacement of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).

While the move may appeal to the party's most liberal base, it could be seen as a call for open borders by moderates and independents, who want some level of border enforcement. President Trump has been quick to capitalize on this perception, warning that eliminating ICE would lead to a country where people are afraid to leave their homes.

The Democratic Party's shift to the left has also been fueled by the rhetoric of some presidential hopefuls, such as Elizabeth Warren, Kirsten Gillibrand, and Kamala Harris, who are all but campaigning for the presidency. However, this stance may not resonate with voters in key swing states, where moderate Democrats are trying to hold onto their seats.

The party's defense of hounding Trump administration officials has also put them on the defensive. While they can argue that Trump uses rough language and tactics, positioning their party as favoring personal harassment of government officials may not be a winning strategy.

The retirement of Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy has also sparked a media debate, with liberal commentators calling for Democrats to block any Trump nominee this year. However, this stance may be seen as obstructionist and could backfire in key states where moderate voters are crucial to Democratic success.

The Washington Post noted that liberal agitation over the Supreme Court retirement and the crisis over immigrant child separation has left Democratic leaders scrambling to keep the political outrage from becoming a liability for the party. The paper also warned that Bernie Sanders-style rhetoric, including costly guarantees of government jobs, free health care, and free college, could backfire in parts of the country where Trump won in 2016.

In conclusion, the Democratic Party's shift to the left may be a double-edged sword, appealing to their most liberal base but potentially alienating moderate voters and independents who are crucial to their electoral success.

Title: Obama Hails Progress in Iran Nuclear Deal, Warns of Continued Vigilance

Article:

President Barack Obama hailed the completion of the Iran nuclear deal as a significant step towards a more secure United States, region, and world. The deal, which was certified by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), marks a milestone in preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. Obama emphasized that this progress was achieved through strong American diplomacy, without resorting to another war in the Middle East.

As part of the deal, the United States lifted nuclear-related sanctions against Iran, and Iran released five American citizens held captive. In a separate agreement, the U.S. granted clemency to seven Iranians held in the United States. Obama described his use of the constitutional pardon power as a "one-time gesture" to Iran, given the unique circumstances of the moment.

The deal also resolved a decades-long dispute regarding Iranian assets frozen during the 1979 Tehran hostage crisis. The U.S. will return $400 million in Iranian funds, along with $1.3 billion in interest, settling claims at the Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal in The Hague. U.S. citizens had already recovered $2.5 billion in claims against Iran through the same tribunal, according to the State Department.

However, Obama also emphasized that the U.S. will not ignore Iran's "destabilizing behavior elsewhere" and its ballistic missile program. The Treasury Department imposed sanctions on 11 individuals and companies involved in Iran's ballistic missile program, and Obama vowed to "remain vigilant" in enforcing these sanctions.

The deal was met with criticism from Republican presidential candidates, who condemned the agreement as a "pattern of negotiating with terrorists" that endangers U.S. safety and security.

**Keystone XL Oil Pipeline: What You Need to Know**

The Keystone XL oil pipeline project has been a contentious issue for years, with the Senate voting against its completion. The remaining segment of the pipeline, if completed, will be approximately 1,200 miles long, connecting Alberta, Canada, to the Gulf of Mexico. The pipeline has been the subject of a heated debate among politicians, energy companies, and environmentalists.

About 40% of the project has been built so far, with two segments already operational. The remaining segment would allow for the transportation of up to 830,000 barrels of crude oil per day from Canada's oil sands to the U.S. Gulf Coast, where it would be refined into gasoline and other fuels.

Opponents argue that some of the crude would be exported, but TransCanada, the company building the pipeline, claims this would not be financially viable. Alberta estimates it has the third-largest proven oil reserves in the world, but this oil is valuable only if it can be transported to a market where it can be sold.

The construction phase of the pipeline is estimated to create about 42,000 direct and indirect jobs and generate around $2 billion in earnings in the U.S. However, opponents dispute some of these numbers, and once construction is complete, the pipeline would create only about 50 new permanent jobs.

The president has significant leverage over the pipeline, as it requires a presidential permit due to its crossing of the U.S.-Canada border. The State Department has completed an environmental review, concluding that the pipeline would have little impact on greenhouse gas emissions and would not significantly affect the price of gasoline in the U.S.

The project has faced legal challenges, including a Nebraska Supreme Court case over the pipeline's route. The court is expected to announce its ruling in the coming months. If the legislation passes the Senate and becomes law, the pipeline would receive an immediate green light.

There are other pipelines that can move oil sands crude, but there is not enough capacity to meet the demand. Producers in Canada are pursuing transporting oil sands by rail cars, but this option becomes less attractive as world oil prices fall.

Title: Trump Campaigns in New Hampshire, Seeks First Victory in Republican Primaries

The Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has been campaigning in New Hampshire, seeking his first victory in the Republican primaries. Trump, who has led in polling for the past six months, is the odds-on favorite to win, and a victory would give him a much-needed rebound after a less-than-stellar showing in Iowa's caucuses.

Trump received a hero's welcome at a rally in Manchester, where thousands braved a storm to attend the event. He emphasized the importance of getting out and voting, saying "Tomorrow is going to be the beginning... We have to celebrate tomorrow evening. We have to have a great victory. It is so important because we are going to make America great again."

The New Hampshire primary is expected to be a crucial test for several candidates, including Trump, Sen. Marco Rubio, and three current or former governors. Businesswoman Carly Fiorina and three current or former governors need a strong showing to remain viable.

The race will next head to South Carolina, where Trump also leads in the polls, followed by Nevada and then Super Tuesday on March 1, when numerous delegates to the nominating convention are at stake.

Trump's opponents, including Rubio, Kasich, and Christie, are also campaigning hard, vying for the support of undecided voters. Rubio is hoping to regain his momentum after a strong showing in Iowa, while Kasich is appealing to blue-collar Democrats who helped power Ronald Reagan's winning campaigns.

The primary is likely to be a decisive test for several candidates, with some analysts predicting that it will be hard for Bush, Kasich, and Christie to survive disappointing showings.

Title: Iowa Caucuses Set to Provide Clarity in Presidential Contests

The Iowa caucuses are finally here, with voters from both the Republican and Democratic parties set to weigh in on Monday night. The results could bring much-needed clarity to the respective nominating contests, or they may not, depending on the turnout. The number of voters who show up will be crucial, as voting in a caucus is more challenging than voting in a primary. A big turnout benefits outsiders Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, while a lower turnout helps Ted Cruz and Hillary Clinton.

The previous record for Republican turnout was 122,000 votes in 2012, and some analysts predict Trump could surpass that number, potentially reaching 150,000. On the Democratic side, Bernie Sanders needs a turnout above 124,000, the number that turned out in 2004.

The weather may also play a factor, with a winter storm predicted to start on Tuesday, which could depress turnout. The state is well-suited for Ted Cruz, with a strong conservative evangelical base, and he needs to win Iowa to have a clear path to the nomination. If he comes in second to Trump, he will face a much harder path.

Marco Rubio has a strategy of coming in third in Iowa, second in New Hampshire, and then winning somewhere else. He needs a strong third-place finish in Iowa to convince his donors that he has a clear path to the nomination. A stronger-than-expected finish would help him consolidate the mainstream wing of the GOP.

On the Democratic side, the big question is whether Bernie Sanders has the organization to upset Hillary Clinton. Sanders has been trying to expand his reach to rural areas, but Clinton's team has built an organization that covers all 99 counties and 1,683 precincts in Iowa. If Sanders beats Clinton in Iowa, it would be an upset, and he would head into New Hampshire with more momentum. A win in both Iowa and New Hampshire could change the dynamic in the South, where Clinton has built a firewall based on her support among African-American Democrats.

The Iowa caucuses will be closely watched, with many eyes on the results to see how the presidential contests unfold.

Title: Illinois Sees Decline in Crime Rates Following Introduction of Concealed Carry Permits

The state of Illinois has seen a significant decline in crime rates since the introduction of concealed carry permits, with a 20% decrease in robberies, 20% decrease in burglaries, and 26% decrease in motor vehicle thefts. The decline is attributed to the increased presence of armed citizens, which has a deterrence effect on criminals.

According to the Illinois State Rifle Association, the number of concealed carry permits issued has reached 68,549, with an estimated 100,000 citizens expected to be carrying by the end of the year. The demand for permits has been high, with gun training and shooting classes filling up quickly.

The Chicago Police Department has credited better police work and the confiscation of over 1,300 illegal guns as reasons for the decline in crime rates. However, the impact of concealed carry cannot be dismissed, as the data suggests that increased concealed carry rates have coincided with lower crime rates.

A July study by the Crime Prevention Research Center found that 11.1 million Americans have permits to carry concealed weapons, a 147% increase from 4.5 million seven years ago. Meanwhile, homicide and other violent crime rates have dropped by 22%.

In Illinois, Cook County has the state's largest number of concealed carry applications, with 28,552 requests. However, accounting for population, less than 1% of residents are carrying. Mason County has the top per-capita rate in Illinois, with 14% of its residents holding concealed carry licenses.

Sheriffs in Mason and Shelby counties, where concealed carry rates are high, do not anticipate the increased carry rate to significantly impact crime rates. They believe that the majority of permit holders are law-abiding citizens who want to exercise their Second Amendment rights.

From a national perspective, Florida has the most active concealed carry permits, at nearly 1.3 million, while Hawaii has the fewest, at 183. Illinois would compare to Virginia and Alabama, with 363,274 and 379,917 permits, respectively.

Title: Trump Cancels Meeting with Danish Prime Minister Over Greenland Purchase Comments

Article:

President Donald Trump abruptly canceled a planned meeting with Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen on Tuesday, citing her comments that the idea of the United States purchasing Greenland is "absurd." The meeting was initially expected to take place on September 2-3 as part of Trump's trip to Europe.

In a tweet, Trump stated that he would be postponing the meeting, citing Frederiksen's comments that there would be no discussion about the potential purchase of Greenland. The White House later clarified that the entire trip to Denmark had been scrapped, including a planned meeting with the Queen of Denmark.

The sudden cancellation caught many off guard, with commentators expressing surprise that the visit was centered on buying Greenland. The Wall Street Journal had reported last week that Trump had expressed interest in acquiring the semi-autonomous territory, which is under Danish control and has a population of approximately 56,000.

Frederiksen had previously stated that Greenland is not for sale and that the idea of the United States purchasing the territory is not a serious proposal. Trump had also compared the proposal to a "large real estate deal," stating that Denmark is losing money by carrying Greenland and that the United States could help Denmark by taking over the territory.

The cancellation of the meeting has sparked reactions from both sides, with some left-wing commentators mocking the White House and others finding humor in the situation. The U.S. ambassador to Denmark, Carla Sands, had tweeted hours before the cancellation that Denmark was "ready" for the President's visit.

The idea of the United States purchasing Greenland is not a new concept, as the U.S. made a similar effort in 1947. However, this time around, the proposal has been met with skepticism and humor, with even Trump himself appearing to join in on the joke.

Title: The Value of Women on the Bench: A Perspective from a Former Chief Justice

The article discusses the importance of having women serve as judges on the highest courts in the country. Leah Ward Sears, a retired chief justice of the Georgia Supreme Court, argues that women like Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg have been instrumental in shaping a fair and just jurisprudence in the United States. According to Sears, women have brought a unique perspective to the bench, one that is more attuned to the experiences and challenges faced by women and families.

Sears notes that the presence of women on the bench has helped to erode the "judicial boys' club" and has led to more gender-sensitive decisions. She highlights Justice Ginsburg's notable opinions, including her majority opinion in United States v. Virginia and her concurring opinion in Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt. These opinions demonstrate Justice Ginsburg's commitment to protecting the rights of women and promoting gender equality.

Sears also emphasizes that women's lives are often different from those of men, and that experiencing the lived reality of womanhood in America can add valuable insights to the decision-making process. She notes that female judges, particularly those who have had to balance their professional and personal lives, have inspired generations of young women to become lawyers and judges.

The article concludes by expressing gratitude that Justice Ginsburg will be able to continue serving on the Supreme Court for at least the next five years, and hopefully longer.

Title: Supreme Court Confirmation Battle Looms as Abortion Activists Mobilize Against Trump's Pick

The confirmation battle for the next Supreme Court justice is shaping up to be a contentious and intense process, with abortion activists already mobilizing against President Trump's nominee. Specifically, activists are targeting Republican Senators Lisa Murkowski and Susan Collins, who are known for voting against their party and are pro-choice. The National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League (NARAL) has been in panic mode since Justice Anthony Kennedy's retirement and is using social media to galvanize its supporters.

NARAL President Ilyse Hogue warned that any of Trump's list of 25 potential nominees will vote to decimate abortion rights under Roe v. Wade. The group is planning to go after senators who vote to confirm the nominee, urging them to examine their values and moral compasses.

Indivisible, a group established in opposition to President Trump, is also rallying its members, setting up a hotline to connect people with their senators and creating a script for callers to read. Abortion is not the only driving issue behind the protests, as groups in support of Obamacare are also gearing up for the fight. Protect Our Care, a coalition designed to maintain the Affordable Care Act (ACA), is warning that the new justice could be a deciding vote that gets rid of protections for pre-existing conditions.

However, there is another challenge for activists who care about abortion rights and the ACA: Three Democratic senators, Joe Manchin, Heidi Heitkamp, and Joe Donnelly, may also break ranks with their party to join Republicans in voting to confirm the president's nominee. All three senators voted to confirm Trump's first Supreme Court pick, Justice Neil Gorsuch, and are seeking re-election in states that Trump won in 2016.

It is also important to note that the man or woman Trump nominates to replace Justice Kennedy may not be as predictable as everyone assumes.
