Kennedy was appointed by President Ronald Reagan, who described him as a conservative, but Kennedy's record shows that he has only been conservative about half the time. Chief Justice John Roberts, appointed by President George W. Bush, has also issued some rulings that make many conservatives cringe.

Regardless, senators can expect a summer full of activist-filled lobbies, protests, and threats against their political futures as they weigh their votes for or against the next justice of the Supreme Court.

Title: Maryland Lawmakers Introduce Legislation to Replace Taney Bust with Thurgood Marshall's in the U.S. Capitol

Article:

Maryland lawmakers have introduced legislation to replace a bust of Chief Justice Roger Taney, who served on the Supreme Court for 17 years, with a tribute to Thurgood Marshall, the first African American justice. The proposed change aims to correct a historical injustice and provide a fitting tribute to Marshall's legacy.

Taney's bust has been a part of the Capitol building since 1876, despite his controversial role in the Dred Scott case, which upheld slavery. The legislation, backed by Democratic members of the Maryland House delegation, seeks to replace the Taney bust with a tribute to Marshall, a renowned attorney, government official, and Supreme Court justice.

Marshall's legacy is marked by his tireless defense of civil rights and his role in ending segregation. His enshrinement in the Capitol would be a fitting tribute to his contributions to American history. The replacement would also provide a symbolic closure to the history of Maryland's place in the old chamber, where Taney's bust has stood for almost 150 years.

The proposed change is seen as a step towards correcting a historical injustice and acknowledging the significance of Marshall's enshrinement. The legislation is currently under consideration and has sparked debate among lawmakers and historians.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Urges Roy Moore to Step Aside Amid Allegations of Inappropriate Relationships

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, has called on Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore to step aside from the upcoming election, citing allegations of inappropriate relationships with teenagers when Moore was in his 30s. The allegations, reported by the Washington Post last week, claim that Moore pursued romantic relationships with multiple women when they were teenagers, including one woman who was 14 at the time.

According to the report, one woman, Leigh Corfman, alleged that Moore took her to his home in 1979, undressed her, and touched her over her bra and underpants. Another woman, Gloria Deason, claimed that she was 18 when Moore took her on a date and bought her wine. The age of consent in Alabama, both then and now, is 16.

Moore has vehemently denied the allegations, stating that he has never been guilty of sexual misconduct with anyone and has never purchased alcohol for underage women. Both Moore and his GOP allies in Alabama have questioned the timing of the story, suggesting it was planted to derail his political career.

McConnell, who had backed Moore's opponent, Luther Strange, in the primary, is now exploring other Republican options for the seat, including Strange himself. The December election is to replace ex-Sen. Jeff Sessions, a Republican who stepped down to become President Trump's attorney general.

In a statement, McConnell said, "We're looking at whether or not there is not someone who can mount a write-in campaign successfully." Moore has fired back on Twitter, saying that McConnell is the one who should step aside.

The controversy has sparked a heated debate within the Republican Party, with some calling for Moore to drop out of the race and others defending him against what they see as a political smear.

Title: Political Violence and Intimidation Against Republicans on the Rise

Article:

In recent weeks, a growing number of incidents have highlighted the increasing trend of violence and intimidation against Republicans and supporters of the president. The latest example is a woman in Tennessee who was charged with felony reckless endangerment for allegedly trying to run Republican Congressman David Kustoff off the road after a town hall meeting. The woman, Wendi Wright, was reportedly enraged over Kustoff's support for the American Health Care Act and screamed at the congressman and his aide, striking his car windows and reaching inside the vehicle.

On the same day, a man in North Dakota was escorted from a town hall meeting after he became physical with Republican Rep. Kevin Cramer over his support for the GOP Obamacare replacement. The man shouted questions about the tax implications of the bill before shoving cash down the congressman's collar.

A recent article by Michaelangelo Signorile, published by The Huffington Post, has also sparked controversy. Signorile called on protesters to harass Republicans at dinner, when they're out shopping, and even at home, arguing that societal norms for basic decency no longer apply to liberals. The article has been shared over 29,000 times.

Political violence has become increasingly common as left-wing organizations have whipped up mobs against Republicans and supporters of the president. A popular parade in Portland, Oregon, was cancelled after threats of violence against one of the groups participating, a local Republican organization. An email warning parade organizers promised 200 or more protesters would rush into the parade and drag the Republican marchers out, if that's what it took to keep them from participating.

In another incident, a North Carolina GOP office was firebombed a month before the election, and a building adjacent to it was spray-painted with graffiti: "Nazi Republicans get out of town or else." A female high school student was also attacked after declaring her support for Trump, with a fellow student taking her glasses off and punching her in the face, saying, "Fuck you, you bitch."

Olivia Corn, president of Cornell University's College Republicans, said she was physically assaulted the night after Trump won the election, with her attacker reportedly saying, "Fuck you, racist bitch, you support a racist party." A Maryland high school student wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat was also punched and kicked by students protesting Trump after he started arguing with them.

These incidents highlight the growing trend of political violence and intimidation against Republicans and supporters of the president.

Title: White House Criticizes CNN and MSNBC for Cutting Away from Coronavirus Briefing

The White House has criticized CNN and MSNBC for cutting away from a Monday evening briefing on the coronavirus pandemic, which was delivered by President Donald Trump and his administration. White House spokesman Judd Deere called the decision "pretty disgraceful" and thanked Fox News for keeping Americans informed.

The briefing, which was held on March 23, 2020, focused on the administration's plan to work with local economies to "cautiously resume" activities after the pandemic has shut down industries. However, CNN and MSNBC cut away from the briefing, citing that the information no longer appeared valuable to the ongoing discussion around public health.

A CNN spokesperson responded to Deere's tweet, stating that the network will make its own editorial decisions and will not show the briefing live unless an official request is made by the White House. MSNBC also defended its decision, saying it aired the briefing for over an hour before cutting away.

The criticism of the administration's daily coronavirus briefings has been ongoing, with some accusing them of spreading misinformation. Last week, President Trump got into a spat with NBC News reporter Peter Alexander over a question about his message to Americans who are scared about the coronavirus. Trump responded by calling Alexander a "terrible reporter" and saying the question was "nasty" and "bad."

As of March 23, 2020, COVID-19 has infected more than 43,000 people in the U.S., resulting in at least 552 deaths, according to data from Johns Hopkins University.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid Calls for Gun-Control Debate in Wake of Connecticut School Shooting

Article:

In the aftermath of the devastating shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has announced that the Senate will hold a debate on gun control measures. This decision comes as a growing number of lawmakers, including some who have previously opposed stricter gun laws, are rethinking their stance.

Reid, a Democrat from Nevada, has historically been a supporter of gun rights, voting against the renewal of the assault-weapons ban in 2004. However, he has stated that "every idea should be on the table" in the wake of the Connecticut tragedy, which left 20 children and six adults dead.

Other Democratic senators, including Joe Manchin III of West Virginia and Mark R. Warner of Virginia, have also expressed a willingness to consider stricter gun laws. Manchin, who has been a strong supporter of gun rights in the past, said that "everything should be on the table" and that lawmakers should consider addressing mental health treatment, military-style assault weapons, and high-capacity magazines.

Warner, who has previously been a pro-gun Democrat, said that the status quo is no longer acceptable and that he hopes the debate will not be a "flash point" that is quickly forgotten.

Some lawmakers, however, remain skeptical about the effectiveness of stricter gun laws. St. Louis County Police Chief Tim Fitch likened the situation to the 9/11 attacks, suggesting that arming school officials could help prevent similar tragedies. Rep. Louie Gohmert of Texas expressed a similar sentiment, saying that he wishes Sandy Hook Principal Dawn Hochsprung had access to a firearm.

The debate on gun control is expected to be a complex and contentious one, with some lawmakers pushing for stricter laws and others advocating for increased access to guns for teachers and school officials. The White House has pledged to use its power to engage citizens in an effort to prevent similar tragedies, but has not yet provided specifics on what legislative measures it will support.

Title: Political Divisions Emerge Over Reade's Allegation and Biden's Plan

The article discusses the controversy surrounding Tara Reade's allegation that Joe Biden sexually assaulted her and the Democratic presidential candidate's plan to address healthcare concerns. Some critics argue that liberal feminists are being hypocritical for not supporting Reade as fervently as they did Christine Blasey Ford, who accused Brett Kavanaugh of sexual assault. The article notes that if Blasey's story had been more solid or less ambiguous, it might have been easier to know what to do with Reade's accusation.

The article also highlights the comparison between the sexual assault allegations against Trump and Biden, stating that while both candidates have faced accusations, the allegations against Trump are more numerous and severe. However, the article argues that journalists should not engage in a simplistic comparison between the two, as it can be misleading and obfuscating.

Regarding Biden's plan, critics argue that it is insufficient and does not address the concerns of young voters. The plan, which would allow people to buy into Medicare at age 65, is seen as a concession that does not go far enough. In contrast, some argue that young voters should not sit out the election and instead should participate to establish themselves as a reliable force and hold politicians accountable.

The article presents a balanced view of the controversy, highlighting the differing opinions and perspectives on the issue.

Title: Hedge Fund Billionaire Tom Steyer's Climate Change Advocacy and Political Influence

Article:

Hedge fund billionaire Tom Steyer has been a vocal advocate for climate change awareness and action, using his personal wealth to fund a series of advertisements and political campaigns aimed at influencing the outcome of elections. Ahead of the midterms, Steyer is seeking to expand his political organization, NextGen Climate Action, into a major player in the political landscape, with a focus on climate change as a key issue.

Steyer's efforts have been met with criticism from some, who accuse him of using his wealth to sway elections and undermine the democratic process. In 2013, the Washington Post fact-checker awarded Steyer four Pinocchios for his claims about the Keystone XL pipeline, calling them "ultra-lame" and "ultra-deceitful."

Despite this criticism, Steyer remains committed to his cause, using his wealth to support Democratic candidates and environmental groups. In February, he gathered a group of liberal donors and environmental philanthropists at his ranch in California to discuss his plans to raise $50 million to match his own $50 million investment in the organization.

Steyer's efforts are part of a broader shift within the environmental movement, as donors and philanthropists are increasingly turning their attention to political campaigns rather than philanthropic efforts. The new fundraising push seeks to tap into the fortunes of Silicon Valley, where many donors rank climate change as their top political issue.

As part of his efforts, NextGen Climate Action is asking supporters to choose a congressional candidate to target in its next ads, with four of the five candidates being Republicans. However, the fifth candidate, Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana, is a vulnerable Democratic incumbent who has close ties to the oil and gas industries and has been an outspoken supporter of the Keystone pipeline. It remains unclear whether an attack from a hyper-progressive, anti-fossil fuels group like NextGen would help or hurt her in red-state Louisiana.

Title: Republican Tax Plan to Slash State and Local Tax Deductions

The Republican-led tax plan, introduced by the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Ways and Means, aims to overhaul the tax code by slashing state and local tax deductions. The plan, which would reduce federal revenues by roughly $1.5 trillion over 10 years, eliminates the most widely-used deduction – income tax – and caps property tax deductions at $10,000. State and local deductions are used largely by high-tax states that tend to vote Democratic in presidential elections.

The plan is expected to disproportionately affect Democratic-leaning states, such as California, New York, and New Jersey, which have state income tax rates of 13.3%, 8.82%, and 8.97%, respectively. These states, along with Minnesota and Oregon, voted against Donald Trump in the 2016 election.

Connecticut's Commissioner of Revenue Services, Kevin Sullivan, stated that the plan "has been developed in a way that looks at who were the prevailing forces in the presidential election and who were not." Middle-class households in these states may end up paying more taxes under the Republican plan.

Conservative groups have defended the tax bill, saying it would simplify the tax code, reduce the overall burden on the economy, and spread the costs and burdens more fairly. However, officials in the affected states argue that millions of residents, not just high-earners, would suffer because of lost tax breaks and less funding available for public services.

The proposed bill would also eliminate a tax exemption for billions of dollars of private activity bonds issued by state and local governments annually to finance affordable housing, non-profit hospitals, and colleges, as well as airports and port facilities. This measure would affect both Democratic and Republican states alike.

The plan has been met with opposition from some Republican legislators from high-tax states, including Representative Lee Zeldin of New York. The legislation is still pending and has sparked concerns about its impact on middle-class families and the economy.

Title: Trump Jr.'s Lawyer Turns Over Thousands of Documents to Congress, Denies Any Concerns

The lawyer for Donald Trump Jr., Alan Futerfas, has stated that his client has cooperated with congressional committees and turned over thousands of documents in response to their requests. The documents, which were provided under promises of confidentiality, have been selectively leaked, and Futerfas has expressed confidence that any questions raised about them have been easily answered in the appropriate forum.

The documents were turned over as part of the ongoing investigations into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential campaign. American intelligence services have accused the Kremlin of engaging in a deliberate effort to boost President Donald Trump's chances while bringing down his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton. The Trump campaign's response to these efforts has spawned multiple congressional investigations and a special counsel inquiry, which has led to the indictment of Trump's former campaign chair, Paul Manafort, for financial crimes.

The correspondence between Trump Jr. and WikiLeaks, which represents a small portion of the thousands of documents turned over, is not clear what investigators will make of it. However, the stakes for the Trump family are high. Trump Jr.'s June 2016 meeting with Natalia Veselnitskaya, a Russian lawyer with connections to Russia's powerful prosecutor general, is already a subject of interest in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation. The messages exchanged with WikiLeaks add a second instance in which Trump Jr. appears eager to obtain damaging information about Hillary Clinton, despite its provenance.

Although Trump Jr. mostly ignored the frequent messages from WikiLeaks, he at times acted on its requests. When WikiLeaks first reached out to Trump Jr. about putintrump.org, he followed up on his promise to "ask around." According to a source familiar with the congressional investigations into Russian interference with the 2016 campaign, Trump Jr. emailed other senior officials with the Trump campaign, including Steve Bannon, Kellyanne Conway, Brad Parscale, and Trump son-in-law Jared Kushner, about the contact with WikiLeaks. Kushner then forwarded the email to campaign communications staffer Hope Hicks. At no point during the 10-month correspondence did Trump Jr. rebuff WikiLeaks, which had published stolen documents and was already observed to be releasing information that benefited Russian interests.

Title: Clinton Faces Challenges in Wooing Sanders' Supporters

Article:

Hillary Clinton's victory speech in New York highlighted her desire to bridge the gap with Bernie Sanders' supporters, acknowledging that there is more that unites the two camps than divides them. However, the road to winning over Sanders' voters will require more than just words. Clinton can take several steps to demonstrate her commitment to the issues that have driven Sanders' campaign. She could offer him a prime-time speaking spot at the Democratic National Convention, select a vice presidential running mate who shares his concerns, or incorporate his policy positions into the party platform.

Clinton could also offer to help pay off Sanders' campaign debt, a gesture that would be reminiscent of President Barack Obama's support for her in 2008. However, there may be limits to how much Clinton can do to win over Sanders' supporters. She has already moved to the left during the primary, and reversing course to appeal to the center for the general election could complicate her efforts.

A more significant challenge lies in whether Sanders himself will wholeheartedly endorse Clinton if she wins the nomination. Sanders has been critical of Clinton throughout the campaign and has shown little enthusiasm for her candidacy. Even Howard Dean, who lost the 2004 Democratic primary to John Kerry, found it easier to endorse his opponent than to bring his supporters on board. Dean, who supports Clinton, noted that it's easier for the candidate to understand the need to get on board, but bringing supporters along is a much tougher task.

Title: Large Majorities of Americans Perceive Unhealthy Relationship Between Trump Administration and News Media

Article:

A recent survey conducted by a nationally representative American Trends Panel has revealed that a large majority of Americans believe the relationship between the Trump administration and the news media is unhealthy. The survey, conducted from March 13-27, 2017, among 4,151 adults, found that 83% of Americans consider the current tensions between the administration and the news media to be problematic, with only 15% saying the relationship is healthy despite the current tensions.

The survey also found that 73% of Americans believe that these tensions are getting in the way of access to important national political news and information. This sentiment is not limited to one political party, as 88% of Democrats and 78% of Republicans agree that the relationship is unhealthy. Additionally, the findings are consistent across various demographic groups, including age, race, income, and education.

The survey also revealed that nearly all Americans (94%) are aware of the current state of the relationship between the Trump administration and the news media, with 72% saying they have heard a lot about it. There were some age differences in awareness, with younger Americans (18-29) being less likely to have heard a lot about the relationship, but still 87% of this age group had heard at least a little about the issue.

The survey did not explore who Americans blame for these tensions or what they want done about the situation. However, the findings suggest that Americans are highly aware of the current state of the relationship and have concerns about its impact on their access to important political news and information.

Title: New York City Businesses Feel the Pinch of $15 Minimum Wage Increase

New York City businesses with 11 or more employees have been required to pay their workers at least $15 per hour since the beginning of 2019. While the intention behind the increase was to boost workers' wages, many businesses are already feeling the negative impacts and making difficult cuts. According to the Wall Street Journal, some businesses are raising prices, cutting hours, or even laying off workers.

The minimum wage increase is particularly challenging for businesses in boroughs with lower disposable income, such as the Bronx. Bronx Chamber of Commerce President Lisa Sorin noted that while Manhattan businesses might be able to absorb the increase, places like the Bronx are forced to "keep up or get out." Even businesses that are not forced to shut down due to the minimum wage increase can still be stifled by the added costs.

Restaurant owner Susannah Koteen had to cancel plans to expand her Harlem business due to the uncertainty of hiring more staff in an unpredictable industry. "You would just have no choice but to cut people at the bottom," she said. These anecdotes highlight the reality that while many people support higher wages in theory, the reality of a higher minimum wage can be damaging to both minimum wage employees and small business owners.

Retailer John Bonizio, who owns four Metro Optics Eyewear locations, initially supported the minimum-wage increase, believing it would put more money in customers' pockets. However, he now believes that small businesses are being "picked off" by the increased costs. The experiences of these business owners demonstrate the complex and multifaceted effects of the minimum wage increase, which can have both positive and negative consequences for workers and businesses alike.

Title: Nike Pulls Sneakers Featuring Early American Flag Amid Controversy Over Historical Significance

Article:

Nike has pulled its sneakers featuring an early version of the American flag, also known as the "Betsy Ross" flag, after former NFL player Colin Kaepernick reportedly expressed offense and tied the image to slavery. The decision has sparked controversy, with some experts arguing that the flag's historical significance has been co-opted by groups with white supremacist ideologies.

The 13-star flag, designed by Philadelphia seamstress Betsy Ross, was America's first national flag, adopted in 1777. While Ross lived during slavery, her flag's relationship to white supremacy is unclear, with some historians noting that Philadelphia had neutral leanings during the Revolutionary War.

Historians contacted by [redacted] noted that the flag has been used by white supremacist groups "from time to time," but it is not listed as a hate symbol by the Anti-Defamation League. Mark Pitcavage, senior research fellow at the ADL's Center on Extremism, stated that while the flag has been used by white supremacists, he has "never once thought about" adding it to the list.

The controversy surrounding the flag is not new, with some groups co-opting it as a symbol of their ideology. In 2016, students at a majority-white high school in Michigan waved the 13-star flag during a football game, sparking criticism from the NAACP.

Nike's decision to pull the sneakers was intended to avoid offense, but it has also opened it up to political rebuke. Arizona Governor Doug Ducey, who was set to provide financial incentives for Nike to add a manufacturing facility in the state, pulled the funding after Nike's decision.

The flag has evolved since its earliest iteration, adding more stars as more states joined the union. According to University of Memphis associate professor Scott P. Marler, "If all these historians didn't know [the relationship between white supremacy and the Betsy Ross flag], then Nike shouldn't be expected to know it."

Title: Expert Witness Disqualified: Law Professor's Personal Animus Against Trump Discredits Her Testimony

Article:

Law professor Pamela Karlan's testimony in the impeachment inquiry has been criticized for her personal animus against President Donald Trump and his son, Barron. While testifying, Karlan made a comment about the difference between a president and a king, stating that the Constitution prohibits the president from making his son a baron. This comment was seen as a cheap shot and an example of her strong personal bias against Trump.

Karlan's statement was met with criticism from Representative Matt Gaetz, who asked her if her statement reflected contempt for conservatives. Karlan denied any intent to offend, but her words were seen as an example of leftist academics' tendency to ridicule and belittle those who hold opposing views.

The article goes on to discuss the concept of leftist projection, where individuals project their own biases and prejudices onto others. The author argues that Karlan's statement is an example of this phenomenon, as she accuses conservatives of being fearful and hostile, while her own words demonstrate a lack of respect for those who disagree with her.

The article also references a theory by evolutionary psychologist Dr. Nigel Barber, who suggests that conservatives are more fearful and hostile due to their brain biology. The author argues that this theory is flawed and that Karlan's statement is an example of leftist projection.

The article concludes by stating that the left's elitist attitude towards Trump and his supporters drives their desire to impeach him, and that their professed concern for the constitution and elections is hypocritical.

Title: California Voters' "Zombie Votes" May Impact Democratic Primary Outcome

Article: The California primary election is underway, with over 3.7 million ballots already mailed in. However, a significant chunk of those votes will be for candidates who have dropped out of the race, dubbed "zombie votes" by politicos. Paul Mitchell, with the electoral research firm Political Data Inc., projects that 350,000 to 400,000 Californians have already voted for a candidate who has dropped out. This number could grow to over half a million.

While some voters have been waiting until the last minute to cast their ballots, many have already done so, with less than a quarter of the 16 million Californians who received a mail ballot having returned it by the eve of the election. Those ballots need only be postmarked by tomorrow and arrive by Friday to be counted, which may lead to possible problems and delays in the final outcome of close races.

The "zombie votes" may have implications for candidates still in the running. Votes for Democratic candidates who quit can affect how many delegates the remaining candidates will be allotted. Party rules dictate that a candidate must earn 15% of the statewide vote to get any statewide delegates, and also that a candidate must earn 15% of the vote in any of the state's congressional districts to receive any delegates apportioned at the district level. This means "zombie votes" could cause other candidates to miss the 15% threshold.

Mitchell used Michael Bloomberg as a hypothetical example, stating that if Bloomberg hypothetically received 13.8% of the vote, but candidates no longer running also receive a percentage of the vote, then "them not being in the race could easily have gotten Bloomberg over the top of 15%." However, since those votes are still counted in the delegate math, Bloomberg could theoretically stay under 15% just because of other candidates' votes.

It's also possible that a candidate who has dropped out will nonetheless exceed the threshold enough to win some delegates in certain congressional districts. Those delegates would be chosen by the ex-candidate and expected to vote for them on the first ballot at the Democratic National Convention.

As for the anticipated flood of same-day voting, either in person or by mail, it's difficult to say precisely which candidate stands to benefit most. Joe Biden, for instance, has been buoyed by a robust victory in the South Carolina primary and a stream of quitting candidates who endorsed him. Californians who didn't vote early may be swayed by all that good news for Biden. Conversely, the former vice president lost that momentum propulsion among all Californians who have already voted by mail at a time when he trailed other contenders.

Heading into the final hours of the California primary, the latest available public polls still indicated Bernie Sanders with a significant lead.

Title: Green Party's Jill Stein Seeks to Break Through Political Gridlock

The 2016 presidential election has seen two of the most disliked candidates in electoral history, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, leading to a surge in support for third-party candidates like Gary Johnson and Jill Stein. Stein, a 66-year-old Harvard-trained physician from Massachusetts, is running on the Green Party ticket and is currently polling at around 2 percent.

Stein believes this election presents an historic opportunity for third parties to break through the political gridlock and challenge the dominance of the Democratic and Republican parties. She argues that the current system is flawed and that Americans are forced to choose between the lesser of two evils. Stein suggests that a new voting system could allow voters to choose their conscience without feeling forced to compromise.

Stein and Johnson share common ground on issues like foreign policy, marijuana legalization, and same-sex marriage. However, they differ significantly on economic issues. Stein favors a single-payer health care system, which she claims would cost taxpayers nothing, and would invest in the clean energy sector, aiming to end the use of fossil fuels by 2030.

Stein has faced criticism for her views on vaccines, with some interpreting her comments as anti-vaccine. However, she maintains that she is simply calling for reforms to the FDA, which she believes is corrupted by lobbyists. Stein characterizes the media coverage of her statements as misleading and compares it to the "birther" issue of this election.

As the election approaches, both Johnson and Stein's poll numbers are slipping. To gain recognition as a minor party, they need to reach 5 percent of the popular vote, which would grant them easier ballot access and matching public funds. Stein believes that this election is a chance for Americans to break free from the choice between a "fascist or a warmonger" and choose a more progressive path.

Title: How the Iran Crisis May Impact the 2020 Primary and General Elections

The recent American drone strike that killed Iranian military leader Qassem Soleimani has heightened tensions between the two nations and put American troops in the Middle East on high alert. As the situation unfolds, it's unclear how it will affect the 2020 primary and general elections. This article will explore the potential impact of the crisis on the primary and general elections, using political science and polling data to analyze the issue.

While most research suggests that foreign policy doesn't significantly influence voters' decisions, there are exceptions. When foreign policy is a major part of the national conversation and the two parties have clearly contrasting positions, it can have a greater impact. The Iran crisis may meet these conditions, with the Democratic primary candidates' views on the issue likely to be scrutinized closely.

Former Vice President Joe Biden, who has experience in foreign policy, is currently leading among Democratic primary voters in terms of trust on the issue, according to CNN and HuffPost/YouGov polls. However, other candidates, such as Bernie Sanders, are not far behind. The primary debate next week will be crucial in determining how the candidates' views on Iran will be perceived by voters.

The Iran crisis could also serve as a litmus test for the candidates, with voters paying close attention to their stance on the issue. In the 2016 Republican primaries, Ben Carson struggled to articulate his position on terrorism after the Paris attacks, which likely hurt his campaign. Similarly, the candidates' views on Iran could make or break their chances in the primary.

However, the impact of the Iran crisis on the general election is less clear. Republicans have traditionally been seen as better at protecting the country from external threats, but the gap has narrowed during the Trump era. Trump's approval rating has been stable despite several major news events, and it's unclear whether the current crisis will change that.

The "rally-around-the-flag effect," where a president's approval rating increases during times of crisis, is not a guarantee. Factors such as the seriousness of the event, the country's war fatigue, and media coverage can influence the size and likelihood of the effect. In this case, the factors suggest that a rally-around-the-flag effect is unlikely.

Ultimately, the most plausible theory is that opinion on Iran will break down along partisan lines, with little impact on the general election. Elite cues, such as the president's critics supporting or opposing a conflict, drive public opinion on foreign policy. As the elite opinion is currently split along partisan lines, public opinion is likely to follow suit.

Title: Obama's Syria Choices Haunted by Iraq War Experience

The Syrian regime's possible use of chemical weapons has presented a dilemma for President Obama, reminiscent of the "slam dunk" phrase used by then-CIA director George Tenet about Iraq's alleged weapons of mass destruction. Tenet later regretted the phrase, as it was used to justify the US-led invasion of Iraq, which has cost thousands of lives and damaged the US reputation.

Fast-forward to the present, and the Iraq War's ghosts are weighing heavily on Obama's decision-making regarding Syria. According to former officials and analysts close to the administration, Obama and his top advisers are hesitant to get it wrong again, fearing another costly and lengthy military intervention.

Obama's initial assertion that the Syrian regime's use of chemical weapons would be a "red line" that would trigger a US military response has been met with skepticism. Critics argue that the "small scale" use of chemical weapons does not meet the threshold, while some lawmakers, such as Senator John McCain, are calling for more decisive action.

The Obama administration's "red line" statement has left room for maneuver, with the president warning that "a red line for us is we start seeing a whole bunch of chemical weapons moving around or being utilized." However, some experts see this as a loophole big enough to fly a cruise missile through.

The debate surrounding Syria's use of chemical weapons has sparked a review of history, with some drawing parallels to the controversial Tonkin Gulf Resolution, which gave President Lyndon Johnson authority to conduct war in Vietnam without a formal declaration.

As the Obama administration weighs its options, retired Marine Corps General Anthony Zinni warned that "the trouble with statements like that is you can get drawn into military operations." The US is now faced with the dilemma of whether to intervene in Syria, a decision that will have significant implications for Obama's legacy.

Title: Trump Signs Executive Order Encouraging Police Reform, Critics Say Falls Short

President Trump signed an executive order on Tuesday, aimed at improving police training and encouraging departments to adopt higher certification standards on use of force. The move comes amid growing pressure to address police brutality and racial disparities in law enforcement following the killing of George Floyd.

The order creates a database to track officers with multiple instances of misconduct and encourages departments to involve social workers and mental health professionals in calls related to homelessness, mental illness, and addiction. It also bans the use of chokeholds, except when an officer feels their life is endangered. However, critics argue that the order falls short of addressing systemic issues and does not provide practical solutions to curb police violence.

The order was met with mixed reactions, with some praising the move as a step forward, while others criticized it as an empty gesture. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi called the order "weak" and "sadly and seriously short" of what is required to combat racial injustice and police brutality.

The executive order does not address concerns about racial disparities in policing, with many arguing that police disproportionately target African Americans and people of color. Trump defended law enforcement, saying the vast majority of officers are selfless and courageous public servants, and denounced proposals to defund police departments.

The order also does not address the concerns of activists who have rallied behind the slogan "defund the police," which they say would involve taking some money given to departments and using it for mental health, social work, and other functions apart from patrol-style policing. Trump and Republicans have seized on what they call "extreme ideas" about abolishing police departments altogether.

The exact details of the order are still unclear, but it is expected to face scrutiny and criticism from both sides of the political aisle.

Title: The Illusion of Money's Power in Presidential Elections

The notion that a candidate's wealth or financial backing can guarantee success in a presidential election is a common misconception. History has shown that even candidates with significant financial resources have failed to win the election. Examples include Hillary Clinton in 2008 and Jeb Bush in 2016, who both had significant financial advantages but ultimately fell short.

This phenomenon is not new, with notable examples dating back to Ross Perot in 1992. The latest example is Howard Schultz, who is expected to run in the 2020 election. Even David Koch, the Libertarian Party's vice presidential candidate in 1980, is a testament to the idea that money alone is not enough to guarantee success.

While a minimum amount of money is necessary to run a campaign, it is not the most important factor. The real significance of money lies in its ability to determine which candidates are taken seriously by the media. Consultants and TV ads are the primary recipients of campaign funds, with many candidates spending the majority of their funds on TV ads. However, these ads are often ineffective in persuading voters and come at a premium.

In recent years, TV ads have become less effective due to the electorate's polarization. In 2020, earned media will play a crucial role, with social media platforms like Facebook and Instagram becoming increasingly important. While some voters may be persuaded by TV ads, many more are influenced by their friends and peers.

The 2020 presidential election will be a test of whether candidates can effectively utilize social media to reach and persuade voters. The first-quarter fundraising totals for each candidate will be closely tracked, providing insight into their campaign's financial strength and strategy.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Authorizes Subpoena for Full Mueller Report and Underlying Evidence

The House Judiciary Committee has authorized Chairman Jerry Nadler to issue a subpoena for special counsel Robert Mueller's full report and all underlying evidence, giving him the discretion to do so at any time. This move is likely to launch a legal confrontation between Congress and the Justice Department. However, Nadler indicated that he will not issue the subpoena immediately, instead giving Attorney General William Barr time to reconsider his decision to redact the report.

The committee also authorized subpoenas for five former senior aides to President Donald Trump, including former chief of staff Reince Priebus, former adviser Steve Bannon, former White House counsel Don McGahn, McGahn's former deputy Ann Donaldson, and former communications director Hope Hicks. The authorization puts Congress on aggressive footing while Barr reviews Mueller's report and redacts several categories of information.

Democrats have argued that Congress should have access to all information, even if it is blacked out of the version of the report Barr makes public. They note that Republicans received material in all four categories when they demanded documents from the Justice Department over the past two years. Barr has indicated he intends to provide the redacted version of the report to Congress by mid-April and has offered to testify before Congress in early May. House Democrats rejected that offer as insufficient and demanded he testify immediately.

Republicans on the Judiciary Committee have criticized the subpoena effort as a partisan push to attack the president. Rep. Doug Collins (R-Ga.) said Democrats are asking Barr to violate laws and regulations to reveal redacted information. Collins also suggested that some of the Trump aides who Democrats authorized subpoenas for have indicated a willingness to cooperate.

Title: Romney Seeks Momentum Boost After Debate Season, Claims Enthusiasm and Support on the Rise

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, expressed confidence and optimism on Tuesday, stating that the head-to-head debates with President Obama had "super-charged" his campaign. Speaking to a crowd of approximately 6,000 supporters outside Las Vegas, Romney emphasized the growing enthusiasm and support for his campaign.

Romney renewed his attack on Obama's second-term agenda, claiming that the president's campaign is struggling to present a clear agenda. "He's been reduced to trying to defend characters on Sesame Street and word games of various kinds, and then misfired attacks after one and another," Romney said. "You know the truth is that attacks on me are not an agenda."

Romney also highlighted his campaign's momentum, stating that after four debates, including a vice presidential sit-down, "we haven't heard an agenda from the president, and that's why his campaign is taking on water and our campaign is full steam ahead."

A CNN instant poll showed that Obama had a slight edge in the most recent debate, focused on foreign policy. However, Romney's senior adviser, Kevin Madden, pointed to areas where Romney stood out, such as his stance on China and modernizing the Navy.

Romney's running mate, Paul Ryan, echoed the campaign's confident demeanor, telling the audience that in two weeks, Obama will become a former president, and Romney will be the next President of the United States. Both Romney and Ryan urged the audience to vote early, as polls show a tight race in Nevada, with Obama holding a slight edge.

Title: Trump Administration Backs Judge's Ruling to Strike Down Entire Affordable Care Act

The Trump administration has shifted its stance on the Affordable Care Act (ACA), now supporting a federal judge's ruling that would invalidate the entire law, rather than just certain provisions like protections for patients with pre-existing conditions. This decision has alarmed Democrats, who vow to oppose the move.

In a filing with the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals, three Justice Department lawyers wrote that the department has determined the district court's judgment should be affirmed, stating that the United States is not urging the reversal of any portion of the judgment. This change in position marks a significant shift from the Trump administration's previous stance, which had only sought to strike down certain elements of the ACA.

The ACA, also known as Obamacare, has been the subject of repeated legal challenges since its passage in 2010. The law has transformed the nation's health system, creating new patient protections and reshaping payments for doctors and hospitals. Over 20 million Americans are covered through the ACA's Medicaid expansion and insurance exchanges.

The Trump administration's proposed drug price reforms also rely on provisions contained in the ACA. However, senior Trump health officials have not detailed how they would respond if the entire law is struck down.

The GOP-led states that initially brought the lawsuit, Texas v. United States, had called for the entire law to be invalidated because Congress eliminated the individual insurance mandate penalty. The Trump administration had previously argued that only certain elements of the ACA, such as protections for patients with pre-existing conditions, should be struck down.

House Democrats have denounced the Trump administration's new legal position as "unconscionable," warning that millions of Americans will lose their healthcare if the decision is upheld. The Justice Department spokesperson, Kerri Kupec, stated that the department has determined the district court's comprehensive opinion came to the correct conclusion and will support it on appeal.

Legal experts anticipate that the 5th Circuit's ruling will be appealed to the Supreme Court, regardless of the outcome. If the courts ultimately strike down Obamacare, the consequences could be substantial for patients, healthcare organizations, and other groups that have adapted to the nine-year-old law.

Title: Latino Leaders Focus on Voter Registration and Election Efforts Amidst Delayed Immigration Reform

Article:

Latino leaders and advocacy groups are shifting their focus from protesting President Barack Obama's decision to delay executive action on immigration reform to a strategy of voter registration and election efforts. This change in approach aims to increase political power and influence in Washington to push for an overhaul of the country's immigration system.

Latino groups, unions, and civil rights organizations are working to register voters, raise money to elect more Hispanics to Congress, and highlight ballot initiatives in states like Oregon that would hinder access to driver's licenses. They also plan to launch direct mail and radio and TV ads as Election Day approaches.

The decision by leading Washington advocacy groups not to urge their large voting bloc to stay at home in November confirms the political calculation of senior Democrats on Capitol Hill and in the White House: Latino voters won't abandon the party, even with a delay on executive action. Latino leaders believe that electing more Republicans to Congress weakens the chances of any immigration reform legislation passing and that picking a fight with Obama – their most powerful ally – could backfire.

The White House has also played a role in quelling some anger by holding a series of meetings with stakeholders since the announcement that Obama would not move forward with executive action before the election. However, it remains unclear whether Hispanics will respond to the call, even with the efforts of groups spending millions of dollars on Election Day.

The drive to raise cash has continued, with the Latino Victory PAC and the Congressional Hispanic Caucus BOLD PAC hosting a fundraiser next week. The Hispanic Heritage Month get-out-the-vote movement has registered over 38,000 people online and has more voter registration events planned in Texas, Florida, and Utah.

According to an analysis from the polling firm Latino Decisions, Latino voters could prove decisive in close Senate, House, and gubernatorial races. The firm has identified the Senate contests in Colorado, Michigan, North Carolina, and Georgia as campaigns where Latino voting rates could swing the election. Even in Kansas, where Latinos make up 5.5% of registered voters, Hispanic turnout could swing the election if candidates target them.

The top-tier gubernatorial races for Latino influence include Illinois, Florida, Arizona, Connecticut, Massachusetts, and Texas, according to the firm. If these elections come down to the margins, the growing Hispanic electorate in each state could decide the outcome.

Latino leaders believe that electing more Republicans to Congress weakens the chances of any immigration reform legislation passing and that picking a fight with Obama – their most powerful ally – could backfire.

Title: US Jobs Market Adds 222,000 Jobs in June, Exceeding Expectations

The United States added 222,000 jobs in June, according to the Labor Department's latest report, exceeding economists' expectations of 140,000 to 200,000 jobs. This marks a significant increase from the 152,000 jobs added in May. The unemployment rate has fallen by 0.4% since the start of the year, with the number of unemployed individuals decreasing by 658,000.

The jobs report showed growth in various sectors, including healthcare, social assistance, financial, and mining. Average hourly earnings increased by 4 cents in June, reaching $26.25, with a year-over-year increase of 2.5%. The labor force participation rate remained steady at 62.8%.

Economists were divided on the implications of the jobs report for future interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. Some, like American Action Forum President Douglas Holtz-Eakin, believe the report will allow the Fed to increase rates, while others, like National Association of Federally-Insured Credit Unions Chief Economist Curt Long, think wage growth has stalled, making another rate increase less likely.

The jobs report comes amid President Trump's claims that the media is not giving enough attention to the economy's gains since his presidency. House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi criticized the report, saying it shows an economy where workers are not receiving bigger paychecks. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady and House Democratic Caucus Chairman Joe Crowley called for continued efforts to boost jobs and the economy.

Jason Furman, former Chairman of President Barack Obama's Council of Economic Advisers, described the job gains as "impressive" but wage growth as "disappointing."

Title: Trump Freezes Pay for Federal Workers, Citing Higher Salaries and Benefits

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced that he will freeze pay for civilian federal workers, canceling their automatic 2.1% raise for 2019. The decision has been met with criticism from union bosses and Democratic politicians, but Trump's administration argues that federal workers already receive higher salaries and benefits compared to their private sector counterparts.

According to the Congressional Budget Office, federal workers earn an average salary higher than those in the private sector, with benefits that are 47% richer. Additionally, they receive up to 49 paid days off per year and have a more difficult time being fired, with a firing process that can take up to 120 days. At age 55, federal employees can retire with a gold-plated package, including defined benefits that protect them from inflation.

Trump's decision to freeze pay is seen as a move to "reward good workers" and "remove federal employees who undermine the public trust." In May, Trump issued executive orders making it easier to fire workers for poor performance or misconduct, shortening the performance improvement period from 120 days to 30 days and streamlining the appeals process.

The Office of Personnel Management data shows that only 0.5% of federal workers are terminated each year, compared to 2.5% in the private sector. However, more than half of federal workers approve of Trump's changes, according to a June poll. The changes are also expected to save taxpayers $100 million a year by limiting federal employees' union business activities to 25% of their work hours.

Public-sector unions have challenged the changes in court, with a federal district court judge ruling that the changes must be decided through collective bargaining. The Trump administration is appealing the decision. The unions are also fighting against reforms in the Veterans Administration, where a scandal erupted in 2014 over employees doctored patient waiting lists to make themselves look good. The VA Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act was enacted in 2017 to cut red tape involved in firing and disciplining wrongdoers, but union-driven litigation has held up the reforms.

Trump's ability to protect ailing vets and get taxpayers their money's worth in every department of government depends on winning the battle to restore merit-based management in the federal bureaucracy.

Title: Federal Appeals Court Rules Trump Administration Can Deny Grant Money to "Sanctuary" Jurisdictions

Article:

A federal appeals court has ruled that the Trump administration can deny grant money to "sanctuary" jurisdictions that refuse to cooperate with federal immigration authorities. The 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals in New York overturned a lower court ruling that stopped the administration's 2017 move to withhold grant money from the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant Program. The program dispenses over $250 million a year to state and local criminal justice efforts.

The Justice Department argued that the grant conditions require states and cities to share information about criminals in custody, which the federal government uses to enforce national immigration laws. The court ruled that the conditions are lawful and do not intrude on powers reserved only to states.

The decision conflicts with rulings from other appeals courts across the country, indicating a Supreme Court review is likely. The ruling marks a key win for the administration in its efforts to crack down on "sanctuary" policies that limit local law enforcement cooperation with federal immigration authorities.

The Heritage Foundation's Mike Howell, a former member of the Department of Homeland Security's Office of Legal Counsel, said the ruling is an important development, considering the dependence of states like New York on DOJ grant money. "When you look at the amount of money that flows in via grants generally, the federal government has a lot of power over states and localities," he said. "If you open the door to the federal government being able to condition that grant money, it's a huge deal."

Sanctuary policies generally forbid local law enforcement from honoring detainers, or requests from Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) that they be alerted to an illegal immigrant's release from custody so they can be picked up by ICE and put through deportation proceedings. Proponents of the policies claim it makes cities safer because it encourages illegal immigrants to cooperate with police without fear of deportation. However, the Trump administration has been pushing back by highlighting cases in which criminals are released onto the streets only to re-offend.

Title: Trump's Immigration Order: A Review of the Facts and the Law

The recent controversy surrounding President Trump's immigration order has sparked heated debates and legal challenges. As a neutral journalist, it is essential to examine the facts and the law to understand the context and implications of this issue.

The U.S. Constitution grants the President significant powers in foreign policy, including immigration, as outlined in Section 212(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952. This provision allows the President to suspend the entry of aliens or impose restrictions if deemed necessary. Trump's predecessors, including Barack Obama, have issued similar bans on travel to or from certain countries based on risk assessments.

It is crucial to note that there is no constitutional right for foreign nationals to enter the United States. Instead, it is a privilege granted by the government, as stated in the article. The immigration order put forth by the Trump administration is not unprecedented, as previous presidents have issued similar bans.

The Ninth Circuit Court's decision to uphold a restraining order against Trump's immigration order has been criticized for ignoring federal law and imposing politics over legal reasoning. This has sparked concerns about the role of the judiciary in the country.

The article also touches on the idea of breaking up the Ninth Circuit Court, which has been discussed in the past. In 2004, the Republican-led House passed a bill to split the circuit into three separate entities, but it was rejected by the Senate. The idea of abolishing the Ninth Circuit has also been proposed, but it remains a topic of debate.

In conclusion, the Trump administration's immigration order is a complex issue that requires a nuanced understanding of the facts and the law. While opinions may vary, it is essential to separate fact from fiction and to examine the legal implications of this issue.

Title: Trump Jr. Criticizes BBC for Omitting Key Details in Jerusalem Attack Report

Article:

Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of US President Donald Trump, has once again taken aim at the BBC for what he perceives as biased reporting on an attack in Jerusalem. On July 14, 2017, Trump Jr. tweeted that the BBC's headline "Three Palestinians killed after deadly stabbing in Jerusalem" was misleading, as it did not mention that the three Palestinians were killed after stabbing a female Israeli police officer to death.

This is not the first time Trump Jr. has criticized the BBC for its reporting on Israel. In a previous instance, he called out the outlet for what he deemed "anti-Israel bias." Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu publicly thanked Trump Jr. for his support for Israel.

The BBC's reporting on the recent attack in Jerusalem has been met with criticism from other social media users, who argue that the outlet failed to provide a complete account of the incident. Two Israeli policemen were killed and a third injured in the attack, which was described as a "Muslim terror attack" by some users.

The BBC did provide more information on the victims, identifying them as Advanced Staff Sergeant Major Kamil Shanan, 22, and Advanced Staff Sergeant Major Hail Sattawi, 30, both of whom were Druze from Israel's northern Galilee region.

It is worth noting that Trump Jr. is currently facing scrutiny over his own actions, including a meeting with a Russian lawyer last year. Some lawmakers are calling for him to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee.

Title: North Korea Vows to Restart Nuclear Reactor, Escalating Tensions on Korean Peninsula

North Korea has announced its intention to restart a nuclear reactor at the Yongbyon nuclear plant, which could potentially produce about one bomb's worth of plutonium per year. This move is seen as a further escalation of tensions on the Korean Peninsula, already heightened by the country's almost daily threats.

According to a statement from North Korea, the country will begin work to restart all facilities at the Yongbyon plant without delay, citing the need to resolve an acute electricity shortage and bolster its nuclear-armed forces. Analysts believe that Pyongyang now views its nuclear arms program as essential for national security and non-negotiable.

The plutonium reactor was shut down in 2007 as part of international nuclear disarmament talks, which have since stalled. The resumption of plutonium production and other facilities at the main Yongbyon nuclear complex is likely to boost fears in Washington and among its allies about North Korea's timetable for building a nuclear-tipped missile that can reach the United States.

The Pentagon has sent two F-22 Raptor fighter jets to South Korea to participate in U.S.-South Korean military drills, following last week's news that nuclear-capable B-2 stealth bombers conducted a training flight to the Korean Peninsula. The North, led by its young leader Kim Jong Un, has blamed the U.S.-South Korean military drills for its recent actions, including cutting hotlines to the South and annuling the 1953 armistice that ended open warfare on the peninsula.

South Korea's new president, Park Geun-hye, described the security situation as "grave," but believes that discouraging North Korea from provocations through strong diplomatic and military deterrence is just as important as punishing the communist nation after provocations.

State Department spokeswoman Victoria Nuland expressed skepticism about whether North Korea will actually follow through on its vow, stating, "There's a long way to go between a stated intention and actually being able to pull it off." The White House has confirmed that the U.S. is paying close attention to the situation on the Korean Peninsula, with the entire national security team focused on the issue.

Title: FBI Director Comey's Letter on Clinton Emails Sparks Controversy Ahead of Election

The FBI Director James Comey's decision to announce the review of newly discovered emails related to Hillary Clinton's use of a private server has sparked controversy and criticism from top Clinton campaign officials. On Sunday, Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta called the letter "long on innuendo, short on facts," stating that Comey could not even confirm whether the emails contained significant information. Podesta urged Comey to provide more details about the emails and questioned the timing of the announcement, just 11 days before the election.

Attorney General Loretta Lynch also objected to Comey's decision, citing department policy against taking actions that could interfere with an election. Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook expressed similar concerns, stating that Comey's action could fuel conspiracy theories and urged him to provide more information about the emails.

Meanwhile, Trump campaign officials praised Comey's decision, with Trump running mate Mike Pence saying it would not alter the campaign. However, Democratic vice presidential nominee Tim Kaine called the move "extremely puzzling" and a "distraction," questioning why Comey would release incomplete information about an ongoing investigation.

The controversy surrounding Comey's letter has sparked debate among lawmakers, with Senator Ron Johnson, chairman of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, stating that the investigation has been "bungled from the start." Representative Adam Schiff, the senior Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, called it a "terrible error in judgment" and urged Comey to acknowledge the mistake and reiterate that there is no new evidence that alters the previous conclusion that Clinton had been "extremely careless" in using a private server.

The FBI obtained a warrant to review the emails, which were found during an investigation into former Congressman Anthony Weiner's sexting scandal. The emails were linked to Huma Abedin, a longtime Clinton aide and adviser, who has been fully cooperating with the FBI.

Title: Democratic Primary Debate: Candidates' Search Traffic Reveals Surprising Standouts

The first Democratic primary debate saw a crowded stage of 10 candidates vying for attention, with some managing to stand out more than others. According to tweets and Google search data, two candidates in particular saw a significant spike in search traffic: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio and Hawaii Rep. Tulsi Gabbard.

De Blasio's strategy was to challenge Sen. Elizabeth Warren's progressive credentials, attempting to run to her left and gain attention. He achieved this by interrupting fellow candidates and trying to upend the debate format. Gabbard, on the other hand, gained attention by engaging in a foreign policy debate with Ohio Rep. Tim Ryan, correcting him on the 9/11 attacks and ultimately winning the upper hand.

Gabbard's sudden surge in search traffic may not be entirely unexpected, as her Wikipedia page views have been steadily increasing over the past week, aside from Sen. Warren's. This suggests that people are not just curious about who she is, but are actively seeking more information about her.

Google Trends data reveals that people from early primary states, such as New Hampshire and Iowa, are driving the interest in Gabbard. This could indicate that she is gaining traction among voters who are paying attention to the primary debates.

While Gabbard's hawkish stance on terrorism and her support for Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad have raised eyebrows among some Democrats, her sudden surge in search traffic suggests that she is gaining attention and recognition. However, it remains to be seen whether this interest will translate into sustained support and a viable presidential campaign.

Title: The Case for Immigration: A Call to Action for Progressives

The debate surrounding immigration in the United States has long been dominated by claims of its supposed harms, with critics citing increased crime rates, lower wages, and strain on government budgets as reasons to restrict legal immigration. While some argue that these claims are not entirely accurate, the proponents of immigration have often failed to present a clear and concise case for its benefits.

According to Andrew Selee, president of the Migration Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research group, the left has struggled to articulate why immigration is important to the country. This lack of a coherent political case has allowed the anti-immigration movement to dominate the conversation.

The border crisis has drawn significant attention, often overshadowing the benefits of legal immigration. However, it is essential to note that three-quarters of immigrants are here legally, and the foreign-born population is nearing record highs. As restrictionists push for cuts in legal admissions, progressives must make a stronger case for the importance of immigration.

The progressive movement has historically focused on the need for legalization and has been driven by a desire to protect the rights of undocumented immigrants. This perspective views undocumented individuals as victims of poverty and violence, and many have been in the United States for over 15 years, with some having American children. Progressives warn that deportation campaigns can destabilize entire communities, harming both immigrants and natives.

To sustain the longest and most diverse epoch of mass migration in American history, progressives must develop a clear and concise case for why immigration is essential to the country. This requires moving beyond the emotional appeals of "our diversity is our strength" and instead providing concrete examples of how immigration benefits the economy, slows demographic decline, and enhances American society.

Title: Economists Urge Continued Direct Cash Payments to Americans Amid Economic Uncertainty

Article:

A group of 153 economists, described as "left-leaning" by Reuters, have signed an open letter urging US policymakers to continue providing direct cash payments to Americans until the economy is stronger. The letter, organized by the Economic Security Project and The Justice Collaborative, claims that direct cash payments can improve financial security, boost consumer spending, and speed up the recovery. However, critics argue that these payments have not achieved the desired effects and have instead contributed to the economic collapse of the United States.

The letter was signed by several prominent economists, including Jason Furman, who chaired the Council of Economic Advisers during the Obama Administration, Claudia Sahm, a former Fed economist, Darrick Hamilton from the Kirwan Institute for the Study of Race and Ethnicity at The Ohio State University, and Indivar Dutta-Gupta, co-executive director at the Georgetown Center on Poverty and Inequality.

The economists argue that the $600 supplement added to weekly unemployment benefits, which is set to expire at the end of the month, will leave jobless Americans at risk of facing a cash cliff while jobs are still scarce. They are urging Congress to extend the program to ensure financial security for those affected.

The letter comes as Congressional lawmakers are on a two-week recess and will face pressure to make decisions when they reconvene in late July. With the US budget deficit reaching record levels, some critics argue that the government is printing money and using it to plug the deficit, which could lead to financial ruin.

It is worth noting that the economists' letter does not provide a clear plan for how the economy will recover or how the direct cash payments will be funded.

Title: Census Data Reveals Population Decline in Liberal States, Potential Loss of Congressional Seats

The United States Census Bureau has released population estimates, which show that liberal states New York and California are experiencing an exodus, leading to a potential loss of congressional seats. According to the data, these two states, along with 25 others and the District of Columbia, have lost residents due to domestic migration over the past two years.

New York, in particular, has seen a significant decline in population, with a total population decrease of 0.4% since 2010, ranking 46th-lowest out of 50 states. This stagnation is expected to result in the loss of one or two congressional seats in the coming years.

Experts attribute the decline to the high cost of living in New York, including high taxes, regulations, and housing costs, making it unaffordable for many residents. Staten Island Republican Councilman Joe Borelli noted that both immigrants and native New Yorkers are leaving the state due to its unaffordable nature.

Similarly, California's population growth has slowed significantly, and for the first time in its history, it may lose a congressional seat. The Los Angeles Times reported that the state's economic woes are making it harder for people to make a living, leading to an exodus. According to William Frey, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, California's population migration could result in the loss of a seat in the US House of Representatives.

Frey's analysis of census data suggests that Texas may gain three seats after the 2020 decennial count, while Arizona, Colorado, and Oregon may gain one seat each. The apportionment population count includes the state's total resident population, citizens and non-citizens, as well as a count of overseas federal employees and their dependents who have that state listed as their home state in their employers' administrative records, according to the US Census Bureau.

Title: Trump to Announce Executive Action on Census Citizenship Question Despite Ongoing Court Challenges

The Trump administration is planning to announce an executive action on the citizenship question for the 2020 census, despite ongoing court challenges, according to two administration officials. The announcement is expected to take place on Thursday afternoon, with President Trump holding a news conference in the Rose Garden or elsewhere at the White House.

The administration's efforts to add the question have been blocked in the courts due to challenges from some U.S. states and civil rights groups. Critics argue that asking about citizenship in the census discriminates against racial minorities and is aimed at giving Republicans an unfair advantage in elections. Trump and his supporters, however, believe it makes sense to know how many non-citizens are living in the country.

The administration is still ironing out the details of the action, which is likely to be an executive order. The case has already made its way to the U.S. Supreme Court, which last month ruled against the Republican president's first attempt to add the question, saying the administration's rationale was "contrived." The Department of Justice has since sought to shake up its legal team, but a second federal judge rejected its efforts, saying it had to offer detailed reasoning for the change.

Attorneys within the Trump administration are studying the census issue and intend to keep the president's order within the confines of the Supreme Court decision, but they are aware that whatever action he takes is likely to be challenged in court again. The U.S. Constitution specifically assigns the job of overseeing the census to Congress, limiting a president's authority, which could complicate any effort to add the question via presidential missive.

The census is used to determine how many seats each state gets in the U.S. House of Representatives and also affects how billions of dollars in federal funds are doled out across the country.

Title: Congressional Republicans Push for Medicare and Medicaid Cuts in Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

The ongoing negotiations over the fiscal cliff and deficit reduction have sparked a renewed debate over the future of Medicare and Medicaid. Congressional Republicans are advocating for significant cuts to these programs, which have been a cornerstone of public welfare for over half a century. However, post-election polls suggest that a majority of voters from both President Obama and Mitt Romney's camps oppose large-scale Medicare cuts as a means to reduce the budget deficit.

The Obama administration has already pledged to extract over $1 trillion in savings from Medicare and Medicaid over the next decade, primarily through measures such as reducing annual increases in Medicare reimbursements for hospitals, nursing homes, and other healthcare providers, as well as eliminating unjustified subsidies for private Medicare Advantage plans. The Affordable Care Act, passed in 2010, is expected to reduce projected Medicare spending by $716 billion over 10 years.

In his 2013 budget proposal, President Obama suggested additional cuts of $340 billion over 10 years, achieved through measures such as requiring drugmakers to pay rebates to Medicare in certain circumstances, reducing payments to healthcare providers for treating patients recently discharged from the hospital, reducing coverage of bad debts owed by patients, and increasing premiums for high-income beneficiaries.

While some savings may be achievable through further negotiations with healthcare providers, experts agree that there are limited options for reducing Medicare and Medicaid spending beyond these measures. The debate highlights the complexity of addressing the fiscal cliff and deficit reduction, as any significant changes to these programs may have far-reaching consequences for vulnerable populations.

**Senate Impeachment Trial to Conclude with Closing Arguments and Vote**

The Senate impeachment trial of President Donald Trump is set to resume on Monday at 11 a.m. EST, with both sides preparing to make their final arguments before senators vote on whether to convict or acquit the president on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

The two articles of impeachment, approved by the Democratic-controlled House on December 18, stem from allegations that Trump held up military aid to pressure Ukraine into announcing investigations for his political benefit, including one involving former Vice President Joe Biden, a Democratic rival in the 2020 election. Trump has denied any wrongdoing, and his defense team has argued that the House failed to prove its case and that the charges are too subjective.

The Senate is expected to vote on Wednesday, with a two-thirds majority required for conviction. With a 53-47 Republican majority, it is likely that Trump will be acquitted.

Lead House impeachment manager Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) said Sunday that Democrats "proved the corrupt scheme that they charged in the articles of impeachment." He emphasized that even if the Senate votes to acquit, "it's enormously important that the president was impeached" and that the House's efforts to expose his wrongdoing will help slow the momentum away from democratic values.

Senators will have two hours to deliver speeches explaining their views on the charges before voting. GOP Sens. Joni Ernst (Iowa) and Lamar Alexander (Tenn.) said Sunday that while Trump's actions were not impeachable, he should have gone through the Department of Justice if he had concerns about Biden and his son's former position on the board of Burisma, a Ukrainian energy company.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) said Sunday that "the day of reckoning is coming for congressional and Senate oversight of Joe Biden" and plans to investigate the matter further.

Title: Critique of Leftist Ideology and Opposition to Border Wall

The article by Dennis Prager, a nationally syndicated radio talk-show host and columnist, presents a critique of the left-wing ideology and its opposition to building a wall on the United States' southern border. Prager argues that the left's opposition to the wall is based on false claims, which he believes are lies. He questions whether leftists genuinely believe these lies or are simply engaging in deception.

Prager highlights several examples of what he considers left-wing falsehoods, including the notion that the United States and the Soviet Union were equally responsible for the Cold War, and that men and women are the same except for body parts. He also questions the left's stance on issues such as rape culture in universities and the idea that the statement "There is only one race: the human race" is a racist statement.

Prager also challenges the left's argument that the country cannot afford the $5.7 billion allocated for the border wall, pointing out that the Democrats have approved $1.3 billion for border security in the past. He notes that California has allocated $77 billion for a high-speed train project, despite being $2 trillion in debt.

Regarding the effectiveness of the wall, Prager argues that the left's claims that it would be ineffective are contradicted by their own past support for border fencing. He cites examples of Democrats, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Chuck Schumer, who have supported fencing in the past.

Prager concludes that the left's opposition to the wall is either based on delusion or deception, and that their actions are driven by a desire to humiliate the President of the United States.
