The order also notes that some local governments have responded to protests by taking down monuments, and that this is a disservice to the country's common inheritance. The order emphasizes that these statues are not just physical structures, but symbols of American history and heritage.

President Trump also spoke about the issue during a Fourth of July celebration at Mount Rushmore, accusing those who want to tear down Confederate statues of wanting to "overthrow the American Revolution" and fundamentally change the country. He emphasized that this left-wing cultural revolution is designed to destroy the very civilization that rescued billions from poverty, disease, violence, and hunger, and lifted humanity to new heights of achievement, discovery, and progress.

The National Garden of American Heroes is expected to be open prior to July 4, 2026, the 250th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence.

Title: Congressman Jeff Van Drew Leaves Democratic Party, Citing Disagreements on Policy and Values

Congressman Jeff Van Drew officially switched parties from the Democratic Party to the Republican Party on Thursday, citing disagreements on policy and values. During a meeting in the Oval Office, Van Drew explained that he had grown increasingly uncomfortable with the Democratic Party's shift towards "far-left anti-American policies."

Van Drew stated that he had been a Democrat for many years, but a meeting with a local county chairman two weeks ago led him to reevaluate his party affiliation. The county chairman threatened him, saying that if he didn't vote to impeach Trump, the chairman would "destroy" him. This incident, combined with past experiences, made Van Drew question whether he wanted to continue being a Democrat.

Van Drew also mentioned that he had previously considered switching parties when he was in the New Jersey state Senate. He recalled voting on two bills that promoted faith and patriotism, which were met with disapproval from far-left Democrats. He noted that these bills were "very Republican" and that he believes in American exceptionalism.

Van Drew emphasized his support for capitalism, stating that socialism has no place in the United States. He believes that the country can afford to give people opportunities to succeed and that being bipartisan is not a bad thing. He also criticized the "extreme" members of the Democratic Party who told him that being bipartisan would make him "like a Republican."

Van Drew specifically took aim at Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY) and the Green New Deal, stating that it's something that should never be considered. He believes that the country can have a strong environment and a good economy simultaneously.

In addition, Van Drew mentioned that lowering taxes, balancing the budget, and honoring first responders and veterans are important to him. He also noted that the Democratic Party is becoming less tolerant of diverse thought as it becomes more extreme.

Former Republican President Ronald Reagan was one of Van Drew's favorite presidents, and he agreed with Reagan's comment that the Democratic Party had left him.

Title: Hispanic Republicans Warn of Consequences of Trump's Nomination

A group of about two dozen Hispanic leaders met in Colorado on Tuesday, expressing concerns about the potential consequences of Donald Trump capturing the Republican presidential nomination. They warned that if Trump becomes the nominee, the Republican Party may lose the Hispanic vote and ultimately the White House.

The meeting, which was described as the first of its kind, was attended by Alfonso Aguilar, director of American Principles Project's Latino Partnership and a former official in the administration of President George W. Bush. Aguilar stated that if Trump is the nominee, "we think if you are the candidate that Republicans will lose the White House."

The Hispanic leaders plan to monitor the rest of the GOP field and may decide to write off other candidates based on their immigration views. They emphasized that immigration is a threshold issue for many Hispanics, who will not consider candidates who do not support robust legalization.

The Trump campaign declined to comment on the meeting. Trump has downplayed the idea that he has fallen out of favor with Hispanics, despite an AP-GFK poll showing 72% of Latinos view him unfavorably, compared to 11% who see him in a positive light.

The debate on Wednesday, hosted by CNBC, may focus more on immigration, which is a crucial issue for many Hispanic voters. The meeting was billed as the first of its kind, and attendees have scheduled another meeting a day before the December 15 debate in Nevada, which is home to many Latino voters.

The Hispanic leaders also highlighted how President Obama broke his promise to push an immigration fight during his first year in office and how Hillary Rodham Clinton, the likely 2016 Democratic nominee, said last year that illegal immigrant children surging across the U.S.-Mexico border should be sent home.

The issue of immigration has divided the GOP field, with some candidates, such as former Gov. Jeb Bush and Sen. Marco Rubio, backing a pathway to legal status for illegal immigrants, while others, like Sen. Ted Cruz, have vowed to oppose "amnesty" and support expanding legal immigration. Trump has focused on the enforcement side of the debate and signaled he is open to reducing legal immigration.

The Hispanic leaders warned that if Trump becomes the nominee, they will not support him and may even encourage Latinos to write in their own candidate. Aguilar stated that it would be "naive" to suggest that Trump is the only GOP candidate who could jeopardize the party's chances of winning over more Hispanics.

Title: American High School Students' Views on Free Speech Raise Concerns

The recent survey conducted by the Knight Foundation has raised concerns about the views of American high school students on free speech. The survey found that while 91% of students believe that unpopular speech is a protected right, only 64% believe that free speech is more important than protecting someone from being offended. This disparity highlights the complexity of the issue and the need for a nuanced understanding of the First Amendment.

The survey also showed that students of color are less likely to prioritize free speech over protecting someone from being offended, with smaller majorities of Asian, Hispanic, and black students holding this view. This raises concerns about the potential for cultural and societal pressures to influence students' views on free speech.

The survey's findings are a mixed bag, with some positive trends and some red flags. While the percentage of students who believe that unpopular speech is a protected right has increased by eight points since 2004, the fact that only 64% of students prioritize free speech over protecting someone from being offended is a cause for concern.

The survey's results also highlight the importance of defining what constitutes "hate speech" and how it should be addressed. The quote from David Burge, "I'll let you ban hate speech when you let me define hate speech," underscores the need for a clear and consistent definition of hate speech that balances individual rights with the need to protect others from harm.

The survey's findings are a reminder of the ongoing debate about the role of free speech in American society. While some may argue that certain forms of speech are too extreme or offensive to be protected, others believe that the First Amendment's safeguards of fundamental rights are essential to a healthy and functioning democracy.

Ultimately, the survey's results suggest that there is no easy answer to the question of how to balance individual rights with the need to protect others from harm. However, by engaging in open and respectful dialogue, Americans can work towards a better understanding of the complexities of free speech and the importance of protecting individual rights while also promoting a safe and inclusive society.

Title: House Republicans Propose Funding Measure to Ease Military Readiness Cuts

The House Republicans have introduced a spending measure aimed at providing more funding for military readiness while easing the impact of across-the-board cuts on agencies such as the FBI and the Border Patrol. The proposal would fund day-to-day federal operations through September and prevent a potential government shutdown later this month.

The measure would award the Defense and Veterans Affairs departments their detailed 2013 budgets, while other agencies would be frozen at 2012 levels and then subject to the 5% domestic agency cuts and 7.8% Pentagon cuts ordered by President Barack Obama. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that these cuts would slow the economy by 0.6% and cost about 750,000 jobs.

The new House Republicans' legislation would provide an increase for military operations and maintenance efforts as well as veterans' health programs, but would put most of the rest of the government on budget autopilot. Domestic agencies would face reductions exceeding 5% compared to last year, but the FBI and the Border Patrol would be able to maintain current staffing levels and avoid furloughs.

The proposal would also provide about $2 billion more than the current level to increase security at U.S. embassies and diplomatic missions worldwide. The across-the-board cuts would carve $85 billion in spending from the government's $3.6 trillion budget for this year, concentrating the cuts in the approximately $1 trillion allocated to the day-to-day agency operating budgets set by Congress each year.

President Obama has convened the first Cabinet meeting of his second term to discuss next steps, stating that he is continuing to seek out Republican partners to reach a deal to ease or head off the cuts. The new Republican funding measure is set to advance through the House on Wednesday.

Title: US Economy Adds 227,000 Jobs in January, Surpassing Expectations

The United States economy added 227,000 jobs in January, according to the first jobs report of the new administration. The White House attributed the strong hiring to President Trump's efforts to turn the economy around, citing recent polls showing increased consumer confidence.

The Labor Department reported that the jobless rate rose from 4.7 percent to 4.8 percent, as 76,000 more workers entered the workforce to look for jobs. Employers in the retail, construction, and financial sectors hired the most workers, according to the report.

The strong hiring surpassed expectations, with the jobless rate rising slightly. Average hourly earnings were up 3 cents to $26 in January, compared to December's 6-cent increase. For the year ended January 31, wages increased 2.5 percent.

White House press secretary Sean Spicer attributed the job growth to President Trump's efforts, saying that the president's campaign promise to "make America work again" had already begun to take effect before he took office. Spicer also backed away from President Trump's criticism during the campaign that the Labor Department's employment levels underestimated the jobless rate.

The government also revised its estimate down for job creation in November and December, lowering the total number of jobs created in that period by 39,000.

While the job growth is a positive sign, Spicer noted that there is still more work to be done to ensure every American who wants a job has the opportunity to find one. The president's jobs agenda is described as "big and bold," with Spicer emphasizing that the administration is committed to turning the economy around.

Title: The Republican Party's Struggle to Win Elections Amidst Internal Divisions

The real unemployment rate, also known as the U6 figure, has reached a 17-year low, largely attributed to the Trump Administration's deregulation efforts and tax cuts. This has led to a prosperous economy for many Americans. However, the Trump Administration still faces challenges, including government spending issues, the failure to repeal Obamacare, and significant wealth disparities.

Despite the positive economic developments, the Republican Party is struggling to win elections, particularly in special elections in 2018 and the upcoming midterms. This is partly due to the party's internal divisions, which have been exacerbated by the Trump Administration's policies.

The Republican Party is often described as a "tentpole party" due to its internal divisions. Republicans have different beliefs on issues such as international trade, immigration, and social issues, making it difficult to find common ground. The party's divisions are further complicated by the fact that Donald Trump is not on the ballot, making it unclear why voters should support the GOP.

The article suggests that the Republican Party needs to more fully embrace Trumpism, take a stance on trade and immigration, and wage the Culture War. The party also needs to address the concerns of blue-collar workers and social conservatives who supported Trump in the 2016 election.

In conclusion, the Republican Party faces significant challenges in winning elections due to its internal divisions and the lack of a clear message. The party needs to find a way to unite its factions and appeal to a broader range of voters if it hopes to succeed in the future.

Title: FBI Re-Opens Investigation into Hillary Clinton's Email Server, Raising Questions About Her Integrity

The FBI has re-opened its investigation into Hillary Clinton's personal email server, just two weeks before the presidential election. The decision was made after the agency uncovered new emails that "appear to be pertinent" to the case, which it is still trying to determine whether they contain classified information and what their significance is.

According to the FBI's letter to Congress, the investigation was reopened due to an "unrelated investigation" into Anthony Weiner's sexting activities, which led to the discovery of the new emails. The FBI is seeking to determine whether the emails contain classified information and whether they are relevant to the original investigation.

The news has raised questions about Hillary Clinton's integrity and whether she is still a viable candidate for the presidency. The FBI's decision to re-open the investigation means that Clinton is once again under criminal investigation, which could impact her ability to campaign and potentially even her ability to serve as president.

The investigation is ongoing, and it is unclear what the outcome will be. However, the fact that the FBI has re-opened the investigation and is still seeking to determine the significance of the new emails suggests that the agency believes the emails are potentially important and could have a significant impact on the case.

It is worth noting that the FBI's decision to re-open the investigation does not necessarily mean that Clinton will be charged or convicted. However, it does raise questions about her judgment and whether she is still a suitable candidate for the presidency.

Title: FBI Whistleblower Sibel Edmonds Criticizes Special Counsel Robert Mueller, Alleging Deep State Ties and Conflicts of Interest

Article:

FBI whistleblower Sibel Edmonds recently appeared on The Alex Jones Show, where she made several explosive claims about Special Counsel Robert Mueller's involvement in the investigation into alleged ties between President Trump and Russia. Edmonds, a former FBI translator, has a history of criticizing Mueller, citing his role in suppressing evidence and issuing gag orders in her own case.

Edmonds stated that Mueller's appointment as special counsel in the Trump-Russia probe was a shock to her, given his past actions. She noted that Mueller had helped suppress evidence and issued gag orders in her own case, and that FBI agents had internally blown the whistle on him for allegedly squashing investigations into terror networks.

Edmonds also highlighted Mueller's close friendship with former FBI Director James Comey and his ties to the deep state, which she believes makes him an unsuitable choice to lead the investigation. She claimed that Mueller had a history of corruption and had invoked the state secrets privilege to protect a terrorist network.

Edmonds also expressed disappointment that lawyers for those under investigation, such as General Michael Flynn, are not taking a more aggressive approach to defend their clients. She believes that there are FBI agents who would testify that Mueller is not an impartial special counsel and that he has conflicts of interest in pursuing Flynn's case.

Edmonds has also discussed Mueller's conflicts of interest on her own website, citing his direct involvement as former FBI Director and his role in covering up and protecting Gulen Networks' criminal operations within the United States. She has demanded that Mueller step down from the investigation.

While Edmonds' claims are serious and concerning, it is essential to note that they are not universally accepted and have not been proven. The investigation into alleged ties between Trump and Russia is ongoing, and Mueller's role as special counsel remains a topic of debate.

Title: Carly Fiorina Enters Republican Presidential Race, Highlights Her Background and Personal Story

Carly Fiorina, the former CEO of Hewlett-Packard, announced her candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination on Monday, both on Good Morning America and through a tweet. Fiorina, who was the first woman to lead a Fortune 20 company, was ousted from her position in 2005 after a boardroom struggle.

Fiorina has a diverse background, having served as a surrogate in John McCain's 2008 presidential campaign and running for the U.S. Senate from California in 2010, where she lost to Democratic incumbent Barbara Boxer. Here are five things you may not know or remember about Fiorina:

After graduating from Stanford University with a degree in medieval history and philosophy, Fiorina's father, a federal appeals court judge, suggested she attend law school. However, Fiorina dropped out after a semester, citing "blinding headaches every day" while studying law. She later earned graduate business degrees from the University of Maryland and MIT.

Fiorina's early career included working for temporary agency Kelly Services, where she was part of a group of mostly female workers dubbed "Kelly girls." She also held secretarial positions while in college, including a stint filing and typing for Hewlett-Packard, the company she would later lead.

Fiorina was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2009 and underwent a double mastectomy. At campaign appearances, women often approach her to share their own experiences as cancer survivors, which Fiorina describes as a "sisterhood."

Fiorina's husband, Frank Fiorina, also has a humble beginnings, having started his career by driving a tow truck for a family-owned body shop. He later became an executive at AT&T.

Fiorina's 2010 Senate campaign ad, featuring a flock of sheep grazing peacefully, took a dramatic turn when one sheep was shown with scary red eyes, symbolizing her opponent, Tom Campbell, as a "wolf in sheep's clothing." The ad became known as the "demon sheep" ad.

Title: Senate Republicans' Healthcare Bill Fails to Gain Traction

The Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's efforts to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA) have come to a halt, with the bill failing to garner enough support to pass. The bill, known as the Better Care Reconciliation Act (BCRA), was met with widespread criticism and lack of enthusiasm from the public and lawmakers alike.

The BCRA's failure is particularly striking given the Republican Party's control of both the White House and Congress. The bill's lack of popularity was evident, with only 12% of the public supporting it. The bill's provisions, which aimed to repeal the individual and employer mandates, allow individuals to purchase catastrophic plans, and block-grant Medicaid funding, were seen as insufficient and unclear.

The bill's failure to address the root issues of the healthcare system, such as high costs and lack of access, has left many wondering what the next steps will be. The article notes that the BCRA's focus on tweaking the existing system rather than making substantial reforms has led to a lack of excitement and engagement from the public.

The article also highlights the challenges facing Congressional Republicans in reforming healthcare, including the need to balance universal access with cost control. The author suggests that a market-based approach could be a viable solution, but notes that it will require big ideas and pragmatic politics.

In conclusion, the failure of the BCRA serves as a reminder of the complexity and challenges of healthcare reform. As the article notes, the stakes are high, and the outcome will have significant implications for the economy and individual Americans.

Title: New Jersey Joins 14 Other States in Allowing Unauthorized Immigrants to Obtain Driver's Licenses

New Jersey has become the 15th state to pass a law allowing unauthorized immigrants to obtain driver's licenses, joining a growing list of states that have taken similar measures. The legislation, passed by the New Jersey Legislature on Monday night, would create two forms of driver's licenses: a federally compliant Real ID license and a "standard" driver's license for driving and identification purposes. Unauthorized immigrants would be able to apply for the latter using foreign passports or driver's licenses, rather than a Social Security number.

The move brings the total number of unauthorized immigrants living in states with driver's license options to nearly 5.3 million, according to 2017 estimates. California, Connecticut, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, Washington, Illinois, Vermont, Maryland, Delaware, Hawaii, Oregon, and New York, as well as Puerto Rico and Washington, D.C., already offer similar licenses.

Research suggests that making driver's licenses available to unauthorized immigrants improves safety. Obtaining a license requires testing and training on road safety, as well as proof that an applicant can get auto insurance. Drivers with licenses are also more willing to cooperate with law enforcement, reducing burdens on police forces.

A 2016 study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences journal found that after California implemented its driver's license law in 2015, hit-and-runs dropped between 7% and 10% on average, amounting to roughly 4,000 fewer such accidents annually.

Policies allowing unauthorized immigrants to obtain driver's licenses also have financial benefits, both for local governments and for drivers. The Fiscal Policy Institute found that state and county governments could collect about $57 million in annual revenue, as well as $26 million in one-time revenues, by issuing 150,000 driver's licenses to unauthorized immigrants in New York City. The researchers also determined that it would likely lower auto insurance premiums overall.

An analysis conducted by New York City found that having a driver's license provides additional financial stability for families and increases employment opportunities for unauthorized immigrants. Having a car allows them to look for jobs and housing that are not located near public transportation.

However, even with a driver's license, unauthorized immigrants may still be at risk for deportation. A lawsuit filed in January claimed that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles had unlawfully targeted unauthorized immigrants by sending their names, photos, car registrations, and other personal information to ICE. The Trump administration has pushed back against efforts to prevent ICE from accessing DMV data, stating that such records allow it to investigate crimes such as human trafficking by "building criminal cases, identifying criminal suspects, and enhancing officer safety."

Title: Giuliani's Activities Under Scrutiny as Associates Face Campaign Finance Charges

Rudy Giuliani, the personal attorney of former President Donald Trump, has largely disappeared from public view since two of his associates, Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman, were arrested on campaign finance charges. The sudden reticence may be due to concerns about his own potential legal peril as his dealings come under scrutiny by federal investigators.

Legal experts point to a range of activities in which Giuliani has engaged over the years that may be of interest to investigators. These include his connections to Ukraine and his efforts to get the then-U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, Marie Yovanovitch, removed from her post. House investigators have reviewed material filed by an anonymous State Department whistleblower that Democrats have called "propaganda" about Yovanovitch that was sent to the State Department by Giuliani.

Giuliani's activities in Ukraine are tied to the indictment of Parnas and Fruman, who face conspiracy, false statement, and other charges linked to alleged campaign finance violations. The indictment recounts an alleged scheme by Parnas and Fruman to get Yovanovitch removed from her post, with the pair allegedly pursuing this goal at the behest of a Ukrainian official. While nothing in the indictment implicates Giuliani, he too was pushing for Yovanovitch's dismissal.

Giuliani's dealings with Parnas and Fruman are also under scrutiny. Parnas has told NPR that he helped translate and arrange interviews for Giuliani with former Ukrainian officials. Parnas's company, Fraud Guarantee, paid Giuliani $500,000 to consult on technology and provide legal advice, Giuliani has said. All of these connections are of potential interest to investigators.

Furthermore, Giuliani's activities in other areas are also being examined. Questions have been raised about his advocacy on issues related to Turkey that align with Ankara's interests. Giuliani reportedly pushed Trump to extradite a Turkish cleric, Fethullah Gulen, who lives in exile in Pennsylvania. The Turkish government has been pressuring the U.S. to hand over Gulen, whom Ankara blames for the failed 2016 coup against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

Giuliani's ties to an Iranian dissident group known as the MEK have also raised eyebrows. The group was listed by the State Department as a foreign terrorist organization before being removed from the list in 2012. Giuliani has made speeches on the group's behalf and has been paid for his efforts. Giuliani told NPR that the Justice Department has never contacted him about his activities and whether they fall under the rubric of foreign lobbying. However, FARA experts say that's an incorrect reading of the law.

The Justice Department has put a recent emphasis on FARA enforcement, particularly in the wake of the Russia investigation. One high-profile setback came in September when former Obama White House counsel Greg Craig was found not guilty of making false statements to the Justice Department about work he did for the Ukrainian government.

Title: Police Officers Involved in Fatal Shooting of Black Man in New Jersey Put on Administrative Leave

A dashboard camera recorded the fatal shooting of 36-year-old Jerame Reid, a black man, by two police officers in Bridgeton, New Jersey. The incident has sparked renewed protests and discussions about racial disparities in police use of force. According to the video, officers Braheme Days and Roger Worley stopped Reid's car for running a stop sign. Days, who is black, warned his partner, Worley, who is white, that he saw a gun in the glove compartment. The officers pulled out their guns, and Days yelled at Reid to show his hands. Reid disobeyed the orders and stepped out of the car with his hands at shoulder level, at which point both officers fired, killing him.

The officers have been placed on administrative leave while prosecutors investigate the shooting. Reid had a prior criminal record, having spent about 13 years in prison for shooting at state troopers when he was a teenager. Days was also involved in Reid's 2014 arrest for drug possession and other crimes.

The Associated Press obtained records showing that Days and Worley were involved in multiple uses of force between 2012 and 2014, with Days involved in 11 incidents and Worley in 23. The AP also found that the two officers were the subjects of multiple complaints alleging abuses of power over the past two years, although all the complaints were dismissed.

Reid's death comes as demonstrators around the country continue to protest racial disparities in the criminal justice system and police use of force. According to available FBI data, police are disproportionately likely to kill black Americans, even in situations where the victim was not attacking anyone else. Some victims were killed while fleeing, committing a felony, or resisting arrest.

The incident is the latest in a string of high-profile police shootings involving black men and boys, including the deaths of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, John Crawford in Ohio, and Tamir Rice in Ohio. Studies have shown that officers may overestimate threats posed by their victims, which may be a result of subconscious racial biases.

Title: Iraq's Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki Deploys Security Forces Amid Government Formation Stalemate

Iraq's Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki has taken steps to consolidate his power, deploying security forces loyal to him around Baghdad and denouncing critics on state television. The move comes as the country struggles to form a new government following parliamentary elections in April.

Maliki's State of Law bloc narrowly won the elections, but the formation of a new government has stalled. The prime minister has accused the country's ethnic Kurdish president, Fouad Masoum, of violating the constitution by not naming a new prime minister. The US and other foreign powers have called for a new unity government to stem sectarian resentment and combat the self-declared Islamic State and its allies.

The deployment of security forces and Maliki's fiery speech have raised concerns among US officials, who are urging the prime minister to step down. A senior Iraqi official described Maliki as "out of his mind" and "living on a different planet," suggesting he is not aware of the chaos he has created.

The situation remains uncertain, with rumors of tanks surrounding the presidential palace and presidential guards on high alert. The US has not confirmed reports of military movements, but will continue to monitor the situation closely.

Finding a replacement candidate for Maliki has proved difficult, as the country's highest court has ruled that his State of Law bloc is the biggest in the new parliament. The ruling has complicated efforts to propose an alternative candidate, as the country's leading cleric and neighboring Iran's Shi'ite establishment have some support for Maliki.

The deputy speaker of Iraq's parliament, Haider al-Abadi, has said that a bloc of Shiite parties is close to choosing a new prime minister, but critics accuse him of sectarianism. Maliki and his advisers fear they could be arrested or assassinated if they lose their grip on power, and have refused to consider stepping aside or endorsing another candidate.

The situation in Iraq remains volatile, with the country struggling to form a new government and the US and other foreign powers urging Maliki to step down.

Title: The Complexities of Immigration: A Nation's Dilemma

The recent federal raid in Sandusky, Ohio, which resulted in the detention of 114 undocumented immigrants, highlights the complexities of the ongoing immigration debate in the United States. The operation, led by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), targeted individuals who had been living and working in the country for decades, some with families and children.

The situation raises questions about the effectiveness of current immigration policies and the moral implications of enforcing them. The deployment of the U.S. military to the southern border, as proposed by President Trump, has sparked controversy and concerns about the potential consequences of such an action.

The caravan of migrants from Guatemala and Honduras, currently making its way to the U.S.-Mexico border, has become a hot topic in the national debate. While some argue that the caravan poses a national security threat, most experts agree that it is primarily a humanitarian crisis, driven by poverty, violence, and political instability in the migrants' home countries.

The debate surrounding the caravan has become increasingly politicized, with both sides using emotional appeals to sway public opinion. The president has stated that he will use the military to stop the caravan if necessary, citing concerns about national security. However, this approach has been met with criticism, as it ignores the principle of Posse Comitatus, which prohibits the military from enforcing civilian laws.

The situation highlights the need for a more nuanced and compassionate approach to immigration. While some argue that building a border wall and deporting undocumented immigrants is the solution, others believe that a more comprehensive and humane approach is necessary. This includes providing a pathway to citizenship for long-time undocumented residents, as well as addressing the root causes of migration, such as poverty and violence.

Ultimately, the complexities of immigration are a reflection of the complexities of the world we live in. As a nation, we must strive to find a balance between national security, economic needs, and humanitarian concerns.

Title: Reddit Shuts Down Over 2,000 Communities with History of Hate Speech

Reddit, a popular online platform with over 430 million monthly visitors, has taken action to curtail hate speech by shutting down over 2,000 communities that have a history of violating its content policy. The move comes amid ongoing protests for gender, racial, and LGBTQ+ equality.

Reddit's decision to purge these communities, which include subreddits such as "The_Donald," a pro-Trump forum, "Gender Critical," a TERF forum, and "CapoTrapHouse," a radical left forum, is a response to several brands vowing to ban advertisements on Facebook in protest of hate speech. The company did not name every community being removed, but provided a list of at least 10, including "The_Donald," "Gender Critical," "CapoTrapHouse," "Dark Humor And Memes," "Consume Product," "Cum Town," "ImGoingtoHellforThis2," "Wojak," and "Soy Boys."

Reddit's administrators have the power to step in when users break the site's rules, and the company argues that these communities consistently broke several rules, including hosting and upvoting rule-breaking content, antagonizing other communities, and refusing to meet basic expectations. The company stated that it has worked in good faith to help these communities preserve their spaces, but has not seen sufficient efforts to comply with its policies.

The specific examples of hate speech include "The_Donald," which has promoted hate speech even before the 2016 election, and "Gender Critical," which has been identified as a TERF forum that consistently denies that trans women are women and has supported JK Rowling's TERF tirade. The subreddit has also had hateful discussions about denying trans women access to bathrooms.

Reddit's decision to take action against hate speech is part of its mission to craft more rules around hate speech and support its communities by taking stronger action against those who try to weaponize parts of the platform against others. The company emphasized that this is just the start of its efforts to address hate speech and that it will continue to work on improving its policies and enforcement.

Title: Conservatives Criticize Mainstream Media as "Fake News," Claiming Bias and Inaccuracies

Conservatives have been actively using the term "fake news" to discredit mainstream media outlets, claiming that they are biased and inaccurate. This trend has been observed across various conservative news media platforms, including websites and social media. The term is often used to deny news reports that are unfavorable to President Trump or his administration.

According to Angelo Carusone, president of Media Matters, a liberal group that monitors news media for bias, the "fake news" label is an effort to erode the mainstream media's credibility and legitimacy. He believes that by applying this term to credible outlets, it becomes more believable to their audience.

Conservative news media outlets have been particularly vocal in their criticism of the mainstream media. Erick Erickson, a writer and radio host, wrote that Andrew F. Puzder, Trump's choice for labor secretary, should be credited for pointing out that minimum wage increases lead to higher unemployment. He labeled those who disagree as pushing "fake news." However, research has shown that the effects of minimum wage increases vary from city to city.

Infowars, a website run by conservative provocateur Alex Jones, labeled a CNN report about Ivanka Trump moving into the White House office reserved for the first lady as "fake news." President Trump himself has used the term to deny news reports, including a recent tweet denying reports that he would stay on as executive producer of "The New Celebrity Apprentice" after taking office in January. However, it is unclear what work, if any, he will do on the show.

Many conservatives argue that the outrage over "fake news" is a result of liberals unwilling to accept Trump's victory and attributing his success to external factors. Laura Ingraham, an author and radio host, believes that "fake news" is just another excuse for the left's failed agenda.

It is worth noting that the term "fake news" has been used by both sides of the political spectrum, with some critics arguing that it is a way to discredit and silence opposing viewpoints.

Title: House Intelligence Committee Subpoenas Rudy Giuliani in Impeachment Inquiry

The House Intelligence Committee has issued a subpoena to President Trump's personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, as part of the ongoing impeachment inquiry into Trump's alleged attempt to pressure Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter Biden. The subpoena, signed by House Intelligence Committee Chair Adam Schiff, House Foreign Affairs Committee Chair Eliot Engel, and House Oversight Committee Chair Elijah Cummings, requires Giuliani to produce documents related to the investigation by October 15.

The subpoena is part of the House's impeachment inquiry into Trump's actions, which includes investigating the extent to which Trump jeopardized national security by pressing Ukraine to interfere with the 2020 election and withholding security assistance provided by Congress to help Ukraine counter Russian aggression. The inquiry also includes an investigation of credible allegations that Giuliani acted as an agent of the President in a scheme to advance his personal political interests by abusing the power of the Office of the President.

The subpoena specifically requests Giuliani produce documents related to his conversations with Ukrainian officials, including a September 19 interview on CNN where he admitted to asking the government of Ukraine to target Vice President Biden. The subpoena also requests Giuliani produce any text messages, phone records, and other communications indicating that he was not acting alone and that other Trump Administration officials may have been involved in the scheme.

The House Intelligence Committee is investigating the extent to which Trump and his administration pressured Ukraine to investigate Biden and his son, as well as any efforts to cover up these matters. The inquiry is ongoing, and Giuliani has been ordered to produce the requested documents by October 15.

Title: Rep. Tulsi Gabbard Protests CNN Over Exclusion from Democratic Town Hall

Rep. Tulsi Gabbard, a Democratic representative from Hawaii, is protesting CNN's decision to exclude her from a Democratic town hall event in New Hampshire, just days before the state's primary on February 11. The event, which will feature eight Democratic presidential candidates, was announced by CNN last week. Gabbard's campaign has expressed disappointment and frustration over her exclusion, citing her strong polling numbers in the state.

The town hall event will take place over two nights, with a lineup of candidates that includes former Vice President Joe Biden, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, businessman Andrew Yang, and billionaire Democratic donor Tom Steyer on the first night, and Sen. Bernie Sanders, former South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg, Sen. Amy Klobuchar, and former Gov. Deval Patrick on the second night. Gabbard was noticeably absent from the list, despite her strong polling numbers in New Hampshire.

Gabbard's campaign has announced plans to hold a demonstration outside the New Hampshire venue where the CNN town halls will take place, in response to her exclusion. The campaign has stated that the move is an attempt to silence Gabbard and limit voters' access to information about her candidacy. "This attempt to silence Tulsi is bigger than one person – it's our right as voters to hear from ALL the candidates, and to have our voices represented," the campaign said.

CNN has not commented on the matter, and it is unclear whether Sen. Michael Bennet and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, the other two candidates not invited to participate, received an invitation.

Title: Senate's Gang of Eight Launches Aggressive Lobbying Campaign to Weaken Conservative Opposition to Immigration Overhaul

The Senate's Gang of Eight, a bipartisan group of senators, is launching an aggressive lobbying campaign to weaken conservative opposition to a sweeping immigration overhaul. The campaign aims to define the bill as a workable compromise on a highly complex issue, one that will help broaden the GOP's reach to Latino and moderate voters.

Hours after the bill was unveiled, Republicans began making their pitch for it on conservative talk radio and urging their colleagues to hold their fire until they've had a chance to analyze it. The push is part of a broader strategy to smooth passage for the complex legislation in the Senate, where the idea is to lure more than just a handful of Republican senators. If a broadly backed bill passed the Senate, House Republicans would be hard-pressed to reject it, proponents believe.

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), a member of the Gang of Eight, said in an interview, "Defining the bill quickly is good. We're going to be aggressive in marketing the bill. We're going to be open-minded about making it better. But this is an all-hands-on-deck approach."

On Wednesday, Graham and Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) made the rounds on conservative talk radio, with Rubio planning for more appearances on Thursday. The initial reaction on the right was far less intense than they anticipated, proponents said. Rubio's offices in Washington and Florida received fewer than 500 calls on immigration, with more than 150 of those in favor of his bill, according to a source in his office.

Some GOP senators were circumspect, saying they would wait and see the details of the bill before making their minds up whether to pick it apart. "I'll take another look at it," said Sen. Thad Cochran (R-Miss.), who voted to block the 2007 bill. "Is that enough for me? I don't want to say yet. But it was a lot better than I thought it was," said Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, about the border security measures.

On the left, Democrats tried to shore up their own base. Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.), another leading supporter, and Democratic senators privately met with a room full of immigration activists to implore them to put aside their fears for the "greater good" of passing the bill. A senior White House official, Cecilia Muñoz, met with House Democrats in House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer's office, offering broad support for the bill, hearing from Democrats worried about elements of the bill's treatment of undocumented immigrants. The White House would also like the bill tweaked.

Title: Supreme Court Endorses Broad Presidential Authority Over Immigration, But Narrows Trump's Travel Ban

The Supreme Court has partially endorsed the administration's view that the president has significant authority to control who crosses the border, stating that the president's powers to limit immigration are "undoubtedly at their peak when there is no tie between the foreign national and the United States." However, the opinion also suggests that some justices may believe that President Trump exceeded his authority when he sought to impose a blanket ban on entry to the United States from certain predominantly Muslim countries.

The court's decision limits the scope of the travel ban, which will be narrower than the one proposed by Trump in his first week in office and a later revised version. The ban will still apply to certain individuals who do not have a "tie" to the United States, but it is unclear which specific individuals will be affected.

The Supreme Court's decision is a rare legal victory for Trump, who had faced criticism from lower courts for imposing a de facto ban on Muslims entering the country. The Department of Homeland Security and Trump himself hailed the decision, stating that it would allow the department to "largely implement the President's executive order." However, critics disputed these assessments, with the American Civil Liberties Union's deputy legal director, Cecillia Wang, saying that the ban will not apply to many people while the court case proceeds.

The court's decision is likely to lead to months of administrative and legal wrangling as consular officials try to determine which individuals are allowed to seek entry into the United States and which are barred by the opinion.

Title: Rockets Hit U.S. Embassy Compound in Baghdad, Minorly Injuring One Person

A reported three rockets struck the U.S. Embassy compound in Baghdad on Sunday, causing minor injuries to one person, according to a U.S. official speaking to CNN. The State Department confirmed the incident, stating that they are aware of reports of rockets landing in the International Zone, but did not provide further details on whether embassy employees were injured.

The security situation in the area remains tense, with Iranian-backed armed groups posing a threat. The State Department has urged the Iraqi government to take action to protect diplomatic facilities. This is not the first incident in recent months, with 14 attacks on U.S. personnel in Iraq attributed to Iran and Iranian-backed militias.

The U.S. Embassy in Baghdad has been a focal point of tensions between the U.S. and Iran. Protests erupted at the embassy after the U.S. struck an Iranian-backed militia, which it claimed killed a U.S. contractor in an attack. The U.S. also killed Iranian General Qassem Soleimani in a strike at the Baghdad airport, prompting Iran to promise retaliation and strike multiple Iraqi bases housing U.S. troops. The attack resulted in the brain injuries of 34 service members, the Pentagon announced on Friday.

The State Department did not directly blame the Sunday strike on Iran, and Iran has not taken responsibility for the attack. Representative Michael McCaul, the ranking Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, tweeted that he is "closely monitoring" the reports of the rocket attacks on the embassy. He emphasized that "violent acts against our diplomatic facilities are simply unacceptable" and called for ensuring the safety of American diplomats, troops, and other Americans in Iraq.

Iraqi Prime Minister Adil Abdul Mahdi condemned the strike, stating that Iraqi forces will investigate to stop future attacks and punish the perpetrators.

Title: MSF Faces Criticism from Employees Over Allegations of Colonialism and White Supremacy

MSF, a global medical humanitarian organization, has been accused by over 1,000 current and former employees of perpetuating colonialism and white supremacy. The employees, who signed a letter to the organization's management, have demanded an investigation into MSF's activities, which include providing medical services worldwide and previously transporting migrants across the Mediterranean from North Africa.

The letter, which was signed by board members in the UK and southern Africa, among others, criticized MSF's "decades of power and paternalism" and denounced the organization's alleged "white savior" mentality. The criticism came in response to a statement released by MSF's Italian branch, which sparked controversy by using the phrase "all lives matter." Some saw the phrase as conflicting with the Black Lives Matter movement.

MSF's Italian president, Claudia Lodesani, later apologized for the statement, stating that the organization fully supports the Black Lives Matter movement and condemns racism and all discrimination. International President Dr. Christos Christou welcomed the letter, saying that MSF's priority is to shift decision-making closer to where the needs are and involve patients and communities in designing intervention strategies.

The controversy comes as MSF halted its partnership with French migrant transport NGO SOS Méditerranée in April. The Ocean Viking, a ship operated by SOS Méditerranée, has since resumed operations, rescuing around 180 migrants earlier this month. The ship was initially denied access to ports in Italy and Malta, but was later granted access after unrest among the migrants on board, including threats to the crew and suicide attempts, was reported.

Title: Trump Walks Out of Infrastructure Meeting with Democrats, Leaving Uncertainty on White House Priorities

The meeting between President Donald Trump and Democratic leaders on infrastructure development ended abruptly on Wednesday, with Trump refusing to shake hands with Democrats and leaving the meeting. The sudden departure has left lawmakers scrambling to assess the impact on other White House priorities, including a pending trade deal with Canada and Mexico.

The meeting was called to discuss infrastructure development, but Trump's frustration with Democratic investigations into his presidency led to the impasse. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi accused Trump of throwing a "temper tantrum" for all to see. Trump denied the accusation, claiming he was "extremely calm" during the meeting.

The White House has indicated that Trump is prepared to put off most of his legislative agenda until after the 2020 election, acknowledging that Democrats and Republicans are unlikely to reach consensus on many issues. Trump has also stated that he will not work on legislation until Democratic investigations into his administration are complete.

The sudden departure from the meeting has left the status of several White House priorities uncertain. The U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), a trade deal that would replace NAFTA, faces a high hurdle in the Democratic-controlled House and may be further delayed by the latest squabble. The deal requires Democratic support, and the latest developments make its prospects even more doubtful.

Additionally, talks to fund the government after September and raise the nation's debt ceiling are ongoing, but the White House and lawmakers were making progress before the latest impasse. White House officials did not respond to questions about the trade agreement, but an administration official said negotiations on the budget and debt ceiling continued.

The president has indicated that he is willing to put off moving forward on several legislative priorities, including healthcare and immigration reform, until after the election. Trump has stated that Republicans will not vote on a plan to deal with healthcare until after the election, and he has used similar language to justify holding off on moving forward on immigration reform.

The sudden departure from the meeting has left lawmakers and experts uncertain about the future of several White House priorities.

Title: Attorney General Holder Discusses Drone Strikes on American Soil

Attorney General Eric Holder testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee, addressing the issue of drone strikes on American soil. In his testimony, Holder expressed that while it is possible to imagine an "extraordinary circumstance" where a drone strike could be ordered against an American terror suspect, it has never been done and is unlikely to occur. He emphasized that the government has no intention of carrying out drone strikes inside the United States and that the possibility is "entirely hypothetical."

Senator Ted Cruz, R-Texas, pressed Holder on whether it would be constitutional to target an American terror suspect "sitting at a cafe" if the suspect did not pose an imminent threat. Holder reiterated that the government has no intention of carrying out drone strikes domestically and that the possibility is "entirely hypothetical."

In a letter to Senator Rand Paul, R-Kentucky, Holder stated that it is possible to imagine an "extraordinary circumstance" where the president could authorize the military to use lethal force within the United States, but emphasized that this scenario is "unlikely to occur." Holder cited the 2001 al-Qaeda attacks on New York and Washington, as well as the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor in 1941, as potential scenarios where such action might be considered.

Senator Paul expressed dissatisfaction with Holder's response, stating that the refusal to rule out the possibility of drone strikes on American citizens and soil is "more than frightening" and an "affront to the constitutional due process rights of all Americans."

Jeffrey Toobin, CNN senior legal analyst, noted that Holder made it clear that he would examine the facts of each situation separately and advise the president on his legal authority. Toobin also stated that while the scenario is currently hypothetical, it may not remain so in the future.

The issue of targeting American terror suspects with lethal force was brought into sharp focus in 2011 when Anwar al-Awlaki was killed in a drone strike in Yemen. The Obama administration has stated that targeting Americans overseas with drones is only permitted when the U.S. government determines a suspect to be an imminent threat to the United States and when capture would not be feasible.

Title: Obama's 2012 Income and Taxes: A Look at the President's Financial Disclosure

The White House has released the Obama family's 2012 tax returns, revealing that President Barack Obama's income has decreased significantly since taking office. The president and First Lady Michelle Obama reported an adjusted gross income of $608,611, with the majority coming from the president's salary. The Obamas donated almost one-quarter of their income to charity, with the largest contribution being $103,871 to the Fisher House Foundation.

According to the tax returns, the Obamas paid $112,214 in federal income taxes, with an effective federal tax rate of 18.4%. The president and First Lady also paid $29,450 in state income taxes to Illinois. The Obamas reported itemized deductions of $258,385, which brought their taxable income down to $335,026.

The Obamas' income from book sales has decreased since 2009, when they made $5.5 million. In 2011, they reported about $790,000 in income. The president's book royalties accounted for $258,772 of their 2012 income, with the majority coming from his 1995 memoir "Dreams From My Father," his 2006 political book "The Audacity of Hope," and a 2010 children's book "Of Thee I Sing: A Letter to My Daughters."

The Obamas also claimed $39,875 in income from outside the United States, which was all from book royalties, but did not disclose details about which countries the income came from. The president and First Lady donated $150,034, or 24.6%, of their income to 33 charities, a slight dip from the previous year.

The White House also released the tax returns for Vice President Joe Biden and his wife, Jill Biden, which showed they paid $87,851 in federal income taxes on $385,072 in adjusted gross income, with an effective federal tax rate of 22.8%. The Bidens paid state income taxes in two states and reported donating $7,190 to charity.

Title: Republicans' Relatively Passive Reaction to Obama's Immigration Decision

The recent decision by President Obama to suspend deportations of some illegal immigrants has sparked a mixed reaction from Republicans, with some denouncing the move and others taking a more equivocal stance. This unusual response is notable, especially in an election year where both parties are known for their strong reactions to even the smallest controversies.

While some influential Republicans, such as William Kristol, have praised Obama's decision, others, like Marco Rubio, have pushed back on the circumstances surrounding the decision rather than its substance. Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, has taken an ambiguous stance, largely avoiding questions about the issue.

The decision to suspend deportations is seen as a strategic move by Obama to appeal to Hispanic voters, who are becoming an increasingly important demographic in American politics. The "emerging Democratic majority" theory, which suggests that certain groups more favorably inclined towards Democrats are becoming more plentiful as a share of the American population, relies heavily on Hispanic voters.

According to exit polls, Hispanics represented about 9% of voters in the 2008 election, up from 2% in the 1992 election. However, some analysts argue that "permanent" majorities are an illusion, and demographic and cultural changes produce shifts in public opinion, causing parties to adapt their positions accordingly.

The Republican Party has historically taken a more conservative stance on immigration, but some Republicans seem to be recognizing the changing demographics and adapting their positions. The Pew Hispanic Center survey found that only about one-third of Hispanic registered voters listed immigration as an extremely important issue, while close to 50% said the same of jobs, education, and healthcare.

While Obama's approval ratings among Hispanic voters have not always been outstanding, relatively few have said they plan to vote for Romney. The decision to suspend deportations could motivate some additional turnout among Hispanic voters, potentially swinging a net of about 1 percentage point in support to Obama. If Romney treads softly on the issue, it may be to return the focus to the economy, which has been a major concern for many Hispanics hit hard by the recession.

Title: Republicans Shift Focus to Hillary Clinton After Benghazi Hearing

Article:

The Republican Party has shifted its attention to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton after the recent hearing on the Benghazi attack. The hearing, led by the GOP-led House Oversight Committee, aimed to investigate the events surrounding the death of the U.S. ambassador to Libya and three other Americans. The incident has been a stain on Clinton's record as America's top diplomat.

Before she stepped down as secretary of state, Clinton testified for hours on Capitol Hill on the Benghazi attack. She was forceful in her defense, and the conventional wisdom at the time was that she was not politically wounded. However, the story was given new legs thanks to the House hearing, which showcased the testimony of State Department whistleblowers who had not previously testified.

The Republican National Committee and American Crossroads, a Karl Rove-backed pro-GOP super PAC, have issued emails critical of Clinton, questioning her leadership during the attack. Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida, a possible 2020 GOP White House contender, also criticized Clinton in an interview on Fox News Channel.

Many Republicans see the deadly attack on the diplomatic compound in Benghazi and the initial reaction by the State Department and the White House as a huge scandal, one that they feel Democrats tried to cover up with the president's re-election in mind. They accuse the administration of not bolstering security prior to the attack, botching the response to it, and misleading the public in its slow-to-evolve explanation of events.

Democrats, on the other hand, call the GOP drumbeat a "witch hunt." An independent review of the Benghazi incident, led by Adm. Mike Mullen and former ambassador Thomas R. Pickering, discovered no wrongdoing by Clinton. However, critics noted that neither Mullen nor Pickering interviewed Clinton.

The question is whether the Benghazi incident could come back to haunt Clinton if she decides to run for president in 2020. An independent review of the Benghazi incident, led by Adm. Mike Mullen and former ambassador Thomas R. Pickering, discovered no wrongdoing by Clinton. However, critics noted that neither Mullen nor Pickering interviewed Clinton.

The hearing was not the end of the story, as House Speaker John Boehner called on the president to release emails that he says show how the White House wanted to change the Benghazi attack "talking points."

Title: Sen. Ted Cruz's Plan to Defund Obamacare Faces Uncertainty

Sen. Ted Cruz, a Texas Republican, has proposed a plan to tie the government's finances to the funding of President Barack Obama's healthcare plan, stating that there are not enough Republicans on board to make the idea a reality. Cruz believes that a "grass-roots tsunami" will bring fellow conservatives to his side in the next month, but opponents argue that the plan risks a government shutdown and would never be signed into law by the president.

Cruz's plan would provide a year of funding for the federal government, minus Obamacare, and requires 41 senators or 218 representatives to support it. While he has gained support from a handful of Republicans, including Sens. Marco Rubio and Mike Lee, many others have expressed opposition, including establishment figures like Sen. John McCain and Sen. Rand Paul.

Democrats, including former Vermont Gov. Howard Dean, have strongly opposed the tactic, calling it "crazy ideas from the far right." The Heritage Foundation, a conservative organization, has sponsored a tour for Cruz to build support for the effort to defund Obamacare, with President Jim DeMint stating that the American people were "lied to" about the healthcare law.

Cruz believes that the plan would force Democrats to shut down the government if they refuse to support a measure that funds all federal programs except Obamacare. However, opponents argue that the plan would risk alienating Americans who are tired of seeing the federal government's finances used as a pawn in partisan bickering.

Title: Texas Senate Candidates Engage in Heated Debate on Domestic Policy Issues

The first of three debates between Republican Senator Ted Cruz and Democratic challenger Representative Beto O'Rourke took place on Friday night in Dallas, with the two candidates engaging in a lively and often contentious discussion on various domestic policy issues. The debate focused on topics such as immigration, healthcare, gun control, and professional football players taking a knee during the national anthem.

Senator Cruz characterized Representative O'Rourke as being part of a "revolutionary fringe" and accused him of being out of step with the people of Texas. He claimed that O'Rourke wants to abolish Immigration and Customs Enforcement, take away Texans' guns, and impeach President Trump. Cruz also criticized O'Rourke for being an absentee senator who missed half of the votes in the United States Senate in 2016.

Representative O'Rourke countered by accusing Senator Cruz of caring more about tax cuts for corporations than his constituents. He said that Cruz wants to deport every single Dreamer and accused him of being an absentee senator who spent more time campaigning in Iowa than working for Texas.

The debate highlighted the vast differences between the two candidates on almost every hot topic, particularly on immigration and border security. Senator Cruz emphasized the need to secure the border, while Representative O'Rourke advocated for bringing people out of the shadows and allowing them to get right by law.

The candidates also sparred on gun control, with Senator Cruz accusing Representative O'Rourke of wanting to get rid of the Second Amendment. Representative O'Rourke countered by saying that he learned to shoot as a kid but believes it's time for universal background checks and a ban on assault weapons.

The debate comes as the Texas Senate race has become one of the most-watched and talked-about contests of the 2018 midterms. Recent polls show the candidates running within single digits of each other, and the Cook Political Report has reclassified the race as a toss-up. The outcome of the election could have significant implications for both Texas and the national political landscape.

Title: Senate Majority Leader McConnell Secures Votes for Impeachment Trial Rules Without Witnesses

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has secured the necessary votes to establish the rules for President Trump's impending impeachment trial, according to multiple reports. The decision comes despite protests from Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, who has argued that Republicans should allow witnesses and documents to be called in the trial.

McConnell told colleagues during a closed-door lunch on Tuesday that he had secured the necessary backing to begin the trial, according to the Washington Post. Politico first reported that Republicans were growing increasingly confident in their ability to set the trial parameters without input from Democrats.

The decision to establish the rules without witnesses is similar to the format used during the impeachment trial of former President Bill Clinton. Opening arguments will be held before a vote to determine which witnesses, if any, will be called to testify.

Senate Majority Whip John Thune said that Republican leadership is "trying to get consensus among Republicans about how to go forward" and is taking the temperature of their members to see where they stand. Thune expressed hope that members will be prepared to move forward along the lines of the Clinton rules.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has delayed sending the articles of impeachment to the Senate, but Republicans have been ramping up pressure on her to deliver them. Senator Josh Hawley introduced a resolution on Monday that would preemptively dismiss the articles if they are not sent over in a timely manner.

It is unclear whether former adviser John Bolton, who has said he would testify if subpoenaed, will be called to testify during the trial.

Title: Obama Reflects on Disappointments and Challenges of His Second Term

President Barack Obama held a news conference to review the first year of his second term, acknowledging the disappointments and challenges he has faced. Despite citing some positive economic indicators, such as improving employment and growth rates, Obama did not provide specific details about his agenda for the year ahead. Instead, he emphasized the need for action and acknowledged the difficulties in achieving his goals due to Congressional opposition.

Obama's approval ratings have hit a record low, and many Democrats are disillusioned with the controversies surrounding the health insurance law and revelations about widespread intelligence surveillance. The president faced tough questions from reporters, who pressed him on the disappointments of his second term, including failures on immigration, budget policy, gun violence, and healthcare.

In his response, Obama laughed off the question about whether this has been the worst year of his presidency, joking that reporters have chronicled "at least 15 near-death experiences" during his tenure. He maintained a composed demeanor, acknowledging the frustrations and setbacks, but did not provide a clear vision for his second term.

Title: Biden Declares Equality Act Top Priority, Urges Action Against Discrimination

Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden declared the Equality Act his top legislative priority, emphasizing the need to enshrine LGBTQ protections into the nation's labor and civil rights laws. In a keynote address to hundreds of activists at the Human Rights Campaign's annual Ohio gala, Biden expressed his commitment to signing the legislation into law.

The Equality Act, which recently passed the Democratic-run House, aims to address discriminatory practices against the LGBTQ community. However, it faces an uncertain future in the Republican-controlled Senate. Biden emphasized the importance of taking action against discrimination, citing examples of attempts to bar transgender troops in the military, allow medical professionals to refuse treatment to LGBTQ individuals, and permit homeless shelters to refuse transgender occupants.

Biden's visit to Ohio, a key battleground state, marked his first trip to the state since launching his presidential bid. He used the occasion to underscore his long-standing alliance with the Human Rights Campaign and LGBTQ activists, a crucial factor in his contention that he is more progressive than his party's left flank acknowledges.

The former vice president recalled his 2012 presidential campaign, when he announced his support for same-sex marriage before his boss, President Barack Obama, had done so. He lamented the widespread discrimination still existing in the U.S. and abroad, citing recent killings of black transgender women and the high rate of suicide attempts among LGBTQ children and teens.

Biden's speech was part of a busy weekend for Democratic presidential hopefuls, with more than a dozen candidates addressing thousands of activists in California. Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren and Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, nodded to Biden's absence with subtle jabs. However, Biden made no mention of his rivals, focusing instead on his message and confidence in his position atop the pack of 24 presidential hopefuls.

The Human Rights Campaign has identified about 1.8 million "equality voters" in Ohio, including 400,000 LGBTQ citizens, their family members, friends, and allies. Trump won Ohio by a narrow margin in 2016, and Biden's visit aimed to capitalize on the state's diversity and his own alliance with LGBTQ activists.

Title: Hoteliers Host Republican Senator Ted Cruz at Manhattan Event, Apologize for "Terrible Mistake"

Article:

Ian Reisner, one of the two hoteliers who hosted Republican Senator Ted Cruz at an event in Manhattan, has issued an apology for hosting the senator. Reisner and his business partner, Mati Weiderpass, are prominent New York real estate developers and gay rights advocates. Their hotel, OUT NYC, is known for being gay-friendly.

The event, which took place last week, aimed to discuss common ground between Cruz and the hoteliers on issues such as Israel. However, news of the event sparked backlash from the LGBTQ+ community, with boycotts and hate campaigns launched against the hoteliers on social media.

Reisner took to his Facebook page to apologize for hosting Cruz, stating that he was "shaken to his bones" by the negative reaction and that he had made a "terrible mistake." He claimed to have been unaware of Cruz's opposition to same-sex marriage, but later reviewed videos of Cruz's statements on the issue and expressed shock and anger.

It is unclear whether Reisner was genuinely unaware of Cruz's stance on same-sex marriage or if he was simply trying to appease the LGBTQ+ community. Regardless, his apology has been met with skepticism by some, who argue that it was a "ridiculous" claim.

The incident highlights the pressure that individuals can face when they stray from the perceived norms of the LGBTQ+ community. The hoteliers' decision to host Cruz, despite his opposition to same-sex marriage, was seen as a betrayal by some, and their subsequent apology was seen as a necessary step to avoid further backlash.

Title: Former Editor's Notes on Milo Yiannopoulos' Unpublished Memoir Emerge in Court Documents

Article:

Court documents have revealed scathing notes from former editor Mitchell Ivers on Milo Yiannopoulos' unpublished memoir, which were filed in response to Yiannopoulos' lawsuit against Simon & Schuster. The notes, which were made public in July, criticize Yiannopoulos' writing as "unclear," "unfunny," and "delete." Ivers' comments also express concern over Yiannopoulos' perceived biases and lack of self-awareness.

Yiannopoulos, an alt-right provocateur, had sued Simon & Schuster after the publisher cancelled his book in February following the emergence of footage showing him appearing to condone pedophilia. Yiannopoulos has now accused Ivers of being biased against his work and flirting with him.

The notes, which were made public in court documents, include Ivers' criticisms of Yiannopoulos' writing, as well as his attempts to make Yiannopoulos aware of how he is perceived by others. Ivers advised Yiannopoulos to acknowledge the accusations against him and to avoid using language that could be perceived as offensive.

Yiannopoulos has responded to the criticism, claiming that Ivers is biased against him and that he is being unfairly targeted. He has also accused Ivers of flirting with him and being inconsistent in his criticisms.

The controversy surrounding Yiannopoulos' book has sparked widespread criticism and outrage, with many condemning his views on various social and political issues.

Title: Conspiracy Theories and the "Earpiece" Phenomenon: A Recurring Fixture of Presidential Campaigns

The "earpiece" phenomenon has become a recurring theme in presidential campaigns, with conspiracy theories surrounding the use of secret earpieces or earpieces to cheat during debates. The latest instance of this phenomenon involves Hillary Clinton, with Infowars.com and the Drudge Report suggesting that she wore an earpiece during a recent presidential forum. The story was fueled by a tweet from actor James Woods and was endorsed by Donald Trump Jr.

This is not the first time the "earpiece" conspiracy has surfaced in presidential campaigns. In 2004, blogger Joseph Cannon noticed an odd bulge in George W. Bush's suit jacket during an early October debate, leading to speculation that he was wearing an earpiece. The story gained traction, with NASA scientists analyzing images of the "Bush bulge" and The Washington Post and The New York Times obtaining denials from Bush campaign staffers.

In 2008, blogger Ann Althouse wrote that she had noticed Barack Obama wearing an earpiece during a presidential debate, but later reconsidered her analysis and recognized that she was looking at light reflecting off Obama's ear. The 2012 election saw some chain emails circulating, accusing Obama of wearing an earpiece and having a suspicious Bush-like suit bulge.

The persistence of the "earpiece" phenomenon can be attributed to people's tendency to believe what they want to believe, based on their partisanship and conspiracy worldview. According to Joseph Uscinski, a professor of political science at the University of Miami, people are more likely to take allegations of cheating at face value if they are already predisposed to believe that the opposing party would cheat.

The "earpiece" conspiracy theory is often fueled by grainy images and speculation, with no concrete evidence to support the allegations. However, it continues to spread, with some candidates and their supporters perpetuating the myth. The persistence of this phenomenon highlights the importance of critical thinking and media literacy in the face of misinformation.

Title: Massachusetts Representative-Elect Seth Moulton's Military Service Shines in Campaign

Article: Seth Moulton, a newly elected House Representative for Massachusetts' Sixth Congressional District, has made his military service a central focus of his campaign. The Democrat, who unseated nine-term incumbent John Tierney and defeated state Sen. Richard Tisei on Election Day, has spoken candidly about his experiences in Iraq, where he served four combat tours.

Moulton joined the Marines shortly after graduating from Harvard and before the 9/11 terrorist attacks in 2001. He has credited his military service with helping to spur his decision to run for office, stating that his experiences in Iraq showed him the consequences of failed leadership and the importance of effective governance.

During his campaign, Moulton has been praised for downplaying his own military connections, a departure from the trend of politicians exaggerating their military service. He has also been recognized for his efforts to reform the scandal-plagued Department of Veterans Affairs and has received endorsements from high-ranking military officials, including Generals Stanley McChrystal and David Petraeus.

Moulton's military service has been marked by two Bronze Star awards for heroism, although his parents were not aware of the honors until last month, according to his campaign spokesman. In addition to his military experience, Moulton has campaigned on issues such as fishing regulation in his district and his business background, having earned an MBA from Harvard Business School and worked at a startup.

As a representative-elect in a firmly Republican House of Representatives, Moulton's background and secure position in a deep blue state make him a bright spot for Democrats on an otherwise dark Election Night.

Title: Russia and Ukraine Agree to Cease-Fire, but Details Remain Sketchy

Russia and Ukraine have agreed to a cease-fire, according to statements from both leaders, following a telephone conversation between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Petro O. Poroshenko. The agreement, which was announced on Wednesday, aims to bring an end to the ongoing conflict in eastern Ukraine.

According to Putin, the plan includes a range of measures, including the withdrawal of Ukrainian artillery from the separatist strongholds, an end to airstrikes, the exchange of all detainees, and the opening up of humanitarian corridors for residents of the affected areas. International observers will also be deployed to monitor the cease-fire.

The agreement does not, however, address the key issue of autonomy for the separatist eastern regions, which has been a central demand of the Kremlin since March. This omission is seen as critical to Russia's long-term goal of maintaining influence over Ukraine's domestic affairs and blocking any future attempt to join NATO.

The details of the agreement are still unclear, with both sides providing somewhat contradictory statements. Poroshenko's office initially announced that the two leaders had agreed to a "lasting cease-fire," but later clarified that they had only endorsed the need for a cease-fire and hoped negotiations would begin in earnest on Friday.

The agreement was reached during a telephone conversation between Putin and Poroshenko, with the two leaders discussing the need for a cease-fire and the start of negotiations. The talks are set to continue in Minsk, Belarus, on Friday, with representatives from Ukraine, Russia, and Europe attending.

Title: Trump Defends Family Separation Policy, Blames Democrats Amid Growing Criticism

Article:
