President Donald Trump dug in on Monday, defending his administration's policy of separating migrant children from their parents at the U.S.-Mexico border, blaming Democrats for the controversy. "I say it's very strongly the Democrats' fault," he said at the White House. "The United States will not be a migrant camp and it will not be a refugee holding facility, not on my watch."

Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen rejected criticism, saying the department is enforcing laws passed by Congress and called on lawmakers to reform immigration laws. "We are doing none of those things. We are enforcing the laws passed by Congress," she said.

The policy, which has been in place since April and May, has resulted in nearly 2,000 children being separated from their families. The U.S. protocol prohibits detaining children with their parents because the children are not charged with a crime and the parents are.

Criticism is mounting from both sides of the political aisle. Former First Lady Laura Bush called the policy "cruel" and "immoral," while Republican Senator Susan Collins expressed concern about the child separation policy. Former Trump adviser Anthony Scaramucci questioned using the policy to pressure Democrats on immigration legislation.

First Lady Melania Trump also weighed in, saying she believes the country should "govern with heart" and "follow all laws." Her spokeswoman added that Mrs. Trump hopes both sides can come together to achieve successful immigration reform.

The policy has been widely condemned by religious groups, including some conservative ones, and has sparked widespread outrage. House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi called the policy "an utter atrocity" that "debases America's values and our legacy as a beacon of hope, opportunity, and freedom."

The controversy has also led to a debate over pending immigration legislation, with the House expected to vote this week on a bill pushed by conservatives that may not have enough support to pass. The White House has said Trump would sign either a bill or a compromise measure with key proposals supported by the president.

Title: Obama and Romney Camps Agree on Key Battleground States

The 2012 presidential race has narrowed down to a core of nine states, considered battlegrounds across nearly every region. Both the Obama and Romney campaigns agree on the importance of these states, which include Colorado, Florida, Iowa, North Carolina, Ohio, Virginia, and Wisconsin, in addition to New Hampshire and Nevada.

These states are a mix of familiar presidential battlegrounds and newcomers to the swing state roster. Every one of them was carried by President Barack Obama in 2008. According to campaign officials and strategists, the state of play and forces at work in these nine states are as follows:

Colorado, with nine electoral votes, is the biggest prize in the Mountain West. This explains why two of the nation's top five media markets in terms of ad buys were Denver and Colorado Springs in the two weeks preceding the conventions. The Romney campaign's strategy in Colorado depends on turning out the GOP base, particularly on the energy-oriented Western Slope and in El Paso County's Colorado Springs, home to a politically active evangelical Christian community and a heavy military influence. This year, the expectation among Republicans is that Romney will gain more traction in the Denver suburbs than John McCain did in 2008.

The Obama campaign's strategy in Colorado closely resembles the one successfully employed by Democratic Sen. Michael Bennet in 2010. Bennet ran well among Hispanics and benefited from an enormous gender gap – 17 points, according to exit polls. The same themes Bennet used – notably abortion rights and contraception – have been put to use again in Colorado and were underscored at the Democratic convention in Charlotte last week. There's a reason the president campaigned in Colorado with Sandra Fluke in early August, and he'll be back again later this week.

Title: Cashless Payments Gain Popularity Amid Pandemic, But Concerns About Accessibility and Security Remain

The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the adoption of cashless payments, with almost half of Americans opting for digital transactions over cash, according to a YouGov poll. This shift has led businesses to implement cashless protocols, such as Starbucks' pledge to shift to cashless payments to reduce the risk of virus transmission.

Proponents of cashless payments argue that it is a more hygienic and convenient option, as it eliminates the need to handle cash and reduces the risk of germ transmission. They also claim that it would save businesses time and money, as well as reduce the risk of theft and improve payment tracking.

However, opponents of cashless payments argue that it is discriminatory, as it excludes individuals without bank accounts, such as those who are young, low-income, homeless, or undocumented. They also express concerns about the potential for hacking and privacy breaches, as well as the logistical difficulties of implementing a cashless society.

Some critics argue that a cashless society would be difficult for people who are less tech-savvy, such as the elderly, who often struggle to navigate digital systems. Others worry about scenarios in which individuals could lose access to their entire bank account if hacked.

The debate surrounding cashless payments has sparked discussions about the need for a universal digital banking system and the potential for a digital national currency. While some countries, such as China, are piloting digital currencies, the United States has not yet implemented a similar system.

Experts weigh in on the issue, with some arguing that digital wallets would have improved the government's ability to provide stimulus relief and provide banking services to those without accounts. Others express concerns about the potential for discrimination and the need for a more inclusive financial system.

As the debate continues, it remains to be seen whether the shift towards cashless payments will continue to gain momentum or if concerns about accessibility and security will slow its adoption.

Title: Hillary Clinton Blames Multiple Factors for 2016 Election Loss

Hillary Clinton, the 2016 Democratic presidential nominee, has attributed her defeat to a range of factors, including the letter from FBI Director James Comey announcing the reopening of the investigation into her use of a private email server as secretary of state, alleged Russian interference, and voter suppression. In an interview with CBS News, Clinton discussed her campaign's post-mortem, which is set to be released on September 12.

Clinton pointed to the Comey letter as a significant factor in her loss, stating that analysts believe it cost her the election. She also mentioned alleged Russian interference, including the leak of John Podesta's emails and the use of Facebook to spread negative stories about her. Additionally, she blamed voter suppression, citing specific states like Wisconsin and North Carolina, and sexism and misogyny, which she believes are endemic to society.

Clinton's comments come ahead of the release of her book, "What Happened," which is expected to provide more insight into her campaign's strategy and mistakes.

Title: The Paradox of Greta Thunberg: A Critique of Progressive Ideology

The article "The Sabbath was made for man, and not man for the Sabbath" from an anonymous author presents a scathing critique of progressive ideology, using Greta Thunberg as a prime example. The author argues that progressives often criticize pro-lifers for caring about babies only before they are born, but not after. However, the author turns the tables, suggesting that progressives are guilty of the same hypocrisy.

The article claims that Greta Thunberg, a 16-year-old climate activist, has been "groomed" into a zealot by her parents, who have exploited her Asperger's syndrome to further their own agenda. The author believes that Thunberg's individuality has been subsumed by the cause, making her a "perfect vessel" for progressive ideology.

The article also suggests that Thunberg's parents have manipulated her to live in fear of a climate Armageddon, trading one neurosis for another. The author argues that this is a prime example of progressive ideology, which values conformity over individuality and autonomy.

The article concludes that Greta Thunberg is meant to be a model for others to follow, sacrificing their own identities and allegiances for the sake of a perceived greater good. The author believes that this is an "abortion of the soul," where human dignity is devalued and individuality is lost.

In this article, the author presents a critique of progressive ideology, using Greta Thunberg as a prime example. While the article raises some valid points about the potential risks of conformity and the devaluation of individuality, it also relies heavily on personal attacks and speculation, which may not be supported by fact.

Title: US Visa Program Adjusts Guidelines for International Students Amidst Ongoing Pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic has forced educational institutions in the United States to adapt to online learning, and the Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP) has responded by updating its visa guidelines for international students. The changes aim to ensure that nonimmigrant F-1 and M-1 students pursuing academic and vocational coursework in the US are taking a balanced course load that includes in-person instruction.

According to the new guidelines, nonimmigrant F-1 students attending schools operating entirely online will not be allowed to take a full online course load and remain in the US. Instead, they will need to enroll in other schools or programs that offer in-person instruction or take other measures to maintain their lawful status. Active students currently in the US enrolled in such programs must depart the country or take alternative measures, such as transferring to a school with in-person instruction, to avoid immigration consequences.

Nonimmigrant F-1 students attending schools with in-person classes are still bound by existing federal regulations, which allow them to take a maximum of one class or three credit hours online. However, students attending schools with a hybrid model, which combines online and in-person classes, will be allowed to take more than one class or three credit hours online. These schools must certify to SEVP that the program is not entirely online and that the student is not taking an entirely online course load this semester.

The rule change requires colleges to update their information in the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) within 10 days of the start of the fall semester if instruction starts in-person and is then switched to online-only. Students will be responsible for falling into compliance, either by adjusting their course load or returning home.

The changes aim to ensure that international students, who make up 5.5% of the US higher education population, are taking a balanced course load that includes in-person instruction. According to the Institute of International Education, international students contributed $44.7 billion to the US economy in 2018.

Title: Trump's Planned Tariffs on Aluminum Imports May Hit American Beer Industry Hard

The proposed 10% tariff on aluminum imports by President Donald Trump could have a significant impact on the American beer industry, with some analysts predicting that costs will be passed on to consumers. The tariff, which is intended to address a trade imbalance and national security concerns, could result in a $347.7 million tax on brewers and lead to the loss of tens of thousands of jobs, according to the Beer Institute, a trade group.

The majority of beer produced in the US is sold in aluminum cans, which are cheaper and easier to ship than bottles. Cans also protect against ultraviolet rays, reducing the risk of beer going stale or "skunked." The tariffs could also hurt craft beer, as aluminum offers a good surface for colorful, effective branding.

Industry watchers say the planned levies may exacerbate a shift by consumers away from beer towards spirits and wine, which are mainly sold in bottles. Soda companies like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo, which use more aluminum cans than makers of alcoholic beverages, are also likely to be affected.

Beer makers are not taking the tariff sitting down. MillerCoors, the US division of Molson Coors, tweeted that "American workers and American consumers will suffer as a result of this misguided tariff," adding that there isn't enough can sheet aluminum available in the US to satisfy demand.

The tariff has also raised concerns among food manufacturers that rely on steel and aluminum to package products like tuna fish and soup. The Grocery Manufacturers Association, a trade group representing big food companies, has asked the administration to exempt packaging containers from the tariffs, saying they will act as a regressive tax on low-income consumers.

The Can Manufacturers Institute, which represents the industry that produces cans, has warned that the tariffs could cause closures to US-based plants and trickle down into higher food costs for consumers. The industry employs 22,000 workers across 34 states in the US and uses 2.1 million tons of tin plate in 2016, with companies only getting 58% of that domestically.

The sector is planning to file a petition with the US Commerce Department for relief from tariffs on imports of raw materials that go into cans, including aluminum sheets and steel tin-plate, if the tariffs go through.

Title: US Government Temporarily Halts Prosecution of Parents Who Cross Border with Children Due to Lack of Space

The US government has announced that it will not prosecute parents who cross the border illegally with their children for the time being, due to a shortage of space to house them. This decision comes after the Trump administration faced international criticism for its "zero-tolerance" policy of separating immigrant children from their parents.

According to Customs and Border Protection (CBP) officials, the agency is not referring new cases for prosecution, as it struggles to find space to detain families. White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders stated that the administration is not dropping its policy of "zero-tolerance" but is seeking a "temporary solution" until it can house migrant families.

The decision to halt prosecution is a temporary measure, as the CBP expects to resume referrals for prosecution once it has sufficient space to detain families. The agency is still sending adults who are caught crossing illegally without children to be prosecuted.

The Trump administration's policy of separating families has sparked widespread criticism, including from some within the Republican Party. The US military has been asked to prepare to house up to 20,000 unaccompanied child migrants on its bases.

Despite the temporary reprieve, the fate of thousands of families remains uncertain. The US government has yet to reunite over 2,000 children with their parents, and it is unclear how it will house families while parents are prosecuted.

The immigration crisis has sparked new political tensions, with President Trump expressing frustration at US immigration laws and reiterating that people should be turned away at the border. Democrats have accused him of wanting to circumvent the US Constitution's guarantee of due process for those accused of crimes.

The situation has also led to heated rhetoric, with President Trump lashing out at a Democratic congresswoman who urged Americans to confront members of his inner circle in public places. The congresswoman, Maxine Waters, called for resistance against Trump and his administration.

The immigration crisis has triggered a new wave of political tension, with both sides refusing to back down. The situation remains uncertain, as the US government struggles to find a solution to the crisis.

Title: Bomb Explosion Rocks Tel Aviv, Wounding at Least 10 in Suspected Terrorist Attack

A bomb exploded on a bus in central Tel Aviv on Wednesday, wounding at least 10 people in what Israeli officials have described as a terrorist attack. The blast occurred on the eighth day of an Israeli military offensive against the Hamas-ruled Gaza Strip.

The explosion shattered windows on the bus, which was driving along a tree-lined street next to Israel's defense ministry complex. According to Israel's ambulance service, three of the wounded are in a severe condition.

Israeli authorities have confirmed that the bombing was not a suicide attack and are combing the area for the person responsible. A man has been arrested, according to Israeli media reports.

The bombing comes just one day after the terrorist group Hamas discussed a possible ceasefire. However, Hamas spokesman Sami Abu Zuhri praised the attack, stating that it was a "natural response to the Israeli massacres" in Gaza and that Palestinian factions will "resort to all means" to protect their civilians in the absence of international efforts to stop Israeli aggression.

The incident is likely to complicate efforts to secure a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip. Israel had been considering a ground invasion of Gaza, but had postponed the plan in hopes of reaching a diplomatic solution. With this latest attack, Israel is more likely to proceed with a ground invasion.

Title: Americans' Views on Free Speech: A Mixed Bag of Support and Concerns

The recent polling results on Americans' views on free speech issues have raised concerns about the extent to which significant portions of the population do not venerate the First Amendment's core principles. The survey, conducted by YouGov, found that pluralities of both Democrats and Republicans agree that certain fringe and despicable worldviews, such as those of the KKK and neo-Nazis, should be censored or banned by the government. The results also showed that Americans are roughly evenly split on whether people should be barred by law from joining the KKK or the American Nazi Party.

The survey also asked about ISIS, with a stronger inclination towards censorship, fueled disproportionately by Republican responses. According to YouGov, GOPers lead Democrats in wanting to remove ISIS books from the library by 14 points. The results have sparked debate about whether this is a sign of xenophobic prejudice or a recognition of the group's lethal threat.

The article also touches on the complexities of monitoring and addressing radicalization, particularly in the case of pro-ISIS ideas. Law enforcement would be derelict not to heed warning signs of radicalization, and this calculation also applies to radical right-wing groups and militias.

The article also notes that the YouGov survey did not poll explicitly left-wing organizations or movements, such as Antifa, and questions why this was not included. The author argues that the speech and political gatherings of communists and hard leftists are protected, but any criminal conduct is not.

Finally, the article raises concerns about the ACLU's stance on free speech, citing its vulnerability to political tribalism. However, it also notes the Supreme Court's consistent and strong jurisprudence on the First Amendment, with recent rulings on both pro-speech and pro-religious freedom cases being unanimous.

Overall, the article presents a mixed bag of views on free speech, highlighting both concerns and complexities in the debate.

Title: Lawmakers Debate Commander Power in Military Sexual Assault Cases

Article:

A recent Navy judge's ruling has sparked debate among lawmakers about the extent of commanders' power in military sexual assault cases. The judge ruled that two defendants in military sexual assault cases could not be punished with punitive discharge due to President Obama's public remarks, which were deemed to have exercised "unlawful command influence." The decision was made in a pretrial hearing and was first reported by Stars and Stripes.

The issue has been a contentious one, with some arguing that commanders wield too much power in both the front and back end of prosecutions. Eugene R. Fidell, who teaches military justice at Yale Law School, stated that statements by high officials have always been problematic, as they can distort the question of conviction. Fidell noted that while people look to officials to take a stand on issues, the administration of justice is also at stake.

The Senate is considering measures to address the issue, including a mandatory review of decisions by commanders not to prosecute sexual assault cases, making retaliation a crime, and subjecting sex offenders to automatic dishonorable discharges. Commanders would no longer be able to overturn jury convictions unilaterally.

Senator Susan Collins, a co-sponsor of the bill, believes that the recent legislative changes will make a real difference in curbing sexual assault in the military. She stated that the issue was a legitimate policy dispute that resulted in significant, meaningful reforms.

The issue of military sexual assault has been a long-standing concern, with lawmakers from both parties pursuing changes to military law to combat the problem. Recent events, including the release of sexual assault data by the Defense Department and high-profile cases, have put a spotlight on the issue. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, a Democrat, attached herself to the effort last August and oversaw the first Senate hearing on sexual assaults in the military in nearly a decade. Her efforts received a boost from several committee members who pressed military officials to testify on the issue during the defense budget hearings this spring.

Title: Florida Declares State of Emergency as Hurricane Dorian Gains Strength

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has declared a state of emergency for 26 counties in the possible path of Hurricane Dorian, which is expected to become a major hurricane by Friday. The National Hurricane Center (NHC) reported that the storm's maximum sustained winds reached 85 mph, with higher gusts, and is moving northwest at a speed of 13 mph.

The storm is currently about 150 miles north-northwest of Puerto Rico, having caused limited damage to the island and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Forecasters warn that the storm will strengthen into a dangerous Category 3 hurricane, with sustained winds of at least 111 mph, and heavy rainfall expected over the Bahamas, Florida, and the Southeastern United States.

The NHC has issued a warning for the Bahamas, Florida, and the Southeastern United States, predicting 4 to 8 inches of rain, with isolated areas receiving up to 10 inches. The agency warns that this rainfall may cause life-threatening flash floods.

Florida residents are advised to make emergency preparations, as the storm's center is expected to hit the state's coast late Sunday or early Monday. The NHC emphasizes that it is too early to pinpoint the exact location where the eye will make landfall.

In related news, President Trump declared an emergency in Puerto Rico, ordering the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to provide equipment and resources to alleviate the impacts of the emergency. Puerto Rico Governor Wanda Vázquez Garced thanked Trump for the declaration, stating it would allow federal aid to arrive more quickly after the storm passes.

FEMA has prepared for the storm by stockpiling supplies, including three times as many generators, nine times as many meals, five times as many liters of water, and 16 times as many blue tarps, compared to 2017 levels.

Meanwhile, the fifth named storm of the 2019 Atlantic season, Tropical Storm Erin, has formed, with winds reaching 40 mph. The storm is expected to remain on a north-northeastern track, likely arriving at Canada's coast late this week.

Title: Culture's Obsession with Politics: A Threat to Fun?

Article:

The article discusses the growing trend of politics dominating every aspect of culture, making it tedious and cringe-worthy. The author shares their personal experience of being asked what they write about, only to be met with passionate discussions that often escalate into yelling matches. The author argues that this obsession with politics is not only exhausting but also a threat to fun.

The article highlights the transformation of Teen Vogue, once a magazine focused on fashion and lifestyle, into a "woke" and "terrifying" rage pamphlet. It also mentions the media's reaction to Melania Trump's high heels, with some outlets staging a "freakout" over the "optics" of wearing fancy shoes to a disaster area.

The author also touches on the impact of politics on other aspects of culture, including music. Taylor Swift, known for her personal life and music, is criticized for being an "embodiment of Trump culture." The author argues that when politics is extended into every sector of life, it leads to a "war on fun."

The article concludes by urging readers to "do better" and not let politics consume every aspect of their lives.

Title: Study Reveals Partisan Divide in Climate Policy Support, but Finds Room for Bipartisan Agreement

A recent study conducted in Washington State explored the factors influencing public support for climate policies. The research found that Democrats and Republicans tend to support policies backed by their own party and are less supportive of those backed by the opposing party. This phenomenon is attributed to the desire to conform to the views of their fellow party members, as people tend to overestimate the degree of opposition from the opposing party.

The study also discovered that people's estimates of how their fellow citizens would respond to policies strongly predicted their own support for those policies. This finding is consistent with social psychology's understanding that people are heavily influenced by what others think. As a result, the actual degree of political polarization on climate change belief and support for climate policy is likely less than people perceive it to be.

Interestingly, the study found that political disagreement was significantly smaller when it came to Republican-backed policies, with little distance between Republicans and Democrats in evaluating a Republican-proposed carbon tax. This suggests that a carbon tax, such as the one proposed by prominent Republicans like James Baker III and George Shultz, may have more potential for bipartisan agreement than previously thought.

The study's findings offer a nuanced understanding of the factors driving public support for climate policies and highlight the importance of considering the role of partisanship in shaping opinions. While environmental activists may focus on convincing skeptics about the reality and urgency of climate change, the research suggests that climate policy gridlock may be more about exaggerating disagreement than actual disagreement.

Title: Croatia Deploys Army to Border as Thousands of Refugees and Migrants Cross

Croatia has placed its army on alert to deploy along its border with Serbia, as thousands of refugees and migrants continue to cross the country in search of a new home. The move comes after Hungary closed its borders, causing a surge in traffic through Croatia. Over the past two days, nearly 10,000 people have entered the country.

Croatian Prime Minister Zoran Milanovic has stated that his country will not seal its border entirely, but instead plans to try to usher people along to neighboring countries. "What else can we do?" Milanovic said, according to the Associated Press. "You are welcome in Croatia and you can pass through Croatia. But, go on. Not because we don't like you but because this is not your final destination."

The influx of refugees and migrants has put pressure on Croatia, with the country closing highways leading in from Serbia and Hungary building a fence along its border with Croatia. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has urged Europe to establish reception centers in Greece and Serbia to register and screen those arriving, as well as relocate them to other countries. The agency also called for each EU member nation to accept 40,000 refugees, in addition to the voluntary amounts to which they have already committed.

Jamal al-Shahoud, a refugee from Syria, described the situation at the border as "here no food, no water. No buses, no trains. Nothing here. Just tired." Many migrants and refugees are being forced to make their way through the countryside, as police lines are being broken and people are running into the countryside.

Title: US and Iran Engage in Unprecedented Nuclear Diplomacy, with Prospects of a First-Step Deal

The United States and Iran are engaged in unprecedented nuclear diplomacy, with US Secretary of State John Kerry joining the talks in Geneva alongside British, French, and German foreign ministers. The sudden development comes after nearly two years of fruitless talks to limit Iran's nuclear program in exchange for lifting sanctions.

Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif stated that a joint text is being prepared, but emphasized that "a very difficult task" lies ahead. Zarif emphasized the need for balance in the first step, with each side trying to alleviate the most immediate concerns of the other side.

US officials want an initial deal that would "put time on the clock" by halting the advancement of Iran's nuclear program in exchange for "very limited" sanctions relief until a final, far more sweeping deal is reached, perhaps within six months. Iran, on the other hand, wants the endgame defined to allow the "right" of a robust peaceful nuclear program, including enrichment of uranium on Iranian soil, and all sanctions lifted.

The negotiations are taking place as opponents in Congress are demanding more sanctions on Iran, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has slammed a potential deal as a "historic mistake," and hardliners in Iran have vociferously opposed any accommodation with the West.

Despite the challenges, Zarif expressed optimism that a deal can be reached, stating that "a day is a tall ambition" and that the parties will "try" to finalize a text. However, he warned that time is short and that opponents in Congress and elsewhere are already creating obstacles in the way of agreement and mutual understanding.

The negotiations are being led by US Secretary of State John Kerry, who was invited by European Union High Representative Catherine Ashton to take part in a trilateral meeting with Zarif. The US is seeking to "put time on the clock" by halting the advancement of Iran's nuclear program in exchange for "very limited" sanctions relief until a final, far more sweeping deal is reached.

The prospects of a deal have sparked criticism from opponents, with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declaring that the proposed agreement is a "historic mistake" and that Israel will do everything necessary to defend itself and its people. In Iran, Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has given unprecedented support to Iran's negotiating team, praising them as "sons of the revolution" in a bid to quiet hard-line opposition.

The negotiations are also being closely watched by Congress, where some lawmakers are moving to speed up fresh sanctions measures, which could disrupt the sensitive talks. Zarif warned that any new US sanctions would spark a fierce reaction in Tehran and deepen mutual mistrust that has long plagued these talks.

**GOP Debate: Key Moments from the Final Pre-New Hampshire Primary Face-Off**

The final Republican debate before the New Hampshire primary took place on Saturday night, with five key moments standing out from the evening's discussion. The debate, hosted by ABC News, saw candidates Ben Carson, Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio, John Kasich, Chris Christie, and Donald Trump take the stage to address various topics and engage in some heated exchanges.

One unusual moment occurred at the start of the debate, as Ben Carson refused to take the stage, prompting Ted Cruz to do so, and Donald Trump to pause and stand beside him. The debate continued with a focus on various policy issues, including healthcare, foreign policy, and national security.

Marco Rubio, who has seen a surge in popularity in New Hampshire, faced criticism from Chris Christie on his voting record and his pattern of missing votes in the Senate. Rubio repeated a line about President Obama knowing what he's doing, which Christie criticized as a memorized speech.

Donald Trump, who is currently leading in New Hampshire polls, had an unremarkable performance, sticking to his typical talking points and avoiding tough questions on his past immigration positions. He did, however, take shots at Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio.

The debate also saw a discussion on foreign policy and national security, with candidates weighing in on the topic of waterboarding. Ted Cruz said he would not bring back the practice, while Donald Trump stated he would bring it back and go further. Marco Rubio did not directly answer the question, instead pivoting to attacking President Obama's plan to close the detention center at Guantanamo Bay.

The debate concluded with Ted Cruz facing questions about his campaign's actions on the night of the Iowa caucuses, including sending out messages reporting Ben Carson's suspension. Cruz apologized to Carson, who criticized the incident as indicative of Cruz's "DC values."

Title: Pentagon Delays Implementation of Potential Ban on Transgender Troops

The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Joseph Dunford, has informed the military that the Pentagon will not implement a ban on transgender troops until the President's direction has been received by the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary has issued implementation guidance. Until then, there will be no modifications to the current policy, and the military will continue to treat all personnel with respect.

The current policy allows transgender troops to serve openly, with around 15,000 transgender troops currently serving in the United States military. In 2016, then-Secretary of Defense Ash Carter announced that already-serving transgender troops could come out without fear of discharge, and established a plan to allow openly transgender people to enlist within one year.

On Wednesday, President Trump declared on Twitter that the United States Government will not accept or allow transgender individuals to serve in any capacity in the U.S. military. This announcement raised the possibility that thousands of transgender troops in uniform might be purged. However, Trump made the announcement without consulting the Pentagon or his Secretary of Defense, James Mattis, who has previously supported open transgender service.

The Navy has clarified that, for now, transgender troops may still serve and receive transition-related medical care, and Dunford's letter makes clear that this remains official policy in every branch of the armed forces. The Pentagon is not defying Trump's declaration, but is signaling its discomfort and perhaps even irritation with his abrupt attack on transgender individuals who want to serve their country in uniform.

The Secretary of Defense will soon have to decide whether to escalate this discomfort into concrete pushback.

Title: Politicians Unite Against Trump's Decision to Withdraw from Foreign Wars

Article:

In a rare display of bipartisanship, politicians from both parties in Washington have come together to express their opposition to President Trump's decision to withdraw troops from foreign wars, specifically the civil war in Syria. The move has united Republicans and Democrats alike, with some lawmakers drafting bipartisan legislation to counter the administration's decision.

The Politico website reported that the decision has sparked a new round of Congress-versus-the-administration tensions, with lawmakers from both parties voicing their concerns about the potential consequences of the withdrawal. The article quotes Democrats and Republicans alike expressing their support for the Kurds, who are seen as brave and hardworking individuals fighting against tyranny.

However, critics argue that politicians are quick to rally behind foreign causes, but often neglect the needs of their own constituents. For example, the USMCA trade agreement, which has been stalled in Congress for years, has failed to garner the same level of bipartisan support. Thousands of family farmers across the United States are desperate for the agreement to be approved, but it remains stuck in limbo.

The article also highlights the irony of politicians coming together to support the Kurds, who are not fighting alongside American troops, but rather in their own civil war. The author questions why politicians are so quick to support foreign causes, but not their own country's veterans, who are often left without the healthcare benefits they deserve.

The article concludes by noting that the decision to withdraw from foreign wars has sparked a new round of tensions between Congress and the administration, with lawmakers from both parties voicing their concerns about the potential consequences.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Presidential Campaign Gains Access to Ready for Hillary Email List

The Hillary Clinton presidential campaign has obtained access to the full Ready for Hillary email list, a significant data goldmine that will likely boost the Democratic front-runner's fundraising and organizing efforts. The campaign gained entry to the list through a swap with another independent group, according to a Democrat with knowledge of the list.

The Ready for Hillary list, which contains close to 4 million names, was originally created as a plug-and-play list of supporter names with contact information, representing an energized base of people who could be tapped for money or volunteering. The list was unavailable to the campaign for the first six weeks of Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign, as it was tied up with lawyers reviewing options available to the campaign.

The campaign had been relying on an outdated supporter list from 2008, but gaining access to the Ready for Hillary list will provide a significant boost to their efforts. The list will allow the campaign to quickly identify and engage with potential supporters, volunteers, and donors.

A Democratic strategist, Tracy Sefl, who served as a senior adviser to the independent super PAC, emphasized the importance of the list, stating, "I could offer about 4 million reasons why the Ready for Hillary list is an important resource."

The campaign's access to the list comes as a welcome relief for volunteers like Lynette Hull, a 17-year-old high school student from Las Vegas who was one of the first interns to sign up with the campaign. Hull was tasked with phone-banking, working through an old database of Clinton supporters to sign up new volunteers. However, she found the experience to be time-consuming and unproductive, with many people declining to participate.

There is some overlap between the Ready for Hillary list and the campaign's own list of supporters. When Clinton officially announced her presidential bid, Ready for Hillary emailed its list six times, encouraging them to sign up with the official campaign. Clinton staffers have also been signing up new supporters in the early states on their own.

A Clinton campaign spokesman declined to comment for this report.

Title: San Francisco's Unpredictable Approach to Regulation: Bans and Subsidies Abound

San Francisco's approach to regulation is a puzzle, with the city implementing bans and subsidies on various issues, often leaving residents and businesses scratching their heads. Recently, the city banned electric bicycles, citing concerns over safety and intrusiveness, only to later consider subsidizing them as a more environmentally friendly mode of transportation. This unpredictability is not limited to e-bikes, as the city has also proposed banning companies from offering free food and drink to employees, citing concerns over local restaurants being hurt by the perk.

In contrast, the city has banned plastic straws, joining a growing list of progressive cities taking action against the perceived environmental threat. However, some argue that straws are a small part of the ocean waste problem, and that a more comprehensive approach to addressing plastic pollution is needed.

San Francisco has also taken a unique stance on insurance companies, urging them to divest from coal and tar sands investments. This move is part of a broader trend of cities and states seeking to use their regulatory powers to promote environmental causes. However, some argue that this approach is misguided, as insurance companies have only a small percentage of their investments in fossil fuels, and that savvy investors are better equipped to evaluate the risks and benefits of these investments.

As the city continues to navigate the complex issues of regulation and environmentalism, it's clear that the "ban it or subsidize it" game is far from over. With new causes and controversies emerging, it's anyone's guess what the next big issue will be.

Title: White House May Send Letter to Pelosi Arguing Against Impeachment Inquiry

The White House is expected to send a letter to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., arguing that the administration does not have to comply with the Democrats' impeachment inquiry. The letter, which may be sent as early as Friday, dares Pelosi to put the question of a formal impeachment inquiry before the House of Representatives for a vote.

According to Fox News senior judicial analyst and Fox Nation host Judge Andrew Napolitano, the White House's argument has merit. Napolitano explained that Speaker Pelosi is not required to put the question of an impeachment inquiry up for a vote, but if she did, and if it was approved by a majority of House members, then her inquiry would be strengthened.

Napolitano noted that the Constitution does not require a full House vote before the House begins an impeachment inquiry, but when it does so, it does so based on federal law, not the Constitution. He stated that the White House has the legal right to fight the Democrats' effort to compel their cooperation.

However, if Pelosi were to put the question of an impeachment inquiry up for a vote and a majority of House members approve it, that would change the game. Napolitano explained that if the House votes by majority vote to proceed with an impeachment inquiry, it would strip the president of almost all of his defenses and enhance its own ability to extract information from a reluctant White House.

In a recent episode of "Liberty File with Judge Napolitano," the judge spoke with two Republicans mounting presidential primary challenges against President Trump in 2020. Former Massachusetts Gov. Bill Weld agreed with the president's critics, stating that the conduct the president engaged in is precisely the sort of conduct the Framers were worried about and why they put the impeachment and removal power in the hands of Congress.

Title: Jussie Smollett Files Counterclaim Against City of Chicago Over Alleged Hate Crime Hoax

Actor Jussie Smollett has filed a counterclaim against the city of Chicago, naming multiple police officers and two brothers as defendants, in connection with the alleged hate crime incident that took place in late January. Smollett had initially claimed to be a victim of a racist and homophobic attack, but the city later determined that the incident was a hoax. Smollett faced 16 counts related to making false statements to police, but the charges were dropped in exchange for community service and a $10,000 fine.

According to the counterclaim, Smollett alleges that the malicious prosecution caused him various issues, including humiliation, mental anguish, and extreme emotional distress. The counterclaim was filed in response to a lawsuit filed by the city of Chicago to recover $130,106 in investigation costs. Smollett had requested that the city's lawsuit be thrown out, citing that he could not have known what the police investigation would cost. However, U.S. District Judge Virginia Kendall ruled that the case would proceed to the discovery phase.

As of August, Smollett's team still maintained that they had evidence that the hate crime hoax was real. The counterclaim names the city, the Chicago Police Department, Detectives Michael Theis and Edward Wodnicki, Supt. Eddie Johnson, and the two brothers involved in the alleged attack, Abimbola and Olabinjo Osundairo, as defendants. The claim argues that the proceedings against Smollett were terminated in his favor and indicate his innocence, as all 16 counts of the criminal indictment were dismissed two and a half weeks after the indictment was filed. The claim also asserts that the city of Chicago cannot recover investigation costs from Smollett because it already accepted the $10,000 fine as payment in full in connection with the dismissal of the charges against him.

Title: Google and Silicon Valley Faced with Lawsuit Over Allegations of Censorship and Discrimination Against Conservative Employees

Article:

A class action lawsuit has been filed against Google, alleging a culture of censorship and discrimination against right-of-center employees. The lawsuit, filed on behalf of former Google engineer James Damore and other conservative employees, claims that the company's diversity efforts have led to illegal discrimination against white male employees. The suit alleges that managers openly discuss blacklists meant to sabotage the careers of those with conservative viewpoints, and that employees are pressured to undergo "Bias Busting" re-education sessions focusing on white male privilege.

Internal messages included in the lawsuit reveal employees conspiring against Damore after he shared a memo criticizing the company's diversity policies and calling for more tolerance of conservative viewpoints. One employee wrote, "You know, there are just certain 'alternative views, including different political views' which I do not want people to feel safe to share here." Another employee stated, "If Google management cares enough about diversity and inclusion, they should, and I urge them to, send a clear message by not only terminating Mr. Damore, but also severely disciplining or terminating those who have expressed support." Damore was subsequently fired.

The lawsuit is not an isolated incident. Google's new fact-checkers have been accused of policing right-of-center media outlets and wrongfully attributing false statements to The Daily Caller. Left-of-center outlets have received no such policing from Google, which has previously censored content that does not align with its political goals.

This pattern of discrimination and censorship is not unique to Google. Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube have also been accused of targeting conservative and independent voices. Facebook has been accused of burying conservative viewpoints from its trending topics section, while YouTube and Google have targeted conservative and independent video channels for censorship and demonitization. Both Facebook and Google have empowered left-wing fact-checkers to discredit conservative voices on their platforms, with little oversight.

The lawsuit against Google highlights the growing concern among conservatives about censorship and discrimination in the tech industry. As the most powerful companies in the world, Google, Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube have a significant impact on the global conversation. The allegations of censorship and discrimination against conservative employees and users raise questions about the companies' commitment to free speech and diversity.

Title: TSA Fails to Detect Explosives or Weapons in 95% of Tests at Busiest Airports

The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has faced criticism after an internal investigation revealed security failures at dozens of the nation's busiest airports. The investigation, conducted by Homeland Security Red Teams, found that undercover investigators were able to smuggle mock explosives or banned weapons through checkpoints in 95% of trials.

According to officials briefed on the results of a recent Homeland Security Inspector General's report, TSA agents failed 67 out of 70 tests, with Red Team members repeatedly able to get potential weapons through checkpoints. In one test, an undercover agent was stopped after setting off an alarm at a magnetometer, but TSA screeners failed to detect a fake explosive device taped to his back during a follow-on pat-down.

Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson was reportedly frustrated by the findings and sought a detailed briefing on them last week at TSA headquarters in Arlington, Virginia. U.S. officials insist that changes have already been made at airports to address vulnerabilities identified by the latest tests. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) stated that Secretary Johnson directed TSA to implement a series of actions to address the issues raised in the report, and some of these actions are already in place.

This is not the first time the TSA has had trouble spotting Red Team agents. A similar episode occurred in 2013, when an undercover investigator with a fake bomb hidden on his body passed through a metal detector, went through a pat-down at New Jersey's Newark Liberty Airport, and was never caught. The TSA has acknowledged that Red Team tests are meant to "push the boundaries of our people, processes, and technology" and that testers often make these covert tests as difficult as possible.

The DHS inspector general's office has also conducted a series of undercover tests targeting checked baggage screening at airports across the country, finding "vulnerabilities" throughout the system due to human error and technological failures. The review attributed these failures to a lack of noticeable improvements in checked baggage screening since a previous review in 2009, despite spending $540 million for equipment and $11 million for training.

Title: Twitter Agrees to Remove Racist Tweets After French Organization Threatens Lawsuit

Twitter has agreed to remove a series of racist tweets that sparked outrage in France, following a threat of lawsuit from a French organization. The tweets, which used the hashtag #unbonjuif, or "a good Jew," prompted a flood of anti-Semitic messages that flooded the platform. The French Union of Jewish Students, led by Vice President Elie Petit, had demanded the removal of the tweets, citing French law, which prohibits hate speech.

The controversy highlights the challenges faced by social media companies in policing their content and adhering to local laws. Many European countries have strict laws against hate speech, which evolved in the aftermath of the Holocaust. Twitter's decision to remove the tweets came after a conference call with French executives, who explained the French perspective on the issue.

However, the move has sparked debate among digital experts and users, with some arguing that it represents an attack on freedom of expression. Manuel Diaz, a digital expert, believes that Twitter should not censor content, but rather build global monitoring teams to quickly detect and suspend tweets that do not respect local laws. He notes that Twitter has successfully detected and suspended fake accounts in the past, and can do the same with hate speech.

The incident is not an isolated one, as Twitter has faced similar challenges in Germany, where it blocked an account of a banned neo-Nazi group. The company's decision to remove the tweets in France came a day after the German incident, highlighting the need for Twitter to adapt to local laws and regulations.

Title: Man Arrested for Firing Rifle Inside Pizzeria Amid False "Pizzagate" Conspiracy Theory

Article:

Edgar Welch, a 28-year-old father of two, was arrested on Sunday after firing a military-style rifle inside the Washington, D.C. pizzeria Comet Ping Pong. Welch claimed he drove from North Carolina to get a "closer look" at the restaurant, which he believed was at the center of the false "Pizzagate" conspiracy theory. He stated that he had no intention of firing a shot and regretted how he handled the situation.

Welch's actions were reportedly motivated by internet articles that led him to believe Comet Ping Pong was involved in a child sex ring allegedly run by associates of Hillary Clinton. However, he acknowledged that the information he received was not 100% accurate and that just because there were no children present at the pizzeria, it did not mean a pedophile ring did not exist.

Welch also listens to Alex Jones, a conspiracy theorist who regularly spreads conspiracy theories on his radio show and websites. Jones is known for his eccentric views, which Welch described as "a bit eccentric" and "touches on some issues that are viable but goes off the deep end on some things."

The "Pizzagate" myth, built through creative interpretations of emails hacked from John Podesta and released by WikiLeaks to harm Clinton's presidential campaign, has spread beyond Washington, D.C. and has affected other businesses, including the Austin pizzeria East Side Pies. The owners of East Side Pies became aware of the conspiracy theory through strange comments on their Facebook page and Reddit threads linking their pizzeria to the fake story.

The online posts have made wild and baseless accusations about East Side Pies, including interpreting their logo as a symbol of the "Illuminati," questioning photos of pizza-eating children on their Facebook account, and claiming a picture of staffers with former Austin Mayor Lee Leffingwell was proof of nefarious political ties. The owners of East Side Pies have also been accused of having connections to the CIA.

The Austin police and FBI are investigating the threats and vandalism of a pizza delivery truck, which was reportedly linked to the conspiracy theory.

Title: Trump Voters Remain Loyal Despite Criticism and Controversy

Article:

Despite facing ridicule from the national media, chiding from their neighbors, and repeated public relations flare-ups from the White House, President Trump's voters remain remarkably loyal to him, according to pollsters and analysts. These voters reject the notion that they should regret their vote, citing frustration with the resistance mounted by Democrats determined to stymie Trump at every turn.

However, they also blame much of the stalled Trump agenda on congressional Republicans, party leaders, hard-line conservatives, and moderates whose squabbling caused major problems in the Obamacare repeal effort. According to Kevin Madden, a Republican Party strategist, Trump voters are invested in seeing their support validated and still believe it can pay off. They have less trust in the people and institutions trying to convince them they made the wrong choice, like the media and political elites, than they do in the president himself.

Polls have consistently found that the tales of Trump voters abandoning ship are few and far between. Instead, most Trump supporters see him as a powerful leader and celebrate his crusade against political correctness and his combative approach to the news media. They have forgiven him for backing off some of the promises he made on the campaign trail by chalking it up to the fact that he is still getting acclimated to the job and has never been a politician.

Recent polls have shown that a significant majority of Trump backers remain satisfied with their vote. A Fox News survey found that 97% of Trump backers remained satisfied with their vote, while 2% wished they had voted differently. A Washington Post/ABC News poll found that 96% of Trump voters said supporting Mr. Trump was the right thing to do, and 2% said they regretted their decision. A University of Virginia Center for Politics and Public Opinion Strategies poll showed 93% of Trump backers approved of the job he was doing, compared to 52% for House Speaker Paul D. Ryan and 28% for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.

While some cable news networks have made a cottage industry of finding Trump voters who may have fallen off the bandwagon, the data suggests that this is not a widespread phenomenon. The University of Virginia survey found that 88% of respondents said that media criticism of Trump reinforces that the president is on the right track, and the same percentage agreed with Trump's assertion that the press is "the enemy of the American people." The Washington Post/ABC News poll showed that 8 in 10 Trump supporters believed news organizations regularly publish false stories.

Overall, Trump's approval rating remains underwater, according to polls, as the White House struggles with accusations that campaign operatives had ties to Russian officials. The recent firing of FBI Director James B. Comey also ignited calls by Democratic activists and some members of Congress for Trump's impeachment. Democrats hope that the anti-Trump wave, coupled with Trump defections, could help them make serious gains in congressional elections next year. However, so far, anti-Trump sentiment has failed to translate into electoral success, with Republicans winning two special congressional elections to maintain Republican-held districts.

Title: Iowa Caucuses Spark Debate Over Democratic Party's Future

The Iowa caucuses have concluded, and the results are sparking a rift between the moderate and progressive wings of the Democratic Party. Senator Bernie Sanders leads the popular vote with 26.3%, while former Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, trails closely behind. The outcome has raised questions about the viability of Vice President Joe Biden's campaign, which had been considered a front-runner.

The results show a split between the progressive and moderate wings of the party, with Sanders, Senator Elizabeth Warren, and entrepreneur Andrew Yang receiving 51,821 votes combined, while Biden, Buttigieg, and Senator Amy Klobuchar received 54,894 votes combined. This could lead to a protracted and competitive primary, potentially ending in a contested convention.

The Iowa caucuses have been criticized for their unique voting process, with some calling for a switch to a primary system. The caucuses have been plagued by issues, including low turnout and confusion among voters. A former Democratic congressman from Iowa argues that the process still has value, citing its affordability and accessibility for long-shot candidates.

However, others argue that Iowa's first-in-the-nation status is a relic of the past and that it's time for the country to take control of the election process away from the state. The results of the Iowa caucuses will likely have a significant impact on the Democratic primary, and it remains to be seen whether Buttigieg can expand his support across the country, particularly among minority voters.

Title: Obama Criticizes Romney-Ryan Plan, Citing Study on Medicare Costs

Article:

President Barack Obama continued his attack on the Romney-Ryan plan to reform Medicare, citing a study that suggests the plan would increase costs for future recipients. Speaking to a crowd of around 3,000 people at the Florida Institute of Technology in Melbourne, Florida, Obama stated that the plan would result in skyrocketing costs for seniors and increased profits for insurance companies.

According to the study by Harvard professor David Cutler, the plan would increase insurance profits by $16 billion to $20 billion. Cutler, a health policy expert and former adviser to Obama, conducted the study for the liberal Center for American Progress Action Fund.

The Romney campaign responded by calling Cutler an "ObamaCare drafter" and accusing the president of using discredited studies and falsehoods to attack Mitt Romney. The campaign also pointed out that Obama had cut Medicare spending by $716 billion to pay for his healthcare plan.

The debate over Medicare has been a key issue in the presidential campaign, with both sides presenting different visions for the future of the program. Romney and Ryan have proposed containing Medicare costs by giving retirees voucher-like government payments to buy private insurance, while Obama has argued that this would increase costs for seniors and reduce the quality of care.

The study by Cutler, which was also cited by Obama, suggests that older Americans would have to pay more out of pocket to cover the rising costs of healthcare under the Romney-Ryan plan. The Congressional Budget Office has also projected that future retirees would pay more under Ryan's plan than if they went into traditional Medicare.

The debate over Medicare is likely to continue as the presidential campaign heats up, with both sides presenting their visions for the future of the program.

Title: Obama and Romney Exchange Jokes at Charity Dinner, Take Break from Campaign

In a rare moment of levity, President Barack Obama and Republican challenger Mitt Romney put aside their political differences to engage in a lighthearted comedy routine at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner in New York. The annual charity event, organized by the Catholic Archdiocese of New York, benefits needy children and has become a tradition for presidential candidates.

The two men traded jokes and witty remarks, poking fun at each other's policies and personal characteristics. Romney, a teetotaling Mormon, joked about his lack of drinking habits, saying, "I've already seen early reports from tonight's dinner: 'Obama embraced by Catholics, Romney dines with rich people.'" Obama, meanwhile, poked fun at his own debate performance, saying, "I particularly want to apologize to Chris Matthews... Four years ago, I gave him a thrill up his leg, this time I gave him a stroke."

The two also took aim at each other's policies, with Romney joking about Obama's handling of the national deficit and Obama poking fun at Romney's wealth. Romney quipped, "The president's remarks are brought to you by the letter O and the number 16 trillion," while Obama joked, "Earlier today, I went shopping at some stores in Midtown... I understand Governor Romney went shopping for some stores in Midtown."

The event, overseen by Cardinal Timothy Dolan, president of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, was expected to raise $5 million for Catholic charities. The two men will put their comedic skills aside on Monday night, when they face off in their third and final debate in South Florida.

Title: Americans' Skepticism of Government Intervention Shifts Amidst National Crisis

Article:

A recent Gallup poll has revealed that Americans are generally skeptical of government intervention, with a majority believing that the government should do less. However, this sentiment has shifted in times of national crisis, with a growing number of people advocating for the government to take a more active role in solving the country's problems. The current COVID-19 pandemic is one such instance, where Americans are increasingly looking to their government to provide guidance and support.

Despite this shift, President Trump's handling of the crisis has been met with skepticism. His initial downplaying of the virus and promotion of unproven treatments have led to a decline in public trust. According to a recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll, most Americans do not trust Trump's statements about the virus. In contrast, Americans trust their local officials and government health experts for information on the virus.

The White House has not held press briefings over the weekend, with Trump tweeting that they are not worth the time and effort. A briefing was scheduled for Monday evening, but was later removed from the schedule. The White House press secretary, Kayleigh McEnany, stated that Trump and the task force will hold briefings later in the week, but with a "different look."

Meanwhile, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has criticized Trump's efforts to withhold funding from the World Health Organization and other steps his administration is taking to sideline the global health agency.

In other news, two former federal health officials are calling for a $46 billion public health investment in the next coronavirus aid package to safely reopen the economy. Researchers have suggested that states with a low transmission rate of COVID-19, defined as one new infection per million people, can safely ease social distancing measures. However, the World Health Organization has stated that there is currently no evidence that people who have recovered from COVID-19 and have antibodies are protected from a second infection.

Additionally, New York City's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has reported an uptick in calls to the poison control center after Trump's comments on using disinfectants to combat the virus. As the pandemic continues to dominate the political conversation, Americans' ambivalence about science and experts is likely to come to the forefront.

Title: American Jewish Congregation's Support for Palestine's New Status Sparks Debate

A recent email sent by a group of rabbis from the B'nai Jeshurun synagogue in White Plains, New York, expressing cautious optimism about Palestine's new status at the United Nations, has sparked a heated debate within the American Jewish community. The email, which was signed by the rabbis and the synagogue's board of directors, stated that the vote could be a step towards a two-state solution and Middle East peace.

While some congregants welcomed the move, others were left feeling "numb" and "shocked" by the rabbis' decision to publicly take a stance on the issue. The email's tone and timing were seen as jarring by some, who felt it was a departure from the typical reluctance of mainstream congregations to speak out on the matter.

Gary Rosenblatt, editor and publisher of The Jewish Week, noted that the sense of a need for a unified front in the American Jewish community is breaking down. Rabbi Lester Bronstein, one of the signers of the email, said that the statement reflects what more and more rabbis believe, but in trickles, are able to say it.

The email was not without its critics, with some congregants expressing dismay and disappointment. Eve Birnbaum, a member of the synagogue for about 15 years, said she was "very dismayed" that the rabbis and the board would take a position that is contrary to what many members believe.

The debate is not new, as American Jews have long had a vigorous and sometimes vitriolic debate about the positions of the Israeli government and the peace process with the Palestinians. However, the tendency has been to keep critical views within the fold. The email from B'nai Jeshurun's rabbis has brought the issue to the forefront, sparking a discussion about what it means to support Israel and whether it means never criticizing it.

The synagogue, which is not affiliated with any of the major branches of Judaism, has attracted attention for its success at energizing a once-struggling congregation. The email has also sparked a heated debate online, with some rabbis and community leaders weighing in on the issue.

**Charleston Church Shooting Suspect Accused of Racially Motivated Massacre**

A former friend of the man accused of the Charleston, South Carolina church shooting has come forward, stating that Dylann Roof had become an avowed racist. Joey Meek, who reconnected with Roof a few weeks ago, said that while they got drunk together, Roof began complaining about "blacks taking over the world" and that "someone needed to do something about it for the white race."

Roof, 21, is accused of fatally shooting nine people during a Bible study at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston on Wednesday night. He was charged with nine counts of murder and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.

Meek called the FBI after recognizing Roof in surveillance footage, noting that Roof wore the same stained sweatshirt he wore while playing Xbox videogames at Meek's home the morning of the attack. A classmate reportedly described Roof as a "pill popper" who "told racist jokes."

Those who knew Roof say they remember him talking about a scheme fueled by his segregationist ideals. Meek said Roof told him he wanted to "start a civil war." Meek also stated that Roof told him he had used birthday money from his parents to buy a.45-caliber Glock pistol and had a "plan" that was six months in the making. Meek said it scared him enough that he took the gun out of Roof's car and hid it in his house until the next day.

Roof made incriminating statements indicating he was involved in the shooting, according to reports. Police captured Roof in Shelby, North Carolina, after a motorist spotted him at a traffic light on her way to work. His apprehension ended an intense, hours-long manhunt.

The victims included a state senator who doubled as the church's minister, three other pastors, a regional library manager, a high school coach and speech therapist, a government administrator, a college enrollment counselor, and a recent college graduate - six women and three men who felt called to open their church to all.

The shooting has evoked painful memories nationwide, a reminder that black churches have often been the targets of racist violence. The Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, founded in 1816, has a history of being a beacon of black power and a symbol of resistance against racism.

Title: FCC Plans to Repeal Net Neutrality Rules, Giving Internet Service Providers Sweeping Powers

The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is set to vote on December 14 to repeal the 2015 net neutrality rules, which prohibited internet service providers (ISPs) from blocking or slowing down access to certain online content. The move would give ISPs the power to decide what web content consumers can access and at what price.

FCC Chairman Ajit Pai, a Republican appointed by President Donald Trump, announced the plan to rescind the rules, which were championed by former President Barack Obama. The rules were intended to ensure a free and open internet, giving consumers equal access to web content and preventing ISPs from favoring their own content.

The repeal is likely to be approved, with three Republican and two Democratic commissioners on the FCC. The move is opposed by Google parent Alphabet Inc and Facebook Inc, which had urged Pai not to rescind the rules. Netflix also expressed its opposition, stating it would "roll back these core protections."

Pai argued that the FCC will no longer be in the business of micromanaging business models and preemptively prohibiting services and applications and products that could be pro-competitive. He stated that the Obama administration had sought to pick winners and losers and exercised "heavy-handed" regulation of the internet.

The planned repeal is expected to draw a legal challenge from advocates of net neutrality. The FCC received over 22 million comments on the issue, with many expressing concerns about the potential impact on consumers and the internet.

The repeal is the latest example of a legacy achievement of Obama being erased since Trump took office. Pai has moved quickly to undo numerous regulatory actions since becoming FCC chairman, pushing a broad deregulatory agenda. The FCC's repeal is certain to have significant implications for the internet and the way consumers access online content.

Title: Attorney General Barr's Investigation into Russia Probe Origins Continues, Sources Say

Article:

Attorney General William Barr has assigned John Durham, a U.S. attorney, to investigate the origins of the Russia probe. According to multiple sources familiar with the matter, Durham is "very dialed in" and "asking all the right questions." Durham has been briefed on the "four corners" of the investigations into the FBI's use of Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrants, among other issues.

Barr has met with Durham on multiple occasions in recent weeks, sources within the Justice Department confirmed to Fox News. Durham's high level of engagement in the probe comes days after Barr expressed dissatisfaction with the answers he received from the intelligence community in the early stages of his review into the origins of the Russia investigation.

Durham is specifically reviewing the FISA warrant obtained by the FBI to surveil former Trump aide Carter Page, as well as general issues relating to surveillance during the 2016 campaign and matters flowing from the FISA process. Fox News is told Durham would handle the prosecution of any criminal action he might uncover.

Before the 2016 midterm elections, Republicans who controlled key House committees sought to "tee up" potential targets for future investigation. They pointed in particular to the apparent conflict in testimony between the co-founder of the opposition research firm Fusion GPS, Glenn Simpson, and DOJ official Bruce Ohr. Fusion GPS was retained by the Hillary Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee (DNC), which in turn hired British ex-spy Christopher Steele to write the infamous dossier that the FBI relied on in its FISA application to surveil Page.

Simpson testified to the House Intelligence Committee that he contacted Ohr about the largely discredited dossier after Thanksgiving 2016, but Ohr's records point to contact months earlier, in August. Bruce Ohr became a backchannel for Steele to the FBI in the fall of 2016 after the bureau fired the ex-spy over contacts with the media.

Last month, Republican Rep. Mark Meadows made a criminal referral for Ohr's wife, Nellie, who worked for Fusion GPS. Nellie did extensive opposition research on Trump family members and campaign aides while working for Fusion GPS, according to a transcript of her closed-door interview with Congress.

Title: Cape Wind Project Approval Sparks Controversy Over Alleged Political Pressure

The Cape Wind project, the nation's first offshore wind farm, has received the green light after over a decade of debate. However, opponents of the project claim that the Obama administration applied pressure to get the project approved, citing documents obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is accused of fast-tracking the project despite safety concerns for local aviation.

According to documents obtained by the Alliance to Protect Nantucket Sound, an organization opposed to the project, the FAA acknowledged in 2009 that the Cape Wind project is "highly political" and that it would be difficult to refuse approval due to pressure from the White House to promote green energy production. A 2010 PowerPoint presentation also stated that the Secretary of the Interior had approved the project, and it would be "very difficult politically to refuse approval."

Congressman Cliff Stearns, who led the investigation into the failed solar panel firm Solyndra, is now calling for a probe into Cape Wind, stating that the emails he has seen show the White House pushing the FAA for political reasons. Audra Parker, president of the Alliance to Protect Nantucket Sound, welcomed a congressional investigation, saying that the documents reveal a pattern of political pressure and the FAA's willingness to sacrifice safety concerns for the project.

Cape Wind spokesman Mark Rodgers denied the allegations, stating that the project has undergone a comprehensive review and has been approved three times by the FAA, including during the Bush administration. Rodgers believes that the FAA will once again rule in favor of the project despite political pressure from opponents.

The project is facing multiple lawsuits and the possibility of further delays as both sides continue to dispute the issue. The FAA is currently reviewing the project again after a federal appeals court overturned its previous ruling that the 130 proposed turbines posed no hazard to aviation.

Title: Trump's Ambassador Pick to South Africa Raises Questions About Qualifications and Controversial Past

Article:

President Donald Trump has nominated Lana Marks, a luxury-handbag designer from Palm Beach, as his pick for ambassador to South Africa. While Marks was born and raised in South Africa and attended the University of the Witwatersrand, she lacks any diplomatic experience or training. Her professional background is in designing high-end handbags made from exotic animal skins, with prices ranging from $19,000 to $400,000.

Marks' nomination has raised eyebrows due to her lack of qualifications and a history of legal issues. According to reports, she has been involved in over a dozen lawsuits in Aspen, New York, California, and South Florida, with allegations of stiffing her attorneys, accountants, landlords, and employees. Specifically, she was evicted from her office on Worth Avenue in July 2015 for failing to pay $25,399 in rent and other expenses. Additionally, her landlords filed complaints against her for failing to pay rent in 2004, 2007, and 2009, although the cases were settled without eviction.

The nomination also raises questions about Trump's priorities, as Marks is a member of Mar-a-Lago, his "winter White House" in Palm Beach. Since Trump took office in 2017, membership fees to join the private club have doubled to $200,000, and members have gained access to exclusive events, including dinner-time strategy sessions with the President and even the ability to run a federal agency. Four Mar-a-Lago members have been nominated as ambassadors abroad, including Marks.

The nomination will now go to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for confirmation, which may consider the past lawsuits against Marks. Trump's own track record on South Africa is also questionable, as he has tweeted about the country's "large scale" land seizures and killing of white farmers, a claim that has been widely debunked as a myth perpetuated by white supremacists.

Title: Former Vice President Joe Biden Calls for President Trump's Impeachment

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden has publicly expressed his support for the impeachment of President Trump, stating that the president has "indicted himself" by obstructing justice and refusing to comply with the congressional inquiry. Biden made these comments during a campaign event in Rochester, New Hampshire, where he emphasized that Trump has "violated his oath of office, betrayed this nation, and committed impeachable acts."

Biden's comments come as the House Democrats continue their impeachment inquiry into Trump's dealings with Ukraine. The investigation was triggered by a whistleblower's complaint against Trump over his alleged pressure on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate Trump's political opponents, including Biden and his son Hunter.

The White House has released a memo summarizing Trump's July 25 phone call with Zelensky, which Trump has defended as "perfect." However, the call was part of a whistleblower's complaint against the president, which led to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's announcement of a formal impeachment inquiry into Trump.

Since then, a flurry of developments have given added impetus to the impeachment probe. Trump has called on China to investigate the Bidens, claiming that "nobody has any doubt that they weren't crooked." However, he has yet to provide evidence of any wrongdoing.
