Biden's response to Trump's attacks over recent weeks has been criticized as slow and ineffective by some Democrats, raising unpleasant memories of the "Swift Boat" attacks by Republicans on Democratic nominee John Kerry in 2004. Biden's campaign manager, Kate Bedingfield, has stated that the campaign will not engage in Trump's "game" and will instead focus on the corruption in his own administration.

In a tweet, Trump responded to Biden's comments, saying that the former vice president is "ripping off" countries for millions of dollars and calling for his own impeachment. Biden fired back, saying that Trump should "stop stonewalling the Congress, honor your oath, and respect the Constitution."

Title: Romney Outlines Foreign Policy Differences with Obama, Emphasizes Need for Clear Leadership

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, outlined his foreign policy differences with President Obama on Monday, emphasizing the need for clear leadership and a recommitment to a two-state solution between Israelis and Palestinians. Speaking at the Virginia Military Institute, Romney accused the Obama administration of "passivity" on the international stage, which he said is damaging the interests of the US and its allies.

Romney laid out his "bedrock principles" towards the Middle East, stating that the US must adhere to them to give American allies the certainty a stable world needs. He emphasized the importance of free trade, saying that the US must "champion free trade and restore it as a critical element of our strategy, both in the Middle East and across the world." Romney also called for U.S. aid to Egypt to come with new conditions that would push the new regime to respect democracy and live up to its peace treaty commitments with Israel.

On Iran, Romney remained vague on whether he would support a pre-emptive military strike, saying instead that "we must make clear to Iran through actions – not just words – that their nuclear pursuit will not be tolerated." He also emphasized the need for the US to do more to get arms into the hands of Syrian rebels, saying that the US must "work with our partners to identify and organize those members of the opposition who share our values and ensure they obtain the arms they need to defeat Assad's tanks, helicopters, and fighter jets."

Critics from the Obama camp and beyond said Romney's speech lacked substance and failed to articulate a dramatically different vision from the president's. Gordon Adams, an international relations professor at American University, said that when it comes to defining exactly what Romney would do, "it's pretty much the same thing when the rubber hits the road that Obama's already doing."

Romney's speech did not provide clear answers on how he would address the complex issues in the Middle East, and critics argued that his proposals were unrealistic and lacked a comprehensive strategy. However, Romney emphasized the need for clear and predictable behavior from the White House, saying that the world will see a new approach under his leadership.

Title: Controversies Surrounding the Affordable Care Act: A Review of the Facts

The Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, was signed into law by President Obama in 2010. Since its implementation, the law has faced numerous criticisms and controversies. One of the most notable issues is the promise made by the White House and Democrats that individuals could keep their healthcare plans, which has been disputed by many.

In 2010, President Obama acknowledged that between 8-9 million people may lose their coverage due to the new law. This admission was made during a healthcare summit before the signing of the bill. Additionally, every Senate Democrat voted against a resolution that would have allowed people to keep their healthcare plans.

In September 2010, Senate Republicans brought a resolution to the floor to block the implementation of the grandfather rule, warning that it would result in canceled policies and violate President Obama's promise. Three years later, Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius admitted under oath that end-to-end security testing was not done on Healthcare.gov before its launch, putting American personal information at risk and making them vulnerable to fraud and identity theft.

Associate Professor of Economics at St. John's University, M. Northrop Buechner, has argued in Forbes that President Obama's actions in changing the Affordable Care Act are unconstitutional. According to Buechner, the Constitution authorizes the President to propose and veto legislation, but not to change existing laws. The changes made by President Obama, therefore, are unconstitutional.

The article highlights the controversy surrounding the Affordable Care Act and the criticisms it has faced since its implementation. While impeachment is not likely with a divided Congress, the article presents a review of the facts and the arguments made by Associate Professor Buechner, highlighting the constitutional concerns surrounding President Obama's actions.

Title: Minnesota Rep. Michele Bachmann's Retirement Announcement Dominates News Cycle, Highlights Her Impact on Washington

Minnesota Representative Michele Bachmann's decision not to seek a fifth term has sparked a flurry of reactions from both supporters and detractors. While her political career has been marked by controversy and criticism, Bachmann's impact on Washington cannot be denied. As a conservative Christian and Tea Party advocate, she rode the wave of the movement's early success and became a national figure.

Bachmann's political career has been marked by a series of missteps and fabrications, but she also secured a place in political history by opening the door for conservative female candidates and new Republican Tea Party favorites, such as Texas Senator Ted Cruz and Florida Senator Marco Rubio. She also established herself as a fundraising juggernaut, raising nearly $15 million for her 2012 race against Democrat Jim Graves.

Conservative blogger Dan Riehl notes that Bachmann's audacity helped open the door for conservative female candidates and new Republican Tea Party favorites. "She was a voice against the Republican establishment, a thorn in its side," he said. "In certain ways, she was an iconic figure – effective just because she was there... She was kicking on the door early and was isolated. You have some people benefiting from the heat she took."

Bachmann's effectiveness as a legislator was not her primary focus, but she founded the House Tea Party Caucus and became a face of the emerging movement, making "repeal Obamacare" her clarion call. Congresswoman Bachmann was able to skillfully use the media, particularly cable media, to articulate a very conservative message and articulate opposition to the Obama administration in ways that went beyond that of mainstream Republicans.

Despite her controversies, Bachmann remains a polarizing figure, and her retirement announcement dominated the news cycle. While some Republicans cringe at her antics, others see her as a champion of conservative values. "Michele Bachmann was someone who ran on principles and lives those principles," said Jake Duesenberg, head of the East Metro Tea Party organization. "She packed the house" at a recent Tea Party gathering, he noted.

Bachmann's legacy is complex, marked by both her impact on the Tea Party movement and her controversies. While she may not have been the most effective legislator, she was a force to be reckoned with in Washington, and her retirement announcement has sparked a renewed discussion about her legacy.

Title: Obama's "Better Off" Claim Haunts Democrats as Election Cycle Progresses

The 2012 presidential election cycle has seen a renewed focus on a statement made by President Barack Obama during his first campaign: "If we don't put people back to work, if we don't make the tough decisions now, then we'll be right back in this very same place four years later, asking for another term." This statement has come back to haunt him, with his surrogates and aides struggling to provide concrete evidence of the country being better off after three years of his presidency.

Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley's flip-flop on the issue has sparked controversy, with his initial statement on Face the Nation saying the country is not better off, followed by a tweet claiming it is better off due to job creation. This reversal has left many questioning the administration's stance on the issue.

Vice President Joe Biden has also been asked about the matter, stating that the country is indeed better off, but failing to provide concrete evidence to support this claim. Obama campaign senior adviser David Axelrod and Democratic National Committee spokesman Brad Woodhouse have also been asked about the issue, with Axelrod citing the time it took to create the economic crisis and Woodhouse stating that the country is absolutely better off.

The Obama campaign's deputy campaign manager, Stephanie Cutter, also addressed the question on the Today Show, stating that the country is better off and providing a brief overview of life four years ago. However, many Americans remain skeptical, citing personal experiences of job losses and struggling businesses.

The debate surrounding the "better off" question highlights the challenges the Obama administration faces in convincing the public that their policies have had a positive impact on the economy. As the election cycle progresses, it remains to be seen whether the administration can provide concrete evidence to support their claims.

**US Imposes Tariffs on Chinese Goods, China Responds with Duties on US Shipments**

The United States and China have exchanged blows in a trade war that is expected to have far-reaching consequences for the global economy. The US imposed a 25% levy on $34 billion of Chinese goods entering the country, effective from Friday, with farming plows and airplane parts among the products targeted. China responded immediately with duties on US shipments, including soybeans and automobiles.

The tariffs, which were widely telegraphed, had a limited impact on financial markets, with US stocks rising and the dollar extending losses. Treasuries gained, and gold declined as investors assessed the impact of the escalation in the trade rift.

The US released jobs figures that showed few signs of early pressures on employment from the trade tension. US hiring topped forecasts in June, while the unemployment rate rose from an 18-year low and wage gains unexpectedly slowed.

The extent of the economic damage will depend on how far both sides go. If the US and China cool off after a first round of tariffs, the fallout will be modest, according to economists. However, if the trade war escalates, the US could see a slowdown in growth, with economists predicting a 0.8 percentage point decline by 2020.

The US runs a bilateral trade deficit of $336 billion with China and imports much more from it than the reverse, giving it an early advantage. Trump has declared trade wars as "easy to win" and believes the skirmish will prompt American companies to return operations to the US.

China has other ways to retaliate, including going after US companies such as Apple and Walmart, which operate in its market and are keen to expand. It could introduce penalties such as customs delays, tax audits, and increased regulatory scrutiny, or take more drastic steps like devaluing the yuan or paring $1.2 trillion holdings of US Treasuries.

The strength and size of both economies means the fight could rage on for years. Beijing has shown little interest in making fundamental changes to its economic model, and President Xi Jinping has balked at US demands to stop subsidizing Chinese firms under his plan to make the nation a leader in key technologies by 2025.

Title: A Divided Nation: Exploring the Rise of Political Polarization

The article recounts the author's personal experience of losing a close friend due to political differences. The author, a former Nixon staffer, describes how a woman he worked with for decades, a self-proclaimed militant leftist, stopped speaking to him after the 2016 presidential election. The author attributes this sudden change to Trump's personality, suggesting that there is something about him that frightens or excites bullies.

The article goes on to explore the phenomenon of political polarization, noting that it has become a "Civil War" between brothers, children, and parents. The author wonders why Trump's presidency has unleashed such rage and bitterness, concluding that it is not about policy, but rather about personality. He suggests that Trump's strong and dominant personality may be the reason for the intense hatred and anger from some individuals.

The article also touches on the idea that the left has an "astonishing capacity for hate," referencing historical examples of hate and rage from various groups. The author questions why this type of hate and rage often comes from the left, noting that decent, life-loving men and women do not riot or demand special treatment.

The article concludes by expressing the author's sadness over losing a close friend and his confusion about why Trump's presidency has caused such a strong reaction.

Title: Trump Accuses Mueller's Office of Coercing Witnesses to Testify Against Him

President Donald Trump has launched a new attack on Special Counsel Robert Mueller's office, accusing it of trying to coerce witnesses to testify against him. This comes after Mueller's office accused former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort of lying to the FBI and violating a plea agreement.

Trump took to Twitter to express his concerns, stating that "at least 3 major players are intimating that the Angry Mueller Gang of Dems is viciously telling witnesses to lie about facts & they will get relief." He appears to be referring to Manafort, long-time political adviser Roger Stone, and conservative writer Jerome Corsi, an ally of Stone who rejected a plea deal from Mueller.

Trump's legal team has joint defense agreements with witnesses in the Mueller investigation, and they have shared information about the probe. Manafort, Stone, and Corsi have accused Mueller's office of coercing testimony, as has Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani. Giuliani claimed that prosecutors are treating Manafort "like he's a terrorist," citing documents from Corsi indicating that prosecutors want him to provide false information about Trump.

Manafort struck a deal to cooperate with Mueller's team in September, but maintained his joint defense agreement with Trump. This unusual development has raised concerns among lawmakers and legal analysts, who believe Manafort's decision to cooperate was highly deceptive and undermined the investigation.

Some lawmakers have proposed legislation to protect the special counsel's job, while others have accused Manafort and other witnesses of seeking pardons from the president. White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders denied any plans to remove Mueller or grant pardons related to the investigation.

The controversy surrounding Mueller's office and its investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election continues to unfold.

Title: House Democrats Introduce Comprehensive Election Reform Bill, HR 1

The House Democrats have introduced a comprehensive election reform bill, known as HR 1, which aims to address various issues in four key areas: voting, political money, redistricting, and ethics. The 571-page bill is a compilation of existing problems and proposed solutions, building on a pledge made by Democratic House candidates last year to pass legislation addressing these concerns.

The bill's introduction comes as a response to the American people's feelings of being "left out and locked out" from their democracy, according to Representative John Sarbanes, D-Md. The bill's provisions aim to increase voter registration, improve election transparency, and reduce the influence of money in politics.

Some of the bill's provisions push the envelope, including the proposal to take away the power of state legislatures to draw congressional districts and instead have independent commissions do it. This is intended to prevent gerrymandering and ensure fair representation.

The bill also includes an update of the Disclose Act, a measure aimed at increasing transparency in political spending. The bill would require digital companies like Facebook and Google to set up public databases cataloging political ad purchases and create measures to block ad buys by foreign nationals.

Other provisions include making voter registration easier, allowing citizens to register online or automatically through government data, and providing same-day registration and at least 15 days of early voting for federal elections. Election Day would also become a federal holiday.

The bill would also crack down on efforts to remove voters from the rolls or prevent them from casting ballots, and felons could regain their voting rights after completing their sentences. Federal elections would require paper ballots to prevent computer tampering, and state chief election officials would be prohibited from getting involved in federal campaigns.

The bill would also revive core anti-discrimination provisions of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, which were effectively shut down by the Supreme Court six years ago. Additionally, it would state that failing to vote is not grounds for taking away a person's voter registration.

The bill's provisions would also expand the prohibition on foreign political money, mandate the disclosure of big donors behind socially active 501(c)(4) organizations, and require presidential inaugural committees to disclose expenditures. A new matching-fund program would support House candidates who agree to raise only small-dollar contributions, and the public financing system for presidential candidates would be updated.

While the bill's introduction is a significant step towards addressing election reform, its passage is unlikely this year due to Republican control of the Senate and the opposition of the GOP.

Title: Surplus Military Equipment Sent to Local Police Departments Declines Despite Trump's Executive Order

The amount of surplus military equipment sent to local police departments across the United States has decreased significantly in recent months, despite an executive order signed by President Trump aimed at increasing these transfers. According to Department of Defense data, shipments of military gear in the first three months of 2018 fell by half compared to the same period last year. The value of armored vehicles, high-caliber rifles, and other equipment also decreased.

The executive order, signed by Trump in August, rescinded limits imposed on the program by the Obama administration after the Ferguson, Missouri, riots in 2014. Some police officials have expressed caution about the program, citing concerns about the optics of receiving military equipment. "If you have a long rifle or you have a military vehicle, it looks bad," said Sgt. Stephen Wells, a spokesman for the Kern County Sheriff's Office in California.

The program, which has recycled about $6.8 billion in military equipment purchased by federal taxpayers since 1991, came under scrutiny after the Ferguson riots. Images of officers wearing tactical gear standing alongside armored vehicles flashed across network news and drew bipartisan criticism in Congress. In response, Obama placed limits on some kinds of equipment in 2015, saying the show of force opened a rift between the police and the community at a time when both would have benefited from better relations.

Trump administration officials argued that the restrictions went too far, limiting police from obtaining equipment that could help them meet modern challenges. However, data show a bump in shipments in September, the month immediately following Trump's action, but this appears to have been an anomaly. The average monthly value of military gear shipped to local departments in 2016 was just over $17 million, while so far this year, the average monthly value stands at $5.2 million.

A White House spokeswoman referred questions to the Justice Department, which in turn referred questions to the Defense Department. A Defense Logistics Agency spokeswoman said the decline is "likely due to those... items not being available." While some police departments are more aware of the public relations concerns associated with the equipment, Wells and others suggested that local law enforcement is unlikely to abandon the program entirely. The equipment remains crucial for dangerous situations such as an active shooter.

The most common items transferred to police last year were military rifles, followed by weapon sights and night-vision goggles. James Pasco, executive director of the Fraternal Order of Police, believes Trump's order has put police across the nation in a stronger position. However, critics pounced on the program again last year when the Government Accountability Office created a fictitious agency and obtained more than 100 military items worth $1.2 million, including night-vision goggles and simulated pipe bombs.

The Project on Government Oversight, a Washington-based watchdog group, predicted last fall that Trump's order would have little effect on the shipments. The more significant change, experts said, has been on how the government oversees the program. "Trump did not make a huge difference in what is or is not allowed, despite statements from some in the administration," said Peter Tyler, a senior policy analyst with the group. "Mostly what the Obama-era order did was put in some very helpful accountability steps."

Title: The Power of Mothers in Shaping America's Future

The article highlights the significance of mothers in shaping the future of America. The author emphasizes that mothers are the center of the home and the foundation of society, and that they have the power to mold the future of the nation. The article also notes that the current state of American society is a concern, with many children lacking a love and appreciation for the flag and the country.

The author argues that the decline of traditional values and the lack of teaching about American history and heritage in schools are contributing factors to this problem. They suggest that parents must take responsibility for teaching their children about American values and the importance of liberty.

The article also references various quotes and statements from notable figures, including Barbara Bush and Peter Wolf, emphasizing the importance of parents being the first line of defense in teaching their children about American values and history.

The author concludes by emphasizing the significance of mothers in shaping the future of America and encourages them to take an active role in nurturing and fostering the principles and ideals of freedom in their homes.

This article presents a neutral and factual account of the importance of mothers in shaping the future of America, without taking a political stance or expressing personal opinions.

Title: Trump Discusses Campaign, Speech, and Controversies in Pre-Recorded Interview

In a pre-recorded interview with ABC's George Stephanopoulos, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump discussed his campaign, his upcoming acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention, and various controversies surrounding his campaign. When asked if he thought he would get this far in the election, Trump replied, "People have asked me that question, and I guess the answer has to be yes, or I don't think I would have done it."

Trump emphasized that his acceptance speech will focus on the country's problems and the need for change, stating, "We have deep problems, we have really deep-seated problems... It's not about the entrance, it's about the words and it's about getting the words done." He also mentioned that the speech will cover topics such as trade, law and order, and the nation's borders.

When asked about his campaign's progress, Trump said, "I am who I am. I'm a very honest person. I think that my message is a good message. It got me here. We had almost 14 million votes. That's more votes than anybody in the history of the Republican Party." He also disagreed with polls showing that many Americans consider him unqualified to run for the presidency, stating, "I think I'm very qualified, but don't forget Hillary is spending hundreds of millions on ads."

Trump also addressed the controversy surrounding his wife Melania's speech, which was criticized for similarities to Michelle Obama's 2008 Democratic National Convention speech. He defended Melania, saying, "She's been with me a long time, a good person. She came to see me, she hated to see the conflict and she made a mistake. People make mistakes. You've made mistakes. We all make mistakes." He also praised the media for not holding Melania responsible for the controversy.

The interview did not touch on Trump's feud with Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, who has refused to endorse him.

Title: Researchers Develop Biodegradable Tube to Bridge Nerve Gaps, Restoring Function in Mice and Monkeys

Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh have made a breakthrough in bridging gaps in peripheral nerves, a common problem in nerve injuries. The team developed a biodegradable tube that releases a protein called glial-cell-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) for several months, guiding the nerve to grow along the proper path and inducing faster growth. In a study published in Science Translational Medicine, the researchers demonstrated the effectiveness of the device in mice and monkeys.

The device, developed by Kacey Marra, a professor at the University of Pittsburgh's departments of plastic surgery and bioengineering, aims to help soldiers injured in combat, as well as civilians who suffer nerve injuries in car accidents or other incidents. Marra notes that over half of injured soldiers suffer nerve injuries, and the current treatment involves relocating a nerve from another part of the body, which often results in limited recovery.

The new device restored nearly 80% of function in the damaged nerve, according to the study. The tube is made of the same polymer as dissolvable stitches, which has already been federally approved for surgical use. The researchers are now planning clinical trials in humans, with the first trials likely to start in 2021 and take at least three years.

Other researchers are exploring the use of stem cells or other cells to help bridge the gap in the nerve, but Marra's approach is likely to have an easier time receiving federal approval because it does not involve cells. Christine Schmidt, a professor and chair of the department of biomedical engineering at the University of Florida, notes that the nerve tested in the study is relatively small in macaques, and scaling up to larger nerves will be a challenge.

The researchers are also studying whether their method will work for facial nerves and are exploring the regeneration of muscles affected by injured nerves. Marra believes her device can be competitively priced compared to moving a nerve from elsewhere in the body and potentially even compared to existing repair approaches for small nerve gaps.

Title: U.S. Military to Reduce Aircraft Carrier Presence in Persian Gulf Due to Budget Constraints

The U.S. military is planning to reduce its aircraft carrier presence in the Persian Gulf from two to one, effective immediately, due to looming budget constraints. The decision was confirmed by U.S. military officials, who stated that the Navy made the request to Defense Secretary Leon Panetta, who approved it.

The USS Harry S. Truman, which was scheduled to deploy from Norfolk, Virginia, has been cancelled, and the USS John C. Stennis, currently the only carrier in the Gulf, will return home later this month. The Navy has 10 aircraft carriers in its fleet, with only three forward-deployed at any given time. The reduction in carrier presence is expected to save the Navy "several hundred million dollars per year."

The decision comes as lawmakers continue to debate how to avoid automatic budget cuts, set to take effect on March 1. The Pentagon has warned that if Congress does not act, it will have to absorb $46 billion in spending reductions in this fiscal year and face a $35 billion shortfall in operating expenses.

In a speech at Georgetown University, Defense Secretary Leon Panetta expressed concerns about the potential consequences of the budget cuts, stating that a "dangerous and callous attitude" is developing among some lawmakers, who are willing to allow the cuts to take place in order to blame the other party for the consequences.

The military services have also outlined widespread civilian furloughs, layoffs, and hiring freezes that will affect workers across the country. The Navy will cease deployments to South America and the Caribbean and limit those to Europe, while the Air Force will cut operations at various missile defense radar sites from 24 hours to eight hours. The Army will cancel training center rotations for four brigades and cancel repairs for thousands of vehicles, radios, and weapons.

Additionally, U.S. troops are likely to see a smaller pay hike next year than initially planned, due to strains on the budget. The Pentagon will recommend a 1% pay increase in 2014, instead of the previously planned 1.7% raise.

Title: US President Trump Speaks with Russian President Putin, Discussing Various Issues

Article:

US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin held an hour-long phone call, covering a range of topics, including the "Russian hoax." The conversation was the first between the two leaders since the release of the Mueller report, which cleared Trump of colluding with Russia.

According to Trump's tweet, the conversation was "long and very good." When asked if he had warned Putin against meddling in the 2020 elections, Trump rebuked the reporter, saying it was "very rude" and that getting along with countries is a good thing. The White House press secretary, Sarah Sanders, confirmed that the matter of alleged Russian meddling was briefly discussed during the call, but did not provide further details.

The call also touched on the investigation by US Special Counsel Robert Mueller into alleged Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. The redacted report concluded that Russia had interfered in the election "in sweeping and systematic fashion," but did not find evidence of Trump campaign collusion with Russia.

In addition to discussing the Mueller report, Trump and Putin also touched on thorny foreign policy issues. The White House described the conversation as an "overall positive conversation."

Title: Obama Administration Proposes New Regulations to Reduce Carbon Emissions and Increase Renewable Energy

The Obama administration has proposed new regulations aimed at reducing carbon emissions and increasing the use of renewable energy sources in the United States. The plan, which is expected to be finalized in the coming months, sets a goal for power companies to generate 28% of the country's energy from renewable sources by 2030, up from the current 11%. Additionally, the regulations require power companies to cut carbon emissions to 32% of 2005 levels over the same period.

The new rules are seen as a major step towards recasting the energy industry in the United States and positioning the country as a leader in the fight against climate change. The regulations will also face significant challenges, including legal challenges and opposition from energy companies.

The Obama administration's plan is modeled after the approach taken by Western European countries such as Sweden and Germany, which have made significant strides in reducing their carbon footprint. Germany, for example, has set a goal of generating 80% of its energy from renewable sources by 2050.

However, the path to a greener energy future is not without its challenges. Energy companies are likely to oppose the regulations, and some states may refuse to comply. The Obama administration has given states flexibility to come up with their own plans, but if they refuse, the administration will impose a plan.

The new regulations are expected to have a significant impact on the energy industry, with potentially hundreds of coal-fired power plants being closed. Critics argue that the rules will lead to steep price increases, while supporters believe the benefits will outweigh the costs.

The Obama administration claims that the rules will not increase energy prices, but it is unclear how the new regulations will be implemented and what the impact will be on consumers. The plan is expected to be finalized in the coming months, and it remains to be seen how the energy industry and the public will respond.

**Coronavirus Spreads Across the United States, 21 Cases Confirmed on Quarantined Cruise Ship**

The novel coronavirus has spread to eight more states, bringing the total number of cases in the United States to over 100, according to U.S. officials. The virus has also been confirmed on a cruise ship that was barred from docking in San Francisco, with 19 crew members and two passengers testing positive out of 46 people tested.

Vice President Mike Pence, who is leading the White House's response to the outbreak, announced the news at a news conference. The Grand Princess ship, which has around 3,500 passengers and crew, will be taken to a non-commercial port where everyone on board will be tested.

President Donald Trump has expressed concerns about allowing passengers to disembark, citing the potential risk of spreading the virus further. "I'd rather have them stay on, personally, but I fully understand if they want to take them off," Trump said.

The virus has already caused significant disruptions to daily life in the United States, with school closures, work-from-home orders, and event cancellations. The South by Southwest music and technology festival in Austin, Texas, was called off on Friday.

The virus has also had a significant impact on the economy, with stocks plummeting and companies grappling with the fallout. The Trump administration is considering tax relief for the cruise, travel, and airline industries, according to a source familiar with the plan.

The virus has been reported in more than 90 countries, with over 100,000 cases and over 3,400 deaths worldwide. The World Health Organization has declared the outbreak a global health emergency.

Title: College Republicans Release Report on GOP's Struggles with Young Voters

The College Republican National Committee (CRNC) has released a 95-page report detailing the Republican Party's struggles with young voters in the 2012 elections. The report, titled "Grand Old Party for a Brand New Generation," presents a scathing critique of the GOP's views on social and economic issues, messaging, and outreach efforts.

The study, based on two national surveys of 800 registered voters aged 18-29 and six focus groups, reveals a dismal picture for the Republican Party. The report highlights several key challenges the party faces in wooing young voters, including its perceived stance on issues such as gay marriage, its treatment of Hispanic voters, and its economic policies.

The report notes that the GOP's focus on downsizing Big Government and cutting taxes has been a major turn-off for young voters, who are more concerned with issues such as education, healthcare, and the economy. The study also criticizes the party's use of polarizing rhetoric and its failure to effectively communicate its message to young people.

The report presents a way forward for the Republican Party, highlighting the need for a more inclusive and diverse message that resonates with young voters. The study concludes that the GOP can win back young voters, but it will require significant work to repair the damage done to the party's brand over the past decade.

The report is the result of extensive polling and focus groups conducted by the Winston Group, a Washington-based GOP polling firm. The study is a significant investment for the CRNC, which has 250,000 members on 1,800 campuses across the country.

Title: Leaks Fallout: Experts Weigh In on Potential Harm to U.S. Intelligence Efforts

The recent wave of leaks about the National Security Agency's (NSA) surveillance programs has sparked concerns about the potential harm to U.S. intelligence efforts. Director of National Intelligence James Clapper has described the leaks as having done "huge, grave damage" to the country's intelligence gathering capabilities. However, Glenn Greenwald, the Guardian columnist who served as the primary conduit for the leaks, disputes this claim, stating that "there's not a single revelation that we've provided to the world that even remotely jeopardizes national security."

Intelligence experts and former officials interviewed by [source] agree that there will likely be some harm to U.S. intelligence efforts, but not in the way many Americans might expect. The most significant impact is likely to be felt by the U.S. Internet industry, as some of its international customers flee in search of sites thought to be more secure from American government snooping.

Former officials suggest that it's not the specifics of what was leaked that are the issue, but rather the huge wave of publicity generated by the leaks. Every news story could serve as a revelation to some terrorists, and a reminder to others, of the nation's capabilities. "It's kind of Darwinian," said former NSA Director Michael Hayden. "The more stuff like this is in the public domain, we'll still catch terrorists, but it will be the stupid terrorists... The guys we should really be worried about will be far less likely to be swept up in this effort."

While many Americans view terrorists as careful and well-informed, ex-intelligence officials say that in reality, their skill sets run the gamut, and the biggest terror threat in the United States right now actually seems to be homegrown extremists who are not hardened operatives and who lack first-rate tradecraft. These are the precisely the sorts of novices who could be tipped off or decide to behave more furtively precisely because of the recent spate of surveillance disclosures.

Former NSA General Counsel Joel Brenner noted that intelligence agencies make a living off of other people's mistakes, and that even seemingly minor changes in language can affect the way targets of U.S. intelligence behave. Hayden, who ran off-the-record seminars for journalists at NSA headquarters, emphasized the importance of using vague phrases instead of specific terms like "intercepts" in stories.

Despite the controversy surrounding the leaks, there remains considerable dispute about whether the harm comes directly from the leaks themselves or from media coverage that has treated them as earth-shattering revelations. Some experts argue that there are things that are available to be known that people don't know, and that part of the American public expressed shock this week at things that were already in the public domain.

Title: President Trump's Independence Day Address: A Call to Courage in the Face of Crisis

Article:

In his Independence Day address at Mount Rushmore, President Trump emphasized that the United States was born out of crisis and courage, rather than peace and reflection. He urged Americans to draw inspiration from the bravery and sacrifices of their ancestors, who fought to preserve the nation's culture and civilization.

The monument to the four American heroes - George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln, and Teddy Roosevelt - stands as a reminder of the challenges faced by previous generations to protect their country from foreign and domestic enemies. The president's speech was an exaltation to the American tradition of courage, encouraging Americans to honor the legacy of their heroes and not try to reason with those who seek to erase their history.

The article highlights the struggles and sacrifices made by millions of Americans who have fought to preserve and strengthen the nation's heritage, which is now being threatened by a radical fringe. The author, Mike Huckabee, emphasizes that the forces tearing the country apart will have to contend with a usually-silent majority that will gather to honor their heroes and the "Star-Spangled Banner."

The article concludes with a message of hope, urging Americans to take heart in the optimistic message of President Trump's speech and to stand up once again to defend American values.

Title: Obama Administration's Deportation Record: A Complex Issue with Multiple Perspectives

The Obama administration's record on deportations has been a topic of controversy, with some praising the efforts to remove illegal immigrants and others criticizing the practice as inhumane. In 2010, then-ICE Director John Morton boasted about the agency's record-breaking deportations, stating that the numbers were "straight, on the merits, no cooking of the books." The Washington Post reported on a memo suggesting that ICE had set a goal of 400,000 deportations, with a focus on criminal alien removals.

However, under pressure from activists and critics, the administration has since shifted its stance on deportations. President Obama has stated that it is not smart or effective to focus solely on deportation, and Vice President Joe Biden has echoed this sentiment. Some activists argue that deportation is an illegitimate policy tool and that it breaks up families and causes suffering.

On the other hand, some argue that deportation is a necessary tool to maintain border control and uphold the rule of law. According to the Pew Hispanic Center, in 2013, 59% of deportees were convicted of a crime, and a third were felons. Additionally, 98% of those deported last year were repeat immigration violators, illegal border crossings, or immigration fugitives.

The debate surrounding deportation is complex and multifaceted, with valid arguments on both sides. While some argue that deportation is a necessary tool to maintain border control and uphold the rule of law, others argue that it breaks up families and causes suffering. The Obama administration's record on deportations has been a topic of controversy, with some praising the efforts to remove illegal immigrants and others criticizing the practice as inhumane.

Title: Extinction Rebellion Protests Disrupt London, Commuters Push Back

The Extinction Rebellion (XR) group has been causing disruptions in European cities, including London, with their radical anti-climate-change protests. The group's actions have resulted in thousands of arrests and significant disruptions to daily life. In London, protesters have blocked roads, glued themselves to buildings, and even climbed onto commuter trains, causing delays and inconvenience to commuters.

The XR group's tactics have been met with growing public frustration, with a recent snap poll showing over 60% of Londoners are fed up with the protests. The group's leaders have defended their actions, citing the urgency of the climate crisis and the need for drastic measures to address it.

However, critics argue that the group's methods are extreme and ineffective, and that their actions are causing more harm than good. The group's reliance on donations and celebrity endorsements has also been questioned, with some pointing out the hypocrisy of wealthy individuals and celebrities supporting a movement that seeks to disrupt the economy and way of life.

The article highlights the challenges faced by authorities in dealing with the XR protests, with some officials expressing frustration and others calling for a more robust response. The article also notes that the protests have sparked a pushback from commuters, who are tired of the disruptions and are demanding a more effective response from authorities.

Overall, the article presents a nuanced view of the Extinction Rebellion protests, highlighting the complexity of the issue and the challenges faced by those involved.

Title: House Speaker Paul Ryan Expresses Caution on Supporting Donald Trump

Article: House Speaker Paul Ryan has expressed hesitation in supporting presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump, stating that he is not yet ready to endorse the candidate. This decision has put Ryan in line with other prominent Republicans who have been slow to back Trump. Despite Trump's unconventional campaign, Ryan's reluctance to endorse him has given fellow House Republicans permission to go their own way.

Historically, a party nominee has never failed to gain the support of a House speaker or majority leader from their party. However, Ryan's decision to withhold his endorsement is not unprecedented. In 1896, Speaker Thomas Brackett Reed ran against William McKinley and refused to serve as vice president, but eventually backed the nominee. Similarly, in 1964, Senator Barry Goldwater had to wait for the endorsement of Senator Everett Dirksen of Illinois before the "Stop-Goldwater" movement was halted.

Ryan's remarks caught Republicans off guard, but they also gave them a sense of freedom to make their own decisions about Trump's candidacy. If Ryan had issued a forceful endorsement, it would have put pressure on fellow House Republicans to follow his lead, something many have been unwilling to do. In his statement, Ryan emphasized the need for the party to unify and placed the burden of unification on Trump, stating, "I'm not there right now, and I hope to, though, and I want to. But I think what is required is that we unify the party, and I think the bulk of the burden on unifying the party will have to come from our presumptive nominee."

Title: Stock Market Sees Largest Single-Day Decline Since 1987, Dow Falls 9.99%

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) plummeted by 9.99% on Wednesday, marking the largest single-day percentage decline since the 1987 stock market crash. The Dow fell 2,352.60 points to close at 21,200.62, while the Nasdaq tumbled 9.43% to 7,201.80 and the S&P 500 dropped 9.5% to 2,480.64.

Investors reacted to the news of the Federal Reserve's emergency relief package, which included nearly $1.5 trillion in support, by selling heavily. The move came a day after President Donald Trump addressed the nation on the government's response to the novel coronavirus outbreak.

The decline marks the third consecutive day of massive losses, with Tuesday's gains now feeling like a distant memory. The market's sharp drop may be attributed to concerns that the Federal Reserve's efforts may not be enough to stabilize the economy in the long term.

"We continue to emphasize that this Fed will act aggressively and in particular that central banks are focused on safeguarding market functioning at this point, and will continue to provide liquidity in scale," said Ebrahim Rahbari, director of global economics at Citi Research. "However, despite the sharp initial risk rally, we think these measures will still not be sufficient to durably stabilize market sentiment yet in light of credit concerns and escalating health concerns."

The novel coronavirus has already disrupted various American institutions, with Broadway shut down, major sports events canceled, and entire seasons put on hold. The travel industry was particularly hard hit, with airlines such as United Airlines, Delta, and American Airlines experiencing significant declines. The ban on travel between the U.S. and Europe, announced by President Trump, has led to flight cancellations and disruptions.

Cryptocurrencies were not immune to the market's volatility, with Bitcoin and other major cryptocurrencies suffering their worst declines in years. SaaS shares were also down over 8%, and Slack's earnings failed to excite investors, leading to a sell-off.

The market's decline comes as the country prepares to ramp up its COVID-19 testing regime, leaving investors searching for a silver lining.

Title: Obama Returns to Washington Amid Looming Sequester Deadline

President Barack Obama returned to Washington on Monday, with time running out to find a solution to avoid the looming sequester, a $1 trillion package of across-the-board cuts that he himself proposed. The sequester is set to take effect on March 1, and Republicans, led by House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, are emphasizing that the blame lies with the president.

Ryan stated on ABC News' This Week that "don't forget it's the president that proposed the sequester and designed the sequester." He noted that House Republicans have twice passed legislation replacing the sequester with smarter cuts in other areas of government, but the Senate has yet to pass a spending bill to replace it.

In his State of the Union Address on February 12, Obama explained that the sequester was a result of Congress' inability to agree on spending cuts, and that it would jeopardize military readiness, devastate priorities like education and energy, and slow the recovery. However, Ryan argued that the cuts are looming because the president refused to cut spending in any area, leading to the sequester.

Other Republicans, including House Speaker John Boehner and Majority Leader Eric Cantor, also blame the White House for the sequester. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid claims that Democrats will issue their answer at some point, stating that they believe the right way to eliminate the deficit is to target waste and abuse with smart spending cuts and closing tax loopholes.

The threat of the sequester has been exacerbated by Congress' decision to take a 10-day President's Day break, leaving only four working days to find a solution. Obama spent his weekend playing golf in Florida, including a game with Tiger Woods.

Title: Trump Announces "Fake News Awards" Winners, Accusing CNN, NY Times, and Other Media Outlets of Dishonesty

Article:

In a recent tweet, US President Donald Trump announced the winners of his "most dishonest and corrupt media awards of the year," targeting news organizations including CNN and the New York Times. The list of alleged falsehoods and exaggerations includes claims made by various news outlets, with Trump accusing them of spreading misinformation and propaganda.

Some of the specific examples cited by Trump include:

* CNN reporting that Republicans won five special elections to the Democrats' nil, when in fact Republicans won four and Democrats won one.
* NBC News stating that the US has a $17 billion trade deficit with Canada, when the actual trade surplus is $8.1 billion.
* The New York Times reporting that Colbert's Late Show had its highest ratings when Trump appeared on it, when in fact the show had higher ratings when it debuted.
* CNN stating that the Senate had said there was no collusion between Russia and the Trump campaign, when no such statement was made.
* NBC News reporting that the Trump administration had signed more bills through the legislature than any president, ever, when in fact Presidents Clinton, Carter, Truman, and Roosevelt had passed more legislation at the same point in their presidencies.

Trump also accused various news outlets of spreading false information about his administration, including claims about his tax plans benefiting him personally and the US being the highest-taxed nation in the world.

It is worth noting that some of these claims have been disputed or debunked by fact-checking organizations and other reputable sources. The accuracy of the information presented by Trump has been questioned, and some have criticized his use of the term "fake news" to describe any reporting that he disagrees with.

The "Fake News Awards" have been met with criticism and skepticism from many in the media and the public, with some accusing Trump of using the term to discredit and silence legitimate reporting.

Title: House Democrats Reach Agreement with White House on USMCA Trade Deal

The House Speaker, Nancy Pelosi, announced on Tuesday that House Democrats have reached an agreement with the White House on the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) trade deal. The agreement is seen as a victory for American workers, with Pelosi stating that it is "infinitely better" than the initial proposal from the administration.

The deal overhauls the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and is designed to raise wages and improve working conditions for both Mexican and American auto workers by tightening regulations. The agreement was negotiated with the AFL-CIO, the largest federation of unions in the country, which confirmed it would back the trade agreement.

Ways and Means Committee Chairman Richard Neal described the final days of negotiations as "hot" but called the deal a "transformative agreement" and "an opportunity we couldn't let get away from us." AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka praised the deal, stating that it is a "vast improvement over both the original NAFTA and the flawed proposal brought forward in 2017."

The agreement comes after months of negotiations, with Democrats advocating for tighter labor enforcements in USMCA to avoid the criticisms of the former North American Free Trade Agreement. Pelosi remained optimistic about an eventual agreement, saying a deal was "imminent" last month.

Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador announced that an amended version of USMCA will be signed on Tuesday by officials from the U.S., Canada, and Mexico. Prior to Pelosi's announcement, President Trump tweeted in anticipation of the deal, stating that the USMCA Trade Bill is "looking good" and will be the "best and most important trade deal ever made by the USA."

Title: EPA Proposes National Rules to Reduce Sulfur in Gasoline, Aim to Improve Air Quality and Efficiency

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has proposed national rules to reduce the amount of sulfur in gasoline, which the agency believes will significantly reduce harmful pollution, prevent thousands of premature deaths and illnesses, and lead to efficiency improvements in cars and trucks. The proposed rule would require a reduction in the sulfur content of gasoline, which is already in use in California, Europe, and Japan.

According to the EPA, the lower-sulfur gasoline will help catalytic converters work better and reduce emissions that lead to smog. The agency estimates that by 2030, the rules will annually avoid up to 2,400 premature deaths, 23,000 cases of respiratory ailments in children, and other gains, totaling between $8 billion and $23 billion in yearly health-related benefits.

The oil industry opposes the rule, claiming it will add 6 to 9 cents to the cost of a gallon of gasoline. However, the EPA estimates that the rule will only increase gas prices by a penny a gallon. Some Republicans have also criticized the proposal, alleging that it will increase consumer costs.

Automakers, on the other hand, support the proposal, stating that the fuels are needed so newer catalytic converters can better scrub smog-causing particles out of vehicle emissions. The Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers' Gloria Bergquist said, "Our cleaner cars will need even cleaner fuels like those already sold across Europe and Asia, and we are pleased EPA is proposing cleaner fuels."

The proposed rule would take effect in 2017, and the EPA is seeking public comment on the proposal.

**Supreme Court's Handling of Obamacare and Same-Sex Marriage Sparks Mixed Opinions**

A recent CNN/ORC poll has revealed that Americans are divided on the Supreme Court's handling of landmark decisions on Obamacare and same-sex marriage. While 43% of respondents approve of the court's overall performance, 55% are opposed. The poll also found that 53% of Americans believe it's too soon to make a judgment on the court's handling of these issues.

The poll highlights the importance of the upcoming Supreme Court decision on the King v. Burwell case, which could determine the future of Obamacare. If the court rules in favor of the plaintiffs, 7.5 million people in states that rely on the federal exchange could lose their subsidies, making healthcare more unaffordable for them. The decision could also lead to insurance companies' calls for double-digit premium hikes in some states.

On the issue of same-sex marriage, the poll revealed that 63% of Americans believe it is a constitutional right, with 49% saying it was a constitutional right as recently as 2010. The poll also found that 64% of those who favor Obamacare trust the court to handle healthcare policy, compared to 39% who are opposed.

The poll results showed that support for same-sex marriage reaches across most age demographics, with 73% of those under 50 and 52% of those over 50 agreeing that it is a constitutional right. Democrats and independents are more likely to agree that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry, with 74% and 69% respectively agreeing.

The poll also found that voters across party lines agree that everyone should be eligible for the same subsidies, with 74% of Democrats, 56% of independents, and 49% of Republicans agreeing. Additionally, 62% of voters said they would be more likely to vote for someone who works to ensure a universal subsidy level, compared to 28% who said they would not.

The poll results also highlighted the potential political implications of the Supreme Court's decisions. Republicans could face the biggest political price, with 41% of voters saying they would be less likely to vote for a Republican who didn't vote to fix Obamacare, compared to 31% who said they would be more likely.

The poll surveyed 1,025 adults at the end of May and had a margin of error of +/- 3.5 percentage points.

Title: Diplomatic Efforts Intensify to End Fighting in Eastern Ukraine

Diplomatic efforts are underway to bring an end to the renewed fighting in eastern Ukraine, as French President Francois Hollande and German Chancellor Angela Merkel held urgent talks in Kiev, presenting a new peace initiative. The meeting aimed to find a solution to the conflict, which has killed nearly 5,400 people since April, according to the UN.

The US Secretary of State, John Kerry, who was also in Kiev, emphasized the need for a diplomatic solution, but warned that the US would not ignore Russian aggression. Ukraine and the West have accused Russia of arming rebels in eastern Ukraine and sending regular troops across the border, while Russia denies direct involvement but acknowledges that some Russian volunteers are fighting alongside the rebels.

Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko expressed hope that the talks with Merkel and Hollande would lead to a ceasefire, while Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk reiterated that Ukraine would not consider any proposal that undermines its territorial integrity.

The US is currently providing non-lethal assistance to Ukraine, but Kerry hinted that the possibility of providing defensive weapons is being reviewed. However, Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman Alexander Lukashevich warned that any decision to supply weapons to Ukraine would "inflict colossal damage" on Russian-American relations.

The debate within NATO and the West is shifting, with some officials expressing concern that arming Ukraine could escalate the conflict. However, others argue that providing Ukraine with effective defenses could reduce the risk of a major escalation.

Meanwhile, NATO is unveiling a plan to bolster its military presence in Eastern Europe in response to the Ukraine crisis, including a rapid reaction force of up to 5,000 troops and a network of small command centers in several countries. The European Union has also added 19 individuals, including five Russians, to its sanctions list over the Ukraine crisis.

The fighting in eastern Ukraine has intensified in recent weeks, with the fiercest battles near the town of Debaltseve, a crucial rail hub linking the rebel-held cities of Donetsk and Luhansk. Over 1.2 million Ukrainians have fled their homes since last April, when the rebels seized a significant portion of the Luhansk and Donetsk regions following Russia's annexation of Crimea.

Title: Trump Meets with Speaker Ryan Amid Party Unity Concerns and Tax Return Controversy

Article:

A meeting between Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, and Speaker of the House Paul Ryan is set to take place on Thursday, as Trump seeks to unify the party after a contentious primary election. However, Ryan has expressed concerns about the party's unity, stating that it is crucial to ensure that the party is truly unified before moving forward.

The meeting comes amidst ongoing questions surrounding Trump's refusal to release his tax returns. Trump has stated that he will not release his returns until an IRS audit is complete, which may not occur until after the election. This decision has been criticized by his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton, who has released 33 years of her tax returns. Clinton has questioned why Trump is hesitant to do the same.

In an effort to address concerns about his tax plan, Trump has brought in conservative economists Larry Kudlow and Stephen Moore to help rewrite his initial plan. The plan, which is expected to add $10-12 trillion to the national debt, aims to provide tax breaks for the middle class and support businesses.

Trump has also announced plans to establish a commission on radical Islam, which would study his immigration policies, including his proposal for a temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States. This move has sparked controversy among some Republicans, who are questioning Trump's conservative credentials.

Despite the ongoing concerns, a recent Reuters poll suggests that Trump is in a dead heat with Clinton, with both candidates receiving 40% of the vote and 19% of voters undecided.

Title: Vice President Pence Addresses CPAC, Emphasizes Trump Administration's Commitment to Promises

Vice President Mike Pence addressed the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) on Thursday night, rallying conservatives around President Donald Trump's agenda. Pence emphasized the administration's commitment to keeping promises made to the American people, stating, "President Trump is a man of his word, and we're keeping the promises he made to the American people. Over at the White House, I like to say we're in the promise-keepin' business these days."

Pence criticized the Democratic Party for making promises it could not keep, saying it's time to prove again that "our answers are the right answers." He outlined the Trump administration's priorities, including a strong military, more jobs, less taxes, respect for the Constitution, and a deep and abiding faith in the goodness of the American people.

On healthcare, Pence reiterated the administration's goal to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. "President Donald Trump is leading the fight to repeal and replace Obamacare. And let me assure you, America's Obamacare nightmare is about to end," Pence said. He emphasized that the American people know better and that Obamacare has failed.

Other key members of the Trump White House also spoke at CPAC, including top advisers Steve Bannon and Reince Priebus. Bannon warned that the battles between the media and the administration are far from over, stating, "It's not only not going to get better, it's going to get worse every day with the media." He stressed that the Trump administration will continue to fight and encouraged the audience to hold the president's team accountable for delivering on promises made.

Title: Obama's State of the Union Address Focuses on Economic Growth and Bipartisanship

The 2013 State of the Union address delivered by President Barack Obama emphasized the need for economic growth, job creation, and bipartisanship. The president's speech highlighted several proposals aimed at stimulating the economy, including increasing the minimum wage, guaranteeing preschool, and promoting high-tech job growth. However, some of these ideas have been previously proposed and failed to gain traction in a divided Washington.

Obama also emphasized the importance of addressing climate change, announcing executive actions to reduce pollution and promote sustainable energy sources. He also touched on issues such as cybersecurity, voting reform, and equal treatment for gay Americans. The president's speech was met with mixed reactions, with 53% of those surveyed in a CNN/ORC instant poll saying it would not lead to bipartisan cooperation.

The president's proposals did not include a clear plan for how they would be paid for, with White House officials promising more details when the budget proposal is released in a few weeks. Obama's speech was also notable for its tone, with the president taking a more conciliatory approach than in his inaugural address. He praised some Republicans, including Senator John McCain, and acknowledged the need for compromise.

The speech was delivered against the backdrop of a struggling economy, with unemployment at 7.9% and the nation's growth rate shrinking in the last three months of 2012. The president's proposals aim to reignite the economy and create jobs, with a focus on high-tech industries and manufacturing hubs. However, the Republican Party is likely to resist some of these proposals, which they see as increasing government spending and debt.

Overall, Obama's State of the Union address was a call to action, urging Congress to work together to address the nation's economic and environmental challenges. While some of his proposals may face resistance, the president's speech highlighted his commitment to finding solutions and promoting bipartisanship.

Title: Global Initiative to Accelerate COVID-19 Research and Development Launched, US Will Not Participate

The World Health Organization (WHO) announced a global initiative on Friday to accelerate the development of safe and effective drugs, tests, and vaccines to combat COVID-19. The initiative, led by WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, will bring together international partners to ensure equitable access to new tools for COVID-19 prevention, diagnosis, and treatment.

French President Emmanuel Macron and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen will participate in the initiative, along with British Foreign Minister Dominic Raab and UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres. The goal is to ensure that when new tools become available, no one is left behind and those who can afford them can access them.

The United States will not participate in the initiative, according to a spokesperson for the US mission in Geneva. The US had previously suspended funding to the WHO, citing concerns over the organization's response to the outbreak.

More than 2.7 million people have been infected with COVID-19, which has claimed nearly 190,000 lives since emerging in Wuhan, China. Over 100 potential vaccines are being developed, including six already in clinical trials. Dr. Seth Berkley, CEO of the GAVI vaccine alliance, emphasized the need for global leadership to identify and prioritize vaccine candidates and ramp up manufacturing capacity.

The initiative aims to address concerns about vaccine availability and effectiveness, particularly in vulnerable populations such as the elderly, who have weaker immune systems. The GAVI vaccine alliance and the World Bank are working to address these issues and ensure that a vaccine is available to all who need it.

Title: Obama's North Carolina Stopovers: A Potential Public Relations Nightmare

The Democratic National Convention, scheduled to take place in Charlotte, North Carolina, in September, is shaping up to be a challenging event for President Barack Obama's re-election campaign. The state's Democratic Party is embroiled in a sex scandal involving former executive director Jay Parmley and communications staffer Adriadn Ortega, which has led to Ortega filing a defamation suit against the party. The White House has remained silent on the matter.

Several Democratic officials have announced they will boycott the convention, citing concerns over Obama's policies, including his stance on illegal immigration, jobs, and coal mining. Moderate Democrats are not the only ones skipping the event; some progressive groups are also protesting Obama's decision to deliver his acceptance speech at Bank of America Stadium, which received a $45 billion bailout in 2008 and has been linked to several controversies.

The Charlotte News and Observer noted the absence of high-level Obama surrogates at the North Carolina Democratic Party convention, which some found "odd." The party's credibility is already under scrutiny due to the ongoing scandal. The White House has not commented on the matter.

The Democratic Party's financial struggles are also a concern, with fundraising efforts slow and labor unions expressing anger over the convention being held in a city with no unionized hotels and a state where compulsory union membership or payment of dues is prohibited. The state's voters recently approved a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage, which conflicts with Obama's stance on the issue.

The event is expected to be a public relations nightmare for Obama's campaign, with disgruntled leftists, centrists, and corporate donors all expressing discontent. The controversy surrounding the party's leadership and the choice of venue may overshadow the convention's intended message of unity and hope.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Obamacare Subsidies, President Obama Visits Tennessee Amid Controversy

The Supreme Court's recent decision to uphold Obamacare subsidies for individuals living in states without state-based exchanges has given President Obama a reason to celebrate. The President promptly held a press conference at the White House, stating that the Affordable Care Act is "here to stay." However, his victory tour has been met with criticism, particularly in Tennessee, where the effects of the ACA have been felt deeply.

Representative Diane Black (R-TN), a former nurse, has questioned the President's decision to visit Tennessee, citing the state's struggles with the ACA. She pointed out that Obamacare customers in Tennessee can expect a 36% premium increase next year, despite the President's promise that the law would save families an average of $2,500 per year. Additionally, she noted that 28,000 Tennesseans lost their insurance coverage in a single day, despite the President's pledge that "if you like your health care plan, you can keep it."

The ACA's impact has been particularly devastating in Tennessee, where state-sponsored insurance programs, such as AccessTN and CoverRX, were effectively shut down due to the ACA. Letters are being sent to explain the changes to people covered by these programs, and 16,000 people enrolled in CoverTN, a limited benefits plan, have already been notified that it will end on December 31. Many families have also received notice that they will no longer be able to buy into CoverKids.

The controversy surrounding the ACA has been further highlighted by a nationwide CNN poll, which revealed that twice as many Americans were hurt by Obamacare than benefited from it. Representative Black has sent a message to President Obama that no speech can put a Band-Aid on what these families endured.

Title: Bipartisan Budget Deal Reached, But Both Sides Express Disappointment

The bipartisan budget deal crafted by Republican Rep. Paul Ryan and Democratic Sen. Patty Murray has been met with a mix of reactions from both sides of the aisle. The agreement, which sets the federal budget at around $1 trillion for the next two years, replaces a significant portion of the sequester cuts with other trims and increased fees. However, neither side seems entirely satisfied with the outcome.

Conservative Republicans are unhappy that the deal does not cut federal spending or reduce the national debt, while Democrats are disappointed that it does not restore funding for domestic programs or extend unemployment insurance. The Washington Post notes that the deal "denies both Republicans and Democrats what they want most," with Republicans not getting changes to Medicare and Social Security and Democrats not getting new taxes.

Sen. Patty Murray and Rep. Paul Ryan have framed the agreement as a compromise, with Murray stating that "neither one of us got everything we wanted and we were able to keep the other person from getting some of the big things they wanted." Ryan emphasized the deal's conservative credentials, highlighting that it reduces the deficit without raising taxes.

The deal's passage is not without its challenges, with Ryan facing skepticism from House conservatives. However, Ryan's reputation as a fiscal conservative may help him sell the deal to his colleagues. The National Journal notes that Ryan may face a tough sell, but his ability to frame the agreement as "conservative" could help sway some votes.

The deal has received mixed reviews from news outlets, with some calling it a "least bad" option and others sounding alarm bells over its lack of significant reforms. The House is expected to vote on the deal on Thursday.

Title: Former House Majority Leader Dick Armey Leaves FreedomWorks Over Internal Differences

Article:

Dick Armey, the former House Majority Leader, has resigned from his position as chairman of the conservative Tea Party group FreedomWorks, citing internal differences over the organization's future direction. According to a confidential contract obtained by The Associated Press, Armey agreed to resign in exchange for $8 million in consulting fees paid in annual $400,000 installments. The contract specifies that Armey would resign from his position at FreedomWorks and its sister organization, the FreedomWorks Foundation, by the end of November.

Armey's departure comes as a sign of acrimony within conservative and Republican ranks, as the party struggles to recover from its November electoral losses and figure out how to adapt its principles and issues to compete with the Democratic Party. Armey confirmed his departure, stating that his differences with FreedomWorks are a matter of principle, but declined to specify his concerns.

Armey had been with FreedomWorks since its founding in 2004 and was a key figure in the Tea Party movement. However, he has expressed dissatisfaction with the group's direction and the November election results, in which several GOP candidates supported by FreedomWorks Super PAC donations were defeated by Democratic rivals.

The internal resignation memo published by Mother Jones shows that Armey asked FreedomWorks CEO Matt Kibbe to remove his name, image, and signature from all group materials and web operations. Kibbe and other FreedomWorks officials were unavailable for comment.

FreedomWorks has faced criticism for its internal secrecy and its role as a high-financed super political action committee. The group received a large donation from a shadowy Tennessee-based corporation, Specialty Group Inc., which funneled $5.28 million to the Tea Party group. The identity of the corporation's donor remains unknown.

Armey's departure marks a significant blow to FreedomWorks, which has seen its influence wane in recent years. The group's internal divisions and financial issues have raised questions about its ability to continue as a major player in the political landscape.

Title: Clinton Ally's Political Organization Donates to FBI Official's Wife's Campaign

The Wall Street Journal has reported that a top Clinton ally's political organization, Common Good VA, donated nearly $500,000 to the 2015 state Senate campaign of Dr. Jill McCabe, the wife of FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe. The donation, along with an additional $207,788 from the Virginia Democratic Party, accounted for more than a third of Dr. McCabe's campaign funds.

At the time of the campaign, Andrew McCabe was the Associate Deputy Director of the FBI, and he was later promoted to Deputy Director, assuming an oversight role in the investigation into Hillary Clinton's email practices. The FBI has confirmed that McCabe sought internal guidance to prevent any potential conflict of interest and implemented a system of recusal from all FBI investigative matters involving Virginia politics during his wife's campaign.

A law enforcement official acknowledged that while McCabe was barred from investigations into Virginia politics, the donation from the Virginia governor's PAC could raise optics issues. However, a spokesman for Virginia Governor Terry McAuliffe, who supported Dr. McCabe's campaign, denied any suggestion of impropriety, stating that the governor's support was based solely on his desire to elect candidates who would help pass his agenda.

The revelation has sparked fresh Republican complaints about the investigation into Hillary Clinton's email practices, with Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus calling the donation a "down payment" to influence the FBI's criminal investigation into Clinton's private email server. The FBI's Ethics and Integrity Program manual does not require employees to flag connections to senior management, but it does require employees to seek guidance and follow a process to prevent any appearance of a conflict of interest.

The investigation into Hillary Clinton's email practices is ongoing, with McCabe continuing to be involved in the aftermath. The latest revelations have sparked renewed scrutiny and debate about the investigation's integrity and potential conflicts of interest.

Title: Congress Returns from Break, Fails to Address Sequestration Cuts

Congress returned from its weeklong break on Monday, but failed to make any progress on addressing the looming $85 billion in forced spending cuts, known as sequestration. The cuts are set to take effect in just four days, and lawmakers are still at odds over how to avoid or mitigate their impact.

Despite the lack of progress, lawmakers continued to blame each other for the impending cuts. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham said that sequestration is "inevitable" and that the pressure from the cuts may "wake us up" to the need for new taxes to address the country's debt.

House Speaker John Boehner and other Republican leaders blamed President Barack Obama for the cuts, saying that he proposed them and is not doing enough to stop them. They also dismissed Democratic calls for new taxes on the rich as part of a more "balanced" plan.

Meanwhile, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid warned that the cuts would have devastating effects, including kicking 70,000 kids out of the Head Start program, placing air traffic controllers and FBI and border patrol agents on furlough, and cutting Medicare, education, and medical research.

House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer urged Republicans to work with Democrats to find an alternative to the sequester, but so far, no progress has been made. Senate leaders Reid and Mitch McConnell are expected to introduce their own bills to replace the cuts early this week, but it remains to be seen whether this will be a genuine effort to address the issue or just more political posturing.

Title: Moscow Police Arrest Over 750 People During Protest Demanding Fair Elections

Moscow police arrested more than 750 people during a demonstration outside city hall on Saturday, where protesters called for fair elections after the upcoming city council elections on September 8 excluded opposition candidates from being on the ballot.
