According to OVD-Info, a Russian organization that monitors political arrests, 779 people were detained. Moscow police earlier reported 295 people had been taken in, but did not provide a final figure.

The protest was organized by opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, who was arrested on Wednesday and sentenced to 30 days in jail. Other opposition politicians, including Ilya Yashin, Dmitry Gudkov, and Ivan Zhdanov, were also detained on Saturday.

The protest, which was reportedly unauthorized by the government, saw clashes between police and protesters, with people shouting "Russia will be free!" and "Who are you beating?" Moscow police estimated the number of protesters at 3,500.

The opposition politicians were excluded from the ballot because they did not receive enough signatures to qualify, according to election officials. Supporters of the opposition party claim the government is forcing them out, preventing them from participating in the elections.

During the protest, helmeted police barged into Navalny's video studio as it was conducting a YouTube broadcast, arresting program leader Vladimir Milonov. Police also searched Dozhd, an internet TV station covering the protest, and ordered its editor-in-chief, Alexandra Perepelova, to undergo questioning at the Investigative Committee. The charges faced by the detainees are currently unknown.

The September vote for Moscow's city council has become a significant issue in Russia, with the Kremlin struggling to deal with opposing views in its capital of 12.6 million. The city council, which has 45 seats, is responsible for a large municipal budget and is currently controlled by the pro-Kremlin United Russia party. All seats are up for grabs in the September 8 vote.

Title: Senate Panel Endorses Chuck Hagel for Pentagon Chief, Despite Intense Republican Opposition

Article:

The Senate Armed Services Committee has voted 14-11 to advance Chuck Hagel's nomination to lead the Pentagon, despite intense Republican opposition. The vote underscores the deep divisions within the committee, with all Republicans present voting against Hagel. Hagel, a former Republican senator and Vietnam War veteran, has faced criticism for his past votes and statements on issues such as Iran, Israel, and the Iraq war.

During his confirmation hearing, Hagel faced tough questioning from committee Republicans, who accused him of being "wrong on so many things" and having a "rocky" performance. Senator John McCain, a Republican, described Hagel's performance as the "worst" he had seen for any nominee. Senator Lindsey Graham, also a Republican, expressed concerns about Hagel's testimony, saying it was "not reassuring" and that the next secretary of Defense will face a "world on fire."

Despite the opposition, Democratic Chairman Carl Levin pushed forward with the vote, saying "the time has come for the committee to act on this nomination." The vote now moves to the full Senate, where Majority Leader Harry Reid is pushing for a vote later this week.

Hagel's nomination has been met with criticism from some Republicans, who have raised concerns about his past votes and statements. Senator Ted Cruz, a Republican, questioned Hagel's personal finances, leading to a dispute with Senator Bill Nelson, a Democrat. Committee Republicans had previously delayed the vote, citing concerns about Hagel's personal finances, but Levin argued that the demands were beyond the scope of those traditionally asked of previous nominees.

The outcome of the vote is uncertain, with at least five Republicans opposed to Hagel and several others indicating they will vote against him. However, two Republicans, Senators Thad Cochran and Mike Johanns, have announced their support for the nominee. The vote is expected to be a test of the Republican Party's willingness to support a nominee who has been criticized by some of their colleagues.

**GOP Elders Express Concerns Over Shutdown Efforts**

A growing rift within the Republican Party is emerging over the idea of shutting down the federal government to protest the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. The plan, supported by a group of conservative lawmakers, has sparked concerns among party elders, who warn that such a move could have negative consequences for the party and the country.

The plan, which gained momentum after the 2010 elections, has been met with opposition from many Republican leaders, including Senator John McCain, who called the idea "nuts" and Senator Tom Coburn, who warned that it could cost the party control of the House. Even Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, expressed concerns about the potential consequences of a government shutdown.

While some conservative lawmakers, such as Senator Ted Cruz and Senator Marco Rubio, have expressed support for the plan, others, like Senator Mike Lee, have faced criticism from their colleagues. The plan requires almost every Republican in the Senate to join the effort, which is unlikely to happen.

The debate highlights the ongoing divisions within the Republican Party over how to address the Affordable Care Act. While some lawmakers believe shutting down the government is a necessary step to repeal the law, others argue that it would be a mistake and could have negative consequences for the country.

The debate is also fueled by the fact that the Affordable Care Act has been a major issue in recent years, with many Republicans seeking to repeal it. However, despite numerous attempts, the law has remained in place, and some lawmakers are now looking for alternative strategies to address their concerns.

The debate is expected to continue as lawmakers prepare for the 2014 elections and the ongoing debate over the Affordable Care Act.

Title: Supreme Court Nominee Judge Kavanaugh Discusses His Approach to the Law and His Personal Life

Article:

Judge Brett Kavanaugh, nominated as an associate justice of the U.S. Supreme Court, recently spoke about his approach to the law and his personal life. In a speech at the White House, he discussed his 28-year career as a lawyer, including his 12 years as a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit and his five years of service in the White House for President George W. Bush. He emphasized his commitment to being a neutral and impartial arbiter, stating that a good judge must be an umpire who favors no political party, litigant, or policy.

Kavanaugh also highlighted his record of advancing and promoting women, noting that a majority of his 48 law clerks have been women. He also mentioned his experience as a coach of girls' basketball teams. He emphasized that he has always followed the law and has not made decisions based on personal or policy preferences.

In his speech, Kavanaugh also addressed the recent allegations against him, stating that he has been subjected to wrongful and sometimes vicious allegations. He testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee to defend his family, his good name, and his lifetime of public service. He denied the allegations, which he described as "ridiculously distorted" and "completely contrary to my record and character."

Kavanaugh also expressed his frustration and distress at the way the allegations have been handled, stating that he was "very emotional" during his testimony and that his tone was "sharp" at times. He acknowledged that he said a few things he should not have said and apologized for his emotional outburst.

In conclusion, Judge Kavanaugh emphasized his commitment to being a fair and impartial judge, stating that he will continue to be the same kind of judge he has been for his entire 28-year legal career: hardworking, even-keeled, open-minded, independent, and dedicated to the Constitution and the public good.

Title: US Military Reports Unsuccessful Attempt to Kill Iranian Commander in Yemen

The US military has reportedly attempted to target Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) commander Abdul Reza Shahlai in Yemen, just days after the successful airstrike that killed Iranian Quds Force commander Qassem Soleimani in Iraq. According to US military officials, the operation was unsuccessful.

Shahlai, a key figure in financing the activities of the Iranian military force, has a history of targeting Americans and US allies globally, according to the State Department. He was allegedly involved in planning multiple assassinations of coalition forces in Iraq and provided weapons and explosives to Shia militia groups. Additionally, he was linked to a plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador in Washington eight years ago.

The announcement comes as the Trump administration defends the military necessity of the strike against Soleimani, which has faced skepticism from Democrats and some Republicans on Capitol Hill. The Pentagon has not confirmed the failed strike, but a spokesperson, Navy Cmdr. Rebecca Rebarich, stated that the US has seen reports of a January 2 airstrike in Yemen, which is considered a safe space for terrorists and adversaries to the US.

Defense Secretary Mark Esper did not explicitly address the reports of the failed strike in a tweet, but emphasized that the US will continue to defend its people and interests in the Middle East and call on Iran to de-escalate the situation and cease its malign activities in the region.

Title: Trump to Chair First Security Council Session Amid Differences Over Iran Policy

Article:

US President Donald Trump will preside over his first Security Council session, where he is expected to face opposition from fellow leaders over his efforts to isolate Iran and reject globalism. The session is likely to be "the most watched Security Council meeting ever," according to US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley. However, it may also deepen perceptions of Trump's increasing isolation on the world stage, following the UN General Assembly's laughter at his boasts about his achievements.

US allies, represented by UK Prime Minister Theresa May and French President Emmanuel Macron, side with Russia and China in their opposition to Trump's withdrawal from the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran and are uneasy about US sabre-rattling towards Tehran. Macron used his address to the UN General Assembly to present himself as the antithesis to Trump, rejecting Trump's appeal for national "patriotism" to take precedence over multilateral action.

The original plan was to devote the session to Iran, allowing Trump to highlight Iran's role in the Syrian and Yemeni conflict, its missile developments, and the full range of what Washington calls Tehran's "malign activities." However, the administration feared that would also highlight transatlantic rifts over the Iran nuclear deal, from which Trump withdrew in May. The Iranian president, Hassan Rouhani, would also have had a right to attend and speak in a session exclusively about his country.

The subject of the session has been widened to counter-proliferation, including North Korea, but Iran is still likely to be a central point of contention. The Trump administration has set out its campaign against Iran at the UN General Assembly, producing a special booklet, "Outlaw Regime," chronicling Iran's "destructive activities." The administration sent several senior officials to a conference organized by anti-Tehran activists, United Against a Nuclear Iran (UANI), to denounce the Iranian government.

National Security Adviser John Bolton issued a series of threats, saying that Iran would have "hell to pay" if it did not change its behavior. He singled out the commander of the external arm of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, Qassem Soleimani, who has led the Iranian military campaign in Syria in support of the Assad regime and IRGC operations in Iraq. Bolton stressed that the campaign against Soleimani would focus on funding and arms supplies, but asked for clarification later, the US envoy on Iran and the head of the State Department Iran Action Group, Brian Hook, did not rule out military action.

In his own remarks to the UANI conference, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said that an Iranian-backed militia was responsible for rocket attacks against the US embassy compound in Baghdad and the US consulate in Basra, in southern Iraq. He warned that the US would respond directly against Iran in the event of another such attack from Iran or a militia deemed to be an Iranian proxy.

The National Iranian American Council condemned the administration's rhetoric, noting Bolton's role in the buildup to the ill-fated Iraq invasion in 2003. "No serious person believes that Bolton and this administration is working towards a diplomatic end with Iran," the NIAC statement said. "He earned his credentials in the Bush White House as an Iraq war architect, he made his intentions for war with Iran well-known as a private citizen, and he is now putting that plan into action."

Title: FBI Team Headed to Lebanon to Assist in Investigation of Brig. Gen. Wissam al-Hassan's Assassination

A car bombing in Lebanon killed Brig. Gen. Wissam al-Hassan and two others last week, triggering sporadic clashes across the country. The assassination occurred just 30 minutes before al-Hassan was set to meet with Lebanese lawmaker Amar Houri to discuss a threatening text message sent from a Syrian phone number. Similar threats had been sent to three other lawmakers, including Fatfat, although they did not realize it until after al-Hassan's assassination.

The FBI has announced that a team is en route to Lebanon to assist in the investigation into al-Hassan's death. The U.S. State Department has condemned the attack and vowed to assist in the investigation.

Since the assassination, sporadic fighting has erupted across Lebanon, threatening to plunge the country into chaos and raise fears that it could be drawn into the 19-month-old civil war in neighboring Syria. The unrest has resulted in at least three deaths and over two dozen injuries nationwide.

The youth wing of the March 14 coalition has called for a peaceful rally in Beirut's Martyrs' Square, while the March 14 movement, an anti-Syrian coalition, has emerged in response to the 2005 assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. His son, Saad, leads the coalition.

Syria has condemned the attack, but this has not stopped accusations that it is behind the killing, which marks the country's highest-profile assassination in more than seven years. The United States has also condemned the attack and vowed to assist in investigating the bombing.

Title: Delta Airline Catering Workers Protest "Poverty Wages and Unaffordable Healthcare"

A group of airline catering workers, represented by Unite Here, held a protest at Detroit Metropolitan Airport on Friday, demanding better wages and healthcare. U.S. Representative Rashida Tlaib joined the protest, which included eight workers blocking traffic at the airport and nearly 100 union members rallying outside Delta's McNamara Terminal departures.

The protesters held signs reading "Delta: one job should be enough," highlighting their demand for a living wage and affordable healthcare. Eight workers were arrested by airport officers, but Tlaib rode with the workers in the van as they were transported for processing.

Tlaib praised the workers for their determination, stating, "The airline catering workers are desperate for a better quality of life and put their bodies on the line in their fight against the exorbitant corporate greed by the airlines denying them of their right to a living wage and good healthcare."

The protest coincided with Delta Air Lines distributing $1.6 billion in profit-sharing to its employees. Unite Here Local 24 President Nia Winston, who was among those arrested, emphasized that airline catering industry workers contribute to the airport's success but cannot afford basic necessities like healthcare. Winston vowed that the protests will continue until airline catering workers receive a fair contract and recognition for their labor.

Protests were also held at other key Delta hubs, including Minneapolis, Seattle, and major airports for United and American Airlines.

Title: U.S. Congress Reaches Agreement on Sanctions Against Russia, Iran, and North Korea

The United States Congress has reached an agreement on legislation that imposes new sanctions on Russia, Iran, and North Korea. The bill, which is set to be voted on in the House of Representatives on Tuesday, aims to hold the three countries accountable for their "dangerous actions" and limit any potential efforts by President Donald Trump to lift sanctions against Moscow.

The Countering Iran's Destabilizing Activities Act, which was passed by the Senate a month ago, was held up in the House after Republicans proposed including sanctions on North Korea. The revised bill would require Trump to submit a report to Congress on any proposed actions that would "significantly alter" U.S. foreign policy in connection with Russia, including easing sanctions or returning diplomatic properties in Maryland and New York.

Under the proposed bill, Congress would have at least 30 days to hold hearings and then vote to uphold or reject Trump's proposed changes. Many lawmakers hope the bill will send a message to Trump to maintain a strong line against Russia, which has been criticized for its annexation of Crimea and meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.

The bill is seen as a way to punish Russia for its actions, including its annexation of Crimea and interference in the 2016 election. Russia has denied any meddling in the U.S. democratic process, while Trump has said that his campaign did not collude with Russia.

House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi said Russia's "outrageous and unacceptable" behavior in the 2016 election and in Europe "demand that we have strong statutory sanctions enacted as soon as possible." However, she expressed concerns that including North Korea in the legislation could face procedural delays in the Senate.

Senior Republican lawmakers did not immediately comment on the latest bill. The European Union has also expressed concerns about the U.S. moves to step up sanctions on Russia, warning of possibly "wide and indiscriminate" "unintended consequences," particularly on the EU's efforts to diversify energy sources away from Russia.

The revised bill aims to bolster the energy security of European allies by maintaining their access to key energy resources outside of Russia, according to House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy and Ed Royce, chair of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer said a strong sanctions bill is essential and expects the House and Senate to act on the legislation promptly on a broad bipartisan basis. Senator Ben Cardin, the top Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said the agreement was reached after "intense negotiations."

Title: Hong Kong Protests Continue for 24th Weekend, Police Fire Tear Gas and Water Cannon

Hong Kong's New Territories and Kowloon peninsula saw widespread protests on Sunday, with activists blocking roads and vandalizing shopping malls across the region. The 24th consecutive weekend of anti-government demonstrations showed no signs of abating, with protesters demanding greater autonomy and an independent inquiry into police tactics.

Protesters, many of whom wore masks and goggles, clashed with police in several areas, including Tuen Mun, where running battles broke out between riot police and protesters. The violence spilled onto the streets, with police firing tear gas and water cannon to disperse the crowds.

In Sha Tin, protesters vandalized a train station and a restaurant seen as pro-Beijing, overturning tables and smashing glass panels. The rail station was closed, and scuffles broke out between police and protesters of all ages.

The protests also spread to the Kowloon district of Mong Kok, one of the world's most densely populated areas, where police used water cannon and tear gas to try to clear the main artery of Nathan Road. The area was littered with loose bricks under the bright, neon lights.

Protesters are angry about what they see as police brutality and meddling by Beijing in the former British colony's freedoms, guaranteed by the "one country, two systems" formula in place since the territory returned to Chinese rule in 1997. China denies interfering and has blamed Western countries for stirring up trouble.

The protests come as thousands of people gathered at a Saturday night vigil for "martyrs," following the death of a student in hospital this week after falling from a car park during a protest. Many called for revenge.

Seven pro-democracy city lawmakers have been detained or face arrest and are due to appear in court on Monday on charges of obstructing a May meeting of the local assembly. The lawmakers believe the government, along with the police and the pro-establishment camp, are trying to escalate the anger of Hong Kong people to cancel or postpone the upcoming district council election.

The colony of Hong Kong island and the Kowloon peninsula was acquired after two "opium wars" with China and was expanded to include the much larger, rural New Territories on a 99-year lease in 1898. Britain returned all the land to China when that lease expired in 1997.

Protesters have called for a general strike on Monday and urged people to block public transport, although such calls in the past have often come to nothing. They have also demanded an independent inquiry into police tactics, something the government has refused.

Title: Trump's Choice for Secretary of State: A Divisive Pick with Complex Implications

The nomination of Rex Tillerson, CEO of ExxonMobil, as Donald Trump's Secretary of State has sparked controversy and raised questions about the new administration's stance on Russia and the environment. Tillerson's reputation as a "Friend of Vladimir" due to his close ties with Russian President Putin has drawn criticism from some Republican senators, who have expressed concerns about his potential conflicts of interest and loyalty to the United States.

Tillerson's background as a corporate executive and his lack of government experience have also raised eyebrows. However, Trump sees his pick as a testament to his ability to think outside the box and bring a business-friendly approach to diplomacy. Tillerson's experience leading ExxonMobil, a company with global interests, has given him a unique perspective on international relations and the challenges of navigating complex global issues.

The nomination has also sparked debate about the Trump administration's stance on climate change and the environment. Tillerson has been a vocal supporter of the fossil fuel industry and has opposed U.S.-NATO sanctions on Russia, which has raised concerns about his commitment to addressing climate change and protecting the environment.

While some see Tillerson as a "friend of Putin" and a potential threat to U.S. interests, others view him as a pragmatic choice who can bring a business-friendly approach to diplomacy. The nomination has also sparked questions about the Trump administration's priorities and its willingness to challenge the status quo.

Ultimately, the confirmation process will determine whether Tillerson is confirmed as Secretary of State and what implications his nomination will have for the Trump administration's foreign policy and environmental agenda.

Title: Christian Students Ask Supreme Court to Review Case Over Free Speech Rights on Campus

A pair of Christian students have petitioned the U.S. Supreme Court to review a lawsuit against Georgia Gwinnett College (GGC), claiming that the institution's speech zone and speech code policies violate their First Amendment rights. Chike Uzuegbunam and Joseph Bradford, who were students at GGC at the time the lawsuit was filed, sued multiple GGC officials, challenging two policies in the college's Student Handbook: the "Freedom of Expression Policy" and the "Student Code of Conduct." According to Alliance Defending Freedom (ADF), the religious rights law firm representing the students, these policies prevented them from exercising their freedom of speech and freedom to exercise their rights.

In 2016, Uzuegbunam attempted to distribute religious literature in a plaza on campus, but was told to stop by a campus security officer, citing campus speech zone policy. The policy required students to reserve one of the two zones available on campus to exercise their free speech. The two zones made up only 0.0015 percent of the campus. Uzuegbunam reserved and was granted one of the speech zones, but was later ordered to stop distributing religious literature after receiving complaints. A lieutenant for campus police told Uzuegbunam that his faith-sharing efforts amounted to "disorderly conduct" under a GGC policy.

The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia dismissed the case, which was affirmed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. During the time the case was in the district court, GGC amended its speech zone policy and eliminated its speech code, but did not provide relief for the students. The policies now allow students to engage in expressive activity in open outdoor areas on campus without obtaining a permit, unless the group is over 30 people.

The lower courts found that the lawsuit became moot when Uzuegbunam graduated from GGC and after the college had changed its speech zone policy and code. However, ADF attorneys argue that the case is still alive, citing opinions from other circuit courts. They argue that the Eleventh Circuit is the only federal appellate court that does not hold officials accountable for violating constitutional rights when they change the policies later during the litigation.

The case drew attention in 2017 after the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a Statement of Interest supporting the two students. The DOJ argued that the students had adequately provided enough evidence to allege a violation of their First and Fourteenth Amendment rights and that GGC's speech policies were not "content-neutral, established an impermissible heckler's veto, and were not narrowly tailored to achieve a compelling government interest."

Title: Obama Administration Reportedly Pursues Alternative Climate Deal to Bypass Senate Approval

The Obama administration is reportedly working on a "politically binding" international climate agreement, which would bypass the need for Senate approval, according to The New York Times. The agreement is expected to be signed at a United Nations meeting in Paris next year. This move comes as the administration faces dim chances of securing the necessary two-thirds majority in the Senate to ratify a new international treaty.

The proposed agreement would combine legally binding conditions from the 1992 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change with new voluntary pledges. This hybrid approach would allegedly "name and shame" countries into cutting fossil fuel emissions, without requiring a ratification vote.

State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki downplayed the reported developments, stating that no details of the agreement have been written, and it is too early to determine whether it will require Senate approval. The administration's goal is to negotiate a successful and effective global climate agreement to address the pressing issue.

Some lawmakers have expressed concerns about the administration's approach. Senator John Barrasso, R-Wyo., stated that the president is trying to go around Congress and ignore Americans who cannot afford more expensive, extreme energy regulations. House Science Committee Chairman Lamar Smith, R-Texas, emphasized the importance of congressional approval as an "important safeguard" for international agreements.

Senator James Inhofe, R-Okla., said the report shows the administration has given up on its dream of enacting an internationally binding global warming treaty and will continue to fight the president's economy-crushing domestic greenhouse gas regulations.

Title: Trump Blames Democrats for Fate of DACA, Calls for Merit-Based Immigration System

Article:

President Donald Trump stated on Sunday that the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program is "probably dead," placing the blame on Democrats. In a tweet, Trump claimed that Democrats do not want the program and are instead seeking to take away "desperately needed money" from the military. The program, which was introduced by the Obama administration, allows certain immigrants who were brought to the United States as children to remain in the country without fear of deportation.

Trump announced last year that he would rescind the DACA program, giving Congress six months to come up with a legislative fix. However, lawmakers have yet to reach a deal with the White House, and Trump has stated that a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border must be part of any DACA approval.

In a separate tweet, Trump emphasized his desire for a merit-based immigration system, stating that he wants people coming into the country who will help make it "strong and great again." He also expressed opposition to lotteries, which are often used to determine the selection of immigrants.

The president's comments come amid controversy over a report that he referred to immigrants from African nations, El Salvador, and Haiti as coming from "shithole countries" during a White House meeting with lawmakers last week. The report has sparked widespread criticism and outrage.

U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services announced on Saturday that it would begin accepting new requests for immigrants seeking protections under the Obama-era program, following a preliminary injunction that blocked Trump's decision to end DACA.

Title: Hundreds of Thousands March in Paris to Show Solidarity and Defiance Against Terrorism

Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets of Paris on Sunday to demonstrate their unity and defiance in the wake of the recent terrorist attacks. The massive march, which was attended by over 40 world leaders, focused on themes of freedom and French national pride. Demonstrators chanted "liberté" (freedom) and "Charlie" in reference to Charlie Hebdo magazine, and many waved French flags and sang the national anthem.

The march was a show of solidarity with the victims of the attacks and a rejection of terrorism. It was also a celebration of French culture and values, with many demonstrators carrying flags and wearing armbands with the slogan "Je suis Charlie" (I am Charlie).

French law enforcement officials have been instructed to be on high alert, with a French police source telling CNN that terror sleeper cells have been activated in the country over the past 24 hours. Amedy Coulibaly, the suspect killed during a hostage siege at a kosher market, had made several phone calls about targeting police officers in France, according to the source.

In related news, an incendiary device was thrown through the window of the archive of the Hamburger Morgenpost, a regional tabloid daily, early on Sunday morning. The paper had published Charlie Hebdo cartoons on its front page after the Paris massacre, with the headline "This much freedom must be possible!" Two people were detained and an investigation has begun.

Corresponding events were held throughout France and around the world, as people showed their support for the victims of the attacks and their rejection of terrorism. However, the specter of violence remains, with French authorities warning that new terror cells have been activated and Al Qaeda taking credit for the deadly raid.

Title: Author's Shift in Perspective on the Second Amendment

The author of this article recounts their personal journey from being skeptical of gun safety reform to becoming a strong advocate for stricter gun control measures. The turning point came with the tragic death of Noah Pozner, a victim of the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. The author's perspective on the Second Amendment has since shifted, and they now believe that the right to bear arms no longer promotes freedom and happiness but instead poses a daily threat to it.

The author argues that the Second Amendment's original purpose, to ensure a well-regulated militia, is no longer necessary with the existence of a professional and disciplined military. They also question the motivations behind the National Rifle Association's (NRA) stance on gun ownership, likening it to the Confederates who fought to preserve slavery.

The author highlights the negative consequences of widespread gun ownership, citing the high rate of gun-related deaths in the United States and the fear and ignorance that fuel the gun culture. They also suggest that the rise of gun ownership may be linked to the decline of the white majority and the fear of losing power.

The author concludes that it is time for America to grow up and address the root causes of violence, rather than perpetuating a culture of fear and ignorance. They urge the country to become adults, so that children like Noah Pozner have a chance to do the same.

Title: Vatican Releases Document on Gender Theory, Rejecting Idea of Gender Change or Choice

The Vatican has released its first document on gender theory, titled "Male and Female He Created Them," which reaffirms the Catholic Church's stance on the sexual complementarity of men and women. The document, published during LGBTQ Pride Month, calls for a "path of dialogue" and listening on the issue of gender theory in education.

The document aims to help Catholic teachers, parents, students, and clergy address the "educational crisis" in the field of teaching sexuality. It emphasizes the importance of a "positive and prudent sexual education" in Catholic schools, where children can learn the "full original truth of masculinity and femininity."

The document rejects the idea of gender fluidity, describing it as a symptom of the "confused concept of freedom" and "momentary desires" characteristic of post-modern culture. It also rejects terms such as "intersex" and "transgender," stating that the purpose of the biological complementarity of the male and female sex organs is to ensure procreation.

The document's release has been met with criticism from LGBT Catholics, who have denounced it as harmful and contributing to hatred, bigotry, and violence against gay and transgender people. The Rev. James Martin, a Jesuit priest and author of "Building a Bridge," noted that the document appears to rely heavily on previous papal pronouncements, Vatican documents, and philosophers and theologians, with little consideration for the real-life experiences of LGBT people.

Pope Francis has consistently argued against people choosing their own genders, and this document represents the first official comprehensive text articulating the Vatican's position on gender theory. The document calls for a new alliance among families, schools, and society to promote a "positive and prudent sexual education" in Catholic schools.

**Baltimore Courts Immigrants to Revitalize Shrinking Population**

Hundreds of people gathered at Baltimore's harbor in September to celebrate a significant milestone: nearly 50 individuals were sworn in as U.S. citizens. The diverse group included young and old, military personnel, parents, and children, representing countries such as El Salvador, China, and Honduras. As they raised their right hands and recited the naturalization oath, they became fully American.

Baltimore's efforts to revitalize its shrinking population are focused on courting immigrants, a strategy employed by other cities to boost their economies. The city's population has declined significantly since its peak in the 1950s, with a current population half of what it was in the 1960s. Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake aims to bring in 10,000 new families over the next decade, with a focus on immigrants.

Zakaria al-Saghir, an Iraqi immigrant, moved to Baltimore County with his family in September. He credits word-of-mouth recommendations from relatives for choosing the city, citing its welcoming atmosphere and community. The city's International Rescue Committee provides support services, including language classes and job training, to help newcomers adjust to life in the United States.

Baltimore's administration is working to make immigrants feel safe and welcome, prohibiting police and city officials from asking about immigration status. The city is also offering Spanish-language nutrition and exercise classes, Spanish story time at the library, and cultural training for police officers.

Catalina Rodriguez, Baltimore's Hispanic Community Liaison, is responsible for ensuring these programs run smoothly. She is training police officers to recognize foreign identification cards and reminding them to use an interpretation service on their mobile phones in 170 languages.

While it is too early to calculate Baltimore's return on investment, Philadelphia, another Northeast city, has seen success in recruiting immigrants to revitalize its population. Philadelphia's growth was largely driven by Asian and Hispanic immigrants, who helped the city recover from decades of decline.

However, some experts are skeptical about the effectiveness of Baltimore's approach. Steven Camarota of the Center for Immigration Studies believes that ignoring immigration status or offering services will not lead to large-scale immigration. He argues that immigrants, like anyone else, are attracted to cities with job opportunities.

David Kallick, director of Immigration Research at the Fiscal Policy Institute, disagrees, citing the benefits of attracting new immigrant residents, including increased property taxes and economic growth. While there are short-term costs associated with providing services to new immigrants, Kallick believes that investing in long-term initiatives is necessary for Baltimore's success.

Title: State Department Official Requested Extra Security for Benghazi Consulate Before Deadly Attack

The State Department's top security official in Libya, Eric Nordstrom, had requested additional security for the consulate in Benghazi in the months leading up to the deadly attack that killed Ambassador Christopher Stevens and three other Americans on September 11. However, Nordstrom did not receive a response to his requests, according to documents obtained by CNN.

Nordstrom, who served as the regional security officer in Libya until July, had expressed concerns about the Libyan government's ability to protect American diplomatic facilities. He sent two cables to State Department headquarters in March and July, requesting additional security agents for the Benghazi post, but did not receive a response.

The Republican-led House Oversight and Government Reform Committee will hold a hearing on the attack on Wednesday, with Nordstrom, Deputy Assistant Secretary Charlene Lamb, Undersecretary of State for Management Patrick Kennedy, and Army Lt. Col. Andrew Wood, commander of a security support team in Tripoli, expected to testify.

According to a summary of Nordstrom's interview with House Oversight and Government Reform Committee Democrats, he stated that Lamb believed it was unnecessary to assign more security agents to the Benghazi post, citing a residential safe haven to fall back on in an emergency. Nordstrom also noted that Undersecretary Kennedy had issued a memo in December requiring five agents to be assigned to Benghazi.

Senior State Department officials have said that security personnel in Benghazi were outmanned and outgunned during the attack and that no reasonable security presence could have successfully fended it off. The attack was described as unprecedented, with a senior agency official stating that it would be difficult to find a precedent for an attack like this in recent diplomatic history.

The Oversight Committee hearing has been criticized by Democrats as election-year political grandstanding rather than a serious effort to find answers about the attack.

Title: Former Vice President Joe Biden and Intelligence Agency Directors Submitted Unmasking Requests for Michael Flynn

The documents released on Wednesday revealed that former Vice President Joe Biden and the directors of the three main U.S. intelligence agencies submitted unmasking requests for information about Michael Flynn, contained in highly classified intelligence reports. The unmasking requests were made in January 2017, shortly after Flynn's contacts with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak.

The documents show that Biden's unmasking request was made on January 12, 2017, while James Comey, John Brennan, and James Clapper, the former directors of the FBI, CIA, and Office of the Director of National Intelligence, respectively, made similar requests. Denis McDonough, who served as chief of staff to President Obama, also submitted a request on January 5, 2017.

Unmasking refers to the process where high-level U.S. government officials request information about American citizens mentioned in classified foreign intelligence reports. It is not illegal to make unmasking requests, but the Flynn case is unique because information about his phone calls with Russia's ambassador was leaked to the media during the presidential transition period.

The list of names was released by Senators Chuck Grassley and Ron Johnson, who received the information from Richard Grenell, the acting director of national intelligence, who declassified the information last Thursday. Paul Nakasone, the director of the National Security Agency (NSA), provided the list to Grenell on May 1.

It is unclear whether Biden or others who submitted the unmasking requests saw the information related to Flynn. The document released on Wednesday stated that the unmasking requests were made under 16 different government officials' names for an unspecified number of intelligence reports. "Below is a list of recipients who may have received Lt. Gen. Flynn's identity in response to a request processed between 8 November 2016 and 31 January 2017 to unmask an identity that had been generically referred to in an NSA foreign intelligence report," the document stated. "While the principals are identified below, we cannot confirm they saw the unmasked information."

The list includes several high-profile Obama administration figures, including Brennan, Clapper, and Biden, as well as lesser-known officials at the Treasury Department and State Department. A flurry of requests were submitted in mid-December 2016, the records show.

The unmasking issue has been a focus of Republicans' efforts to figure out who leaked information about Flynn's communications with Kislyak. Kislyak contacted Flynn on December 28, 2016, the same day the Obama administration ordered 35 Russian diplomats to leave the U.S. because of Russian hacking during the presidential campaign.

The records do not settle the question of who made the unmasking request for information from Kislyak's communications with Flynn. Comey suggested in testimony to the House Intelligence Committee on March 2, 2017, that someone in the FBI made the request that revealed Flynn spoke with Kislyak. Clapper submitted an unmasking request on December 28, 2016, according to the declassified documents. However, Clapper suggested in testimony to the House Intelligence panel that the FBI submitted the request regarding the Kislyak phone calls.

The declassified records list Comey as the only FBI official to make an unmasking request for Flynn records. That request was submitted on December 15, 2016, two weeks before Flynn spoke with Kislyak. John Bass, who served as U.S. ambassador to Turkey, submitted a request for Flynn information on December 28, 2016. The next request was not submitted until McDonough, the White House chief of staff, did so on January 5, 2017.

McDonough did not respond to a request for comment. The Biden campaign also did not respond to a request for comment.

Days after Flynn's contacts with Kislyak, FBI and Justice Department officials began discussing whether Flynn violated the Logan Act, an obscure law that prohibits American citizens from negotiating with foreign governments regarding U.S. government policy. FBI officials arranged to interview Flynn regarding his contacts with Kislyak. The retired lieutenant general ended up pleading guilty to making false statements to the FBI during that interview, which was conducted at the White House on January 24, 2017.

The Justice Department filed a motion to drop the case against Flynn on May 7 after the discovery of FBI documents related to the Flynn investigation. One document was an FBI memo dated January 4, 2017, that authorized the closure of a counterintelligence investigation against Flynn. The memo said that the FBI found no evidence that Flynn was working as an agent of Russia. The bureau had investigated Flynn and three other Trump associates for possible Russia ties since August 2016.

Grenell, who also serves as ambassador to Germany, took the list of names to the Justice Department last week asking for the information to be released to the public. Grenell has been behind a recent push to declassify and release documents related to the FBI's investigation of Trump associates. He was involved in the process of declassifying footnotes from a Justice Department inspector general's report on the investigation. Those footnotes showed that the FBI received evidence in 2017 that Russian intelligence operatives might have fed disinformation to Christopher Steele, the author of a dossier that accused the Trump campaign of conspiring with the Kremlin.

Title: US Launches Airstrikes to Protect Haditha Dam in Western Iraq

The United States military launched airstrikes against Islamic State targets around the Haditha Dam in western Iraq, the Pentagon announced on Sunday. The strikes are part of the ongoing air campaign against the militant group, which has seized territory throughout Iraq and Syria.

According to Navy Rear Admiral John Kirby, the Pentagon press secretary, the airstrikes were conducted to prevent terrorists from threatening the security of the dam, which remains under control of Iraqi security forces, with support from Sunni tribes. The dam is the second-largest hydroelectric contributor to Iraq's power system, and its destruction or release of water could create a catastrophic threat to thousands of Iraqis.

The strikes were conducted by a mix of fighters and bombers, which destroyed five Humvees, one armed vehicle, a checkpoint, and damaged a bunker, according to the U.S. Central Command. The new strikes represent the first shift towards targets in western Iraq, a largely Sunni region that is currently a patchwork of conflicting loyalties.

The U.S. military has conducted 138 airstrikes in Iraq since the air campaign began on August 8. The strikes have targeted various areas, including the Mosul Dam, Mount Sinjar, and Amerli, a Shiite Turkmen town. The U.S. military has stated that the airstrikes are part of its mission to support humanitarian operations and protect U.S. personnel.

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has rejected the suggestion that the strikes open a new front in the war against the Islamic State or represent an escalation of U.S. military operations. The announcement comes after President Obama said the U.S. is prepared to "take the fight" to the militant group, which threatens to destabilize the region and could present a threat to the West.

Title: Unrest Erupts in Ferguson After Memorial to Michael Brown Destroyed in Fire

Ferguson, Mo. - Five protesters were arrested and some businesses were damaged Tuesday night after a memorial to Michael Brown was destroyed in a fire. The incident reignited tensions in the St. Louis suburb that was rocked by violence this summer after Brown, an unarmed teenager, was shot by a Ferguson police officer.

According to Capt. Ron Johnson with the Missouri State Highway Patrol, two St. Louis County police officers were injured during the unrest. One officer was hit just underneath his eye with a rock and is expected to recover.

The unrest started when a beauty supply store was looted and vandalized by several people attempting to haul out a cash register. The store's manager said this was the third time the store had been broken into in the last six weeks.

Police responded to the break-in, and then several gunshots were heard, with approximately 200 people gathering at the site where demonstrations were held after the Aug. 9 shooting of Brown by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson. After the break-in, a fire was reported at a restaurant on Carson Road. The investigation shows gasoline appears to have been poured around the restaurant, and the fire was put out by Ferguson firefighters.

Some protesters said they were in the streets because the makeshift memorial to Brown burned earlier in the day. Protesters believed it was set intentionally. The fire started around 6:45 a.m. CT Tuesday on Canfield Drive, the street where Wilson killed Brown, said Capt. Jeremy Corcoran with the Ferguson police.

The cause of the fire has not yet been determined, but Capt. Johnson does not believe a police officer started it. A full investigation is underway to determine the cause.

Later Tuesday, residents rebuilt the memorial. The blaze angered many people who live near the scene, with one man saying it was like a grave being desecrated.

Around 12:15 a.m., unpeaceful people started to flash lights into the eyes of police, shouting about shooting officers and burning down the town, Capt. Johnson said. He said the protesters were positioning themselves close to officers, so the decision was made to disperse the crowd. When they attempted to break up the group, some started throwing bottles, rocks, and other items at police, injuring two officers.

The unrest continued when someone near Canfield fired shots at the officers. Capt. Johnson said he saw the muzzle flash from the gun and sought shelter. Officers were wearing bulletproof vests, but Capt. Johnson said a lot of the heavy equipment used during the unrest in August was not used Tuesday, but they will start to respond to the area in riot gear if it becomes necessary.

One person was also arrested for allegedly throwing a Molotov cocktail at a parking facility.

Brown's death led to weeks of protest and unrest in the St. Louis suburb. After a month without an arrest, Brown's parents and activists questioned why Wilson had not been indicted in the killing. At the time of the shooting, witnesses in the area said Brown had raised his hands to surrender as he was shot. A state grand jury and the U.S. Department of Justice are continuing to investigate.

Title: EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt Confronted by Mother and Son Over Environmental Concerns

Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Scott Pruitt was confronted by a mother and her 2-year-old son while dining out in Washington, D.C. The woman, Kristin Mink, a sixth-grade teacher, approached Pruitt and expressed her concerns about his environmental policies, specifically mentioning her son's love for clean air and water. Mink urged Pruitt to resign, citing the numerous ethics complaints and federal inquiries surrounding his actions.

Pruitt faces investigations from the EPA's inspector general, the Government Accountability Office, and the White House regarding allegations of excessive spending on travel and security, dealings with subordinates and lobbyists, and other matters. A senior counsel for the EPA resigned last month amid allegations of mismanagement and spending. Pruitt has also faced criticism over the rental of a Capitol Hill condo tied to a prominent oil and gas lobbyist and the use of first-class travel and luxury hotel suites.

Mink had prepared notes before approaching Pruitt, stating that she had to decide what to say due to Pruitt's "scandal-ridden" reputation. Pruitt left the restaurant after the encounter, but his spokesman attributed his departure to finishing his meal and needing to return to the EPA for a briefing, denying any connection to the confrontation.

Title: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos Held in Contempt of Court for Violating Order to Stop Collecting Loans from Former For-Profit College Students

A federal judge has held Education Secretary Betsy DeVos in contempt of court for violating an order to stop collecting loans from thousands of former students of a defunct for-profit college chain. The ruling was issued by U.S. Magistrate Judge Sallie Kim in San Francisco, who fined the Education Department $100,000 and required the agency to make monthly reports to prove it is complying with the order.

The dispute stems from a lawsuit filed by thousands of former Corinthian Colleges students who claim they were defrauded by the chain before it collapsed in 2015. The suit challenges DeVos' 2017 decision to provide only partial relief to borrowers based on their incomes, rather than full forgiveness of their federal student loans.

In May 2018, Kim ruled that the partial-relief formula was unlawful and ordered the department to stop using it and stop collecting student loans from former Corinthian students. However, the department acknowledged in a September court filing that it incorrectly sent loan bills to more than 16,000 former Corinthian students, prompting over 3,000 to send payments. The department also garnished wages or tax refunds from 1,800 borrowers and provided credit agencies with negative reports about 800 borrowers.

The judge found that there was "no question" the department and DeVos violated the May 2018 injunction, stating that the defendants had not provided evidence that they were unable to comply with the preliminary injunction and that the evidence showed only minimal efforts to comply. The Education Department did not respond to requests for comment.

Lawyers for the former Corinthian students called the ruling a "rare and powerful action" that provides consequences for the "extreme harm" DeVos caused. The judge threatened to impose further sanctions if the department fails to follow her order, saying she would appoint a court official to serve as a "special master" to help enforce the injunction. The $100,000 fine will repay students for expenses they incurred to raise the issue to the court.

Title: Delivery Services Struggle to Keep Up with Surge in Demand Amid Pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a significant increase in demand for delivery services as people opt to stay at home and avoid public spaces. This surge has put a strain on food delivery services like GrubHub and DoorDash, which are scrambling to hire more workers to meet the demand. Grocery orders have seen a 150% increase in March compared to the same period last year, with many restaurants converting to takeout-only businesses to stay afloat.

The delivery system relies on an army of couriers, who face one of the highest risks of exposure to the virus. Many of these workers are independent contractors who lack health coverage and other benefits. In March, workers for the grocery delivery service Instacart held a nationwide strike, demanding sick leave and protective gear like masks.

The situation raises ethical questions about whether it is fair to ask others to take on the health risks associated with delivery work when individuals are not willing to do it themselves. Industry experts argue that having a small number of people do food shopping for larger groups is better than having everyone crowd grocery aisles themselves. However, many delivery apps have been accused of exploiting workers and restaurants by taking the lion's share of the income from deliveries.

Some labor rights activists see the increased importance of delivery workers and others in low-paying "essential" jobs as an opportunity to push for better conditions and benefits. This could lead to more strikes and protests in the coming weeks and months.

Industry experts emphasize the importance of tipping well, giving good ratings, and making an effort to protect couriers from infection as much as possible. They also stress that skipping delivery will not significantly affect workers' income due to the high demand.

The debate highlights the complex issues surrounding the gig economy and the need for better working conditions and benefits for those who rely on it.

Title: Lawsuits Challenge University of Michigan's Culture of Speech Suppression

The University of Michigan's president, Mark Schlissel, has been sued for constitutional violations, along with some members of the university's administrative staff, for allegedly suppressing free speech on campus. The lawsuit, filed by the organization Speech First, claims that the university's "elaborate investigatory and disciplinary apparatus" is designed to punish students for speech deemed "demeaning," "bothersome," or "hurtful" by their peers.

The complaint argues that the university's system is unconstitutional prior restraint and too vague to provide adequate notice of what speech is prohibited. The university's warnings about bias and the importance of creating a "safe and inclusive" environment have been criticized for being overly broad and potentially chilling to humor, parody, satire, or plain speech about various topics.

The Foundation for Individual Rights in Education (FIRE) has given the University of Michigan a red rating, indicating that it has at least one policy that restricts freedom of speech. FIRE has established a grading system to evaluate colleges and universities based on their commitment to free speech and inquiry.

The article also mentions that the University of Michigan has been criticized for its handling of bias incident reports, with the Wall Street Journal's Jillian Kay Melchior being thwarted in her request for records by a fee of over $2,400. The university's secrecy has been seen as an indication that it is embarrassed by its own policies.

The article concludes by noting that the University of Michigan is one of the top recipients of federal research funding, with $735 million in 2015, and that almost 40% of all federal research funds went to institutions with formal policies restricting constitutionally protected speech.

Title: Conservative Movement Shifts Toward Restraint in Military Intervention

The Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) has seen a shift in the conservative movement's stance on military intervention, with younger attendees gravitating towards a more restrained view. This change was evident in the lukewarm reception given to Rep. Louie Gohmert's hawkish comments, which tied together various wars and blamed them on former President Jimmy Carter.

Gohmert's speech, which emphasized the importance of committing to war, received a polite applause from the crowd, but it was Sen. Rand Paul's address that garnered a more enthusiastic response. Paul, a libertarian and son of the anti-war icon Rep. Ron Paul, called attention to the cultural divide within the GOP, stating that the party has grown stale and needs to adopt a more consistent approach to freedom.

The CPAC panel discussion, titled "Too Many American Wars? Should We Fight Anywhere and Can We Afford It?", highlighted the shift in the conservative movement's stance on military intervention. The event featured a standing-room-only crowd, with Sen. Marco Rubio warming up the audience by discussing God, students, and the American dream.

Paul's 13-hour filibuster against the president's drone authority drew criticism from influential Republicans, but it also earned praise from civil libertarians on both sides of the aisle. The event sparked over 1 million tweets, with 450,000 using the hashtag #standwithrand.

The CPAC gathering comes as the GOP is struggling with identity issues and trying to carve out a future. The roster of speakers reflects the struggle, with some big names missing, including New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and Virginia Gov. Bob McDonnell. American Conservative Union chairman Al Cardenas explained that the conservative movement is not a home for everyone and that the party needs to be true to its conservative values.

The shift in the conservative movement's stance on military intervention is a significant development, as it signals a move away from the hawkish views of the past. Younger attendees, such as Taylor University student Kasey Leander, appreciate the old guard's hard-line conservatism but also see the appeal in Paul's message. The CPAC gathering will continue to be a platform for conservatives to discuss and debate their stance on military intervention, with the party's future identity and message hanging in the balance.

Title: American Airlines' Preemptive Raise for Employees Sparks Controversy and Insight into the State of the Economy

American Airlines' decision to give its flight attendants and pilots a preemptive raise has sent shockwaves through the business world, with Wall Street analysts and investors expressing concerns about the potential impact on the airline's profits. The move is seen as a response to the growing gap in compensation between American Airlines and its competitors, Delta and United. However, the decision has sparked a broader discussion about the state of the economy and the role of labor in the business world.

Some analysts argue that the raise is a short-sighted move that will increase costs and potentially harm the airline's competitiveness. Others see it as a necessary step to address the morale problem and set the stage for future negotiations. The debate highlights the ongoing tension between the interests of shareholders and employees, with some arguing that the focus on cost-cutting has led to a decline in wages and benefits for workers.

The article also touches on the broader economic implications of the raise, noting that a world where labor is paid first could lead to increased spending and economic growth. The author suggests that a more balanced approach, where companies prioritize paying their workers, could lead to a more robust economy and increased economic opportunities.

The article presents a neutral and factual account of the situation, providing quotes from various stakeholders and experts, including analysts, economists, and business leaders. It does not take a stance on the issue, instead presenting the different perspectives and arguments for and against the raise.

Title: Trump Threatens to Remove CNN's Jim Acosta from Press Conferences if He "Misbehaves"

Article:

In an interview with Fox News' Chris Wallace, President Trump discussed the recent controversy surrounding CNN's Jim Acosta's White House press pass. The press pass was temporarily restored by a federal judge on Friday, but Trump indicated that new rules and regulations will be put in place to ensure decorum at press conferences.

Trump stated that if Acosta "misbehaves," he will be removed from press conferences or the conference will be stopped. He also mentioned that the administration is writing up rules of decorum, including restrictions on asking questions and making statements.

The controversy surrounding Acosta's press pass began after he refused to pass the microphone to a female White House aide during a press conference, resulting in a brief physical contact between the two. CNN filed a federal lawsuit against the Trump administration, demanding the reinstatement of Acosta's press credential. The White House initially suspended his hard pass, which provided expedited access to the White House grounds.

The temporary order from the federal judge lasts for 14 days, during which time CNN can petition the court for a permanent injunction. Further hearings are expected to take place in the coming weeks to determine whether yanking the credential violated CNN's and Acosta's First and Fifth Amendment rights.

In the interview, Trump emphasized his support for the First Amendment, stating, "Nobody believes in the First Amendment more than I do, and if I think somebody is acting out of sorts, I will leave." He also warned that reporters who misbehave will not be treated kindly.

The entire interview will air on "Fox News Sunday" at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. ET.

Title: Defense Secretary Hagel Faces Challenges in Confronting New Round of Defense Cuts

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is facing a significant challenge as he prepares to confront a new round of defense cuts, which could take $100 billion a year from the Pentagon. According to sources close to him, Hagel's approach to dealing with the sequester's impact on the military is different from the way the president wants to handle it. The former Republican senator from Nebraska has shown signs of fighting back against sequestration cuts by reinstating five of 11 furlough days for Pentagon civilian employees without getting White House approval. However, whether the White House will allow him to take similar actions again is still an open question.

Hagel and his commanders will need to choose between retaining troops and their benefits programs or paring back on modern weapons systems. The fight may determine the military's future as the nation winds down its war presence in Afghanistan and Iraq. Hagel shares President Obama's goal of a more efficient, if leaner, military, but he is pushing to separate Pentagon spending entirely from the rest of the non-defense budget, putting him at odds with the White House.

The White House is trying to put pressure on Republicans to spare social programs at the same time they are moving to restore some defense cuts. "If you just start to carve out certain popular items from the sequester, you don't solve the problem," a source close to Obama told Politico. "Chuck is just doing his job. He wants to exempt the military from the sequester, and that's understandable. But we're looking to get rid of the sequester across the board."

Hagel is also facing challenges within the Pentagon itself, including finding a replacement for top deputy secretary Ashton Carter, who is leaving the Pentagon at the end of the year. Hagel is reportedly still interviewing people for the job, but Robert Work, a former undersecretary of the Navy, is considered the top candidate.

Dealing with the budget cuts will be Hagel's most pressing and constant challenge, and it may eventually lead to a more public conflict with the president, according to Sen. Jeff Sessions, an Alabama Republican who voted against Hagel during his confirmation. "The first thing he's got to do is confront the political team in the White House, which is asserting too much influence over policy decisions," Sessions told Politico. "I just think it's his duty to speak the truth to the president and stand up, and you can't just always continue in office if you are asked to execute a policy that you truly believe is harmful. You have to make up your mind if you should stay or leave."

Title: Obama's ISIS Strikes Spark Congressional Debate and Vote

Article:

President Barack Obama's decision to launch airstrikes against the Islamic State (ISIS) in Iraq has sparked a congressional debate and vote, with some lawmakers questioning the president's authority to take military action without their approval. The White House has stated that Obama is operating under his constitutional powers as commander-in-chief, citing requests from the Iraqi government and Kurdish regional officials for assistance in battling the group.

The president has been sending notifications to Congress on the airstrikes under the War Powers Act, which requires congressional authorization for military action beyond 60 days. However, recent presidents have ignored this requirement, and some lawmakers are now pushing for greater involvement in the decision-making process.

Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican minority leader, has called for Obama to provide a "strategic plan" to protect the United States and its allies from ISIS. He has expressed concerns that training and equipping the militaries of partner nations will not generate sufficient combat power to protect America.

In an interview, Obama emphasized the need for a ground presence in Syria to confront ISIS, citing the Free Syrian Army as a potential partner. However, the opposition has been fractured, and moderate militias are viewed as less capable than ISIS. The president also reiterated his stance on Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, stating that his actions have foregone legitimacy due to the use of chemical weapons and barrel bombs against his own people.

The debate highlights the ongoing tensions between the executive and legislative branches over the use of military force, with some lawmakers seeking greater oversight and others advocating for a more robust response to the growing ISIS threat.

Title: Louisville Police Chief Intends to Fire Officer Involved in Breonna Taylor's Death

The Louisville Metro Police Department (LMPD) Chief Robert Schroeder has announced his intention to fire Detective Brett Hankison, one of the three officers involved in the shooting death of Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old emergency medical technician. Taylor was killed on March 13 when the officers entered her apartment, mistakenly believing it was the target of a "no-knock" arrest warrant.

According to Schroeder's letter to Hankison, the officer's actions displayed "an extreme indifference to the value of human life" when he fired ten rounds into Taylor's apartment. The chief stated that Hankison's conduct was a "shock to the conscience" and that he had previously been disciplined in January 2019 for reckless conduct that injured an innocent person.

Hankison, who has been with the LMPD since 2003, will have the opportunity to provide additional information or mitigating factors before his termination is finalized. The River City Fraternal Order of Police, which represents LMPD officers, did not respond to a request for comment.

Benjamin Crump, an attorney for Taylor's family, called the police chief's letter "damning" and expressed hope that the other officers involved in the incident would also be fired and criminally charged. Taylor's death, along with the death of George Floyd and other police killings of Black people, has become a rallying cry for the Black Lives Matter movement and has sparked nationwide protests against racism and police brutality.

The incident occurred when LMPD officers entered Taylor's apartment, believing it was the target of a "no-knock" arrest warrant. However, the warrant was actually intended for a different residence. According to Lieutenant Ted Eiden, the officers knocked on the door before forcing entry and were shot at by Taylor's boyfriend, Kenneth Walker. One officer was struck in the leg, and all three returned fire, hitting Taylor at least eight times. Walker was initially charged with attempted murder and assault but had the charges dropped last month.

Title: Trump Jr. Admits Meeting with Russian Lawyer, Contradicting Previous Denials

Article:

Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of former US President Donald Trump, has admitted to having a meeting with a Kremlin-connected Russian lawyer, Natalia Veselnitskaya, during the 2016 presidential campaign. The meeting was reportedly held because Veselnitskaya promised Trump Jr. negative information on Hillary Clinton. This revelation raises questions about the accuracy of previous denials made by Trump Jr. and other members of the Trump campaign.

According to The Washington Post, Trump Jr. had previously denied any contacts with Russian individuals during the campaign. In March, he stated that he may have met with people who were Russian, but emphasized that he was not representing the campaign in any way. In July 2016, he claimed that the Clinton campaign's allegations of Russian interference were "lies" and that the Democratic National Committee and Clinton campaign would "do anything to win."

Donald Trump Sr. also denied any collusion with Russia during a January press conference, although he dodged the question when asked directly. Later, off-camera, he gave a firm denial. Other Trump campaign officials, including Mike Pence, Kellyanne Conway, and Sean Spicer, also denied any contacts with Russia, with Pence responding "of course not" and Conway saying "absolutely not." Spicer referred reporters back to Trump's denial.

The meeting between Trump Jr. and Veselnitskaya took place in June 2016, and it is unclear what specific information was discussed. However, the revelation raises concerns about the extent of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election and the accuracy of previous denials made by the Trump campaign.

Title: Obama Calls Iran Nuclear Deal a "Success" Amid Bipartisan Concerns Over Dollar Use

Article:

President Barack Obama hailed the Iran nuclear deal as a "success" during a meeting with leaders of the world's major nuclear powers in Washington, despite bipartisan concerns in Congress that the administration may allow Tehran to use the US dollar in business transactions. The deal, which lifted economic sanctions on Iran in exchange for limits on its nuclear program and international inspections of its facilities, has been criticized by some lawmakers and the government of Israel, who argue that it allows Iran too much wiggle room to continue work on nuclear weapons undetected by international inspectors.

According to Obama, the deal has achieved a "substantial success" and focused on the dangers of nuclear proliferation in an effective way. He emphasized that the agreement is a success of diplomacy that hopefully will be able to be replicated in the future.

However, critics of the deal, including Republican lawmakers and presidential candidates, have expressed concerns that the administration may be allowing Iran too much flexibility in its nuclear program. House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, a Wisconsin Republican, stated that the administration should not further reward Iran, citing its recent ballistic missile tests. House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer, a Maryland Democrat, also expressed opposition, saying that the administration should not grant Iran any new relief without a corresponding concession.

U.S. officials have clarified that the Treasury Department is considering the matter, and any changes would not give Iran substantial access to the US financial system. The officials emphasized that the deal is achieving its intended results, with Iran having dismantled two-thirds of its installed centrifuges, shipped 98% of its enriched uranium stockpile out of Iran, and removed the Arak reactor core and filled it with concrete. If Iran were to cheat, the breakout time to build a nuclear weapon has gone from two to three months to about a year.

The agreement is set to be discussed further during the ongoing Nuclear Security Summit, with international leaders seeking to address concerns over nuclear proliferation and non-proliferation.

Title: Sen. Tom Cotton Criticizes "Stalin-like" Cover-up of Ocasio-Cortez's Green New Deal FAQ

Sen. Tom Cotton, an Arkansas Republican, has accused the news media of engaging in a "Stalin-like" cover-up of a Green New Deal document produced by Democratic Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's office. Cotton made the comments during a radio interview on "The Hugh Hewitt Show" on Tuesday.

The controversy surrounds a "frequently asked questions" (FAQ) explainer released as part of the Green New Deal's rollout, which was later retracted. The FAQ included ideas such as "high-speed rail at a scale where air travel stops becoming necessary," expanding public transit "with goals to replace every combustion-engine vehicle," and "economic security for all who are unable or unwilling to work." These ideas were flagged and mocked by opponents to the legislation.

Ocasio-Cortez has attempted to distance herself from the FAQ, claiming that "doctored" Green New Deal documents were "floating around" and that a "draft version" had been uploaded and taken down. Her chief of staff, Saikat Chakrabarti, explained that an early draft of the FAQ was published to the website by mistake and does not represent the actual Green New Deal resolution.

Cotton criticized the media for not reporting on the controversy, saying it was a "classic example of a gaffe being when you say what you really mean." He did not specify how the media were "complicit" in the alleged cover-up.

The Green New Deal resolution, as written, calls for "net-zero greenhouse gas emissions" within 10 years and "guaranteeing a job with a family-sustaining wage, adequate family and medical leave, paid vacations, and retirement security to all people of the United States." Most declared 2020 Democratic presidential candidates have expressed support for the Green New Deal, including Sens. Kamala Harris, Kirsten Gillibrand, Cory Booker, Elizabeth Warren, and Amy Klobuchar.

Title: CNN Analyst John Avlon's "Reality Check" Fails to Fact-Check Senator Tammy Duckworth's False Claims

Article:

CNN analyst John Avlon delivered a "Reality Check" on the New Day show, allegedly fact-checking Fox News host Tucker Carlson. However, the segment actually spread misinformation by replaying Illinois Democratic Senator Tammy Duckworth's false claims about President Donald Trump's speech at Mt. Rushmore.

Avlon set up his attack on Carlson, stating that calling one's opponent unpatriotic is unpatriotic. He then spent almost a minute touting Duckworth's family's long history of military service and her own record of military and public service. Avlon then played a clip of Duckworth appearing on Sunday's State of the Union, where she claimed that President Trump spent more time honoring dead Confederates than discussing the coronavirus pandemic.

However, a fact-check reveals that Duckworth's assertion is false. President Trump did not mention Confederates in his speech at Mt. Rushmore. Instead, he spoke about former Presidents and other historical figures. Duckworth also claimed that Trump spent all his time talking about dead traitors, which is also false.

Avlon did not bother to fact-check Duckworth's claims, instead choosing to attack Carlson and Fox News for allegedly spreading misinformation. The CNN analyst concluded that some people fearmonger when they don't have facts on their side, and that Fox News's own lawyer argued that Tucker Carlson's audience doesn't expect him to report facts.

Title: Concerns Raised Over Secret Service Protection of First Black President

The Secret Service has faced scrutiny in recent times over its handling of President Barack Obama's security, with some expressing concerns that the agency may not have taken the same level of care with the first black president as it has with previous leaders. The agency has denied reports that Mr. Obama received significantly more threats than other presidents, stating that the numbers have leveled out and are consistent with those of his predecessors.

Despite this, many African Americans have expressed concerns about the Secret Service's handling of Mr. Obama's security, citing the recent incident in which a fence-jumper made it into the White House. Roland Martin, a talk show host, noted that the ability of the individual to breach the White House's security measures was a stark reminder of the fears many had about the potential harm to the first black president.

The episodes have raised questions about the Secret Service's ability to protect Mr. Obama, with some attributing the agency's perceived lack of commitment to his race. Joshua DuBois, a former White House aide to Mr. Obama, noted that the president's security feels personal for many African Americans, who want to ensure he is protected and whole.

Donald W.
