Tucker, a retired Secret Service agent and one of the first black members of the agency, stated that he had no reason to believe the agency had not protected Mr. Obama vigorously, but acknowledged that he had heard concerns about the issue regularly. The Secret Service has not provided specific numbers on the number of threats received by Mr. Obama, but has denied reports that he received significantly more than other presidents.

Title: The Blurred Lines Between Issue Ads and Express Advocacy in Political Campaigns

The distinction between issue-based and express advocacy political ads has become increasingly unclear, making it challenging for the general public to discern the purpose behind certain advertisements. This ambiguity is a result of the Supreme Court's Citizens United decision in 2010, which allowed social welfare organizations to run political ads without disclosing their donors. However, a recent federal court ruling has introduced a new twist: 501(c)(4) groups must now disclose donors for certain types of issue ads.

Crossroads GPS, a social welfare organization co-founded by Republican strategist Karl Rove, has been one of the most prominent political advertisers this spring, running ads attacking President Obama on various issues. The organization's president, Steven Law, emphasizes the importance of reaching viewers emotionally and persuasively, stating that simply producing policy white papers is not enough.

Political scientists and campaign finance lawyers agree that the line between issue ads and express advocacy has become blurred. Deborah Jordan Brooks, a government professor at Dartmouth College, notes that ads can now easily be categorized as either issue-based or express advocacy, making it difficult to distinguish between the two. Robert Kelner, a campaign finance lawyer, emphasizes that the First Amendment's benefits come with a price: allowing some ads to remain anonymous.

The recent federal court ruling has led some groups to switch to express advocacy ads, which can be risky for social welfare organizations, as they cannot make politics their primary purpose. Without 501(c)(4) status, organizations would lose the ability to accept anonymous contributions, which gives them significant political clout. The exact number of ads a 501(c)(4) group can run before jeopardizing its status remains unclear, leaving organizations and experts alike uncertain about the boundaries.

Title: Supreme Court Declines to Intervene in Redistricting Disputes, Leaving Decisions to Politicians

The Supreme Court has declined to get involved in disputes over redistricting, ruling that conflicts over partisan gerrymandering are best left to politicians and the electoral process. The court's decision, announced on Thursday, comes after two cases presented to the justices alleged that redistricting plans discriminated against political parties and limited their First Amendment associational freedoms.

The cases, brought by North Carolina Democrats and Maryland Republicans, claimed that redistricting plans not only discriminated against them based on their political views but also handicapped their ability to exercise their First Amendment rights. However, the court declined to intervene, citing the fundamental flaw in every partisan gerrymandering claim: the idea that a political party or faction has a "group right" to control a proportional number of seats.

The court has long recognized that this concept is foreign to the Constitution, making it difficult to define which political associations deserve a proportion of seats and how to assign voters to those groups. The justices found that the latest set of plaintiffs did not solve the doctrinal problems and that better math would not give form to a justiciable cause of action.

In its decision, the court essentially ruled that the individual right claimed by the plaintiffs – to be "free" of partisan gerrymandering – was the same as the long-discredited group right to proportional representation. As a result, the court will not adjudicate claims for partisan gerrymandering, leaving redistricting judgments with the political branches.

The decision is seen as a victory for the Constitution, as it keeps redistricting decisions with the politicians who are accountable to the people.

Title: Vice President Biden Urges New Citizens to Help Undocumented Immigrants

Vice President Joe Biden addressed a crowd of 104 newly naturalized citizens and their families at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change in Atlanta, Georgia, on Thursday. In his keynote speech, Biden strongly condemned House Speaker John Boehner's comments regarding the immigration bill passed by the Senate earlier this year. Boehner stated that the House had "no intention" of voting on the bill.

Biden expressed his disappointment with Boehner's decision, calling it a "step backward in the history of the country." He encouraged the new citizens to help the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants living in the United States, urging them not to "pull up the ladder behind you" and to "reach back, help as you move on, and don't be afraid."

The Vice President also highlighted the importance of immigration reform, stating that it is crucial to provide a path for undocumented immigrants to earn their way and become contributing members of society. He noted that the House is in session for only 14 days before the end of the year, making it unclear what President Obama could do if the bill dies.

In his speech, Biden also shared a personal anecdote about his Irish-Catholic mother, who advised him not to bow or kiss the Queen of England's ring, saying "Joey, nobody is better than you, and you're not better than anybody else." The audience laughed at the story, which Biden used to emphasize the importance of humility and equality.

In closing, Biden pledged to help undocumented immigrants "out of the shadows," emphasizing that they came to the United States for a better life and are capable of contributing to society. He encouraged the new citizens to join him in this effort, stating that they are "incredibly capable of contributing, and many are already contributing."

Title: Republican Senators Resist Efforts to Repeal Obamacare, Citing Concerns Over Coverage Loss

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, have faced resistance from within his own party. Despite promises from many Republicans to dismantle the healthcare law, some senators from Medicaid expansion states are hesitant to support the repeal, citing concerns over the potential loss of coverage for tens of thousands of residents.

Governors from states where Medicaid expansion has been implemented, including some Republicans, have also expressed opposition to the repeal. Ohio Governor John Kasich, a Republican, stated that while there may be philosophical disagreements, stripping coverage from individuals with mental illnesses is not a viable option. Nevada Senator Dean Heller, also a Republican, echoed similar sentiments, saying that the current bill before the Senate is not the answer and will be difficult to support.

Other senators from across the political spectrum have also expressed concerns about the potential consequences of repealing the ACA. They are being pressured by their governors and state insurance officials to resist any bill that would increase premiums, reduce the number of insured individuals, or have other negative effects. The article does not specify which senators or governors have expressed these concerns.

The article also mentions President Trump's involvement in the healthcare debate, noting that he has been working with House Republicans to pass a healthcare bill. However, it does not provide further details on his role or the outcome of his efforts.

Title: President Obama Proposes Environmental Protections, Faces Opposition from Republicans

Article:

President Barack Obama has announced plans to propose new protections for clean water, clean air, and threatened species and landscapes. However, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and other Republicans in Congress are pushing back with a legislative blitz, aiming to weaken environmental regulations. This move is reminiscent of the 1994 Republican-led effort to cripple environmental statutes enacted under Presidents Johnson and Nixon.

The usual criticisms of "executive overreach" and "job-killing regulations" have been raised, but beneath the rhetoric lies a deeper concern that President Obama is attempting to fulfill the promise of laws passed by Congress years ago, which would be impossible to implement with today's Congress. The notion of regulatory overreach has also infected the presidential campaign, with Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker suggesting shifting the Environmental Protection Agency's functions to the states. This would create chaos, as businesses would have to navigate 50 different sets of rules, and undermine the even-handed enforcement of federal environmental laws.

In May, the administration approved a long-overdue rule increasing the number of streams and wetlands protected by the Clean Water Act. The rule will ensure cleaner drinking water and has little impact on responsible development. However, the House has already passed a bill to weaken it, and Senator John Barrasso of Wyoming introduced a similar bill in April, claiming the rule would "devastate" private property rights. President Obama should veto any such measure.

The administration has also made progress on climate change, increasing automobile efficiency, cracking down on mercury emissions, and reducing harmful smog. The most significant initiative is a final rule due later this summer to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from existing coal-fired power plants. The rule requires individual states to develop emission-reduction plans tailored to their energy mix, a crucial step towards reducing America's greenhouse gas emissions by 28% from 2005 levels by 2025. Senator McConnell has urged states not to cooperate, while sending mixed signals to the rest of the world about President Obama's ability to deliver. It is likely that Republicans will try to undermine the rule.

Title: White House Explores Funding Sources for Border Wall in Case of Emergency Declaration

The White House is working to identify federal funds that could be redirected to construct a border wall, should President Trump invoke his emergency powers to do so. According to Congressional and Pentagon sources, the Army Corps of Engineers has been asked to identify projects that could be canceled or delayed, allowing funds to be repurposed for a border barrier. Projects under scrutiny include military construction and civil engineering works designed to prevent damage from future disasters.

President Trump has threatened to declare a national emergency if he is unable to make a deal with Democratic lawmakers to fund his border wall. However, on Friday, he stated that he was not inclined to take that step immediately. An emergency declaration could activate special powers under which the president can redirect federal money without additional authorization from Congress.

Some see an emergency declaration as a face-saving way out of the spending stalemate that has shuttered parts of the federal government for the last three weeks. Senator Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., has urged the president to declare a national emergency, stating, "Mr. President, declare a national emergency now. Build a wall now."

Tapping emergency powers to short-circuit a political fight would almost certainly invite a legal challenge. Trump repeated on Friday that he was not inclined to take that step immediately. However, with talks at a standstill over the president's demand for $5.7 billion in border wall funding and 800,000 federal workers missing a paycheck, the White House is exploring the possibility.

According to a Democratic congressional aide, money that might be redirected includes funds for flood control and disaster prevention that was appropriated in February 2018, as well as the Army Corps' current budget for energy and water projects. Raiding those funds for the border wall would likely draw opposition from lawmakers who are counting on Army Corps projects in their home districts, as well as those who are concerned about losing control of the purse strings.

Representative Adam Smith, D-Wash., has expressed strong opposition to the idea, stating, "It's a spectacularly bad idea, a complete waste of money. The only emergency we have on the border right now is people seeking asylum. And people seeking asylum are not trying to sneak in. They're turning themselves in and asking for a hearing."

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., dodged questions on Friday about an emergency declaration and the administration potentially using Army Corps money to pay for the wall. "When the president acts, we will respond to whatever he does," she said.

The president continues to argue that a wall is desperately needed. On Friday, he hosted a roundtable discussion with state, local, and community leaders to call attention to what he describes as a humanitarian and national security crisis. A new NPR/Ipsos poll finds that the president's Oval Office speech on the subject had little effect on public opinion, with only 38% of those surveyed convinced there is a crisis on the border, and even fewer persuaded of the need for a border wall.

Title: FBI's Handling of IRS Targeting Scandal Raises Concerns

The FBI's decision not to file criminal charges in connection with the IRS's admitted targeting of conservative nonprofits has raised concerns about the agency's handling of the investigation. The FBI's conclusions were reached without interviewing even a single one of the 41 targeted clients of the American Center for Law and Justice (ACLJ), a non-profit organization that represents conservative groups. This lack of transparency has sparked questions about the fairness and thoroughness of the investigation.

The FBI's decision not to interview the victims of the potential crime has been criticized by some as a lack of accountability. The ACLJ has filed a lawsuit on behalf of its clients, which is ongoing. The organization is seeking answers about the FBI's handling of the investigation and the role of the Department of Justice attorney in charge of the investigation, who was a significant donor to President Obama's campaigns.

The controversy surrounding the IRS's targeting of conservative nonprofits has been ongoing since 2013, when Lois Lerner, the former director of the IRS's Exempt Organizations Division, admitted to systematic targeting. The investigation was launched in May 2013, and the FBI's conclusions were leaked to the media without the victims being interviewed. The ACLJ has criticized the FBI's handling of the investigation, saying that it was cursory and conclusory, with a predetermined outcome.

The controversy has sparked questions about the fairness and thoroughness of the investigation, as well as the role of the Department of Justice attorney in charge of the investigation. The ACLJ is seeking answers about the FBI's handling of the investigation and the role of the attorney, who was a significant donor to President Obama's campaigns. The organization is also seeking answers about the FBI's decision not to interview the victims of the potential crime.

The controversy surrounding the IRS's targeting of conservative nonprofits is ongoing, and the ACLJ's lawsuit is seeking answers about the FBI's handling of the investigation. The controversy has sparked questions about the fairness and thoroughness of the investigation, as well as the role of the Department of Justice attorney in charge of the investigation.

Title: Trump Admits Mistake, Reveals Imaginary Video Footage

Article:

In a sudden turn of events, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump admitted on Friday that he had made a mistake regarding his previous claims about seeing "top-secret" footage of the $400 million cash payment the Obama administration made to the Iranian government. The payment was publicly disclosed in January and was part of the 2015 nuclear deal.

Trump initially claimed that the payment was a hostage payment to a terrorism-sponsoring government, stating, "We paid $400 million for the hostages. Such a bad precedent was set by Obama." However, the money was actually Iran's cash in the first place, paid to the U.S. by the deposed Shah of Iran in 1979 to buy fighter jets. The U.S. froze those assets when the Shah was deposed, but paid the $400 million back to the current government as part of the 2015 nuclear deal.

Trump also claimed to have seen a video of the plane carrying the cash to Iran, describing it in detail, saying, "I'll never forget the scene this morning. Iran―I don't think you've heard this anywhere but here―Iran provided all of that footage, the tape, of taking that money off that airplane." However, a campaign spokeswoman later revealed that Trump had only seen the b-roll footage included in a specific Fox News clip.

Two days after Trump's initial claim, he abruptly changed course and admitted that the video he had seen was actually widely-circulated news footage of the plane carrying U.S. hostages in Geneva. This admission marks a rare instance of Trump acknowledging a mistake and recognizing basic reality. The article concludes that this may be a sign of Trump's latest "pivot," which has never quite stuck, and that it remains to be seen how long this newfound willingness to acknowledge facts and be nice to fellow humans will last.

Title: Republicans Show Little Appetite for Gun Control Legislation, Leaving Obama's Plan Uncertain

Article:

In the aftermath of the Newtown, Connecticut, school shooting, President Barack Obama is gearing up for a campaign-style push for new gun control measures. However, it appears that any comprehensive legislation restricting weapons and ammunition may not even receive a vote on the House floor. Interviews with multiple House Republicans from the Midwest and Northeast reveal a lack of enthusiasm for sweeping gun bills. Without internal pressure from center-right Republicans and given Speaker John Boehner's difficulties with conservative members of his conference, it seems unlikely that he will prioritize gun control.

Even if Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid were to attempt to muscle through a bill, there is only minimal support among rank-and-file House Republicans for gun control. Representatives Charlie Dent and Jim Gerlach, moderate Pennsylvania Republicans from swing districts, have expressed concerns about mental health and prevention of future shootings, but do not believe additional gun restrictions are the answer.

Dent noted that semi-automatic weapons are commonly owned in his district and beyond, and Gerlach stated that he is not seeking new curbs on firearms or ammunition. Instead, he emphasized the importance of keeping weapons out of the hands of those who should not have them. Gerlach expressed openness to tightening background checks but does not support gun restrictions.

Other House members and senior GOP aides have indicated that the fiscal cliff and the supplemental spending bill for Hurricane Sandy have dominated the conference's internal conversation for the past month. The gun issue is likely to be raised at their retreat later this week in Williamsburg, Virginia, and additional pressure may come with Obama's inaugural and State of the Union speeches.

Title: Trump Defends Refugee and Immigration Restrictions, Blames Protests and Schumer's "Fake Tears"

The Trump administration has launched a defense of its controversial refugee and immigration restrictions, with President Trump blaming protests and Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer's "fake tears" for difficulties at U.S. airports. The restrictions, signed into law on Friday, impose a 120-day suspension of the refugee program and a 90-day ban on travel to the U.S. from seven terror hotspots, including Iraq, Syria, Somalia, and Sudan.

The order has sparked chaos at the nation's airports as customs agents struggled to interpret the order, and outraged civil rights groups and Democratic lawmakers have spoken out against it. Schumer, D-N.Y., who has pledged to fight the order "with every fiber of my being," tweeted Saturday that "there are tears running down the cheeks of the Statue of Liberty tonight."

On Sunday, Schumer struggled to hold back tears at a press conference as he called the order "mean-spirited and un-American." Trump responded Monday morning, saying that only 109 people out of 325,000 were detained and held for questioning. He blamed the chaos at airports on a Delta computer outage, protesters, and "the tears of Senator Schumer."

However, the chaos began on Saturday, and most of the chaos was not related to the Delta systems outage. Trump also urged his Twitter followers to "study the world" and reminded them that "there is nothing nice about searching for terrorists before they can enter our country."

Trump doubled down on his criticism of Schumer, telling reporters that he thought there was about a 5% chance the tears were real. "I noticed Chuck Schumer yesterday with fake tears," Trump said. "I'm going to ask him who is his acting coach."

Trump aide Stephen Miller also defended the move, saying on Fox & Friends that the list of countries was from a list drawn up by the Obama administration, and that the move was a preventive measure to stop terror attacks like those seen in Europe. "Our task in this new administration is to prevent what happened in parts of France and Belgium and Germany from happening in the United States," Miller said. "Where you have large pockets of radicalization that extend through generations and that become a long-term security problem."

The Trump administration was forced to make a number of clarifications on the status of permanent legal residents or "green card" holders, while a federal judge issued a stay on deportations late Saturday.

Title: UK Government Sued Over Approval of Large Gas-Fired Power Plant

The UK government is facing a lawsuit over its decision to approve a large gas-fired power plant in north Yorkshire, despite objections from its own planning authority and concerns about the project's impact on climate change. The plant, developed by Drax, would be the largest gas power station in Europe and could produce 75% of the UK's power sector emissions when fully operational, according to environmental lawyers ClientEarth.

The planning inspectorate recommended that the 3.6GW gas plant be refused permission due to its significant adverse effects on the environment and the government's commitment to cut greenhouse emissions. However, Andrea Leadsom, the secretary of state for business, energy, and industrial strategy, overruled the advice and gave the project the green light in October.

ClientEarth has been granted permission to sue the government, with the case expected to be heard in about two months. The environmental lawyers argue that the project's large scale, level of carbon emissions, and long operating life make it a significant threat to the UK's carbon targets.

Drax, the company behind the project, claims its ambition is to be carbon negative by 2030, achieved through burning wood or plants and capturing and storing emissions. The company believes its carbon-negative ambition can be achieved alongside new, high-efficiency gas power capacity as part of its portfolio.

The UK government's actions to tackle the climate emergency are under scrutiny this year, with the country set to host a vital UN summit in Glasgow in November. The world's nations must dramatically increase their pledges to cut carbon emissions to avoid a disastrous 3-4C rise in global temperatures.

The government is set to bring its environment bill before parliament on Thursday, which it says underlines its commitment to tackling the climate crisis. The UK has already approved more than 15GW of large-scale gas plants, with ClientEarth arguing that approving Drax's project would take this to three times the government's estimates.

Title: Victoria Toensing's Benghazi Conspiracy Theory Debunked

Article:

Victoria Toensing, a Republican attorney, has been making headlines with her claims that anonymous State Department and CIA whistleblowers have been blocked and threatened by the Obama administration to prevent them from testifying about the September 2012 attack on the U.S. diplomatic facility in Benghazi, Libya. Fox News' Ed Henry even asked President Obama about the story at a recent press conference, with the president responding that he had no idea what Henry was talking about.

Toensing's claims are not new, as she previously wrote an op-ed for Fox News in November 2012 attempting to link the Benghazi attack to the abrupt resignation of former CIA director David Petraeus. Her argument was that Petraeus supported the White House's initial indications that an anti-Islam video had incited the Benghazi attackers, which she believed was "strange" given Petraeus' supposed knowledge of the true circumstances.

Toensing's theory was dense and winding, involving a complex web of conspiracy and speculation. According to her, Petraeus must have known that the administration was aware of the true circumstances of the attack, but was pressured to support the White House's narrative to avoid appearing to undermine the success of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden. She even suggested that the administration was blackmailing Petraeus over his extramarital affair, which ultimately led to his resignation.

However, Petraeus' actual testimony before Congress debunked Toensing's claims. According to The New York Times, Petraeus told lawmakers that classified intelligence reports revealed that the Benghazi attack was a terrorist attack, and that the administration refrained from publicly identifying Al Qaeda affiliates and sympathizers to avoid tipping off the groups. Petraeus explained that the names of suspected groups, including Al Qaeda's franchise in North Africa and Ansar al-Shariah, were removed from the public explanation of the attack to avoid alerting the militants.

Toensing's theory was ultimately proven wrong, as she disregarded basic factual information and common sense to leap to wild conclusions. This latest controversy surrounding Toensing's claims serves as a reminder to approach conspiracy theories with a healthy dose of skepticism and to fact-check information before accepting it as true.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidate Beto O'Rourke Unveils Plan to Combat White Supremacist Violence and Gun Violence

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke has unveiled a plan to classify white supremacist violence as an organized crime problem and create federal domestic terrorism offices to combat hate crimes and gun violence in the United States. The plan was announced on Friday, just days after O'Rourke returned to his home city of El Paso, Texas, where a white gunman targeting Hispanics killed 22 people in a Walmart store on August 3.

Under O'Rourke's plan, if elected president, he would ensure that the FBI and the Department of Justice prioritize neo-Nazi and white supremacist violence, and create dedicated domestic terrorism offices within the Department of Homeland Security and the DOJ. The plan also includes holding internet companies and social media platforms accountable for hosting hate speech and the amplification of domestic terrorism, taking on the National Rifle Association gun lobby group, and implementing a mandatory national buyback program for banned assault weapons and a voluntary buyback program for handguns.

O'Rourke's plan comes as he recalibrates his presidential campaign, which he declared on Thursday. He intends to highlight the plight of immigrants and confront what he characterized as Republican President Donald Trump's racially charged and divisive rhetoric. O'Rourke stated that violent white nationalists should be treated by the U.S. government as seriously as international terrorists.

Senator Cory Booker, one of O'Rourke's Democratic presidential rivals, also announced a plan to create a White House office to combat white supremacy and hate crimes if elected. O'Rourke is one of 23 Democratic candidates vying to become the nominee to take on Trump in next November's election, who have decried what they say is the president's divisive and inciteful rhetoric about undocumented migrants.

Title: Senate Republicans Struggle to Agree on Health Care Bill

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has stated that if Republican senators cannot agree on the current health bill, they will have to find an alternative. Senator John McCain expressed doubts about the bill's chances, saying it is "probably going to be dead." McCain believes Republicans should work with Democrats to craft health care legislation.

Senator Ted Cruz reiterated his push to repeal Obamacare and allow it to go into effect in a year or two, giving time to debate replacement options. Senator Lindsey Graham expressed support for the current bill, stating it is better than Obamacare. However, he acknowledged that different factions within the Republican Party may hinder progress.

The bill requires at least 51 votes to pass, and Republicans have been unable to secure the necessary support. Senator Graham emphasized the need for bipartisan cooperation if Obamacare fails, citing the current issues with insurers dropping out of exchanges and premiums increasing.

President Trump took to Twitter to urge senators to act, stating that Republicans have had their chance to repeal and replace Obamacare. The current negotiations revolve around key issues such as Medicaid funding, pre-existing conditions, and the individual mandate.

Title: White House Installs Senior Aides in Federal Agencies to Monitor and Shape Policy

The White House has appointed senior aides to oversee major federal agencies, creating a direct line of communication between the administration and the Cabinet secretaries. These aides, given the title of senior adviser, have already been responsible for hiring and crafting policy before the Cabinet members took office. They have worked with congressional aides, lobbyists, and others seeking influence in the new administration.

The arrangement appears designed to help the White House maintain control over its priorities, despite pledging to give Cabinet secretaries autonomy. Having senior advisers reporting to both the agency chiefs and the White House could lead to early tensions and conflicts with that pledge.

The chosen aides have been responsible for hiring and policy-making before the Cabinet members took office. They have worked with congressional aides, lobbyists, and others seeking influence in the new administration. The arrangement is seen as a way to keep the White House informed about agency activities and to ensure that its priorities are being implemented.

Historically, liaison positions have been held by junior staffers, with the bigger tasks, such as policy agenda and agency management, left to the Cabinet secretary, deputy secretary, and chief of staff. However, the Trump administration's picks for these posts are more political players than policy experts.

The senior advisers will connect directly to senior White House officials, such as Jared Kushner and Rick Dearborn, Trump's deputy chief of staff for policy. This is a departure from previous administrations, where liaisons were often less powerful.

The new advisers are expected to maintain constant contact with the White House and agencies, sign off on major decisions, and give the White House a window into agencies where Trump is not as personally close to the Cabinet secretaries. Some of the senior White House advisers in the agencies have frequently met with their respective secretaries, who did not pick them for the post.

The jobs have rattled Obama administration political appointees, who have been surprised at young campaign hands having such authority at federal agencies. The advisers at each agency will not face Senate approval, like more than 1,200 other federal government positions, including deputy secretaries and administrators.

Trump himself is likely to have little involvement in the minutiae of the agencies; people close to him expect him to want top-level briefings and little else. He tends to like conflict among his top aides and advisers, with them competing for his attention and respect.

The government is too big to run everything out of the White House, said Max Stier, who leads the Partnership for Public Service, which advised the transition. That pipeline is too small to deal with the breadth and complexity of the federal government.

There are potential upsides for these advisers, such as not facing subpoenas in the event of mishaps at the agencies. However, they could also face tensions with the Cabinet secretaries for micromanaging or feel torn about where to spend the majority of their time, in the West Wing or at the agency itself.

Title: Maryland Gubernatorial Candidate Doug Gansler Criticizes Obamacare Rollout

Maryland gubernatorial candidate Doug Gansler, a Democrat, has expressed frustration with the botched rollout of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) in his state. Gansler, the current attorney general, is critical of the state's online enrollment platform and the hiring of a company from North Dakota to help implement the exchange. He believes the situation is "almost like a 'Saturday Night Live' skit."

Gansler's criticism comes as a test of Democratic voters' patience with the ACA's technical setbacks. The state's current governor, Martin O'Malley, has faced criticism for the slow enrollment process, with fewer than 4,000 Marylanders enrolling in insurance plans by the end of November. The executive director of the state exchange resigned in December.

Gansler, a supporter of the ACA, argues that the state's exchange has "failed miserably" and given "fodder for Republicans" who want to scrap the law altogether. He points to the state's slow enrollment numbers and the fact that it is behind other states in implementing the ACA.

Gansler's criticism of the ACA's implementation in Maryland is a unique aspect of the 2014 gubernatorial race, as it pits a Democrat against another Democrat. The race is seen as a test of Democratic voters' patience with the ACA's technical setbacks and the state's implementation of the law.

Gansler's campaign has faced several setbacks, including a recording that surfaced in The Washington Post capturing him dismissing his opponent, Lt. Gov. Anthony Brown, for relying on his race as a campaign asset. Gansler's campaign has also faced criticism over accusations that he ordered his state trooper detail to violate traffic laws and an ABC News report featuring photos of him at a raucous high school beach party featuring apparent underage drinking.

Brown, the front-runner for the Democratic nomination, has received support from unions and prominent elected officials, including O'Malley, Sens. Ben Cardin and Barbara Mikulski, Baltimore Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, and U.S. House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer.

Gansler's criticism of the ACA's implementation in Maryland is a significant turn of events, as he was an early Barack Obama 2008 endorser and fought in court to uphold the constitutionality of the president's signature achievement.

Title: House Judiciary Committee to Question Witnesses on Legality of President's Immigration Executive Action

The House Judiciary Committee is set to hold a hearing on Tuesday to discuss the legality of President Obama's recent executive action on immigration, which aims to legalize nearly five million people living in the United States illegally. The hearing comes nearly two weeks after the President's announcement, and it will feature a panel of witnesses with varying opinions on the matter.

The witness list includes Dale E. Fowler School of Law Professor Ronald Rotunda, American Center for Law and Justice Chief Counsel Jay Sekulow, Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher Partner Thomas H. Dupree Jr., and National Immigration Law Center Executive Director Marielena Hincapi. Sekulow has argued in prepared testimony that the President's action violates the Constitution, stating that it is not grounded in his authority granted by the Constitution or in authority delegated by a lawful statute passed by Congress.

The Congressional Research Service has determined that Congress does have the power to defund the President's executive amnesty action, despite the agency being funded almost entirely by fees. The agency's funding is subject to congressional approval, and the Supreme Court has recognized that Congress can circumscribe agency discretion to allocate resources by putting restrictions in operative statutes.

The hearing is set to start at 1 p.m. ET and can be watched live.

Title: Congress Approves Budget and Hurricane Relief Deal, Raises Debt Ceiling

The United States Congress has approved a budget and hurricane relief deal, raising the debt ceiling and providing $15 billion in aid for Hurricane Harvey, which affected Texas and Louisiana last month. The deal was brokered between President Donald Trump and top Democrats and passed with bipartisan majorities in both the House of Representatives and the Senate.

The House voted 316-90 in favor of the bill, with all 90 votes against coming from Republicans. The Senate approved the bill 80-17. The deal raises the debt ceiling, funds the federal government through December 8, and provides $15 billion in relief for Hurricane Harvey.

The agreement was the result of an Oval Office meeting between Trump, Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin, Vice President Mike Pence, and congressional leaders from both parties. Trump agreed to tie hurricane relief to funding the federal government and increasing the debt ceiling for a three-month period. Republican leaders had pushed for a longer-term deal, but Democrats were satisfied with the short-term agreement.

The deal was met with a mixed reaction from congressional Republicans, with some expressing frustration and others praising the president's willingness to work across the aisle. Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney faced a chilly reception from some Republicans when they pitched the deal to the House Freedom Caucus.

The deal is seen as a precursor to better days to come, with some lawmakers expressing optimism that the bipartisan cooperation can continue. With the must-pass measures out of the way, President Trump is expected to focus on promoting his plans for major tax cuts, including lowering corporate taxes to as low as 15%.

Title: Attorney General Bill Barr Under Intense Scrutiny Following Roger Stone Sentencing Decision

Attorney General Bill Barr is facing intense scrutiny from Democrats and some Republicans after his decision to overrule prosecutors' recommended sentence for former Trump adviser Roger Stone. The move has sparked concerns about Barr's impartiality and potential political interference in the criminal justice system.

Barr will testify before the Democrat-controlled House Judiciary Committee on March 31, where he will face questions about his handling of the Stone case, as well as his decision to accept Ukraine-related information from Trump's personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani. The controversy has led to calls for Barr's resignation and even impeachment from some Democrats.

House Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler wrote in a letter confirming Barr's testimony that the AG's actions have raised "significant questions" about his leadership of the Department of Justice. Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn., said Barr "ought to be ashamed and embarrassed" and should resign over the issue.

Barr has defended his handling of the Stone case, saying he is doing what he thinks is right and cannot do his job with a "constant background commentary" from Trump's tweets. However, some have criticized his willingness to accept information from Giuliani, who has been accused of spreading disinformation.

The controversy has also led to calls for an investigation into Barr's actions, with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer requesting that the Department of Justice Inspector General investigate the matter. Some Democrats have even called for Barr's impeachment, citing his handling of the Mueller report and his refusal to investigate obvious crimes by the administration.

While some Republicans have backed Barr, others have expressed concerns about his actions. Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., released a statement backing the AG, but Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., and others have criticized him for the politicization of the Department of Justice.

The controversy surrounding Barr's handling of the Stone case has highlighted the ongoing tensions between the Trump administration and the Department of Justice, as well as the challenges facing the AG in balancing his duties as a law enforcement official with his loyalty to the president.

Title: Fox News Hosts Engage in Public Spat Over Donald Trump Interviews

Article: Two prominent Fox News hosts, Megyn Kelly and Sean Hannity, have locked horns over Donald Trump's willingness to grant interviews. The disagreement began when Kelly criticized both Trump and Hillary Clinton for only taking questions from friendly interviewers on her television show, "The Kelly File," on Wednesday night. Kelly stated that Trump, with all due respect to her colleague Sean Hannity, only appears on Hannity's show and rarely ventures out to "unsafe spaces" to expand his reach.

Hannity responded on Twitter, accusing Kelly of supporting Hillary Clinton and pointing out that Trump did, in fact, appear on her show. The exchange is the latest in a series of internal conflicts at the conservative-leaning cable news channel, which has been plagued by internal dissension since the resignation of longtime CEO Roger Ailes in July. Ailes had been accused of serial sexual harassment and had served as an informal adviser to the Trump campaign.

Kelly has been a target of Trump's criticism since the summer of 2015, when she moderated the first Republican primary debate. Trump took exception to her tough questioning and made a comment that was widely interpreted as a reference to menstruation. The resulting uproar led Trump to be banned from a major gathering of conservatives and sparked the biggest crisis of his campaign up to that point.

In contrast, Hannity has been a vocal supporter of Trump, appearing in an advertisement for the Republican nominee and frequently praising him on his show. Trump has also appeared in several one-on-one primetime interviews with Hannity and even cited him as a character witness in the first presidential debate.

Title: House Republicans Storm Secure Room, Protest Impeachment Probe Against President Trump

House Republicans stormed the secure room where lawmakers have been conducting the impeachment probe against President Trump, disrupting a scheduled deposition and demanding fairness from the Democrats running the show. The move enraged Democrats, who accused the Republican lawmakers of creating a potential security lapse by bringing electronic devices into the secure area.

The Republican lawmakers, who were not part of the impeachment committees, claimed that the hearing they disrupted, involving Defense Department official Laura Cooper, was not classified and that Democrats have broken the rules of fairness by shutting them out of the impeachment process. They argued that the investigation into President Trump's communications with Ukraine over former Vice President Joseph R. Biden, a political opponent, is not following any of the precedents for impeachment proceedings.

Democrats countered that Republicans on the committees can participate and ask questions, and that is good enough. They also pointed out that the investigation is being conducted by the Intelligence Committee, and members of the Republican side were present during the depositions and were permitted to ask whatever questions they wanted to.

The incident led to a heated exchange between the two parties, with House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam B. Schiff threatening to bring ethics charges against the Republican protesters and Homeland Security Committee Chairman Bennie G. Thompson asking the sergeant-at-arms to probe the breach of the room. Rep. Eric Swalwell, California Democrat, said the problem was that lawmakers brought in electronic devices, which are usually banned.

The testimony of Defense Department official Laura Cooper, which was delayed due to the Republican protest, ultimately took place five hours after it was scheduled to begin. The details of her testimony remain unclear, but it comes a day after a former U.S. diplomat to Ukraine told lawmakers that President Trump made the release of military aid to Ukraine contingent on that country probing Mr. Biden and his son Hunter, who was on the board of directors of Ukrainian energy company Burisma.

The diplomat, William Taylor, said he uncovered an "irregular" backchannel managed by President Trump's personal attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani to push Ukraine into investigating the Bidens and 2016 election interference. Republicans claimed that Mr. Taylor's testimony was "contradicted" by other witnesses who said there was no quid pro quo.

In the wake of Mr. Taylor's testimony, the committees leading the impeachment probe issued a new demand for State Department documents, including text messages from witnesses and any memos regarding efforts to press Ukraine to open investigations. Three Democratic senators also filed a Freedom of Information Act request with the Justice Department for documents related to Ukraine. A federal judge ordered the State Department to begin releasing Ukraine-related documents within 30 days, which include communications between Mr. Giuliani and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

Title: Senator Rand Paul Expresses Need to Improve Temper in Interviews

Senator Rand Paul, a Republican presidential candidate, acknowledged that he needs to work on controlling his temper during interviews. This comes after he clashed with two reporters, including "Today" show anchor Savannah Guthrie, over his stance on abortion and foreign aid.

Paul denied interrupting female reporters, stating that he has been "short-tempered and testy" with both male and female reporters. He acknowledged that it can be challenging when being interviewed and not being able to see the reporter, particularly if it's a hostile interviewer. Paul expressed a desire to improve his patience and composure during interviews.

The senator's combative day began when he clashed with Guthrie over what he deemed biased questioning. Guthrie pointed out changes in Paul's foreign policy views over the years, including his previous stance that Iran was not a threat, but now considers it a threat. Paul interrupted Guthrie, advising her on how to conduct the interview and stating that she had "editorialized."

Paul also faced questions about his views on abortion, which he has previously supported with exceptions for situations like rape and incest. When asked about his stance, Paul referred to the Democratic National Committee, saying, "Why don't you ask the DNC, 'Is it OK to kill a seven-pound baby in the uterus?'"

Paul has clashed with reporters in the past, including an interview with CNBC anchor Kelly Evans in February, where he chastised her for posing "slanted" questions. He offered Evans a suggestion on how to conduct a better interview, stating that she should start with more objectivity.

When asked about his testy interview with Guthrie, Paul decried questions about the apparent changes in his positions, saying, "'O.K., well we understand that you've been beating your wife for years and you've flip-flopped on 25 different issues and you used to believe this and you used to believe that,' he told the New York Times. 'That isn't journalism.'"

Title: Obama Administration Announces Policy to Defer Deportation of Illegal Immigrant Students

The Obama administration has announced a new policy to defer the deportation of illegal immigrant students, sparking a wave of elation among those affected and praise from Democrats and Latino leaders. The decision comes after Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano approached the White House in mid-May with a plan to use existing laws to lift the threat of deportation for large numbers of illegal immigrant students.

According to administration officials, the policy shift was driven by a review of over 411,000 deportation cases before the nation's immigration courts, which showed that only 593 illegal immigrant students had been halted from deportation. This led to frustration and impatience at the White House, particularly among Latino and immigrant advocates who felt that Homeland Security Secretary Napolitano was thwarting the president's policies.

The new policy, which will allow illegal immigrant students to apply for work permits, requires them to be 30 or younger, have come to the United States before they were 16, be in school or have a high school diploma or military service, and have no criminal record. The policy is expected to benefit thousands of young immigrants who have been living in the United States without legal status.

The decision was met with criticism from some Republicans, who accused the president of overstepping his legal bounds and not consulting with Congress. However, the White House officials said they had concluded that they had the legal authority to implement the policy and that it would be carried out on a case-by-case basis.

The policy shift comes as the White House is awaiting a ruling from the Supreme Court on the administration's lawsuit against Arizona's tough immigration enforcement law. The administration is also concerned about the potential impact on the November election, as some Republicans have criticized the move as an attempt to circumvent Congress and appease Latino voters.

The decision was welcomed by Democratic lawmakers, who had been pushing for the passage of the Dream Act, a proposal that would provide a path to legal status for illegal immigrant students. Senator Dick Durbin, who first introduced the Dream Act 11 years ago, said he had advised the president that he would not be able to muster enough votes in the Senate to pass the bill before the November election.

Title: Democrats Debate "Are You Better Off?" Question as Convention Kicks Off

The 2012 Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, North Carolina, has begun, and the question on everyone's mind is: Are you better off than you were four years ago? This classic query, famously asked by then-candidate Ronald Reagan in 1980, has become a topic of great debate among Democrats and Republicans.

Governor Martin O'Malley of Maryland sparked the discussion when he told CBS News' Bob Schieffer, "No, but that's not the question of this election. The question, without a doubt, we are not as well off as we were before George Bush..." Republican vice presidential nominee Representative Paul Ryan quickly responded, stating that President Obama cannot claim the country is better off, and that the Jimmy Carter years seem like the good old days compared to the current state of affairs.

In response, Vice President Joe Biden told supporters in Detroit, "You want to know whether we're better off? I got a little bumper sticker for you. Osama bin Laden is dead and General Motors is alive! Osama bin Laden is dead and General Motors is alive!"

As the convention continues, more discussion is expected on this topic, with President Obama set to accept his party's nomination on Thursday evening. The NPR Elections Desk is providing coverage from the Democratic convention, with bloggers Eyder, Liz Halloran, and Frank James filing reports and hosting nightly chats on the blog. Tonight's featured speakers include First Lady Michelle Obama.

Title: Holder Recuses Himself from AP Leak Investigation, Launches IRS Inquiry

Attorney General Eric Holder has recused himself from the investigation into the leak of classified information to the Associated Press, citing the need to avoid any appearance of conflict. Holder made the announcement on Tuesday, as the Justice Department and the Obama administration face growing pressure over the twin scandals involving the IRS and the AP leak.

Holder stated that he had recused himself from the investigation due to his own involvement in the initial inquiry, having been interviewed by the FBI. He emphasized that he took the step "out of an abundance of caution" to ensure the investigation remained independent and free from any perceived conflict.

The Attorney General described the leak as "among the most serious, if not the most serious, among the top two or three most serious leaks I have ever seen." He emphasized that the leak put the American people at risk and required an aggressive response from the federal government.

Separately, Holder launched an investigation into the IRS's targeting of conservative political groups, calling the actions "outrageous and unacceptable." The FBI is working with the Justice Department to determine if any laws were broken.

The decision to subpoena the AP's phone records was made by Deputy Attorney General James Cole, according to a Justice Department official. Holder expressed confidence in the officials who made the decision and reiterated the administration's support for a shield law to protect journalists.

The Attorney General's comments come ahead of his appearance on Capitol Hill on Wednesday, where he is expected to face further questioning on the twin scandals.

Title: Trump's Twitter Tirade: A Pattern of Bullying and Demeaning Women

Article:

Tara Setmayer, a former communications director for Rep. Dana Rohrabacher and a CNN political commentator, has expressed her opinions on the recent Twitter spat between Donald Trump and Ted Cruz. In a matter of 48 hours, the national conversation shifted from the War on Terror to the War on Women, thanks to Trump's latest Twitter tirade.

At the time of Trump's infamous tweet threatening to "spill the beans" on Ted Cruz's wife, the world was reeling from the latest ISIS terrorist attack in Brussels. It was also a bad timing, considering Trump failed to allay growing criticism of his lack of foreign policy knowledge with a mediocre speech to pro-Israel group AIPAC, raised eyebrows when he wouldn't rule out the use of nuclear weapons to fight ISIS, and suggested the United States pull back its role in NATO during a bizarre Washington Post editorial board meeting. Not only is Belgium a member of NATO, its headquarters are in Brussels. Whoops.

Trump's tweet was a response to an anti-Trump super PAC's use of a Melania Trump modeling photo in a political ad. However, Trump has a history of throwing temper tantrums and insulting women. From calling women "disgusting," "fat pigs," and "bimbos" to remarks about dropping to their knees and having a nice piece of * * on his arm, the litany of offensive comments is well-documented.

Trump's reaction to the Melania photo was more about feigned outrage designed to distract than some noble act of chivalry. It's more about bullying and demeaning women because that's Trump's modus operandi. An honorable man doesn't need to objectify another man's wife to effectively defend his own.

Attacking Heidi Cruz's appearance was a direct assault against all women and young girls who are often harshly and unfairly judged by their looks. What kind of message does that send coming from a presidential front-runner?

According to the latest CNN poll, 73% of registered female voters in the United States have an unfavorable view of Trump. Those results are consistent with a Reuters poll that found more than half of the women in this country hold a "very unfavorable" view of him. That's a steep hill to climb for Trump in a general election if he ends up the GOP nominee against Hillary Clinton.

Trump's latest antics demonstrate once again that he does not have the temperament, judgment, or common decency to be President of the United States.

Title: Hugh Hewitt Outlines Conservative Priorities for Future Elections, Debates, and Conventions

Hugh Hewitt, a prominent conservative commentator, recently addressed the RedState Gathering, sharing his thoughts on what conservatives should prioritize in future elections, debates, and conventions. Hewitt emphasized the importance of protecting the party system, improving the convention process, and rethinking the role of the media in presidential debates.

Firstly, Hewitt advocated for ending open primaries, citing the potential for non-party members to disrupt the process. He emphasized the importance of parties as vehicles for change in government and the need to protect this system.

Secondly, Hewitt suggested permanently locating the Republican National Convention in either Cleveland or Denver, both swing states that can be easily swapped between election cycles. He praised the logistical success of the 2016 Republican Convention in Cleveland and criticized the Democratic Convention, which he deemed a "total disaster."

Thirdly, Hewitt highlighted the importance of planning and organization, citing the success of the 2016 Republican Convention and the challenges faced by the 2004 and 2012 conventions. He suggested that repeating this success by having conventions earlier in the election cycle could have advantages in campaign finance and messaging.

Lastly, Hewitt discussed the media's role in presidential debates, expressing admiration for CNN's professionalism and fairness during the 2020 debates. However, he questioned the need for the Commission on Presidential Debates and suggested that conservative media personalities could moderate debates instead. Hewitt mentioned several potential moderators, including Katie Pavlich, Ed Morrissey, Guy Benson, Larry O'Connor, Stephen Hayes, Erick Erickson, and Mary Katherine Ham.

Hewitt characterized the 2020 election cycle as a "transition year" and argued that conservatives should take control of the media events, rather than relying on mainstream media figures who may have a liberal bias. He emphasized the importance of having conservative voices moderate debates and questioned why the Commission on Presidential Debates is necessary.

Title: Rep. Chris Collins Resigns Ahead of Hearing Related to Insider Trading Charges

Rep. Chris Collins, a New York Republican, has submitted his resignation letter to Speaker Nancy Pelosi, effective when it is read on the House floor during a pro forma session on Tuesday. This move comes as Collins faces a change of plea hearing on Tuesday afternoon, which may indicate he is considering a deal with federal prosecutors. Collins is accused of eight counts of federal criminal charges, including conspiracy to commit securities fraud, securities fraud, and false statements.

Collins, along with his son Cameron and Stephen Zarsky, are alleged to have engaged in an insider trading scheme involving an Australian biotechnology company, Innate Immunotherapeutics. According to the allegations, Collins provided nonpublic information to his son about confidential drug test results, allowing Cameron and others to trade on that privileged information before the public was aware.

The resignation comes as Collins' staff has been dwindling, with half of his full-time staff leaving the office since his indictment in August 2018. Seven of 14 full-time staffers are no longer working in the office, according to payroll records from May 2019.

The 27th District, which Collins represents, is considered a Republican stronghold, and his resignation could boost the party's chances of holding onto the seat. Several Republican candidates are already vying for the seat, including State Sen. Chris Jacobs, who had the most cash on hand at the end of the second fundraising quarter.

The Democratic field is also expected to grow, with Erie County Democratic Party Chairman Jeremy Zellner stating that he is already hearing from Democrats who may be interested in running. However, the party is currently focused on the upcoming election for county executive.

The resignation of Rep. Chris Collins has sent shockwaves through the political landscape, with his departure potentially changing the dynamics of the 27th District.

Title: Senate Prepares for Impeachment Trial as Democrats Demand Witnesses and Republicans Weigh In

The United States Senate is gearing up for a crucial week, with lawmakers returning to the Capitol on Monday to tackle a packed agenda. The House of Representatives is set to vote on a $1.4 trillion spending deal to avoid a government shutdown and approve a new North American trade pact to replace NAFTA. Meanwhile, the impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump is reaching a critical stage.

Senator Chuck Schumer, the Democratic minority leader, has demanded that Republicans call senior White House officials to testify as witnesses, a request that has been made for the second day in a row. However, about a dozen moderate Democrats have yet to announce how they will vote on the impeachment articles, which are expected to be voted on on Wednesday.

Only two Democrats have publicly indicated they will vote against impeaching President Trump, with Representative Collin C. Peterson of Minnesota planning to vote "no" and Representative Jeff Van Drew of New Jersey planning to oppose the impeachment articles before switching parties. Van Drew's decision to become a Republican could impact his re-election chances in his swing district.

The House Judiciary Committee has released a report detailing the findings of its impeachment inquiry, which charges President Trump with abusing the power of the presidency and obstructing Congress. The report provides no new allegations or evidence but offers a detailed supporting argument for the two articles of impeachment. The report concludes that President Trump has placed his personal and political interests above national security, free and fair elections, and the system of checks and balances, and recommends his impeachment and removal from office.

Title: Trump Accuses Democrats of Dishonesty and Treason Amid Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

US President Donald Trump has lashed out at congressional Democrats, accusing them of dishonesty and even treason, as the impeachment inquiry into his dealings with Ukraine continues. The inquiry, led by the House Intelligence Committee, is focused on a phone call between Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, which has been at the center of controversy.

Trump made the comments during a joint news conference with Finnish President Sauli Niinistö, where he also called Democratic leaders "dishonest" and "lowlife." He specifically targeted House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, calling him "shifty Schiff" and saying he "should resign from office in disgrace." Trump also accused Schiff of helping write a complaint about the call filed by a whistleblower, without providing evidence.

The US president also labeled the entire inquiry a "hoax" and a "fraudulent crime on the American people," while maintaining he would "always cooperate" with Congress. Trump also sparred with a Reuters correspondent, saying "there are those who think I'm a very stable genius" and hinting at potential litigation against those involved in the Russia investigation.

The impeachment inquiry, which may seek to remove Trump from office, stems from a whistleblower's complaint about his July 25 phone call with Zelensky. The call has been the subject of intense scrutiny, with Democrats accusing Trump of pressuring a vulnerable ally to interfere in the 2020 US election for his personal benefit.

The House Oversight Committee has issued a subpoena to the White House, demanding documents related to the call and any related items from acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Schiff have defended the impeachment proceedings, saying they are not "fooling around" and will not "drag on."

The impeachment process is the first part of a two-stage political process by which Congress can remove a president from office. If the House of Representatives votes to pass articles of impeachment, the Senate is forced to hold a trial, requiring a two-thirds majority to convict.

Title: Trump Orders Creation of Sixth Branch of Military to Focus on Space

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump announced on Monday that he is ordering the creation of a sixth branch of the military, specifically focused on space. The new branch, dubbed the "Space Force," aims to enhance American dominance in space, according to Trump. The President stated, "It is not enough to merely have an American presence in space. We must have American dominance in space."

The idea of a Space Force has been discussed before, with proponents arguing it would streamline the Pentagon's operations. However, critics, including Air Force Chief of Staff General David Goldfein, have expressed concerns that it would create unnecessary bureaucracy and undermine the Air Force's existing space-related responsibilities.

The creation of the Space Force would require approval from the U.S. Congress, which has been divided on the idea. Senator Bill Nelson, a Democrat, tweeted that the move would be a mistake, stating, "Now is NOT the time to rip the Air Force apart. Too many missions at stake."

Pentagon spokeswoman Dana White confirmed that the department's policy board will prepare to implement Trump's order, emphasizing that the process will involve input from multiple stakeholders and congressional approval.

The move comes as Trump has also ordered a review of regulations on commercial space flights and signed a directive to enable astronauts to return to the moon and eventually lead a mission to Mars. The U.S. first landed on the moon in 1969, a goal set by former President John F. Kennedy in 1961. Since then, U.S. efforts to explore beyond Earth's orbit have focused on remote spacecraft without human crew members.

Title: Obama to Use Executive Orders to Tighten Gun Laws, NRA Calls it a "Political Stunt"

The National Rifle Association (NRA), the country's most influential gun-rights supporter, is challenging President Obama's new plan to use his presidential powers to tighten firearms laws, calling it a "political stunt" that fails to increase public safety. The plan is expected to focus on small-scale firearms sellers and background checks for gun buyers.

According to Politico, Obama is expected to use executive orders to tighten federal laws, building on recommendations from the gun-control nonprofit Everytown, led by billionaire and former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg. The president's move comes after he ordered his White House team to identify "new actions" that he can take to curb gun violence several months ago.

The NRA has criticized Obama's plan, saying it is a "political stunt" that will not increase public safety. "President Obama failed to pass his anti-gun agenda through Congress because the majority of Americans oppose more gun control," said NRA spokeswoman Jennifer Baker. "Now he is doing what he always does when he doesn't get his way, which is defy the will of the people and issue an executive order."

Obama's plan is expected to require small-scale gun sellers to submit background checks for potential buyers, but it is not expected to completely close the so-called "gun show loophole," which allows for firearm purchases at such venues without a check. The president's move comes after the third anniversary of the 2012 mass shooting at Sandy Hook elementary school, in which a deranged gunman killed 20 children and six adults.

The Obama administration's previous effort to tighten gun laws in the aftermath of the Sandy Hook massacre failed to get enough support for passage from Senate Democrats and Republicans. The president's new plan is expected to face similar opposition from the NRA and other gun rights groups.

The NRA has argued that the existing law already requires those who sell guns with the "principal objective of livelihood and profit" to get a dealer's license through the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, which includes conducting background checks on buyers. The gun industry has successfully argued that voluntary reporting of lost firearms is sufficient, rather than mandatory reporting.

Title: Efforts to Suppress Voting Rights Continue Across the United States

The right to vote is a fundamental aspect of any democracy, and ensuring its protection and accessibility is crucial. However, in the five years since the Supreme Court gutted the Voting Rights Act, efforts to suppress voting rights have intensified, particularly in Republican-led states. These measures aim to make it harder for certain groups, such as minorities and young people, to exercise their right to vote.

In Alabama, for example, the state has had all-white appellate court justices for a quarter-century, due to the requirement of at-large statewide elections for appellate and Supreme Court judges. This practice, also seen in Texas, is being challenged in a lawsuit filed by the Alabama State Conference of the NAACP. Additionally, Alabama has implemented measures such as requiring a photo ID to vote, closing driver's license offices disproportionately in black areas, and imposing a "proof of citizenship" mandate to register to vote.

Similar tactics are being employed across the country, making voter registration harder, limiting voting days, and criminalizing voter registration drives. Partisan gerrymandering has also become more sophisticated, and hackable voting machines pose a threat to the integrity of elections. Closing polling stations forces some voters, disproportionately from minority or poor districts, to travel longer distances and wait in long lines to vote.

The only way to counter these measures is through massive citizen mobilization and electing leaders who prioritize the right to vote. In 2018, efforts to restrict voting rights overwhelmed a voter turnout that was the highest since 1914. In 2020, with the direction of the country at stake, another record turnout is crucial. The Democratic-led House of Representatives passed HR 1, a comprehensive election and democracy reform bill, but it remains stalled in the Republican-led Senate.

If voters can overcome the obstacles designed to make voting difficult and turn out in large numbers in 2020, fundamental democratic reform is poised to move forward.

Title: Senators Clash Over Immigration Reform Amid Boston Bombing Concerns

Article:

A heated debate erupted during a Senate hearing on immigration reform on Monday, with lawmakers from both sides of the aisle trading barbs over the proposed legislation. The discussion was sparked by concerns raised by the recent Boston Marathon bombings, which have led some to question the effectiveness of the current immigration system.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, a Democrat from Vermont, urged restraint in using the Boston bombings to slow or derail the immigration reform bill. He emphasized that the legislation would strengthen national security by allowing the focus on border security and enforcement efforts against those who would do harm.

However, Senator Chuck Grassley, a Republican from Iowa, took issue with Leahy's statement, accusing Democrats of exploiting the Boston bombings to push for immigration reform. He pointed to the Newtown, Connecticut, school shooting and the West, Texas, fertilizer plant explosion, saying that gun control advocates used those tragedies to push for stricter regulations.

The tension escalated when Senator Chuck Schumer, a Democrat from New York, suggested that opponents of the immigration reform bill were using the Boston bombings as an excuse to delay or derail the legislation. Senator Grassley became visibly agitated, interrupting Schumer and denying any involvement in using the Boston bombings as an excuse.

Senator Rand Paul, a Republican from Kentucky, sent a letter to Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, urging a delay in considering the immigration bill until more is learned about the alleged Boston bombers and the failures of the current immigration system. The White House dismissed Paul's concerns, stating that comprehensive immigration reform would enhance national security.

The hearing was the second by the Judiciary Committee on the 900-page proposal, with over 20 witnesses scheduled to testify. The bill, crafted by the "Gang of Eight," would prevent undocumented residents from gaining legal status if they have been found guilty of felonies or more than two misdemeanors. The full Senate is expected to consider the legislation in June, with a bipartisan group of legislators in the House of Representatives working on their own proposal.

Title: Obama's Immigration Executive Actions Move Forward, Despite Deportation Amnesty Halt

The Obama administration's immigration executive actions, announced exactly a year ago, are moving forward, despite the halt of the Deferred Action for Parental Accountability (DAPA) program. The latter, which aimed to grant full tentative legal status to over 4 million illegal immigrants, has been stalled by a federal appeals court and its fate will soon rest with the Supreme Court.

However, the remaining 11 actions, which include changes to the legal immigration system and enforcement priorities, are still advancing. These changes have resulted in a significant drop in arrests of illegal immigrants in the Southwest, with apprehensions at their lowest levels since the 1970s.

Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson has called for a more coordinated approach to border security, which has led to a focus on deporting serious criminals, gang members, and other security threats, rather than rank-and-file illegal immigrants. This shift has resulted in a decrease in deportations, with 230,000 deportations in fiscal year 2015, compared to nearly 410,000 in fiscal year 2012.

According to an estimate by the Migration Policy Institute, approximately 9.6 million of the estimated 11.5 million illegal immigrants in the country have no real danger of being deported, as they have been in the country for a long time and have not committed a serious crime. This number could increase if agents adhere strictly to the new priorities and consider mitigating factors, such as deep family or community ties.

Immigrant rights activists are still waiting for the application of these special circumstances to be applied more broadly. The changes have also led to a shift in the way immigration courts operate, with a focus on prioritizing cases involving serious criminals and security threats.

While the deportation amnesty was a key part of the executive actions, its delay and potential reversal have made the remaining changes less permanent and easier to undo. The fate of the deportation amnesty will soon be decided by the Supreme Court, while the rest of the executive actions continue to move forward.

Title: White House Launches Campaign to Refocus Attention on Obamacare Benefits

The White House is launching a three-week campaign to refocus attention on the benefits of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, as the December 23 enrollment deadline for January 1 coverage approaches. The campaign aims to rebuild confidence in the law among the public and Democratic allies on Capitol Hill, who had threatened to roll back aspects of Obamacare if the insurance marketplace didn't improve quickly.

The White House will take the lead in emphasizing a different benefit each day, which will be amplified through press events and social media by Democratic members of Congress, the Democratic National Committee, congressional campaign committees, and advocacy organizations. The daily message will highlight the law's benefits, such as lower costs for preventative care, protection for those with preexisting conditions, and slowing growth in health care costs.

The campaign is an attempt to get back to the game plan that Democrats wanted to pursue before the faulty website forced them into full-time damage control. The president needs to rebuild confidence in the law among the public and his Democratic allies on Capitol Hill, who have threatened to roll back aspects of Obamacare if the insurance marketplace didn't improve quickly.

The White House acknowledges that the HealthCare.gov website is still not working as smoothly as it should, but officials say they are making progress and will continue to make improvements. The renewed messaging push will run alongside efforts to make further repairs to the insurance marketplace and target key populations for enrollment.

The campaign is a political necessity for congressional Democrats, who will face voters in less than a year. Democrats wrote and passed the law in the face of unified Republican opposition, and if voters aren't aware of the law's upside or can't remember it amid all the problems with the rollout, Democrats will be holding onto an anchor rather than a buoy.

The focus on Obamacare benefits is a two-sided picture, with Democrats delivering benefits on one side and Republicans trying to deny them on the other. This is what polling says will help Democrats win.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell Files Cloture on Republican Police Reform Legislation

The Senate Majority Leader, Mitch McConnell, has filed cloture on the Republican police reform legislation, setting an official date for the vote. The legislation, which was introduced by Senator Tim Scott and McConnell, will require 60 votes to pass and would need seven or more Democratic votes to advance. The bill is a response to the killing of George Floyd and ongoing protests.

In a statement on the Senate floor, McConnell expressed hope that Senate Democrats will put aside "strange political calculations" and support the legislation. He emphasized that the bill will provide more information on no-knock warrants, anti-lynching legislation, and increased funding for body cameras.

Senator Tim Scott, who is leading the Republican effort to pass the legislation, highlighted the importance of understanding the 30,000 plus no-knock warrants that occur annually in the United States. The bill does not include a revision to qualified immunity, a key measure supported by Democrats.

The group of Republican senators who worked on the bill includes Senators Tim Scott, Lindsay Graham, Ben Sasse, James Lankford, John Cornyn, and Shelley Moore Capito. The legislation is expected to be voted on later this week.

Title: TSA's 95% Failure Rate in Airport Security Tests Raises Questions About Effectiveness of Screening Measures

The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has faced criticism after a recent "red team" test revealed that it missed 95% of guns and bombs at airport security checkpoints. While this failure rate is alarming, some experts argue that it may not be as concerning as it seems. The test was conducted at multiple airports and used realistic scenarios, making it difficult to argue that the results are isolated or unrealistic.

The TSA's annual budget is $7 billion, which some argue is excessive given the low risk of airplane terrorism.
