The agency's excuses for its failures, such as the results being specific to a single airport or not representative of real-world scenarios, have been debunked. The test results are consistent with anecdotal evidence that the TSA often misses weapons, with many people reporting that they have inadvertently carried knives or guns through airport security.

The reasons behind the high failure rate are unclear, but experts suggest that it may be due to the mundane nature of the job, with most alerts being false alarms, and the difficulty of remaining vigilant in such situations. Additionally, current screening technologies are not effective at detecting certain types of explosives, and some items allowed through security can be used as weapons.

Despite the failures, there have been no successful terrorist attacks against airplanes since 9/11, and experts argue that terrorists are much rarer than commonly believed. The data suggests that launching a terrorist plot is more difficult than many think, and that the risk of terrorism is low.

While some security measures are necessary to deter the stupid or impulsive, experts argue that the TSA's $7 billion budget is excessive and that the agency should focus on intelligence and investigation rather than trying to guess the next terrorist tactic and target. The real problem with airport security is that it is only effective if the terrorists target airplanes, and experts suggest that a more effective approach would be to focus on intelligence and investigation, rather than trying to outsmart the terrorists.

Title: Labor Secretary: US Economy Well-Positioned to Rebound After Coronavirus-Related Shutdowns

The US economy is "well-positioned" to rebound after the coronavirus-related economic shutdowns are lifted across the country, according to Labor Secretary Eugene Scalia. In an interview with "America's Newsroom," Scalia credited the country's "incredible productive capacity" for helping the country turn the corner in slowing the spread of the virus.

Scalia compared the country's response to the pandemic to the efforts during World War II, noting that the same type of effort is helping the country recover. He also highlighted the private sector's role in the response, citing the example of Rosie the Riveter, who played a crucial role in the war effort.

Meanwhile, private employers slashed 20.2 million jobs in April, according to the ADP National Employment Report released on Wednesday. This marks the largest decline on record since the survey started in 2002. Economists surveyed by Refinitiv expected a record 20.05 million job losses in the private sector.

The report likely still understates the actual damage inflicted by the stay-at-home measures, as the ADP study is only based on data collected through April 12. Since the virus outbreak gained a foothold in the US about two months ago, 30 million Americans have filed for first-time jobless benefits.

Job losses were concentrated heavily in the leisure and hospitality industry, with 8.6 million job losses, as bars and restaurants were forced to close. However, Labor Secretary Scalia expressed optimism that many of those who have lost their jobs will return to their positions once the economy reopens. According to Scalia, "somewhere near 90 percent of people who have gone on unemployment said that they expect to return to their jobs."

Title: Romney Criticizes Obama's Job Growth Record, Calls for Business-Friendly Policies

The Republican presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, has criticized the latest Labor Department report showing a decline in job growth in the United States, stating that President Obama has run out of ideas to create jobs. In an exclusive interview with Bret Baier of Fox News, Romney said that the report shows a continued pattern of job growth stagnation, with only 96,000 new jobs created in August and hundreds of thousands of people giving up on finding employment.

Romney attributed the decline to the Federal Reserve's lack of effective monetary policy and the need for business-friendly policies from the White House. He stated that the Federal Reserve has "shot its bullets" and that fiscal policies are the key to turning around the economy.

Romney also expressed disappointment with President Obama's speech at the Democratic National Convention, saying it lacked confidence and failed to address the country's economic woes. He noted that the unemployment rate has only decreased because many people have stopped looking for work, and that the labor force participation rate has hit a 31-year low.

Romney emphasized his own private sector experience and claimed that his five-point plan to create 12 million new jobs would be more effective than Obama's policies. He also rejected claims that his own speech in Tampa was short on specifics, stating that he outlined five steps to increase jobs and income for Americans.

The upcoming debates will provide an opportunity for Romney to draw a contrast between his vision and Obama's, as well as to clarify Democratic charges that he wanted American automakers to go bankrupt. Romney also rejected claims that he showed a disregard for service members by not mentioning U.S. troops in his acceptance speech.

With just 60 days to go until the election, Romney believes the choice will be clear for voters, stating that people will make up their minds based on whether they think the country is headed in the right direction.

Title: Obama to Campaign for Hillary Clinton, Focus on Intensity and Authenticity

The article reports that President Barack Obama is preparing to campaign for Hillary Clinton, focusing on reminding voters that he didn't always support her and encouraging them to come around to her side. According to Obama's 2008 campaign manager, David Plouffe, the imperative is to make voters feel as passionate about Clinton as they do about stopping Donald Trump. The article highlights Obama's message, which will emphasize the strong and optimistic case for a future President Clinton and why she presents the best chance to succeed him.

The article also notes that Obama will not stop mocking and trolling Trump, but will focus on making the case for Clinton's presidency. White House communications director Jen Psaki stated that Obama will spend most of his time making the strong, optimistic case for the country under a future President Clinton, and why she presents the best chance to be his successor.

The article also mentions that Obama's message is being led out of the West Wing, while the conversations about schedules and logistics are being led out of Brooklyn. The article notes that Obama's popularity will be capitalized on, taking him beyond his normal coalition appeals to young people, African-Americans, and Latinos into places like Iowa and Colorado.

The article also highlights the limited communication between the White House and the Clinton campaign, with only a few points of contact to minimize leaks and potential legal issues. The article notes that Obama's political director, David Simas, and Clinton campaign manager, Robby Mook, talk frequently, but that's about it.

Title: Trump Leads in Florida and Ohio Primaries, Rubio Trails in Home State

Article:

A new poll has shown that Senator Marco Rubio is trailing Donald Trump badly in his home state of Florida, with Trump holding a double-digit lead. The Marist/NBC/Wall Street Journal poll shows Trump with 43% of the vote, while Rubio trails with 22%. Meanwhile, Senator Ted Cruz is essentially tied with Rubio at 21%. In Ohio, Governor John Kasich is locked in a tight race with Trump, with Kasich holding a slight edge at 39% to Trump's 33%.

The primaries in Ohio and Florida are crucial for both Kasich and Rubio, as they are both significantly trailing Trump and Cruz in the delegate count. Rubio's drop in the polls suggests that his campaign may be nearing its end.

Rubio has been critical of the violence at Trump's rallies, saying that both the candidate and protesters share the blame. He has also acknowledged that some protesters appeared to be paid. The CBS News 2016 Battleground Tracker poll showed Rubio falling further behind Trump, with Trump maintaining his lead in the winner-take-all primary.

In Ohio, Trump and Kasich are in a dead heat, with Trump and Kasich tied at 33% each, according to the YouGov poll. Cruz trails at 27%, and Rubio at 5%. Kasich faces a similar situation as Rubio, needing to win in his home state to keep his campaign alive.

The delegate count shows Trump leading with 460 delegates, followed by Cruz with 370, Rubio with 163, and Kasich with 63. The three other states holding primaries on Tuesday are North Carolina, Missouri, and Illinois, with Trump leading in all three states.

On the Democratic side, Hillary Clinton has a big lead in Florida over Bernie Sanders, 62-34%, according to the CBS poll. However, she leads Sanders by single digits in Ohio, 52-43%, and Sanders has a narrow 48-46% lead in Illinois.

Title: State Department Criticized for Lack of Systematic Approach to Security Risk Management

The State Department has been criticized for lacking a systematic approach to managing security risks at foreign diplomatic missions, according to a report released by the department's internal auditor. The report, conducted by the Office of Inspector General (OIG), found that the department does not have a conceptual framework or process for risk management, and that there is no one person or office specifically tasked to oversee the assessment of risk in critical, high-threat locations.

The report also addressed claims made by prominent Republicans, including Representative Darrell E. Issa, that the Obama administration-appointed panel that investigated the 2012 Benghazi attacks was tainted by political tampering and failed to hold anyone accountable for security failures surrounding the incident. The OIG found that the Accountability Review Board (ARB) process operates independently and without bias, and that the department's response to the Benghazi ARB "establishes a model for how the Department should handle future ARB recommendations."

The report did, however, criticize the State Department for not fully implementing the recommendations made by the ARB, including boosting U.S. assets at high-risk posts where host countries are incapable or unwilling to protect U.S. missions. The report noted that while the department's standards reflect the quality of construction of posts, they do not address "minimum security standards for occupancy or address requirements beyond construction standards."

The report credited Secretary of State Hillary Clinton for taking a direct role in implementing the Benghazi ARB recommendations and said that Secretary John Kerry is following through. The report concluded that the Benghazi ARB recommendations, when implemented, should significantly improve the department's ability to provide better security for U.S. diplomatic missions and employees.

Title: Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush Proposes Immigration Overhaul with Legalized Status for Undocumented Immigrants

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, in his new book "Immigration Wars" co-authored with Clint Bolick, has proposed an overhaul of the US immigration system, aiming to make it easier for undocumented immigrants to gain legal residency without a path to citizenship. Bush suggests that those who want to become citizens could return to their country of origin and apply.

According to Bush, the proposal would allow undocumented immigrants to pay a fine or perform community service to gain legal status, ensuring they do not commit serious crimes. Over time, they could live a life of dignity without becoming citizens. Those who want to become citizens would need to return to their country of origin and apply.

Bolick, a lawyer and director of the Goldwater Institute's Scharf-Norton Center for Constitutional Litigation, believes the proposal would increase the number of people who can immigrate to the United States for work. He notes that the current system prioritizes family ties over skills and education, with two-thirds of immigrants entering the country through family preferences.

Bush, often mentioned as a potential presidential candidate, emphasized the need for Republicans to propose alternative solutions to current immigration policies. He believes that opposing policies without offering alternatives can lead to a downward spiral.

The proposal also addresses the issue of spending and entitlement reform, with Bush advocating for a combination of spending restraint and reform of the entitlement system. He believes that the president should be transparent about their plan and engage with the public to find common ground.

When asked about his potential presidential bid, Bush stated that he is not running yet and will decide in the future.

Title: Putin's Endorsement of Trump: A Masterclass in Statecraft

Article:

Christian Whiton, a former deputy special envoy for human rights in North Korea under the George W. Bush administration, has written an article for CNN discussing Vladimir Putin's endorsement of Donald Trump. Putin, the Russian president, has called Trump the "absolute leader" of the US presidential race, praising his "lively" and "talented" nature.

Whiton suggests that Putin's endorsement is not a random occurrence, but rather a calculated move to exploit Trump's character flaws and self-delusion about Russia's intentions. Putin, a former KGB intelligence officer, knows that identifying and exploiting character weaknesses is a key aspect of statecraft. He has successfully done so with previous US presidents, including George W. Bush and Barack Obama, who underestimated his intentions and were taken in by his charm.

Putin's endorsement of Trump is likely motivated by the Russian president's desire to expand his sphere of influence and assert Russia's dominance over the West. Trump's self-referential and self-delusional nature makes him an ideal target for Putin's manipulation. Trump's willingness to praise Putin's leadership and his desire for closer relations with Russia are music to Putin's ears.

Whiton notes that Trump's approach to politics is reminiscent of a reality TV show, with a focus on spectacle and showmanship. Putin, a master of showmanship himself, likely sees Trump as a kindred spirit. The Russian president has a history of using flattery to get what he wants, and Trump's ego is no exception.

In conclusion, Putin's endorsement of Trump is a masterclass in statecraft, demonstrating his ability to identify and exploit character flaws to achieve his goals. As Whiton notes, it's a reminder that everything is showbiz, and Putin is a master of the game.

Title: Early Voting Surges in Nevada and Across the Country

As the United States approaches its presidential election, a record number of Americans are casting their ballots early. According to the Pew Research Center, over 34 million votes have been cast so far, with the total expected to surpass 50 million by Election Day. This surge in early voting is a trend that has been building over the past few decades, with 37 states and the District of Columbia now allowing some form of early voting.

For some voters, the convenience of early voting is a major draw. "People want to choose the most convenient thing, especially if they're anticipating long lines" on Election Day, says David Damore, a professor of political science at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. Others see it as a way to fulfill their civic duty and make their voices heard. "We're fortunate to get to do it on the clock," says Belinda, a hotel employee who voted early with her coworkers.

The trend of early voting has been around since the Civil War, when Republicans pushed for legislation to allow servicemen to cast their votes while away from their home states. However, it wasn't until the 1970s that early voting for convenience took shape, with the introduction of absentee ballots and vote-by-mail systems. Today, states like Nevada and Colorado have seen nearly half of their total electorate cast their votes five days before the election.

Some analysts believe that the surge in early voting may be a sign that Americans are taking their role in the electoral process more seriously. "The importance of the outcome looms over most people," says Damore. "That may not fire enthusiasm, but it becomes important to people to participate." Others see it as a way to avoid the hassle of Election Day crowds, particularly in a race as volatile as this one.

For some, the chance to vote early simply means an easy way to fulfill a sense of obligation. "It was very fast. I thought it was going to be more difficult," says Raul Sanchez, a first-time voter who was inspired to participate by a desire to see someone other than Donald Trump win the White House.

Title: Democrats Weigh In on Border Wall Demolition as Beto O'Rourke's Comments Spark Debate

Article:

In the wake of Beto O'Rourke's statement that he "absolutely" supports tearing down existing barriers along the southern border with Mexico, other Democratic presidential hopefuls are being asked to weigh in on the issue. O'Rourke, a former Texas congressman and potential 2020 candidate, made the comment during an interview with MSNBC host Chris Hayes, stating that he would take down the existing wall if given the chance.

Since then, several other Democrats have expressed openness to the idea, including New York Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, who told Fox News that she could support tearing down the wall if it "makes sense" and "if it's done for a reason." Gillibrand's statement was met with skepticism from Republicans, who see the issue as a way to paint Democrats as extreme and pro-open borders.

Other Democrats, such as Texas Representative Veronica Escobar, have also expressed reservations about the effectiveness of border walls, stating that they "don't work" and are "monuments to division." However, not all Democrats are on board with the idea of tearing down existing walls. House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, D-Md., has rejected the notion, stating that border walls "obviously" work in some areas and should not be removed.

The debate has sparked a heated discussion among politicians and the public, with some Republicans using O'Rourke's comments to label Democrats as "the party of open borders." The issue is likely to remain a contentious topic as the 2020 presidential election approaches, with both sides vying for public opinion and political advantage.

**Supreme Court Weighs President Obama's Deportation Amnesty**

The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday regarding President Obama's deportation amnesty, with conservative justices questioning the president's authority to grant temporary legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants. The case, United States v. Texas, has sparked intense debate and political polarization, with Hispanic activists rallying outside the courthouse and vowing political retribution if the court rules against the president.

The Obama administration argues that the president has the authority to defer deportation and offer work permits to certain undocumented immigrants, citing previous presidents who have taken similar actions. Liberal justices, including Justice Sonia Sotomayor, argue that the president's actions are in line with past practices and are necessary to address the humanitarian crisis at the border.

Conservative justices, however, are concerned that the president is overstepping his authority and encroaching on Congress's lawmaking powers. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, often a swing vote on the court, questioned where the president derived the power to grant temporary legal status.

The case has drawn intense interest from Congress, with Democrats and Republicans filing opposing briefs. The court's decision is expected to have significant political implications, with Hispanic leaders vowing to rally their community to punish Republicans for their stance on illegal immigration.

A tie decision is possible, with eight justices on the bench after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia. A tie would leave in place the ruling of the lower appeals court, which decided 2-1 that the Obama administration's amnesty violated immigration law. The court's decision is expected to be announced in the coming months.

Title: Clinton Turns to Animal Impersonations to Fact-Check Republican Claims in Nevada Caucuses

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has taken an unorthodox approach to fact-checking Republican claims, using animal impersonations to emphasize the importance of accuracy in political discourse. Speaking before a crowd in Reno, Nevada, Clinton recalled a radio ad featuring a dog that barks every time a candidate makes an untrue statement. She then demonstrated the concept by yelping "Arf! Arf! Arf! Arf!" to general applause.

As the Nevada caucuses approach this Saturday, Clinton and her opponent, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, have been crisscrossing the state. Sanders' campaign has gained momentum, with over 100 staffers on the ground and a significant increase in paid staff and television ad spending. Clinton, meanwhile, has skipped a campaign event in Florida to focus on Nevada, sending her husband, former President Bill Clinton, to campaign in her stead.

Sanders has pinned his hopes on voter turnout in Nevada, stating that if people come out in large numbers on caucus day, he believes he will win. However, it is possible for a candidate to win the caucuses but lose the battle for Democratic National Convention delegates, as Clinton did in 2008 against then-Senator Barack Obama.

The Clinton campaign may have inadvertently stirred controversy with comments made by campaign spokesman Brian Fallon, who compared Nevada to Iowa and New Hampshire, stating that the state is 80% white voters. This remark reportedly angered allies of Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid, who pushed to move Nevada near the front of the primary calendar due to its diversity.

Title: Pompeo Criticizes Secret Meeting Between Democratic Senators and Iranian Foreign Minister

Article:

United States Secretary of State Mike Pompeo expressed skepticism and criticism towards a recent report that several Democratic senators secretly met with Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif during the Munich Security Conference. Pompeo stated that Zarif is designated by the United States for sponsoring terrorism and has been involved in the downing of a commercial airliner, killing 176 innocent people.

Pompeo did not specify which senators were involved in the meeting, but noted that he hopes they were reinforcing American foreign policy and not their own. The news of the alleged secret meeting was first reported by Mollie Hemingway at The Federalist, citing a source briefed by the French delegation to the conference.

Senator Chris Murphy of Connecticut was confirmed to have met with Zarif in Munich, but his office did not respond to requests for comment. Zarif was designated for sanctions by the Treasury Department last summer for sponsoring terrorism around the world.

Senator Murphy and other Democrats have repeatedly worked to preserve the Iranian Nuclear Agreement, which the United States officially left in 2018. Former Secretary of State John Kerry, who has been openly undermining United States foreign policy since President Trump took office in 2017, was also seen with Zarif in Munich.

The commercial airliner that Pompeo referred to had 176 innocent people on board from Iran, Canada, Ukraine, Sweden, Afghanistan, Germany, and Great Britain. The Iranian government initially denied responsibility for the crash, blaming engine failure, before later admitting to shooting down the plane.

Title: Free Trade Loses Favor Among Voters in Presidential Election

The 2016 presidential election has seen a significant shift in public opinion towards free trade, with a growing number of voters viewing it as an economic drag on the United States, rather than a job creator. This change in sentiment has been observed across both Democratic and Republican primary voters, with a majority of Republicans opposing free trade and a significant portion of Democrats also expressing skepticism.

According to exit polling, only a third of Republican primary voters in Wisconsin believe that free trade spawns American jobs, while 54% believe it costs the country jobs. Among Democratic primary voters, the numbers are split, with 41% saying free trade helps jobs and 42% saying it costs the country jobs. Similar results have been seen in other states, including Illinois and Mississippi.

The shift towards protectionism is attributed to the downward pressure on Americans' earnings in recent years, regardless of political party. The tough economic times and a ready target in trade have pushed both parties' presidential fields towards protectionism, with four of the five remaining candidates opposing the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a massive 12-nation deal signed by President Obama.

Businessman Donald Trump, who is leading the Republican race, has threatened to rip up not only the TPP but also previous deals such as the North American Free Trade Agreement. This has forced Senator Ted Cruz, his closest competitor, to adopt a stiffer stance on the issue. In the Democratic race, Senator Bernie Sanders has made his opposition to trade deals over the past two decades a chief selling point, and front-runner Hillary Clinton has played a feverish game of catch-up, recanting her previous glowing praise for TPP.

Only Ohio Governor John Kasich remains a defender of the TPP among the Republican candidates. Economists can calculate the benefits to the overall U.S. economy from trade and say there is little question that it does help. However, that does little to comfort those who lose out, and those are the voices to which the candidates are responding.

The near-uniform opposition at the top of the ticket this year could doom the chances for trade deals for years to come, although some analysts say there is a brief opening this year, with both President Obama and House Speaker Paul D. Ryan supporters of a deal while still in office and seeing their window of opportunity closing.

Title: Attorney General William Barr Skips House Hearing, Escalating Tensions with Congress

Article:

Attorney General William Barr skipped a House hearing on Thursday, sparking a confrontation between the Trump administration and the House of Representatives. The hearing was intended to focus on the Russian interference in the 2016 election and Barr's handling of the special counsel Robert Mueller's report. However, Barr refused to testify, citing concerns over the committee's decision to add an hour of questions from staff lawyers.

The move is the latest escalation of tensions between the Trump administration and the House, which has opened wide-ranging investigations into the president. The administration has announced plans to fight lawmakers' demands for information and has gone to court to block some of them.

House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler accused the Trump administration of ignoring subpoenas and refusing to testify, saying it reflects an effort to prevent Congress from providing any check on the president's actions. Nadler warned that if Congress fails to stand up to the administration, it risks losing its ability to hold any future president accountable.

The hearing was marked by a lack of cooperation from the Trump administration, with Barr not attending and the Justice Department refusing to provide an unredacted version of the Mueller report to Congress. The department cited concerns over grand jury testimony, information about pending cases, intelligence gathering secrets, and information that could infringe on the privacy of individuals not charged.

Congressional Democrats have insisted they deserve to receive the full report and underlying information gathered during the 22-month investigation. The Justice Department has refused to provide the unredacted report, citing a lack of legislative purpose for the request.

The confrontation has sparked a debate over the role of Congress in investigating the president and the administration's refusal to cooperate. The House Judiciary Committee has threatened to hold Barr in contempt and may subpoena him to testify. The committee has also tentatively scheduled special counsel Robert Mueller to testify on May 15.

Title: Senate Cloture Vote on Budget Deal May Be Less About the Budget Than Internal GOP Politics

The upcoming cloture vote on the short-term budget compromise in the Senate may not be as much about the budget deal itself as it is about internal Republican politics. The 14 Republicans on the Appropriations Committee are the key to the vote, with six of them facing reelection in 2014. However, more than enough Republicans have already expressed support for the deal, making it likely that Democrats will reach the 60-vote threshold needed to pass the bill.

The vote is significant because it would reset the Budget Control Act with more manageable caps on discretionary spending for fiscal 2014 and 2015, allowing the Appropriations Committee to regain its relevance. The committee has been working on 12 fiscal 2014 spending bills, and the deal would allow them to package them together in a single omnibus package in January.

However, the vote is also seen as a test of internal Republican politics, particularly within the Appropriations Committee. Sen. Richard Shelby (R-Ala.) is opposed to the deal, which could help him become the chair of the committee if the GOP regains the Senate in the 2014 elections. Shelby's opposition is seen as a courtesy to his fellow Alabaman, Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.), who is fiercely against the budget plan.

The vote is also seen as a test of Sen. Thad Cochran's (R-Miss.) leadership, as he is seeking reelection and could potentially become the chair of the committee if the GOP regains the Senate. Cochran's decision to seek reelection means he could potentially challenge Shelby for the chairmanship.

The contrast between the House and Senate Republicans is stark, with the House Appropriations Committee voting overwhelmingly in favor of the deal. The seven Republicans on the House committee from states represented by Republicans on the Senate Appropriations Committee also voted in favor of the deal.

Title: Republican Memo Fails to Clear Trump of Collusion or Obstruction Allegations

The recently released Republican memo has failed to provide any new information that would clear President Trump of allegations of collusion with Russia or obstruction of justice, according to experts and officials. The memo, which was released by House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes, claims that the FBI's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election was based on a dossier compiled by former British intelligence officer Christopher Steele, which was funded by the Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton's campaign.

However, the memo has been met with skepticism by Democrats, who have denounced it as a tactic to undermine the investigation and protect Trump. They have also pointed out several errors and omissions in the memo, including the fact that it does not provide any new information that would contradict the findings of the special counsel's investigation.

The memo also claims that the FBI was more forthcoming with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) than previously thought, but this has been disputed by Democrats. According to people familiar with the Democratic memo, the FBI did not name the Democratic National Committee or Hillary Clinton's campaign in its application for a warrant to surveil Carter Page, a former Trump campaign adviser who was under investigation for his ties to Russia.

The FBI had suspected that Page was acting as a Russian agent, and the memo does not provide any new information that would contradict this assessment. The New York Times has filed a motion to unseal all materials related to the wiretap of Page, including the FBI's application for the warrant and other court documents.

Title: House Republicans Unveil Replacement Plan for Affordable Care Act, but Challenges Ahead

House Republicans have unveiled a replacement plan for the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, which aims to repeal and replace the healthcare law. The plan, called the American Health Care Act, generally follows GOP principles and repeals the individual and employer insurance mandates, which Republicans see as interference in personal health-care choices and markets. The plan also overhauls Medicaid, federally supported health care for the poor, which many Republicans see as too costly.

The plan provides tax credits for individuals to purchase their own policies and allows states to manage Medicaid funding. However, independent analysts say the repeal-and-replace plan shows just how difficult it is to have "insurance for everybody" and health-care benefits that "beautifully" cover people, all while reducing costs.

The plan is expected to be a difficult lift, with some analysts estimating that 8 million to 12 million fewer people would be covered under the GOP plan, compared to the ACA, which added coverage for more than 20 million people. The Congressional Budget Office has yet to report on the plan's costs or its effect on the number of insured.

The plan is also facing opposition from both conservative and moderate Republicans, with some viewing the tax credits as a new "entitlement" program and others saying they are too meager to help low-income Americans. The plan is also expected to face opposition from Democratic governors and senators who expanded Medicaid under Obamacare.

The plan's key provisions include:

* Dropping the individual and employer mandates by repealing their penalties immediately and retroactively to 2016
* Replacing subsidies that help low-income Americans buy private insurance plans on federal insurance market exchanges with tax credits that could be applied to private plans
* Funding Medicaid expansion fully, but only through 2019, after which the funding would decline
* Continuing popular parts of Obamacare, such as allowing young adults to stay on their parents' health insurance until age 26 and prohibiting denial of coverage for a preexisting condition

The plan will "drive down costs, encourage competition, and give every American access to quality, affordable health insurance," said House Speaker Paul Ryan. However, Democrats strenuously disagree, even as premiums have dramatically risen and choices declined in many Obamacare insurance markets.

The plan will now face a difficult path to passage, with Republicans needing to muscle through the plan on their own using a budget process known as "reconciliation" that requires only a majority vote for passage in both houses of Congress.

Title: Democrats Tone Down "Blue Wave" Predictions Amid Tighter Midterm Election Outlook

Article:

As the midterm elections approach, top Democrats are tempering expectations about a potential "blue wave" sweeping the party into power on Capitol Hill. Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez and Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders have expressed caution about the likelihood of a Democratic victory, citing a tight race for control of Congress.

Perez stated that he does not use the term "blue wave" to describe a possible Democratic victory, instead emphasizing the importance of "blocking and tackling" and "organizing" to win elections. Sanders, an independent who ran for president in 2016 as a Democrat, also cast doubt on the "wave" narrative, predicting a very close election with a handful of votes determining whether Democrats gain control of the House.

The cautious comments come as the midterm landscape reflects a Republican advantage in the Senate and a tough fight for control of the House, with a handful of races potentially determining the outcome. The Republican National Committee Chairwoman, Ronna McDaniel, expressed confidence that the GOP can hold the Senate and has a shot at retaining control of the House.

In contrast, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi expressed optimism about a Democratic victory, stating that if the election were held today, Democrats would win the majority. However, a recent NBC News-Wall Street Journal poll found that the Democratic advantage has ebbed, with the party holding a 7-point lead over the GOP, down from a 12-point lead in September.

Early voting in certain states has offered positive signs for Democrats, but the poll suggests that the race is tightening. The Cook Political Report rates many districts as competitive, with Democrats and Republicans neck and neck on the question of which party should control Congress.

Title: Manafort's Trial to Begin: Former Trump Campaign Chairman Faces 18 Criminal Counts

The trial of Paul Manafort, former Trump campaign chairman, is set to commence on Tuesday in Alexandria, Virginia. Manafort is facing 18 criminal counts, including bank and tax fraud, which could result in up to 30 years in prison. He has pleaded not guilty to all charges.

The charges stem from Manafort's lobbying work in Ukraine on behalf of politicians with ties to Russia. Prosecutors allege that he was paid over $60 million for his work, which included support for former Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych. Instead of paying taxes on the income, prosecutors claim he used it to fund a lavish lifestyle, including three homes, a $21,000 watch, a $105,000 car, and New York Yankees season tickets.

The trial is expected to present around 500 pieces of evidence and up to 35 witnesses, including Manafort's former business associate Rick Gates, who was charged alongside him but pleaded guilty and cooperated with the special counsel's team.

Manafort's work as a Ukrainian political operative occurred nearly a decade before he took over the Trump campaign in mid-2016. He organized the Republican convention in July 2016 but quit the Trump team a month later. Prosecutors have said they will not present evidence of Russian collusion during the trial, but have claimed they have the authority to prosecute Manafort under a May 2017 order by Deputy Attorney Rod Rosenstein.

Manafort's attorneys have attacked the order, claiming that Mueller exceeded his authority. District Judge T.S. Ellis III, overseeing the Virginia trial, denied their motion, holding that Mueller's mandate authorizes him to pursue charges in this case.

The Virginia trial is the first of two that Manafort will face this year, with a September trial scheduled in Washington, D.C. on charges of failing to register as a foreign agent and making false statements to investigators.

Title: Candidates Make Final Push with Limited Opportunities to Shift the Election

Article:

With only two weeks left until the 2012 presidential election, both Mitt Romney and President Barack Obama are making their closing arguments to sway undecided voters. The campaigns are relying on powerful turnout operations and resonant messages to tip the race in their favor. As the candidates exchange charges and counter-charges following the final debate, here's a breakdown of what they said, what they meant, and what it tells us about the state of the race.

Obama's recent TV ad and policy booklet aim to quash criticism of his thin second-term agenda. The ad presents a list of priorities, including education, manufacturing, and energy, which are not new ideas but presented in a more organized and accessible way. Obama's senior adviser, David Axelrod, stated that the new tactics are not a reaction to criticism but a reflection of the campaign being in the closing argument phase.

Romney's campaign, on the other hand, is focusing on building confidence in the Republican candidate's ability to lead the country. Romney spokesman Kevin Madden said that swing voters were asking themselves if Romney passes the "commander-in-chief test" after the foreign policy debate, and that he gave voters a sense of confidence in his plan for the next four years.

With few opportunities left to make a significant impact, both campaigns are relying on their existing strategies to sway undecided voters. The outcome of the election will depend on which side can execute their plans most effectively.

Title: White House Rejects Boehner's "Plan B" to Avert Fiscal Crisis

The White House has rejected House Speaker John Boehner's proposal for a "Plan B" to avert the looming fiscal crisis, which Boehner's office described as "defying common sense." The plan, introduced by Boehner on Tuesday, would raise taxes only on households making more than $1 million, while also cutting entitlements and proposing a tax reform debate next year.

The White House Press Secretary, Jay Carney, stated that the plan "doesn't ask enough of the very wealthiest in taxes and instead shifts the burden to the middle class and seniors," and cannot pass the Senate. In response, Boehner's spokesman, Brendan Buck, accused the President of "moving the goal posts" and threatening every American family with higher taxes.

Boehner's "Plan B" could be a failsafe option in case he is unable to secure the votes to pass any future deal struck with the White House. However, it could also be aimed at spurring Obama to compromise a bit more. A Boehner aide said the speaker is "hopeful an agreement will be reached," but complained that the president's latest counteroffer includes $1.3 trillion in revenue increases and "only" $850 billion in spending cuts.

The plan has received mixed reviews from Republican House members, while Democratic leaders have expressed swift opposition. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's office called the plan "the farthest thing from a balanced approach" and said it "will not protect middle-class families because it cannot pass both Houses of Congress." House Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer described it as a "political ploy" and urged Democratic members to vote against it.

The fiscal crisis is looming, with taxes set to rise on everyone on January 1, followed by a wave of spending cuts. Without a deal, tax rates will rise for everyone, with middle-income families facing a roughly $2,000 increase next year. Capital gains and dividends rates would also go up, and long-term unemployment aid would expire. With a deal, most Americans would likely be spared major tax increases, but those making above a certain threshold could still be hit, depending on what both sides agree to.

Title: US Health Care Spending to Increase Slightly Over Next Decade, According to New Estimate

The United States is expected to spend slightly more on health care over the next decade than it would have without the Affordable Care Act (ACA), according to a new estimate released by the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS). The agency projects that the ACA will add $478 billion to health care costs over the next decade, driving up average spending by one-tenth of a percent faster than if the law had never been passed.

The CMS estimate suggests that health care spending will continue to grow at unusually low levels in the next year due to the slow economic recovery. However, spending growth will spike in 2014, jumping from 3.8 percent in 2013 to 7.4 percent in 2014 as major provisions of the ACA go into effect. Growth will remain higher for several years as millions of Americans obtain health coverage with the help of insurance exchanges, federal subsidies, and expanded Medicaid programs.

By 2021, federal, state, and local governments will make up nearly 50 percent of all health spending in the US, up from 46 percent in 2011. Republicans have criticized the report, saying it shows that the ACA has failed to reduce health care costs as promised. However, the administration has defended the law, citing the expected reduction in out-of-pocket expenses for Americans, particularly on prescription drugs.

The projections have changed little from last summer, when the CMS first projected that the ACA would drive health care spending up slightly in the next decade. The administration has shrugged off the data, saying that the law only appears to raise spending because it is measured against unusually low recent growth rates during the economic recession.

Key provisions in the ACA, such as bringing more healthy Americans into insurance pools, allowing Medicare to experiment with new "bundled payment" methods, and cutting down on emergency room visits by mandating coverage for everyone, could help control spending further. However, it remains to be seen whether these measures will be enough to bend the cost curve in future decades. The newly insured population will be younger and healthier than those currently insured, and they are expected to drive up the demand for prescription drugs and doctors. This could be a good sign for reducing spending in the long term, as patients who regularly visit the doctor and practice preventative medicine can avoid more expensive health problems in the future.

Title: The US Must Get the Sanctions Narrative Right in Iran Nuclear Talks

The ongoing negotiations between the United States and Iran over the Iranian nuclear program require a nuanced understanding of the complex domestic politics within the Islamic Republic of Iran. The US must avoid the trap of assuming that Iran's participation in talks is solely a result of economic pressure and sanctions. Instead, it is crucial to recognize the role of the 2013 presidential election and the emergence of President Hassan Rouhani, which led to a shift in Iran's foreign policy.

Sanctions did play a part in the transformation of the balance of power within the Iranian political system, but not as a direct cause of Iran's return to the negotiating table. Rather, sanctions contributed to a pre-existing transformation that had begun in 2009, prior to the current sanctions regime. The sanctions helped to perpetuate a divide within the conservative forces of the Iranian establishment over the economy, ultimately paving the way for Rouhani's victory.

The election of Rouhani, not sanctions, was the key to Iran's shift on foreign policy and nuclear negotiations. The success of his administration and the coalition alliance is critical for reaching a mutually beneficial deal on the nuclear program and advancing a more moderate and inclusive Iran. However, the persistence of sanctions without meaningful relief or significant incentives will undermine the Rouhani administration and inhibit the potential for a resolution.

The US and its partners must get the sanctions narrative right to avoid undermining the new government in power. While sanctions contributed to an ongoing realignment of political factions, they alone did not bring Iran to the negotiating table. The US would be best served to devise a meaningful incentives package with an eye on the domestic Iranian political scene, rather than increasing sanctions on Iran.

Title: Senate and White House Negotiations on Continuing Resolution Remain Unclear

The ongoing negotiations between the Senate and the White House over a continuing resolution (C.R.) to fund parts of the government at current levels have reached a stalemate. The current offer on the table is a one-year C.R., which would delay the fight over government funding and allow for a temporary extension of current spending levels.

Some Republican lawmakers have suggested a two-week C.R. that would push the battle into early January, allowing them to shift some of the blame onto the incoming Democratic House majority. However, the White House has reportedly not been keen on this option.

The administration's hard-liner, Stephen Miller, stated on "Face the Nation" that a shutdown was "absolutely" on the table if a deal is not reached. President Trump also tweeted that a wall is vital for "good Border Security." However, by Tuesday, the president had reversed course and begun searching for a way out of the situation, while still trying to avoid appearing to cave.

The press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, said the president would be open to a bipartisan compromise similar to one hammered out by Senate appropriators earlier this year, which included $1.6 billion for fortifying existing barriers. The rest of the $5 billion could be siphoned from other agencies, an idea that prompted immediate blowback from Democrats.

Lawmakers from both parties agree that some kind of continuing resolution is still the most likely way forward, but what exactly the president would agree to remains unclear. The president's plan, if he has one, is still unclear, and his press secretary refused to provide any clarity at a press briefing on Tuesday afternoon.

The standoff is a classic example of the president's negotiating style, which involves making the other side blink and signaling that he will do whatever it takes to get his way, even if he ultimately winds up capitulating.

Title: Clinton Campaign Insists It Won't Be Derailed by FBI Announcement

The Hillary Clinton campaign is confident that it will not be significantly impacted by the recent FBI announcement regarding her private email server, despite the renewed investigation being a major talking point in the final week of the presidential race. The campaign has built a robust infrastructure and has been focused on getting out the vote, with a strong emphasis on early voting and absentee balloting.

According to early voting statistics, Clinton's campaign is seeing strong turnout in key battleground states, with Democrats outpacing Republicans in states like Florida and Nevada. The campaign believes that this momentum will carry over to Election Day, despite the FBI's renewed probe.

Clinton's campaign has been adamant that the FBI's announcement is unprecedented and that there is nothing new to be discovered. They have been critical of FBI Director James Comey's decision to reopen the investigation so close to the election, calling it "pretty strange" and "deeply troubling."

Meanwhile, Trump's campaign is celebrating the news, with Trump himself calling Comey's decision "brave" and saying that it will help to "bring back his reputation." The Trump campaign has been criticized for not seizing on Clinton's vulnerabilities, but Clinton's campaign believes that voters have had plenty of time to digest the contrasting choices in the election.

Clinton's campaign has been focused on getting out the vote, with a strong emphasis on early voting and absentee balloting. They believe that this will be crucial in driving up turnout on Election Day.

Title: Trump Mocks Impeachment Effort, Promises Reelection in Pennsylvania Visit

Article:

President Donald Trump visited Pennsylvania on Tuesday, where he mocked the Democratic impeachment effort and promised his reelection in 2020. Trump called the impeachment process "impeachment lite" and claimed it would lead to his victory in the next election. He also touted his administration's achievements, including the killing of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the creation of the Space Force, and a strong economy.

Trump's comments came as House Democrats unveiled two articles of impeachment, charging him with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The articles stem from Trump's request that Ukraine investigate his political rival, former Vice President Joe Biden, and his efforts to impede Congress's investigation into the matter.

Trump's visit to Pennsylvania was seen as an attempt to rally supporters in a key swing state. Pennsylvania was a crucial state in the 2016 election, with Trump winning the state and its 20 electoral votes by a narrow margin. The state is expected to be a battleground in the 2020 election, with Trump's visit aimed at boosting his support among working-class whites and rural voters.

Trump also addressed the long-awaited release of the Justice Department report into the 2016 Russia investigation, which found that the FBI was justified in opening its investigation into ties between the Trump presidential campaign and Russia. Trump claimed the report showed "outrageous, scandalous and unprecedented abuses of power" and called FBI agents "scum."

Title: Breitbart's Traffic Plummets: A Sharp Decline in Web Traffic Since Trump's Inauguration

Breitbart News, a conservative news website, experienced a significant decline in web traffic since the inauguration of President Donald Trump in January 2017. According to Alexa.com, a web-ranking analytics company, Breitbart's traffic dropped from being the 29th most trafficked site in the United States in January to 59th in May. This decline is in stark contrast to the site's earlier claims of rapid growth and surpassing major news outlets like Fox News, Huffington Post, and Buzzfeed.

In January 2017, Breitbart's CEO, Larry Solov, boasted that the site had surpassed these news outlets in traffic, citing Alexa.com rankings. However, just a few months later, the numbers tell a different story. According to Alexa.com, Fox News is now the 64th most-trafficked site, while Huffington Post is at 60, and Buzzfeed is at 50. The Washington Post, known for its investigative reporting, has seen a significant increase in traffic, ranking 41st.

ComScore, another web-analytics company, also reported a significant decline in Breitbart's traffic. In November 2016, the site had nearly 23 million unique visitors, but by April 2017, that number had dropped to 10.7 million, a 53% decline. In contrast, the four sites that Breitbart benchmarked itself against saw relatively stable or increasing traffic.

The traffic graph on Alexa.com shows a sharp decline in Breitbart's traffic around April 30, Trump's 100-day mark. An Alexa customer representative suggested that the traffic anomalies could be attributed to Breitbart enabling and disabling its certified-results feature, which created an apples-to-oranges comparison with sites that don't enable the feature.

Other conservative media sites, such as National Review Online, Infowars.com, The Daily Caller, and Drudge Report, have also experienced declines in traffic in recent months. Fox News, a major competitor to Breitbart, saw a slight drop in viewership during the same period, but still remains a top-ranked news site.

The decline in Breitbart's traffic raises questions about the site's ability to maintain its audience and relevance in the post-election landscape.

Title: Vice President's Office Defends Trump's Tweets by Drawing Contrast Between Elaine Chao and Ilhan Omar

The office of Vice President Mike Pence has responded to criticism of President Donald Trump's recent tweets, which targeted four freshman Democratic congresswomen of color. In an email to a journalist, Darin Miller, the deputy press secretary for the Vice President, defended Trump's comments by highlighting the difference between Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao and Representative Ilhan Omar.

According to Miller, Chao is a "good immigrant" who "worked hard and assimilated" and is now dedicated to serving her country. In contrast, Omar "seems content to criticize America at every turn" and has opposed the emergency border aid bill, which provided humanitarian aid for asylum seekers.

However, the truth is that both Chao and Omar immigrated legally to the United States and now serve in the federal government. Chao was appointed as Secretary of Labor during the George W. Bush era and is married to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell. Omar, on the other hand, is a representative from Minnesota who has been a vocal critic of Trump's policies.

The debate surrounding Trump's tweets continues to play out in Congress, with the House of Representatives voting on a resolution to officially condemn the tweets. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi was forced to apologize after running afoul of an old House rule that prohibits lawmakers from insulting a president's character on the floor. Trump, of course, had something to say about it.

Title: Cruz Campaign Uses Santa Claus to Collect Voter Data

The Ted Cruz campaign has launched a unique initiative to connect with supporters and gather voter data during its seven-day, 12-city tour across Minnesota. The campaign's strategy involves having a costumed Santa Claus at each event, where attendees can take photos and provide their information to receive a personalized card with a unique code. The campaign aims to build a lasting relationship with voters and gather valuable data to inform its future outreach efforts.

According to Jeff Roe, the campaign's manager, the idea to use Santa Claus was born out of a desire to create a memorable experience for supporters and gather more information than traditional methods, such as collecting business cards or handwritten names. The campaign has been brainstorming ways to connect with supporters since its August swing through southern states, where it collected data from around 19,000 people at 13 rallies.

Red Bartholomew, the 64-year-old Santa Claus hired by the campaign, has a history of performing at Tea Party events, fundraisers, and church functions. He believes he has found a kindred spirit in Senator Cruz, who shares his views on limited government and individual freedom.

While some attendees were surprised to see Santa at a political event, many were grateful for the distraction and the opportunity to take photos with their children. Mary Kay Storhaug, a 45-year-old from Andover, Minnesota, said the Santa provided a welcome distraction for her kids during the rally.

The campaign's goal is to collect data from attendees and build a lasting relationship with voters, particularly in states like Minnesota that often receive little attention from candidates until just before voting begins. According to Roe, the photos are part of building a meaningful engagement that will last for hopefully their whole life and the campaign's whole life.

However, at least one attendee, Red Bartholomew, expressed some caution about sharing his information, stating he screens his calls for various reasons.

Title: Wisconsin Senator Ron Johnson: The Face of the Tea Party Movement

Article:

In 2010, George Will dubbed Wisconsin businessman Ron Johnson the face of the Tea Party movement, a label that stuck. Johnson, a 55-year-old manufacturer of plastic products from Oshkosh, was one of the first Tea Party candidates to run for office. He launched his campaign through Tea Party rallies across Wisconsin, waving the "bloody shirt" of victimized conservatives to the ecstatic crowd.

Johnson's political career began as a response to the perceived threat of Obamacare, which he saw as a mortal threat to individual freedom. He described the Affordable Care Act as "the greatest assault on freedom in my lifetime" and argued that it was a government overreach that needed to be stopped.

As a self-proclaimed fan of Ayn Rand's "Atlas Shrugged," Johnson's definition of freedom is limited to economic freedom, specifically the freedom to purchase products of one's choice. He has been a vocal supporter of the Tea Party movement, which he believes is a grassroots movement that needs to be organized and mobilized to achieve its goals.

In a recent interview, Johnson expressed his concerns about the Tea Party movement's recent losses, stating that the movement may be maturing and realizing that winning elections is necessary to advance policy. He also emphasized the importance of the Tea Party grassroots being flexible and open to compromise.

However, some critics have questioned Johnson's commitment to the Tea Party movement, pointing out that he has received significant funding from the Koch brothers and has been referred to as their "model senator." Johnson has also been accused of being out of touch with the grassroots movement, as he has been known to distance himself from certain Tea Party groups and has not been as vocal in his support for the movement as some of his colleagues.

Overall, Ron Johnson's political career is a testament to the power of grassroots movements and the importance of staying true to one's principles. While some may question his commitment to the Tea Party movement, Johnson remains a vocal advocate for limited government and individual freedom.

Title: Washington Gridlock: Sequester Cuts Remain in Place as Both Sides Refuse to Budge

The $85 billion in across-the-board spending cuts, known as the sequester, are set to take effect, with neither President Barack Obama nor congressional Republicans showing signs of compromise. The cuts, designed to be so severe that no one would want to keep them in place, have become a reality, with both sides refusing to budge on the key issue of revenues.

House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) acknowledged in an interview on NBC's "Meet the Press" that the sequester's impact is still unclear, stating, "I don't think anyone quite understands how the sequester is really going to work." However, he did not indicate any willingness to revisit the issue.

The sequester was designed to be a painful solution to reduce the federal budget, but 18 months later, Republicans have come to accept it as a way to cut government spending. While some Republicans, like Boehner, have expressed concerns about the sequester's impact on the economy, others are planning to vote on a bill to ease the cuts' impact, particularly for the military and veterans.

Administration officials, however, argue that even added flexibility would not change the bottom line, citing projections that the cuts will result in 750,000 lost jobs. White House economics adviser Gene Sperling stated on ABC's "This Week," "When you have those types of harsh spending cuts in such a short, concentrated period of time, it is like saying to somebody, 'You can cut off three of your fingers, but you can have the flexibility to choose which ones you want to cut off.'"

The sequester's implementation could mark a new era in Washington, with a temporary stall in emergency budget wars that have dominated the city since Republicans took over the House in 2011. The debt limit will not need to be raised until May at the earliest, and some top-level aides predict it could stretch until August. The prevailing wisdom in the Capitol is that House Republicans cannot demand anything in exchange for extending the country's borrowing authority, as they lost the right to do so when they agreed to lift the ceiling in January without insisting on equal cuts.

Title: Trump Ties with Bush in Republican Presidential Poll, Clinton Leads in Democratic Race

Article:

A recent Reuters-Ipsos poll has shown that Donald Trump, a billionaire real estate developer, has surged to a virtual tie with Jeb Bush, a former Florida governor, in the race for the 2016 Republican U.S. presidential nomination. The poll, conducted from July 6-10, found that Trump had the support of 15.8% of self-identified Republicans, while Bush had 16.1%.

The poll also showed that other Republican candidates, including New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul, surgeon and author Ben Carson, and Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, trailed behind Trump and Bush. In the Democratic race, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton remained in the lead with the support of 48.3% of self-identified Democrats, followed by Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders at 22.9% and Vice President Joe Biden at 10.7%.

The poll's findings come as Trump's comments on illegal immigration have dominated news coverage of the Republican campaign in recent weeks. Trump has been criticized for his comments on Mexico and illegal immigration, including his statement that Mexico is sending "rapists and other criminals" to the United States. He has also accused Bush of being weak on illegal immigration, bringing Bush's Mexican-born wife into the debate.

The controversy over Trump's comments has led to several businesses cutting ties with him, including NBC Universal, Univision, Macy's, Serta, and NASCAR. However, Trump's hardline stance on illegal immigration may find a receptive audience among Republican primary voters, who often accuse President Barack Obama of not doing enough to secure the border with Mexico.

The Reuters-Ipsos poll surveyed 404 self-identified Republicans age 18 or over and had a credibility interval of 5.7 percentage points. The poll also surveyed 504 self-identified Democrats age 18 or over, with a credibility interval of 5.1 percentage points.

Title: The Dangers of a Recession: A Global Economic Downturn's Devastating Consequences

The article by Derek Thompson highlights the severe consequences of a recession, emphasizing that it is not a desirable or easy solution to achieve. While a downturn might seem like a way to hinder President Trump's re-election chances, it would also lead to widespread suffering, including job losses, business closures, and economic instability. The author argues that this would disproportionately affect the most vulnerable populations, including low-skilled workers, who would struggle to find new employment and would see their wages stagnate.

The article also touches on the potential long-term effects of automation, which could accelerate during a recession. This could lead to a concentration of unemployment among the poorest workers, causing a ripple effect on their wages and overall economic well-being. The article notes that the recent progress in wage growth among low-income workers would be undone, and the labor market would struggle to recover.

Furthermore, the article discusses the impact of a global economic downturn on Central American workers, who would be disproportionately affected by reduced growth in the US, their largest trading partner. The author emphasizes that addressing the living conditions of these workers before they cross the border or even if they don't cross at all is crucial.

The article presents a nuanced and fact-based analysis of the consequences of a recession, highlighting the devastating effects on individuals, communities, and the economy as a whole. It encourages readers to consider the human toll of economic downturns and the need for a more comprehensive approach to address the challenges faced by vulnerable populations.

Title: Beto O'Rourke Releases 2017 Tax Returns, Revealing $370,412 in Income

Beto O'Rourke, a former Texas Representative and 2020 presidential candidate, has released his 2017 tax returns, showing a total income of $370,412. The returns, filed jointly with his wife Amy Sanders O'Rourke, cover the period from 2008 to 2017. The couple plans to release their 2018 tax return as soon as it is filed.

According to the returns, the O'Rourkes' largest annual income was $496,280 in 2009, which included a $272,775 gain from an investment partnership. Their lowest reported income was $163,539 in 2012, the year after O'Rourke left the El Paso City Council and before he took his seat as a United States congressman.

In 2017, the O'Rourkes reported selling Stanton Street Technology, an El Paso-based internet web design firm started by O'Rourke about 20 years ago, for $300,000, resulting in a net gain of $195,627 after costs. However, they ended up losing $3,000 after all capital gains and losses were calculated for that year.

O'Rourke earned $162,211 for serving in Congress in 2017, according to his tax return. His wife, Amy, earned $53,364 from her work as the Choose to Excel director for the Council on Regional Economic Expansion and Educational Development (CREEED), an El Paso business leaders group aimed at improving education levels in the El Paso area.

The O'Rourkes paid $81,019 in federal income tax in 2017 and $88,798 in 2009, when they had their largest reported income. Other Democratic presidential candidates, including Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders and California Senator Kamala Harris, have also released their tax returns.

Title: Trump University Documents Reveal Aggressive Sales Tactics to Target Financial Weaknesses

A recent release of over 400 pages of Trump University documents has provided a rare glimpse into the business practices used by Donald Trump to build his business empire. The documents, which are central to a class-action lawsuit against Trump University in California, detail how Trump staff were instructed to target prospective students' financial weaknesses to encourage them to sign up for a $34,995 Gold Elite three-day package.

The documents contain an undated "personal message" from Trump to new enrollees, stating, "Only doers get rich. I know that in these three packed days, you will learn everything to make a million dollars within the next 12 months." The courses are now subject to legal proceedings from unhappy clients.

The playbook instructs Trump University staff to identify buyers and push them to sign up for the most expensive package, and to put the cost on their credit cards. If potential students hesitate, teachers are told to read a script that emphasizes the need for financial change and the benefits of joining the program.

The documents also reveal that Trump University staff were instructed to spend lunch breaks in sign-up seminars "planting seeds" in potential students' minds about how their lives won't improve unless they join the program. They were also told to ask students personal questions to discover weaknesses that could be exploited to help seal the deal.

The release of these documents has sparked controversy, with Trump attacking the judge, Gonzalo Curiel, as a "hater" and "biased" on social media. However, Curiel has denied any bias and has released the documents as part of the ongoing legal proceedings.

The documents have also been criticized by New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, who has sued Trump University. Schneiderman stated, "You are not allowed to protect the trade secrets of a three-card Monte game. If you look at the facts of this case, this shows someone who was absolutely shameless in his willingness to lie to people, to say whatever it took to induce them into his phony seminars."

Title: Obama and Romney Clash in Final Presidential Debate, Focus on Foreign Policy

The third and final presidential debate between President Barack Obama and Republican challenger Mitt Romney took place on Monday night, with the two candidates engaging in a lively discussion on foreign policy. The debate, held at Lynn University in Boca Raton, Florida, saw the two candidates presenting their views on a range of international issues, including Iran, Syria, and Al Qaeda.

Romney, who has been trailing Obama in recent polls, sought to paint the president as weak on foreign policy, accusing him of presiding over a decline in American influence and emboldening enemies like Iran. Obama, on the other hand, criticized Romney for being "all over the map" on foreign policy, accusing him of pushing a plan that is either wrong or a rehashing of his own policies.

The debate saw the two candidates engaging in a series of sharp exchanges, with Obama employing biting one-liners to attack Romney's views. Romney, however, used a lighter touch, at times scolding Obama for getting too aggressive. The two candidates also found common ground on certain issues, such as ruling out military action in Syria and supporting sanctions against Iran.

The debate touched on several key issues, including the Libya terror attacks, which have been a major point of contention in the campaign. Romney accused Obama of not providing a clear example of American leadership on the world stage, while Obama sought to portray Romney as unsteady on the world stage, with a mix of poor judgment and outdated views.

The debate was moderated by CBS News' Bob Schieffer and lasted 90 minutes. The final presidential debate is seen as a crucial opportunity for either candidate to shake up the race, with just two weeks to go until Election Day. Recent polls have shown the two candidates neck and neck, with Obama holding a slight edge in some surveys.

Title: New Data Suggests President Obama May Be a Net Job Creator

Article:

According to recent data released by the Labor Department, the United States has added 4.4 million jobs since President Obama's inauguration in 2009. This figure is a significant revision from the previously reported 4 million jobs recovered, and if confirmed, would mean that Obama's administration has created 125,000 more jobs than it lost during his first term.

The data shows that jobs have been slowly trickling back, particularly in professional services, healthcare, and manufacturing, with the Labor Department attributing the revised figures to more complete data from unemployment insurance records. While the numbers are subject to slight revisions in February, the preliminary data suggests that the economy has recovered 4.4 million jobs since early 2010, enough to account for the jobs lost during Obama's first term.

However, Republican nominee Mitt Romney's campaign is quick to point out that the unemployment rate remains high, with 8% of Americans still struggling to find work. Romney's campaign cites a 2009 report by Obama's then-chief economic adviser, Christina Romer, which predicted that unemployment would be at 5.4% with 9 million more people working. Romney's campaign argues that Obama's policies have failed to meet these expectations.

Despite the revised job numbers, the unemployment rate remains stuck at 8.1%, with the U.S. population growing 3.8% since Obama took office, but jobs growing only 1.5% over the same period. Approximately 12.5 million Americans were still counted as unemployed in August.

Title: Trump Administration Withdraws from Iran Nuclear Deal, Former Obama Officials Criticize Decision

The Trump administration has announced its decision to withdraw from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), also known as the Iran nuclear deal, a key foreign policy achievement of the Obama administration. Former Obama officials have spoken out against the decision, criticizing it as a blow to American credibility and a potential threat to regional security.

Former United Nations Ambassador Samantha Power and former National Security Adviser Ben Rhodes have taken to social media to express their disappointment and concern. Power tweeted that the decision would "pave the way for Iran to restart its nuclear program" and "isolate the US and rally the world around Iran." Rhodes stated that the move would "make Obama look bigger" and "isolate the US from its European allies."

Former Secretary of State John Kerry also weighed in, saying that the decision would "weaken our security, break America's word, isolate us from our European allies, put Israel at greater risk, and empower Iran's hardliners."

President Obama himself has also spoken out against the decision, stating that "walking away from the JCPOA turns our back on America's closest allies."

However, critics of the Obama administration's deal argue that it failed to address Iran's continued support for terrorism and its development of long-range ballistic missiles. They point out that the deal did not prevent Iran from pursuing its nuclear program and that it has not led to improved relations with the country.

The Trump administration's decision to withdraw from the deal has been met with criticism from many in the international community, including European leaders and other world powers. The move is seen as a significant shift in US foreign policy and a potential blow to the global effort to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Weigh In on Allowing Incarcerated Felons to Vote

Article:

In a recent CNN town hall, Democratic presidential candidates Bernie Sanders and Kamala Harris expressed differing opinions on the topic of allowing convicted felons to vote while still incarcerated. Sanders advocated for the idea, stating it is a matter of principle and a way to combat voter suppression. Harris, on the other hand, expressed openness to the idea but later walked back her statement.

Pete Buttigieg was the only candidate to flatly reject the notion, receiving applause from the Democratic audience. CNN anchors were surprised by Sanders' stance, with some arguing that even convicted terrorists should be allowed to vote from their prison cells.

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's chief of staff, Saikat Chakrabarti, supported the idea, stating that those affected by unjust laws should have a say in electing representatives to change them. However, others argued that this approach is subjective and unworkable.

Guy Benson, a conservative commentator, questioned the idea of allowing non-violent felons to vote while still incarcerated, citing examples of individuals who committed serious crimes. He argued that the right to vote is guaranteed to eligible US citizens, and those who commit felonies forfeit their ability to participate in the electoral process.

The article also touched on the idea of a tiered approach, where non-violent felons are allowed to vote while violent offenders are not. However, this approach was criticized for being arbitrary and unfair.

In conclusion, the debate surrounding the issue of allowing incarcerated felons to vote remains contentious, with different opinions and perspectives being presented by Democratic presidential candidates and commentators.

Title: Obama Administration to Buy Illinois Prison, Denies Plans to House Guantanamo Prisoners

The Obama administration has announced plans to purchase the Thomson Correctional Center, a state prison located 150 miles west of Chicago, for $165 million. The move is intended to alleviate overcrowding in high-security prisons and create jobs, according to administration officials. However, Republican lawmakers have expressed concerns that the purchase could ultimately lead to the transfer of Guantanamo Bay prisoners to the United States.

Administration officials have denied any plans to house Guantanamo prisoners at the Thomson facility, citing concerns about public safety and overcrowding. A Justice Department official stated, "This is about public safety and 50 percent overcrowding in high-security prisons."

Despite these denials, Republican lawmakers, such as Virginia Representative Frank Wolf, have expressed concerns that the administration could still find ways to transfer Guantanamo prisoners to the United States. Wolf, who chairs a key House subcommittee overseeing the sale, accused the administration of circumventing Congress and attempting to fulfill Obama's pledge to shut down the Guantanamo Bay prison camp.

The move to transfer prisoners stateside has been met with opposition from some lawmakers, who worry it could pose a security risk. The Obama administration and Federal Bureau of Prisons are moving forward with the purchase, citing the need to ease overcrowding and create jobs.

The Thomson prison was built in 2001 but never fully opened due to budget troubles. The purchase is seen as a way to revitalize the facility and create economic opportunities in the region. However, House Appropriations Committee Chairman Hal Rogers warned that the administration's move could be a "back-door" attempt to open the prison and transfer terrorists from Guantanamo Bay onto U.S. soil, which would be met with opposition from his committee.

Title: Hillary Clinton Targets Center Ground in Scathing Speech Against Trump

Article:

In a speech billed as a national security address, Hillary Clinton aimed to appeal to a broad center in the general election, rather than shifting further left to woo supporters of her Democratic rival Bernie Sanders.
