Instead, she delivered a forceful rebuke of presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump, framing her pitch in patriotic terms that could resonate with Republicans.

Clinton presented herself as the real defender of American values and a commander-in-chief with a steady hand, emphasizing her commitment to America's exceptionalism. She criticized Trump's views on the military, calling him a threat to national security. The speech was devoid of new policy proposals, focusing on Trump's perceived weaknesses.

Clinton's strategy is to appeal to independent and Republican voters concerned about Trump's erratic foreign policy pronouncements, as well as his statements on women, Mexican immigrants, and Muslims. She has the potential to attract moderate Republicans who are turned off by their party's stance on social issues but feel she is tough enough on foreign policy.

The speech was met with a mixed reaction from Republicans, with some expressing concerns about Trump's fitness for office. At least nine Republican governors and several senators have declined to endorse him, and a growing number of lifelong Republicans are considering voting for a Democrat for the first time in November.

Clinton's message on American global leadership may not resonate with the GOP base, which is increasingly isolationist, but it is finding an audience with many moderates and foreign policy thinkers. The hashtag #RepublicansForHillary trended on Twitter, with some prominent Republicans expressing their support for Clinton.

Clinton's campaign has not publicly discussed its strategy to appeal to moderate Republicans, but aides acknowledge that there are Republicans who could support her, particularly those concerned about foreign policy issues. The challenge for Clinton will be to convince anti-Trump Republicans that they need to vote for her, not simply refrain from voting for Trump.

Title: President Obama to Discuss Poverty and Lack of Economic Opportunity at Georgetown University Summit

President Barack Obama will participate in a discussion at Georgetown University's three-day Catholic-Evangelical leadership summit on poverty, which was initiated by Pope Francis' call to focus on the issue. The summit aims to address the root causes of poverty and inequality in the United States.

According to White House aide Jerry Abramson, President Obama believes that recent high-profile confrontations between police and blacks are often a result of a lack of economic opportunity. Abramson stated that these issues are not new and have been simmering for decades in the U.S. The president will discuss the need to provide more opportunities for urban children and the importance of addressing the issue of limited opportunities based on one's ZIP code.

The White House has been working to address these issues since President Obama's first day in office. The administration has implemented policies aimed at rebuilding the economy, protecting civil rights, expanding college access, providing tax credits to working families, and targeting more money to high-poverty neighborhoods.

Title: US and Canada Reach Deal on Revised NAFTA Agreement

The United States and Canada have reached a last-minute agreement on a revised North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), dubbed the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). The deal was struck just hours before the midnight deadline, marking a reversal of a weeks-long impasse and a flurry of tough rhetoric.

The agreement, which updates the original NAFTA, aims to strengthen the middle class, create good jobs, and promote economic growth in the region. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland announced the deal in a joint statement, stating that it will give workers, farmers, and businesses a high-standard trade agreement, resulting in freer markets, fairer trade, and robust economic growth.

The breakthrough came after the US and Mexico agreed to hold off publishing a bilateral deal between the two countries, in the hopes of hammering out an agreement with Canada. The deal incorporates the components of the bilateral agreement between the US and Mexico, including rules of origin for automobiles, new digital trade rules, intellectual property protections, and strengthened labor rules.

Senior Trump administration officials are calling the deal a big win for the US, Canada, and Mexico, saying it represents the fulfillment of one of President Donald Trump's most important campaign promises. The deal also addresses some of the key issues that stalled negotiations between Canada and the US, including greater access to Canada's dairy market and the elimination of Class 7 milk pricing.

Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau called the deal a "good day for Canada," while President Trump tweeted that it's a "great deal for all three countries." The deal will now be reviewed and ratified by the US Congress and the Canadian Parliament before taking effect.

Title: A Call to Action for a Presidential Candidate: Closing the Gap and Winning a Majority

As the Republican primary season approaches its homestretch, a prominent figure in the party has been advised on how to bridge the gap and secure a majority of support. The article offers a neutral and factual analysis of the candidate's strengths and weaknesses, providing suggestions on how to improve their chances of winning the presidency.

The article highlights the candidate's ability to energize a significant portion of Republican primary voters and make the party more attractive to lower-income and working-class Americans. However, it also notes that getting to 50% is the next hurdle, and recent statements and tweets are driving away voters.

The article provides four key recommendations for the candidate to improve their chances of winning:

1. Stop fighting with everyone and tone down the negativity. The article suggests that the candidate's aggressive and belittling language is pushing away voters and that they should focus on making provocative points in a more constructive way.
2. Get facts right. The article notes that the candidate often fudges facts and misstates information, which raises doubts about their knowledge on various issues. It recommends supporting statements with accurate facts and anecdotes.
3. Learn more policy. The article suggests that the candidate should take the time to learn about various issues and demonstrate a deeper understanding of policy. It notes that voters want to know what the candidate would do if elected, beyond building a wall.
4. Make policy announcements. The article recommends that the candidate give a small number of actual policy addresses to demonstrate their ability to tackle various issues and grow their support.

The article also advises the candidate to stop citing polls and focus on the hopes and dreams of voters. It notes that elections are not about politicians, but about the people and their aspirations.

Overall, the article provides a neutral and factual analysis of the candidate's strengths and weaknesses, offering practical advice on how to improve their chances of winning the presidency.

Title: Senate Republicans' Strategy to Block Recess Appointments

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., has expressed his intention to refuse to consider any nominee submitted by President Obama to succeed late Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia. However, Republicans may not need to worry about a recess appointment, as they have a constitutional loophole to prevent it. According to the Constitution, the House and Senate must meet every three days unless an agreement is reached to skip a session and go on recess. This means that Senate leaders can schedule "pro-forma" sessions at three-day intervals, effectively blocking a recess appointment.

These brief meetings, often referred to as "gavel-in, gavel-out," do not involve any legislative business and are simply a way for the House and Senate to comply with the constitutional requirement. By doing so, Republicans can prevent President Obama from making a recess appointment to the Supreme Court.

This strategy has been used before. In 2011 and 2012, Democrats controlled the Senate, but Republicans controlled the House. The House refused to agree to an adjournment resolution, forcing the Senate to meet every three days. In 2012, President Obama made four recess appointments during this window, but the Supreme Court later voided them, ruling that the Senate was indeed in session.

The same tactic was used by Democrats during the final two years of President George W. Bush's term, when they blocked his attempts to make recess appointments. In 2003, Senate Republicans criticized Democrats for holding up judicial nominations, including the nomination of Judge Bill Pryor to the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Georgia. Democrats had concerns about Pryor's views on women's issues and homosexuality, and they filibustered the nomination. During a summertime adjournment, Bush went around the Senate and appointed Pryor without its advice and consent.

In the current situation, Democrats may try to force Republicans to take a vote on a Supreme Court nominee, but Republicans are aware that the best way to prevent a recess appointment is to simply meet every three days.

Title: Senator Ted Cruz Forced to Leave Restaurant by Protesters Amidst Brett Kavanaugh Debate

Article: Senator Ted Cruz, a Texas Republican, was escorted out of an upscale Italian restaurant in Washington's Penn Quarter neighborhood on Monday night by a group of protesters chanting "We believe survivors." The incident occurred as Cruz and his wife, Heidi, were preparing to sit down for dinner at Fiola.

A woman approached the senator and asked him about his stance on Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, whose nomination has been met with controversy due to allegations of past sexual misconduct. Two women, Christine Blasey Ford and Deborah Ramirez, have accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault, which he has denied.

The woman, who identified herself as a survivor of sexual assault, asked Cruz if he believed survivors of sexual assault and if he would speak with Kavanaugh about the allegations. Cruz politely declined to answer and attempted to exit the restaurant with his wife.

As the senator and his wife tried to leave, a crowd of over a dozen people began chanting and recording the incident on their phones. Cruz politely asked to be excused and tried to work his way through the crowd, saying "God bless you" to one protester who gave him a middle finger. A few protesters cheered and yelled "bye" as the couple exited the restaurant.

One protester asked Cruz if he would confirm his "best friend," Brett Kavanaugh, and another shouted "Beto is way hotter than you, dude," in reference to Cruz's Democratic opponent, Rep. Beto O'Rourke. O'Rourke tweeted that Cruz and his wife should not have been treated that way and should be treated with respect.

The incident highlights the intense emotions and controversy surrounding the nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court.

Title: UN General Assembly Votes Overwhelmingly in Favor of Resolution Condemning US Recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's Capital

The United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly in favor of a resolution on Thursday, condemning the United States' decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The resolution, which was passed with 128 votes in favor and nine against, declares that any changes to the status of Jerusalem "have no legal effect, are null and void, and must be rescinded." The resolution also calls upon all states to refrain from the establishment of diplomatic missions in the Holy City of Jerusalem.

The vote was seen as a rebuke to the Trump administration's decision, which was announced in December. The resolution does not explicitly mention the United States, but it is clear that it is directed at the White House. The US was one of only nine countries to vote against the resolution, with 35 countries abstaining.

The vote took place at a rare emergency session of the 193-member UN General Assembly, which was called by Turkey and Yemen on behalf of two international organizations of Arab and Muslim countries. The US had made a concerted effort to swing countries to its side before the vote, with Ambassador Nikki Haley threatening to cut off funding to the UN if countries voted against the US.

Despite these efforts, the vote stacked heavily against the US, with even close allies like the UK and Egypt voting in favor of the resolution. The vote is seen as a stark illustration of how isolated the US has become in its stance on Jerusalem.

The US recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital has been widely criticized by the international community, with many countries viewing it as a violation of international law and a blow to the prospects for a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The move has also sparked concerns about the potential for increased tensions in the region and a further erosion of trust between the US and its allies.

The vote is seen as a significant rebuke to the Trump administration's decision, which was announced in December. The resolution does not explicitly mention the United States, but it is clear that it is directed at the White House. The US was one of only nine countries to vote against the resolution, with 35 countries abstaining.

The vote is also seen as a blow to the Trump administration's efforts to isolate the Palestinian Authority and its leader, Mahmoud Abbas, who has been critical of the US recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The move has also sparked concerns about the potential for increased tensions in the region and a further erosion of trust between the US and its allies.

In conclusion, the UN General Assembly's vote on Thursday is a significant rebuke to the Trump administration's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The vote is seen as a stark illustration of how isolated the US has become in its stance on Jerusalem, and it highlights the deep divisions within the international community over the issue.

Title: National Donors Pour Money into Wisconsin Sheriff's Race, Pitting Gun Control Groups Against the NRA

The upcoming election in Milwaukee County, Wisconsin, has become a battleground for gun control groups and the National Rifle Association (NRA). The race pits incumbent Sheriff David Clarke Jr., a strong supporter of Second Amendment rights, against his opponent, Police Lieutenant Chris Moews. Clarke, known for his outspoken ads, has been a vocal advocate for gun ownership and personal safety.

The primary election on Tuesday will decide whether Clarke gets another term in office or Moews takes the reins. The winner will likely become the next county sheriff, as no Republicans are running in the contest. The race is a rematch of the one four years ago, in which Clarke beat Moews by six points.

This time around, Moews has received significant financial backing from gun control groups. Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's Independence USA super PAC has paid $150,000 to air television ads targeting Clarke's conservative pro-gun policies. This amount is more than what Clarke and Moews have spent on their entire campaigns combined. Bloomberg's spokesman, Howard Wolfson, stated that the decision to get involved in the sheriff's race was made because it allowed them to shape policy on a local level and highlight the contrast between the two candidates on the issue of gun control.

The Greater Wisconsin Committee has also spent $400,000 on anti-Clarke ads. Clarke, who runs as a Democrat but often aligns himself with conservative Republicans, has received support from the NRA. The organization has solicited donations from its members on his behalf and purchased online ads for his re-election bid. The NRA has described Clarke as a "rising national star" and has come to his defense.

In a recent interview, Clarke emphasized his stance on gun ownership, stating, "Am I big on a person's right to be able to defend themselves? Yes. You know why? Because it's a natural right." Moews, on the other hand, has expressed a different view, saying, "If I have the opportunity to defend myself and my family, I will do so to the best of my abilities, but I'm certainly also going to call 911 if I have the ability because I need the cavalry to come and help me."

Title: Egypt Launches Airstrikes Against Islamic State Targets in Libya in Response to Execution of Christians

Egypt has launched airstrikes against Islamic State (IS) targets in Libya in retaliation for the gruesome execution of 21 Egyptian Christians shown in a video released Sunday. The strikes, conducted in coordination with the recognized Libyan government based in Tobruk, targeted camps, training sites, and weapons storage areas of the IS affiliate in Libya. According to a Libyan air-force commander, 40 to 50 militants were killed in the strike.

The airstrikes were made in response to an IS video released Sunday showing the execution of 21 Egyptians, all Coptic Christians, at the hands of masked IS supporters. The video, shot in IS signature style, shows that the group's Libyan branch has the numbers, wherewithal, and operational security to hold captives for weeks and then carry out a highly-produced murder show in a beach without fear of intervention from Egypt or anyone else.

Egypt's military is mostly trained for domestic control and running the expansive business empires of its senior officers. What Egypt will actually be able to do about the group in Libya remains to be seen. However, the days of ignoring IS in Libya will be over. Unlike in Iraq, where there is a central government to work with, or in Syria, where there is both a strong national army and outside support for Bashar al-Assad's side of the fight against Syria, Libya barely has any functioning institutions anymore.

The recognized Libyan government in Tobruk has called for the US-led coalition attacking IS forces in Syria and Iraq to turn its attentions to Libya. Libyan Prime Minister Abdullah al-Thinni has asked for Western military intervention against IS and Al Qaeda members he says are present in his country.

The Islamist rival government in Tripoli, a group called Libyan Dawn, says it has no affiliation with either IS or Al Qaeda. At least three groups among the multitude fighting in Libya's civil war have declared loyalty to IS, one in each of the country's component regions: Barqa in the east, Fezzan in the desert south, and Tripolitania in the west, around the capital.

The Islamic State's self-proclaimed provinces have compounded Libya's instability by introducing the prospect of Islamist-against-Islamist violence between those who support and those who oppose the group. But Tripolitania has leapt to the fore as the province that most clearly threatens Westerners and Western interests. Last month, fighters under the group's banner claimed responsibility for a brazen attack on a luxury hotel in the capital, Tripoli, that is a hub for visiting Westerners and leaders of the Islamist-backed provisional government.

In a commentary published in the Daily Telegraph, Shashank Joshi warns that "it's important to separate [the IS] role in Libya from the broader civil war there. Not every Libyan opposition faction is jihadist, and acting as if it were, by taking firm sides, is a recipe for disaster."

Title: Trump's Reality TV Playbook: How His Background in Reality TV Influences His Presidential Campaign

The rise of Donald Trump's presidential campaign has been met with much speculation and analysis. One aspect that has received less attention is the influence of his background in reality TV on his campaign. As a host of a reality TV show for over a decade, Trump has internalized the conventions of the genre, which are now playing out across the presidential campaign landscape.

According to Robert Thompson, founder of the Bleier Center for Television and Popular Culture at Syracuse University, the Trump campaign has employed a range of reality TV tricks to run his campaign and exert control over others. "The Trump campaign has used a whole bunch of tricks from reality television to run his campaign and extend control over other people's campaigns," Thompson said.

Thompson attributes Trump's success to his understanding of reality TV rules, which are also being unconsciously followed by those covering him. Trump's campaign has incorporated several key elements from reality TV, including:

1. Conflict: Trump's campaign has been marked by controversy and conflict, with opponents and critics often finding themselves at odds with him.
2. "Confession rooms": Trump has used his campaign as a platform to share personal stories and anecdotes, often painting himself as a victim or a hero.
3. Editing and manipulation: Trump's campaign has been accused of using selective editing and manipulation to shape public perception and create a narrative that benefits him.
4. Emotional appeals: Trump's campaign has relied heavily on emotional appeals, using fear, anger, and nostalgia to connect with voters.
5. The "outsider" narrative: Trump's campaign has positioned him as an outsider, a "non-politician" who can shake up the status quo and bring change to Washington.
6. The use of "shock value": Trump's campaign has often used provocative statements and actions to grab attention and generate headlines.

While Trump's background in reality TV is just one factor contributing to his success, it is undeniable that his understanding of the genre has played a significant role in shaping his campaign.

Title: Defense Secretary James Mattis: The Clarifier of Trump's Statements

Article:

Defense Secretary James Mattis has earned the nickname "the clarifier" for his ability to shift the tone and message of President Trump's seemingly never-ending stream of off-the-cuff comments. According to sources close to the Defense secretary, Mattis is providing a more detailed clarification to the president's statements, without drawing the ire of the commander-in-chief.

Mattis has been a favorite of Trump's even as the notoriously unpredictable president has soured on a number of administration officials. The two have an open dialogue, which includes frequent working dinners and regular phone calls and meetings, earning Mattis significant leeway in interpreting Trump's public and Twitter comments.

Mattis's savvy became apparent within the first few weeks after Trump's election. The retired Marine Corps general, who has long disapproved of using torture to gather intelligence, prompted Trump to change his tune after meeting with him to discuss the Defense secretary position. Mattis also opposed Trump's early views that NATO was "obsolete" and later placated world leaders after Trump did not reaffirm America's commitment to the military alliance while at an opening ceremony for NATO's new Brussels headquarters in May.

More recently, when Trump reportedly sought to fire the top U.S. commander in Afghanistan, Gen. Jon Nicholson, because the United States is "losing" the war, Mattis defended the general while not disparaging Trump's view. "I will tell you right now, he is our commander in the field, he has the confidence of NATO, he has the confidence of Afghanistan, he has the confidence of the United States," Mattis told reporters earlier this month.

Mattis is also adept at responding when faced with criticism that he is pushing back on Trump's assertions. He himself called the idea that he contradicted Trump "ludicrous" and "widely misinterpreted." "I was asked if there were any diplomatic efforts left, and I said of course, it didn't contradict anything the president said. We're not talking to the North Koreans right now," Mattis told reporters at the Pentagon on Thursday.

The secretary did admit that there are issues he and the president disagree on, but revealed the division of opinions in a complimentary tone. "The first time I met with President Trump, we disagreed on three things in my first 40 minutes with him, on NATO, on torture and something else, and he hired me. This is not a man who's immune to being persuaded if he thinks you've got an argument," Mattis said.

When asked about critics who say he and other national security leaders should step down when Trump makes divisive remarks, Mattis pointed to service to the greater good. "You know, when a president of the United States asks you to do something, I come – I don't think it's an old-fashioned school at all I don't think it's old-fashioned or anything. I don't care if it's Republican or Democrat, we all have an obligation to serve. That's all there is to it."

Title: Biden Warns Russia and Other Foreign Governments Against Election Interference

Washington (AP) - Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden has issued a stern warning to Russia and other foreign governments, stating that he would take aggressive action as president to counter any interference in U.S. elections. This comes after Democratic leaders issued a new warning that Congress appears to be the target of a foreign interference campaign.

Biden emphasized that he would treat foreign interference as an "adversarial act that significantly affects the relationship between the United States and the interfering nation's government." He criticized President Donald Trump for not doing enough in response to U.S. intelligence agencies' assessment that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election.

The new alarms give a renewed urgency to concerns that foreign actors could be trying to influence the vote or sow disinformation. Biden stated that he has begun receiving intelligence briefings and warned that Russia, China, and other adversaries are attempting to undermine the presidential election. He did not provide evidence, but said that Russia is "still engaged" after 2016 and that China is also involved in efforts to sow doubts in the American electoral process.

Democratic leaders, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer, and the top Democrats on the House and Senate intelligence committees, sent a letter to FBI Director Christopher Wray, expressing concern that Congress appears to be the target of a "concerted foreign interference campaign" to influence the 2020 presidential election. They requested an all-members, classified briefing on the matter before the August recess.

The FBI declined to comment on the letter. While the exact concerns were unclear, there have been worries since Trump was elected that Russia's efforts to sow American chaos are ongoing in the 2020 election. Intelligence authorities said that the 2016 effort included hacking of Democratic email accounts during the campaign by Russian military intelligence officials and the subsequent disclosure by WikiLeaks.

In a statement, Biden said, "If any foreign power recklessly chooses to interfere in our democracy, I will not hesitate to respond as president to impose substantial and lasting costs." He also stated that he would treat foreign interference as an "adversarial act that significantly affects the relationship between the United States and the interfering nation's government."

The article does not provide specific details about the alleged interference campaign, but it highlights the concerns of Democratic leaders and the need for vigilance in protecting the integrity of the election process.

Title: Obama's Immigration Options Limited, but Some Steps Could Ease Fears for Undocumented Immigrants

The Valdez family, who came to the United States illegally 13 years ago, is among the millions of undocumented immigrants living in the country. Nancy Paredo, the mother, and her children, Axel, Yan, and Demis, are living in Staten Island, New York. Due to New York's liberal immigration philosophy, they are not afraid of being deported daily, but they are cautious and closely watching Washington this summer.

Axel, a 5-year-old American citizen, was born in the United States. His brothers, Yan, 15, and Demis, 13, were born in Mexico and remain undocumented. The family's situation highlights the complexities of the US immigration system, with only Congress having the power to grant legal status to individuals like the Valdezes.

President Obama has announced a new effort to fix the immigration system, but his options are limited. The focus will be on reducing deportations among people who have been in the country for years. Various executive actions could impact the 11 million people living in the United States with no legal status.

One of Obama's easiest options would be to refine a 2010 policy that says undocumented, non-criminal, breadwinning immigrants would not be high deportation priorities. This change could ease some of the family's fears, but immigrant advocates and families say it's unclear whether it would make a big difference.

A more forceful step from the President would be to fully eliminate deportation for some immigrants – at least for a time. Yan is currently applying for protection under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) policy, which lasts two years and would give him work permits and a social security number. A move from the President could grant DACA-like protections to the parents of US citizens.

Extending these protections could impact some 3.8 million people. The number would be even higher if the President chose to extend protections to the parents of DACA-recipients. However, that's a step that government lawyers say would almost surely invite legal scrutiny and Republican opposition.

President Obama's most far-reaching – and controversial – move would be to extend DACA-like protection to all undocumented immigrants who meet certain criteria, which is an estimated 9.6 million people. The Valdez family could be free from deportation fears, but it's another move that would almost surely bring a legal challenge.

The Valdez family, like many others, is eager for action from the President. Nancy Paredo said, "I hope he does something by this summer. I hope it's not the same nonsense he always says. That he's going to do something and then he doesn't do it." The family often visits Washington to add their voice to the pressure for reform.

Title: Democrats Seek Opposite of Trump's Style to Win in 2020

Article:

In the 2020 presidential election, Democrats are searching for a candidate who can effectively counterbalance the style and attitude of incumbent President Donald Trump. According to the Extreme Pendulum Swing Theory, changing the party in power requires a total opposite of the current chief executive, not necessarily in policy, but in style and attitude.

The theory suggests that voters often seek a stark contrast to the current administration, which has been characterized by Trump's bombastic and confident approach. In the past, this has led to the rise of candidates who offer a distinct opposite, such as Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton, and Barack Obama.

In the current Democratic field, three candidates stand out as potential opposites to Trump: Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar, and Andrew Yang. Buttigieg, a young and Ivy League-educated Navy veteran, offers a contrasting attitude regarding America's place in the world, while Klobuchar, a U.S. senator with real-deal political experience, presents a deliberate and understated style. Yang, a detail-oriented Asian American technocrat, brings a fresh perspective and a focus on the modern economy.

While other candidates, such as Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren, may have some qualities that could appeal to voters, they do not fit the bill as strong opposites to Trump. Biden's style is too similar to Trump's, and Warren's penchant for exaggeration and anger may not provide the necessary contrast.

The Democratic Party often wins with "nerdy wonks," according to one Democratic strategist, and Buttigieg, Klobuchar, and Yang may be the best choices to fill this slot. They offer a unique blend of experience, policy expertise, and a willingness to challenge the status quo, making them strong contenders to take on Trump in the 2020 election.

Title: Pakistani Court Rules Men Can Marry Underage Girls Who Have Had Their First Menstrual Cycle

A Pakistani high court has ruled that men can marry underage girls as long as they have had their first menstrual cycle, contradicting the Sindh Child Marriage Restraint Act, which prohibits marriage below the age of 18. The ruling was made during a court hearing into the kidnapping, forced conversion, and marriage of 14-year-old Christian girl Huma Younus.

Huma's parents received documents from the abductors, including papers showing her alleged conversion to Islam and a marriage certificate. However, the family claims the documents are fake, as the date on the documents matches the day of her abduction. The Christian couple supplied the court with baptismal and school documents proving Huma is 14 years old.

The Sindh Child Marriage Restrant Act was passed almost six years ago to stop forced marriages to minors in the province. The practice is prevalent among Hindus and Christian girls, according to various media outlets. The court ruling has sparked outrage, with Huma's mother, Nagina, stating that the government and judges are delaying the decision because her daughter is 14 years old and want to wait for her to turn 18.

The International Christian Concern (ICC) has condemned the ruling, stating that it is "wrong on so many levels." The ICC's President, Jeff King, highlighted the issue of forced marriage and forced conversion in Muslim countries, where young Christian women are frequently targeted by Muslim men. King noted that the family usually knows the perpetrator and that the practice is not a rare occurrence.

The case has been sent to the Supreme Court of Pakistan, with another hearing scheduled for March 4.

Title: California's Political Leaders Gear Up to Resist Trump's Agenda

California, a state that Hillary Clinton won by more than 4 million votes, is preparing to lead the resistance against President-elect Donald Trump's agenda. The Golden State is a hub of political power for the left, with Silicon Valley and Hollywood industries that lean liberal. With a population of over 40% Hispanic, California will be a key battleground for Trump's immigration policies.

California's Secretary of State, Alex Padilla, stated that the state is ready to oppose Trump on federal policies that would harm California and on nominees like Senator Jeff Sessions, a Republican and immigration hard-liner nominated to lead the Department of Justice. Outgoing Representative Xavier Becerra, appointed as the state attorney general, will lead the local charge in California's immigration fight.

California's mayors have also pledged to resist aggressive immigration enforcement. Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti has been adamant about keeping L.A. as a "sanctuary city" and announced a fund to defend immigrants from deportation.

The state's political leaders are signaling they will be part of the resistance to Trump's pick for attorney general. Senator Dianne Feinstein, the top Democrat on the Judiciary Committee, will consider the Sessions nomination. Becerra said all legal options are on the table to fight to defend California's policies, including litigation and political action.

Voter turnout in California was 73.5%, the state's second-highest in history, with some attributing the high turnout to the interest taken in the election by Hispanics who worried about Trump's promises to build a U.S.-Mexico border wall and implement mass deportations. Trump has complained about voter fraud in California, claiming it contributed to his loss in the popular vote, but provided no evidence to support these accusations.

While Trump and California have been at odds, state politicians say they are willing to work with the president-elect where their interests align. However, they are prepared to resist his agenda on issues like immigration, healthcare, and social security. The potential clash between California and the federal government could pit the country's two largest bureaucracies against each other on almost every issue.

Title: Trump Predicts Democrats Will "Get Beaten So Badly" if They Campaign on Abolishing ICE

President Donald Trump has expressed his opposition to the growing calls from some Democratic politicians to abolish Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), warning that such a move would be a major electoral mistake. In an interview with Maria Bartiromo on "Sunday Morning Futures," Trump stated that if Democrats campaign on abolishing ICE, they will "get beaten so badly."

Trump emphasized the importance of ICE in enforcing immigration laws and taking out dangerous criminal organizations, such as MS-13. He noted that ICE agents are "much tougher" than MS-13 and that abolishing the agency would lead to a country where people are afraid to leave their homes.

The calls to abolish ICE, once limited to the far-left fringes of the Democratic Party, have gained momentum in recent weeks, particularly in response to the Trump administration's tough policies on illegal immigration. Several Democratic politicians, including Senator Kirsten Gillibrand and Mayor Bill de Blasio, have publicly expressed support for abolishing ICE.

Other Democratic politicians, such as Senator Kamala Harris and Representative Mark Pocan, have also weighed in on the issue, with Harris suggesting that the U.S. should consider "starting from scratch" and Pocan announcing plans to introduce a bill to abolish the agency.

Meanwhile, President Trump has taken to Twitter to express his support for ICE agents and to warn that abolishing the agency would be a mistake. He tweeted that there is "zero chance" of ICE being abolished and that the radical left wants to eliminate the agency, along with law enforcement.

The shift in the Democratic Party's stance on ICE has been met with enthusiasm from some Republicans, who believe it will give them an electoral advantage in the 2020 elections. Senator Tom Cotton, for example, tweeted that Democrats want to campaign on "open borders, mass migration, & abolishing ICE" and encouraged voters to "give them points for honesty and let's vote."

Title: Critique of Social Justice Movement: A Lack of Definition and Logic

The social justice movement has been a topic of much debate and discussion in recent years. Noah Rothman, a young writer and editor at Commentary magazine, has written a book titled "Unjust: Social Justice and the Unmaking of America," which critiques the concept of social justice. Rothman argues that social justice is not only nonsensical but also lacks definitional rigor and interior logic.

Rothman's critique is based on his research into the literature on social justice, which he found to be lacking in agreed-upon definitions. He notes that almost every definition of social justice includes some version of "economic justice," which he believes is actually about power rather than true social justice. Rothman argues that social justice is often used as a euphemism for socialism and that its advocates want the power to do what they want, regardless of the consequences.

Rothman also critiques the concept of "retributive justice," which he believes is based on the idea that historically oppressed or disadvantaged groups are owed something in the name of social justice. He argues that this worldview ignores individual circumstances and sweeps up vast abstract categories of human beings into notions of collective guilt or victimhood.

The author also references philosopher Friedrich Hayek's views on social justice, who saw it as the negation of plain old justice. Hayek believed that a person should only be responsible for the wrongs they committed against a specific person, and that holding someone accountable for the actions of someone else is unjust.

Rothman's book has received criticism from some quarters, with some arguing that he is not qualified to critique social justice because he is not a member of a historically oppressed group. However, Rothman argues that social justice is not about individual experiences or identities, but rather about the principles of justice and fairness.

Overall, Rothman's book is a thought-provoking critique of the social justice movement, which challenges readers to think critically about the concept of social justice and its implications.

Title: Democrats Highlight Potential Consequences of Sequestration on Public Safety

The Democratic Party is emphasizing the potential consequences of sequestration on public safety, warning that spending cuts could lead to increased crime, prison riots, and a surge in illicit drugs reaching U.S. soil. Senate Appropriations Committee Chairwoman Barbara Mikulski (D-Md.) stated that the cuts would undermine the ability to "catch the bad guys," citing the importance of federal grants for local law enforcement agencies.

Mikulski noted that the spending cuts would affect local law enforcement officials who rely on federal grants for staffing and equipment purchases, including bullet-proof vests. Rep. G.K. Butterfield (D-N.C.) added that a significant event, such as a major crime wave or a terrorist attack, could alter the public's mindset and make them more receptive to the Democratic Party's warnings.

Federal prison union officials have also expressed concerns about the potential consequences of sequestration, citing past budget cuts and continued staffing shortages. Dale Deshotel, president of the Council of Prison Locals, warned that prison wardens are being forced to use unprepared guards to deal with emergencies, increasing the risk of accidents and riots.

Additionally, warnings are growing that the spending cuts will hinder the ability to monitor and intercept illicit drugs, potentially leading to a surge in cocaine trafficking and availability on U.S. streets. Marine Gen. John Kelly, head of Southern Command, testified before the House Armed Services Committee that sequestration could lead to a loss of critical air and water surveillance assets, allowing cocaine to flood the streets of major cities.

While polls show that roughly half of Americans are still undecided about the effects of sequestration, Democrats are hoping that their warnings about increased crime and other dangers will resonate with the public and sway public opinion against the spending cuts.

Title: The Refugee Crisis in Europe: A Complex Issue with No Easy Solutions

The refugee crisis in Europe is a complex and multifaceted issue that has sparked intense debate and discussion. While some argue that the crisis can be solved with a simple solution, the reality is that it is a complex issue with no easy answers. The immediate problem is the influx of refugees fleeing war and terrorism in the Middle East, but the crisis cannot be addressed without considering the past and future implications.

The future is a significant constraint on what can be done in the present. The current generation of refugees will eventually pass on, and the next generation will grow up in their new home, with no memory of the Middle East. This new generation will likely face challenges integrating into their new society, as they may not share the same values and culture as their host country. This can lead to feelings of disconnection and resentment, which can be exploited by extremist groups.

No country has an unlimited capacity to absorb immigrants, and especially those whose cultures are fundamentally different from their own. The past and future of the crisis are inescapable, and it is crucial to consider the long-term implications of admitting a foreign population, especially one with a history of being foreign.

The current refugee crisis is a direct result of the conflicts in the Middle East, which were exacerbated by the withdrawal of American troops from Iraq and the destabilization of governments in Egypt and Libya. The West, including the United States, could have done more to support these countries and mitigate the crisis. Instead, the Obama administration's policies have created a vacuum that has been filled by extremist groups like ISIS.

In the short term, the West can provide financial aid to Middle Eastern countries like Jordan and Egypt, which are already taking in refugees. This would help alleviate the burden on these countries and provide a more sustainable solution. However, a more comprehensive approach will require a long-term commitment to addressing the root causes of the crisis, including the instability in the Middle East and the need for more effective governance.

Ultimately, the refugee crisis in Europe is a complex issue that requires a nuanced and multifaceted approach. It is not a simple problem that can be solved with a single solution, but rather a complex issue that requires a sustained effort to address the underlying causes and provide a more sustainable future for those affected.

Title: Romney Criticizes Obama's Foreign Policy, Avoids Specifics on Iran

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, has been criticizing President Barack Obama's foreign policy, focusing on accusations that the current administration has "apologized" for America and projected weakness. Romney made these comments in a speech in Fairfax, Virginia, outside Washington, where he emphasized the importance of a strong America in shaping global events.

In an interview with ABC News, Romney declined to respond to Obama's charge that he has a tendency to "shoot first and aim later," stating that this is politics and he won't worry about the campaign. The sharpest foreign policy difference between the two candidates emerged in their responses to questions about Iran.

Romney's stance on Iran is to prevent the country from obtaining a nuclear weapon, but he stopped short of specifying where he would draw the line in the development of nuclear capability. This vagueness is crucial, as Iran already has the capability to produce a nuclear weapon, although it may take several months or years to realize.

Romney has said he would never allow Iran to enrich uranium, suggesting he would enforce a series of United Nations Security Council resolutions demanding that Iran suspend its production of all nuclear fuel. However, Iran was in violation of this demand during most of George W. Bush's second term, and suffered fewer economic consequences than it has under Obama, who has imposed the first sanctions against Iran's oil revenues.

Both Romney's critics and supporters agree that Obama has been too cautious in supporting opposition forces in Syria, describing him as too risk-averse in the Middle East. Romney's campaign has also criticized a statement issued by the American Embassy in Cairo hours before protests began there, saying it did not strongly support freedom of speech.

Romney's critics, including Professor Cohen and former Ambassador Williamson, argue that the administration has failed to make clear that American aid to Egypt is contingent on the protection of American interests. They also suggest that the administration has been too slow to engage with opposition forces in Syria, and that the United States should provide more support to these groups. However, both men stopped short of saying that the United States should provide lethal arms to the opposition.

Title: House Speaker Pelosi Demands Briefing on US Military Strike Against Islamic State Leader

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has called for a briefing on the recent US military strike that resulted in the death of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. The raid, which was announced by President Trump on Sunday, was carried out without informing congressional leaders in advance, according to Trump. Pelosi stated that the House must be briefed on the operation and the administration's overall strategy in the region, emphasizing the need for "strong, smart, and strategic leadership from Washington."

Pelosi commended the US military for carrying out the raid, but did not mention Trump, who had made killing al-Baghdadi a priority and gave the order for the strike. She noted that the death of al-Baghdadi is significant, but the death of ISIS leader does not mean the death of ISIS. Pelosi also expressed concerns that scores of ISIS fighters remain under uncertain conditions in Syrian prisons, and countless others in the region and around the world remain intent on spreading their influence and committing acts of terror.

Pelosi's comments echo those of Democratic presidential hopeful and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden, who has criticized Trump's military policy in Syria, saying it has made ISIS potentially stronger. Trump was harshly criticized from both sides of the aisle earlier this month when he pulled out US troops from the Turkey-Syria border, allowing a Turkish military advance on US-allied Kurdish forces in the region. The House passed a joint resolution on an overwhelmingly bipartisan 354-60 basis, rejecting Trump's decision and calling on him to present a clear strategy to defeat ISIS.

Title: IRS Withholding Guidelines Begin to Deliver Bigger Paychecks to Workers

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has started implementing new withholding guidelines, which are expected to result in bigger paychecks for many American workers. The changes, which went into effect on January 1, 2018, aim to adjust the amount of federal taxes withheld from paychecks. The exact amount of extra cash workers will receive depends on factors such as their income, how often they are paid, and the number of withholding allowances they claim on their IRS Form W-4.

According to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, the new rules will mean more take-home pay for about 90% of American workers. Those whose employers have already made the changes are starting to see the benefits, with some receiving an extra few dollars to a few hundred dollars in their paychecks.

For example, Wayne Love, who works in managed care in Spring Hill, Florida, received an extra $200 in his paycheck last week, which he plans to use to offset a $300 increase in the cost of his health insurance. Julia Ketchum, a secretary at a public high school in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, was pleasantly surprised to see her pay go up $1.50 a week, which adds up to $78 a year and will cover her Costco membership.

The nonpartisan Tax Policy Center estimates that a middle-income household will receive a tax cut of $930 this year, lifting their after-tax income by about 1.6%. However, the exact impact will vary depending on individual circumstances.

Experts suggest that taxpayers review the new IRS calculator, which will be available later in February, to ensure they are having the correct amount withheld. They should also update their W-4 information after the IRS releases a revised version later this year.

The IRS has stated that the new withholding tables should produce an accurate withholding amount for people with simpler tax situations. However, those with more complicated tax situations, such as those who itemize or have larger families, may want to take a closer look.

The IRS, payroll, and tax professionals are still adjusting to the passage of the new tax law, and the IRS plans to make further changes involving withholding matters in 2019. Many in the industry expect the IRS to update the W-4 form in 2019 to fully reflect the scope of the law.

Title: Obama's Midterm Endorsements Leave Some Democrats Feeling Underwhelmed

Former President Barack Obama's list of 81 midterm endorsements has left some Democrats feeling disappointed and underwhelmed. The list, which came after most states had held their primaries, has been met with a mix of reactions from party strategists, former aides, and fundraisers.

While some Democrats appreciate Obama's continued popularity and the buzz his endorsements created, others argue that his decision to stay out of the primaries has been a disappointment. They believe that Obama's influence could have been more impactful if he had gotten involved earlier in the primary season.

Obama's decision to largely stay above internal party fights is consistent with the behavior of many other ex-presidents, who have generally sought to stay above internal party squabbles. However, some Democrats argue that the current political environment demands more involvement from Obama, given the stakes of the midterm elections.

The release of the endorsement list was consistent with Obama's post-Oval Office goal of staying above the fray and not becoming a foil to former President Donald Trump. Aides and people close to Obama have said that his desire is to allow a new crop of Democrats to take over the party, and he has avoided taking sides in the primaries.

While some candidates have benefited from Obama's endorsements, others have been left feeling snubbed. In Texas, former State Department official Ed Meier, who served under Obama, fell short in a congressional primary. Similarly, former State Department aide Alison Kiehl Friedman, who was running for Congress in Virginia, and former Commerce Department aide Sam Jammal, who was running for a seat in California, did not receive Obama's endorsement.

Some former aides and donors have expressed disappointment with Obama's decision to stay out of the primaries, saying it was a missed opportunity to make a difference. However, others have praised his endorsements, citing the buzz they created and the help they provided to some candidates.

Overall, Obama's midterm endorsements have left some Democrats feeling underwhelmed, while others appreciate his continued influence and popularity.

Title: Appeals Court Sides with Ohio Business Owners Challenging Birth Control Mandate

A divided appeals court panel has ruled in favor of two Ohio business owners who challenged the birth control mandate under the Affordable Care Act, citing religious grounds. Francis and Philip Gilardi, owners of Freshway Foods and Freshway Logistics, argued that providing contraceptive coverage would force them to violate their Roman Catholic beliefs and moral values.

The three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, in a 2-1 decision, reversed a lower court ruling that had denied the Gilardis' request for a preliminary injunction to block the Department of Health and Human Services from enforcing the mandate against them as business owners. The court ruled that the lower court erred when it concluded the Gilardis were unlikely to succeed on the merits and sent the case back to the lower court to consider other factors for an injunction.

Judge Janice Rogers Brown, an appointee of President George W. Bush, wrote that the mandate "trammels the right of free exercise -- a right that lies at the core of our constitutional liberties -- as protected by the Religious Freedom Restoration Act." Brown stated that the Gilardis faced a "Hobson's choice" between abiding by their faith, paying a penalty of over $14 million, and crippling their companies, or becoming complicit in a grave moral wrong.

In a dissenting opinion, Judge Harry T. Edwards, an appointee of President Jimmy Carter, argued that legislative restrictions may trump religious exercise. He questioned what would stop another company from seeking an exemption from a requirement to cover vaccines.

Judge A. Raymond Randolph, an appointee of President George H.W. Bush, joined Brown's main conclusion about the Gilardis but dissented from her conclusions about Freshway companies' exercise of religion. Randolph asked why the free-exercise right should be limited to religious organizations when many business corporations adhere to religious dogma.

The Gilardis' lawyer, Francis Manion, said he was pleased that the court accepted the "bulk" of his arguments but will appeal the part of the ruling on the free exercise religious rights of corporations. The Department of Health and Human Services declined to comment on pending litigation.

The ruling is one of several on the birth control issue, which is likely to be resolved by the Supreme Court. At least three other federal appeals courts have issued conflicting rulings on the mandate, with one siding with Oklahoma businesses and two siding with the Obama administration in challenges brought by Pennsylvania and Michigan companies.

Title: Obama's Criticism of Trump's Presidency: A Case of Selective Memory?

Article:

Former President Barack Obama has continued his public criticism of his successor, President Donald Trump, making claims that Trump's successes are due to Obama's policies and that his setbacks are his own doing. However, Obama's statements seem to be based on a selective memory, as he fails to acknowledge the significant economic and energy-related changes that have taken place during Trump's presidency.

Trump ran on a platform of economic growth, deregulation, and tax reform, which has led to a significant increase in economic growth and job creation. In contrast, Obama's administration focused on renewable energy sources and reducing the use of fossil fuels, which has not been as successful in achieving its goals.

Economists and experts have also weighed in on the matter, with some predicting that Trump's economic policies would lead to recession, while others have praised his efforts to boost economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has climbed about 7,000 points since Trump was elected, and unemployment has hit near-record lows.

It is worth noting that Obama's criticism of Trump's presidency is not unique, as many former presidents and vice presidents have also spoken out on current political issues. However, it is unclear whether Obama's criticism is motivated by a genuine desire to improve the country or simply a desire to relive his own presidency.

In conclusion, Obama's criticism of Trump's presidency is a case of selective memory, as he fails to acknowledge the significant changes that have taken place during Trump's presidency. It is unclear whether Obama's criticism is motivated by a genuine desire to improve the country or simply a desire to relive his own presidency.

Title: Polarizing Rhetoric in Presidential Campaigns: A Double-Edged Sword

The 2016 presidential election has seen a surge in polarizing rhetoric from candidates, with Republican contenders Donald Trump and Ted Cruz being the most notable examples. While some argue that this type of language is a key factor in their success, others believe it is a recipe for further division and polarization. The debate has sparked discussions about the impact of extreme rhetoric on American politics and society.

According to Frederick Mayer, a professor of public policy, political science, and environment at Duke University, both Trump and Cruz have tapped into widespread anxieties about American decline, terrorism, and perceived threats to the American way of life. Their messages have resonated with certain segments of the population, contributing to their high poll numbers.

However, others argue that this type of rhetoric can have a negative impact. Junior Adam Lemon, president of the Duke College Republicans, believes that extreme language is necessary for candidates to stand out in a crowded field. However, he also notes that cable news coverage of Trump's comments has boosted ratings.

Steve Hassey, communications director for Duke Democrats, attributes Trump's high poll numbers to his ubiquitous presence in the media. He notes that the polarizing nature of Trump's comments makes the coverage of him even more polarizing.

Despite the challenges, some remain optimistic about the possibility of bipartisan reform. Frederick Mayer believes that, despite the current polarization, there are still opportunities for discussion and cooperation on certain issues. On campus, there have been instances of bipartisan discussions, such as the Battle of the Brains debate hosted by Duke Student Government.

However, others acknowledge that there are barriers to fostering discussion between students of opposing political parties on campus. Adam Lemon notes that there are more liberals on campus than conservatives, and that conservatives are often afraid to express their opinions, leading to a lack of engagement.

Frederick Mayer attributes the polarization and lack of engagement to a deeper issue: a loss of trust in institutions and politicians. He believes that this lack of trust is a major obstacle to functional governance and that it is a problem that needs to be addressed.

Title: Concerns Over Trump's Handling of Protests and Military Deployment

Article:

Last week, the Trump administration faced criticism for its handling of protests and the deployment of military forces. The president's decision to use federal law enforcement to remove Americans who stood in his way of a photo-op sparked concerns over the erosion of First Amendment rights. The incident also raised questions about the role of the military in domestic conflicts.

The use of military forces to quell protests has been met with criticism from some lawmakers and military leaders. Secretary of Defense Mark Esper and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Mark A. Milley have been accused of blindly following the president's orders, despite the potential violation of constitutional rights. This has led to concerns about the military's role in domestic conflicts and the potential for abuse of power.

The article also highlights the concerns over Trump's handling of the military and his willingness to use it to achieve his political goals. The author, Tammy Duckworth, a former U.S. Army lieutenant colonel and combat veteran of the Iraq War, expressed her disappointment in the president's actions and the potential damage it could cause to the country.

The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of the upcoming elections and the need for Americans to make their voices heard at the ballot box. The author urges citizens to hold their elected officials accountable for their actions and to demand better leadership from those in power.

Title: Boy Scouts of America President Robert Gates Faces Backlash Over Support for Openly Gay Scoutmasters

Article:

Boy Scouts of America President Robert Gates has faced criticism from prominent evangelist Franklin Graham for his recent call to end the organization's ban on openly gay scoutmasters. Graham, son of famous televangelist Billy Graham, denounced Gates' decision, stating that it would put children at risk and undermine the organization's moral values.

Gates made the remarks during the scouts' annual meeting in Atlanta, where he argued that the current ban is unsustainable and that the organization must adapt to the changing societal norms. He emphasized that he does not plan to revoke the membership charters of local troops with gay adults in supervisory roles.

Graham, however, expressed strong opposition to Gates' stance, stating that the decision would "bend to LGBT activist groups" and put young, innocent boys at risk. He urged former Boy Scouts and parents involved in the organization to express their displeasure and consider withdrawing their support if Gates leads the organization down this path.

Gates' decision to support openly gay scoutmasters is a significant shift from the organization's previous stance. In 2013, the Boy Scouts of America voted to allow openly gay scouts, and Gates himself had previously stated that he would not broach the issue during his term as president, fearing it would cause a "formal, permanent split" in the organization.

The debate surrounding the issue has sparked mixed reactions, with some advocates for gay scouts welcoming Gates' remarks, while others with ties to the organization remain ambivalent. Some prominent companies, including Lockheed Martin and Walt Disney, have ended their partnerships with the scouts in protest of the ban.

Title: Trump Campaign Seeks to Capitalize on Impeachment Push with Dubious Fundraising Email

The Trump reelection campaign sent out a fundraising email on Tuesday, attempting to capitalize on the growing momentum behind the Democratic push for impeachment. The email urged supporters to join the "Official Impeachment Defense Task Force" and claimed that immediate contributions would result in donors being added to this task force. The email also promised that donations would be "double matched," a claim that is unlikely to be true due to federal campaign finance laws.

The email's language is designed to create a sense of urgency and importance, stating that the "future of American freedom rests on the shoulders of men and women willing to defend it from these hateful attacks." It also claims that President Trump has personally requested a list of people who have joined the task force and urges donors to send their money before a deadline.

However, experts note that campaigns have wide latitude to make promises in fundraising emails, and the claims made in this email do not have to be true. The email's pledge to "double match" donations is particularly suspect, as federal campaign finance laws impose strict limits on individual donations. It is unlikely that a single generous donor could match new small donations, as hundreds or thousands of donors would be needed to make a significant impact.

The Trump campaign did not respond to questions about its "Official Impeachment Defense Task Force," how many donors had joined, or how it planned to "double-match" their contributions. The email's language is designed to create a sense of urgency and importance, but the claims made in the email are likely exaggerated or misleading.

Title: Ringling Bros. Circus to Close After 100 Years of Operation

Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, a beloved institution in the entertainment industry, will be closing its curtains for the final time after over 100 years in operation. According to a press release from Feld Entertainment, the company that has owned the circus for the past 50 years, the decision to cease operations was made due to declining ticket sales and high operating costs.

The circus will hold its final performances in May, with a series of 30 shows scheduled across the United States before the curtains close. The decline in ticket sales was accelerated after the decision to remove elephants from the show, according to CEO Kenneth Feld.

The high operating costs and declining ticket sales made the circus an unsustainable business for the company, according to Feld. The decision to remove elephants from the show was made in 2015, and it appears that this change did not have the desired effect of boosting ticket sales.

The Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus has a rich history, dating back to its founding in 1919. The circus has entertained millions of people over the years, and its closure marks the end of an era in the entertainment industry.

Title: Senate Leaders Put Aside Differences to Honor Longest-Serving Republican Senator

Article:

In a rare display of bipartisanship, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Minority Leader Chuck Schumer put aside their differences to pay tribute to Senator Orrin Hatch, the longest-serving Republican senator in history. Hatch, who has served for 40 years, was recognized for his dedication and commitment to the Senate, as well as his ability to disagree without being disagreeable.

During the ceremony, McConnell praised Hatch's songwriting skills, noting that he has released gold and platinum albums. Schumer described Hatch as a "terrific guy" and an "honorable man," highlighting his ability to work across the aisle and find common ground with his opponents.

Hatch himself took the floor to express his gratitude and to urge his colleagues to work together. He acknowledged the slow pace of confirming President Trump's cabinet nominees and expressed hope that the Senate could find a way to set aside their differences and work together to address the country's challenges.

The senator also took a moment to reflect on his work with the late Senator Edward Kennedy, with whom he formed an unlikely friendship despite their ideological differences. Hatch praised Kennedy's ability to find common ground and work with his opponents, and expressed his own desire to see more of that spirit in the Senate today.

The ceremony was a brief respite from the partisan tensions that have dominated the Senate in recent weeks. The chamber adjourned at 2:30 a.m. after a party-line vote confirmed Tom Price as the next secretary of Health and Human Services.

Title: Trump Family Sues Deutsche Bank and Capital One to Block Subpoenas for Financial Records

The Trump family, including President Donald Trump, his sons, and daughter, have filed a lawsuit against Deutsche Bank and Capital One to block subpoenas issued by House Democrats seeking their financial records. The lawsuit, filed in New York, argues that the subpoenas serve "no legitimate or lawful purpose" and are intended to harass the Trump family and cause political damage.

The Trumps' lawyers claim that the subpoenas are overly broad and seek to rummage through their personal finances, businesses, and private information, going back decades. They argue that the House Financial Services and Intelligence Committees are seeking to intimidate the Trump family and undermine their privacy rights.

The lawsuit seeks to invalidate the subpoenas, which were issued as part of investigations into potential foreign influence on the U.S. political process and the abuse of the U.S. financial system for illicit purposes. Deutsche Bank, a German lender, has stated that it will comply with the subpoenas and provide the requested information.

The Trump family's lawyers, led by Marc Mukasey and Patrick Strawbridge, argue that the subpoenas violate the Right to Financial Privacy Act and are an invasion of privacy. They claim that the House committees are seeking to obtain every single financial transaction made by the Trump family, including checking withdrawals, credit-card swipes, and debit-card purchases, going back to the childhoods of individual Trumps.

The lawsuit comes as the Trump administration continues to fight against mounting House investigations into his administration, presidential campaign, and business empire. The Trump family's lawyers have vowed to fight all congressional subpoenas, accusing Democrats of trying to sully his presidency.

The House Financial Services and Intelligence Committees have responded to the lawsuit, calling it "meritless" and designed to delay accountability. The committees are seeking to obtain the Trump family's financial records as part of their investigations into potential foreign influence and financial abuse.

The lawsuit is the latest escalation in the Trump administration's fight against congressional investigations, which have been ongoing since the 2016 presidential election. The Trump family's lawyers are seeking to protect their privacy rights and prevent what they claim is an invasion of privacy.

Title: Manafort Jury Deliberates, Asks Judge Questions on Complex Case

The jury in the Paul Manafort trial has not yet reached a verdict, with deliberations ongoing since Thursday morning. The jurors spent the day discussing the case behind closed doors, but did not come to a conclusion. Instead, they sent Judge T.S. Ellis four questions, including one asking for a definition of "reasonable doubt" again.

The case against Manafort, a former campaign chairman for President Donald Trump, involves 18 counts of financial fraud and conspiracy. Prosecutors have presented hundreds of exhibits of evidence, and jurors must reach a unanimous verdict on each count. If they fail to do so, a mistrial will be declared for those counts.

The jury's questions to Judge Ellis included one on the definition of "reasonable doubt," which Ellis answered by stating that prosecutors do not need to prove their case beyond "all possible doubt," but rather beyond doubt based on reason. The judge also answered a question on whether someone would need to file an FBAR (Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts) if they owned less than 50% of a company and had no signatory authority over it. Ellis explained that if a person controlled the disposition of money from the account or was acting as an agent for another person, they would be required to file the FBAR.

The jury also asked about the definition of a "shelf company," which refers to a company with no apparent activity, often used in offshore financial transactions. Judge Ellis declined to provide a definition, instead instructing the jurors to rely on their collective recollection.

The jury's final question was about the exhibit list, which includes hundreds of pieces of evidence presented during the trial. They asked if they could get a list of which exhibits match up with each of the 18 charges against Manafort. Judge Ellis denied this request.

The jury's deliberations will continue, with the outcome of the case still uncertain.

Title: IRS Commissioner Blames "Fundamental Failure" for Loss of Public Trust

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) Commissioner, Daniel Werfel, has acknowledged that the agency has lost the public's trust due to a "fundamental failure" in management, which included the political targeting of conservative groups. In his first appearance before a Congressional committee, Werfel emphasized his primary mission to restore trust in the tax collection agency. He has ordered a review of a broad spectrum of IRS operations and installed new leadership at several critical levels of the agency, pledging to permanently fix the problems and be open and transparent with the American people.

The hearing was the fourth since the IRS Inspector General released a report in May, which revealed that during the 2010 and 2012 elections, groups with conservative-sounding names that applied for tax-exempt status were singled out for extended questioning by an IRS office in Cincinnati. Werfel called the conduct "inappropriate and unacceptable."

Members of Congress from both parties criticized the IRS misconduct, with Rep. Hal Rogers (R-KY) calling the agency's actions "grave violations of the public trust" and Rep. Ander Crenshaw (R-FL) criticizing "newly discovered incredible waste" in IRS spending on employee conferences and videos. The Inspector General's office is scheduled to release a report on the conferences on Tuesday, which is expected to show the IRS spent $50 million to hold 220 employee conferences between 2010 and 2012.

The IRS scandals come at a sensitive time for the agency, as it will play a key role in implementing the Affordable Care Act, President Obama's signature legislative achievement. The Obama administration is seeking a 9% increase in IRS funding for the federal budget year that starts in October. Representative Crenshaw said Congress will have to "think very carefully about how much money to provide the IRS."

Commissioner Werfel emphasized that the solution is not more money, but rather finding the "optimal footprint" for agency operations and then addressing funding. The political impact of the controversy has been on display, with Rep. Darrell Issa (R-CA) stating that interviews with workers in the Cincinnati IRS office show the targeting of conservative groups was "a problem that was coordinated in all likelihood right out of Washington headquarters – and we're getting to proving it."

Title: Iraqis Protest US Embassy in Baghdad, Chanting "Down, Down USA!" After US Airstrikes Against Iran-Backed Militia

Article:

A crowd of angry Iraqis protested outside the US Embassy in Baghdad on Tuesday, storming through a main gate and chanting "Down, Down USA!" in response to recent US airstrikes against an Iran-backed militia. The protesters, many of whom wore militia uniforms, set up tents outside the embassy and vowed to stage a sit-in until American troops leave Iraq and the embassy is closed.

The US Embassy compound was breached, with protesters entering the compound and setting fire to three trailers used by security guards. The US military responded by firing tear gas to disperse the crowd. The US has sent additional forces to bolster security at the embassy, and an Army Apache helicopter flew over the premises, dropping flares in a "show of force" to disperse the crowd.

The protests followed deadly US airstrikes on Sunday that killed 25 fighters of the Iran-backed Kataeb Hezbollah, which the US military said was in retaliation for last week's killing of an American contractor in a rocket attack on an Iraqi military base. The US military said the airstrikes were a "precision defensive strike" on five sites belonging to Kataeb Hezbollah.

The Iraqi government has condemned the US airstrikes, with Interior Minister Yassine al-Yasseri saying the prime minister had warned the US that the strikes would have serious consequences. The Iraqi government has deployed additional security forces to separate the protesters from the embassy, but has not intervened to break up the crowd.

The US Embassy has urged American citizens not to approach the compound and to review their personal security and emergency preparedness. The Embassy's Facebook page also warned that the situation is "fluid and unpredictable" and that "the security situation in Iraq remains volatile."

The protests are a response to the US airstrikes, which were seen as a escalation of tensions between the US and Iran. The US has said the airstrikes were necessary to protect American lives and interests, while Iran has condemned the strikes as an act of aggression.

Title: Hillary Clinton Outlines Priorities for First 100 Days as President

Hillary Clinton, a former First Lady, Senator, and Secretary of State, has outlined her priorities for her first 100 days as President. In a recent article, she emphasized the importance of building an economy that works for everyone, keeping America safe through strength and smarts, and coming together to build a stronger, fairer America.

Clinton highlighted four key issues she plans to address during her first 100 days in office. First, she aims to invest in infrastructure and manufacturing to grow the economy and create good jobs with rising incomes. She also plans to introduce comprehensive immigration reform legislation, which would keep families together, create a path to citizenship, and secure the border.

Second, Clinton intends to tackle the issue of secret, unaccountable money in politics by introducing a constitutional amendment to overturn Citizens United. She believes this will help protect citizens' rights to vote, not corporations' rights to buy elections.

Third, she wants to start working on end-to-end criminal justice reform, which would address the issue of people being sent away for too long for non-violent offenses. Finally, she plans to roll up her sleeves and get to work for American families, focusing on issues that matter to them.

Clinton emphasized that her opponent, Donald Trump, has run his campaign on divisiveness, fear, and insults, pitting Americans against each other. She believes that every issue Americans care about is on the ballot this year, and it's about who they are as a country and whether they will have change that makes them stronger together or pushes them further apart.

Clinton's commitment to creating good jobs with rising incomes will be a central mission of her presidency, and she plans to pay for it by asking the wealthy, Wall Street, and big corporations to pay their fair share.
