She believes that if Americans can dream it, they should be able to build it, and that this commitment will go beyond her first 100 days in office.

Overall, Hillary Clinton's priorities for her first 100 days as President focus on creating an economy that works for everyone, keeping America safe, and coming together to build a stronger, fairer America.

Title: House Intelligence Committee Republicans Launch "Phase 2" of Probe into Origins of Unverified Anti-Trump Dossier

The House Intelligence Committee Republicans have sent a letter to current and former officials, including former FBI Director James Comey, requesting information about the origins of the unverified anti-Trump dossier. The letter, obtained by Fox News, poses a series of questions about when officials learned the document was funded by Democratic sources and how it was used to obtain surveillance warrants at the secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court.

The letter, dated February 20, threatens to issue subpoenas if the requested information is not provided voluntarily. Committee Chairman Devin Nunes, R-Calif., is seeking information about when officials learned of the dossier's Democratic funding and whether they held meetings about the unverified allegations against Trump or took any official action.

The letter includes a dozen questions about the dossier, including how officials learned of the document's Democratic funding and whether they held meetings about the unverified allegations against Trump or took any other official action. The questionnaire was sent to about two dozen current and former officials, including Comey, former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, and former CIA Director John Brennan.

In a previous memo, Nunes alleged that the anti-Trump dossier was crucial in the application for a surveillance warrant against Trump associate Carter Page. Democrats have called the memo misleading and want to release a memo of their own, although they have been delayed by national security objections from the White House.

The new letter is part of "Phase 2" of the investigation, which Nunes announced earlier this month. The investigation is expected to scrutinize the State Department and other agencies. A source close to the investigation has not ruled out the possibility that more officials could be questioned as the next phase of the probe continues.

In related news, an Obama State Department official, Jonathan Winer, acknowledged having regular contact with the dossier's author, Christopher Steele, and shared over 100 of his reports with Russia experts at the State Department over a two-year period. Winer also shared Trump-related material passed on by a Clinton contact with Steele, which later made its way to the FBI.

Title: Trump's Tulsa Rally Falls Flat: Low Attendance Raises Questions About Campaign's Momentum

The highly anticipated rally by President Trump in Tulsa, Oklahoma, on Saturday failed to draw the expected crowd, with only around 6,200 attendees showing up. The event was seen as a crucial opportunity for the president to revitalize his reelection campaign, which has been struggling in recent months. However, the low turnout has sparked concerns about the president's ability to rally his base and win over undecided voters.

The rally's poor attendance has been attributed to various factors, including warnings from public health officials about the risk of spreading the coronavirus, as well as teenagers on TikTok claiming they made reservations but had no intention of attending. The president's campaign blamed protesters for blocking supporters from entering the arena, but this claim has been disputed by reporters on the ground.

The event's lackluster turnout has been met with mixed reactions from political analysts. Some see it as a sign that enthusiasm among Trump's base supporters has eroded, while others argue that it's too early to draw conclusions and that elections are not determined by rally crowds. The president's speech was also criticized for lacking a clear message on why voters should want him in office for another four years.

The small crowd size has raised questions about Trump's ability to manage the current crises, including the pandemic and social unrest, and whether he can effectively address the concerns of voters. The president's campaign is planning upcoming rallies in Florida, Texas, and North Carolina, but the poor turnout in Tulsa has added to the uncertainty surrounding his reelection chances.

Experts warn against drawing too many conclusions from a single event, especially during uncertain times. However, the rally's poor attendance has sparked concerns about the president's ability to rally his base and win over undecided voters.

Title: Secretary of State John Kerry Holds First Weekend of Meetings with World Leaders

Article:

In his first weekend as the 68th United States Secretary of State, John Kerry held a series of meetings and phone calls with world leaders, according to a readout released by the State Department. The conversations aimed to address various global issues, including the Middle East peace process, terrorism, and economic cooperation.

Kerry spoke with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu about the country's recent elections and the Middle East peace process. He also discussed Israeli-Palestinian relations with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas and vowed to continue efforts with Congress to send funds to the authority.

The Secretary of State also spoke with Israeli President Shimon Peres, with whom he has a long-standing relationship since his time as a freshman senator. Kerry discussed the recent terrorist attack on the U.S. Embassy in Ankara with Turkish Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu, who updated him on the investigation into the suicide bomber's identity. The bomber was identified as Ecevit Sanli, a member of the Marxist Leninist organization DHKP-C, which is considered a terrorist organization by the U.S. government.

Kerry also had discussions with other world leaders, including Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida and South Korean Foreign Minister Kim Sung-hwan, as well as Mexican Foreign Secretary Jose Meade. He expressed condolences for the victims of the explosion at the offices of the state oil company Pemex in Mexico City, which killed and injured many.

In addition, Kerry spoke with Canadian Foreign Minister John Baird, with whom he agreed to stay in touch on the Keystone XL pipeline project, which would extend from Canada's tar sands to the Gulf of Mexico. Construction on the southern portion of the pipeline has already begun, while the northern leg in the United States awaits approval.

Kerry also had lunch with former Secretary of State George Shultz, who served under President Ronald Reagan, and has now met or spoken with each living secretary of state.

Title: Republicans Hold Slight Advantage in Senate Control Fight, According to Latest Polling Data

The latest polling data suggests that Republicans have a slight advantage in the fight to take control of the Senate in November, with a 60% chance of picking up the six seats needed to regain control of the upper chamber, according to The New York Times. The YouGov online panel, considered one of the highest-quality, nonpartisan polling methods, indicates that Republicans have made gains in Michigan, Georgia, and North Carolina, but these shifts were offset by positive numbers for Democrats in Colorado and Alaska.

The Times' forecasting model, which incorporates surveys, fundraising data, and other information, suggests that Republicans have a slight lead in Arkansas, Louisiana, North Carolina, Iowa, and Michigan. However, the newspaper notes that these leads are not significant, indicating that the campaign remains up for grabs.

Polling techniques are critical to the accuracy of predictions, and declining response rates are creating less accurate predictions. The traditional method of random-digit dialing is becoming less effective, as young voters and nonwhite voters are less likely to respond to telephone surveys. The YouGov survey, which produced the first set of data from an online panel this year, is considered more accurate than traditional methods.

The Times concludes that Republicans appear to have narrow leads in enough states to win the Senate, but only narrow leads. The outcome of the election remains uncertain, and the campaign is expected to be closely contested.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Calls Special Election to Replace Late Senator Frank Lautenberg

Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey has announced a special election to replace the late Senator Frank Lautenberg, with the election set to take place on October 16. The decision has sparked debate and speculation about Christie's motivations, with some critics suggesting that he aimed to maximize his re-election chances by scheduling the special election separately from the general election in November.

According to Christie, the decision was driven solely by the importance of having an elected representative in the United States Senate, citing the significance of the current legislative agenda. He emphasized that the added costs of holding a special election, estimated to be around $12 million, were outweighed by the value of having an elected representative in the Senate.

However, critics have questioned Christie's motives, suggesting that he may have wanted to avoid a potential boost to his re-election prospects by scheduling the special election separately. Newark Mayor Cory Booker, a Democrat running for the Senate seat, could have drawn large numbers of energized Democrats to the polls, potentially cutting into Christie's expected victory margin in November.

While some have expressed skepticism about Christie's explanation, it remains unclear whether the governor's decision was driven by political considerations or a genuine desire to ensure representation in the Senate. The special election will take place on October 16, with voters set to choose a new senator to fill the seat left vacant by Lautenberg's passing.

Title: Obama and Xi Jinping Conclude Summit with Tentative Commitments on Cyberattacks and South China Sea

The summit between President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping concluded with commitments on two of the most sensitive issues: alleged Chinese cyberattacks on the U.S. and Chinese island-building in the South China Sea. The commitments from Beijing put off any immediate threat of the U.S. imposing sanctions on Chinese entities over cyberattacks or taking more robust military action around China's artificial islands.

The U.S. and China announced an agreement not to direct or support cyberattacks that steal corporate records for economic benefit, likely staving off the immediate prospect of U.S. sanctions. However, it was unclear how effective the measures would be. The U.S. officials reacted with caution to Mr. Xi's apparent commitment to not "militarize" the islands Beijing has been building in the South China Sea, where several of China's neighbors have conflicting territorial claims.

Mr. Obama had pressed Mr. Xi to freeze island-building in the Spratlys chain, which has raised concern in the U.S. and among its allies about Beijing's military ambitions. At the news conference, Mr. Xi repeated China's long-standing position that it has had sovereignty over the South China Sea islands "since ancient times." A senior U.S. administration official said Mr. Xi's commitment was new, although it sounded similar to statements made by lower-level officials to Secretary of State John Kerry over the summer.

Satellite imagery released Friday showed that China had recently completed a runway on one of its artificial islands, which could allow it to accelerate construction and begin air patrols in the area, according to IHS Jane's Defence Weekly. China has said in recent months that its new facilities on the islands are designed to improve living conditions, marine safety, and weather monitoring, but would also be used for military purposes.

The U.S. officials say China's facilities could be used to enforce territorial claims in the area and to establish an air defense identification zone over much of the South China Sea. Mr. Obama voiced concern over the issue, saying China is "now a powerhouse and that means it's got responsibilities" to help uphold international rules.

The summit also saw progress toward a far-reaching trade and investment agreement that would open up closed sectors of China's economy, U.S. officials said. The U.S. and China have held intense negotiations over cybersecurity measures after a series of computer breaches the White House has blamed on Beijing. U.S. officials have prepared economic sanctions against Chinese companies they believe benefited from information stolen as part of the cyberattacks, but have held off on implementing them.

The summit concluded with a joint statement from the two leaders, who pledged to "candidly" address issues on which they disagree. Mr. Xi called for the pursuit of "win-win cooperation" and said the U.S. and China are building a new model for major country relations.

Title: US Issues Waivers for Iran Nuclear Sanctions as "Adoption Day" Arrives

The United States has issued waivers for nuclear sanctions against Iran, marking the "adoption day" of the Iran Nuclear Deal. The move comes as Iran is tasked with reducing its nuclear program, as agreed upon in the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) signed by the US, the UK, France, Russia, China, Germany, and Iran.

According to the agreement, Iran must reduce its stockpiles of enriched uranium, dismantle two-thirds of its centrifuges, and halt construction of new nuclear facilities. Western officials expect this to take four to six months, with Iran motivated to act quickly.

The sanctions being lifted apply mainly to non-US citizens and companies doing business with Iran, while most sanctions will still apply to US citizens under separate sanctions imposed on Iran for its support of terrorism and human rights violations. Sales of civilian passenger aircraft and handicrafts, such as carpets, will be allowed.

The adoption day marks a milestone in the implementation of the JCPOA, with President Obama stating that it is a "calendar-driven event" rather than a reflection of any action by Iran. The agreement requires the US and the European Union to direct the issuance of waivers, which will only go into effect once Iran meets its obligations.

Despite renewed tensions with Iran over its involvement in Syria's civil war and its recent ballistic missile test, Obama maintained that these issues are separate from the need to ensure Iran does not develop a nuclear weapon. The US and international community will continue to monitor Iran's progress and put pressure on the country through bilateral channels to ensure compliance with the agreement.

Title: Mueller's Questions for Trump: A Recap of the Investigation's Focus Areas

The New York Times has obtained an exhaustive list of questions that special counsel Robert Mueller's office wants to ask President Donald Trump as part of their investigation into potential ties between the Trump campaign and the Russian government, as well as possible attempts to obstruct justice. The questions cover a range of topics, including Trump's knowledge of his associates' contacts with the Russian ambassador, his motivations behind the firing of FBI Director James Comey, and his contacts with Roger Stone.

The list of questions, obtained by Michael S. Schmidt of The New York Times, provides a broad overview of the lines of investigation Mueller is pursuing and how they intersect with the commander-in-chief himself. Most of the questions involve subjects that have been reported on publicly and serve as a recap of Trump administration controversies and the president's most explosive tweets and statements.

The questions include queries related to Michael Flynn, Trump's knowledge of his contacts with the Russian ambassador, and whether Trump had extended a possible offer to pardon his former national security adviser, who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI. Other questions delve into Trump's motivations behind the firing of FBI Director James Comey, the June 2016 Trump Tower meeting, and Trump's contacts with Roger Stone.

According to The New York Times, Mueller's team presented the list of questions to Trump's legal team as part of negotiations to get Trump to sit down with investigators. The president's lawyers transcribed the questions, which The New York Times obtained from a person outside Trump's legal team.

Mueller has reportedly been pushing to interview the president directly, something his lawyers have fretted over given the president's penchant for exaggeration and lying. Trump's top personal lawyer, John Dowd, resigned in March, following reports that Trump wasn't willing to listen to his legal advice, including about sitting for a Mueller interview. Rudy Giuliani, the former prosecutor, New York City mayor, and Trump confidant, brought onto the president's legal team in April, is reportedly now trying to decide whether a Mueller interview will go forward.

For the full list of Mueller questions, read The New York Times' exclusive here.

**Clinton Campaign Seeks to Preemptively Stop Sanders' Momentum**

The Hillary Clinton campaign has announced its pledged delegate lead has grown to 199, a significant margin that makes it challenging for Bernie Sanders to catch up. Despite this, Sanders is expected to add another small caucus state to his column, with Maine voting on Sunday. Clinton operatives have not made any overt calls for Sanders to suspend his campaign, but have continually highlighted the delegate math, hoping the deficit will make the argument itself.

Sanders' top aides and supporters have begun making a new argument to justify the long slog: it's great for Clinton. They argue that Sanders' participation in the process will boost turnout among Democratic voters and keep Clinton in the news, the alternative being ceding months of headlines to Donald Trump and the fractured Republican Party.

Clinton insiders are eager to begin recruiting Republicans turned off by the prospect of Trump, but the threat of Sanders sticking it out until June makes the general election pivot more difficult. Sanders' operatives contend that even if he can't win, his participation will bring millions of new people into the process, citing exit polls from Massachusetts that showed 17 percent of voters were new to the process and those voters overwhelmingly supported Sanders.

Democratic turnout could be a time bomb for the party, with about 3 million fewer Democrats voting in the 15 states that held primaries or caucuses through March 1 than did in 2008. Meanwhile, Trump's candidacy has turned out droves of new voters. Sanders' campaign believes that if he can turn out voters all across America, it's very important for the nominee and for Democrats up and down the ballot.

The question remains how constructive the rest of the primary will be for Clinton. Some argue that as long as she is winning and not forced to constantly try and maneuver to the left of Sanders, it's not a bad thing. Others believe that Sanders' participation will only help Trump, the angry populist, every day he remains a candidate.

Title: Media's Obsession with Trump: A Pathological Commitment to Collusion Fable

The media's relentless pursuit of anti-Trump narratives has become a staple of modern journalism. The latest iteration of this phenomenon is the re-emergence of Russian collusion claims, which have been met with skepticism by many. The article argues that the media's fixation on these claims is a testament to their commitment to a "collusion fable" that has been perpetuated through repetition and manipulation.

The author contends that the media's obsession with Trump's supposed connections to Russia is a distraction from more pressing issues and a reflection of their own biases. They point out that the media's coverage of Trump's presidency has been marked by a lack of nuance and a reliance on sensationalism.

The article also criticizes the media's treatment of Trump's statements, claiming that they are often taken out of context and distorted to fit a predetermined narrative. The author argues that Trump's opponents, including some Republicans, have played a significant role in perpetuating these myths and reinforcing the media's narrative.

The article concludes by suggesting that the media's obsession with Trump is a form of "propaganda" designed to shape public opinion and undermine the president's credibility. The author argues that this kind of journalism is not only unfair but also damaging to the media's reputation and the public's trust.

Title: Republicans Scramble to Stop Trump's Momentum in Presidential Primary

The Republican Party is facing a new reality as the primary season unfolds, with Donald Trump emerging as the frontrunner. The party's strategy to protect an establishment candidate by frontloading the primaries and caucuses has backfired, leaving Trump with a significant lead. With only 20 states remaining before the first Tuesday in June, the anti-Trump forces are running out of opportunities to derail his momentum.

To stop Trump, Republicans must focus on two key strategies: keeping the field populated and Trump under 50 percent. The latest NBC News/SurveyMonkey Weekly Election Poll suggests that Trump's opponents, Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, would struggle to beat him in a head-to-head contest. Instead, they must focus on drawing straws to decide who will attack Trump and who will support him.

Another crucial strategy is to keep Trump under 50 percent of the delegates needed to win the nomination. With 1,744 delegates remaining, Trump must be stopped in winner-take-all states like Florida and Ohio. The two most important states are Florida and Ohio, where Trump leads, and Texas, which has a system where a 50% majority winner earns all the delegates.

Additionally, Republicans must focus on showdown states like Wisconsin, Indiana, and California, where Trump's opponents can try to slow down his momentum. Wisconsin's April 5 primary and Indiana's May 3 primary are crucial, as they could be opportunities for Trump's opponents to gain ground.

Finally, if Trump goes to the convention close to but shy of a guaranteed first-ballot victory, the anti-Trump forces must outmaneuver him by stacking the deck with delegates willing to bail on Trump once their commitment is over. This would require a pragmatic approach, shopping for voters willing to become delegates and open to switching candidates at the convention.

While it's still possible to stop Trump, it requires a lot of odd-shaped pieces to fall into place. The Republican Party must act quickly to intervene at the grassroots level and shop for voters willing to become delegates and switch candidates at the convention.

Title: Clinton's Lead Narrows as FBI Investigation and New Emails Dominate Election News

The US presidential election is heating up as Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton's lead is dwindling, coinciding with a resurgence in support for Republican candidate Donald Trump. The FBI's recent investigation into Clinton's use of a private email server while serving as secretary of state has sparked a new wave of scrutiny, with some polls showing her average lead halved since the last presidential debate.

The latest development comes as Trump's campaign has been gaining momentum, thanks in part to the release of emails from Clinton's campaign chairman, John Podesta, which have been trickling out for weeks. While the contents of these emails have been mostly embarrassing rather than damaging, they have given Trump supporters fresh ammunition to attack Clinton.

The FBI's investigation has also shed new light on the Clinton family's blurred lines between their business, charitable, and political interests. Although most of the new information relates to Bill Clinton, it has given Trump supporters a new angle to attack Hillary Clinton.

Pollsters and observers agree that the election is now an unpopularity contest, and it doesn't take much to swing the mood of independent voters. The combination of no news from Trump and bad news from Clinton has already halved her average lead in the polls.

While Clinton still maintains a 3.4% average lead in national polls, some Democrats are expressing concern that few polls were conducted after the news broke about the FBI and the emails. An ABC News-Washington Post tracking poll released on Sunday showed a one-point overall lead for Clinton, with some voters saying the news has hardened their opinions.

The poll found that about a third of likely voters say they are less likely to support Clinton given the FBI's disclosure, while 63% say it makes no difference. Only 7% of Clinton supporters felt it would make a difference, but this rises among groups already predisposed not to vote for her.

The potential for a pullback in motivation of Clinton supporters or further resurgence among Trump's supporters may cause concern in the Clinton camp, especially since this dynamic was already underway. The notion that the FBI may not change any minds but will bolster opinion and perhaps turnout was also supported in a poll of voters in 13 battleground states.

The risk of a pullback in motivation among Clinton supporters and the potential for further resurgence among Trump's supporters may cause concern in the Clinton camp.

Title: The Real Threat to the Republic: National Debt and Entitlement State

The article discusses the importance of recognizing the true threats to the Republic, which are not the rituals and spectacles of politics, but rather the growing national debt and entitlement state. The author draws parallels between the decline of the Roman Empire and the current state of the United States, highlighting the dangers of ignoring the fundamental problems and instead focusing on symbolic gestures.

The article notes that the Roman Empire's decline was caused by the accumulation of debt driven by entitlements, which is a similar problem facing the United States today. The author argues that the real threat to the Republic is not the gladiatorial contests of politics, but rather the barbarian horde of debt and entitlement.

The article also highlights the disconnect between the rituals of governance and the reality of the situation. The author notes that the presidential budget proposal is an example of this disconnect, with politicians and activists focusing on symbolic gestures rather than addressing the fundamental problems.

The article concludes by emphasizing the need for a more realistic approach to governance, rather than relying on rituals and spectacles. The author notes that the real threat to the Republic is the growing national debt and entitlement state, and that ignoring this problem will only lead to further decline.

Title: Jeb Bush to "Actively Explore" Running for President in 2016

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush announced on his social media accounts that he will "actively explore" running for President of the United States in 2016. In a statement, Bush explained that he had been having conversations with his family about the future of the nation and, after thoughtful consideration, decided to explore the possibility of running for the highest office.

Bush also announced that he will establish a Leadership PAC in January to facilitate conversations with citizens across America and support leaders, ideas, and policies that will expand opportunity and prosperity for all Americans. This move is seen as a preliminary step for prospective presidential candidates, similar to Florida Senator Marco Rubio, who formed his own PAC, Reclaim America, after being elected to the Senate in 2010.

Bush's announcement comes after he fell short in the 1994 elections against Democrat Lawton Chiles, but he was later elected governor of Florida in 1998 and served two terms. If successful, he would be the third member of his immediate family to serve as Commander-in-Chief, following his father, George H. W. Bush, and his brother, George W. Bush. His son, George P. Bush, was recently elected as Texas' next Land Commissioner.

Bush did not specify when he will make a final decision about officially entering the race, but the formation of a Leadership PAC is seen as a crucial step for prospective candidates.

Title: Virginia Democrats Face Backlash for Politicizing Charlottesville Tragedy

Article: The Virginia gubernatorial race is heating up as the election draws near, with the Democratic candidate, Lt. Gov. Ralph Northam, facing criticism for a mailer that some have deemed "stomach-turning" for politicizing the Charlottesville tragedy. The mailer, which features a photo of the white supremacist Tiki-torch marchers, condemns Republican candidate Ed Gillespie for not speaking out against President Trump's "good people on both sides" comment made on August 12. However, Gillespie had already denounced the white supremacists before the rally took place.

The Northam campaign's move to tie Gillespie to the unpopular president is seen as a desperate attempt to gain an advantage in a close race. The Richmond Times-Dispatch, which endorsed Gillespie, slammed the Democratic campaign for the mailer, calling it "practically libel." The Daily Progress, a Charlottesville-based paper, also criticized the Northam campaign for using the tragedy to score political points.

Gillespie had issued a strongly worded response to the Charlottesville tragedy, and Virginia newspapers have praised him for his actions. The Daily Progress described the Northam campaign's tactics as "stomach-turning" and criticized them for politicizing the tragedy. The article concludes that while it is fair to challenge Gillespie on his stance on the Trump agenda, exploiting the tragedy for political gain is unacceptable.

Title: Constitutional Debate: Does the Pardon Clause Prohibit Commuting Sentences of Impeachment-Related Crimes?

The debate surrounding the scope of the pardon clause in the United States Constitution has sparked a heated discussion among legal scholars and constitutional experts. A strong argument, rooted in the Constitution's text, history, and structure, suggests that the phrase "except in cases of impeachment" not only prohibits the prevention or undoing of an impeachment but also bans a president from using the pardon and reprieve power to commute the sentences of individuals directly associated with any impeachment charges against them.

This argument is not partisan, as it would apply to future presidents, regardless of political affiliation. The impeachment charges against President Trump focused on his alleged withholding of foreign aid and refusal to cooperate with the congressional investigation, as well as his "previous invitations of foreign interference in United States elections" and "previous efforts to undermine United States Government investigations into foreign interference in United States elections."

According to this interpretation, President Trump would not be able to use the pardon and reprieve power to commute the sentences of those charged with crimes related to Russian interference in the 2016 campaign, including Roger Stone, who was convicted of lying to Congress and obstructing its investigation into Russian election interference. This obstruction impeded the ability of Congress to gather information that could have been vital to the impeachment inquiry, benefiting Trump.

The interpretation stems from the fact that the Constitution's Framers were deeply concerned about presidents abusing power to protect co-conspirators. As an example, Edmund Randolph, a Virginia delegate, voiced concerns about the pardon clause at the Constitutional Convention, stating that the president may be guilty of treason and that the pardon power could be used to protect his own instruments.

The votes of Randolph's fellow delegates on the wording of the pardon clause at the convention reflect the overarching concern to curb the president's power. On August 25, 1787, delegates voted on the matter, and as it stood, the president had the power to grant reprieves and pardons. Unanimously, the delegates voted to insert "except in cases of impeachment" after the word pardon, which is the language we are familiar with today. Directly afterward, they rejected the addition of the phrase "but his pardon shall not be pleadable in bar" in a six-to-four vote.

These votes reflect more than merely semantic differences. The language "his pardon shall not be pleadable in bar" was pulled directly from the British, banning the king from pardoning officials who were being impeached, but did not prevent him from pardoning officials after their impeachment. The traditional interpretation of the meaning of "except in cases of impeachment" is that it simply removed this loophole, preventing presidential pardons both during and after impeachment and conviction. However, the Framers' rejection of the British phrase after having inserted "except in cases of impeachment" strongly suggests that the American delegates saw the new phrase as having a meaning distinct from the traditional interpretation.

If "except in cases of impeachment" already covered both of those limits on presidential pardons, why would the Framers then need to vote on whether to include the British language – language that would have merely imposed the first limit they'd already unanimously approved? Given the unclear record of what the Framers meant to do that day, any interpretation of its meaning based only on the evidence we have about the day the phrase was adopted is speculative at best.

Title: Washington Navy Yard Shooting: A Cautionary Tale of Avoiding Speculation

The recent shooting at the Washington Navy Yard, which left at least 12 people dead and several others wounded, has sent shockwaves across the nation. As the investigation is still in its early stages, it is essential to exercise caution and avoid jumping to conclusions about the motives and circumstances surrounding the incident.

The author, who lived through the 2002 "Beltway sniper" attacks, emphasizes the importance of not speculating about the cause of the shooting. The DC snipers, John Allen Muhammad and Lee Boyd Malvo, had unclear motives, and their attacks took place during a time of heightened anxiety and fear. The author notes that the media and the public should not make assumptions about the motives or circumstances of the Washington Navy Yard shooting until more information is available.

The article also highlights the increased awareness of gun violence in America since the 2002 sniper attacks and the more recent mass shootings at Sandy Hook Elementary School, a movie theater in Aurora, and a military base in Fort Hood. The author suggests that the public should wait patiently for credible information and not rush to draw conclusions.

The article concludes by encouraging Americans to reflect on the incident and consider the broader questions surrounding gun violence, mental health, and public safety. The author notes that if the shooting is an act of terrorism, the country should examine how to combat the diffuse threat of individuals becoming radicalized and perpetrating violence on US soil. If it is another case of a disturbed individual with grievances or mental illness, the country should examine issues of mental health, gun control, and access to firearms.

Overall, the article serves as a reminder to avoid speculation and wait for credible information to emerge before drawing conclusions about the Washington Navy Yard shooting.

Title: Role Models for Professional Appearance: Lessons from Women Leaders

The article discusses the importance of appearance in the workplace and public space, particularly in the context of social media and the increasing scrutiny of public figures. The author argues that women like Hillary Rodham Clinton, Julia Gillard, and Kirsten Gillibrand, who have navigated traditionally male-dominated environments, can serve as role models for professional appearance. The article highlights the significance of appearance in the digital age, where pictures are widely shared and judgments are made quickly.

The author suggests that women who have been in the public eye, such as politicians and business leaders, have had to consider how their image affects their relationships and perception. They have likely made decisions about their wardrobe choices, balancing functionality and comfort with professional expectations. In contrast, celebrities like Jennifer Lawrence, Nicole Kidman, and Rihanna may not be the best role models for professional appearance, as their fashion choices are often curated for red-carpet events or charity appearances.

The article also notes that women who have become fashion icons due to their public roles, such as Michelle Obama and the Duchess of Cambridge, are not necessarily representative of women in more practical professional roles. Instead, the author suggests that women like Christine Lagarde, Sheryl Sandberg, Indra Nooyi, and Mary Barra, who are leaders in their respective fields, could serve as better role models for professional appearance. However, the author acknowledges that these women may not discuss their fashion choices publicly due to concerns about being taken seriously.

The article concludes that embracing the importance of appearance and discussing it openly can help to address the issue and move forward.

Title: UN Survey Reveals Global Priorities: Climate Change Ranks Low on List

A recent United Nations survey of 6.7 million people from 193 countries and the Palestinian territories has shed light on the global community's priorities. The online poll, which went live in March, asked citizens to rank 16 subjects in order of importance. The results show that education took the top spot, while climate change ranked last.

The survey's findings are consistent across various demographics, including age, sex, and education level. In the United States, climate change ranked 10th in priority, while in Britain, it ranked 9th. The survey results are available on the Watts Up With That website, which covers global warming and climate change news.

Meanwhile, delegates to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, meeting in Lima, Peru, are facing difficulties in reaching a final agreement by the end of the forum on Friday. The Associated Press reported that the momentum from the historic U.S.-China pact to resist global warming is showing signs of fading, as the familiar rich-poor conflict persists over who should take action to address climate change.

The U.S.-China agreement, reached in November, commits the United States to real cuts in greenhouse gases, while China has made a promise to cut pollution. Foreign Policy recently reviewed the agreement and concluded that China's commitments are minimal.

Title: White House Blocks Lev Parnas Testimony in Senate Impeachment Trial

The White House has announced its intention to block Lev Parnas, a Rudy Giuliani associate, from testifying in the Senate impeachment trial, according to a report by the Wall Street Journal on Monday. Parnas, who was involved in Giuliani's efforts to gather dirt on Joe Biden, made explosive claims about President Trump's involvement in Ukraine during a series of interviews released on Wednesday.

In the interviews, Parnas stated that President Trump was aware of all his movements and would not have taken any actions without the consent of Giuliani or the President. Parnas also accused Attorney General William Barr of being aware of Giuliani's and Trump's actions, but Barr denied having any knowledge of such dealings.

During the House impeachment hearings, former U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch testified that Parnas and his associate Igor Fruman, along with Giuliani, were working to oust her in order to advance their business interests. The two are also believed to have worked with former top Ukrainian prosecutor Yuriy Lutsenko to obtain information on the Bidens.

Parnas was indicted in October on campaign-finance charges and is accused of disguising donations to Republican candidates to advance his personal interests and those of other Ukrainian politicians.

The President's impeachment defense team, led by attorneys Alan Dershowitz and Ken Starr, has announced its intention to "swiftly reject" the articles of impeachment and acquit the President. In a trial brief, the team stated that the House Democrats have failed to prove any wrongdoing by the President and that the Senate should reject the articles of impeachment.

Democrats have alleged that President Trump withheld military aid from Ukraine to pressure the country to investigate corruption allegations against Joe and Hunter Biden.

Title: Barr Assures Senators He Won't Interfere with Mueller Investigation

Washington - William Barr, President Donald Trump's attorney general nominee, met with Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-SC) ahead of his confirmation hearings, scheduled for next week. During their meeting, Barr assured Graham that he will not interfere with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation.

According to Graham, Barr answered "no" to questions about whether he believes Mueller is on a witch hunt, whether he would be fair to the president and the country, and whether he sees any reason to stop or terminate the investigation. Barr also committed to ensuring Mueller can finish his job.

The news comes as Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who has been overseeing the investigation, announced his plans to step down after Barr is confirmed. Some Democrats have expressed concerns about Barr's previous statements criticizing the investigation, specifically a memo he wrote to Rosenstein calling the probe "fatally misconceived."

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) and Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) have called for Barr to recuse himself from the Mueller probe, citing his memo as a reason. However, Graham has dismissed these concerns, noting that Barr and Mueller are good friends who have known each other for over 20 years and their wives attend a Bible study together.

Graham assured that Barr has a high opinion of Mueller and is committed to letting him finish his job. The confirmation hearings for Barr are set to take place next week.

Title: John Hinckley, Who Attempted to Kill a President, Wins Freedom

A federal judge in Washington, D.C., has granted John Hinckley Jr.'s request to leave the mental hospital where he has resided for decades and live full-time with his elderly mother in Williamsburg, Virginia. The 61-year-old Hinckley, who attempted to assassinate President Ronald Reagan in 1981, will be allowed to live on his own or in a group home after one year, under the terms of the order. However, he is not permitted to contact his victims, their relatives, or actress Jodie Foster, with whom he was obsessed.

Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity for the March 30, 1981, attack outside the Washington Hilton Hotel, in which President Reagan was seriously injured and his press secretary, James Brady, was shot in the head. A year after the attack, a court ruled that Hinckley was not responsible for his actions due to his mental illness.

The Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and Institute have expressed opposition to Hinckley's release, stating that they believe he still poses a threat to others. However, Saint Elizabeths Hospital, where Hinckley has been treated for the past decade, reports that he no longer presents a danger to himself or others, and his depression and psychosis are in full remission.

Hinckley's lawyer, Barry William Levine, argued that his client is entitled to live under the least restrictive conditions, consistent with public safety. The judge's order includes conditions that Hinckley will not consume alcohol, illegal drugs, possess firearms, or travel to areas where the current president or members of Congress are present.

The Justice Department has expressed concerns about Hinckley's potential to reoffend, citing his narcissistic personality disorder and the risk that he may not be able to change his behavior. However, Hinckley's family members have promised to monitor his behavior and ensure he does not pose a threat to others.

Title: Harvard Freshman's Visa Revoked After Immigration Officials Question Him About Friends' Social Media Posts

A 17-year-old Palestinian refugee, Ismail B. Ajjawi, had his visa revoked and was deported back to Lebanon after landing at Boston Logan International Airport on Friday night. Ajjawi was scheduled to start his freshman year at Harvard University, where he intended to study Chemical and Physical Biology.

According to Ajjawi, he was subjected to hours of questioning by immigration officials, who searched his phone and computer, and confronted him about his friends' social media posts sharing anti-US political views. He claimed that he was held for eight hours at the airport, with five hours of questioning, before his visa was revoked.

Ajjawi stated that he was questioned about his religion and religious practices in Lebanon, and that an immigration officer asked him to unlock his phone and laptop, which were searched for five hours. The officer then asked him about his friends' social media activity, citing posts that were against the US. Ajjawi denied any involvement with the posts, explaining that he had no control over his friends' online activities.

Despite his defense, the immigration officer canceled Ajjawi's visa and told him he would be deported. Ajjawi is now back in Lebanon and is in contact with a lawyer and the university, hoping to resolve the issue before classes start on September 3.

The U.S. Customs and Border Protection stated that Ajjawi was deemed "inadmissible" to the country, citing information discovered during the CBP inspection. Harvard University is working to bring Ajjawi back to campus, and the university's International Office is providing legal assistance.

Ajjawi's story has sparked controversy, with some criticizing the decision to revoke his visa and deport him. His friend Selah Chehade described the act as "unfair" and "not appropriate." Ajjawi's revoked visa comes after he was featured in a local news story about his success story, from being a refugee in Lebanon to getting into Harvard on a full scholarship.

Title: Republicans to Face Painful Self-Examination if Romney Loses Election

Article:

The Republican Party is bracing for a potentially painful process of self-examination and internal debate if Mitt Romney loses the 2012 presidential election. Despite being considered a vulnerable incumbent, President Barack Obama's strengths on national security and personal likability have made him a formidable opponent. If Romney loses, the Republican Party will need to explain what went wrong and determine how to approach governing and campaigning in the future.

The debate will not only be a topic of interest for political enthusiasts but will also have implications for the party's strategy and messaging in the years to come. Even before the election, arguments about Romney's potential loss are already emerging.

If Romney wins, he will be the President of the United States. If he loses, he will be the scapegoat for the entire Republican Party. Republicans were not thrilled about nominating Romney in the first place, partly due to his moderate stance and partly due to his perceived ineptness in the 2008 primaries. Romney's campaign has been marked by missteps, including his response to the Affordable Care Act ruling, his comments about the British, and his criticism of Americans who don't pay income taxes.

On a deeper level, Romney was a problematic candidate for 2012. As a candidate closely tied to Wall Street, he may have been more vulnerable to attacks about being a "wealthy plutocrat" and his wife's equestrian pursuits. Former Mississippi Governor Haley Barbour noted in August that Democrats had successfully branded Romney as such.

Title: Deficit Reduction Experts Discuss Stalled Talks on "Fiscal Cliff"

The "Face the Nation" program on Sunday featured deficit reduction experts Erskine Bowles and Alan Simpson discussing the stalled talks in Washington over the "fiscal cliff." Despite the lack of progress between President Obama and House Speaker John Boehner on how to avert end-of-year spending cuts and tax hikes that could throw the economy back into recession, Bowles expressed optimism, stating he is "more encouraged" than he had previously been.

Bowles, who co-chaired President Obama's fiscal commission in 2010, noted that both sides have taken positions that differ from previously hardened stances. He praised Boehner's willingness to increase taxes and the president's openness to cut entitlements. However, Bowles emphasized that the president's proposal to cut around $350 billion to Medicare is "not enough."

Simpson, a former senator from Wyoming and co-chair of the president's fiscal commission, agreed that entitlements are the engine driving the country towards the fiscal cliff. He noted that the AARP and other senior groups will have depleted the treasury in 30 years due to the rising cost of healthcare and the number of baby boomers aging into entitlement programs.

Simpson advocated for raising taxes through tax reform, which should take place after the New Year. He emphasized that entitlements must be reformed, stating that "if anybody out there who is, quote, rich doesn't think their taxes go up, the drinks are on me."

Both Bowles and Simpson, who became prominent voices in the deficit reduction debate in 2010, warned that going over the "fiscal cliff" would be a "disaster" and slow the economy by four percent. Simpson also criticized lawmakers who are playing politics with the "fiscal cliff," calling their actions "terribly bizarre and juvenile."

Title: Former Trump Strategist Steve Bannon Warns of Impeachment Threat to Trump's Presidency

Article:

Steve Bannon, former chief strategist to President Donald Trump, has warned that impeachment is a "mortal threat" to the president's presidency. In an interview with The Post, Bannon stated that he believes House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is "very focused" and that Trump will likely be impeached within the next six weeks. Bannon also expressed dismay at the uncoordinated approach of the White House to the impeachment inquiry, citing a recent press conference by Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney as an example.

Bannon advised the White House to establish an impeachment squad and augment the legal team to focus on the issue 24/7. He also suggested that Trump should not rely on surrogates like Mulvaney or Rudy Giuliani, but instead bring in people to share the burden.

Regarding the 2020 presidential election, Bannon remains bullish about Trump's chances, dismissing the current crop of Democratic candidates. He predicted a total implosion by the end of the year for former Vice President Joe Biden and a centrist revolt against Senator Elizabeth Warren. If Biden falters and Warren appears to be marching toward nomination, Bannon believes that Mike Bloomberg or Hillary Clinton could enter the race, making them stronger contenders.

Bannon also discussed the importance of the Democratic Party's strategy, stating that whoever becomes the nominee will need to focus on swing states like Arizona, Texas, Georgia, and the Carolinas, as well as Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin. He also touched on his growing interest in China, which he views as the primary threat to the United States.

It is worth noting that Bannon's comments on the impeachment inquiry and the 2020 election are based on his personal opinions and do not reflect the official stance of the White House or any other political entity.

Title: FBI Lawyer Suspected of Altering Document Related to Trump Campaign Surveillance

The FBI is investigating an allegation that one of its lawyers altered a document related to the surveillance of former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page. The news comes as the Justice Department inspector general is set to release a report on December 9 that is expected to revive debate about the FBI's Russia investigation.

According to a person familiar with the situation, the FBI lawyer is suspected of altering the document, which is part of a review of the FBI's Russia investigation. The investigation was launched in 2016 and was taken over by special counsel Robert Mueller, who charged six Trump associates and more than two dozen Russians with interfering in the 2016 election.

The FBI obtained a secret surveillance warrant in 2016 to monitor the communications of Page, who was never charged in the Russia investigation or accused of wrongdoing. The warrant was renewed several times and approved by different judges in 2016 and early 2017.

President Donald Trump has long attacked the FBI's investigation as a "hoax" and a "witch hunt," and has seized on any findings of mistakes or bad judgment in the report to support his claims. Supporters of the FBI are likely to hold up any findings that the investigation was done by the book or free of political considerations.

The investigation is expected to find mistakes by lower-level officials within the FBI but will not accuse senior leaders of being motivated by political bias. The FBI and the inspector general declined to comment on the allegations.

The FBI's investigation was launched in 2016 after the agency received information that Trump campaign adviser Carter Page had met with a Russian intelligence officer during a trip to Moscow. The investigation was taken over by special counsel Robert Mueller, who charged six Trump associates and more than two dozen Russians with interfering in the 2016 election.

The FBI obtained a secret surveillance warrant in 2016 to monitor the communications of Page, who was never charged in the Russia investigation or accused of wrongdoing. The warrant was renewed several times and approved by different judges in 2016 and early 2017.

The investigation is expected to revive debate about the FBI's Russia investigation, which has been a contentious issue since the beginning. The FBI's investigation was launched in 2016 after the agency received information that Trump campaign adviser Carter Page had met with a Russian intelligence officer during a trip to Moscow. The investigation was taken over by special counsel Robert Mueller, who charged six Trump associates and more than two dozen Russians with interfering in the 2016 election.

The FBI obtained a secret surveillance warrant in 2016 to monitor the communications of Page, who was never charged in the Russia investigation or accused of wrongdoing. The warrant was renewed several times and approved by different judges in 2016 and early 2017.

The investigation is expected to find mistakes by lower-level officials within the FBI but will not accuse senior leaders of being motivated by political bias. The FBI and the inspector general declined to comment on the allegations.

The FBI's investigation was launched in 2016 after the agency received information that Trump campaign adviser Carter Page had met with a Russian intelligence officer during a trip to Moscow. The investigation was taken over by special counsel Robert Mueller, who charged six Trump associates and more than two dozen Russians with interfering in the 2016 election.

The FBI obtained a secret surveillance warrant in 2016 to monitor the communications of Page, who was never charged in the Russia investigation or accused of wrongdoing. The warrant was renewed several times and approved by different judges in 2016 and early 2017.

The investigation is expected to revive debate about the FBI's Russia investigation, which has been a contentious issue since the beginning.

Title: Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke to Leave Administration at End of Year

The Trump administration announced on Saturday that Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke will be leaving his position at the end of the year. President Trump commended Zinke for his service, stating that he had accomplished much during his nearly two-year tenure.

The president also announced that a new Secretary of the Interior will be announced next week. One potential replacement being considered is Senator Joe Manchin III, a West Virginia Democrat who recently won re-election. An influential strategist suggested that Manchin would be a likely choice, as he would be willing to "toe the line" with Trump's policies.

Zinke's departure is part of a year-end shakeup at the White House, following the recent departures of Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Chief of Staff John Kelly. Zinke's job had been under intense scrutiny for months, with investigations and scandals surrounding his use of government planes and an alleged shady land deal in his hometown of Whitefish, Montana.

The Interior Department inspector general referred the land deal scandal to the Justice Department, and Representative Raul Grijalva, the incoming chair of the House Natural Resources Committee, has vowed to investigate the matter. Environmental groups have been critical of Zinke's tenure, with the Center for Biological Diversity calling him the "worst Interior secretary in history" due to his "slash-and-burn approach" to public lands and wildlife.

Title: Primary Voting Results: Clinton's Momentum Slows, Trump's Stays Strong, and Sanders Defies Expectations

The latest primary voting results have brought mixed news for the leading candidates, with Hillary Clinton's momentum slowing, Donald Trump's staying strong, and Bernie Sanders defying expectations. Clinton was expected to extend her Super Tuesday dominance to Mississippi and Michigan, but it was Sanders who won Michigan, while Trump's momentum stalled in Kentucky and Louisiana.

In Michigan, Sanders defied expectations by winning the state, despite Clinton's late attacks on his voting record on the auto industry bailout. Sanders also won an overwhelming number of counties throughout the state and took 87% of the votes of those under 30. Clinton, on the other hand, failed to win the county that is home to Flint, the city with lead-poisoned water that she had made the focus of her campaign.

Trump, despite losing late-deciders in Kentucky and Louisiana, still won the states due to the large number of early voters who supported him. His campaign's momentum was expected to stall due to the millions of dollars in attack ads paid for by rivals and independent super PACs opposed to his nomination.

John Kasich, the Ohio governor, went all-in for Michigan in hopes of generating momentum ahead of his do-or-die primary in his home state on March 15, but finished third, a hair or two behind Texas Sen. Ted Cruz. Cruz has now racked up delegates and is just 99 behind Trump. Marco Rubio, on the other hand, had a night of total frustration, finishing third or worse in multiple states and winning zero delegates.

The results have made it difficult for Sanders to overcome Clinton's delegate lead, even if he continues to best her in the voting booths from here through June. Sanders needs to make a habit of winning by wider margins than his breakthrough in Michigan gave him. Despite the challenges, Sanders has defied expectations and remains a strong contender in the race.

Title: Celebrating American Democracy: A Call to Action on Voting Rights

The Electoral College vote has ratified the results of the 2016 presidential election, with Donald Trump emerging as the winner. While some may be unhappy with the outcome, Joshua A. Douglas, a law professor at the University of Kentucky College of Law, argues that the process worked as intended. In an op-ed for CNN, Douglas emphasizes that the Electoral College system is a crucial part of American democracy, and that the electors' votes reflect the will of the people in each state.

Douglas acknowledges that various factors, such as Russian interference and FBI Director James Comey's announcement about Hillary Clinton's emails, may have influenced the campaign. However, he notes that these factors did not prevent people from voting, and that the election ultimately reflects the will of the people.

The real issue, according to Douglas, is not the Electoral College system, but rather the barriers to voting that many Americans face. He highlights the importance of protecting and defending the right to vote, particularly for those who are not registered, face strict voter ID requirements, or are affected by felon disenfranchisement laws.

Douglas also suggests that the Electoral College system is anti-democratic and has outlived its purpose. However, he acknowledges that it is currently the system in place and that it represents a reasoned judgment that the president should have the support of wide geographic areas of the country.

In conclusion, Douglas urges Americans to focus on the real battle that can save democracy: exercising the fundamental right to vote. He encourages people to channel their energies into making a difference by working to remove barriers to voting and encouraging civic participation, especially among younger generations.

Title: President Trump Unveils New Afghanistan Strategy, Emphasizing Flexibility and Tougher Stance on Pakistan

Article:

President Donald Trump unveiled his new strategy for Afghanistan on Monday evening, announcing tweaks to the current approach rather than a complete overhaul. The strategy focuses on five "core pillars": eliminating timelines for the duration of the U.S. troop presence, utilizing all elements of power, including diplomatic and economic tools, getting tougher on Pakistan, increasing Indian involvement in economic development, and expanding authorities for U.S. forces to combat terrorism.

The president did not provide details on the number of additional troops heading to Afghanistan, leaving that decision to Defense Secretary Jim Mattis. The current troop level stands at around 8,400, with reports suggesting an additional 4,000 troops may be sent.

Trump emphasized that the U.S. will no longer discuss troop levels or drawdown dates, leaving conditions on the ground to guide the strategy. He stated that America's enemies must never know the U.S. plans or believe they can wait out the U.S. military. The president also floated the idea of a political settlement involving the Taliban and Afghanistan, but noted that it is unclear if or when this will happen.

The president stressed that the U.S. is not nation-building, but rather focusing on killing terrorists. He did not provide information on the cost of the new strategy, but mentioned that the U.S. will ask its NATO and other allies to do more. The current annual spending in Afghanistan is around $45 billion.

Trump acknowledged the frustration of the American people after 16 years of war without an end in sight, stating that the U.S. will not repeat the mistake of the previous administration in Iraq by pulling out too early, leaving a vacuum for terrorists to fill. He emphasized the importance of addressing reality and defeating terrorists, citing the recent terrorist attack in Spain as evidence.

The president concluded his speech by calling for unity among Americans, emphasizing that all service members are part of the same American family and urging the country to find the courage to heal its divisions.

Title: States Seek $1 Trillion Federal Bailout Amid COVID-19 Budget Shortfalls, But Experts Advise Alternative Solutions

Article:

State and local officials are urging the federal government to provide a nearly $1 trillion bailout to help address COVID-19-related budget shortfalls, which would amount to about $7,800 per household in new federal spending. However, experts argue that this approach would not be the most effective solution and could have unintended consequences.

The proposed bailout would be more than twice the projected COVID-related state and local revenue losses for 2020 and 2021 combined. Critics argue that it would not only force responsible states to pick up the tab for irresponsible ones but also incentivize bad behavior by enabling financially imprudent state and local lawmakers to escape the consequences of their fiscal mismanagement.

Some states, such as Wyoming, Alaska, and North Dakota, have saved more than 25% of their annual revenues in rainy day funds, while others, like Illinois, Kansas, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey, have put aside 1% or less. This disparity highlights the need for states to take responsibility for their own fiscal decisions.

While some states have responded to COVID-19 shortfalls with belt-tightening measures, others have eschewed restraint and instead counted on a federal bailout. Illinois, for example, adopted a 2021 budget with record-high spending, a $6 billion deficit, and no reductions in personnel costs.

History suggests that federal bailouts only drive up state spending and forestall necessary reforms. Instead, states can address COVID-19 budget shortfalls and boost the economic recovery by taking a more responsible approach.

One way to do this is by safely reopening parts of society, saving lives and livelihoods, and making data-driven, localized decisions that reflect the importance of child care availability and in-person school options. States can also focus on paring back recent spending increases, as Florida has done, reducing per-capita and inflation-adjusted spending by 16% over the last two decades.

Another area of excessive spending is Medicaid, where New York's spending has increased 20% per recipient over just three years, a difference of $20 billion in 2019. States can also realize long-term savings by bringing public employee compensation in line with the private sector.

The federal government can help states cope with revenue losses by relieving them of the burden of unfunded federal mandates, such as the Davis-Bacon Act and the new paid family and sick leave mandate. Increasing the size, scope, and debt of the federal government is not the solution to the widespread economic hardships caused by COVID-19. Instead, state and local officials can respond sensibly, through short-term adjustments and responsible budgeting, to boost recovery and set the stage for a stronger future.

Title: Brazil's Amazon Rainforest Sees Record-Breaking Fires Amid Environmental Concerns

Brazil's Amazon rainforest has seen a record-breaking number of fires this year, with nearly 73,000 blazes recorded between January and August, according to data from the country's space research agency, the National Institute for Space Research (INPE). This marks an 83% increase over the same period last year and is the highest since INPE records began in 2013.

The surge in fires has raised concerns about President Jair Bolsonaro's management of the environment, with many criticizing his administration's policies and actions. The fires have also had a significant impact on the region, with smoke from the blazes causing a daytime blackout in Sao Paulo and prompting tens of thousands of people to take to social media to express their concerns.

The hashtag #prayforamazonia became a global Twitter trend, with many calling for action to protect the Amazon rainforest. The unprecedented surge in fires has occurred since Bolsonaro took office in January, vowing to develop the Amazon region for farming and mining, despite international concerns over increased deforestation.

Wildfires often occur in the dry season in Brazil, which ends in late October or early November, but they are also deliberately started in efforts to illegally clear forest for cattle ranching. INPE said the large number of wildfires could not be attributed to the dry season or natural phenomena alone.

Environmental activists have pointed to a recent increase in deforestation as the trigger for the fires, with deforestation in Brazil's portion of the Amazon rainforest soaring more than 88% in June compared with the same month a year ago, according to INPE data. The Brazilian leader has faced mounting domestic criticism over his rhetoric regarding the environment, which activists blame for emboldening loggers, miners, and farmers in the Amazon.

Bolsonaro has also come under increased pressure from international powers to protect Brazil's environment under the terms of a landmark free trade deal brokered over two decades between the European Union and South American bloc Mercosur, of which Brazil is a member. The pact requires the Latin American giant to abide by the Paris climate accord, which Bolsonaro has threatened to pull out of, and also aims to end illegal deforestation, including in the Brazilian Amazon.

The unprecedented surge in fires has also led to Norway and Germany halting tens of millions of dollars of Amazon protection subsidies to the Amazon Fund, accusing Brazil of turning its back on the fight against deforestation.

Title: Pressure on Hillary Clinton to Address Ferguson Situation Unfounded, Experts Say

Article: The notion that Hillary Clinton is under pressure to address the situation in Ferguson is a misconception, according to experts. As the presumptive 2016 Democratic Party nominee, Clinton's position is strong, providing no incentive for her to wade into "politically treacherous waters" and every reason to lay low.

While President Barack Obama has chosen not to address the issue of systematic racial injustice in the American criminal justice system, some argue that the next Democratic Party presidential nominee would be a logical choice to tackle this topic. The demographics of the country are changing, with the youngest cohort of voters being less white than the national average and more liberal on economic issues. This demographic shift would normally push the party to tackle new issues that were too hot for previous leaders to touch.

However, the lack of a contested primary campaign this cycle means that Democrats are missing an opportunity to put new issues on the table. So far, it has been Republican Rand Paul who has made the boldest statement on the issue, with Democrats like Clinton choosing to remain silent. The Democratic Party, with its more multiracial coalition, will continue to be the political vehicle for the interests of people of color, but the lack of a contested primary is denying the country the circumstances in which high-profile Democrats are forced to address the issues that Ferguson has placed squarely on the national agenda.

Title: Three Members of the "Squad" Endorse Sen. Bernie Sanders for President

Article:

Three members of the so-called "Squad," a group of far-left freshman members of Congress, have announced their support for Sen. Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.), Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.), and Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) have publicly endorsed Sanders, a move that could significantly impact the Democratic primary.

The endorsements were announced following Sanders' recent heart procedure and a rally in Queens, N.Y., where he will appear with Ocasio-Cortez on Saturday. Omar and Tlaib have expressed their support for Sanders, with Omar stating that he is leading a "working-class movement to defeat Donald Trump that transcends generation, ethnicity, and geography." Omar also believes Sanders is the best candidate to take on Trump in 2020.

The endorsements are seen as a significant blow to Sen. Elizabeth Warren's campaign, who, like Sanders, represents the party's progressive wing. The endorsements also come after Warren faced criticism from multiple candidates during the recent Democratic debate in Ohio, where she had risen in the polls in recent weeks.

The "Squad" members' endorsements are also seen as crucial in attracting young voters, as the top three Democrats in the polls are all senior citizens. Sanders, 78, former Vice President Joe Biden, 76, and Warren, 70, are all considered older than the average voter.

Title: Sen. Ted Cruz Links Raising Debt Ceiling to Funding Affordable Care Act

Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas discussed the debt ceiling and the Affordable Care Act in an exclusive interview with CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday. Cruz emphasized the importance of using the debt ceiling as leverage to rein in the executive branch and achieve three objectives: reducing government spending, avoiding new taxes, and mitigating the harms from Obamacare.

Cruz noted that the debt ceiling has been raised 58 times since 1978, with 20 instances where Congress attached specific and stringent requirements to spending restraints. He argued that President Obama's demand to raise the debt ceiling without constraints is unreasonable.

The United States is expected to reach its borrowing limit on October 17. The government temporarily shut down on October 1 after Republicans in the House refused to pass a spending bill that would allow the government to pay its bills, seeking changes or delayed implementation of the Affordable Care Act. Cruz has been seen as a driving force behind the government shutdown, urging fellow Republicans to tie any government funding plan to defunding the Affordable Care Act.

Cruz believes that allowing Obamacare to go further into effect would "destroy the private health care system." He blamed Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid for refusing to take up a series of piecemeal bills passed by the House to fund certain government programs. Democrats in the Senate and the White House, however, are only willing to pass a "clean" spending bill that does not carry restrictions or changes to the health care law.

Cruz has faced criticism from both Democrats and some Republicans for the government shutdown. However, he believes that the attacks are a sign that they are winning the argument, as Obamacare is not working. According to a recent CBS News poll, 72% of Americans disapprove of the shutdown, with more Americans blaming congressional Republicans than Obama. Despite this, Cruz does not think his actions have taken a negative toll on his party's image, stating that many people are too focused on politics.

Title: Houston Rockets GM Daryl Morey Apologizes for Tweet Supporting Hong Kong Protests

The Houston Rockets' general manager, Daryl Morey, has apologized for a deleted tweet that showed support for the Hong Kong anti-government protests. The tweet, which read "Fight for Freedom. Stand with Hong Kong," sparked backlash from the Chinese Consulate-General in Houston and the Chinese Basketball Association. Morey's apology on Twitter stated that he did not intend to offend any of the team's Chinese fans or sponsors and acknowledged that he had "had a lot of opportunity since that tweet to hear and consider other perspectives."

The NBA has also released a statement acknowledging that Morey's tweet had offended many of the league's fans and friends in China, but emphasized that the league values individuals' freedom to express their opinions on matters important to them. The statement also expressed the NBA's respect for China's history and culture, and its hope that sports can be used as a unifying force to bridge cultural divides.

The controversy has highlighted the challenges that American companies face when operating in China, where the government is sensitive to any perceived criticism. The NBA has formed partnerships with some of China's biggest tech companies and has opened NBA retail stores in the country. The Chinese Consulate-General in Houston urged the Rockets to "correct the error" and take immediate concrete measures to eliminate the adverse impact of Morey's tweet.

The NBA's statement on the matter varied slightly from the English version when released on popular social network Weibo in China, with the Chinese version expressing "extreme disappointment" and "serious hurt" caused by Morey's tweet. The NBA was not immediately available for a follow-up request for comment.

Title: Attorney General Bill Barr to Skip House Judiciary Committee Hearing Amid Negotiations Over His Testimony

Article:

Attorney General Bill Barr is expected to skip a long-awaited hearing before the Democrat-led House Judiciary Committee on Thursday, according to a source on the committee. The decision comes after Barr has faced intense scrutiny and criticism from congressional Democrats, who have accused him of sacrificing his integrity to appease President Trump.

The hearing was originally scheduled to have Barr testify before the committee, but negotiations over his appearance have stalled. The committee wants to have Judiciary Committee staff question Barr on his handling of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report, while Justice Department officials insist that members of Congress should conduct the inquiry.

The dispute is the latest development in the ongoing tensions between the Trump administration and House Democrats over access to Mueller's report and government witnesses who have defied congressional subpoenas to testify. The report, which was released in recent weeks, found no evidence to support claims that the Trump campaign colluded with Russians.

The House Judiciary Committee has subpoenaed the Justice Department for the unredacted version of the Mueller report and underlying material gathered from the investigation. The Justice Department has offered to make the full report, minus grand jury material, available to a limited group of members, which Democrats have refused.

The dispute could eventually end up in court. The House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has criticized Barr for drawing his own conclusion that Trump did not obstruct justice, and punted to Barr and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein. The White House has asserted it will fight a subpoena for former White House counsel Don McGahn, who was a vital witness for Mueller in the report.

In a separate development, a former White House staffer who was at risk of being held in contempt of Congress has agreed to testify, potentially averting a showdown between Democrats and the White House. The House Oversight Committee has scheduled an interview for Wednesday with Carl Kline, who worked as the White House's personnel security director.

Title: Obama and Romney Clash on Economy in Ohio Visits

Article:

In a speech in Cleveland, Ohio, President Barack Obama acknowledged that the divergent views between him and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, on how to revive the economy will define the election. The president emphasized that the election is about the country's economic future and that the nation is slowly "digging out of a hole that is nine million jobs deep." He blamed Republican policies over the previous decade for driving up the deficit and benefiting the rich at the expense of the middle class.

Obama listed the Bush-era economic and policy choices, such as tax cuts for the wealthy, deregulation, and increased spending on wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, which he said led to the recession of 2008 and 2009. He stated that the current stalemate in Washington between two fundamentally different views on the direction of the country is what is holding the economy back.

Romney, on the other hand, argued that private enterprise, not government, is the key to expanding the economy and that the Obama administration's policies on financial regulation, health care, and energy have stifled growth and held back the recovery. He expressed his desire to make the United States once again the most attractive place in the world for job creators.
