Napolitano's staff was reportedly caught off guard by the news of her departure, with some viewing her as "out of sight, out of mind" since her comments on the 2009 attempted bombing on a Detroit-bound flight and her subsequent comments on the Times Square bombing attempt.

Despite her critics, Napolitano has received praise from President Obama, who commended her for her service and her efforts to secure the nation's borders and make the immigration system more fair and consistent with American values. If confirmed, Napolitano would become the first female president of the University of California.

Title: U.S. Surpasses Pre-Recession Jobs Total, But Recovery Remains Slow

The United States has reached a milestone, surpassing the number of jobs it had before the recession started. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the country added 217,000 jobs in May, bringing the total number of payroll employment to nearly 138.5 million. This marks the fourth consecutive month of payrolls increasing by at least 200,000, a feat not seen since September 1999 to January 2000.

The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 6.3 percent, while the labor-force participation rate held steady at 62.8 percent, near the lowest levels since the late 1970s. Economists had expected an increase in payrolls of around 210,000 jobs, which would put the total above the record of 138.4 million jobs at the start of 2008.

Despite reaching this milestone, analysts note that the jobs recovery has taken more than six years and has excluded many workers. Heidi Shierholz of the Economic Policy Institute stated that the country should have added around 7 million jobs in that time, leaving it in a "really big hole." The economy is growing, but at a slow pace, according to Shierholz.

Economists point to weak consumer demand and employers struggling to find workers with the right skills as some of the problems holding the economy back. The situation is particularly bleak in California's San Joaquin Valley, where low wages and high unemployment rates are a major concern.

Title: Wealthy Gulf Countries Refuse to Take in Syrian Refugees, Citing Terrorism Concerns

The article reports that five of the wealthiest Muslim countries, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Kuwait, and Bahrain, have not taken in a single Syrian refugee, citing concerns about the risk of terrorism. These countries, which are among the top 50 wealthiest nations by GDP, have instead opted to donate aid to those affected by the crisis. According to the article, the total donations from the Gulf States are estimated to be around £589 million, less than a quarter of the amount donated by the United States and a fraction of the £65 billion spent on defense in 2012.

The article also highlights the contrast between the Gulf States' inaction and the efforts of European countries, which have received asylum applications from Syrians. For example, Germany has received nearly 350,000 applications, while the UK is processing 7,030 applications.

Sherif Elsayid-Ali, Head of Refugee and Migrants' Rights at Amnesty International, has slammed the Gulf States' inaction as "shameful" and "a disgrace." The article also quotes Arabian expert Sultan Sooud al-Qassemi, who notes that the Gulf States have taken refugees in the past, such as during the Kuwaiti invasion by Saddam Hussein.

The article concludes by highlighting the moral obligation that the Gulf States have to take in refugees from the Syria crisis, given their influence and wealth.

Title: US and Allies Prepare for Possible Military Strike in Syria Amid Reports of Chemical Attack

The United States and its allies are preparing for a possible military strike in Syria in response to an alleged chemical attack near Damascus on Saturday. US President Donald Trump tweeted that Russia should "get ready" for missiles to be fired at its ally Syria, stating "Get ready Russia, because they will be coming, nice and new and'smart!'".

The alleged attack occurred in the rebel-held town of Douma, with opposition activists and rescuers reporting that government aircraft dropped bombs filled with toxic chemicals, resulting in over 500 people being treated for symptoms indicative of exposure to a chemical agent. The Syrian-American Medical Society (Sams) and local aid workers reported that 70 people had died, including 43 who showed symptoms consistent with exposure to highly toxic chemicals.

The United States, the United Kingdom, and France have agreed to work together and are believed to be preparing for a military strike in response to the alleged chemical attack. However, senior Russian figures have threatened to meet any US strikes with a response, with Russian Ambassador to Lebanon Alexander Zasypkin warning that missiles would be shot down and their launch sites targeted if they threatened the lives of Russian personnel.

The US Defense Secretary James Mattis stated that the US is still assessing the chemical attack and that the US military stands ready to provide military options if they are appropriate as the president determines. White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said a final decision had not been made, and "all options remain on the table".

French President Emmanuel Macron stated that any strikes would target "the regime's chemical capabilities". In the UK, sources told the BBC that Prime Minister Theresa May looked ready to join military action in Syria without seeking parliamentary consent first.

A US Navy guided-missile destroyer, the USS Donald Cook, is in the Mediterranean Sea, and there are reports that Russian battleships have left the country's naval base in the Syrian port city of Tartus. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) is due to deploy to Syria "shortly" to determine whether banned weapons were used.

The Syrian government has denied mounting a chemical attack on Douma, describing the reports as a "provocation" designed to justify Western intervention against its ally. Russian officials have also questioned the evidence of the attack, with Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova asking whether the aim of Western strikes might be "to quickly remove the traces of the provocation... [so] international inspectors will have nothing to look for in terms of evidence".

Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed hope that common sense would prevail and that the situation would stabilize, stating that Russia would "keep all its international obligations in full".

Title: China's Economic Growth Slows Down: A Shift in the World's Second-Largest Economy

China's economic growth has slowed down significantly, with the government taking measures to stimulate the economy. The country's growth rate has been slowing down faster than expected, with some experts calling it a "sharp slowdown." The government has cut lending rates to try to boost growth, but the economy is still facing challenges.

One area where the slowdown is being felt is in air travel. The International Air Transport Association reports that air travel in China has been hit hard, with growth rates slowing down to single figures. This is a significant change from the 15-20% growth rates seen in previous years.

The slowdown is not just limited to air travel. Exports to Europe have fallen sharply due to the economic problems in the region, and business confidence has weakened, particularly among smaller businesses. The government's tightening of the housing market and construction of public infrastructure has also had an impact.

Andy Rothman, a China macro-strategist for CLSA, believes that the Communist Party's efforts to slow down the economy have been overdone. The government has been trying to slow down the economy to improve its quality, but this has led to a decline in demand for things like steel and concrete, hurting factories.

The government is now trying to encourage home buying and approve new public projects to help stabilize the economy. Last month, home sales picked up in major cities. However, some experts believe that the economy needs more serious reform to get back on track.

Ren Xianfeng, a senior analyst with IHS Global Insight, is optimistic about the short-term outlook, but more pessimistic about the medium and longer term. She believes that the government needs to build a more innovative economy that favors private firms and helps finance them, rather than just state-owned companies.

Overall, China's economic slowdown is a significant development that could have far-reaching implications for the global economy. While some experts are optimistic about the short-term outlook, others believe that the economy needs more serious reform to get back on track.

**Senator Richard Burr's Stock Sales Raise Questions Amid Coronavirus Pandemic**

Senator Richard Burr, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, sold off a significant portion of his stocks in February, just as the coronavirus pandemic was spreading globally. According to reports, Burr sold between $628,000 and $1.72 million worth of his holdings in 33 separate transactions on February 13.

As the head of the intelligence committee, Burr has access to classified information about threats to America's security, including the coronavirus. His committee received daily briefings on the pandemic around the time of his stock sales, according to a Reuters report.

A week after Burr's sales, the stock market began to decline, losing about 30% of its value. The senator's office has defended his actions, stating that he filed a financial disclosure form for his personal transactions several weeks before the U.S. and financial markets showed signs of volatility due to the growing coronavirus outbreak.

Burr's sales included dumping up to $150,000 worth of shares of Wyndham Hotels and Resorts, a chain based in the United States that has lost two-thirds of its value, and up to $100,000 of shares of Extended Stay America, an economy hospitality chain. Shares of these companies are now worth less than half of what they did at the time of Burr's sales.

Burr's public comments on the pandemic have been less dire than his private remarks, which were obtained by NPR. In a February 27 luncheon speech, he warned that the virus could have a significant impact on the economy, stating that it was "more aggressive in its transmission than anything that we have seen in recent history... It is probably more akin to the 1918 pandemic."

In contrast, Burr co-authored an op-ed on February 7, assuring the public that "the United States today is better prepared than ever before to face emerging public health threats, like the coronavirus." He wrote that "Congress and the federal government have been vigilant in identifying gaps in its readiness efforts and improving its response capabilities."

Members of Congress are required by law to disclose their securities transactions, and Burr's sales were his largest stock selling day in at least the past 14 months, according to a review of Senate records.

Title: Republicans Expected to Dominate Midterm Elections, but Face Challenges in 2016 Presidential Contest

Article:

The upcoming midterm elections are expected to favor Republicans, with many attributing this to the perceived failures of the Democratic Party's radical policies. However, it is unclear whether this momentum will carry over to the 2016 presidential contest. The article argues that the Democratic Party has become increasingly driven by ideology, disconnecting them from reality and leading to potential losses.

The author, David Horowitz, claims that the Democratic Party has abandoned its pragmatic approach, citing the election of Barack Obama as an example. He argues that Obama's promises of change and hope were empty and deceptive, and that it has taken years for the American people to realize this.

Horowitz also suggests that Republicans will win the midterms due to the negative consequences of the Democratic Party's policies, including a poor economic recovery, high unemployment, and a weakened healthcare system. He believes that the American people are fed up and will turn out the party responsible.

The article also touches on the idea that Republicans will not engage in negative campaigning, instead focusing on policy and staying positive. Horowitz believes that Democrats, on the other hand, will use negative tactics to attack Republicans, painting them as racists, sexists, and homophobes.

The author argues that Republicans need to adopt a more aggressive approach, attacking Democrats with a moral indictment and highlighting their own flaws. He cites examples of Democratic politicians, such as Elizabeth Warren and Hillary Clinton, who have changed their stance on issues like the Islamic State.

Horowitz also references his own book, "Take No Prisoners: The Battle Plan for Defeating the Left," in which he outlines a strategy for Republicans to win elections by attacking their opponents with moral indictments.

It is worth noting that the article presents a one-sided view of the Democratic Party and its policies, and does not provide a balanced perspective. Additionally, some of the claims made by Horowitz, such as the idea that the Democratic Party is driven solely by ideology, are subjective and not supported by evidence.

Title: Russia Launches Naval Bombardment in Syria, Raising Concerns Over True Intentions

Russia launched a naval bombardment in Syria on Wednesday, targeting ISIS targets in the western part of the country. The strikes were conducted from the Caspian Sea using long-range missiles that flew 1,500 kilometers to their targets. This marks a significant escalation of Russia's military presence in the region.

The Russian Defense Ministry said the strikes were conducted in coordination with the Syrian government, which has been embroiled in a long-running civil war. The strikes were aimed at Islamist factions in the provinces of Hama and Idlib, with the Syrian shelling apparently conducted in concert with Russian airstrikes.

The development has raised concerns that Russia's primary goal is to prop up the embattled Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad, rather than fighting terrorism. The United States has been critical of Russia's involvement in the conflict, with Defense Secretary Ashton Carter calling the Russian campaign a "fundamental mistake."

Despite the tensions, Russia has expressed willingness to cooperate with the United States in carrying out attacks in Syria. However, the two countries have yet to agree on mutual flight safety rules in Syrian airspace, with the U.S. military diverting one aircraft over Syria to ensure a safe flying distance from Russian fighter jets.

The Russian Defense Ministry has said it is prepared to take information and intelligence from the U.S.-led coalition against ISIS, and has called on all sides to share targeting reconnaissance. However, the U.S. military has expressed skepticism about Russia's intentions, with a senior defense official saying that only 3.5% of Russia's airstrikes in Syria have targeted ISIS.

NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg has condemned Russia's incursion into Turkish airspace, calling it "unacceptable, dangerous, and reckless behavior." The Turkish government has also cast doubt on Russia's claims that its airstrikes are targeting ISIS, with Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu saying that only 2% of Russia's airstrikes have targeted the terror group.

The developments come as Russia's military presence in Syria continues to grow, with the country deploying naval assets and ground troops to the region. The U.S. has expressed concerns that Russia is not targeting ISIS, but rather attacking the Syrian opposition and civilians.

Title: Vice President Pence: US Making Progress in Battle Against Coronavirus, Emphasizes Importance of Continued Cooperation

Article:

In an exclusive interview with ███ News, Vice President Mike Pence discussed the country's progress in combating the deadly coronavirus. Before the interview, Pence asked if the reporter had been tested for COVID-19, and the reporter confirmed having taken a rapid test, which came back negative. The vice president emphasized that the country is making real progress in the battle against the virus.

Pence stated that the administration is closely monitoring the data and believes that if Americans continue to follow guidelines, the country will be in a different place by the end of April. He highlighted the development of a new testing format, including a 15-minute test developed by Abbott Laboratories, which is being made available across the country.

The vice president also addressed the importance of continued cooperation and social distancing, particularly in the context of religious gatherings. While many churches and synagogues have closed their doors, Pence acknowledged that some are still holding in-person services, citing biblical scripture. He emphasized the importance of finding ways to continue practicing faith and social distancing during this critical time.

Pence also discussed the economic relief efforts, stating that Congress is working together to provide assistance to families and small businesses. He highlighted the Paycheck Protection Program, which will allow small businesses to keep employees on the payroll for two months. The vice president expressed optimism about the country's progress and emphasized the importance of putting the coronavirus in the past.

When asked about the ongoing debate over nationwide mail-in balloting, Pence declined to reveal the administration's game plan, stating that it will be an important debate in the days ahead. The vice president's primary focus remains on combating the virus and providing relief to those affected.

Title: Alaska Considers Unconventional Approach to Stabilize Obamacare

Alaska, one of the reddest states in the country, is taking an unusual step to prevent Obamacare from collapsing. The state legislature has passed a bill to shore up its lone surviving Obamacare insurer, setting up a $55 million fund to subsidize enrollees' costs. The legislation, originally proposed by Governor Bill Walker, a Republican-turned-independent, sets up a fund financed through an existing tax on insurance companies to help cover medical expenses for high-cost enrollees.

The bill is awaiting Governor Walker's signature and is expected to ensure that the 23,000 Alaskans enrolled in exchange plans won't suddenly lose their insurance. The fund will help cover medical expenses for high-cost enrollees, but the money currently goes into Alaska's general fund, and redirecting it to bolster Obamacare has sparked criticism from some lawmakers due to the state's massive budget deficit.

Republican state lawmakers, who sued Governor Walker for expanding Medicaid under the health law, swear they remain opposed to Obamacare. However, they say they're doing what's necessary to prevent health insurance premiums from spiraling out of control and letting thousands of people lose their coverage.

The bill's passage reflects Alaska's unique demographic challenges, including a relatively small population with some of the highest health care costs in the nation. The state's rural areas make it difficult to access facilities, and a few especially sick patients have put a strain on insurers. In the individual market, nearly 500 enrollees with severe medical conditions cost Alaska insurers about $59 million in less than two years, according to state documents.

An analysis by Avalere Health showed that the lowest-cost "silver" level plan in Alaska cost $956 per month before any subsidies were factored in, the highest rate in the nation. Rate increases were seen before Obamacare, but "not to the degree we're experiencing now," said Lori Wing-Heier, head of the Alaska Division of Insurance.

The insurance fund, if approved by the governor, will go into effect on June 30. The legislation also authorizes Alaska to apply for an Obamacare waiver that lets states change pieces of the federal law starting in 2017 as long as those reforms meet certain requirements.

State lawmakers, including Senator Dan Sullivan and Representative Lance Pruitt, said they were left with little choice but to approve the fund as insurers pulled out of the state. "Rather than leaving these folks hanging, we had to do something," said Senator Cathy Giessel. "We're trying to maintain ACA? I think what we're trying to do is live within the new reality that's out there."

Title: Endorsement: Sen. Bernie Sanders for President

The article is an endorsement of Sen. Bernie Sanders for the Democratic Party nomination and eventual presidency. The author, a prominent figure, highlights Sanders' commitment to addressing the fundamental challenges facing working people, including healthcare, education, and economic inequality. The article emphasizes Sanders' ability to expose President Donald Trump's broken promises and lies, citing his high popular approval rating and ability to inspire a new generation of voters.

The author notes that Sanders has a strong track record of standing up to Trump, having voted against corporate trade treaties and the war in Iraq. They also highlight his commitment to progressive policies, such as Medicare for All, a Green New Deal, tuition-free college, and a $15 minimum wage.

The article also touches on Sanders' ability to bring together the working class and middle class, citing his record of inspiring young people and earning their overwhelming support. The author notes that Sanders is the only candidate who has inspired a new generation and earned their trust.

In contrast, the author views Joe Biden as a decent man but one who has a different record and offers no bold reforms. The article concludes by stating that Sanders represents the moral center, with policies such as healthcare for all, tuition-free college, and a Middle East policy that recognizes both Israel and Palestine.

Overall, the article presents a factual and informative overview of Sen. Bernie Sanders' platform and qualifications, highlighting his commitment to progressive policies and his ability to inspire a new generation of voters.

Title: Pope Francis Visits Ireland Amidst Ongoing Abuse Scandals

Pope Francis visited Ireland over the weekend, where he sought forgiveness for the Catholic Church's sexual abuse scandals and demanded "firm and decisive" measures to find "truth and justice." The pontiff met with abuse victims and held a Mass in front of tens of thousands of worshippers in Dublin's Phoenix Park. However, his visit was marred by accusations from a former Vatican official that he had personally ignored allegations against senior clergy.

Archbishop Carlo Maria Vigano wrote in a letter published in the National Catholic Register that he had told Francis of the allegations against Cardinal Theodore McCarrick in 2013, but that Francis had responded by lifting sanctions imposed on McCarrick by his predecessor, Pope Benedict. The Vatican declined to comment on the claims.

The visit was also marked by protests from abuse victims and their supporters, who braved the rain to attend the "Stand for Truth" rally in Dublin. The rally was attended by around 5,000 people, with some protesters dressed as nuns and holding signs reading "the church protects pederasts."

The abuse scandals have had a significant impact on the Catholic Church's reputation, with multiple investigations in Ireland finding that Church leaders protected hundreds of predatory priests. The scandals have also led to a decline in attendance at Masses and a shift in Irish public opinion, with the country voting to legalize abortion and same-sex marriage in recent years.

The Pope's visit comes as the Church faces a global crisis, with a devastating report earlier this month accusing more than 300 priests in the US state of Pennsylvania of abusing more than 1,000 children since the 1950s. The Pope met with eight abuse victims during his visit, including a woman who was assaulted by a priest when she was 13 years old.

Title: Obama Seeks Fallback Measure to Prevent Tax Increases, But Republicans Remain Divided

Article:

President Barack Obama has proposed a fallback measure to prevent tax increases for most Americans, but it remains unclear whether it will pass in the House of Representatives. The plan, backed by Congressional Democrats, would extend the Bush-era tax cuts for income below $250,000, increase the tax rate for capital gains and dividend income, and extend some other tax breaks. However, it would not address the debt limit, which is expected to be reached early in 2013.

The proposal is a response to the Republican-led House's rejection of Speaker John Boehner's "Plan B," which would have extended the Bush tax cuts for income up to $1 million, affecting only an estimated 0.3 percent of households. While some Republicans have expressed willingness to consider a compromise, others have refused to budge, citing concerns about increasing taxes.

The fallback plan would also delay the so-called sequester, a series of across-the-board spending cuts set to take effect in January, and extend federal unemployment benefits for an estimated two million Americans who have been out of work for long enough to exhaust their initial state aid.

Democrats have emphasized the importance of passing the bill, which they say would protect the middle class and provide a foundation for future deficit reduction efforts. However, Republicans have expressed skepticism, citing concerns about the bill's impact on the national debt and the need for more significant spending cuts.

The standoff has left the fate of the tax cuts and the debt limit uncertain, with both sides refusing to budge. The outcome will have significant implications for the economy and the nation's fiscal health.

Title: U.S.-China Trade Deal: Unclear Terms and Lack of Transparency Raise Doubts

The recent announcement of a U.S.-China trade deal, dubbed "Phase One" or "preliminary," has sparked concerns about its effectiveness in serving American interests. The lack of transparency and unclear terms have raised questions about the agreement's substance and potential benefits.

The U.S. Trade Representative's office released a statement detailing U.S. tariff reductions, but failed to provide specifics about China's own pledges. The absence of information on what China will buy from the United States and when it will make these purchases has left many questions unanswered. The administration has not provided any details on structural reforms and changes to China's economic and trade regime, which are crucial to addressing the intertwined U.S.-China technology and national security rivalries.

The deal's vagueness has led to concerns that it may not address the core issues and may not be enforceable. The lack of a strong dispute resolution system and the absence of a clear mechanism for judging Chinese compliance have raised doubts about the agreement's effectiveness.

The politics surrounding the deal are also puzzling. China's economy has taken a significant hit from the trade war, and Beijing is struggling to contain unrest in Hong Kong. The new U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) may offset some of the losses suffered by agriculture-heavy states critical to President Trump's re-election hopes.

However, experts argue that this is not the right time for Trump to reach a deal with China, as the country's economy is still struggling and a deal that promotes real U.S. interests remains impossible to reach due to verification obstacles. Instead, the administration should keep the pressure on China and signal to American businesses that major tariffs on China are here to stay, which may increase the odds of building a new, improved bilateral relationship.

The only reasons for optimism on the U.S.-China trade front are the deal's tentativeness and the likelihood of U.S.-China decoupling, which will continue due to the unbridgeable technology and national security gap between the two countries.

Title: Obama Considers Canceling Meeting with Putin over Snowden's Asylum Bid

Article:

United States President Barack Obama is considering canceling a scheduled meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin due to the ongoing friction over fugitive security leaker Edward Snowden's asylum bid. Snowden, a former National Security contractor, has been staying at a Moscow airport since June, appealing to the Russian government for asylum. The tension between the two leaders has been escalating, with Obama seeking Snowden's return and Putin pondering allowing him to stay in Russia.

The planned meeting was part of Obama's trip to St. Petersburg for the Group of 20 nations summit. White House spokesman Jay Carney declined to comment on the trip, stating that the president intends to travel to Russia for the G-20 summit, but did not provide further details.

Putin has called the U.S. "hypocritical" amid the spying disclosures and stated that bilateral relations are more important than squabbles about secret services. Critics of the White House's handling of the Snowden affair have urged Obama to step up pressure to bring him home, with some even suggesting moving the summit out of Russia altogether.

Senator Lindsey Graham, speaking to CNN, encouraged Obama to be more forceful with Russia and consider boycotting the 2014 Olympic Games in Sochi if Snowden is granted asylum and Russia does not change its policy on Syria and Iran. "Should you go to St. Petersburg, Russia, for the G-20 summit if they give Snowden asylum and they don't change their policy toward Syria and continue to help Iran?" Graham asked. "Should you go? My advice to you is I wouldn't go to St. Petersburg. I would ask for a change of venue."

Title: Obama Announces Executive Order for Paid Sick Leave for Federal Contractors

The White House has announced a new executive order requiring federal contractors to provide paid sick leave to their employees. The regulation, which will take effect in 2017, will grant approximately 300,000 federal contract workers up to seven days of paid sick leave per year. This move is part of President Obama's broader efforts to expand worker protections and address income inequality.

The new rule will allow workers to use their paid time off to care for themselves or a family member, or to deal with absences resulting from domestic violence or sexual assault. The Labor Department will publish a final rule prohibiting federal contractors from discriminating against employees and job applicants who discuss their salaries, aiming to promote pay transparency and help workers recognize pay discrimination.

This announcement is the latest in a series of pro-worker actions taken by the Obama administration. In December 2011, President Obama signaled his intention to address income inequality and declining economic mobility. Since his reelection, the pace of pro-labor action has increased, with new overtime regulations, a federal worker pay raise, and an upcoming White House summit on worker voice.

The administration has also taken steps to extend minimum-wage and overtime pay rules to home-health workers and proposed increasing the weekly salary threshold for overtime pay. Additionally, the Labor Department has banned discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity in the federal contracting workforce.

The president's actions are motivated by a desire to improve conditions for workers and build a legacy. As a community organizer in Chicago, Obama has a special interest in helping those on the economic margins. The labor movement is also an important Democratic Party constituency in the 2016 presidential election, and these actions help protect Obama's legacy.

However, labor leaders are unhappy with the White House's pace on workplace safety regulations and its negotiation of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal. AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka criticized the administration's lack of action on workplace safety and Hillary Clinton's strategy of not being specific about her views on the TPP.

Title: President Obama Pressures Republican Senators on Supreme Court Nominee, Amid Shift in Focus to Senate Control

Article:

President Barack Obama conducted a series of interviews with TV stations from six Republican senators' home states, urging them to schedule a confirmation hearing and vote on his Supreme Court nominee, Judge Merrick Garland. The move comes as Democrats shift their focus from filling the high court vacancy to winning control of the Senate in November.

The president's media blitz targeted incumbent Republican senators in Arizona, Iowa, Missouri, New Hampshire, Ohio, and Wisconsin, all of whom are running for re-election. The goal is to pressure Senate Republican leadership to take action on Judge Garland's nomination, which has been pending for seven weeks.

A government watchdog group, the Foundation for Accountability and Civic Trust, has asked Judge Garland to authorize the release of his Office of Professional Responsibility records from his tenure at the Justice Department during the Clinton administration. The group's director, Matthew G. Whitaker, stated that Americans need to know whether any such records exist and to examine existing records to evaluate Judge Garland's qualifications to serve as a Supreme Court Justice.

During the George W. Bush administration, Senate Democrats used a similar issue as justification for blocking the nomination of conservative lawyer Miguel Estrada to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit. Democrats insisted that they would not allow a final vote until the White House released Mr. Estrada's working papers from his time at the Clinton Justice Department.

Polling data suggests that Republicans such as Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley of Iowa are losing support in their home states for blocking the Garland nomination. A survey found that 44% of respondents said they are less likely to support Mr. Grassley in November because of his stance.

Conservative activists, however, remain skeptical of the Democratic push for Judge Garland's confirmation. The Judicial Crisis Network is airing a $500,000 ad campaign over the Senate's recess to highlight Judge Garland's record and warn of potential consequences if he is confirmed.

Title: Study Suggests Fake News May Have Had Significant Impact on 2016 Presidential Election

A recent study conducted by researchers at Ohio State University suggests that fake news stories may have had a substantial impact on voters in the 2016 presidential election, potentially influencing the outcome of the election. The study, which was first reported by The Washington Post, analyzed the voting habits of Obama voters in 2012 and found that those who believed fake news stories were more likely to defect from the Democratic ticket.

The researchers surveyed 585 voters who supported Obama in 2012 and found that 10% of them voted for Trump, 4% supported minor parties, and 8% declined to vote. The study sought to determine what accounted for the defections from Clinton. The researchers asked voters 281 questions, including fake news statements, and found a significant correlation between belief in fake news statements and vote choice.

The study found that a much larger percentage of Obama voters who did not believe any of the fake news statements voted for Hillary Clinton in 2016 (89%) compared to those who believed one or more of the statements (61% and 17%, respectively). The researchers also controlled for other factors that could have influenced voters' decisions, such as age, race, political identification, and gender.

Using multivariate regression analysis, the study found that belief in fake news statements still accounted for a significant portion of the defections when other factors were considered. The researchers concluded that former Obama voters who believed one or more of the fake news stories were 3.9 times more likely to defect from the Democratic ticket in 2016 than those who did not believe any of the false claims.

While the study suggests that fake news may have had a significant impact on the election, the researchers emphasized that it is impossible to conclude that fake news caused Obama voters to defect from Clinton in 2016. The study notes that it is possible that a voter first decided not to vote for Clinton and then cited false stories to rationalize their decision.

The study's findings have implications for the ongoing debate about the role of fake news in the 2016 election. The researchers' conclusion that fake news may have had a significant impact on the election outcome is consistent with other studies that have found that misinformation and disinformation can have a significant impact on voters' decisions.

Title: Celebrities Join Forces to Promote Gender Equality and Challenge Stereotypes

The United Nations has launched the HeForShe campaign, a global movement aimed at engaging men in the fight against violence against women. Actress Emma Watson, a prominent advocate for gender equality, delivered a speech at the UN, urging men to join the conversation and challenge the negative stereotypes surrounding the term "feminism." Watson emphasized that gender equality is not just a women's issue, but a human rights issue that requires the involvement of men.

Watson's speech has gone viral, sparking a wider conversation about the importance of gender equality. The UN's HeForShe campaign aims to engage men in the fight against violence against women, which affects one in three women globally. The campaign highlights the need for men to take an active role in promoting gender equality and challenging the societal norms that perpetuate gender-based violence.

The rebranding of feminism has gained momentum, with celebrities like Beyoncé and Emma Watson using their platforms to promote gender equality. Beyoncé's MTV Video Music Awards performance, which featured the word "FEMINIST" on stage, sparked a significant increase in conversations about feminism on social media.

However, despite the growing awareness and celebrity support, there is still much work to be done to achieve gender equality. Women are still underrepresented in media, with studies showing that they are featured less frequently and less prominently in news stories. In entertainment, research has found that there are significantly more male characters than female characters in recent films.

The economic front also shows a persistent gap, with women's earnings ratio peaking at 81% in 2005 and 2006. The lack of progress in these areas highlights the need for continued action and advocacy to create a more equitable society.

The HeForShe campaign and the rebranding of feminism are important steps towards achieving gender equality, but it will take a collective effort from individuals, organizations, and governments to create a world that is fairer for everyone.

Title: Escalating Tensions: Trump's Retreat from Diplomacy Increases Global Peril

The recent attacks on tankers and nuclear production have highlighted the consequences of President Trump's retreat from diplomacy, making the world a more perilous place. While the incidents are considered measured provocations, they underscore the need for a more nuanced approach to address the situation.

The damage to the tankers has been described as "very minor" by Trump, and he seems to recognize the danger of escalation. However, the deployment of an additional 2,500 U.S. troops to the region and calls for striking Iran have raised concerns about the potential for further escalation. If the U.S. were to strike Iran, it is likely that Iran would respond, perpetuating a cycle of violence.

Brett McGurk, a national security expert and former presidential envoy, warned that the administration's failure to address the root issues of its Iran policy may lead to a choice between backing down or resorting to military action. The conflation of Shiite Iran with the Sunni Taliban has also raised concerns, as it may provide legal cover for the U.S. to attack Iran under the 2001 authorization for the use of military force against Al Qaeda and its offshoots.

The administration's 12-point plan, proposed by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, has been met with skepticism, as it essentially calls for Iran to surrender. The plan has been criticized for its unrealistic expectations and lack of engagement with Iran.

The recent meeting of the Trilateral Commission in Paris highlighted the growing distrust among allies towards the U.S. The administration's attempts to bully Europe and Asia into joining Iran sanctions have pushed Iran back towards a nuclear path and increased the risk of war.

In the current situation, there are few good options, but an international force to protect tankers and secret diplomacy to revive the nuclear deal may be worth exploring. However, it is unclear whether this will be successful, and the situation remains precarious.

Title: Israel's Intelligence Minister Denies Knowledge of Trump's Alleged Order to Assassinate Assad

Article:

Israel's Intelligence Minister, Yisrael Katz, has denied having any knowledge of a reported instruction from US President Donald Trump to assassinate Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. The claim was made in a new book by journalist Bob Woodward, "Fear: Trump in the White House," which alleges that Trump told his defense secretary, James Mattis, that he wanted to have Assad killed in response to a chemical attack on Syrian civilians in April 2017.

According to the book, Mattis told Trump that he would "get right on it," but instead developed a plan for a limited air strike that did not threaten Assad personally. Trump has denied the quotes attributed to Mattis, calling them "made-up frauds" and a "con on the public." Mattis has also dismissed the book as "a uniquely Washington brand of literature."

Katz told Tel Aviv radio station 103 FM that he has no knowledge of any such instruction and that Israel did not take a decision to topple Assad. He stated that while Israel has carried out air strikes against suspected attempts by Assad's Iranian and Lebanese Hezbollah allies to set up permanent posts or advanced arms, it has not taken a stance on the 7-year civil war in neighboring Syria.

Israel has maintained a formal neutrality on the conflict, but Katz acknowledged that Assad's actions are "terrible" and something that Israel abhors and condemns. He also stated that Israel did not see a better alternative to Assad among Syrian rebel groups and has taken care to preserve its interests.

The book by Woodward, a renowned journalist known for his reporting on the Watergate scandal, is based on interviews with top aides and insiders, with the understanding that he would not reveal how he obtained his information. The Washington Post published excerpts from the book on Tuesday.

Title: Israel Launches Airstrikes in Syria, Denies Targeting President Assad

Israel launched airstrikes in Syria on Friday and Sunday, killing scores of Syrian soldiers, according to reports. The Israeli government has sought to downplay the attacks, claiming they were aimed at Hezbollah, a Lebanese militant group, rather than the Syrian government.

Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's confidant, Tzachi Hanegbi, told Israeli radio that Netanyahu aimed to avoid an increase in tension with Syria by making it clear that any future actions would be targeted at Hezbollah, not the Syrian regime. The Israeli government has also informed the Syrian government through diplomatic channels that the attacks were not intended to affect the outcome of the Syrian civil war.

Hezbollah, which seeks Israel's elimination, has long relied on the Syrian government to transfer weapons from Iran into its own hands. The two have drawn closer together as a result of the Syrian civil war, with Hezbollah fighters battling the Syrian opposition from inside the country.

Israel has maintained official silence about the airstrikes, with a senior Israeli official stating that the goal is to make it clear to the Syrian government that Israel's sole interest is in preventing advanced weaponry from reaching Hezbollah, not intervening in the Syrian civil war or helping the rebels topple the regime.

The airstrikes hit a military facility near the presidential palace in Damascus, killing dozens of elite troops, according to Syrian officials. Israeli analysts believe the attacks were likely targeting weapons meant to be transferred from the Syrian military to Hezbollah. A US official told The New York Times that Friday's smaller airstrike, on the Damascus International Airport, had a similar target.

Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad called the Israeli strikes a "declaration of war" and threatened retaliation. However, both Syria and Israel appear to be seeking to avoid escalation, with neither side wanting the situation to develop into something greater.

In the past, Israel has staged military moves inside Syria on a few occasions, including assassinations, bombings, and the destruction of a suspected nuclear reactor in 2007. On each occasion, the Syrian regime has either ignored the incident or vowed retaliation that was never fulfilled. Israeli security analyst Reuven Pedhazur believes that neither Hezbollah nor Israel desires a fresh conflict, mindful that the next encounter would be much more destructive than the 2006 war.

Title: Over 175 Former US Officials Sign Statement Criticizing Trump's Decision to Revoke John Brennan's Security Clearance

A group of over 175 former US State Department and Pentagon officials have added their names to a statement criticizing President Donald Trump's decision to revoke the security clearance of former CIA Director John Brennan. The statement, initially signed by 15 former directors and deputy chiefs of the Central Intelligence Agency and Office of Director of National Intelligence, now includes prominent officials who worked under both Democratic and Republican presidents.

The new signatories include former NATO Commander Admiral James Stavridis, former Deputy Secretaries of State Anthony Blinken and William Burns, and former Undersecretaries of State Nicholas Burns, Wendy Sherman, and Thomas Pickering. While they may not agree with all of Brennan's public attacks on Trump, they believe that "the country will be weakened if there is a political litmus test applied" before former officials are allowed to voice their views.

Separately, US Senator Mark Warner, the Democratic vice chairman of the Intelligence Committee, filed legislation on Monday that would limit the president's ability to revoke an individual's security clearance. Trump said last week he was considering withdrawing clearances for other former high-ranking officials as well as Bruce Ohr, a current Justice Department official.

Brennan, who has publicly characterized Trump's comments at a recent summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin as "treasonous," has said he might sue the Trump administration over the revocation of his clearance. Representatives Elijah Cummings and Stephen Lynch, top Democrats on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, in a letter on Monday to White House Chief of Staff John Kelly, questioned the security clearance of John Bolton, Trump's national security adviser.

Cummings and Lynch asked Kelly to turn over documents related to whether Bolton, in security clearance forms or "other White House vetting materials," reported that in 2013 he participated by video in a roundtable discussion on gun rights organized by Maria Butina. Butina was arrested in July and accused of acting as a Russian agent while developing ties with U.S. citizens and infiltrating political groups.

The Washington Post has reported that Bolton recorded the video promoting an expansion of gun rights in Russia used by Right to Bear Arms, a group Butina formed. The White House National Security Council had no immediate comment on the letter. White House aides also declined to comment.

Russia has denied any interference in the 2016 U.S. election. Trump has said there was no collusion with his campaign.

Title: Former Vice President Joe Biden Outlines Plan to Address Racial Inequalities and White Supremacy in the United States

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden has emphasized the need for fundamental changes to address racial inequalities and white supremacy in the United States. In a recent statement, he highlighted the importance of addressing systemic racism across laws and institutions, as well as providing opportunities for black Americans to succeed.

Biden emphasized the need to root out systemic racism, citing examples such as the proposal in New York to enhance penalties for making false 911 calls based on race, gender, or religion. He also proposed directing resources to actively undo the negative effects of systemic racism on opportunities for black Americans, including supporting mission-driven lenders in low-income communities and expanding programs to help launch black-owned businesses.

The former vice president also emphasized the importance of addressing racial disparities in homeownership, citing the gap between African American and white homeownership rates. He proposed giving local officials the tools to combat gentrification, end discriminatory lending practices, and eliminate exclusionary zoning laws.

Biden also highlighted the need to address police brutality and systemic racism in law enforcement. He commended the Democratic Party's proposed legislation, which includes reforms such as banning chokeholds, ensuring independent prosecutors in police-involved killings, and requiring training for officers on racial and religious bias.

The former vice president also proposed an additional $300 million to reinvigorate community policing, which he believes is essential to building relationships between police and the communities they serve. He also emphasized the need to prevent 911 calls in scenarios where police should not be the first responders, such as mental health emergencies, and to invest in services for people experiencing homelessness.

Biden acknowledged that addressing these issues will not be easy, as institutions resist change and racism has been a fixture in society for hundreds of years. However, he emphasized the need for leadership at the highest levels of government and sustained grassroots pressure from communities to bring about change.

Title: Franken Remains Unopposed, Defying Republican Hopes

Article:

Minnesota Senator Al Franken, a Democrat, appears to have defied Republican expectations by not yet drawing a serious challenger for his seat in the 2014 elections. Franken, a former comedian and liberal talk show host, won his seat in 2009 by a narrow margin of 312 votes after a seven-month recount and legal battle. Despite being considered a top GOP target, Franken has managed to cultivate a reputation as a serious lawmaker and has amassed a formidable war chest.

The Republican Party has struggled to find top-flight candidates to challenge Franken, with potential contenders including relatively unknown state legislators, inexperienced businessmen, and a conservative radio host with a history of controversial statements. The party's recruitment challenge is not unique to Franken's seat, as they face similar difficulties in several other states.

Franken's success in fending off a serious challenger speaks to the broader challenges Republicans face in their efforts to overcome the Democrats' 10-seat advantage in the Senate. The party needs to expand its map by putting seats like Franken's in play, but so far, they have struggled to find competitive candidates in states like Michigan, New Hampshire, and Iowa.

Franken's strategy has been to keep his head down, avoid national press, and focus on populist issues like privacy and consumer protection. He has also cultivated a reputation as a serious lawmaker and has a strong war chest. Minnesota, which was once considered a purple state, has taken on a more bluish hue, and the state Republican Party is reeling from its recent losses.

A recent poll by the Democratic firm Public Policy Polling showed Franken with a double-digit lead over six potential Republican candidates, and his approval rating is just above the 50 percent threshold, a key indicator for incumbents. Republicans hope national atmospherics, such as the growing unpopularity of Obamacare and the scandals surrounding President Obama, will help put Minnesota in play, but Franken's campaign is well-prepared and has a strong financial foundation.

Title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise CEO Meg Whitman Expresses Reservations About Supporting Donald Trump

Article:

Hewlett Packard Enterprise CEO Meg Whitman, a prominent Republican Party donor, reportedly expressed reservations about supporting Donald Trump's presidential bid during a closed-door summit in Park City, Utah. The event was attended by former presidential hopeful Mitt Romney and other GOP donors. According to attendees, Whitman questioned whether it is reasonable to support Trump, citing his controversial statements.

Whitman also compared Trump to Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini, according to anonymous attendees who spoke to Politico. However, she did not explicitly endorse Hillary Clinton, stating that she will make a decision after the conventions and the selection of vice presidential running mates.

Whitman, 59, has a history of involvement in politics, having served as CEO of eBay and advised Mitt Romney during his 2012 presidential campaign. She also supported New Jersey Governor Chris Christie before he dropped out of the race. Her net worth is estimated to be around $2.1 billion, according to Forbes.

In response to Whitman's reported reservations, Trump's campaign stated that he is not interested in her endorsement. Trump told CNN that he has never met Whitman and criticized her performance as CEO of Hewlett-Packard, citing her unsuccessful gubernatorial campaign in California and the millions of dollars she spent.

Title: Republican Presidential Debate Highlights Concerns Over Trump's Comments on Islam

The Republican presidential debate hosted by CNN on Thursday night focused on various topics, including the recent violence perpetrated against journalists and protesters by Trump supporters and the Trump campaign. However, the most significant moment of the debate was Donald Trump's comments on Islam, which sparked concerns about political cynicism and religious bigotry.

During the debate, Trump stated that "I think Islam hates us. There's something there that — there's a tremendous hatred there. There's a tremendous hatred. We have to get to the bottom of it." He also declined to clarify his statement, saying it was difficult to separate radicals from the nearly 1.6 billion Muslims worldwide.

When given another chance to walk back his comments, Trump doubled down, stating that "there's tremendous hatred" among many Muslims and that "large portions want to use very, very harsh means." His opponents, including Marco Rubio, criticized Trump's comments, with Rubio saying that presidents cannot simply say whatever they want and that there are pragmatic reasons not to dehumanize 1.6 billion people.

The debate highlighted concerns about the Republican Party's stance on Islam and its potential impact on the perception of the United States around the world. The comments made by Trump and other Republicans may have significant implications for international relations and global understanding.

**China's Economic Turmoil: A New Era of Realism and Uncertainty**

The Chinese stock market has been experiencing a sharp decline, with investors worried about a weakening economy and the risk of a recession-like "hard landing" for China. This, in turn, could have a slowing influence on the global economy, which has contributed to recent downturns in the US stock market. However, some prominent forecasters believe the economy may not experience a hard landing, and instead, will experience a slowdown.

Economists argue that China's growth had been rooted in unsustainable surging investment in factories, property, and other fixed assets, making some market turbulence inevitable. The market plunge may prompt a more realistic view of China's economy, acknowledging its weaknesses and the transition from its rapid growth era to slower growth in the future.

The Chinese government is pursuing sweeping economic changes, including an overhaul of banking rules, a new system of farm property rights, and other steps towards modern regulatory systems and better market-based allocation of resources. While the road ahead may not be smooth, many China watchers believe that a success story would be if the economic bumps become steps along the way to an economy that emphasizes freer markets and more domestic consumption.

The article highlights the risks of economic challenges spilling over into political unrest, with signs of tension within the ruling Chinese Communist Party (CCP) due to President Xi Jinping's blend of centralized personal control and reformist zeal. The article also notes that a struggling China could be tempted to turn to foreign adventurism to placate a public frustrated by slower economic growth and an absence of political freedom.

Economists are not necessarily adopting "hard-landing" forecasts for China, with some predicting the economy will weather its current storm in financial markets. China's policymakers have financial firepower at their disposal to do substantially more in the way of stimulus as needed. The ultimate goal is to achieve a balanced, more sustained growth level.

Title: Trump and Kim Jong-un Engage in Verbal Sparring Over Nuclear Weapons

Article:

In a recent exchange, President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un have traded barbs on social media and in public statements. The verbal sparring began after Kim referred to Trump as an "old lunatic" in response to Trump's address to the South Korean National Assembly. Trump responded by calling Kim "short and fat" on Twitter.

In his speech, Trump urged North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program, stating, "Do not underestimate us. And do not try us... The weapons you're acquiring are not making you safer, they are putting your regime in grave danger." The North Korean Foreign Ministry responded by saying that Trump's "reckless remarks" would not intimidate them and would only accelerate their efforts to develop their nuclear force.

Trump also expressed a willingness to be friends with Kim, stating that it could be a "good thing" for North Korea and the world. However, he noted that it was uncertain whether this would happen.

This exchange is the latest in a series of verbal sparring matches between the two leaders, who have traded insults and threats over North Korea's nuclear and missile programs. The United States has imposed several rounds of sanctions on North Korea in response to its nuclear tests, including its most recent and powerful test on September 3.

Title: Senate Democrats Break from Obama on Key Issues, Criticize White House

Article:

Senate Democrats are breaking from President Barack Obama on several key issues, with some lawmakers criticizing the White House's stance on trade, Iran sanctions, the Keystone XL pipeline, Obamacare, the National Security Agency, and energy policy. This unusual level of public disagreement between the president and his party's lawmakers has been met with minimal concerns about repercussions from the White House.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a longtime ally of Obama, recently rejected a bill to fast-track trade deals, which is strongly backed by the White House. This move has been seen as a rare instance of Reid going against the president.

Some Democrats, such as Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia, have expressed discontent with Obama's State of the Union speech, saying that the president's words were "offensive" and could have been chosen better. Other lawmakers, like Senator Martin Heinrich of New Mexico, have been critical of the White House's stance on NSA surveillance programs.

Not all the criticism is coming from expected quarters. Liberal Democrats have been vocal about their concerns with the White House's policies, and some Democrats not up for reelection have been comfortable clashing with the administration.

The rifts between the White House and Senate Democrats may be a result of poor communication and a lack of coordination. President Obama does not have close personal relationships with most Democratic lawmakers, and his legislative affairs shop has faced criticism from Capitol Hill. The recent addition of Katie Beirne Fallon, a longtime Hill staffer, may help improve communication between the White House and Congress.

Senator Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, who is up for reelection this year, has been critical of the White House's surprise statement ripping her flood insurance bill, which would ease rate increases that disproportionately affect flood-prone Louisiana. Landrieu believes the statement was "unsolicited, unexpected, and misguided."

Title: Network Bias in Identifying Political Affiliations in Scandals

The recent indictment of former Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell on 14 charges, including conspiracy and fraud, has sparked a discussion about media bias in identifying political affiliations during scandals. A closer examination of the coverage by ABC, NBC, and CBS reveals a striking disparity in the way they label politicians' party affiliations.

When McDonnell's scandal broke, all three networks immediately identified him as a Republican, with ABC, NBC, and CBS referencing his GOP affiliation multiple times. In contrast, during the 2008 scandal involving former New York Governor Elliot Spitzer, the networks failed to identify him as a Democrat for two days, with ABC and NBC only providing subtle hints about his party affiliation.

The difference in coverage is striking. While McDonnell's potential crimes are serious, the media's failure to uphold the same party ID standard when it involved a scandal-plagued Democratic governor is notable. In the case of Spitzer, ABC and NBC only provided minimal information about his party affiliation, with NBC not mentioning it at all.

The disparity in coverage is not new, and it is likely that the networks will continue to prioritize identifying Republicans over Democrats in similar situations. The article highlights the importance of media transparency and the need for journalists to maintain a neutral stance when reporting on political scandals.

Title: Michigan Barber Defies Lockdown, Compares Governor's Restrictions to Nazi Tactics

A Michigan barber, Karl Manke, has gained national attention for defying Governor Gretchen Whitmer's coronavirus shutdown and having his license suspended. Manke, who has written a novel about the Holocaust, compared the governor's lockdown measures to the tactics used by the Nazis to trick Jews into entering "cattle cars" during the Holocaust.

During a protest, known as "Operation Haircut," Manke and other barbers and stylists gave free haircuts in defiance of Whitmer's social distancing requirements. The event was attended by state police, who cited several participants for their actions.

In his speech, Manke referenced his novel and compared the governor's restrictions to the Nazi propaganda that convinced Jews to enter "cattle cars" that took them to death camps. He stated, "I will not stand down. I will continue my work with or without a license. I feel I have been denied my livelihood by this governor... this is not a police state. I refuse to live in a police state."

A Court of Appeals panel has ruled that a judge should hold a hearing on the state's motion to temporarily close Manke's barbershop in Owosso and decide on the request by the end of the day Thursday.

It is unclear if Manke was among those who received citations. State police warned participants that they would be cited if they continued to cut hair, and some were cited as disorderly persons. Those convicted of disorderly conduct can face up to 90 days in jail or a fine of up to $500, or both.

Governor Whitmer has stated that it is "unlikely" that barbers, salons, and personal care services will reopen when the stay-home order expires on May 28. She emphasized the importance of social distancing and the need for protocols to be in place before such services can resume.

Some Republican lawmakers, such as state Sen. Kevin Daley, have supported the barber's actions, stating that they need to support small businesses and save livelihoods.

Title: Political Parties Engage in Despondency Arms Race Ahead of Midterm Elections

The 2022 midterm elections are just around the corner, and both the Democratic and Republican parties are resorting to a "despondency arms race" in their fundraising efforts. This phenomenon, where both sides are urging supporters to donate money to level the playing field with their opponents, is a stark contrast to the usual optimism and positivity often associated with election campaigns.

According to recent reports, the Democratic Party is outraising the Republican Party, with the 15 top Democrat-aligned committees reporting a total of $453 million in ad spending, compared to the 15 top Republican committees' $289 million. This shift in fundraising dynamics has led to a surge of despair among Republicans, who are warning their supporters that they are at risk of being "beat up" and unable to defend themselves against the Democratic Party's financial might.

Meanwhile, the Democratic Party is painting a dire picture of their own prospects, with emails warning that the party is "facing Republican opposition unlike anything we've seen" and that "right-wing billionaires are going all out to buy Republicans this election." The Democratic Governors Association has also sent out emails urging supporters to donate, stating that "poll after poll shows Dems slipping" and that "we don't have enough money to fight back."

The irony of this despondency arms race is that both parties are using similar tactics to raise money, with Republicans like Karl Rove urging donors to "open their wallets" and Democrats like Nancy Pelosi warning that the party is "coming up short." This phenomenon is a stark reminder that, in the world of politics, pessimism can be a powerful fundraising tool.

Title: Multiple Police Officers Killed and Wounded in Baton Rouge Shooting

A shooting incident in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, left multiple police officers dead and others injured on Sunday. The city's mayor, Kip Holden, confirmed that three police officers were killed and several others were wounded in the incident. The shooting occurred when officers responded to a call of shots fired and were ambushed by at least one gunman.

According to the Baton Rouge Police Department, the shooting was not believed to be race-related. The department issued a statement saying that the incident was under investigation and that authorities were seeking more than one suspect. The public was advised to be on the lookout for individuals dressed in black and carrying long guns.

The shooting occurred near Airline Highway, a mile from the Baton Rouge Police Department headquarters, where dozens of protesters were arrested earlier this month. Two nearby hospitals were placed on lockdown, but the extent of the injuries sustained by the officers was not immediately clear.

The incident comes amid a wave of protests against police violence in Baton Rouge and other cities, following the deaths of Alton Sterling, a 37-year-old African-American father of five, who was shot and killed by law enforcement officers on July 5. The Black Lives Matter movement has called for police to end racial profiling and has brought the issue to national attention ahead of the November 8 U.S. presidential election.

The Justice Department has opened a federal probe into Sterling's death, but declined to comment on the Sunday shooting. The White House has been briefed on the incident and has offered assistance to local officials.

The Baton Rouge Police Department has confirmed that one suspect is dead and that authorities are checking the shooting scene with a robot to ensure there are no explosives. The public is advised to stay away from the area and to be on the lookout for individuals matching the description of the suspects.

Title: Corporations Scramble to Make Lofty Climate Promises, But Will They Deliver?

In recent years, a growing number of major corporations have made ambitious promises to reduce their carbon footprint and transition to renewable energy sources. Delta Air Lines and BP, two companies often associated with fossil fuels, have pledged to go carbon-neutral. Microsoft and Ikea have committed to actively reducing carbon dioxide emissions. The financial giant BlackRock has promised to prioritize climate considerations in its decision-making.

According to the global nonprofit CDP (formerly the Carbon Disclosure Project), more companies are disclosing their carbon emissions and setting emissions reduction targets. The targets are becoming more ambitious, with an average time horizon of just eight years, compared to 25 years in the past. The number of Fortune 500 companies with concrete, ambitious carbon targets has quadrupled in the past four years, to 23%.

Several factors are driving this increased corporate action. The effects of climate change are becoming more apparent, with wildfires, rising sea levels, and droughts making headlines and affecting business operations. Solar and wind energy have also become significantly cheaper, making it easier for companies to commit to shifting away from fossil fuels.

Investors, customers, and the general public are also increasing pressure on companies to take action. Mainstream investors are asking companies about their climate strategies, and public awareness and concern are growing. Cities and states are taking action, and some companies are seeing the value in setting science-based targets.

Employees are also playing a role, with workers at companies like Amazon pushing their bosses to change. Some companies are seeing this as a way to attract and retain talent. A survey by the app Blind found that half of its users consider a company's climate policy when deciding where to work.

Microsoft's chief sustainability officer, Lucas Joppa, believes framing climate action as an accounting problem, with a focus on quantifying emissions and reductions, helps flip executives' mindsets. However, some experts warn that relying solely on corporate action may not be enough to address the scale of the climate crisis.

Shalanda Baker, a professor at Northeastern University, notes that vulnerable and marginalized communities need to be involved in the transition to green energy and feel the benefits of the shift. She believes government policy is crucial to ensure that corporations prioritize social justice and equity.

While corporate action is a step in the right direction, some experts argue that government policy is necessary to ensure that companies prioritize social justice and equity. Elizabeth Sturcken, a managing director at the Environmental Defense Fund, emphasizes the importance of companies engaging with policymakers and advocating for government action, such as a price on carbon.

Title: Supreme Court Weighs in on Election Rules Ahead of Midterms

The Supreme Court has been actively reviewing and adjusting the rules for the 2014 midterm elections, issuing a series of emergency stays and decisions over the past three weeks. The justices have given Ohio permission to cut early voting by a week, allowed North Carolina to end same-day voter registration, and blocked Wisconsin from implementing a new voter ID law. Another request is pending, seeking to block a Texas voter ID law from being enforced in the upcoming elections.

Legal analysts and judges argue that the Supreme Court's actions are less about broad voting rights principles and more about telling federal judges to stay out of the way, particularly close to Election Day. In each of the cases, lower federal courts had issued orders that would have changed the rules for elections just weeks away, potentially causing confusion among voters and election officials.

The justices who joined in the court's actions on emergency stays do not typically explain their reasoning, leaving it unclear why they made their decisions. However, some justices who disagreed with the decisions shared their reasons, suggesting that the timing of the decisions rather than their merits was the key factor.

The tightening of election laws in the states in question was pursued by Republican-led legislatures and opposed by Democratic and civil rights groups, who argued that it would disenfranchise minorities. The Ohio case was the only one to produce a clearly partisan split, with the five GOP appointees voting to allow the state to cut back early voting by a week and the four Democratic appointees preferring to leave in place an appeals court order barring the change.

In the North Carolina case, the high court overturned an appeals court ban on eliminating same-day registration and out-of-precinct voting, with two Democratic appointees dissenting. In the Wisconsin voter ID case, the court split 6-3, with Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Anthony Kennedy joining the court's liberals to restore a district court ban on enforcing the new voter ID requirements.

Legal experts believe that the Supreme Court's actions are aimed at preventing last-minute voter confusion and ensuring a smooth election process. While the decisions may not have been based on broad voting rights principles, they are intended to maintain order and stability in the electoral process.

Title: Republicans Face Internal Struggles Amidst Dominant Control of Government

The Republican Party has reached unprecedented levels of dominance in the United States, controlling the White House, Senate, House, 34 governorships, and 26 state legislatures. However, despite their apparent strength, Republican leaders are facing internal struggles and criticism from within their own party. According to The New York Times, Republican leaders in Congress are under attack from both the right and left, and are being spurned by frustrated donors and even threatened by the Trump White House for their perceived ineffective leadership and insufficient loyalty.

Since 1980, the Republican Party has adopted a "radicalism for the win" policy, which has led to a party that seeks out the worst in its candidates and demands disunity. This has resulted in a party that is often at odds with itself, as seen in recent events. Last week, Senate Republicans lost one of their own when Roy S. Moore, a firebrand former state judge, defeated Senator Luther Strange in a Senate runoff in Alabama. The retirement of Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee has also sparked a potentially divisive fight for his seat, with the establishment's preferred successor, Gov. Bill Haslam, declining to run. Additionally, House Republican Tim Murphy of Pennsylvania resigned this week after a text from his mistress became public, in which she mocked him for his staunch opposition to abortion as he pressured her to terminate a pregnancy.

In contrast, Democrats are often criticized for their inability to present a unified front and find common ground on policy issues. However, Republicans are currently facing their own internal struggles, with many willing to "hurl bombs" at other Republicans. Despite their dominant control of government, Republicans are struggling to maintain cohesion and present a united front.

Title: Late-Night TV Viewership: Republican Viewers Flock to Jimmy Kimmel, While Stephen Colbert's Audience Remains Liberal

Article:

A recent poll by The Hollywood Reporter has shed light on the demographics of late-night TV viewership, revealing significant differences between the audiences of Stephen Colbert's "The Late Show" and Jimmy Kimmel's "Jimmy Kimmel Live!". While Colbert's show tends to attract a more liberal audience, Kimmel's show has a more even ideological split.

According to the poll, only 17% of "The Late Show" viewers identify as Republican, the smallest margin among the big three late-night shows. In contrast, 33% of "Jimmy Kimmel Live!" viewers identify as Republican, a 16-point gap between the two comedians. Colbert's show also has a significant gap between self-identified Republican and Democratic viewers, with 47% of his viewers identifying as Democrats and 30% as Republicans.

The poll also found that Colbert's audience is predominantly male, with 55% of his viewers identifying as men, while Kimmel's audience is more evenly split between men and women. Additionally, Colbert's viewers are more likely to identify as atheist, with 30% of his audience falling into this category.

In terms of overall viewership, Jimmy Fallon's "The Tonight Show" leads the pack, with a 2-to-1 margin when viewers were asked which host is a "unpredictable, cool dude you want to be friends with." However, Colbert's liberal appeal may be limiting his wider audience growth, as his show saw a significant drop in viewership after the first six weeks of its launch.

The poll highlights the different approaches of the three late-night hosts, with Colbert's show focusing on satire and social commentary, while Kimmel's show takes a more lighthearted and humorous approach. The results suggest that while Colbert's show may appeal to a specific demographic, Kimmel's show has a broader appeal that transcends party lines.

Title: Federal Judge Rules NSA's Bulk Phone Record Collection Likely Violates Constitution

A federal judge has ruled that the National Security Agency's (NSA) bulk collection of phone records likely violates the Constitution, dealing a significant blow to the controversial spy agency. U.S. District Court Judge Richard Leon granted a preliminary injunction sought by plaintiffs Larry Klayman and Charles Strange, but stayed his decision pending appeal, giving the government time to challenge the ruling over the next several months.

In his 68-page opinion, Judge Leon concluded that the government failed to demonstrate a single instance where the program stopped an imminent terrorist attack. He wrote that the program's indiscriminate collection and retention of personal data on virtually every citizen without prior judicial approval infringes on the Fourth Amendment's protection of privacy.

The judge granted the injunction, ordering the government to stop collecting metadata associated with the plaintiffs' Verizon accounts and to destroy any such data already collected through the program. However, the ruling is not yet final, as the government is expected to appeal the decision to the appeals court, and ultimately, the Supreme Court may have the last word.

The NSA's data collection program has been the subject of controversy since former contractor Edward Snowden exposed its existence and scope over the summer. The program, authorized by a secret court, has been defended by the Obama administration as a crucial tool against terrorism. However, Judge Leon's ruling marks the first major legal defeat for the NSA since Snowden's revelations.

Title: United States Under Attack: Foreign Actors Target Election Systems and Infrastructure
