Title: Kentucky Senator's Strategy of Dredging Up Decades-Old Clinton Scandals Fails to Boost Political Aspirations

Article:

Kentucky Senator Rand Paul has found a way to stay in the headlines this winter by referencing decades-old Clinton scandals and the Monica Lewinsky affair. This strategy has proven to be a winning formula for Paul, as it prompts television producers to assemble panel discussions and editors to assign articles. The revelation of personal, decades-old correspondences between Hillary Clinton and Diane Blair, a close friend and confidant to the former first lady, has given the media an excuse to delve deeper into Clinton's past.

The strategy has been met with little resistance from the press, with many celebrating Paul's "Lewinsky star turn" and dubbing it "smart politics." However, the strategy does not seem to be working in terms of boosting Paul's political aspirations. A recent national poll found that only 9% of Republican voters consider Paul their pick to be the GOP's nominee in 2016.

Despite Clinton's historically high popularity among potential candidates, pundits continue to predict that her campaign will face numerous hurdles. The media has been eager to cover Paul's attacks, presenting the material as "bringing fresh insight into the private history of the Clintons" and "new" insights into how Clinton dealt with White House setbacks.

However, some have offered a different perspective on the matter. Veteran Time columnist Joe Klein, who has been writing about the Clintons for 30 years, belittled the notion that the Blair letters were big news or that the previously adjudicated sex scandals still matter today. "If Hillary Clinton does run for President, she should be examined carefully-as a public servant, not as a demonic caricature," wrote Klein. "She's far better than that; I hope we are, too."

Title: FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe Steps Down Amid Criticism and Controversy

FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe has left his post, effective immediately, following weeks of criticism from President Donald Trump and other Republicans. McCabe will take his remaining vacation time until he is eligible to retire from the Federal Bureau of Investigation in March.

McCabe has faced scrutiny over an alleged conflict of interest stemming from his wife's previous run for Virginia state Senate as a Democrat before he became deputy director. He has denied any conflict. Trump and other Republicans have cited the alleged conflict as part of a broader assertion of bias on the part of the FBI, Justice Department, and special counsel's office as they investigate Russian meddling in the 2016 election and any links between the Trump campaign and Moscow.

FBI Director Chris Wray addressed McCabe's departure in an email to employees, stating that he will not be swayed by political or other pressure in making decisions. Wray thanked McCabe for his service and said McCabe would take leave immediately following a conversation between the two.

McCabe's decision to step down surprised many inside the FBI and Justice Department. He will be succeeded, at least temporarily, by the No. 3 official at the bureau, David Bowdich. Special counsel Robert Mueller has obtained two guilty pleas from Trump campaign aides and charged two other Trump campaign officials with tax-related and other offenses related to private work predating the campaign.

The controversy surrounding McCabe's departure is the latest event in a highly unusual back-and-forth between the Trump administration and a federal law-enforcement establishment that is both investigating him as it works for him, and cherishes its independence. The dueling narratives about the Russia investigation have engulfed multiple senior law-enforcement officials and spilled into a fight in Congress.

Title: Mortgage-Interest Tax Deduction: A Policy Under Fire

The mortgage-interest tax deduction, a long-standing policy allowing homeowners to deduct mortgage interest from their taxes, is facing criticism from some policy experts. According to one policy adviser to a U.S. senator, the deduction "makes no sense" from a purely policy perspective. This view is supported by a significant body of academic research, which suggests that the deduction benefits the wealthy more than the poor, has little impact on home ownership, and may even drive up home prices.

Despite this criticism, the mortgage-interest deduction remains a "sacred cow" in Washington, D.C., with powerful forces working to protect it. The National Association of Realtors, for example, has a strong interest in maintaining the deduction, and would likely mount a fierce campaign against any attempts to eliminate or limit it.

Jamie Gregory, a current lobbyist for the Realtors, argues that eliminating the deduction would lead to a decline in home prices, which could destabilize the economy. He also notes that the majority of homeowners, particularly middle-class Americans, rely on the deduction to afford their homes. Phasing out the deduction over time, making it apply only to future homebuyers, is another potential solution that has been proposed.

While some policy experts may view the mortgage-interest tax deduction as a relic of the past, it remains a contentious issue in Washington, with powerful interests on both sides of the debate.

Title: Campaign Finance Reformers Lose Faith in Obama's Commitment to Change

Article:

Barack Obama, the self-proclaimed warrior against the influence of big money in politics, has faced criticism from campaign-finance reformers who claim he has failed to deliver on his promises. Despite his initial commitment to reform, Obama has taken several steps that have led to a significant increase in the influence of big money in politics. The president has granted his blessing to Priorities USA Action, a super PAC run by his former staffers, to raise and spend unlimited sums of money from corporations, unions, or individuals. This move has led to concerns that Obama is abandoning his reformist agenda and embracing a laissez-faire election system.

The White House has also failed to appoint someone to the Federal Election Commission, which has led to concerns about the commission's ability to effectively regulate campaign finance. Additionally, the administration has not responded to a plea to overhaul the FEC submitted in February by good-government types. Obama has also not pressed the Internal Revenue Service to go after nonprofits like the Karl Rove-inspired Crossroads GPS operation, which has raised over $100 million for this year's election.

Reformers, such as Public Citizen President Robert Weissman, have expressed disappointment and frustration with Obama's lack of action on campaign finance reform. "We're seeing daily things get worse, and his failure of action will result in things growing even more worse," Weissman said.

On the other hand, conservative groups like Citizens United, which prompted the eponymous Supreme Court case, are pleased with Obama's lack of action on campaign finance reform. "Obama hasn't been addressing these issues in any way, shape or form. It's great for us," said David Bossie, president of Citizens United.

The Obama campaign and White House have defended the president's actions, citing his executive order limiting lobbyists' access to the administration and his campaign's transparency in releasing information on its top fundraising bundlers. However, critics argue that these measures are insufficient and that Obama has failed to deliver on his promises to reform the campaign finance system.

Title: Trumpism: A Definition Still Elusive 100 Days into Presidency

The Trump administration has reached its 100th day, and the concept of "Trumpism" remains unclear. Initially, his strategists promised a "brash 'America First' approach" that would revolutionize the Republican Party into a true populist "Workers Party." However, the exact meaning of Trumpism has been difficult to define, with some viewing it as a combination of economic populism, social conservatism, and isolationism, while others believe it is simply a reflection of Trump's own impulses and instincts.

On foreign policy, Trump has shifted towards a more conventional Republican stance, earning praise from the bipartisan foreign-policy establishment. On domestic policy, he has moved away from his populist campaign rhetoric, embracing an Obamacare replacement plan that would have raised healthcare costs for older, low-income voters and cut entitlements.

The lack of a clear Trumpist movement in Congress has hindered the president's ability to turn his nationalist, populist, and anti-establishment instincts into a coherent governing agenda. Even the House Freedom Caucus, which was swept into office by the same anti-establishment forces that helped elect Trump, broke with him on the Obamacare bill.

Trump's base of white, working-class voters may not care about his abandonment of populist promises on the Export-Import Bank or Chinese currency manipulation, but they are paying attention to his actions on trade and immigration. Trump has been moving aggressively and confrontationally on these issues, staying focused on the same economic and cultural anxieties he stoked during the campaign.

The test of Trumpism will come with the proposed tax overhaul, which will reveal whether Trump's base feels they have been helped or hurt by the changes. If the Wal-Mart shoppers feel they have been left behind and the Goldman Sachs crowd benefits more, Trump could lose support from his base.

As the Trump administration continues, it remains unclear what Trumpism truly is. Is it a nativist version of what a Mitt Romney administration would look like, or is it up for grabs, waiting for the next impulsive decision of a president who prides himself on being transactional, flexible, and unpredictable?

Title: US Job Growth Slows, but Small Businesses Remain Optimistic Amid Economic Uncertainty

The US labor market added 69,000 jobs in May, a slowdown from the 275,000 jobs added in January. Despite this slowdown, small business owners like Srinivas Konanki, who owns Pipette Calibration Services, a laboratory equipment company outside Boston, remain optimistic about hiring and expanding their businesses. Konanki's company calibrates precise lab tools called pipettes, which measure and dispense liquids.

Konanki's business has been cautious in its hiring, but he hopes to add one more employee this year. He cites the ongoing economic turbulence in Europe and potential cuts to the National Institutes of Health as concerns that could impact his business. Betsey Stevenson, a labor economist at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business, agrees that these factors are real and notes that many businesses are worried about the "fiscal cliff" – a series of decisions facing Congress later this year that could impact the economy.

Despite these uncertainties, the US is still adding new jobs each month. David Kotok, chief economist at Cumberland Advisors, acknowledges that job growth has slowed since the start of the year, but sees reasons to be optimistic. He points to the growing manufacturing sector, the energy sector, and the gradual stabilization of the housing market as positive indicators. If these trends continue, Kotok believes that the US economy and employment will experience a slow but continued recovery.

Title: Primary Day in New York: Front-Runners Trump and Clinton Lead in Polls

The primary day in New York has arrived, with front-runners Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump leading in the polls. Trump is vowing to win enough delegates to clinch the Republican nomination and prevent a contested convention, while Sens. Ted Cruz, Bernie Sanders, and Ohio Gov. John Kasich are not giving up yet.

A big win in New York could tip the scales for both the Republican and Democratic front-runners in this year's race for the White House. Clinton and Trump have each suffered losses in recent contests, shifting the momentum to their rivals. "We have won eight out of the last nine caucuses and primaries! Cheer!" Sanders recently told supporters.

While wins in New York for Trump and Clinton are expected, the margins of those victories are also important. Trump needs to capture more than 50 percent of the vote statewide if he wants to be positioned to win all of the state's 95 GOP delegates. That would put him one step closer to avoiding a contested convention. "We've got to vote and you know Cruz is way, way down in the polls," Trump urged supporters.

Meanwhile, Sanders is hoping for a close race in the Empire State. A loss by 10 points means he'll need to win 80 percent of the remaining delegates to clinch the nomination. Despite a predicted loss in New York, Cruz has not lost momentum. He's hoping to sweep up more delegates this weekend while he's talking about how he can win in November. "Because if I'm the nominee, we win the General Election," Cruz promised his supporters. "We're beating Hillary in the key swing states, we're beating Hillary with Independents, we're beating Hillary with young people."

For now, Cruz, Kasich, and Sanders have all moved on from New York to other states. Trump and Clinton are the only two staying in their home state to watch the results come in.

Title: The Big Lie of the Trump Administration: China is Not the Cause of America's Problems

The Trump administration's claims that China is responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic and its subsequent cover-up are baseless and reckless. This narrative has been perpetuated by Trump and his right-wing allies, who claim that the virus was accidentally released from a Chinese laboratory in Wuhan and that China's "cover-up" blocked an effective global response. However, this narrative is not supported by scientific evidence and has been repeatedly debunked by intelligence agencies and independent analysis.

The article highlights the similarities between Trump's claims and those of Senator Joseph McCarthy, who used lies and innuendos to scare Americans into submission during the Red Scare of the 1950s. The author argues that Trump's claims are equally reckless and dangerous, pushing the world to conflict and undermining global cooperation.

The article also examines the biology and chronology of the pandemic, concluding that the virus was likely present in Wuhan for weeks before the Chinese authorities organized a major New Year's event that spread the virus. The author notes that the Wuhan lab did not have the COVID-19 virus under study, and that the virus is of a kind that originates in bats, but may have had an intermediate mammal host.

The article also criticizes the Trump administration's claims that China covered up the outbreak, pointing out that the Chinese authorities notified the World Health Organization (WHO) on December 31, 2019, and that the genome was fully sequenced and published online on January 11. The author notes that there were some mistakes and delays in the Chinese response, but argues that these were understandable given the early stages of the pandemic.

The article concludes by highlighting the Trump administration's failure to acknowledge the rapid timeline of the pandemic and its own lack of preparedness, and notes that the US has not yet fully gauged the recklessness of Trump and his administration.

Title: EPA Documents Reveal Close Ties Between Agency and Environmental Groups

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has been criticized for its close ties with environmental groups, with lawmakers demanding documents and emails regarding the agency's relationship with the Natural Resources Defense Council. The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, led by Rep. Darrell E. Issa, and Sen. David Vitter have ordered the EPA to hand over the documents, citing concerns that the agency's cozy relationship with the council has allowed it to influence policy decisions and advance its own agenda.

The Energy & Environment Legal Institute has released a report detailing a trail of emails that reveal a revolving door between senior EPA officials and radical environmentalists. The emails show that Sierra Club lobbyists delivered biased research to EPA officials, who then used it to justify shutting down coal plants. The report also reveals that outside activists and government employees met at the J.W. Marriott Hotel across from EPA headquarters to discuss their plans and coordinate their efforts.

The documents also show that government officials provided advance notice of regulatory actions to environmental groups, allowing them to organize grassroots support. Sierra Club employees were even allowed to distribute T-shirts at EPA headquarters. The report highlights the close relationship between EPA officials and environmental groups, with some officials even using pseudonyms to conceal their involvement.

Sen. Vitter has criticized the EPA's relationship with environmental groups, saying it is a "billionaire's club" of left-wing foundations that pull the strings of environmentalist groups that influence Washington. He suggests that the real motive behind the EPA's actions is to advance their own competing projects, rather than genuinely addressing environmental concerns.

The controversy surrounding the EPA's relationship with environmental groups has sparked concerns about the agency's transparency and accountability. The release of the documents and emails has shed light on the close ties between the agency and environmental groups, and the potential for undue influence and manipulation.

Title: The Search for a New Leader: Lessons from Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan

The article discusses the current state of the Republican Party in the United States, citing the lack of a strong leader and the need for new ideas. The author draws parallels between the current situation and the rise of Margaret Thatcher in the UK in the 1970s, who transformed the Conservative Party and led the country through significant reforms. The article also references Ronald Reagan, who brought the conservative movement to the mainstream in the US.

The author notes that while there are many talented individuals on the right with big ideas, they lack the "consumming fire" of Thatcher's personality. The article suggests that the Republican Party may be looking for a leader who can bring a similar level of passion and conviction to the table.

The article concludes by stating that while there may not be another Ronald Reagan or Margaret Thatcher on the horizon, there may be individuals rising from the chaos on the right who can bring about change and reset the trajectory of the party.

Title: Carly Fiorina's Presidential Ambitions: A Case of Sexism or Perception?

Article:

Carly Fiorina, a former business executive and politician, has been accused by many of running for vice president, rather than the top spot. This notion is widely shared among political devotees, insiders, consultants, and media outlets. However, the author of this article argues that this perception is unfair and may be rooted in sexism.

The author, who has worked with Fiorina and consulted for her in previous campaigns, acknowledges their own bias towards Fiorina. However, they point out that no one questions the ambitions of male candidates, even those who may not have a strong chance of winning the nomination. The author notes that many male candidates are running for lower-tier positions, such as Cabinet roles or party elder status, but are not being scrutinized for their ambitions.

Fiorina, on the other hand, is being treated differently. Despite her consistent efforts to take on Hillary Clinton, the expected Democratic nominee, Fiorina is seen as not serious about running for president. The author suggests that this may be due to the fact that Fiorina is a woman, and that America is not used to seeing women rise to the top in politics.

The article highlights Fiorina's unique position as the only female Republican candidate running for president in 2016, despite the party having had several high-profile female officials. The author concludes that Fiorina is indeed running for president, not just vice president, and that her ambitions should be taken seriously.

Title: White House, Democrats Clash Over Soleimani Strike

The White House and Democratic leaders have clashed over the recent strike that killed Iranian military leader Qassem Soleimani, with Republicans defending the decision and Democrats criticizing it. White House counselor Kellyanne Conway accused congressional Democrats of ignoring the danger posed by Soleimani, who was responsible for the deaths of hundreds of U.S. soldiers in the Middle East.

Conway stated that Democrats are "defending Soleimani and attacking this president, and that's on them." She also accused Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and Sen. Robert Menendez of New Jersey of "chest-thumping" with their demands for the White House to produce intelligence leading up to the attack.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell noted that some Democrats have rushed to blame the U.S. government before knowing the facts and have downplayed Soleimani's evil while presenting President Trump as the villain. Former Vice Presidential nominee Joe Lieberman criticized Democrats for their "uniformly skeptical or negative reactions" to Soleimani's death, arguing that the decision deserves bipartisan support.

Democrats have accused Trump of putting the nation on the path to another Middle East war and questioned the legality of the attack, insisting that he should have sought congressional authorization. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff called for Congress to move forward with hearings and constraints, blasting Trump's "dangerous and provocative decision."

Leading presidential candidates, including Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, also criticized Trump, with Warren calling him "dangerous" and Sanders calling for legislation to reassert Congress's constitutional authority over war.

Title: Biden's New York Swing: A Potential Challenge to Clinton's Standing with Liberal Democrats

Vice President Joe Biden's recent swing through New York, a key state in the 2016 presidential election, has sparked excitement among liberal Democrats who see him as a potential challenger to Hillary Clinton's dominance in the party. Biden's itinerary includes events focused on women's issues, labor rights, and economic fairness, all of which are crucial to progressive voters.

Biden's office insists that these events are part of his official duties and would have taken place regardless of his consideration of a presidential run. However, many see his actions as a clear indication that he is exploring a bid to challenge Clinton.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, a strong Clinton supporter, will join Biden at an event supporting a $15 minimum wage for fast-food workers, a key issue for progressive voters. Biden's long history with labor unions could be a major asset in a city with the highest union membership in the state.

While many high-profile New York Democrats have already endorsed Clinton, including Cuomo, Senators Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand, and Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, some are holding out, including New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio. De Blasio's spokesperson declined to comment on Biden's visit and Clinton's standing with progressive voters.

State Senator Gustavo Rivera, a self-proclaimed progressive, has endorsed Clinton but acknowledged that he would like to see Biden enter the race, as he believes it would force Clinton to pay more attention to progressive issues and drive her further to the left.

Clinton's campaign declined to comment on Biden's visit and her standing with progressive voters. Meanwhile, Biden will continue to test his economic fairness message, attacking "trust fund babies" and coming close to John Edwards' 2008 "two Americas" line.

While some critics argue that Biden's record is not reassuring, particularly on issues like the minimum wage and criminal justice reform, a Biden campaign could still be beneficial for Democrats, as it would force Clinton to address progressive issues and lower the threshold for victory, making Bernie Sanders a more viable option.

Title: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Obama's Foreign Policy Strategy in Interview

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has spoken out about the rise of ISIS in Iraq, attributing the group's ascent to President Barack Obama's foreign policy strategy. In an interview with The Atlantic, Clinton stated that Obama's refusal to "build up a credible fighting force" among the people who opposed Syrian leader Bashar Assad created a vacuum that the jihadists filled. Clinton also criticized Obama's broader approach to foreign policy, saying that "Great nations need organizing principles, and 'Don't do stupid stuff' is not an organizing principle."

Clinton's comments signal an attempt to distance herself from Obama ahead of a potential 2016 presidential bid. A source close to Clinton claimed that her remarks were related to her book "Hard Choices" and were simply a commentary on current events. However, a source familiar with the interview stated that Clinton's staff gave the White House advance notice of the interview.

Meanwhile, tensions between Clinton and the Obama administration appear to be escalating. Veteran journalist Ed Klein, author of "Blood Feud," claimed that President Obama authorized senior adviser Valerie Jarrett to meet with Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren, allegedly to encourage her to challenge Clinton in the 2016 presidential election.

Title: Governors' Stay-at-Home Orders Spark Debate Over Essential Services, Including Places of Worship

Governors across the United States have issued stay-at-home orders to combat the spread of the coronavirus, presenting difficult decisions on which businesses and services should remain open. One of the most contentious debates has centered around whether places of worship, such as churches, mosques, and synagogues, should be forced to close.

Over a dozen governors have included exemptions in their orders for religious gatherings, although some have limitations on the number of attendees and social distancing measures. The majority of religious leaders have complied, either by holding small services or switching to online worship. However, some have defied restrictions by continuing to hold regular services to packed crowds.

Law enforcement officials in several states have intervened, with an evangelical Christian pastor in Florida arrested for continuing to hold large services last week. The state's governor later issued a stay-at-home order with an exemption for religious gatherings with no limitations on crowd size.

Advocates for closing all places of worship during the pandemic argue that public health takes precedence over First Amendment freedoms. They point to evidence that religious gatherings can be particularly dangerous, as coronavirus clusters in Washington, California, and several other states have been linked to religious gatherings.

On the other hand, many religious leaders argue that physical attendance is not necessary to practice one's faith and point to online services as a high-quality alternative. Legal analysts say closing places of worship does not violate freedom of religion as laid out in the First Amendment in the specific case of the pandemic.

A vocal group of faith leaders and congregants argue that religion is an essential part of their lives, and the freedom to practice as they see fit – even if it puts them at risk – supersedes public health orders. Others support allowing small religious gatherings that adhere to social distancing, rather than complete bans. Places of worship serve an important role beyond religious services in many communities, some argue. If permitted to safely stay open, they could serve as critical points of support for people with health or economic needs.

Orders that force religious institutions to close completely may backfire, some argue, by creating an adversarial stance between religion and government that stokes fears of persecution.

Title: George Soros-backed Media Network Helps Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's Political Career

The rise of Democratic socialist Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to political prominence has been linked to the support of billionaire George Soros and his network of far-left media outlets. According to reports, Soros-backed organizations, including Justice Democrats and Brand New Congress, played a crucial role in propelling Ocasio-Cortez's political career.

Ocasio-Cortez, a former organizer for Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign, was encouraged to run for office by members of Soros-funded media outlets, including Cenk Uygur, a founder of Justice Democrats. Uygur, who was forced out of the organization after old articles surfaced revealing his past sexist comments, guaranteed favorable coverage for Ocasio-Cortez through his media network.

Ocasio-Cortez's strong online presence, fueled by the coverage of Soros-linked digital media, helped her defeat incumbent Joseph Crowley in the primary election on June 26. Crowley, who was expected to succeed Nancy Pelosi as Democratic leader of the House, greatly outspent Ocasio-Cortez.

In an interview with The Young Turks, a member of the Soros-funded Media Consortium, Ocasio-Cortez acknowledged the role of Justice Democrats and Brand New Congress in her political rise. "I wouldn't be running if it wasn't for the support of Justice Democrats and Brand New Congress," she said.

The Media Consortium, a network of far-left media publications, reaches nearly 300 million people monthly, according to the Media Research Center. The network includes outlets such as Mother Jones, Democracy Now!, and The Young Turks, all of which are funded by Soros. The Media Research Center notes that Soros funds nearly every major left-wing media source in the United States, with 45 outlets receiving support through the Media Consortium.

The report highlights the progressive echo chamber created by Soros, with the intention of shaping public opinion. The Media Research Center details the network's influence, stating that it is a "network of the country's leading, progressive, independent media outlets."

Title: Obama Appoints Ron Klain as Ebola Response Coordinator

The White House has announced that President Barack Obama will appoint Ron Klain as the Ebola Response Coordinator, a role aimed at streamlining the federal response to potential Ebola outbreaks in the United States. Klain, a highly regarded manager with excellent relationships within the administration and on Capitol Hill, will be responsible for ensuring the integration of efforts from various government agencies and making key decisions.

According to White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest, Klain's role will be an important, high-level implementation position, focusing on ensuring the government's response is carefully coordinated and effective. Earnest emphasized that Klain will work closely with White House Homeland Security Adviser Lisa Monaco and National Security Adviser Susan Rice.

Klain's background includes experience in domestic policy and foreign policy, which will be crucial in addressing the Ebola crisis. While some lawmakers have criticized the administration's response to Ebola, citing a lack of preparedness and personal protective gear for healthcare workers, Klain's appointment aims to rectify these issues.

The appointment has received mixed reactions from lawmakers, with some Republicans expressing concerns about Klain's lack of a healthcare background. House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Ed Royce suggested that the President should have chosen someone with medical experience. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida also raised concerns, calling for concrete actions to reassure Americans that the administration is taking the situation seriously.

The term "Ebola czar" is not officially endorsed by the White House, with Press Secretary Earnest instead referring to Klain as the Ebola Response Coordinator. Despite the criticism, Klain's appointment is seen as a step in the right direction, aiming to improve the government's response to potential Ebola outbreaks.

Title: Illinois Governor Rauner's Executive Order Aims to Reduce Red Tape and Licensing Burdens

Article:

Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner has issued Executive Order 16-13, aimed at reducing the state's regulatory burden and licensing requirements. The order aims to cut job-killing red tape by at least 25% over the next two years and save individuals at least $250 million in government fees. To achieve this goal, Rauner has established the Illinois Competitiveness Council, which will oversee the review and reform of state regulations.

One of the key focuses of the council is occupational licensing, which requires individuals to obtain government permission before working in certain professions. This permission often comes with significant time and financial burdens, acting as disincentives to work. The executive order states that licensing rules cause delays in pursuing one's chosen profession and create anti-competitive barriers to entry into the marketplace.

Illinois ranks 30th in terms of overall licensing requirements and burdens, according to the Institute for Justice's comprehensive report. The state requires licenses for 40 low- and middle-income occupations, disproportionately affecting young and low-income Americans. In contrast, Indiana licenses only 15% of its workforce.

Many Illinois licenses do little to ensure public safety, as demonstrated by the less-burdensome standards in other states. For example, Illinois is one of few states that licenses pharmacy technicians, requiring two years of training, while 39 states do not license the occupation at all. Similarly, Illinois requires 1,825 days of training and three tests to become a preschool teacher, while California requires only 365 days of training and no tests.

The Red Tape Reduction Portal, created by Governor Rauner's program, allows Illinoisans to flag state regulations that hinder their businesses. Restoring sanity to licensing follows Rauner's overall message that government should only stand in the way of someone's ability to earn a living if necessary. The current licensing system in Illinois creates substantial time and financial barriers to work that often do little or nothing to ensure public safety.

While cutting back regulation is never easy, there is reason to be optimistic about Illinois' reform efforts. Other states have recently reformed their business regulations, and governors can single-handedly follow through on their promises to open more work opportunities.

Title: Lame-Duck Session Expected to be Uneventful, Focusing on Government Funding Renewal

The upcoming lame-duck session in December is expected to be a quiet one, with both Senate Democrats and House Republicans privately stating that there will be no major legislative push. The main item on the agenda is the renewal of government funding, which will run until December 11. The House is likely to pass a government-funding bill this week, and the Senate will return to Washington in late November for leadership elections.

According to sources, there will be no major legislative efforts on issues such as immigration, tax, or entitlement reform. The Export-Import Bank's charter will be extended until June 30, 2015, avoiding a potential December fight over what some conservatives consider corporate welfare.

The lack of major legislative action is attributed to the uncertainty surrounding the power structure in the next Congress. If Republicans take the Senate, they are unlikely to cooperate in December, and if Democrats maintain control, the political gridlock will remain frozen. There is only one deadline, and it is the beginning of the month.

House Republicans are being cautious not to place any legislative fights in the opening months of 2015, as they do not want Republicans to have a rocky start if they snatch the Senate majority. There is also talk of a closed-door Senate-House policy retreat to develop an agenda if the party grabs control from Harry Reid.

In contrast to previous lame-duck sessions, which resulted in major fiscal deals, this year's session is expected to be uneventful. The government-funding bill will be extended, and there may be some minor legislative action on targeted tax provisions and the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act, which expires at year's end. However, there are no major legislative battles expected, and the post-election period is likely to be a quiet one.

Title: Obama Administration's Female Representation in Executive Branch Increases

The Obama administration has faced criticism earlier this year regarding the lack of female representation in key positions, particularly after prominent office holders like Hillary Rodham Clinton and Hilda L. Solis left the administration. However, since then, President Obama has named a series of women to top posts, including interior secretary, commerce secretary, budget director, and director of the Environmental Protection Agency.

According to a New York Times analysis of federal employment data, as of June 2012, 43 percent of Mr. Obama's appointees had been women, a proportion similar to that of the Clinton administration and an increase from the roughly one-third appointed by George W. Bush.

The largest gains in the number of women in the executive branch occurred during the Clinton administration, with women holding more than 18 percent of cabinet-level jobs. In his second term, the share exceeded 40 percent, with women holding a substantially larger share of senior roles in the executive branch than they did in Congress or in corporate America.

In contrast, the share of women holding board seats on Fortune 500 companies has risen over the last two decades, to 16.6 percent last year from 9.6 percent in 1995, according to Catalyst. While the executive branch continues to have a larger share of women in senior roles than Congress or corporate America, it has also changed less since the 1990s.

Title: President Trump Retweets Controversial Content, Including Conspiracy Theorist and Image Depicting Violence Against Media

President Donald Trump started his Tuesday morning by retweeting a series of controversial images and sources, sparking criticism and concern among critics. The retweets included posts from Jack Posobiec, an alt-right figure known for promoting conspiracy theories, and an image depicting violence against the media.

The retweets came as Trump's initial statement denouncing white supremacists for their role in the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia, was criticized for being inadequate. The statement was released 48 hours after Trump's initial remarks, which were widely seen as insufficient and lacking in condemnation of white supremacist groups.

One of the retweets in question was from Posobiec, who questioned why there was no national media outrage over the violence in Chicago. The retweet remained on the president's account as of Tuesday morning.

Trump also retweeted an image from @slandinsocal, which depicted a person holding a CNN sign being hit by a train, with the commentary "Nothing can stop the #TrumpTrain!" The image was an altered version of an IndyStar editorial cartoon, which showed a Democratic donkey trying to hold back the Trump train.

The retweet was reminiscent of another controversial tweet from the president, which featured a GIF of him body-slamming and punching CNN. The retweet came the day after Trump called a CNN reporter "fake news" during an exchange at the White House.

The timing of the retweets was seen as particularly poor by many social media users, coming just days after a 20-year-old alleged white nationalist drove a car into a crowd of people protesting the "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville, killing one and wounding 19 others. Attorney General Jeff Sessions said the incident appeared to fit the legal definition of domestic terrorism.

The retweet was later deleted, but it is unclear why. The president has deleted tweets and retweets in the past.

Walter Shaub, the former head of the Office of Government Ethics, called on Congress to condemn the president's actions, given the recent violence in Charlottesville.

Trump also retweeted Mike Holden, who called the president a "fascist" in response to news that the president was "seriously considering" a pardon for former Arizona Sheriff Joe Arpaio. Trump had retweeted a story about a possible pardon for Arpaio, who was found guilty of criminal contempt related to a racial profiling case. The retweet was later deleted, but Holden's Twitter bio reads "Officially Endorsed by the President of the United States. I wish that were a good thing."

Title: Marine Corps Delays Pull-up Requirement for Female Recruits

The United States Marine Corps has announced a delay in implementing a new physical standard for female recruits, which requires them to perform three pull-ups. The requirement was initially set to take effect on January 1, but the Marine Corps has pushed back the deadline to gather more data and ensure female Marines have the best opportunity to succeed.

Currently, 55% of female recruits are unable to complete three pull-ups, compared to only 1% of male recruits. The Marine Corps has been using pull-ups as a test of upper body strength for male recruits for over 40 years, and the requirement is necessary for serving in ground combat.

The delay has raised questions about whether women have the physical strength to handle ground combat, which they will be allowed to do beginning in 2016. Some critics argue that women are not physically capable of meeting the same standards as men, citing the need for upper body strength to perform tasks such as pulling oneself out of a canal or carrying ammunition.

However, others argue that women can build the strength they need through training and that some female Marines have already demonstrated their ability to meet the standard. Greg Jacob, a former Marine and advocate for military women, notes that women can develop the strength needed for pull-ups with proper training and motivation.

The Marine Corps has postponed the requirement to avoid losing recruits and current female Marines who may not meet the standard. The Corps has also been criticized for not providing enough training opportunities for women to develop the necessary strength.

The debate surrounding the issue highlights the challenges faced by women in the military as they seek to integrate into previously male-dominated roles. While some argue that women are not physically capable of meeting the same standards as men, others believe that with proper training and support, women can succeed in these roles.

Title: Supreme Court Rules Sixth Amendment's "Speedy Trial" Clause Does Not Apply to Sentencing Phase

The Supreme Court has unanimously ruled that the Sixth Amendment's "speedy trial" clause does not apply to the sentencing phase of a criminal prosecution. The court's decision, Betterman v. Montana, specifically addressed the question of whether the "speedy trial" guarantee applies to the sentencing phase, and the court held that it does not.

The case involved Brandon Thomas Betterman, who was given a seven-year prison sentence 14 months after he initially pleaded guilty to felony bail jumping in a Montana state court. Betterman took the case to Montana's Supreme Court, which ruled that sentencing was not part of the "trial" in a "speedy trial" – a ruling the Supreme Court upheld.

The court's opinion, delivered by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, noted that the Sixth Amendment's "speedy trial" clause protects the accused from arrest or indictment through trial, but does not apply once a defendant has been found guilty at trial or has pleaded guilty to criminal charges. The court ruled that the language in all three stages of criminal proceedings – investigation, charge and trial, and sentencing – have distinctly separate protections.

The court's decision emphasizes that the Sixth Amendment's "speedy trial" clause is focused on the period from arrest or indictment through conviction, and does not extend to the sentencing phase. The court noted that the Constitution may have other protections that apply during the sentencing phase, but did not specify what those protections might be.

In a concurring opinion, Justice Sonia Sotomayor emphasized that Betterman was not wrong to question inordinately long sentencing times, but argued that he brought the wrong case to challenge the issue. Sotomayor noted that the question of whether the due process clauses of the Fifth and 14th Amendments provide additional protections during the sentencing phase remains an open one.

The Supreme Court's decision provides guidance for lower courts and lawyers on the scope of the Sixth Amendment's "speedy trial" clause, and highlights the importance of considering the distinct protections afforded during each stage of criminal proceedings.

Title: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg Criticizes Twitter's Fact-Checking Policy

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has expressed concerns about Twitter's fact-checking policy, stating that private companies should not be the "arbiter of truth" for online content. In an interview with Fox News' Dana Perino, Zuckerberg emphasized that Facebook has a different approach to fact-checking, which does not involve labeling or censoring content.

Zuckerberg's comments come after Twitter attached a fact-check notification to a tweet from President Trump, cautioning users that his claims about mail-in voting were disputed by fact-checkers. Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey responded, stating that the platform's intention is to connect the dots of conflicting statements and show the information in dispute, allowing users to judge for themselves.

Facebook has faced criticism in the past for failing to address controversial content on the platform, but Zuckerberg has no plans to change the company's policy. In a 2017 interview, Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg expressed similar sentiments, stating that Facebook does not intend to be the "publisher and we definitely don't want to be the arbiter of the truth."

Zuckerberg also responded to President Trump's warning that social media giants could face "strong regulation" or "closure" if they continue to "silence conservative voices." He expressed skepticism about the government's role in censoring platforms, saying that it does not strike him as the right reflex.

The debate surrounding fact-checking and content moderation on social media platforms continues to be a topic of discussion, with both Twitter and Facebook taking different approaches to addressing misinformation.

Title: Secretary of State Kerry Urges International Cooperation to Combat Ebola

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry addressed a gathering of foreign ambassadors at the State Department in Washington on Friday, emphasizing the need for a concerted international effort to combat the Ebola epidemic. Kerry warned that if the international community does not come together to address the crisis, Ebola could become a long-term scourge like HIV or polio. He called on countries to use their influence to make stronger commitments to the Ebola fight, which has affected Sierra Leone, Guinea, and Liberia, as well as spreading to the United States and Europe.

Kerry praised a few countries for their contributions to the effort, including Cuba, which has sent 165 health professionals and plans to send nearly 300 more. The United Nations has called for $1 billion to be donated to the Ebola response effort over the next six months, but so far, only about a third of that amount has been met.

Kerry emphasized the importance of international cooperation, stating that every country has a role to play in combating the epidemic. He acknowledged that there may be disagreements on the best course of action, but emphasized that Ebola is not one of them. The World Health Organization estimates that there will be between 5,000 and 10,000 new Ebola cases per week in West Africa by the first week of December, highlighting the urgent need for a coordinated response.

Title: Israel and Turkey Normalize Relations After Netanyahu's Apology for 2010 Mavi Marmara Incident

Article:

In a significant development, Israeli Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu and Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan held a phone conversation, marking the first direct contact between the two leaders since Netanyahu took office in 2009. The conversation was facilitated by US President Barack Obama and came as Obama was leaving the country. During the call, Netanyahu expressed regret for the loss of life in the 2010 Mavi Marmara incident, in which nine Turkish activists were killed, and agreed to complete an agreement on compensation.

According to Erdogan's office, he accepted the apology and emphasized the importance of the centuries-long strong friendship and cooperation between Turkey and Israel. The UN's report on the 2010 flotilla raid, which was released in 2011, found that while Israel's use of force was unreasonable, the country had the right to blockade Gaza and that Turkish authorities did not do enough to prevent a confrontation with the Israeli Defense Forces.

The normalization of relations between Israel and Turkey is seen as a significant development, as it signals a deepening concern among Syria's neighbors about the potential spillover of the war. The exact nature of this concern is unclear, but it may be related to claims of chemical weapons use or other forms of escalation. The development is also seen as a blow to Iran, which prefers its enemies in Tel Aviv and anti-Assad Islamists to remain divided.

It is worth noting that the UN report on the 2010 flotilla raid is still a topic of debate, with some criticizing Israel's actions and others defending them. However, the report's findings do not necessarily support Erdogan's earlier statement that Zionism is a crime against humanity, which he later clarified to mean that Zionism is a crime against humanity only in relation to Gaza.

Title: Federal Judge Blocks Trump's Travel Ban, Citing "Religious Animus" Toward Muslims

A federal judge in Maryland has blocked President Trump's latest travel ban, ruling that the White House's third attempt at "extreme vetting" is still tainted by the president's campaign-season "religious animus" toward Muslims. The ruling, issued by Judge Theodore D. Chuang, an Obama appointee, came just hours after another Obama-appointed judge in Hawaii issued a similar injunction.

The travel ban, which restricts admission to visitors and would-be immigrants from Chad, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Syria, and Yemen, was deemed likely illegal by both judges. However, restrictions on North Korea and Venezuela, two non-Muslim countries, were allowed to go into effect.

Judge Chuang's 91-page ruling stated that the current ban's list of eight countries subject to severe restrictions is similar to the previous list of six, suggesting little has changed. The earlier ban applied to Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen, while the new list adds Chad, North Korea, and Venezuela.

The Supreme Court had been set to hear arguments on the earlier version of the travel ban last week, but after Trump's revisions in September, they called off the hearing, saying the lower courts needed to evaluate the new policy. The 120-day pause on refugee admissions, part of the original executive order, remains mostly in effect, with some court-ordered exceptions. The 120-day period expires at the end of this month, and analysts are waiting to see whether Trump tries to extend the pause.

**Families Separated at the Border: Uncertainty and Uncertainty Remain**

In the wake of President Donald Trump's reversal of his policy of separating children from parents who cross the U.S.-Mexico border illegally, many questions remain unanswered about the fate of the over 2,300 children already separated from their parents. Lilian Merida-Galicia, a 23-year-old Guatemalan, was apprehended with her 7-year-old daughter in mid-May and has been trying to learn her daughter's whereabouts. Her attorney, Michael Avenatti, says she is one of over 60 immigrant parents he represents, with 80% of them not knowing where their children are.

The federal government and Congress are scrambling to address the many unanswered questions raised by Trump's hastily drafted executive order. Attorney Luis Cortes Romero represents a Salvadoran woman who was separated from her 11-year-old daughter with Down syndrome after crossing the U.S.-Mexico border in Texas. The woman is being held in Washington state and has decided she doesn't want to pursue asylum so she can be deported and reunited with her daughter.

Trump has suggested that some of the wrenching tales that have emerged from the border are fabricated by Democrats, sparking criticism from lawmakers and advocates. The president has flip-flopped on his stance on comprehensive immigration legislation, urging Republican lawmakers to drop their efforts to pass a bill until after the November congressional elections.

The House of Representatives has rejected a bill backed by conservatives that would have halted the practice of splitting up families and addressed other immigration issues. The House postponed a vote on a more moderate bill after it failed to attract enough support for passage. Trump's latest tweets could doom that effort.

The uncertainty surrounding the fate of the separated children and their parents remains, with it unclear how and when those children will be reunited with their parents and where families will be held while parents face criminal charges. The U.S. Navy is drafting plans to house up to 25,000 immigrants on its bases and other facilities, but it remains unclear if the government will keep prosecuting cases against people caught crossing the border illegally.

Title: Trump Faces Political Challenges as Coronavirus Pandemic Spreads and Economy Tanks

The ongoing coronavirus pandemic has presented a significant challenge for President Donald Trump's re-election prospects, as the virus continues to spread and the economy takes a hit. The U.S. stock market, which Trump has touted as evidence of his success, has plunged into bear market territory, leaving many Republicans worried about the impact on his political standing.

Trump's response to the crisis has been criticized for being too little, too late, with some Republicans expressing concern that his early downplaying of the virus has damaged his credibility. The president's greatest strength, the economy, is now under threat, and if the stock market continues to decline and real people begin to feel the financial pinch, it could harm his political prospects.

Moderate Democrats have consolidated their support behind former Vice President Joe Biden, who has seized the opportunity to offer a contrast to voters with his own coronavirus speech. Biden lambasted the administration's handling of the crisis, portraying himself as a steady, experienced hand in the face of a public health emergency.

The Trump campaign has defended the president's actions, accusing Biden of trying to "capitalize politically and stoke citizens' fears." However, the growing threat from the coronavirus has forced Trump to reverse course and suspend his large campaign rallies.

The crisis has also reshaped the contours of the presidential campaign, with Democratic officials announcing that Sunday's televised debate between Biden and Sanders will be moved to Washington from Arizona. The debate will be held without an audience, citing contagion concerns.

Biden, Sanders, and Trump have all canceled campaign events in recent days after warnings from public health officials about holding large-scale gatherings. The crisis has also led to a shift in campaign tactics, with Biden's campaign converting planned rallies into "virtual" events and Trump's campaign moving training sessions online.

While some Republicans remain loyal to Trump, others are expressing concern about his handling of the crisis. A Republican strategist said Trump's handling of the coronavirus was hurting him now, but it was too soon to gauge its impact on his long-term political prospects.

Title: Controversy Surrounds President's Use of the Word "S-hole"

The recent controversy surrounding President Donald Trump's alleged use of the term "s-hole" to describe Haiti and certain African countries has sparked a heated debate. The term, which is considered offensive by many, has been met with widespread criticism and outrage. However, some have defended the President's comments, citing the need for honest and open discussions about the challenges faced by these countries.

One argument put forth is that the President's unfiltered and unrefined rhetoric is a reflection of his strengths and weaknesses. While some may wish for a more sophisticated approach, others believe that the President's blunt honesty is a refreshing change from the typical political speak.

Others argue that labeling countries as "s-holes" is not productive and can be hurtful to those who live in these countries. They suggest that a more nuanced approach, such as describing countries as "dysfunctional" or "corrupt," would be more accurate and less offensive.

The article also touches on the idea that the President's comments may have some validity, as many immigrants from these countries do rely on welfare programs and have lower rates of education and employment compared to other immigrant groups. However, this argument is not without its flaws, as it does not take into account the complex factors that contribute to these disparities.

The article also highlights the double standard applied to the President's comments, as many on the left have labeled America as "systemically racist" without providing evidence to support this claim. The article suggests that this labeling is just as hurtful and inaccurate as the President's use of the term "s-hole."

In conclusion, the controversy surrounding the President's use of the term "s-hole" highlights the complexities and nuances of language and the challenges of navigating the complexities of international relations. While some may see the President's comments as offensive and hurtful, others may view them as a necessary and honest discussion about the challenges faced by certain countries. Ultimately, the debate highlights the importance of nuance and context in understanding the complexities of language and international relations.

Title: Trump Appoints Richard Grenell as Acting Director of National Intelligence

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday night that he will appoint Richard Grenell, the current U.S. ambassador to Germany, as the acting director of national intelligence. Grenell, a staunch defender of the president, will oversee the 17 U.S. intelligence agencies and advise the president and the National Security Council on intelligence matters related to national security.

Grenell's appointment comes after Dan Coats vacated the role in August 2019. As acting DNI, Grenell will be responsible for integrating the U.S. intelligence community and advising the president on intelligence matters. Trump has previously expressed suspicion and distrust of the intelligence community, which he has referred to as the "Deep State."

Grenell, a longtime Republican political operative, has close ties to Trump's inner circle and has supported the president's agenda. He will also be the first openly gay Cabinet secretary. Prior to his appointment as ambassador to Germany, Grenell worked as a political adviser to Republicans, as the longest-serving U.S. spokesperson to the United Nations, and as the founder of Capitol Media Partners, a media and public affairs consultancy.

Grenell has been a regular on Fox News and has been aggressively pursuing Trump's agenda in Germany, earning praise from Trump and criticism from some German politicians. As ambassador, Grenell has pressured German companies to cut business with Iran, urged Germany to increase its NATO contributions, and warned against participating in the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline with Russia.

It is unclear whether Trump will ultimately nominate Grenell for the permanent DNI position, which would require another Senate confirmation. Trump has stated that he prefers putting people in "acting" positions because it gives him flexibility.

Grenell's appointment has raised concerns among some German politicians, who have objected to his Twitter diplomacy. However, Grenell has defended his actions, stating that "no one is threatening you" and that the U.S. has the right to its own policy.

Title: House Approves Stopgap Bill to Keep Government Open, Boost Spending

The House of Representatives approved a stopgap bill on Friday, ensuring a short-lived government shutdown and providing a $300 billion boost in spending over the next two years. The bill, which passed with a vote of 240-186, will keep the government open for another six weeks, allowing lawmakers to work on a more comprehensive two-year deal.

The bill lifts strict spending caps on defense and non-defense spending, suspends the debt ceiling for 13 months, and provides additional funding for various programs. President Trump signed the measure shortly after its passage, praising its support for the military and its potential benefits for the economy.

Democrats celebrated the increase in domestic spending, while Republicans highlighted the surge in defense funding. Speaker Paul D. Ryan emphasized the bill's support for the military and disaster relief efforts. Individual lawmakers also pointed to specific provisions benefiting their home states, such as disaster relief for Texas and protections for dairy farmers in Vermont.

However, some lawmakers expressed disappointment over the lack of action on protecting young undocumented immigrants, also known as "Dreamers." House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi reiterated her call for a freewheeling debate on the issue.

The bill had passed the Senate earlier with a vote of 71-28, with support coming from both parties. Senator Rand Paul, a Kentucky Republican, had temporarily held up the proceedings, causing the government to shut down. Paul expressed no regrets over the shutdown, stating that he will continue to advocate for fiscal responsibility and the principles that led to the Republican Party's trust with the government.

Title: The Connection Between Fatherlessness and Mass Shootings: A Statistical Trend

The recent El Paso mass shooting has sparked a renewed discussion about the potential factors contributing to such tragedies. One trend that has emerged is the high incidence of fatherlessness among mass shooters. According to the article, the El Paso shooter's parents divorced eight years ago, and he did not live full-time with his father. This phenomenon is not unique to mass shooters, as a study in Baltimore found that fewer than 20% of teenagers are being raised by married parents.

The author argues that this trend is not limited to mass shooters, but is also prevalent in inner-city violence, where fatherlessness is a common factor. The article suggests that addressing this issue can be done on an individual level by parents staying married, being present, and raising their children.

The author notes that while it is impossible to know for certain whether the El Paso shooter would have committed his act if his parents had stayed together, the chances seem likely. The article highlights the negative consequences of fatherlessness, including feelings of abandonment and confusion, which can calcify into deep-seated anger.

The author also emphasizes the importance of fathers in teaching their sons how to channel anger and aggression in a constructive way, as well as teaching them how to take healthy risks, stand up to bullies, and respect women. While mothers can also pass along these lessons, the author argues that a father's presence is essential in demonstrating how to be a man.

The article concludes that while this trend does not excuse the actions of mass shooters, it is essential to focus on addressing the root causes of fatherlessness and encourage parents to stay married, be present, and raise their children.

Title: The Human Story of Immigration: A Personal Reflection

The story of immigration is often lost in the crossfire of political debates, with both sides presenting their own narratives and agendas. However, it is essential to remember that immigration is about people, not talking points. The story of Paul Gavora, a Czechoslovakian refugee who came to the United States in the 1940s, serves as a powerful reminder of the human side of immigration.

Born in 1931, Gavora grew up in a tumultuous time, witnessing the German invasion and the arrival of the Red Army. He was expelled from school for questioning Communist doctrine and eventually swam the Danube River to escape the Communists. He went on to attend college, worked as a milkman, and eventually opened a chain of supermarkets in Alaska.

Gavora's story is a testament to the American dream, where he was given the opportunity to carve out a life for himself and his family. He remained grateful for the chance to build a new life and invested his time, money, and love in his community.

The story of immigration is not about politics or ideology; it is about people who leave their homes in search of freedom and a better life. It is about those who are desperate to make the most of the American dream, just like Gavora. The takeaway from his story is not that he got rich, but that the United States gave him a chance to build a life he wanted, and he remained grateful for the opportunity his whole life.

The current conversation about immigration is toxic because we disagree about what it means to be an American. Immigrants are often cast as either victims or villains, but the truth is that most are human beings who are desperate to make the most of the American dream. They are not animalistic members of MS-13, nor are they eager to be props for the latest campus debate about intersectionality. They are people who are fleeing their homes in search of freedom and a better life.

The story of immigration is not owned by any party, but each can abandon it. It is a story of people leaving or fleeing their places of birth for the freedom to try their best.

Title: California Voters to Decide on Cage-Free Farm Animal Welfare Measure

California voters will soon decide whether to ban the sale of meat and eggs from farm animals raised in cages. Proposition 12, a November ballot measure, would require more spacious living conditions for pigs, veal calves, and egg-laying hens. The measure applies to animals in California and those raised elsewhere for products sold in the state.

The measure is endorsed by the Humane Society of the United States, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the Sierra Club, the California Democratic Party, the United Farm Workers, and the Center for Food Safety. The Yes on 12 campaign has raised $6.1 million as of September 28, while the opponents, Stop the Rotten Egg Initiative, have raised about $566,000.

The measure requires each farm animal to have a specific amount of floor space, with 43 square feet for a veal calf, 24 square feet for a breeding pig, and 1 square foot for an egg-laying hen. Cage-free conditions will be mandatory for hens by 2022.

The Association of California Egg Farmers and the National Pork Producers Council oppose Proposition 12 primarily because the measure applies to all veal, pork, and eggs sold in California, even when the animals are raised in other states. For example, a pig raised and slaughtered in Illinois could not be housed in a crate if bacon or sausage from that animal is headed to California.

Some farmers argue that confining animals in cages is necessary for their well-being and cost-effectiveness. Ken Maschhoff, a fifth-generation hog farmer, believes that confining pigs during pregnancy is both humane and cost-effective because it prevents fighting between the animals, allowing more piglets to survive in the womb.

However, proponents of the measure argue that confining animals in cages reduces them to products and goes against their natural behavior. Dede Boies, a farmer who raises chickens, ducks, turkeys, and pigs on an open field, believes that confining animals in cages is not in line with their natural behavior and reduces them to products.

The cost of implementing cage-free conditions is a concern for some farmers, with estimates suggesting that it could increase the cost of pork by $100 to $150 per year. However, economists say it's difficult to predict exact price increases.

The outcome of Proposition 12 is uncertain, with some animal welfare groups, such as People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, opposing the measure, citing concerns that it does not go far enough to protect chickens. Even if voters approve the measure, the battle over farm animal welfare is likely not over.

Title: Thousands Protest Across the United States Over George Floyd's Death

Thousands of people took to the streets across the United States to protest the killing of George Floyd, a black man who died after being pinned by a white police officer's knee in Minneapolis. The demonstrations, which began on May 29, have spread to cities including New York, Atlanta, Detroit, and Denver, with protesters demanding justice and an end to police brutality.

In New York, thousands of protesters stormed the security perimeter of Barclays Center in Brooklyn, with police making scores of arrests. The demonstration was marked by clashes between protesters and police, with bottles and other projectiles being thrown. In Atlanta, a police car was among several vehicles set on fire, and windows were smashed at the CNN building.

In other cities, protests were more peaceful, with hundreds gathering in Detroit and Denver to demand justice for Floyd and others who have died at the hands of police. In Atlanta, Bernice King, the youngest daughter of civil rights icon Martin Luther King Jr., implored people to go home, saying, "The only way we get what we really want is through non-violence. Let's do this the non-violent way to deal with the evil of our time."

The protests are a response to the killing of Floyd, who died on May 25 after being pinned by a police officer's knee. The incident has sparked widespread outrage and calls for police reform.

Title: Supreme Court's Recent Decisions on Same-Sex Marriage, Voting Rights, and Abortion Raise Questions on Transparency

The Supreme Court has opened its 2014 term with a flurry of major decisions on same-sex marriage, voting rights, and abortion, all handled in private without explanation or breakdown of how the justices voted. The court did not hold oral arguments, and the two sides in each dispute submitted lengthy briefs summarizing their arguments. The justices issued lists of grants and denials, leaving it to lawyers and journalists to speculate about the whys and wherefores.

The court's decisions have significant implications for the country, with the justices clearing the way for gay and lesbian marriages in Alaska and affecting the lives of thousands of voters, women seeking abortions, and same-sex couples in at least 11 states. However, the court's secrecy surrounding its decisions has raised concerns about transparency and accountability.

Chief Justice John Roberts appeared to be a key player in the court's recent actions, with some speculating that he was among the justices who refused to grant cases from Utah, Oklahoma, Virginia, Indiana, and Wisconsin, clearing the way for gay and lesbian marriages in those states and others. Roberts also seemed to be a decisive vote in the court's blocking of an anti-abortion law in Texas and a voter ID law in Wisconsin.

While some argue that the court's secrecy is necessary to avoid controversy and maintain its independence, others believe that the justices owe the American people clear explanations for their decisions and conduct. The court's decisions have an enormous practical effect on society, affecting the lives of thousands of people, and without explanations or vote counts, the justices' actions can seem arbitrary.

The court's recent decisions may come back to haunt it, as the orders are temporary and can be appealed back to the Supreme Court. The court's decisions on voting rights, abortion, and marriage equality may set it up to issue earth-shaking rulings in the heat of the next presidential election season, putting it at the center of the 2016 political maelstrom.

Title: Obama Acknowledges Website Issues, Pledges to Address Problems and Help Consumers

The Obama administration has acknowledged the difficulties faced by millions of Americans attempting to access the federal healthcare website, which was designed to facilitate enrollment in the Affordable Care Act. President Obama stated that there is "no excuse" for the botched opening of the website, which has frustrated many individuals seeking to compare insurance policies and obtain coverage.

The administration attributes the problems to a combination of factors, including unexpectedly high demand and technical glitches that have blocked or slowed the submission of applications and led to errors in data transmission to insurers. However, the exact reasons behind the high demand and the nature of the technical issues remain unclear.

In response to the website's failures, the administration has implemented a two-part approach to address the issues. First, it has brought in additional information technology experts to work around the clock to resolve the technical problems. Second, it has expanded alternative methods for consumers to access healthcare information and enrollment options, including increased staffing at call centers, in-person assistance from navigators, and downloadable applications.

President Obama has also pledged to personally contact consumers who encountered difficulties with the website and provide guidance on completing their applications, shopping for coverage, and selecting a suitable plan. The administration's efforts aim to ensure that the healthcare exchanges can effectively help enroll the estimated seven million uninsured Americans in 2014.

Title: Apple and Other Retailers Close Stores to Minimize Coronavirus Risk

Apple Inc, a technology company, has announced that it will close all its retail stores, except those in Greater China, for the next two weeks to reduce the risk of coronavirus transmission. This decision follows similar moves by several U.S. retailers on Saturday. The closures are part of a growing global response to the outbreak, as most companies had previously kept their stores open.

Apple CEO Tim Cook stated in a letter that the company will close all its retail stores outside of Greater China until March 27. Urban Outfitters Inc, which owns brands such as Anthropologie and Free People, has also announced that it will close all its consumer stores worldwide until at least March 28. Verizon Communications Inc has temporarily closed some of its stores in the United States, while T-Mobile US Inc will close its mall-based stores starting March 16.

Apple had previously reopened its 42 branded stores in China on Friday, as the number of new cases has decreased in the country where the outbreak originated. The World Health Organization reports that 153,000 people have been infected worldwide, with 5,788 deaths.

Retailers are bracing for a potential blow to sales as consumers in Europe and the United States stay home due to the virus. Some retailers, including Macy's Inc, Saks Fifth Avenue, and Gap Inc's Banana Republic, had initially decided to remain open, citing concerns about lost revenue. However, Apple's hourly workers will continue to receive pay in alignment with business-as-usual operations, and online sales will continue as usual.

Urban Outfitters has also announced that it will continue to pay its store employees while stores are closed. The company's CEO stated that all offices will move to flexible work arrangements worldwide, except in Greater China, where business will continue as usual.

Title: Budget Deal Reached by Murray-Ryan: Convenient for Congress, Bad News for the Nation

The two-year budget agreement crafted by Senator Patty Murray and Representative Paul Ryan has been hailed as a convenient solution for Congress, but it is bad news for the rest of the country. The deal forestalls election-year standoffs and prevents major budget showdowns until at least 2015, which is a relief for lawmakers who have had to spend many late nights haggling over deals and have seen their approval ratings plummet.

However, the deal has some significant drawbacks for the nation. One of the most notable omissions is the lack of an extension of unemployment benefits, which will leave over 1 million laid-off workers without benefits in 2014. According to the Congressional Budget Office, this will slow growth by 0.2 percentage points and reduce the number of jobs by around 300,000.

Furthermore, the deal requires federal employees to increase their contributions to their retirement, effectively cutting their pay by another 1%. This comes on top of pay freezes that have already cut real wages by more than 5% over the last three years. The deal also fails to address the underlying issues that have been holding back the economy, such as the need for infrastructure investment and job creation.

Dean Baker, a senior economist at the Center for Economic and Policy Research, argues that the deal will continue to impose a drag on the economy by preventing the sort of growth that is needed to return to full employment. He notes that the economy still lacks a source of demand to replace the demand generated by the housing bubble, and that the private sector is not likely to fill this gap on its own.

Baker suggests that the government could have devoted funds to rebuilding infrastructure, retrofitting homes and businesses to make them more energy-efficient, and improving healthcare and education, but instead, the deal will lead to further cuts that will both lead to deteriorating services and fewer jobs. As a result, millions of people will continue to be unemployed or underemployed for the foreseeable future, and workers will lack the bargaining power to secure their share of economic growth.

In conclusion, while the budget deal may be convenient for Congress, it is bad news for the nation, as it fails to address the underlying issues that have been holding back the economy and will continue to impose a drag on growth.

Title: Grass-Roots Activists' Efforts to Oppose Immigration Reform Bill Show Signs of Waning Intensity

The current bipartisan immigration legislation, introduced by the "Gang of Eight," has not sparked the same level of opposition as a similar bill in 2007. Coordinated rallies last week to oppose the bill drew sparse crowds, with fewer than 10 people attending a protest in Dover, Delaware. The number of phone calls to lawmakers' offices opposing the bill has also decreased significantly, with some offices receiving fewer than 100 calls per day compared to over 2,000 calls in 2007.

Rusty Childress, a veteran opponent of illegal immigration, expressed frustration with the lack of momentum against the bill, saying, "We have to awaken the sleeping giant."
