However, others, like Alan Ogushoff, who made protest calls to lawmakers' offices in 2007, have become "burned out" and are no longer actively opposing the bill.

The current bill would provide a pathway to citizenship for about 11 million people illegally in the U.S. and create new work visa programs. It would also require the Homeland Security Secretary to submit a border security plan before illegal immigrants gain provisional legal status, the first step in the legalization process. Opponents argue that the bill amounts to amnesty for lawbreakers and does not address the root causes of illegal immigration.

Despite the lack of intense opposition, opponents of the bill are planning to intensify their campaign. "Remember 1986," a group led by Rusty Childress, sponsored coordinated rallies last week and plans to target a "tea-party base" that is "newly energized" since the IRS news broke.

The path to citizenship provision of the Senate bill could prove particularly challenging in the House, where opposition is expected to be stronger. The bill has not yet been tested in the Senate, and efforts by a bipartisan House group to write a similarly broad bill have not succeeded.

In contrast, groups pressing for an immigration overhaul, such as businesses and undocumented youngsters, have been more vocal. The Evangelical Immigration Table, made up of leaders of Christian groups, will launch a new round of national radio ads to promote the bill.

Title: HealthCare.gov Sees Record Sign-ups Ahead of December 15 Deadline

The Affordable Care Act (ACA) exchanges have seen a surge in sign-ups, with over 670,000 people enrolling for coverage ahead of the December 15 deadline for January 1 coverage. This marks the highest number of sign-ups since the launch of the exchanges three years ago. Despite technical issues causing about 1 million people to leave their contact information, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) extended the enrollment deadline until December 19 at 11:59 PM PST.

The increased sign-ups come as the administration has been aggressively promoting the ACA, with President Obama, Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Burwell, Senator Cory Booker, and comedian Bill Murray among those participating in videos to encourage enrollment. The administration has also been working to address technical issues and provide in-person assistance through localhelp.healthcare.gov and the 1-800-318-2596 hotline, available 24/7 in English and Spanish.

Sign-ups have been rising steadily this week, with over 325,000 Americans selecting plans on HealthCare.gov on Monday and over 380,000 on Tuesday, marking two of the biggest days in HealthCare.gov history. Deadlines for state exchanges vary, but several allow enrollment for January 1 coverage for a few more days.

Even with a potential repeal of the ACA, individuals who do not have insurance through their jobs will still be required to purchase it, at least until 2017 and likely longer. A plan to replace the ACA could take several years.

Title: Trump's Remarks on Ukraine Call Suggest He May Be Seeking to Distance Himself from Responsibility

Article:

President Donald Trump has reiterated that his call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was "perfect" and that he did nothing wrong. However, he also made some additional comments that have raised eyebrows. According to sources, Trump said that he did not want to make the call, but was persuaded to do so by Energy Secretary Rick Perry. The call was reportedly about an LNG (liquefied natural gas) plant.

The White House did not respond to requests for comment on the matter. Another source on the call said that Trump added that "more of this will be coming out in the next few days" – referring to Perry.

It is worth noting that text messages released this week between Trump administration officials and Andrey Yermak, a top aide to Zelensky, suggest that Trump's personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, was a primary advocate for arranging the call. There is no mention of Perry playing a role in making the call happen.

Energy Secretary Rick Perry has become increasingly embroiled in the congressional Democrats' impeachment inquiry. Perry led a U.S. delegation to Ukraine for Zelensky's inauguration in place of Vice President Mike Pence, and Democrats have begun to press Perry for more information about the trip and his conversations with Ukrainian leaders. The House subpoena of Rudy Giuliani also seeks documents related to Perry's "involvement with Ukrainian leaders last spring."

Perry has denied any wrongdoing, stating that neither Joe nor Hunter Biden's name ever came up in his conversations with Ukrainian leaders. His spokeswoman, Shaylyn Hynes, said that Perry supported and encouraged the president to speak to the new president of Ukraine to discuss matters related to their energy security and economic development.

Title: Trump Suggests Hosting Next Year's G7 Summit at Trump National Doral Golf Resort

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has expressed interest in hosting the next Group of Seven (G7) summit at his Trump National Doral golf resort in Florida. The summit, which brings together leaders of the world's major industrialized countries, typically rotates among the member countries. Trump believes his resort, located near Miami, would be an ideal location due to its size and proximity to the airport.

In an interview during the current G7 summit in Biarritz, France, Trump emphasized the convenience of his resort's location, stating that it is only a five-minute drive from Miami International Airport. He also highlighted the area's natural beauty and the fact that it is a popular tourist destination.

While a final decision has not been made, Trump believes his resort is the best option, citing its location as a major advantage. "We haven't had anything that could even come close to competing with it, especially when you look at the location," he said.

In a subsequent news conference, Trump reiterated that he would not personally profit from hosting the G7 summit at his resort. "From my standpoint, I'm not going to make any money. In my opinion, I'm not going to make any money," he said.

Trump has attended three G7 summits, with each meeting being held far from any airport that can accommodate his Air Force One plane. He praised the setup in Biarritz, France, which allowed him to avoid the need for lengthy drives or helicopter rides. However, he did not express enthusiasm for the unexpected guests invited by France, such as Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, who held talks on the summit's sidelines.

Title: Understanding the Concept of "Defunding the Police": A Closer Look at the Three R's of Police Reform

The debate surrounding police funding has gained momentum across the United States, with many Americans seeking to understand what "defunding the police" actually means. For some, the phrase is synonymous with the literal elimination of police departments, potentially leading to anarchy. However, for others, it represents a specific set of policy proposals aimed at reforming the way law enforcement operates.

Randal Mayer, a former Cato policy analyst and justice reform advocate, has outlined the "three R's of police reform": Reduce, Reinvent, and Redeploy. According to Mayer, "Reduce" involves reducing expenditures on militarized equipment, over-policing minor violations, and militarized training. This would mean allocating more funds towards testing backlogs of rape kits and increasing detective ranks for investigating serious and violent crimes, which often go unsolved. Additionally, it would involve reducing officers with poor records and requiring subsidized malpractice insurance for police, making them more liable and easier to prosecute for wrongdoing.

The "Reinvent" aspect of police reform focuses on transforming police departments into community-focused organizations with an emphasis on de-escalation training and culture. This would involve reinventing military-style rankings, recruitment tactics, and the overall culture of police departments, as well as changing engagement rules to reduce potential harm to suspects. It also questions what "calling the police" means to the community: Do we want actual help and non-fatal conflict resolution, or a SWAT-style response to a mental health check-in? Do we want unidentifiable men clad in black military garb responding to peaceful protests, or something more community-focused?

The "Redeploy" aspect involves redeploying newly trained and cultured police in the community to maintain a rule of law, while also holding police liable for their conduct and actions. Regardless of one's stance on the "defund the police" debate, these questions are worth considering.

Title: Protesters Occupy Oregon Wildlife Refuge, Demand Release of Local Ranchers

Article:

A group of armed protesters, identifying themselves as the "Citizens for Constitutional Freedom," stormed the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon on Saturday, sparking a standoff with local authorities. The protesters, led by Ammon Bundy, a son of Cliven Bundy, who was involved in a similar standoff against the federal government in 2014, are demanding the release of local ranchers Dwight and Steven Hammond.

The Hammonds were convicted of arson in 2015 for setting fires on federal land in 2001 and 2006. Although they served their original sentences, an appellate judge ruled in October that the terms were too short under federal minimum sentencing laws, and they were ordered to serve four years each. They arrived at the Terminal Island Federal Correctional Institution on Monday afternoon.

The Hammonds' attorneys stated that they have respected the rule of law and have litigated the matter within the federal courts for over five years, following the orders of the court without incident or violation.

Ammon Bundy accused federal officials of launching an "attack" on the Hammonds for refusing to sell their land. The protesters took over the wildlife refuge after participating in a peaceful rally, claiming to be part of a militia group supporting local ranchers. However, Sheriff Dave Ward of Harney County disputed this, stating that the protesters had alternative motives to overthrow the county and federal government.

FBI officials called for a "peaceful resolution" to the standoff, but did not provide specifics about their response, citing "safety considerations" for both those inside the refuge and law enforcement officers involved.

Ryan Bundy, Ammon's brother, stated that they plan to stay at the refuge as long as it takes, and if the situation turns violent, it will be because of the federal government's actions. Dwight Hammond Jr. and his son Steven have claimed that they set the fires to reduce the growth of invasive plants and protect their property from wildfires, while prosecutors argued that the fires were set to cover up poaching.

The dispute is part of a decades-long controversy over the use of public lands, with some Westerners pushing for more local control and others advocating for the federal government to administer the lands for the widest possible uses, including environmental and recreational purposes.

Title: Trump Fills Out West Wing Team with Competing Power Centers

President-elect Donald Trump has begun filling out his senior team in the West Wing, naming Kellyanne Conway as his counselor and Sean Spicer as his press secretary. Trump also appointed campaign spokesman Jason Miller as communications director, campaign spokeswoman Hope Hicks as strategic communications director, and Dan Scavino, who ran social media for Trump's campaign, to do the same for his White House. All four were given the title of assistant to the president.

The flurry of announcements ended weeks of rumors and jockeying for position among Trump's campaign veterans and supporters. Conway and Scavino are considered "Trump originals" who were with him from the start, while Hicks and Miller are more recent hires. The appointments have set up three competing power centers in the administration, promising a continuation of the competition for Trump's ear that occurred throughout the campaign and transition process.

Conway, a veteran GOP pollster, will be the highest-ranking woman in the White House. She will continue her role as a close advisor to the president and will work with senior leadership to effectively message and execute the administration's legislative priorities and actions. Conway has been a trusted advisor and strategist who played a crucial role in Trump's victory. She will be responsible for dealing with data and strategy, pulling from her background, and will likely continue to play a prominent role in communications.

The appointments have sparked concerns among some longtime aides that they are being frozen out in favor of more recent hires like Conway and Miller, as well as members of the GOP establishment like Spicer and incoming White House chief of staff Reince Priebus. Corey Lewandowski, Trump's first campaign manager, announced that he will start a lobbying firm in D.C. rather than accept a White House job other than the one he wanted.

In a statement, Trump said, "Kellyanne Conway has been a trusted advisor and strategist who played a crucial role in my victory. She is a tireless and tenacious advocate of my agenda and has amazing insights on how to effectively communicate our message. I am pleased that she will be part of my senior team in the West Wing."

Conway has been a visible presence throughout the campaign and transition, and her appointment has sparked speculation about the role she will play in the new administration. She has hinted that she would turn down a White House role because it would take her away from her four young children, but ultimately decided to accept the position.

Title: Trump's Press Conference Comments on George Floyd Spark Misinterpretation

President Donald Trump held a press conference on Friday, during which he discussed the country's job numbers and the role of the National Guard in limiting damage caused by riots and looting. Several news outlets, including ABC News, Business Insider, the Independent, and the New York Daily News, reported that Trump said he hoped George Floyd was looking down from heaven and was happy about the improving job numbers. However, a closer examination of the transcript reveals that Trump's comments were actually referring to the concept of "equal justice under the law" and the need for fair treatment from law enforcement.

During the press conference, Trump discussed the importance of equal justice under the law, stating, "Equal justice under the law must mean that every American receives equal treatment in every encounter with law enforcement, regardless of race, color, gender, or creed. They have to receive fair treatment from law enforcement. They have to receive it." He then mentioned George Floyd, saying, "Hopefully George is looking down right now and saying, 'This is a great thing that's happening for our country. This is a great day for him. It's a great day for everybody. This is a great, great day in terms of equality. It's really what our Constitution requires and it's what our country is all about.'"

It is clear that Trump was referring to the concept of equal justice under the law and the need for fair treatment from law enforcement, rather than the job numbers. While there are valid arguments to be made that Trump's comments were tone-deaf, the context of the conversation makes it clear that he was not imagining George Floyd's reaction to the job numbers.

Title: Study Finds Political Polarization Drives Income Inequality in the United States

A recent study published in the Journal of Elections, Public Opinion and Parties has found that political polarization is a significant driving force behind income inequality in the United States. The study, which analyzed data from the two major American political parties, concluded that Democrats and Republicans are primarily focused on addressing the economic concerns of their own constituents, with little consideration for those outside their base.

The study found that Democrats prioritize unemployment, while Republicans focus on inflation and wages. This partisan divide leads to a seesawing of economic priorities, which in turn perpetuates income inequality. The study's authors noted that this phenomenon is not new, but has accelerated since the 1970s.

Another study by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas found that income inequality and political polarization are inextricably linked, with both variables feeding back on each other. This means that as income inequality increases, political polarization grows, and vice versa.

Historically, both parties had a mix of rich and poor constituents who voted their economic interests, maintaining an economic balance for much of the second half of the 20th century. However, this is no longer the case, and the change is not doing the economy any favors.

The Princeton study, which looked at voter partisanship and income from 1956 to 1996, found that partisanship has become more stratified by income. The study's authors concluded that party affiliation is often directly tied to one's tax bracket, with voters voting for their own economic interests. This has led to a constant tug-of-war between the two parties over the economy.

The findings of these studies suggest that political polarization is a significant contributor to income inequality in the United States, and that efforts to address this issue will require a more nuanced understanding of the complex relationships between economic interests, party affiliation, and voter behavior.

Title: Former President George W. Bush to Campaign for Vulnerable Republican Senators

Article:

Former President George W. Bush has announced his decision to campaign for several vulnerable Republican senators in the 2016 Senate election. According to The New York Times, Bush will be supporting Senators Roy Blunt (R-MO), Ron Johnson (R-WI), and Rob Portman (R-OH) in the coming weeks. This marks a significant shift from Bush's previous reluctance to participate in politics since the end of his second term in 2008.

The likely reason for Bush's sudden involvement is the recent rise in his approval ratings. A 2015 CNN poll showed that 52% of Americans have a favorable impression of him, up from 2009 when only around a third of the public approved of him. This increased popularity may have made his endorsement more valuable to Republican senators facing tough re-election battles.

The decision to campaign for these senators may also be a response to the unpopularity of presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump. According to a new Washington Post/ABC News poll, Trump's unfavorability has reached an all-time high at 70% disapproval. This has led some Republican senators to distance themselves from Trump, with Senators Kelly Ayotte (R-NH) and Ron Johnson (R-WI) stating they will "support, but not endorse" him. Senator John McCain (R-AZ) has also expressed concerns about Trump's stance on immigration, calling the election "the race of his life" due to the large Hispanic population in Arizona.

In contrast, Bush's approval ratings have improved significantly since his presidency, making his endorsement more valuable to Republican senators. His decision to campaign for these senators may be seen as a way to maintain the Republican-held Senate as a "check and balance" on the White House, although it is unclear which potential president he is referring to.

Title: US Attorney General William Barr Refuses to Testify to House Judiciary Committee on Russia Inquiry

Article:

US Attorney General William Barr has declined to testify before the Democratic-led House Judiciary Committee on his handling of the Russia inquiry, citing objections to a plan for lawyers to ask questions during the hearing. The standoff has raised the prospect that Barr, the country's top legal official, could be held in contempt of Congress.

The Justice Department also refused to comply with a subpoena issued by Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler, requesting an unredacted version of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report and files from the investigation. Barr was grilled by a Senate panel on Wednesday about his decision to clear President Donald Trump of obstruction of justice, with Mueller expressing frustration over the report summary.

The Justice Department described the conditions placed on the House Judiciary Committee hearing as "unprecedented and unnecessary," stating that most committee members are lawyers and do not require attorneys to ask questions. However, Nadler believes Barr is afraid to testify due to his "dishonest" actions and plans to subpoena him if he does not show up.

Barr testified for the first time since the release of Mueller's 448-page report, which did not establish any collusion between the Kremlin and the Trump campaign. The report concluded that the Republican president had repeatedly intervened with the investigation, which he feared would doom his presidency. Barr defended his actions, stating he was "absolutely" confident that Trump did not unlawfully attempt to impede the investigation.

The standoff between Barr and the House Judiciary Committee comes as Mueller is expected to testify to Congress later this month. The special counsel expressed frustration over the report summary, stating that it did not fully capture the context, nature, and substance of his findings, causing "public confusion about critical aspects of the results of our investigation."

Title: Trump Defends Business Dealings in Russia, Calls Cohen a "Weak Person"

President Donald Trump has defended his business dealings in Russia, calling them "very legal and very cool" as he arrived in Argentina for the G-20 summit. Trump took to Twitter to reiterate his defense, stating that he was doing nothing wrong in running his business during the 2016 presidential campaign.

According to Trump, he was a "very good developer" who decided to run for president and continue running his business, which included looking at doing a building in Russia. He claimed that he put up "zero money, zero guarantees, and didn't do the project," and that it was a "witch hunt" to suggest otherwise.

Trump's comments come after his former personal attorney, Michael Cohen, pleaded guilty to making false statements to Congress about his involvement in pursuing a Trump Tower project in Moscow during the 2016 presidential campaign. Cohen's guilty plea stated that he made false statements "in hopes of limiting the ongoing Russia investigations."

Trump called Cohen a "weak person" and claimed that he is trying to get a reduced sentence by making up a story. He also stated that Cohen is not a "very smart person" and is trying to get a lesser prison sentence.

Cohen's dealings while serving as a senior executive in Trump's global empire included several projects thought to be of interest to Mueller's prosecutors, most notably the pursuit of a Trump Tower project in Moscow during the presidential campaign. According to court documents, Cohen falsely told Congress that the Moscow project ended in January 2016, but he continued to look into business plans on that deal.

Trump's comments have sparked controversy, with Democratic Rep. Adam Schiff calling the news a "very significant plea and statement." Schiff stated that it means that when Trump was representing during the campaign that he had no business interests in Russia, that was not true, and that Cohen's testimony was false.

The investigation into Trump's business dealings in Russia is ongoing, and it remains to be seen what further developments will come to light.

**Saudi Arabia Sentences Five to Death, Three to Prison in Jamal Khashoggi Murder Case**

A Saudi Arabian court has sentenced five individuals to death and three to prison in connection with the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was killed last year. The verdict has been met with criticism from the United Nations and human rights groups, who argue that the trial was a "mockery" of justice and that the masterminds behind the killing remain free.

The court found that the killing was not premeditated, but rather occurred "at the spur of the moment." The five individuals sentenced to death were described as "foot soldiers" in the killing, while two senior security officials acquitted played a more significant role.

The UN special rapporteur for extrajudicial summary or arbitrary executions, Agnes Callamard, called the verdict a "mockery" of justice, stating that the hit-men were guilty, but the masterminds were allowed to go free. The UN-led inquiry reported in February that the evidence pointed to a "brutal and premeditated killing, planned and perpetrated" by Saudi officials.

Human rights group Amnesty International described the verdict as a "whitewash" that failed to address the Saudi authorities' involvement or the location of Khashoggi's remains. The publisher of the Washington Post, where Khashoggi wrote a column, said the lack of transparency and the Saudi government's refusal to cooperate with independent investigators suggested a "sham trial."

Khashoggi's son, Salah, expressed confidence in the Saudi judiciary, stating that the verdicts had been fair to his children. However, the US government has called the verdicts an "important step" in holding those responsible accountable, but will continue to press for full accountability.

The trial was marked by secrecy, with the names of the 11 defendants not immediately released. The Saudi prosecutor said there was no evidence connecting one of the acquitted officials, Saud al-Qahtani, to the killing, and the court dismissed charges against Ahmed al-Asiri, a former deputy intelligence chief.

**US Evacuates Hundreds of Citizens from Quarantined Cruise Ship in Japan**

Two planes carrying hundreds of US citizens who were on the coronavirus-hit Diamond Princess cruise ship in Japan have arrived in the United States. The passengers will be isolated at military facilities for 14 days. The ship, with over 3,700 passengers and crew, has been in quarantine since February 3.

The US Department of State reported that 14 of the repatriated passengers tested positive for the virus and will be kept separate from others. The remaining passengers will undergo a 14-day quarantine, in addition to the time they spent confined on the ship.

In Japan, a public gathering to celebrate the birthday of Emperor Naruhito has been cancelled due to concerns over the spread of the virus. The Tokyo marathon, scheduled for March 1, has also been affected, with the amateur part of the race cancelled and only elite runners allowed to participate.

China has reported 2,051 new cases of the virus in the past 24 hours, with 94% of those cases coming from Hubei province, the epicenter of the outbreak. The country has seen over 70,600 reported cases and 1,771 deaths, with most new cases and deaths reported in Wuhan, Hubei's largest city.

The article also mentions the repatriation of passengers from other countries, including Israel, Hong Kong, and Canada, as well as the consideration of an evacuation flight by the UK.

Title: Hong Kong Protests: A Global Movement for Democracy and Autonomy

The city of Hong Kong has been in lockdown since Tuesday, with barricades and a heavy police presence, as authorities attempt to prevent protests from overshadowing China's National Day celebrations in Beijing. The former British colony has been plagued by nearly four months of street clashes and demonstrations.

The protests, which began in June, have gained international attention, with both sides calling on world leaders to support the protesters. Hong Kongers have taken a DIY approach to protest, using social media, celebrity endorsements, and targeted media campaigns to keep the issue in the spotlight.

The protests are centered around the perceived erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy and democratic freedoms, which were guaranteed by the 1984 Sino-British Joint Declaration. The agreement, signed by then-UK Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Chinese Premier Zhao Ziyang, ensured Hong Kong's autonomy upon its return to China in 1997.

The protests have gained international support, with many calling on the US to take a stronger stance. The Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act of 2019, which would enshrine American support for Hong Kong's democracy and autonomy into law, has been praised as a crucial step in supporting the protesters.

The act would require the State Department to annually certify and report to Congress whether Hong Kong's autonomy and adherence to protecting civil liberties and upholding the rule of law justify its continued special status. It would also ensure that violators of human rights in the region are held accountable by applying sanctions and banning entry to the US.

The passage of the act would send a powerful symbolic message to the people of Hong Kong that American support for their democracy is more than just empty words. Tens of thousands of Hong Kongers have taken to the streets to call for the act to be passed into law.

The protests have also drawn parallels with other global movements, such as those in Venezuela, Sudan, and Algeria, where people are risking their lives to challenge tyrannical regimes. The Hong Kong protests are a reminder that the fight for democracy and human rights is a global struggle, and that the US has a responsibility to support those fighting for their rights.

In conclusion, the Hong Kong protests are a critical moment in the global fight for democracy and autonomy. The passage of the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act of 2019 would be a crucial step in supporting the protesters and sending a strong message to the Chinese government that the world will not stand idly by as democracy is eroded.

Title: Three Fatalities in Oklahoma Walmart Shooting, Shooter Among the Dead

A shooting occurred outside a Walmart store in Duncan, Oklahoma, on Monday, November 18, 2019, resulting in the deaths of two men and one woman. The shooter was also among the fatalities, according to authorities.

The incident occurred around 10:00 a.m. in the parking lot of the Walmart store, with two victims being shot inside a car and the third dying in the parking lot. The Oklahoma State Bureau of Investigation (OSBI) is still processing the scene, and authorities have not released the identities of the deceased.

Police Chief Danny Ford stated that the victims were shot by the gunman, who then took his own life. The OSBI believes the shooter acted alone and that there was no active shooter inside the store. The shooting was described as an isolated incident.

The victims had been inside the Walmart Money Center, which offers various services, before being killed. The shooter did not enter the business. A handgun was found at the scene, and the OSBI is still investigating the motive behind the shooting.

Walmart spokeswoman LeMia Jenkins released a statement offering condolences to the family of the woman killed, who had been employed by the company for less than two months. Jenkins stated that the woman was at the Walmart during her free time and was not scheduled to work that day.

The shooting is the third to occur at a Walmart store in the United States this year, following incidents in El Paso, Texas, and Mississippi. The Oklahoma shooting comes amid a recent spate of high-profile shootings across the country, including incidents in California, New Jersey, and Santa Clarita, California.

**Senate Control Remains Elusive for Democrats as Election Day Approaches**

As Election Day approaches, the final polls suggest that Democrats face an uphill battle to gain control of the Senate. With Republicans defending fewer seats, Democrats must defend 26 seats, including many in conservative states. While some key races remain close, the party has paths to retake the chamber, albeit difficult ones.

The latest RealClearPolitics polling averages show that Democrats are leading in several races, including Florida, Montana, and West Virginia, with margins ranging from 2 to 11 points. In contrast, Republicans are leading in four key races, including Nevada and Arizona, with margins ranging from 0 to 6 points.

Democrats need to gain two GOP-held seats to achieve a majority, but they also have many more imperiled incumbents, and for each one who loses, they would need to pick off another GOP-held seat to keep their hopes alive. These polls indicate that Republicans are the favorite to hold the majority.

However, polling errors in the mid-single digits are common in individual Senate races, and there have been instances where polls underestimated Republican candidates in key Senate races in the past. Democrats are defending more seats than Republicans, and many of those Democratic incumbents are in states won by Donald Trump.

If Democrats were to win every Senate race where the polls are close, as well as all the other races they currently lead by larger margins, they would gain two GOP-held seats, including Nevada and Arizona, and get within one seat of a majority. However, this scenario is unlikely, and Democrats would need to find another pickup somewhere to achieve a majority.

The median outcome in FiveThirtyEight's classic forecast is for a 51-49 Senate controlled by Republicans, but their model gives Democrats about a one-in-five chance of taking over the chamber. While some Senate polls have been off in recent years, it's not uncommon for polls to be off by 5 or 6 points in Senate races.

Title: Trump Campaign Chairman Paul Manafort Resigns Amid Controversy and Poor Poll Numbers

Donald Trump's campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, has resigned, effective immediately. This move comes just days after Trump brought in Steve Bannon, former executive chairman of the right-wing news site Breitbart, as his new campaign leadership. The resignation is the latest in a series of shake-ups within the Trump campaign, which has been struggling with poor polling numbers and self-inflicted controversy.

Manafort's departure was announced on Friday, with Trump expressing gratitude for his work in helping to get the campaign to where it is today. However, the move was met with surprise by some within the campaign, who had been told that Manafort would not be leaving.

The resignation is seen as a response to the growing controversy surrounding Manafort's ties to Russia and Ukraine, as well as his role in advising foreign politicians, including Ukrainian strongman Viktor Yanukovych. Trump had been under pressure to distance himself from Manafort's connections to Russia, which have been criticized as a potential liability in the midst of the ongoing presidential election.

Manafort's departure marks the second major shake-up within the Trump campaign in recent weeks, following the forced departure of campaign manager Corey Lewandowski in June. The campaign has also seen the addition of new leadership, including Kellyanne Conway, who will now be in charge of messaging, and Steve Bannon, who will run the business side of the campaign.

The resignation comes as Trump's campaign is facing mounting pressure to improve its performance in the polls. Trump has been struggling to connect with voters and has seen his approval ratings plummet in recent weeks. The campaign has also been criticized for its handling of controversies, including Trump's recent apology for his intemperate remarks.

In a statement, Trump expressed no regret over Manafort's departure, saying that he appreciated his work in helping to get the campaign to where it is today. However, the move is seen as a significant blow to the Trump campaign, which had been counting on Manafort's expertise to help it navigate the general election.

Title: The Rise of Right-Wing Nationalism: A Complex Phenomenon Beyond Economic Anxiety

The recent rise of right-wing nationalism across the Western world has sparked a heated debate about its causes and motivations. A recent article by Zack Beauchamp in Vox argues that the electoral success of right-wing movements is not primarily driven by economic anxiety, but rather by racism, Islamophobia, and xenophobia. This perspective is echoed by many liberal commentators who view Trump supporters and their analogues overseas as motivated by bigotry and fear.

However, this narrative oversimplifies the complex phenomenon of right-wing nationalism. While it is true that some individuals may be motivated by racist or xenophobic beliefs, it is also important to consider the role of economic factors, such as globalization and its effects on communities. The article notes that communities that are thriving economically do not typically show spikes in suicide and widespread addiction to prescription painkillers, suggesting that economic factors may play a role in the rise of right-wing nationalism.

Moreover, the article criticizes the liberal tendency to dismiss particularistic attachments and forms of solidarity as morally and politically beyond the pale. This perspective views any attachment to a particular nation, language, religion, territory, or ethnicity as an obstacle to be overcome in the pursuit of humanitarianism. However, this approach neglects the natural human desire for particularistic forms of solidarity and the importance of these attachments in human history.

The article concludes that the rise of right-wing nationalism is a complex phenomenon that cannot be reduced to a single cause or motivation. It is essential to consider the role of economic factors, as well as the human desire for particularistic attachments and the reaction against humanitarianism. Ultimately, the article suggests that humanitarian liberals must accept their own role in provoking the very thing they most want to destroy and recognize the importance of particularistic forms of solidarity in human history.

Title: Liberty University President Demands Arrest of Reporters, Accusing Them of Biased Coverage

Article:

Jerry Falwell Jr., the president of Liberty University, has been vocal about his support for free expression and intellectual diversity. In a June statement, he emphasized the importance of open political discourse on college campuses, urging institutions to encourage such discussions. However, Falwell has now taken a different stance, demanding the arrest of two reporters he accuses of painting his school in a negative light.

Falwell criticized reporters from The New York Times and ProPublica for their coverage of Liberty University's decision to partially reopen during the COVID-19 outbreak. He claimed that the reports unfairly portrayed the university's attitude towards the virus as flippant and careless. Specifically, he took issue with a characterization by Times journalist Elizabeth Williamson of a conversation with local physician Thomas W. Eppes Jr., which stated that nearly a dozen Liberty students were sick with symptoms suggesting COVID-19. Falwell disputed this claim, stating that the number of presumptive cases never reached 12.

As a result, Falwell secured arrest warrants for Times photographer Julia Rendleman and ProPublica reporter Alec MacGillis for trespassing, a Class 1 misdemeanor punishable by up to a year in jail. He also threatened to file lawsuits against The New York Times if a retraction or correction is not issued regarding the contagion numbers.

Free speech lawyer Ari Cohn, former director at the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education (FIRE), criticized Falwell's actions, stating that they are "completely in line with Liberty University's faux concern for freedom of expression." Cohn noted that Falwell's idea of freedom of expression only includes expression that he approves of.

The trespassing charges are unlikely to hold up in court, as the reporters were photographing a student who invited them to campus for an interview. However, Falwell's true intention appears to be to intimidate those who criticize his school. This culture of intimidation is also evident within the university's walls, as students have reported receiving threatening phone calls and being reprimanded for expressing dissenting opinions.

For example, Calum Best, a student who wrote a Facebook post arguing for tuition refunds amid the COVID-19 pandemic, received an angry phone call from Scott Lamb, the college's senior vice president for university communications, which included Best's work-study boss. Best described the call as "deep trouble" and realized that his boss had no connection to the matter at hand.

Liberty University's handling of its student newspaper, Champion, has also been criticized. Former editor-in-chief Will E. Young wrote that Falwell actively intervened in Trump-critical coverage, removing a student op-ed lamenting Trump's Access Hollywood tape. The author of that column, Joel Schmieg, resigned after being contacted by a faculty adviser who reprimanded him for expressing his opinion.

As a private institution, Liberty University can set its own rules of conduct. However, it is hypocritical for the university to muzzle student speech while claiming to support free expression and intellectual diversity. Falwell's actions are a bad approach, especially for someone who claims to support free expression and intellectual diversity.

Title: Biden Campaign Launches Massive Turnaround Effort to Boost Support Among Latino Voters

The Biden campaign is making a significant push to increase its support among Latino voters, hiring a team of Hispanic operatives, spending $1 million on Spanish-language outreach, and signing Latino Decisions, one of the nation's top pollsters in the field. The campaign's efforts come as recent polls show Biden with a solid lead nationwide and in many battleground states, including Florida and Arizona.

According to Matt Barreto, co-founder and pollster of Latino Decisions, there is a huge opportunity for Biden to improve his support among Latino voters. Barreto, who also worked on Hillary Clinton's campaign, noted that while Clinton did an okay job with Latino turnout and support levels, there is room for improvement.

The Biden campaign plans to harness the "incredible anger" among Puerto Rican voters in Florida over Trump's handling of Hurricane Maria in 2017. The campaign also sees an opening to increase support levels in border-state Arizona, where Latinos have been deeply influenced by the immigrant rights movement, especially younger Latinos.

The campaign is also planning to engage with Cubans, South Americans, and other Hispanic groups in South Florida, where the ads will be narrated in different accents to resonate with different communities. The Biden campaign has already started running Spanish-language TV ads in Florida and Arizona, with narrators from different backgrounds.

The Trump campaign has also been spending heavily on Spanish-language TV ads, with nearly $1.2 million spent in the past three weeks, according to Advertising Analytics. The Biden campaign has spent less than $100,000 on TV ads in that time, but plans to spend $1 million in five weeks.

The Biden campaign's Latino outreach will extend to other battleground states, including North Carolina and Pennsylvania, where a Latino Decisions poll shows problems for Trump. The poll found that over 70% of Latinos oppose Trump's divisive rhetoric and see Biden as fighting for Latinos.

The campaign's efforts are driven by a combination of common sense and improved finances. The heightened focus on Latinos is a reflection of the campaign's improved financial situation, which has allowed it to invest in a robust Latino outreach effort.

**Trump Administration Puts China Trade War "On Hold" as Leaders Work on Agreements**

The Trump administration has agreed to put tariffs on Chinese goods on hold as leaders from both nations work to hammer out agreements on trade. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said Sunday that the two sides have agreed on a framework for reducing the U.S. trade deficit with China and addressing technology trade irritants, although more meetings are required to finalize the deal.

The U.S. trade deficit with China totaled a record $375 billion in 2017, and the Trump administration had threatened tariffs on $50 billion to $150 billion worth of Chinese goods to deter intellectual property theft and forced technology transfers. Beijing had countered with threats of tariffs on $50 billion worth of U.S. farm, chemical, and other exports.

Mnuchin said the U.S. and China have agreed to put tariffs on hold while they work to execute the framework, with major purchases of U.S. agriculture and energy products expected this year. The U.S. trade deficit with China is expected to be reduced by $200 billion by 2020, although Mnuchin declined to confirm whether China has agreed to a specific commitment to meet this goal.

The Trump administration has repeatedly emphasized the need for China to open up its markets to U.S. goods and services, with President Donald Trump stating that China has become "very spoiled" and needs to be held accountable. However, some experts believe that the latest developments suggest a more conciliatory approach from the Trump administration, with a focus on finding a deal that benefits both nations.

The tech industry has welcomed the trade war cease-fire, but notes that China still needs to make changes to level the playing field for American firms. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer has cautioned that the proof is in the pudding and that the Trump administration must not "blow it" with China.

Title: Cities Declare Sanctuary Status Amidst Trump's Immigration Enforcement Push

Cities across the United States are reaffirming their "sanctuary" status, defying President-elect Donald Trump's plans to deport millions of undocumented immigrants. Mayors and police chiefs from Los Angeles to Washington, D.C. have vowed not to cooperate with the Trump administration's deportation orders, citing concerns about public safety and the potential for increased crime.

The term "sanctuary city" refers to cities that do not require local law enforcement officials to notify U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) about the immigration status of individuals they come into contact with. This means that undocumented immigrants may not be reported to ICE, and local police may not ask about a person's immigration status.

Trump has promised to deport 2-3 million undocumented immigrants with criminal records, and has threatened to cut off federal funding to cities that refuse to cooperate with his administration's efforts. However, it is unclear what specific actions Trump will take to enforce his plan, as the Supreme Court has held that Congress must impose conditions on federal funding that are reasonably related to the purpose of the money.

Some critics argue that sanctuary cities harbor criminals and endanger public welfare, while others believe that local law enforcement should focus on addressing local crime and not take on immigration enforcement duties. Los Angeles Police Chief Charlie Beck has called Trump's plan to deport illegal immigrants "misguided and impractical," stating that local police need undocumented immigrants to be witnesses to violent crime.

The debate surrounding sanctuary cities has been reignited in the wake of the shooting death of Kathryn Steinle by an undocumented immigrant in San Francisco. The shooter had been released from a county jail despite federal requests to hold him until ICE could take custody.

While some Republican lawmakers have expressed support for Trump's plan, it remains unclear what specific actions will be taken to enforce his plan. The Justice Department's inspector general has concluded that some jurisdictions with sanctuary policies may be violating federal law, which could jeopardize millions of dollars in grant money.

Title: Critics Slam Trump's Handling of COVID-19 Crisis, Urge Biden Supporters to Take Allegations Seriously

The article highlights the criticism faced by President Trump's handling of the COVID-19 crisis, with some arguing that his approval ratings should be higher given the national emergency. The author notes that Trump's approval ratings have remained relatively stable, ranging from 45 to 50 percent, despite the country's motive to give him the benefit of the doubt.

The article also touches on the topic of the sexual assault allegation against former Vice President Joe Biden, with the author expressing frustration that conservatives are "weaponizing" the accusations against Trump but not taking the allegations against Biden seriously. The author notes that Biden has spoken publicly about the importance of taking women seriously, citing his support for Dr. Christine Blasey Ford during the Brett Kavanaugh hearings.

The article does not provide a clear stance on the allegations against Biden, instead focusing on the criticism of Trump's handling of the COVID-19 crisis and the importance of taking allegations seriously.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Backs Ban on Abortions After 20 Weeks of Pregnancy

Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey, a potential contender for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, has announced his support for a ban on abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy. This stance puts him in line with other likely GOP candidates who have also backed the "Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act." The bill, which was shelved earlier this year by House Republican leaders following opposition from female lawmakers, would prohibit elective abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy, or five months of gestation, based on the ability of the fetus to feel pain.

In a statement, Christie emphasized the importance of taking action on this issue, stating, "One proposal that brings Americans together is the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, which would protect unborn children beginning at 20 weeks, or five months of pregnancy, based on their ability to feel pain. America is one of just seven countries that permits elective abortions past this point. We can do far better than this. I urge Congress to take swift action on this important issue."

Christie joins a list of other likely Republican presidential contenders who have also expressed support for the ban, including Senators Ted Cruz, Rand Paul, Marco Rubio, Lindsey Graham, Scott Walker, Bobby Jindal, Mike Pence, Rick Santorum, Rick Perry, Jeb Bush, Mike Huckabee, Ben Carson, and Carly Fiorina.

Marjorie Dannenfelser, president of the Susan B. Anthony List, noted the unity among Republican candidates on this issue, stating, "There is complete unity on the Republican side around this push." She also highlighted the contrast between the Republican stance and the Democratic Party's stance on abortion, saying, "Meanwhile, the national Democratic Party and its leaders remind us almost daily of the abortion lobby's importance in their policy and politics. We expect this clear difference to be a focal point of the general election debate."

Title: White House Press Corps Questions Motivation Behind Obama's Sequester Warnings

The White House press corps has become increasingly skeptical about the motivation behind President Obama's dire warnings about the consequences of the sequester spending cuts, which are set to take effect on March 1. Over the past week, the President has issued a series of warnings about the economic and personal consequences of the cuts, but reporters are questioning whether the White House is directing agencies to showcase potential cuts to boost public anxiety and pressure congressional Republicans to compromise.

On Friday, outgoing Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood visited the White House to announce that the Transportation Department was planning to furlough air-traffic controllers around the country, which could result in delays of up to 90 minutes at U.S. airports. However, LaHood faced sharp questioning over whether there weren't less disruptive cuts that could be made. ABC News' Jonathan Karl asked, "You've got a big budget. Can't you find some other way to cut that without telling air traffic controllers to stay home?"

LaHood insisted that agency officials were scouring "every contract" to find the right places to cut, even as he highlighted the difficulty Republican lawmakers would face in dealing with angry travelers. He predicted that lawmakers' phones would "start ringing off the hook" and that "Republicans need to step up here... This is not rocket science."

In recent days, President Obama has held public events highlighting the potential cuts to emergency first-responders and the Pentagon, warning of 800,000 civilian layoffs due to the sequester. The President will visit a shipbuilding yard in Newport News, Virginia on Tuesday to highlight more potential job losses and their impact on the local economy of the defense-heavy region.

**Texas High School Shooting Leaves 10 Dead, 10 Injured**

A shooting at Santa Fe High School in Texas has left 10 people dead and 10 others injured. The suspect, 17-year-old Dimitrios Pagourtzis, a student at the school, was arrested and charged with murder. Authorities found evidence of planned explosives and a diary suggesting the attack was intended to be followed by suicide.

According to Governor Greg Abbott, various kinds of explosive devices were found at the school and off-campus, including a CO2 device and a Molotov cocktail. The governor stated that the suspect gave himself up because he did not have the courage to commit suicide.

The shooting occurred shortly before 8:00 a.m. local time, with the suspect entering an art class and opening fire. Witnesses described the scene as chaotic, with students running and hiding after the fire alarm was activated.

The victims included a school police officer, John Barnes, who was critically injured and undergoing surgery. The shooting is the deadliest school shooting in Texas since the Parkland, Florida, attack in February 2018.

The incident has sparked widespread shock and grief, with hundreds gathering for a vigil near the school. President Donald Trump described the attack as "absolutely horrific" and ordered flags to be flown at half-mast. The Texas governor called the shooting "one of the most heinous attacks we've ever seen in the history of Texas schools."

The incident is the latest in a string of school shootings in the United States, with over 5,000 people killed in shooting incidents so far this year, according to the Gun Violence Archive.

Title: David Koch's Legacy: A Complex Figure with Contradictions

Article:

David Koch, the billionaire libertarian and co-owner of Koch Industries, passed away recently after a long battle with prostate cancer. His legacy is complex and multifaceted, with both positive and negative impacts on the environment and society. One of the most significant criticisms of Koch's legacy is his resistance to action on climate change. During his lifetime, Koch worked tirelessly to undermine efforts to regulate greenhouse gases and promote sustainable energy. He was a major supporter of the fossil fuel industry and donated millions to groups that opposed climate change policies.

Koch Industries, the company he co-owned, was one of the most polluting companies in the country, behind only ExxonMobil and American Electric Power. According to Greenpeace, Koch Industries donated over $127 million to 92 groups that opposed climate crisis solutions over a 20-year period. This has contributed to the ongoing climate crisis, which has seen the Arctic melting, the Amazon rainforest burning, and the Earth experiencing its hottest month in recorded history.

Koch's legacy is also marked by his support for moderate Republicans who opposed climate action. In 2009, he helped defeat a carbon tax bill proposed by Representative Bob Inglis, a moderate Republican, by stopping funding his campaign and donating to a primary opponent. This sent a message to other Republicans that opposing climate action was a key part of Koch's orthodoxy.

However, Koch's legacy is not solely defined by his opposition to climate action. He was also a philanthropist who donated over $1 billion to various causes, including the Smithsonian, Lincoln Center, and cancer research. He supported same-sex marriage and abortion rights, and believed in the value of free trade and humane immigration policies.

Koch's principles were not purely partisan, and he supported criminal justice and prison reform. He donated millions to various hospitals and cultural institutions, including the Hospital for Special Surgery, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

While some may argue that Koch's legacy is complex and full of contradictions, others see his actions as evidence of a larger pattern of corruption and influence-peddling. Trump's defenders may say that the evidence is circumstantial, but circumstantial evidence is not weak evidence – it is evidence based on the circumstances in which an act of wrongdoing is committed. The context and circumstances of Koch's actions, including his donations to anti-climate groups and his support for moderate Republicans who opposed climate action, suggest a larger pattern of influence-peddling and corruption.

Ultimately, Koch's legacy will be debated and argued over for decades to come. Some will see him as a champion of free markets and individual freedom, while others will see him as a symbol of the corrupting influence of money and power.

**Retired Police Captain David Dorn Killed in St. Louis Pawn Shop Ransacking**

A 77-year-old retired St. Louis police captain, David Dorn, was shot and killed by looters at a pawn shop early on June 2, 2020. Dorn, who served 38 years on the force, was found dead on the sidewalk in front of Lee's Pawn & Jewelry, which had been ransacked after peaceful protests over the death of George Floyd turned violent overnight.

According to his wife, St. Louis police Sgt. Ann Marie Dorn, David Dorn was trying to protect his friend's pawn shop when he was killed. The incident was caught on video and posted on Facebook Live, although the video has since been taken down. No arrests have been made.

The violent night in St. Louis saw four officers shot, officers pelted with rocks and fireworks, and 55 businesses burglarized or damaged, including a convenience store that burned. Police also shot and gravely injured a burglary suspect who shot at officers.

Dorn's death came as cities across the United States have seen protests and violence since George Floyd's death on May 25. Dorn served 38 years on the St. Louis police force before retiring in October 2007. He then became chief of Moline Acres, a small town in St. Louis County.

Former St. Louis County police Chief Tim Fitch, who knew Dorn for 30 years, described him as a dedicated and fun-loving individual who was dedicated to helping young people succeed in law enforcement careers. Fitch said Dorn was a role model for many and was known for being honest and holding his officers to high standards.

The Ethical Society of Police, which represents black officers in St. Louis, released a statement saying Dorn was "the type of brother that would've given his life to save them if he had to." St. Louis police Chief John Hayden called Dorn a "fine captain" and said he was well-liked and pleasant.

Title: States Take Steps to Address Systemic Racism and Racial Bias in Public Life

The ongoing efforts to address systemic racism and racial bias in public life have gained momentum across the United States. Lawmakers in several states are pushing for reforms that go beyond policing reforms to tackle the deeper issues of racial inequality. In California, a series of legislative victories have been celebrated, while in other states, lawmakers are still grappling with the complexities of addressing racial bias.

In California, a bill to make ethnic studies a graduation requirement in the California State University system has finally passed the state Senate after being stuck in the chamber for over a year. Another bill, which would allow voters to decide whether to overturn the state's 1996 ban on affirmative action in government and public colleges and universities, has also gained momentum.

In other states, lawmakers are taking a more comprehensive approach to addressing racial bias. In Pennsylvania, Democratic lawmakers are fusing a police reform and racial justice agenda with a pandemic recovery platform under the banner of a "just recovery." In Massachusetts, state Rep. Russell Holmes is prioritizing finding an extra $1 billion over the next few years for struggling school systems, with a focus on cities with high numbers of minority students.

In Ohio, lawmakers are considering resolutions that would declare racism a public health crisis, with the Ohio Legislative Black Caucus pushing for increased spending to address the effects of racism in education, housing, criminal justice, and healthcare. While the resolutions have received some support, they have yet to gain traction in the Republican-controlled House.

The efforts to address systemic racism and racial bias are not without their challenges. In New Hampshire, a bill to create a commission to collect data and make recommendations on racial bias in the state's corrections, judicial, and police systems was rejected, with one Republican lawmaker saying it could "wait." In Ohio, the House failed to act on a resolution declaring racism a public health crisis before lawmakers left for summer break.

Despite these challenges, lawmakers are pushing forward, driven by a desire to address the systemic issues that have plagued public life for decades. As California Assemblywoman Shirley Weber, chairwoman of the Legislative Black Caucus, said, "Everybody has become a reformer."

Title: Republicans Overwhelmingly Believe Cruz and Kasich Should Drop Out of Presidential Race

A recent CNN/ORC poll has revealed that a significant majority of Republicans and GOP-leaning independents believe Senators Ted Cruz and John Kasich should drop out of the presidential race. According to the poll, 52% of respondents think Cruz should drop out, while 63% believe Kasich should do the same. The poll's findings are based on the assumption that neither candidate can win a majority of delegates through the primary and caucus process, and that they could only win the nomination if no candidate reaches a majority.

The poll also found that 60% of Republicans and leaners believe that delegates should vote for the candidate with the most support in the primaries and caucuses if nobody reaches a majority. The current delegate tally has Donald Trump leading with 996 delegates, followed by Cruz with 565, and Kasich with 153, according to The Associated Press.

In terms of delegates, Kasich is still behind Florida Senator Marco Rubio, who dropped out of the race a month and a half ago. A separate poll released this week found that 58% of Ohio Republicans believe Kasich should end his presidential bid.

The CNN/ORC poll also found that a greater percentage of Republicans believe the party will still be divided in November compared to March. The poll results show that 49% of Republicans and leaners think the party will still be divided in November, 41% believe the party is divided but will be united, and 7% think the party is united now. In March, 46% believed the party would be divided in November, 45% thought it would be divided but united for the general election, and 8% thought it was already united.

Title: Rubio Edges Out Bush in Florida Poll, but Margin of Error Makes Result Statistically Insignificant

A recent poll conducted in Florida has shown that Senator Marco Rubio has a slight lead over Jeb Bush in the Republican presidential nomination race, with Rubio garnering 31% support from registered Republican voters and Bush receiving 30%. The poll, conducted by Mason-Dixon Polling & Research, surveyed 400 registered Republican voters in the state and found that Rubio's announcement and media blitz may have helped him catch up with his friend and former mentor Bush.

The poll results are statistically insignificant, as the margin of error is easily within the 4.9% margin of error. However, the poll is still instructive, as it suggests that Rubio's announcement and message may have resonated with voters in his home state.

Rubio's decision to leave the Senate and run for president was met with skepticism from some, who argued that he would struggle to secure enough donors and supporters to win his home state of Florida. However, the poll suggests that Rubio may have overcome these doubts, at least in part due to his compelling message and ability to mobilize supporters.

The poll also highlights the competitiveness of the Republican primary in Florida, with Rubio and Bush essentially tied, and other likely and announced presidential candidates polling in the single digits. The poll results suggest that the state of Florida is very much up for grabs, and Rubio's decision to run may not have been a mistake after all.

Title: The New York Times' "The Interpreter" Blog and Newsletter Skews Coverage towards the "Far Right"

The New York Times' blog and newsletter "The Interpreter" has been found to have a bias in its coverage of political ideologies, with a significant emphasis on the "far right" and "right-wing" movements and politicians. An analysis of over 50 stories written by Max Fisher and Amanda Taub, the blog's authors, reveals that they made 136 mentions of the "far right" and 60 mentions of "right-wing" politicians or movements, compared to just one mention of the "far left" and 10 mentions of "left-wing" politicians or movements.

The analysis also found that 32 stories mentioned the "far right" and 31 mentioned "right-wing" movements or politicians, while only one story mentioned the "far left" and seven mentioned "left-wing" movements or politicians. The article "How YouTube Radicalized Brazil" on the front page of the New York Times, which described President Jair Bolsonaro as a "star in YouTube's far-right community," is an example of this bias.

The analysis also notes that the coverage is not always consistent in its political labeling, with some stories omitting labels for left-wing politicians or movements. For example, a report on corruption scandals involving former left-wing presidents Dilma Rousseff of Brazil and Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina did not provide a label for either of them. Similarly, stories about Venezuela omitted the "far left" label to describe the failed socialist government under Nicolas Maduro.

A search of the New York Times archives also shows that the newspaper is far more likely to use the labels "far-right" and "right-wing" than "far-left" and "left-wing" in its reporting. The search found that the terms "far-right" and "right-wing" were used significantly more often than their left-wing counterparts.

Overall, the analysis suggests that "The Interpreter" blog and newsletter has a clear bias towards covering the "far right" and "right-wing" movements and politicians, while giving less attention to the "far left" and "left-wing" ideologies.

Title: Government Shutdown Looms, But Republicans May Avoid Blame

The federal government is facing a possible shutdown next week, but many Republicans are motivated to avoid taking the blame for it. This sentiment is fueled by a CNN/ORC poll in mid-September, which showed that 51% of people would hold Republicans in Congress responsible for a shutdown, compared to 40% for President Barack Obama.

House Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, initially proposed a spending bill that would have avoided a standoff, but conservatives forced him to go to war with a different version that fully defunds Obamacare. This move may have been a signal that Boehner wants to sidestep a shutdown.

Some lawmakers are drawing parallels to the government shutdowns in 1995 and 1996, which had negative consequences for Republicans. Senator John McCain, R-Arizona, recalled the sting Republicans felt after those shutdowns, saying, "That's what happened the last time we tried this."

The majority of House Republicans fear a shutdown would cost them with voters, according to multiple House GOP aides. Republicans are divided over how far to take the Obamacare battle, and they have the option of dropping the anti-Obamacare push from the shutdown debate and instead including it in the debt ceiling fight coming up.

Democrats, on the other hand, are eager to move on from the shutdown debate and focus on the debt ceiling and budget cuts slated to hit in January. Republicans have 233 members in the House, 16 votes more than a majority, and are divided over how far to take the Obamacare fight.

The government does not necessarily have to shut down at the end of the day on September 30, as funding can be extended for a few hours or even a day or two for Congress to pass legislation. The president can order agencies to keep running if a deal is emerging.

While there are still many factors at play, the dynamics in Congress are unpredictable, and Republicans' gut-level objections to Obamacare make it difficult to predict what will happen. The Senate will pass its version of a spending bill, and House Republicans are considering attaching additional items, such as a one-year delay in the individual insurance mandate in Obamacare or a repeal of the medical device tax. If no one blinks, a shutdown could occur, but it is unclear whether House Republicans will take this route and how Democrats will react.

Title: Panel Discussion on Investigating Joe Biden's Allegations: A Look at Media Coverage and Political Reactions

The recent panel discussion on NBC's Meet the Press featured a lively debate on the topic of investigating Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden's alleged sexual misconduct. The discussion, led by NBC political director Chuck Todd, included Amy Walter from the Cook Political Report and NBC Capitol Hill correspondent Kasie Hunt. The conversation centered around the call to investigate Biden's alleged actions and the media's coverage of the issue.

Todd noted that The New York Times editorial board is not satisfied with Biden's denials and suggested that any investigation should be conducted by an unbiased, apolitical panel, chosen by the Democratic National Committee (DNC). Walter agreed that there is little appetite among Democrats to investigate Biden, citing the party's reluctance to revisit the 2016 email controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton.

Hunt, on the other hand, argued that Republicans are focusing on the handling of Brett Kavanaugh's allegations and the media's coverage of the issue, rather than addressing the allegations against Trump. She noted that voters will ultimately decide what to make of the allegations against Biden.

The discussion highlighted the perceived hypocrisy in the media's coverage of sexual misconduct allegations against politicians. Hunt pointed out that the media has covered the numerous allegations against Trump extensively, while Biden's alleged actions have received less attention. Walter noted that many people believe there is hypocrisy in the way Biden and Kavanaugh were covered, with partisanship driving much of the coverage.

The panel discussion demonstrated the complexities and challenges surrounding the investigation and media coverage of political scandals. While some argue that a thorough investigation is necessary to clear the air, others believe that the allegations are politically motivated and should not be given equal attention. Ultimately, the debate highlights the importance of a nuanced and balanced approach to covering political scandals.

Title: Kerry's Accidental Gambit in London May Have Opened Up a Face-Saving Escape Route for the President

The recent comments made by Secretary of State John Kerry in London may have inadvertently opened up a potential face-saving escape route for President Obama. Kerry's suggestion that Syrian President Bashar al-Assad could avoid a U.S.-led strike by handing over all his chemical weapons was initially dismissed as a "rhetorical argument" by the State Department. However, the proposal received an almost immediate welcome from Syria, Russia, the United Nations, and some Republicans, as well as a key American ally.

The idea of Assad surrendering his chemical weapons could be a significant step forward in the Syria crisis, as it would allow the international community to confiscate the dangerous weapons and avoid a major international military showdown. This development could also help the Obama administration extricate itself from its self-inflicted "red line" trap and avoid a bruising political defeat.

The Senate is set to vote on a resolution authorizing military action in Syria, but the White House is now taking a "hard look" at the idea of Assad surrendering his chemical weapons. A White House official stated that the administration is considering the proposal as a possible way to avoid a military strike.

The sudden shift in tone comes as the administration faces growing opposition to a Syria intervention, with a recent poll showing widespread public opposition to military action. The administration's credibility on the international stage is also at stake, as well as its domestic political capital.

In the face of this new development, the White House may be looking to declare victory and move on from the Syria crisis. The administration's allies in the Senate are still pushing forward with the authorization vote, but it remains unclear what the plan is at this point.

Title: Obama and Romney Engage in Aggressive Debate, Focus on Facts and Figures

The second presidential debate between President Barack Obama and Republican challenger Mitt Romney took place on Tuesday night, with both candidates employing a more aggressive tone than their first encounter. The 90-minute town hall-style debate saw the two candidates frequently interrupting each other and engaging in a heated discussion on various domestic and foreign policy issues.

Obama employed a strategy he has used on the campaign trail, repeatedly using the phrase "not true" to rebut Romney's claims. He focused on correcting what he saw as inaccuracies in Romney's statements, including his claim that oil and gas leases and permits on federal lands and waters decreased by half during Obama's term. According to Bureau of Land Management figures, the number of new leases fell by roughly 42 percent in Obama's first three years in office, compared to the last three years of the George W. Bush administration.

Romney, on the other hand, stuck to his campaign promises, emphasizing his plans to lower tax rates and reduce government spending. He accused Obama of not providing specifics on how to pay for his proposals and claimed that the president's own investments were "sketchy." The two candidates also clashed on issues such as immigration reform, with Obama saying "not true" to Romney's claim that he had dropped the ball on the issue.

The debate was marked by frequent interruptions and a more aggressive tone than the first debate, with both candidates trying to dominate the conversation. Obama was more assertive, while Romney stuck to his campaign promises. The debate will likely be seen as a crucial moment in the presidential campaign, with the final debate on foreign policy set to take place on October 22.

Title: Supreme Court Rules Public Sector Unions Must Obtain Consent for "Fair Share" Dues

The Supreme Court has ruled 5-4 in the case of Janus v. AFSCME that public sector unions do not have a constitutional right to require employees to pay "fair share" dues, also known as "agency fees," to support their activities. This decision means that employees will now have to give their consent before any money from their paycheck goes to support a public-sector union.

The case centered around Mark Janus, a child support specialist at the Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services, who opted out of being a member of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) union. Despite not being a member, Janus was still required to pay "fair share" dues to the union. Janus argued that being forced to pay dues to a union he was not a part of violated his First Amendment rights.

The Supreme Court's opinion, written by Justice Samuel Alito, concluded that the act of taking union dues from employees who chose not to join a union "violates the free speech rights of nonmembers by compelling them to subsidize private speech on matters of substantial public concern." The court held that compelling individuals to mouth support for views they find objectionable violates the First Amendment.

The decision was largely along ideological lines, with Justice Anthony Kennedy siding with the more conservative justices. The majority opinion was delivered by Justice Alito, joined by Chief Justice Roberts, Kennedy, Clarence Thomas, and Neil Gorsuch. Justices Sonia Sotomayor, Elena Kagan, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and Stephen Breyer dissented.

The ruling does not affect unions at private companies, only those in the public sector. Unions argue that "fair share" fees or "agency fees" are necessary to cover the costs of collective bargaining and contract negotiation, as well as representation if a worker is being mistreated by an employer. However, the court's decision may weaken the ability of public sector unions to perform these functions.

Title: Uninsured Rate in the US Continues to Decline, Reaching Historic Low

The uninsured rate among American adults has reached its lowest point since 2008, according to a recent Gallup poll. The survey found that 11.9% of U.S. adults lacked health insurance in the first quarter of this year, a decline of one percentage point from the end of last year and a significant improvement from the 18% without insurance in the fall of 2013.

The decline in the uninsured rate is attributed to the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, which took effect in 2014. The law requires most Americans to have health insurance or pay a penalty. The improving economy and falling unemployment rate may also have contributed to the decline, according to the Gallup report.

The uninsured rate varies significantly across different demographics. Those making less than $36,000 a year have seen the most significant rate of improvement, with 22% still lacking coverage. However, this is down from 30.7% at the end of 2013. The 26-34 age group has also seen significant improvement, but more than 20% still lack coverage.

Notably, minority groups have seen greater improvement in their rates of coverage. About 13% of black adults and 30% of Hispanic adults still lack coverage, but these rates have declined significantly since 2013. In contrast, 98% of adults aged 65 and older have coverage, with almost all qualifying for Medicare.

The Gallup poll provides a comprehensive overview of the uninsured rate in the US, highlighting the progress made since the implementation of the Affordable Care Act. While there is still work to be done to ensure universal coverage, the decline in the uninsured rate is a significant step forward in improving healthcare access for all Americans.

Title: FDA Issues Voluntary Guidelines on Antibiotic Use in Farm Animals, Critics Say Not Strong Enough
