The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has released new guidelines aimed at reducing the use of antibiotics in farm animals, a move aimed at combating the growing threat of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, also known as "superbugs." However, critics argue that the guidelines are too weak and do not go far enough to address the problem.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), antibiotic-resistant bacteria cause at least two million infections and 23,000 deaths in the United States each year, with the cost to the healthcare system estimated to be between $17 billion and $26 billion annually.

The FDA's guidelines ask animal producers to stop using antibiotics for growth promotion, but permit their use for routine disease prevention with a veterinary prescription. Critics argue that this loophole allows producers to continue using antibiotics for growth promotion by simply calling it another name, and provides a disincentive to clean up their facilities.

The guidelines have been met with skepticism by medical and consumer advocacy groups, who argue that the FDA is not doing enough to address the problem. The World Health Organization has warned that antibiotic resistance could mean "an end to modern medicine as we know it."

The FDA's guidelines have also been criticized for being voluntary, rather than mandatory. The agency has emphasized that drug companies support the plan, but critics argue that this is because it does not go far enough to reduce antibiotic use.

The issue of antibiotic resistance is not new, with the FDA acknowledging the problem as far back as 1977. However, despite hundreds of scientific studies confirming the link between antibiotic misuse in farm animals and superbug infections in humans, Congressional opposition and industry lobbying have blocked meaningful action.

The Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act (PAMTA) is a bill that would save eight classes of antibiotics for use on humans and sick animals, but has been the subject of frequent industry attacks. Medical and consumer advocacy groups have filed only 30 of the 225 lobbying reports on the bill, while industry groups have filed 195 reports.

The FDA's guidelines are the latest attempt to address the growing problem of antibiotic resistance. However, critics argue that more needs to be done to reduce antibiotic use and prevent the spread of superbugs.

Title: Trump Replaces Campaign Manager Amid Election Polls Showing Biden Lead

Article: President Donald Trump has replaced his campaign manager, Brad Parscale, with Bill Stepien, his deputy campaign manager, in an effort to boost his re-election bid. The move comes as Trump trails Democratic candidate Joe Biden in opinion polls, with Biden leading by an average of 8.6% as of Thursday night, according to RealClearPolitics.

Many political analysts agree that Biden is a stronger opponent than Hillary Clinton was in the 2016 election. A Quinnipiac poll found that 37% of voters believed Clinton was more honest, while Biden leads Trump by 15 points on the question of honesty. This difference in perception may be a significant factor in Trump's poor performance.

Polls also show that Trump's supporters are more enthusiastic about voting for him than Biden's supporters are about voting for him. However, Biden's supporters are more enthusiastic about voting against Trump, giving him a strong edge. Registered voters with negative opinions of both Trump and Biden prefer Biden to Trump by a 23-point margin, according to a Nationscape poll in June. These voters also rated Biden less negatively overall, with only 33% saying they had a very unfavorable opinion of him compared to 62% who said the same of Trump.

The article suggests that the public's stronger dislike of Trump may be the more consequential enthusiasm gap in the 2020 election.

Title: States' Fiscal Health and Demographics Drive Aid Requests, Not Political Affiliation

The ongoing debate over further coronavirus aid has sparked concerns among lawmakers that some states may use federal funds to address pre-pandemic budgetary issues. President Donald Trump recently tweeted, "Why should the people and taxpayers of America be bailing out poorly run states (like Illinois, as an example) and cities, in all cases Democrat-run and managed, when most other states are not looking for bailout help? I am open to discussing anything, but just asking?"

However, experts argue that the situation is more complex than simply attributing it to political affiliation. According to Christopher Mooney, a professor of state politics at the University of Illinois at Chicago, the response to COVID-19 has created a genuine fiscal emergency. Data from the Rockefeller Institute of Government in New York shows that Democratic states like New Jersey, Massachusetts, and Connecticut pay more in federal taxes than they receive each year, while states like Alabama and Mississippi receive more than they pay.

The imbalances are largely driven by demographics, with America's progressive tax system meaning that residents in wealthy states (often heavily urban and Democratic-controlled) pay higher federal taxes than those in other states. Urban-oriented states typically have high demands for public services, resulting in relatively high spending by state and local governments.

When it comes to state management, Mooney emphasizes that opinions on what constitutes "well-run" or "poorly run" states are subjective. "When you start throwing out words like 'well run' or 'poorly run,' unless you have very specific criteria in mind... it's subjective by definition," he says.

In conclusion, the debate over coronavirus aid highlights the complexities of state fiscal health and demographics, rather than simply political affiliation.

Title: Potential Challengers Emerge in Upcoming Presidential Election

The 2016 presidential election is shaping up to be a highly anticipated contest, with many predicting a showdown between former Florida Governor Jeb Bush and former First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton. Both candidates boast significant strengths, including their name recognition, fundraising abilities, and extensive national experience. However, they also share significant weaknesses, including their long-standing presence in the political arena and the perception that they are part of a dynastic tradition.

Jeb and Hillary's critics point to their ability to raise large sums of money and their connections to the party establishment as reasons why they are likely to dominate the election. However, some alternative candidates, such as Rand Paul, Martin O'Malley, and Joe Biden, see opportunities to challenge the "common wisdom" and prove that the conventional wisdom is wrong.

Both Jeb and Hillary have significant baggage, including their long-standing presence in politics and the perception that they are part of a dynastic tradition. Many voters are looking for new faces and new ideas, and the notion of another Bush-Clinton election is seen as "so yesterday" by some. The two candidates have also faced subtle snubs from their parties' previous nominees, with Hillary's time as Secretary of State under President Obama being seen as unremarkable and Jeb's fundraising efforts being met with skepticism.

The two candidates also face challenges in terms of their political positioning. Hillary's attempts to present herself as a moderate Democrat have been seen as insincere by some, while Jeb's emphasis on issues seen as suspect by the current GOP base has raised questions about his ability to appeal to a broader audience.

While the "common wisdom" suggests that Jeb and Hillary are the front-runners, it is unclear whether they will be able to overcome their weaknesses and secure their parties' nominations. The 2016 election is shaping up to be a highly competitive and unpredictable contest, with many factors still to be determined.

Title: Navigating Politics at the Dinner Table: Tips for a Harmonious Thanksgiving

As the holiday season approaches, many families are preparing for their annual Thanksgiving gatherings. For some, the topic of politics may be a sensitive subject, and it's not uncommon for conversations to turn heated. In fact, a recent survey by NPR found that many Americans dread discussing politics with family and friends.

In an effort to help navigate these potentially tense conversations, NPR gathered stories from listeners about their worst and best experiences discussing politics over the holiday. The results were mixed, with some families finding that discussing politics can lead to a better understanding and understanding, while others have found it to be a source of conflict.

One listener, Aaron Harmon, shared a story about his father-in-law asking him to say grace at the dinner table, which led to a heated debate about his atheism. Another listener, Stephanie Brown, recounted a story about a shouting match between her family members over the 2012 election results.

However, not all stories were negative. Some families have found ways to avoid discussing politics altogether. Sally Carleton, for example, shared a story about her family using a "duck quacker" to signal when someone is about to bring up a sensitive topic.

NPR's Sarah McCammon offered some advice on how to navigate these conversations, suggesting focusing on what brings people together, such as food, children, and sports. Luke Aldridge emphasized the importance of humility and respect in these conversations.

Others suggested introducing new and unusual dishes to the table, which can lead to lively discussions and arguments. Brad Heil's mother has even set ground rules for dinner talk, requiring respect for opposing opinions.

Finally, NPR's Danielle Kurtzleben encouraged listeners to go into conversations informed, with a nod to NPR's politics team and their new podcast.

In conclusion, while discussing politics can be a sensitive topic, there are ways to navigate these conversations and make them more enjoyable. By focusing on what brings people together, being respectful, and introducing new topics, families can have a more harmonious and enjoyable Thanksgiving.

Title: Liz Cheney Ends Senate Bid, Citing Family Illness, Amidst Historical Challenges for Republican Incumbents

Article:

Liz Cheney, daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney, has officially ended her challenge to incumbent Sen. Mike Enzi in the Wyoming Republican Senate primary. Citing illness in her family as the primary reason for her decision, Cheney's exit marks a significant development in the race. However, it also highlights the historical challenges faced by Republican incumbents in their own party primaries.

Since World War II, only 11 Republican senators have been defeated in their own party primaries, compared to over 30 Democratic senators who have faced similar fates. This trend suggests that Republicans tend to support their incumbent senators, often due to factors such as loyalty and a desire to maintain party unity.

Historical examples of Republican senators who have faced challenges and ultimately lost include Sen. Robert La Follette Jr. in 1946 and Sen. Dick Lugar in 2012. In both cases, the challengers ran as more conservative alternatives to the incumbent, often capitalizing on voter dissatisfaction with the sitting senator's moderate stance.

In contrast, Republican challengers who have succeeded in defeating incumbent senators have typically run as more conservative alternatives, such as Sen. Mike Lee in 2010 and Sen. Joe Miller in 2010. However, even in these cases, the challengers often faced significant obstacles and ultimately lost in the general election.

In the case of Liz Cheney, her decision to end her candidacy was likely influenced by her personal reasons, as well as the historical challenges she faced as a Republican challenger. Despite her high-profile name and reputation, Cheney struggled to gain traction in the race, with many Wyoming Republicans siding with Enzi due to his long-standing presence in the state.

Overall, Liz Cheney's decision to end her Senate bid highlights the difficulties faced by Republican challengers in their own party primaries, as well as the importance of personal and family considerations in political decision-making.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Pros and Cons: A Complex Profile of a Potential Presidential Candidate

Article:

Hillary Clinton, a prominent figure in American politics, has been a topic of discussion and speculation about her potential presidential run in 2024. While some Democrats may want her to run, Republicans are counting on her not running, believing she is the candidate they can beat in what appears to be a Republican-friendly year.

Clinton's resume makes her a plausible candidate, with her name recognition and policy knowledge. She has successfully used her experience as the wife of former President Bill Clinton to her advantage, leveraging her "wronged wife" status to garner sympathy and support. However, she has also carried some of her husband's baggage, including his questionable decisions, which she will need to address.

Clinton's strengths include her ability to recognize and discuss policy, as well as her willingness to fight back against criticism. However, she has faced criticism for her public speaking skills, being described as stiff and wooden, and her tone-deafness. Her campaign style has also been criticized as mediocre.

Clinton's ambition and drive are undeniable, but some question whether she truly wants to spend her golden years in the grueling process of running for president. She has the option to live a more luxurious life, delivering speeches and enjoying her family, rather than subjecting herself to the rigors of a presidential campaign.

In 2016, Clinton will face tougher scrutiny than she did in 2008, with the press asking sharper questions and expecting more from her. Her potential candidacy is also seen as a way for her to maintain her influence and access to funding and resources through the Clinton Global Foundation. However, this could dry up once she announces her candidacy, leaving her with only the support of partisan friends.

Overall, Hillary Clinton's potential presidential bid is a complex and multifaceted issue, with both pros and cons to consider.

Title: Thousands of Unauthorized Immigrants Face Uncertainty After Federal Judge Suspends Obama's Deportation Protections

Article:

A federal judge in Texas has suspended President Obama's plan to temporarily protect around 4 million unauthorized immigrants from deportation, leaving many parents of U.S. citizens and green-card holders in a state of uncertainty. This decision has created fear and confusion among those affected, who are worried that they may be forced to leave the country.

Wilfredis Ayala, a 30-year-old construction worker from El Salvador, is one of those affected. He has been living in the United States for over 10 years, after crossing the border illegally by car. Ayala has been dodging deportation orders for the past decade and has never had any trouble with the law until he was arrested for trespassing on private property. He was detained by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) before his lawyer got him released.

Ayala's lawyer, Bryan Johnson, argued that his client was eligible for Obama's deferred action program for parents, which would have protected him from deportation. However, with the program on hold, Johnson is unsure what will happen during their next appointment with immigration officials.

ICE has stated that it is still prioritizing the deportation of criminals and those who recently crossed the border illegally, as emphasized by President Obama during a recent town hall meeting. However, some local immigration offices have been applying the policy inconsistently, detaining parents who would have been left alone before the Texas court ruling.

Marty Rosenbluth, who teaches immigration law at Elon University, says that this inconsistency has created a huge amount of fear among those affected, and people who were preparing to apply for the program now do not know what to do. This could have a long-term impact on Obama's deferred action programs if the courts allow them to take effect.

It may be months before the legal battle over the president's deferred action programs is resolved. In the meantime, Wilfredis Ayala is facing a much shorter timeline, with his next appointment with immigration officials just a week away. "The truth is, I don't know what is going to happen that day," he says.

Title: New York Attorney General Uncovers $1 Billion in Wire Transfers by Sackler Family Amid Opioid Crisis Litigation

The New York Attorney General's Office has reportedly discovered $1 billion in wire transfers by the Sackler family, owners of Purdue Pharma, which may suggest attempts to hide their wealth as they face litigation over their role in the opioid crisis. The transfers include some done through Swiss bank accounts, according to The New York Times.

State Attorney General Letitia James issued subpoenas last month to 33 financial institutions and investment advisers to fully discover the family's wealth. James stated, "While the Sacklers continue to lowball victims and skirt a responsible settlement, we refuse to allow the family to misuse the courts in an effort to shield their financial misconduct."

Court documents filed by James's office on Friday showed initial findings from one unnamed financial institution, revealing a series of transfers by former Purdue board member Mortimer D.A. Sackler. The documents also showed the identification of previously unknown shell companies used to shift Purdue money through accounts around the world and conceal it in at least two separate multimillion-dollar real estate investments in New York.

Purdue Pharma declined to comment, while a spokesperson for Mortimer D.A. Sackler dismissed allegations surrounding the wire transfers, stating, "There is nothing newsworthy about these decade-old transfers, which were perfectly legal and appropriate in every respect. This is a cynical attempt by a hostile AG's office to generate defamatory headlines to try to torpedo a mutually beneficial settlement that is supported by so many other states and would result in billions of dollars going to communities and individuals across the country that need help."

The revelations come as Purdue Pharma has reached a multibillion-dollar tentative settlement with state and local governments over their alleged role in the opioid crisis.

Title: North Carolina's Presidential Election: A Battleground State in the Balance

North Carolina, a state known for its contradictory impulses, is gearing up to be a crucial battleground in the upcoming presidential election. The state's demographics are shifting, making it difficult to predict which way it will tilt in November. With its two biggest population centers, Charlotte and the Research Triangle, having been transformed by an influx of political centrists from other states, the state's party registration preference is now leaning towards the unaffiliated.

The rural white "Jessecrats," conservative Democrats who reliably voted for Jesse Helms, are dying off, and elections are now won in the fast-growing edge towns like Cary, outside Raleigh. Neither Donald Trump, with his hard-edge nationalism, nor Hillary Clinton, with a swirl of scandal surrounding her, is a natural fit for a state that hungers for political moderation.

Polls show Trump and Clinton are evenly matched, with Democrats believing Trump starts with a narrow advantage and Republicans believing Clinton does. What they agree on is that, as at the national level, Republicans are largely coalescing around Trump and ruling out the possibility that Clinton could run away with the state.

Trump needs North Carolina much more than Clinton does, as his difficulties among Hispanic voters are pushing typical swing states like Colorado, Nevada, and Florida towards the Democrats. Trump will likely need to carry the combined 28 electoral votes from North Carolina and Virginia to capture the White House.

Title: Election Day Brings Uncertainty as Close Races Dominate Congressional and Gubernatorial Contests

The 2014 midterm elections are expected to be a nail-biter, with many congressional and gubernatorial races too close to call. The battle for the Senate has boiled down to a referendum on President Obama's final two years in office, with roughly 10 toss-up or battleground races that could decide the outcome. Additionally, nearly a dozen governors are at risk of losing their seats, a volatile landscape not seen in decades.

Turnout is crucial for both parties, with Democrats facing historical midterm headwinds that typically punish the party holding the White House. Polling consistently shows GOP voters are more enthusiastic about this year's elections, suggesting an edge in turnout. However, Democrats point to their tried-and-true ground game as a potential game-changer.

The Senate race landscape is complex, with Republicans needing six net wins to retain control of the chamber. Three races are considered locked down for the GOP, barring a stunning upset: Montana, South Dakota, and West Virginia. However, Republicans are in competitive races in several other states, including those President Obama lost in 2012 and where he continues to have low approval ratings. Arkansas is seen as a likely flip to Republican hands, with GOP Rep. Tom Cotton expected to defeat Democratic Sen. Mark Pryor.

At the state level, nearly a dozen governors are considered in political peril, making it one of the toughest years for incumbent governors in decades. A survey by Governing magazine puts the number of toss-up races at 18, including eight "competitive" races. The incumbents in these 10 toss-up races are a mix of seven Republicans and three Democrats, including high-profile state leaders like Florida GOP Gov. Rick Scott, Wisconsin GOP Gov. Scott Walker, and Illinois Democratic Gov. Pat Quinn.

In the House of Representatives, all 435 seats are up for election, with Democrats needing 17 seats to take the majority. Republicans are expected to pick up at least five more seats. Among the most compelling races are those in Arizona and New York. In Arizona, Republican Martha McSally is trying again to take a House seat from Democrats, while in New York, 30-year-old Republican Elise Stefanik would be the youngest female House member if she wins.

The outcome of these elections may not be known until late, with late-tallied votes from rural Alaska and a possible runoff in Louisiana between Democratic Sen. Mary Landrieu and Republican challenger Rep. Bill Cassidy, as well as a possible runoff in the Georgia race, where a nominee must get 50% of the votes to win.

Title: Trump's Travel Ban: A Misguided Approach to National Security

The recent terrorist attack in London has sparked a renewed debate on national security measures, with President Donald Trump taking to Twitter to express his thoughts on the matter. In a series of tweets, Trump emphasized the need for "smart, vigilant, and tough" measures to ensure the safety of Americans, specifically mentioning his travel ban on six Muslim-majority countries.

However, a closer examination of the ban reveals that it is unlikely to make a significant impact on national security. The ban covers Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen, but since 1975, no one in the United States has died in an attack by a terrorist from any of these countries. In fact, according to a count by the Cato Institute, six Iranians, six Sudanese, two Somalis, and one Yemeni were convicted of attempting or carrying out terrorist attacks on U.S. soil between 1975 and 2015.

Moreover, the ban's focus on these six countries is puzzling, given that citizens of other countries account for a much larger share of terrorist plots, attacks, and casualties in the United States. Between 1975 and 2015, 19 foreign-born terrorists came from Saudi Arabia, 14 from Pakistan, 11 from Egypt, and 11 from Cuba, resulting in a combined death toll of 2,537. In contrast, six foreign-born terrorists came from Iran, six from Sudan, two from Somalia, and one from Yemen, with a combined death toll of zero.

The ban's effectiveness is also questionable, as most foreign-born, US-based violent extremists likely radicalize several years after their entry to the United States, limiting the ability of screening and vetting officials to prevent their entry due to national security concerns. In the one relevant case cited by Trump's executive order, better vetting would have made no difference, as the offender entered the country as a child.

Furthermore, 10 former national security, foreign policy, and intelligence officials from Democratic administrations have stated that there is no national security purpose for a total bar on entry for aliens from the seven countries named in the original travel ban. Since September 11, 2001, not a single terrorist attack in the United States has been perpetrated by aliens from the countries named in the Order.

In conclusion, while Trump's travel ban may be tough and constitutionally sound, it is not a smart approach to national security. The ban's focus on specific countries is arbitrary, and its effectiveness is questionable. Instead of focusing on a narrow set of countries, the U.S. should adopt a more comprehensive approach to national security that addresses the root causes of terrorism and targets those who pose a genuine threat to American lives.

Title: Republicans Narrow Democratic Lead on Generic Congressional Ballot, Trump's Approval Rating Reaches Parity

Article:

A new poll conducted by Morning Consult and published on February 12, 2023, shows that Republicans have erased the Democratic advantage on the generic congressional ballot, with 39% of registered voters supporting the GOP candidate and 38% backing the Democratic candidate. The poll also reveals that President Donald Trump's approval rating has reached parity, with 47% of voters approving and 47% disapproving of his job performance.

The poll, which surveyed 1,985 registered voters from February 8-12, found that voters are split almost evenly along party lines. Democratic voters favor their party by a margin of 85% to 5%, while Republicans favor the GOP by 84% to 8%. Among independent voters, 26% would vote for the Democrat, 25% for the Republican, and nearly half (49%) are undecided.

The poll also shows that Republicans have gained ground on key issues, including the economy, jobs, immigration, and national security. The Democratic advantage on health care has dwindled to just 4 percentage points, down from double digits last year.

The poll's findings suggest that House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) will be a more effective foil for Republicans than House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.), with 28% of voters having a favorable impression of Pelosi and 49% viewing her unfavorably. Ryan's numbers are more mixed, with 36% viewing him favorably and 40% unfavorably.

The Morning Consult poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 2 percentage points.

Title: Republicans Struggle to Distance Themselves from Trump Amid Election

As the presidential election approaches, many House Republicans are finding it challenging to distance themselves from Donald Trump, the Republican nominee. While some, like Representative Mike Coffman of Colorado, have openly expressed their reservations about Trump, others are trying to balance their support for the party with their concerns about his candidacy.

According to Kristen Soltis Anderson, a Republican pollster, Trump's unorthodox nature makes it easier for some Republican candidates to differentiate themselves. For instance, Senator Rob Portman of Ohio is locked in a tight race, and voters can distinguish between him and Trump.

Some endangered Senate incumbents, such as Mark Kirk of Illinois, have flatly declared they will not vote for Trump. Most others are trying to avoid offending Trump's fervent supporters while not alienating more independent-minded centrists. Senator Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire has said she will support Trump but is not endorsing him, and some of her supporters want her to distance herself further after Trump called her "weak" last week.

Senator John McCain of Arizona is facing a right-wing primary challenge this month, and while he has privately expressed contempt for Trump, he has chosen not to take a public stance against him. However, recent polls suggest that Trump's candidacy may be dragging down incumbent senators, particularly in New Hampshire and Pennsylvania.

According to Republican strategists, a five-point Clinton victory in these states might be survivable for down-ballot candidates, but anything more, particularly if her margin hits double digits, could be disastrous. Democrats are optimistic that these wider margins are possible, citing the polarized environment and the fact that ticket-splitting is less prevalent.

Title: Gruber-Gate: A Critical Examination of Jonathan Gruber's Remarks on the Affordable Care Act

The recent release of additional videos featuring economist Jonathan Gruber's comments on the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has sparked a heated debate about the law's passage and the role of the American public. Gruber, one of the architects of the ACA, has been criticized for his remarks, which some have deemed arrogant and elitist.

In the videos, Gruber is heard discussing the ACA's passage, stating that the Obama administration successfully exploited the lack of economic understanding among the American public to pass the law. He also claimed that the law's provision requiring healthy people to pay for insurance was unpalatable to voters, and that the administration's lack of transparency was a crucial factor in its passage.

However, critics argue that Gruber's comments are misleading and inaccurate. They point out that the law's provision requiring healthy people to pay for insurance is a fundamental aspect of insurance, and that many opponents of the law repeatedly highlighted this point during the public debate. Additionally, they note that the administration's marketing efforts to convince young, healthy people to sign up for insurance were extensive and well-documented.

Furthermore, opponents of the law have long warned about its potential flaws, including its potential to reduce the workforce and increase healthcare costs. These warnings were widely reported and fact-checked by media outlets and advocacy groups.

The article also highlights the concept of "solutionism," a term coined by technology scholar Evgeny Morozov, which refers to the tendency of technocrats to assume they can solve complex social problems easily. Gruber's comments are seen as an example of this phenomenon, where he assumed he could solve the healthcare problem by imposing a complex system without fully understanding the consequences.

In conclusion, the recent release of Gruber's videos has sparked a critical examination of the ACA's passage and the role of the American public. While Gruber's comments have been criticized as arrogant and elitist, they also highlight the complex issues surrounding the law's passage and the ongoing challenges it faces.

Title: Senate Approves Budget Deal, Avoiding Government Shutdown and Debt Crisis

The United States Senate has passed a hard-won budget deal, which will permit the government to resume borrowing to pay all its obligations and remove the prospect of a government shutdown in October. The legislation was approved by a 67-28 vote, with President Donald Trump's endorsement and bipartisan support from both Democratic and Republican lawmakers.

The deal, which Trump has promised to sign, would set an overall $1.37 trillion limit on agency budgets approved by Congress annually. It does not address the government's spiraling debt and the return of $1 trillion-plus deficits but takes away the prospect of a government shutdown in October or the threat of deep automatic spending cuts.

The agreement was the result of a pragmatic measure that had much for lawmakers to dislike. Trump stepped back from a possible fight over spending increases sought by liberals, and he achieved his priorities on Pentagon budgets and the stock market-soothing borrowing limit. Democrats in the GOP-controlled Senate delivered most of their votes for the deal, with many of the more solidly conservative Republicans opposing it.

The bill would lift the debt limit for two years, into either a second Trump term or the administration of a Democratic successor. It would reverse scheduled 10% cuts to defense and non-defense programs next year, at a two-year cost of more than $200 billion. An additional $100 billion over two years would add to recent gains for military readiness, combating opioids, and other domestic initiatives, and would keep pace with rising costs for veterans' healthcare.

The bill was powered by a coalition of GOP defense hawks, Democrats seeking to preserve gains in domestic accounts, and the leaders of the House and Senate Appropriations Committees. Democrats voted for the bill by a wide margin, and it won a healthy majority of Senate Republicans.

The deal was a long-sought victory for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who initiated the negotiations and was deeply invested in bringing order and relative predictability to the budget and debt deadlines. Losers included more conservative elements of the White House, who were rebuffed in attempts to add spending cuts to defray the bill's cost.

The bill's passage marks a drama-free solution to a worrisome set of looming Washington deadlines, as both allies and adversaries of the president set aside ideology in exchange for relative fiscal peace and stability.

Title: White House Defends Progress for Black Americans Under Obama Amid Trump's Claims

The White House has defended the progress made by black Americans under the Obama administration, countering claims by Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump that blacks are worse off under President Obama. According to government data, the black unemployment rate has decreased from 12.6% in January 2009 to 8.4% in July, while the jobless rate for whites has fallen more significantly, from 5.7% to 4.3%.

However, other government data suggests that blacks are faring worse under Obama. The black labor force participation rate has decreased from 63.2% in 2009 to 61.2% last month, and black homeownership rates have dropped from 46.1% in 2009 to 41.7% last month. Additionally, the percentage of black Americans living below the poverty line has risen from 25.8% in 2009 to 26.2% in 2014, and the number of black food-stamp participants has increased 58% since 2009.

The White House argues that electing Hillary Clinton as president would build on the progress made under Obama, while Trump's proposals would reverse those gains. "The president's never made the case that the work is finished, that the job is done," said White House press secretary Josh Earnest. "The point is, President Obama's interested in being succeeded in office by someone who is committed to building on the progress we've made thus far as opposed to tearing it down."

Black leaders have criticized Trump's claims, with Ben Jealous, former president of the NAACP, saying, "Donald Trump is dancing around on race and immigration, because his racism and xenophobia is threatening to trump the GOP's chances to hold on to the Senate let alone take back the White House."

While there is little evidence that Trump's plea to black voters is changing minds, dissatisfaction among blacks with the lack of progress under Obama has been no secret. The Urban League's National Equality Index has found blacks losing ground, from 57.4% equality with whites in 2009 to 56.2% this year.

The White House and Hillary Clinton's campaign have emphasized the importance of building on the progress made under Obama, while Trump's proposals would reverse those gains. "The kinds of proposals that have been put forward by the other side would have the effect of eroding our progress, primarily because they would have a devastating impact fiscally and economically doling out significant tax cuts to those at the top of the income scale and leaving the rest of us to pay the tab," said Earnest.

Title: Trump Attacks Impeachment Supporters at National Prayer Breakfast

Article:

President Donald Trump spoke at the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday, a day after the Republican-run Senate acquitted him of impeachment charges. Trump attacked supporters of the impeachment drive, stating that they know what they are doing is wrong but put themselves ahead of the country. He also criticized those who use their faith as justification for doing what they know is wrong.

Trump's speech was met with signs of political tensions generated by the impeachment process. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who led the impeachment drive, was present at the event but did not interact with Trump personally. Trump did not shake Pelosi's hand before his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, and she ripped up a paper copy of his speech.

Several speakers at the event, including social scientist Arthur Brooks, prayed for the nation to get past political polarization. Trump recited a list of things he has done for his religious supporters, from supporting school prayer to international efforts to prevent the persecution of Christians.

The National Prayer Breakfast is a Washington tradition that dates back to 1953, when President Dwight Eisenhower established it at the suggestion of evangelist Billy Graham. Trump spoke less than 17 hours after the Senate finished its impeachment trial, which acquitted him of charges that he abused his power by trying to get Ukraine to investigate political opponent Joe Biden.

Utah Sen. Mitt Romney, the GOP's nominee for president in 2012, voted to convict Trump on abuse of power. Trump fired back in a midnight tweet about Romney's loss in 2012, saying that if the candidate had "devoted the same energy and anger to defeating a faltering Barack Obama as he sanctimoniously does to me, he could have won the election."

Trump's speech was met with criticism from some, with historian Kevin Kruse calling it "bizarre" for a president to use the moment to strike a vindictive tone.

Title: California Declares State of Emergency After First COVID-19 Death and Over 50 Confirmed Cases

The Grand Princess cruise ship is currently off the California coast, with health workers testing some passengers to determine if they have contracted the COVID-19 virus. The move comes after an elderly man, who had underlying health conditions, became the state's first known person to die from the virus. The man was exposed to the virus during a trip from San Francisco to Mexico in mid-February.

Eleven passengers and 10 crew members are currently showing symptoms of COVID-19, with the governor stating that the number may significantly understate the presence of the coronavirus on the cruise ship. The ship is carrying around 2,500 passengers and 1,150 crew members, with only a small fraction of them being tested.

The California National Guard will use a helicopter to deliver testing kits to the Grand Princess on Thursday morning, with the onboard medical team collecting samples and sending them back to a lab in Richmond, California, for analysis.

The cruise line has asked passengers to report any symptoms they may have had, such as a fever or cough, that could indicate they have COVID-19. The company has also emailed a similar message to people who were on the earlier voyage.

The Grand Princess is currently returning from a cruise to Hawaii and was scheduled to make a stop in Ensenada, Mexico, but the call has been canceled to allow for testing to take place. The ship will not be allowed to dock until the testing is complete.

As of Thursday, the Grand Princess was about 100 nautical miles from the coast as it headed towards San Francisco. The cruise ship is the second Princess Cruises ship to be identified with a potential cluster of coronavirus cases, following the Diamond Princess, which was held in quarantine for weeks at the port in Yokohama, Japan.

California has declared a state of emergency to help cope with its first COVID-19 death and over 50 confirmed cases. The state is working to contact people who were on the cruise to Mexico and urge them to monitor themselves for potential COVID-19 symptoms.

Title: FBI Reports Record 3.7 Million Gun Background Checks in March Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has processed a record 3.7 million gun background checks in March, surpassing any previous month since the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) began tracking data in 1998. The surge in background checks is believed to be linked to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which has led to increased uncertainty and concerns about personal safety.

The Trump administration's decision to deem gun shops "essential" businesses has allowed them to remain open, despite many other retailers closing their doors. As a result, gun sales have seen a significant increase, with five of the top 10 days with the highest number of background checks occurring in March.

According to data from the FBI, March was the second-busiest month for gun sales, trailing only January 2013, which followed President Obama's re-election and the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. The surge in gun buying is not limited to experienced gun owners, but also includes first-time buyers and individuals who do not fit the traditional demographic of older, white males.

A sociology professor at Wake Forest University, David Yamane, attributes the increase in gun sales to mass social uncertainty, stating that "mass social uncertainty often leads to an increase in gun buying." The professor notes that spikes in firearm and ammunition purchases and first-time gun buyers have already been reported in areas severely impacted by COVID-19, such as Washington state, California, and New York.

The latest installment of the Ipsos Coronavirus Index also reported rises in purchases of guns and ammunition, although the sample size was relatively small. An NRA video tweeted on March 21 warned that individuals should not only stockpile food but also prepare to defend their property in the event of widespread chaos.

The FBI's data provides a snapshot of the growing trend in gun sales during the pandemic, which is expected to continue as long as the crisis persists.

Title: Supreme Court to Hand Down Major Rulings on Gay Marriage Cases

The Supreme Court is poised to deliver significant decisions on two gay marriage cases, which could reshape the legal landscape for same-sex couples across the country. One case challenges California's voter-enacted ban on same-sex marriage, while the other targets a federal law that prevents legally married gay couples from receiving tax, health, and pension benefits.

The court's justices heard oral arguments in the 4-year-old case challenging California's Proposition 8, which amended the state constitution to define marriage as the union of a man and woman. The justices have several possible outcomes to consider, including making bans on gay marriage unconstitutional nationwide, legalizing gay marriage only in California and six other states, or allowing same-sex marriages to resume in California itself. The court could also uphold Prop 8.

In the second case, the court is considering the constitutionality of the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), which defines marriage as between a man and a woman. The law affects a range of benefits available to married couples, including tax breaks, survivor benefits, and health insurance for spouses of federal employees. The Obama administration abandoned its defense of the law in 2011 but continues to enforce it.

The justices are also considering the case of Edith Windsor, 83, of New York, who sued to challenge a $363,000 federal estate tax bill after her partner of 44 years died in 2009. During a hearing in March, Justice Anthony Kennedy suggested that the law appears to intrude on the power of states that have chosen to recognize same-sex marriages. Other justices called the law "skim-milk marriage" and questioned its constitutionality.

The court's decisions in these cases could have significant implications for same-sex couples across the country.

Title: Critique of Bernie Sanders' Political Approach

The article discusses the author's reservations about Bernie Sanders' political approach, specifically his promise of a revolution to address income inequality and other social issues. The author argues that Sanders' vision is unrealistic and potentially damaging to the progressive cause. According to the author, the United States has never seen a revolution in the classical sense, and the current economic conditions do not warrant one. The author points out that the country is not experiencing widespread economic collapse or social unrest, unlike during the Civil War or the Great Depression, which are the only times when significant social change has occurred.

The author believes that Sanders' approach is unrealistic and may lead to disillusionment among his followers when his promises are not fulfilled. They argue that Sanders' followers may become disillusioned and lose interest in politics, or worse, become cynical about the political process. The author suggests that Sanders' approach is not only unrealistic but also potentially harmful, as it may lead to a loss of talented young leaders who may become discouraged and give up on politics.

The article concludes that Sanders' approach is not the most effective way to bring about change, and that a more practical and achievable approach is needed to inspire and motivate people to work towards positive change.

Title: Schiff Vows to Escalate Standoff Over Spy Complaint; 'Fake News,' Trump Scoffs

Article:

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff has vowed to escalate a standoff with the Trump administration over a dispute about the content of an as-yet-unknown complaint to the intelligence community's official watchdog. The dispute centers around a complaint filed by an anonymous whistleblower within the spy world, which Schiff believes is shielded by privilege and can be withheld from lawmakers.

Schiff stated that the Justice Department has opined that the material is protected by privilege and can be withheld from lawmakers, but he disagrees, saying that "if we have to go to court to get this, we will have a good case." The dispute is over a complaint filed by an anonymous whistleblower within the spy world, which Schiff believes is shielded by privilege and can be withheld from lawmakers.

The complaint is reportedly related to a phone call between President Trump and a foreign leader, which has been described as "inappropriate" by an unnamed intelligence official. Trump has denied any wrongdoing, calling the reports "Fake News" and stating that he would only do what is right and good for the USA.

Schiff has stated that the intelligence community's inspector general has deemed the complaint as "both credible and urgent" and that it should be transmitted to Congress under the clear letter of the law. The committee has placed the highest importance on the protection of whistleblowers and their complaints to Congress.

The committee has also released letters it received from the inspector general and a letter from Schiff to acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire. The committee has scheduled an open session with Maguire next week, during which Schiff stated that they will learn more about the situation.

Other members of Congress have expressed a desire to learn more about the situation, with Senator John Cornyn stating that he believes his panel may be next in line to receive more information. The contretemps over the IG complaint is the latest political battle between Schiff and Trump, who have clashed in the past over issues such as the Russia imbroglio.

Title: Mueller's Report Does Little to Change Political Calculations, Trump Remains Unlikely to Face Impeachment

The release of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's statement on Wednesday did little to alter the political landscape, as Senate Republicans remained unmoved and unlikely to convict President Trump in a Senate trial. According to former Senator Jeff Flake, one of the few prominent Republicans to openly defy Trump, the move will "ratchet up pressure on the Dems to initiate impeachment proceedings, but it doesn't change the fundamentals much." Flake believes that Speaker Nancy Pelosi knows that impeachment would be a bad move for the party and the country in the 2020 elections.

The White House responded to Mueller's statement with a mix of outrage and indifference. President Trump watched the statement live on television from the residence, met briefly with his staff, and issued claims of vindication via Twitter and a press statement. However, sources close to the President reported that he was privately upset that more people were not defending him on television and felt that Mueller had always been out to get him.

Aides in the West Wing described the mood as one of outrage towards Mueller, but acknowledged that the special counsel's report did not reveal any new information or smoking gun that had not already been known. The report's contents were not surprising, and Mueller made it clear that he would not go beyond his report even if he was dragged before a congressional committee.

The release of Mueller's statement has been described as simply "shaking the snow globe and stirring things up" by a White House aide. The move has left many in Washington flummoxed, with some comparing it to the Watergate era, when Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski's conclusions were clear and decisive.

Title: Senate Debates Immigration Reform Bill Amidst Boston Bombing Concerns

Article:

The Senate Judiciary Committee held its second hearing on the proposed immigration overhaul, with lawmakers debating provisions that could grant legal status to some agriculture workers. The discussion was overshadowed by the Boston Marathon bombings and the legal status of the Russian-born suspects. Senate Democrats and Republicans differed over whether illegal immigrants working on U.S. farms should be eligible for a new "blue card," which would allow them to achieve permanent residence after five years. Non-farmer workers would have to wait about twice as long to achieve the same status.

The debate was marked by emotional exchanges, with Senator Chuck Schumer (D-NY) stating that the Boston bombings should not be used as an excuse to delay passage of the immigration reform legislation. Senator Chuck Grassley (R-IA) disagreed, citing the "gaps and loopholes" in the country's immigration system.

The proposed legislation, introduced by a bipartisan group of eight senators, aims to address the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants in the U.S. and the 70% of agricultural workers who are in the country illegally. The "blue card" provision would allow roughly 700,000 to 1.1 million illegal agricultural workers to apply for legal status, provided they have at least a two-year work history, pass a criminal background check, and pay fines and taxes.

Some Republicans, including Senator Jeff Sessions (R-AL), expressed concerns about the proposal, arguing that it was a deal between big business and organized labor that benefits neither the U.S. nor its citizens. Senator Lindsey Graham (R-SC) also raised concerns about the effectiveness of the legislation in tracking immigrants who overstay their visas, citing the 9/11 terror attacks as an example.

The debate is ongoing, with committee leaders expecting to start submitting amendments in May and a vote this summer.

Title: California Attorney General Files Charges Against Journalists Who Exposed Planned Parenthood's Practices

Article:

California Attorney General Xavier Becerra has filed 15 felony charges against investigative reporters David Daleiden and Sandra Merritt, who exposed the practices of Planned Parenthood and its affiliates. The charges stem from recordings made by the journalists of conversations with Planned Parenthood employees, which they claim were confidential and illegal.

The controversy surrounds a series of undercover videos released by the Center for Medical Progress, which showed Planned Parenthood employees discussing the harvesting of fetal organs and the sale of fetal tissue. One video featured Holly O'Donnell, a former StemExpress technician, describing an experience at Planned Parenthood's Alameda Clinic in San Jose, California, where she was asked to harvest the brain of a fetus.

The California Penal Code defines murder as the "unlawful killing of a human being, or a fetus, with malice aforethought." The videos sparked widespread outrage and calls for investigations, but the media largely ignored the revelations.

Becerra, a Democrat, has received financial support from Planned Parenthood and has a 100% legislative rating from prominent pro-abortion groups. His predecessor, Kamala Harris, also received support from Planned Parenthood and was involved in drafting legislation to restrict reporting on "health-care providers."

The move to charge Daleiden and Merritt has been criticized as a partisan abuse of power, with some pointing out that the California Department of Justice has investigated claims of animal cruelty on chicken farms but not the alleged homicide at abortion clinics. The media has also been accused of hypocrisy for suddenly becoming silent about the importance of a free press.

The Center for Medical Progress has released a new video featuring Daleiden discussing abortion procedures with Dr. DeShawn Taylor, former medical director of Planned Parenthood Arizona. Taylor notes that in Arizona, if a fetus is born alive, it is supposed to be transported to a hospital, but there is no standard procedure for verifying life.

Title: President Obama Pays Tribute to Fallen Heroes on Memorial Day

Article:

In his weekly address, U.S. President Barack Obama honored the men and women in uniform who have given their lives in service to the country, ahead of the Memorial Day commemoration. The commander-in-chief asked Americans to honor the nation's fallen heroes and stand with its veterans and military families this weekend.

In his address, Obama reflected on the significance of Memorial Day, noting that it is a day to remember and honor those who have given their lives for the country. He emphasized that the service and sacrifice of those in uniform are not always readily apparent, as they often serve quietly and without seeking recognition. Obama highlighted the bravery and selflessness of those who have served and sacrificed, stating that they gave their lives for the ideals of liberty and justice that make America a beacon of hope for the world.

The President also emphasized the importance of caring for the loved ones left behind by fallen service members, ensuring that veterans receive the care and benefits they have earned, and supporting military families whose loved ones are in harm's way. He urged Americans to work together to preserve the sacrifices achieved by those who have served and to make the country stronger, fairer, and freer.

The White House transcript of Obama's address is available, and video of it can be found on YouTube.

Title: Christians to Connect with Israeli Businesses at Groundbreaking Summit

Article:

A gathering of over 600 business leaders from more than 50 countries will take place in Israel on December 4, as part of the second-annual ARISE conference. The event, themed "Israeli Innovation for Humanity," aims to connect Christian business leaders with Israeli companies in various fields, including medical, agricultural, and transportation, whose products benefit humanity.

The conference's founder and president, Adv. Calev Myers, believes the summit is an opportunity to counter the global anti-Israel Boycotts, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement. "The best way to fight BDS is by bringing more business to Israel," Myers stated.

ARISE is providing an entry point for Christians to connect with Israel's economy through business matchmaking. During the conference, the ARISE team will facilitate hundreds of face-to-face meetings between Christian business leaders and Israeli companies, aiming to create long-term investment relationships. This is expected to result in millions of dollars worth of transactions, strengthening Christian businesses and the Israeli economy.

Myers emphasized the importance of Christians engaging with Israel in the for-profit sphere, stating, "When you connect your business with a for-profit relationship, you're going to be coming to Israel more, you're going to be looking over your investments and your business, you're going to be reading Israeli headlines. It connects you on a deeper level."

For those unable to attend the event in Rishon Lezion, an online digital platform is available, where business owners can upload their profiles and chat with attendees online. The summit will also feature a "Shark Tank"-style competition for Israeli companies and businesses to present their best products to conference attendees, with the winning product receiving a $10,000 grant from ARISE.

The event is laying the groundwork for an even bigger initiative to be launched in 2022 – a global trade center in Jerusalem. Myers believes this will be a significant blow to the BDS movement, stating, "I can't think of a better way to humiliate BDS than by opening up a fully-functioning global trade center in Jerusalem." The center will be a global trade hub, with founding partners being faith-based business networks around the world, aiming to bring Israeli innovation to the nations in the most streamlined way possible.

Myers is encouraging Christians worldwide to participate in the conference, which will provide an opportunity for them to connect their businesses and hearts with Israel.

Title: Obama's Shift in Foreign Policy: A Balancing Act Between Omnipotence and Reality

The current administration's approach to foreign policy has been met with criticism from both sides of the political spectrum. According to Jeremy Shapiro, a former Obama State Department official, President Obama has been attempting to redefine the expectations of his role in recent years. This shift is a response to the growing disconnect between the president's perceived omnipotence and the reality of his capabilities.

Critics argue that Obama's reluctance to discuss the limitations of his power has led to a perception that he is excusing his own actions or inactions. Daniel L. Byman, a former member of the Sept. 11 commission staff, believes that the president is failing to differentiate between issues he can influence and those he cannot. This perceived lack of transparency has led to increased criticism.

The administration's record on foreign policy is marked by several notable instances. Critics argue that Obama failed to stem the rise of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria by rejecting proposals to arm moderate elements of the Syrian resistance. Additionally, his decision to withdraw American troops from Iraq in 2011 left a power vacuum, which some believe allowed the Russian government to intervene in Ukraine without fear of significant consequences.

While some argue that Obama is not solely responsible for the world's crises during his tenure, others believe that his actions and attitudes have contributed to some of these crises. William C. Inboden, a former national security aide to President George W. Bush, notes that Obama is accountable for his responses, or lack thereof, to these crises.

The debate surrounding Obama's foreign policy highlights the complex challenges faced by presidents in balancing their perceived omnipotence with the reality of their capabilities. As the world continues to evolve, the need for effective communication and transparency in foreign policy decision-making remains crucial.

Title: Environmental Protection Agency Chief Scott Pruitt Resigns Amid Ethics Controversies

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) chief, Scott Pruitt, resigned on Thursday, effective July 6, amid a series of ethics-related controversies. Pruitt, a close ally of President Donald Trump, had been under fire for his aggressive efforts to roll back environmental regulations, including his decision to repeal the Clean Power Plan, a program aimed at reducing carbon emissions from power plants.

Pruitt's resignation comes after a string of controversies, including allegations of lavish spending on security, the installation of a $43,000 soundproof phone booth in his office, and accusations that he used his position to receive favors, such as a discounted rental on a high-end condo from an energy lobbyist's wife.

In his resignation letter, Pruitt stated that the "unrelenting attacks on me personally, my family, are unprecedented and have taken a sizable toll on all of us." Trump announced Pruitt's resignation on Twitter and said EPA Deputy Administrator Andrew Wheeler, a former mining industry lobbyist, will become the agency's acting chief on Monday.

Wheeler, who is widely expected to continue Pruitt's efforts to roll back and streamline regulations, stated that he is "both humbled and honored" to lead the agency and expressed his commitment to protecting public health and the environment.

Democrats and environmental advocacy groups welcomed Pruitt's departure, calling him "unquestionably the worst head of the agency in its 48-year history." Republican lawmakers, however, praised Pruitt's efforts to reduce regulatory burdens on industry.

Pruitt's interim replacement, Wheeler, has a background in the fossil fuel industry and has worked with Senator Jim Inhofe, a self-described climate skeptic, on efforts to combat climate legislation. Energy lobbyists expect Wheeler to be less controversial than Pruitt but maintain the same agenda.

Pruitt faced around a dozen investigations during his tenure, including allegations of excessive travel and security spending. The U.S. Government Accountability Office concluded that the EPA violated two laws by installing the $43,000 phone booth for Pruitt's office without informing lawmakers first.

The controversies surrounding Pruitt's tenure included allegations of jobs for his wife, including an aide contacting the CEO of a fast-food chain about his wife becoming a franchise owner. Pruitt also had an employee carry out his personal errands, including researching the purchase of an old mattress from the Trump International Hotel.

Pruitt's resignation marks the end of his tenure as EPA chief, which was marked by controversy and criticism from environmental groups and lawmakers.

Title: California Governor Signs Bill Requiring Presidential Candidates to Disclose Tax Returns

California Governor Gavin Newsom has signed a bill into law, requiring presidential candidates to publish their tax returns before appearing on the state's primary ballot. The bill, SB 27, passed both houses of the California state legislature earlier this month and is aimed at President Donald Trump, who has not publicly disclosed his tax returns.

According to Yashar Ali, who broke the story in his newsletter, Newsom decided to sign the bill into law by the Tuesday deadline, despite initial expectations that he might not do so. The bill's passage is seen as a "freebie" for Newsom, but it could be declared unconstitutional and jeopardize California's relationship with the Trump administration.

Jay Sekulow, a personal attorney for President Trump, has suggested legal action will be taken in response to the move. "The state of California's attempt to circumvent the Constitution will be answered in court," Sekulow stated.

California has often sued the Trump administration over its policies, and the state is also dependent on federal aid in several areas. Earlier this year, Trump canceled nearly $1 billion of funds for California's high-speed rail project, which Newsom had still hoped to use despite canceling the project.

Newsom shared his own tax returns during the 2018 race for governor, but his predecessor, Jerry Brown, did not publish his tax returns. The new law will largely be symbolic, as it will not affect Trump's ability to appear on the general election ballot. California exempts the presidential primary from its usual "jungle primary" process, in which only the top two candidates advance to the general election, regardless of party.

The bill could, however, inspire other Democrat-governed states to follow suit. It will likely boost Newsom's national profile as well.

Title: US Economy Adds 209,000 Jobs in July, But Growth Slows

The United States added 209,000 jobs in July, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, a number that while respectable, is slower than the 298,000 jobs added in June. Over the past six months, the economy has added 1.5 million jobs, marking the strongest six-month period since 2006.

The unemployment rate ticked up to 6.2% in July, from 6.1% in June, as more workers joined the labor force. The economy has been recovering from the 2008 financial crisis, which wiped out 8.7 million American jobs. Blue-collar industries like manufacturing and construction, which were hardest hit during the recession, have started to recover, with manufacturers adding 99,000 jobs and construction firms adding 114,000 jobs since January.

Government jobs are also slowly coming back, with many of these jobs offering middle-class wages. However, stronger hiring has yet to translate into bigger paychecks for most workers, with the average American wage edging up only 1 cent to $24.45 an hour over the past 12 months.

Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen has said she wants to see wages rise faster than inflation, but the latest report does not provide much evidence that this is happening yet. The Fed is gradually winding down its stimulative policies and is nearing its goals for a lower unemployment rate and stable prices.

The jobs report does not move the needle much for the Fed, and investors are focused on when the Fed will eventually hike interest rates, with most economists expecting a rate hike in the spring or summer of 2015.

Title: Supreme Court Rejects Effort to Reinstate Pennsylvania's Gerrymandered Congressional Maps

The Supreme Court has declined to hear an appeal from Pennsylvania Republicans seeking to reinstate the state's gerrymandered congressional maps. This decision marks the first time the Court has turned away a case since Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation gave Republicans a solid majority on the Supreme Court.

In January, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court struck down the state's congressional maps, citing violations of the state constitution. The maps, which were heavily gerrymandered, resulted in Republicans winning 13 of the state's 18 congressional districts in 2012, despite Democrats receiving a majority of the popular vote.

The Pennsylvania Supreme Court's decision should have been the final word on the case, as state supreme courts typically have the final say on questions of state law. However, Pennsylvania Republicans appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court, citing a legal theory that the Court's majority rejected in its 2015 decision in Arizona State Legislature v. Arizona Independent Redistrict Commission.

The Constitution states that the times, places, and manner of holding elections for Senators and Representatives shall be prescribed in each state by the legislature thereof. Pennsylvania Republicans argued that this language prevents the state supreme court from tossing out a partisan gerrymander because a court is not a legislature. However, the U.S. Supreme Court has repeatedly rejected this reading of the word "legislature," most recently in Arizona State Legislature.

The Court's decision not to hear the Turzai case suggests that Republicans do not have the votes to reinstate one of the nation's most egregious gerrymanders. The case marks a significant setback for Republicans, who had hoped to use the Court to overturn the Pennsylvania Supreme Court's decision and maintain their advantage in the state's congressional delegation.

Title: House Approves Coronavirus Response Package with Bipartisan Support

The United States House of Representatives has approved a coronavirus response package, with a vote of 363-40, after negotiations between House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. All House Democrats supported the plan, while 40 Republicans opposed it, with Rep. Justin Amash, an independent from Michigan, voting "present".

Prior to the vote, House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., spoke to reporters about the deal, stating that "some things needed to be cleaned up". President Trump had earlier expressed support for the package, tweeting that it would provide free coronavirus tests and paid sick leave for impacted American workers.

The bill, known as the Families First Coronavirus Response Act, includes provisions for free coronavirus testing, paid emergency leave, and enhanced unemployment insurance. It also includes nutrition security initiatives, such as SNAP, student meals, and food banks, as well as increased federal funds for Medicaid to support local, state, tribal, and territorial governments and health systems.

The revisions to the Democratic bill came after the GOP raised concerns about the sick leave legislation, citing concerns about the Social Security Administration's ability to implement the program and the potential for permanent paid sick leave for all businesses without exemptions.

The bill is expected to be taken up by the Senate next week, with sources indicating that it will likely pass with an overwhelming majority.

Title: Sen. Chuck Grassley Meets with Merrick Garland, Explaining Senate Rules and Customs

Article:

Sen. Chuck Grassley, an 82-year-old senator from Iowa, met with Supreme Court nominee Merrick Garland on Tuesday morning in the Senate Dining Room. The meeting was a result of Grassley's efforts to explain to Garland why it is impossible for the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee to hold hearings on a judicial nominee to the nation's highest court. Grassley had previously refused to hold confirmation hearings for Garland, who was nominated by President Obama to replace the recently deceased Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court.

The meeting was described as pleasant, with Grassley and Garland chatting calmly and not engaging in any heated discussions. The senator even posted a picture on Instagram of the two men having breakfast together. The meeting was seen as a rare example of civility in Washington, with the two high-profile members of the government on opposite sides of an issue sitting down and having a frank discussion.

However, some have questioned the purpose of the meeting, as the GOP had previously announced that they would not hold any hearings on Garland's nomination. The meeting was seen as a way for Grassley to explain the concept of separation of powers to Garland, but others have argued that it was a condescending gesture, with Grassley trying to explain complex Senate rules and customs to the judge.

The meeting comes as Grassley faces re-election in November, with some polls suggesting that his seat may be vulnerable. The GOP is also facing challenges in the upcoming election, with some predicting that the party's majority in the House of Representatives could be significantly reduced. The Supreme Court obstructionism has been a contentious issue, with some arguing that it has been a bridge too far for the general public.

It remains to be seen whether Grassley's meeting with Garland will have any impact on his re-election prospects or the overall political landscape.

Title: NASCAR Bans Confederate Flag, Receives Praise from Celebrities and Criticism from Some Fans

NASCAR has banned the Confederate flag from its races and venues, a decision that has received widespread praise from celebrities and criticism from some fans. The ban was announced on June 10, and since then, the stock car racing series has faced questions about how to enforce the ban at its tracks.

The ban was welcomed by celebrities such as Reese Witherspoon and New Orleans Saints running back Alvin Kamara, who praised NASCAR for ridding itself of a symbol long associated with slavery and racism. Kamara even tweeted that he would like to take a spin in a NASCAR car.

The enforcement of the ban will be a challenge, especially when fans are allowed back into the tracks. NASCAR executive vice president Steve O'Donnell said that the organization will work to develop protocols around enforcement, but it is unclear what will happen to fans who display the Confederate flag.

The ban was largely credited to Bubba Wallace, NASCAR's lone black driver, who publicly condemned the flag and its association with racism. Wallace finished 11th at Martinsville on Wednesday night, driving a Black Lives Matter paint scheme with "Compassion, Love, Understanding" emblazoned on the hood.

Fellow drivers, including Joey Logano and Brad Daugherty, praised Wallace for his efforts, saying he has brought attention to the issue and used his platform for good. Daugherty, the lone black Cup Series team owner, said he was "touched to the core" by the ban.

Not everyone was pleased with the decision, however. Some fans took to social media to express their disappointment and anger, saying their rights are being trampled on. Helmet artist Jason Beam, who paints designs for drivers like Jimmie Johnson and Kyle Busch, tweeted that he did not support erasing particular elements of history to please a particular audience. Wallace responded by saying he had lost respect for Beam.

The ban has also led to some celebrities cutting ties with Beam Designs, including Johnson, Busch, and Ryan Blaney. NASCAR has seen a surge in celebrity interest, with ratings up 1% over last year's average. The ban has also sparked a debate about the role of NASCAR in American society and its relationship with its fans.

NASCAR historian Dan Pierce said that the ban was a necessary step, but questioned whether the drivers got the OK from their sponsors ahead of time or from NASCAR. The ban has also raised questions about how NASCAR will enforce it, especially when fans are allowed back into the tracks.

Title: Americans' Views on Obama's Job Performance and Economy Show Slight Improvement

A recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll has revealed a slight uptick in Americans' approval ratings for President Obama's job performance, with 44% of respondents expressing approval and 41% disapproval. This marks a slight improvement from his all-time low of 41% approval rating in the previous poll.

The poll also found that majorities of Americans do not approve of the president's handling of the economy and foreign policy. However, for the first time since early October, more people have a positive view of the president than a negative one.

The survey also explored Americans' views on the economy, with a majority believing that it is stacked against people like them. A majority of respondents also believe that the widening income gap means that America is no longer a country where people have an opportunity to improve their standard of living, regardless of their background.

When it comes to the current economic conditions, 47% of respondents believe that they are something President Obama inherited, while 39% believe they are mostly responsible for his policies. Forty-one percent believe the economy has improved during his presidency, with 17% giving him some credit and 42% saying it has not really improved.

The poll also touched on the Affordable Care Act, with 36% of respondents believing it was a good idea and 46% believing it was a bad idea. However, only 1 in 5 voters believe the law should be completely repealed, while 2/3 believe it needs a major overhaul or minor modifications to improve it.

In terms of the midterm elections, 45% of registered voters prefer a Republican-controlled Congress, while 45% prefer a Democratic-controlled one. The poll also found that 42% of respondents identified with the Democratic party, 34% with the Republican party, and 17% as independent.

The poll of 1,000 adults was conducted from April 23-27 and has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

Title: Conservative Parties and Thinkers Continue to Shift Towards Center-Right

Article:

The article discusses the current state of conservative politics and the challenges faced by right-leaning individuals and parties. It notes that the nationalist wave that was expected to sweep the globe has instead receded, with globalist forces gaining ground. The article highlights the failures of Brexit and the Trump presidency, which were expected to bring about significant changes, but have instead led to disappointment and disillusionment.

The article focuses on the example of Ruth Davidson, the leader of Scotland's Conservative and Unionist party, who has written an essay calling for a reboot of capitalism. Davidson argues that capitalism must be a moral enterprise that reaches out to those who feel left behind and provides public services and fairness for the little guy. She cites Adam Smith's ideas on the importance of government intervention to ensure basic fairness and notes that capitalism must gain the consent of the people.

The article concludes that conservative parties and thinkers are likely to continue moving towards the center-right, as the problem set remains unchanged. It notes that many of the rich have abandoned conservative parties, preferring to be values voters of the center-left, while many of the former working classes that supported the Left in the past are drifting into center-right or right-wing parties. The article suggests that the middle-class life that many Americans, English, and French felt was their birthright is slipping away, and that capitalism does not look like an opportunity to many people, but rather an opportunity to be fleeced.

Title: Anonymous Trump Official Criticizes President in New York Times Op-Ed

The White House is in turmoil after an anonymous senior Trump administration official published an op-ed in The New York Times, criticizing President Donald Trump's decision-making and leadership style. The op-ed, titled "I Am Part of the Resistance Inside the Trump Administration," describes Trump as "unprincipled and amoral" and claims that many Trump appointees are working to block his "misguided impulses" until he is out of office.

In the piece, the author describes Trump's decision-making process as "half-baked, ill-informed, and occasionally reckless" and compares him unfavorably to the late Senator John McCain, who was described as a "lodestar for restoring honor to public life and our national dialogue."

The op-ed has sparked a heated reaction from the White House, with President Trump questioning the author's legitimacy and demanding that The New York Times reveal their identity. Trump tweeted, "Does the so-called 'Senior Administration Official' really exist, or is it just the Failing New York Times with another phony source?" He also suggested that the author should be investigated for national security reasons.
