Vice President Mike Pence's office has denied any involvement in the op-ed, with communications director Jarrod Agen tweeting, "The Vice President puts his name on his Op-Eds. The @nytimes should be ashamed and so should the person who wrote the false, illogical, and gutless op-ed. Our office is above such amateur acts."

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo also denied involvement, telling reporters during a trip to India, "It's not mine." He also criticized The New York Times for publishing the op-ed, saying it was "false, illogical, and gutless."

The op-ed has sparked a frenzy of speculation about the author's identity, with many social media users speculating that Vice President Pence was the author due to the use of the term "lodestar," one of his favorite words. However, Pence's office has denied any involvement.

The White House Press Secretary, Sarah Sanders, has called the author a "coward" and demanded that they step forward and resign, saying they are not putting the country first, but their own ego ahead of the will of the American people.

Title: Education Secretary DeVos Issues Final Rules on Sexual Misconduct in Schools

The United States Department of Education has issued final rules on how schools will address allegations of sexual misconduct, securing new protections for students and faculty accused of misconduct. The new regulations, which take effect in August, modify Title IX, a 1972 law prohibiting discrimination based on sex in education programs or activities that receive Federal financial assistance.

The new rules narrow the definition of sexual harassment and require schools to challenge evidence and cross-examine students via a live hearing, among other things detailed in the over 2,000-page rule. Schools will only be found in violation of Title IX if they are determined to be "deliberately indifferent" to accusations of sexual assault that occurred in their programs and activities.

Education Secretary Betsy DeVos stated, "Too many students have lost access to their education because their school inadequately responded when a student filed a complaint of sexual harassment or sexual assault. This new regulation requires schools to act in meaningful ways to support survivors of sexual misconduct, without sacrificing important safeguards to ensure a fair and transparent process."

President Trump described the new regulations as "even-handed justice" with "a transparent grievance process that treats the accused as innocent until proven guilty." The Trump administration has been critical of Title IX, stating that it unjustly puts matters of sexual assault and harassment in the hands of education officials.

Senator Lamar Alexander, chairman of the Senate Education Committee, said, "This final rule respects and supports victims and preserves due process rights for both the victim and the accused." Victim advocacy groups, such as Know Your IX, have expressed concerns that the new rules will "roll back the rights of student survivors" and make schools more dangerous.

The National Women's Law Center plans to contest the new rules in court, stating that they will make schools more dangerous for everyone and deny survivors their civil rights.

Title: Gunman Shot Dead After Shooting Two Teenagers at Maryland High School

A shooting occurred at Great Mills High School in St. Mary's County, Maryland, on Tuesday morning, leaving two teenage students injured. The gunman, 17-year-old Austin Wyatt Rollins, was shot and killed by a police officer after a gunfight. The attack occurred before classes began, and the school was evacuated, with students sent to a nearby school.

According to Sheriff Tim Cameron, Rollins had a prior relationship with the 16-year-old girl he shot, who is currently in critical condition. The 14-year-old boy he shot is also injured. The shooting began in a hallway, with the gunman firing at the female and male students, hitting both.

Deputy Blaine Gaskill, the school's resource officer, was alerted and pursued the shooter, engaging in a gunfight. It is unclear whether the gunman was hit by the officer's gunfire or shot himself. Gaskill was not injured, and the cause of the gunman's death is still under investigation.

The female student is in critical condition in the hospital, while the 14-year-old boy is also injured. The school's 1,600 students were evacuated to a nearby school, and federal agents from the FBI, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, and local police are investigating the incident.

Maryland Governor Larry Hogan expressed concern, stating that "prayers are not enough" and that the incident should not be an excuse to pause the conversation about school safety. New York Governor Andrew Cuomo called the attack "another tragic and exasperating reminder of the enduring threat of gun violence" and urged "our so-called leaders in Washington" to take action to stem gun attacks.

Title: Treasury Department Delays Employer Mandate in Health Care Law by One Year

The Treasury Department has announced a one-year delay in the implementation of the employer mandate, a key provision in the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The delay was made after business owners expressed concerns about the complexity of the reporting requirements. Under the ACA, businesses employing 50 or more full-time workers that do not provide health insurance will be penalized.

The postponement will allow the government to assess ways to simplify the reporting process for businesses, with penalties for firms not providing health coverage to employees now set to begin in 2015. The delay will not affect other aspects of the health law, including the establishment of exchanges in states for low-income Americans to obtain health insurance.

Supporters of the employer mandate argue that most firms already provide health insurance to full-time workers, and downplay the effect the requirement would have on small businesses, citing figures showing the vast majority of small businesses employ fewer than 50 workers. Opponents claim the employer mandate is a potential job killer, saying businesses near the 50-worker cutoff will be unlikely to ramp up hiring if it means they're required to provide employees health insurance.

The Obama administration has expressed openness to making the health care law easier to implement, and has acted to shorten applications for health insurance on government-run exchanges from 21 pages to three. The delay is seen as a sign of the administration's determination to implement the health care law effectively and fairly.

While some Republicans have expressed concerns about the roll-out of Obamacare, many Democrats have also voiced concerns about the implementation of the health law. Some have expressed anxiety about the public information campaign on the benefits of the Affordable Care Act, with Senator Max Baucus, a key Democrat who helped craft the legislation, stating that the administration's public information campaign deserves a failing grade.

Title: President Trump Fires FBI Director James Comey, Citing Need for New Leadership

Article:

President Donald Trump fired FBI Director James Comey on Tuesday, citing the need for new leadership at the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The sudden move comes after a tumultuous year for Comey, who faced criticism for his handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server and his agency's investigation into possible ties between the Trump campaign and Russia.

In a letter to Comey, Trump stated that he could not effectively lead the FBI and called for "new leadership that restores public trust and confidence" in law enforcement. The White House said the decision was based on the "clear recommendations" of Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein.

The FBI's acting director, Andrew McCabe, will take over until a new permanent director is appointed. The search for a new director will begin immediately.

The firing comes after the FBI corrected a sentence in Comey's sworn testimony on Capitol Hill last week, which had stated that Huma Abedin, a top aide to then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, had sent "hundreds and thousands" of emails to her husband's laptop, including some with classified information. The FBI later clarified that only a small number of emails were forwarded to the laptop, with most being backed up from electronic devices.

The controversy surrounding Comey's handling of the Clinton email probe and the ongoing investigation into possible ties between the Trump campaign and Russia have led to criticism from both sides of the political aisle. Democrats are calling for an independent prosecutor to investigate the matter, while Republicans have praised Trump's decision to fire Comey.

In his letter to Trump, Sessions said the FBI needs a "fresh start" and emphasized the importance of the next director following "faithfully the rules and principles" of the Justice Department.

Title: Mail-In Voting: A Complex Issue with Both Benefits and Challenges

Mail-in voting has become a contentious topic in the United States, with President Donald Trump's tweets opposing the practice sparking a national debate. However, a closer examination of the issue reveals that most local election officials and voters recognize the need for greater use of mail-in voting, despite the associated challenges.

According to recent surveys, most voters agree that reducing voter density on Election Day and during early voting is essential, and expanding mail balloting is a crucial step towards achieving this goal. However, some Americans still prefer voting in person, citing civic pride and duty as reasons. Others may not trust the postal system or have concerns about the security of their ballots.

A recent survey in Pennsylvania found that roughly half of registered voters plan to vote in person in the fall, while 20% of primary voters who cast mail ballots said they may switch to in-person voting in the general election. Among those who did not vote in the primary but plan to vote in November, most intend to do so in person.

For some voters, particularly those who are new to the process, certain aspects of absentee voting can be confusing. For example, they may struggle to navigate websites to request a ballot or be surprised by the requirement to sign the outside envelope. In recent New Jersey elections, as many as 10% of ballots were not counted due to late arrival or technical deficiencies.

Mail-in voting procedures can also trip up certain groups more than others. An analysis of data from Florida found that African Americans, young people, and first-time voters were less likely to have their mail ballots counted due to lateness or non-compliance with technical requirements.

Election Day polling places serve as a fail-safe for voters who do not receive their mail ballots on time. During the primary season, jurisdictions with limited experience in mail voting have been overwhelmed by the volume of mail ballots, leading to delays and long lines. In Wisconsin, for example, over 10,000 voters requested absentee ballots that never arrived, leaving them with limited options.

In conclusion, mail-in voting is a complex issue with both benefits and challenges. While it can help reduce voter density and increase accessibility, it also requires careful planning and execution to ensure that all eligible voters can participate. As the November elections approach, it is essential to address the concerns and challenges associated with mail-in voting to ensure a smooth and successful voting process.

Title: Supreme Court to Decide on Sales Tax Collection for Online Retailers

Article:

The debate surrounding sales tax collection for online retailers has been ongoing, with some arguing that internet companies are not paying their fair share of taxes and that this is harming bricks-and-mortar retailers and state budgets. However, this notion is far from the truth. The issue is not about internet companies not paying taxes, but rather about whether state and local governments have the authority to collect taxes from out-of-state companies.

A 1992 Supreme Court decision, Quill Corp. v. North Dakota, established that a business must have a significant presence in a state before that state can require it to collect sales taxes. This means that a mom selling handcrafted goods on Etsy does not have to collect sales taxes from her consumers unless they are physically located in her state. However, Amazon collects sales taxes from customers in all 45 states that have a statewide sales tax due to its vast distribution network.

State lawmakers want to see Quill overturned, allowing them to force out-of-state companies to collect sales taxes on their behalf. This argument was recently heard by the Supreme Court in the case of South Dakota v. Wayfair Inc. If the states were to win, they would be able to reach into the pockets of that mom selling her paintings on Etsy, even though she may live on the other side of the country and did not agree to those states' tax laws.

However, overturning Quill could have negative consequences for consumers. Tax competition among states would be lost, and online consumers would lose the ability to shop around for a better tax system. Without the competitive pressure and the fear of losing consumers to lower-tax states, lawmakers would not feel the need to try to rein in their sales tax burden.

Some lawmakers may hope that more revenue would alleviate the need to put their financial house in order. However, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation, 33 states faced shortfalls in fiscal 2017 and/or fiscal 2018, even though revenue collection has been growing in most states. This is because the more states collect in revenue, the more they spend.

Additionally, states are overestimating the revenue they would gain from taxing internet sales. Internet sales are still a small share of overall sales, and taxing them would not make a significant difference. According to a 2017 report by the Government Accountability Office, online sales represent less than 10% of retail sales. Also, the 100 biggest online retailers already tax roughly 90% of their sales.

A reversal of Quill would, however, increase compliance costs for small online retailers, which have razor-thin profit margins. Compliance would require handling thousands of items on a case-by-case basis, making it a significant burden. As an eBay representative noted, "in Minnesota, blankets are taxable, but baby receiving blankets are not taxable. In Texas, deodorant is taxable, but deodorant that has an antiperspirant is not." Tax software is not that precise, and compliance would still have to be handled on a case-by-case basis.

The outcome of the Wayfair case is crucial. If Quill were to be overturned, compliance costs could skyrocket for many retailers, and good principles of taxation would be thrown out the window. Healthy tax competition is at stake. Let's hope the highest court in the land makes the right decision.

Title: US Vice-President Honors Veterans on Veterans Day

Article:

US Vice-President Joe Biden paid tribute to American military veterans on Veterans Day, describing them as the "heart and soul" and "very spine" of the nation. Biden made the remarks during a visit to Arlington National Cemetery, where he laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

In his speech, Biden acknowledged the sacrifices made by the all-volunteer force, stating that the US has never asked so much of its military personnel over such a sustained period. He praised veterans as being "the most trusted among us and the most tested of all Americans."

The US celebrates Veterans Day annually to honor all American veterans, a tradition that began in 1954. Since 2001, over two million Americans have served overseas in the Afghanistan and Iraq wars. A record number of veterans from these wars were elected to the US Congress last week.

In related news, the US Department of Veterans Affairs faced controversy in the past year due to delayed care and falsified records at its hospitals. Ohio is reminding veterans from the Iraq war that they have limited time to collect a bonus authorized by the state in 2009.

Meanwhile, a group representing gay and lesbian veterans will participate in Boston's Veterans Day parade for the first time. A star-studded concert, featuring performers such as Bruce Springsteen, Rihanna, and Carrie Underwood, is also planned for the National Mall in Washington to honor veterans.

Title: House Democrats Unveil Impeachment Articles Against Trump, Announce NAFTA Replacement Deal

House Democrats have unveiled two articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump, charging him with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The move comes as the party announced an agreement with the White House on a replacement for the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), which has been rebranded as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA).

The impeachment articles were unveiled on Tuesday morning, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi stating that Democrats had reached an agreement with the White House on the trade deal. The agreement is expected to be signed by Mexico and Canada in the coming days.

Pelosi and moderate Democrats praised the one-two punch of impeachment and the trade deal, arguing that Democrats needed to prove they can "walk and chew gum at the same time." However, many progressives slammed the strategy, arguing that the USMCA undermines the party's case for impeachment.

Critics of the strategy claimed that the trade deal undermines Democrats' claims that President Trump is unfit for office and lends credence to his argument that he is getting his job done. "Either the Republic is in danger and impeachment is necessary, or it's not that big a deal and Congress can do business as usual," said Adam Serwer, a writer for The Atlantic.

The USMCA deal includes various environmental and labor regulations, which Democrats touted as a major achievement. Trump took to Twitter to praise the deal, saying it would be "great for our country."

Pelosi stated that Democrats did not have much control over the timing of either development, with the impeachment hearings concluding on Monday and the USMCA deal needing to be finalized before Congress goes on recess.

The move has sparked debate among Democrats, with some arguing that it is a necessary step to prove the party can "walk and chew gum at the same time," while others believe it undermines the party's message and lends credibility to Trump's claims.

Title: Romney's Favorability Rating Surges Above 50 Percent, Ties Obama in Favorability Polls

BOCA RATON, Fla. - Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has reached a significant milestone, with his favorability rating surpassing 50 percent, according to the Real Clear Politics average of polls. This marks a turning point in the election, as Romney has managed to puncture President Obama's strategy of making him an unacceptable candidate in the minds of voters.

The debates, particularly the first one, are credited with destroying the Obama campaign's strategy of disqualification. Republican pollster Mike McKenna stated, "Six months of work and $400 million of ad buys went up in smoke in about 10 days. With less than 340 hours to go, they are having real trouble with their footing."

Romney's favorability rating has increased significantly since the debates, jumping from 44.5 percent at the end of September to 50.5 percent by Monday. Tom Jensen, director of Public Policy Polling, a Democratic firm, noted that Romney's favorability surge has been remarkable and explains why Obama has not been able to put away the race at this point.

While Romney's favorability rating has dropped slightly since the debates, he still leads Obama in net favorability, with a 6.5-point advantage. Obama's favorability averaged 49.7 percent, or 4.5 points more than his unfavorable rating.

Romney's campaign has capitalized on his improved favorability ratings, with the candidate stating that the debates "supercharged" his supporters. Republicans believe that Romney has made himself a palatable alternative to Obama, while Democrats argue that he has not provided enough specifics on his policies.

The debates have also highlighted the differences between the two candidates on domestic issues, with Obama emphasizing his progress in addressing the economy and Romney focusing on his own vision for the country. Instant polls showed Obama winning the debate on points, but Republicans believe that Romney's measured and presidential performance has helped him connect with voters.

The Obama campaign has criticized Romney for not providing enough specifics on his policies, while Republicans argue that he has made himself a credible alternative to the president. The election remains a close contest, with both candidates vying for the support of undecided voters.

Title: US Economy Adds 113,000 Jobs in January, But Growth Remains Weak

The US economy added 113,000 jobs in January, according to the government, marking an improvement from the previous month but still falling short of expectations. Economists had predicted an addition of 178,000 jobs, and the report was characterized as "disappointing" and "weak."

The unemployment rate remained steady at 6.6%, with 10 million Americans counted as unemployed. However, the participation rate, which measures the percentage of Americans actively working or looking for work, remained at 63%, its lowest level since 1978. This decline is partly due to baby boomers retiring, but economists are also concerned about the long-term unemployed, who may be giving up on the job market altogether.

The report showed that 3.6 million Americans have been unemployed for six months or more, and those who were relying on extended government benefits lost that lifeline in December. The Federal Reserve has been stressing that its stimulus policies depend on the economic data, and while it has been aiming for an unemployment rate of 6.5%, it is expected to distance itself from using that number as its main measure of the job market.

The report also showed that more than half of January's job gains came from traditional blue-collar sectors, with construction firms adding 48,000 jobs and manufacturers adding 21,000 jobs. The mining industry also added 7,200 jobs. However, the health care sector cut 400 jobs, the first month of job losses since 2003.

Overall, the US economy lost 8.7 million jobs in the financial crisis, and as of January, 7.8 million jobs have come back. However, once economists account for population growth, they expect it will still take years to get back to a pre-recession job market.

Title: Trump Reverses Pledge to Support GOP Nominee, Citing Unfair Treatment

Donald Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, has reversed his pledge to support the eventual Republican nominee, citing what he perceives as unfair treatment by the Republican National Committee (RNC) and the party establishment. This decision comes after Trump initially raised his hand during a debate in August, stating he would not support the nominee if he or she did not win the primary.

However, Trump has since changed his stance, stating he will not support the nominee, regardless of who it is. He has also pointed to the RNC and the party establishment as reasons for his decision. Trump's change of heart is seen as a response to the possibility of a brokered convention and delegate allocation rules, which he believes are unfair.

Trump's decision to reverse his pledge has been met with criticism from some party loyalists, who believe an independent Trump bid would ensure a Hillary Clinton presidency. However, Trump sees his decision as a way to protect his own interests and leverage his strong and devoted following among GOP primary voters.

The article highlights Trump's perception of unfair treatment by the RNC and the party establishment, citing his original pledge to support the nominee and his subsequent change of heart. It also notes that Trump's decision is seen as a way to protect his own interests and leverage his strong support among GOP primary voters.

Overall, the article presents a neutral and factual account of Trump's decision to reverse his pledge to support the GOP nominee, highlighting the complexities and nuances of the situation.

Title: Attorney General Sessions Says He Will Recuse Himself from Russia Investigation if Necessary

Article:

Attorney General Jeff Sessions has stated that he will recuse himself from any investigation involving Russia and the Trump campaign if it is deemed necessary. This announcement comes after reports emerged that Sessions had spoken with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak during the 2016 presidential race, which he did not disclose during his confirmation hearings.

Sessions defended himself during his comments with NBC News, saying he did not discuss the presidential campaign with Russian officials. "Well, I have not met with any Russians at any time to discuss any political campaigns," he said. "Those remarks are unbelievable to me and are false. I don't have anything else to say about that."

The FBI is investigating contact between Russian officials and members of the Trump campaign, although no formal charges have been brought. Committees in the House and Senate are also pursuing their own investigations.

Some lawmakers, including House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, have suggested that Sessions should recuse himself from any Russia-related investigations. "I don't have all the information in front of me, I don't want to pre-judge, but I just think for any investigation going forward, you want to make sure everybody trusts the investigation," McCarthy said on MSNBC's "Morning Joe."

Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., said that if the FBI finds any criminal activity related to campaign aides' alleged contact with Russian officials, a special prosecutor will likely be needed. Rep. Sean Duffy, R-Wis., wished Sessions had been "more clear" during the confirmation process about his meetings with Kislyak.

Sessions, a former Republican senator from Alabama, reportedly spoke with Kislyak during a July Heritage Foundation event at the Republican National Convention attended by about 50 ambassadors. A Department of Justice official told The Washington Post that Kislyak was among a group of diplomats who approached Sessions and spoke with him informally there. Sessions also spoke with Kislyak via phone in September, according to a spokeswoman for the attorney general.

The conversation took place during a time when U.S. intelligence officials assert that Russia was interfering in the 2016 race through a hacking and influence campaign. Democrats have seized on the news, arguing that Sessions must recuse himself from any federal investigation into contact between Russia and Trump's team.

Title: New Study Challenges Conventional Wisdom on Political Polarization

A recent study by political scientists from Princeton, Georgetown, and the University of Oregon has shed new light on the notion that Republicans have become increasingly extreme, while Democrats have remained moderate. The study, published in August, analyzed data on state-level politics and found that the Democratic Party has moved to the left at a faster rate than the Republican Party has moved to the right.

The study's findings contradict the common narrative that Republicans have become more extreme and polarizing, while Democrats have remained centrist. Instead, the data suggests that both parties have moved in their respective directions, with Democrats shifting to the left and Republicans shifting to the right.

The study's authors argue that income inequality has contributed to political polarization at the state level since the 1990s, with Democratic parties moving to the left as they lost power and shed their moderate wing. In contrast, Republican parties have remained relatively stable in their ideological median.

This challenges the notion that Republicans are solely responsible for political polarization and gridlock in Washington. The study's findings suggest that both parties have contributed to the growing divide, with Democrats moving to the left and Republicans moving to the right.

The study's results are supported by other research, including a 2012 book by political scientists Norman Ornstein and Thomas Mann, which found that Republicans have become more ideologically extreme than Democrats since 1973. However, the new study's findings suggest that this trend may not be as one-sided as previously thought.

The study's authors note that while the data does not prove a thesis, it does provide interesting insights into the dynamics of political polarization. The findings suggest that our discussions about polarization need to reflect the fact that it is a bipartisan affair, and that both parties have contributed to the growing divide.

Title: US President Trump Attacks Democrats Over Government Shutdown Proposals

Article:

US President Donald Trump has criticized Democrats for rejecting his proposals to end the longest government shutdown in US history. Trump claimed that his plans had been dismissed before he had even presented them, and accused Democrats of not seeing the importance of border security and being focused solely on the 2020 elections.

The President's proposals included offering temporary protection for around 700,000 so-called Dreamers, who were brought to the US illegally as children, and 300,000 people holding Temporary Protection Status (TPS), who have fled countries affected by war or disasters. However, Democrats called the proposals "unacceptable" and a "non-starter," saying they were a compilation of previously rejected initiatives.

Trump took to Twitter to express his frustration, stating that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other Democrats had "turned down my offer yesterday before I even got up to speak." He also tweeted that his opponents "don't see crime and drugs, they only see 2020 - which they are not going to win."

The President also addressed concerns from the conservative right, who fear his proposals would amount to an amnesty. Trump clarified that his offer was only for a three-year extension and that an amnesty would be part of a larger deal, not a standalone agreement.

The government shutdown, which has entered its fifth week, has affected over 800,000 federal employees, with many setting up crowdfunding campaigns to cover their living expenses. The impasse has also led to a stalemate in negotiations between the President and Democrats, with the latter refusing to negotiate until the government is reopened.

Senator Chuck Schumer, a key Democratic leader, criticized Trump's proposals, saying they were "not a compromise but more hostage taking" and that the President had previously "single-handedly" taken away Dreamer and TPS protections.

Title: Trump Administration to Allow Additional 30,000 Seasonal Workers to Enter the US

The Trump administration has cleared a rule to issue an additional 30,000 H-2B visas to foreign workers who have held them in the past, exceeding the previously expected 15,000 visas. This decision reflects internal tensions within the White House regarding legal immigration. The H-2B program allows foreign workers to fill lower-skilled jobs in industries such as landscaping, fisheries, and holiday resorts, which often struggle to find American workers.

The H-2B program has been capped at 66,000 visas annually, with 33,000 for summer and 33,000 for winter. However, demand often exceeds supply, leading to a shortage. Congress allows the administration to raise the cap each year, and the Labor Department and Department of Homeland Security authorized 15,000 extra visas in 2017 and 2018.

According to the most recent U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services data, half of all H-2B visas in 2017 went to agricultural and horticultural industries, while building and construction, forestry and logging, food services, and handlers and laborers accounted for most of the rest.

The decision comes amid an immigration tug-of-war within the administration between U.S. business allies, who want relaxed rules on recruiting overseas to facilitate growth in a tight jobs market, and immigration restrictionists, who argue that U.S. workers will see wages rise only if foreign workers are prevented from undercutting them.

The group NumbersUSA, which favors immigration restrictions, launched a cable-TV ad campaign in late April, partly in response to the administration's plans for more H-2B visas. "The ad is responding to a number of developments in which businesses are receiving or demanding more work visas so they don't have to recruit from the millions of Americans who are not in the labor market at all," said Roy Beck, the head of NumbersUSA.

Top White House officials, such as Stephen Miller, are seeking to restrict legal immigration programs, including H-1B visas for high-skilled workers and B-1 and B-2 visas for business and leisure visitors from certain countries whose nationals have high rates of overstaying. Meanwhile, Jared Kushner, the president's adviser and son-in-law, is finalizing a legislative proposal to overhaul immigration, which may offer a larger number of H-1B visas for high-skilled workers, with fewer restrictions on the number of green cards available for any one particular country.

The administration has also launched a program to investigate companies that discriminate against American workers in favor of temporary workers, the Protecting U.S. Workers Initiative, housed in the Department of Justice Civil Rights Division. The initiative has reached settlements with five companies, including a landscaping and housekeeping company, for failing to follow all the steps required of the H-2B program; the companies paid tens of thousands of dollars in compensation and penalties.

Other members of the Trump administration have said they favor new legislation to guarantee a number of H-2B visas each year. "For the last two years, rather than come to a decision as to what the right number is, Congress has simply chosen not to act," said Labor Secretary Alex Acosta, testifying last month after saying that he supported the 30,000 increase. "Businesses can't plan. They don't know how many visas are going to be available. And we owe them greater certainty," he said.

The debate over low-skilled and high-skilled foreign labor divides Congress and political parties. A group of five senators, including Dianne Feinstein (D, Calif.), Chuck Grassley (R, Iowa), Dick Durbin (D, Ill.), and Tom Cotton (R, Ark.), said in a letter released in early April that they had "serious reservations about the harmful impact of the H-2B visa program on both immigrant and American workers" and asked for the increase to be reconsidered. Another group of 11 senators, including Republicans Cory Gardner of Colorado, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, and Susan Collins of Maine, as well as Maine independent Angus King and Democrats from Alabama, Delaware, and Minnesota, called on Department of Homeland Security Acting Secretary Kevin McAleenan in late April to expedite the release of the additional visas. "The states we represent lack the working-age population needed to meet the demands for seasonal jobs," their letter said, adding that the 30,000 extra visas "will provide much-needed relief."

Title: The Media's Approach to Truth and Trust in the Age of Trump

The Columbia Journalism Review, a respected voice in the journalism industry, has sparked a debate about the media's role in addressing the truth and trust in the era of President Donald Trump. The Review's analysis highlights the New York Times' efforts to call out Trump's falsehoods without directly labeling him a liar. This approach raises questions about how to discuss a president who defies categorization.

The Review notes that the Times' White House reporter, Maggie Haberman, tweeted that Trump told two demonstrable falsehoods, sparking a weekend-long conversation on Twitter. Some critics found Haberman's charge too mild, while others saw it as a necessary step in holding the president accountable.

The article argues that the media's approach to Trump's truthfulness is misguided. Rather than trying to categorize him as a liar or a truth-teller, journalists should focus on presenting facts and allowing readers to make their own conclusions. The author suggests that the media's efforts to "speak truth to power" by labeling Trump a liar are counterproductive and may even undermine trust in the media.

The article also questions the media's role in shaping public opinion and whether they should be seen as educators or entertainers. The author believes that the media's angry and judgmental tone is not only ineffective but also divisive and may erode public trust.

The article concludes that the media's approach to Trump's truthfulness is a symptom of a larger problem in the media industry. The author, William Murchison, a former Radford Distinguished Professor of Journalism at Baylor University, is writing a book about moral restoration and suggests that the media's angry judgmentalism is making things worse, not better.

Title: Christine Hallquist Makes History as First Transgender Candidate to Win Major Party's Governor Nomination

Article:

Christine Hallquist, a 62-year-old Democrat, has won the Vermont primary election, becoming the first transgender candidate to secure a major party's nomination for governor. Hallquist, a former CEO of the Vermont Electric Co-operative, ran on a platform focused on higher wages for workers, better healthcare for families, and improved education for children. She emphasized that her election is not solely due to her transgender status, but rather her policies and qualifications.

Hallquist's campaign received support from the Victory Fund, a political action committee that backs LGBTQ candidates across the country. Her victory is seen as a significant milestone, not only for Vermont but also nationwide, as it marks the first time a transgender candidate has won a major party's nomination for governor.

Hallquist's background is marked by her transition from male to female in 2015, which she publicly disclosed. She had worked at the Vermont Electric Co-operative since 1998, becoming CEO in 2005. She resigned from her position earlier this year to focus on her gubernatorial campaign.

Hallquist's opponents in the primary election included environmental activist James Ehlers, dance festival organizer Brenda Siegel, and 14-year-old Ethan Sonneborn, who was able to run due to a loophole in the state law that does not require candidates to be of voting age.

If Hallquist wins the general election in November, she would become the nation's first transgender governor. According to the Victory Fund, roughly 200 LGBT candidates are expected to be on the November ballot across the country for state and federal office, including Alexandra Chandler, Massachusetts' first openly transgender candidate for Congress, and Kim Coco Iwamoto, who would be Hawaii's first transgender lieutenant governor if elected.

Title: Excelerate Energy Negotiates Long-Term Contracts for Natural Gas Exports

Excelerate Energy, a Texas-based energy company, is in talks with several foreign companies to secure long-term contracts for the export of natural gas. The company expects to finalize agreements by early next year, with the first shipments expected to depart the Texas coast by 2017. This development comes as the global demand for natural gas is expected to increase by 50% over the next 20 years, driven primarily by emerging markets like India and China.

The United States is poised to become the world's second-largest natural gas exporter, behind Russia, with 15 other export projects currently under review by the Energy Department. The country's natural gas reserves are abundant, and the industry is shifting its focus towards exporting liquefied natural gas (LNG) to capitalize on high prices in global markets.

The shift towards LNG exports is driven by technological advancements in extraction and transportation methods, which have made it possible to ship natural gas across the globe. This has led to the creation of a global market, where energy companies can hunt for the highest prices across different continents before deciding where to ship the gas.

Asia is expected to be a major driver of demand, with countries like Japan and South Korea increasing their imports of LNG. In fact, Cheniere Energy, a Houston-based energy firm, has signed a 20-year deal with the Korea Gas Corporation to ship natural gas to South Korea beginning in 2017.

The growth of the global LNG market is also attracting international energy companies to the United States. Foreign firms are acquiring stakes in American energy projects, seeking access to the country's vast untapped resources. For example, Golden Pass Products, a venture owned by Qatar Petroleum International, was granted a license to export LNG from a proposed site in Texas.

While the expansion of the natural gas industry is expected to transform the sector over the next 20 years, it is not without its challenges. Building LNG terminals can take years, and many utilities are locked into contracts with existing natural gas producers, limiting opportunities for new entrants. However, the industry is expected to continue growing, driven by increasing demand and technological advancements.

Title: Advocacy Groups Shift Focus from National Security, Leaving Congress to Go It Alone on Syria

The debate over potential military action in Syria has left lawmakers facing a daunting political reality: the public is strongly against intervention, and there is no apparent infrastructure in place to change public opinion. This shift is partly attributed to the decline of advocacy groups focused on national security issues, particularly on the right.

In the past, groups like Freedom's Watch, Vets for Freedom, and Keep America Safe were vocal in their support for military intervention. However, since President Barack Obama's election and the 2008 financial crisis, many of these groups have either disbanded or shifted their focus to other topics. Freedom's Watch, for example, disbanded after Obama's election, while Vets for Freedom has gone dormant. Keep America Safe, founded by Liz Cheney and others, closed up shop ahead of Cheney's decision to run for Senate in Wyoming.

Ari Fleischer, a former Bush White House press secretary and co-founder of Freedom's Watch, noted that there is no standing entity dedicated to supporting aggressive foreign and military policy. Pete Hegseth, the former head of Vets for Freedom, expressed support for "limited action" in Syria, but does not expect substantial pro-intervention advocacy from outside groups.

The anti-war side of the advocacy world has also slowed down, with some Democratic-leaning groups that ran TV ads defending opposition to the Iraq war turning their attention to domestic issues. Americans United for Change, for instance, has no current plans to dive into the Syria debate, as it is focused on issues like Obamacare and the budget.

The decline of these advocacy groups has left lawmakers to navigate the political landscape alone, with no clear infrastructure in place to sway public opinion.

Title: Lawmakers Introduce Taxes on Firearms and Ammunition to Fund Mental Health Services and Police Training

Lawmakers at both the state and federal levels are proposing new taxes on firearms and ammunition to fund mental health services, police training, and victims' treatment in the wake of recent mass shootings. The proposed taxes range from a 5 percent tax in New Jersey to a 50 percent tax in Maryland. These measures follow efforts to ban assault weapons and high-capacity magazines and expand background checks, which have had mixed success at the state level.

The taxes, similar to "sin taxes" on cigarettes, aim to deter buyers while generating revenue for favored programs. The sponsors want to direct the money towards mental health services, police training, and victims' treatment. However, firearms groups argue that these taxes unfairly punish law-abiding gun owners.

Lawrence Keane, senior vice president and general counsel for the National Shooting Sports Foundation, stated that the purpose of the taxes is to "frustrate and limit the exercise of the Second Amendment." While acknowledging that some revenue from these taxes and fees would go towards victims' services, Keane emphasized that those paying the tax are mostly not those responsible for gun crime.

Firearms manufacturers already pay a federal tax, which goes towards wildlife conservation. A tax on sales would make firearms more expensive. At the federal level, Representative Linda Sanchez proposed a bill that would impose a 10 percent tax on "concealable" firearms, with the revenue going towards a national gun buyback program. The bill is still in committee.

Several other states have introduced similar measures. California Representative Roger Dickinson introduced a bill to impose a 5-cent tax on every bullet, with the revenue going towards screening young people for mental illness. Massachusetts Representative David Linsky is pushing a 25 percent sales tax on ammunition and firearms, while Maryland Representative Jon Cardin introduced a bill imposing a 50 percent tax on ammo and an annual $25 gun registration fee.

According to the Las Vegas Review-Journal, Assembly Majority Leader William Horne is pushing a draft bill that would include a $25 per gun sales tax, in addition to a 2-cent tax for every round of ammunition. The tax proposals are part of a multi-front campaign by pro-gun control lawmakers to rein in firearms.

While some states, particularly Colorado, have moved forward with new gun regulations, the movement on Capitol Hill has been more restrained. A Senate committee recently voted to enhance penalties on illegal gun buys, but other bills remain on hold. President Obama plans to speak to supporters and donors on Wednesday in Washington, where he is expected to touch on the gun control issue.

Title: Trump Says Soleimani Should Have Been Taken Out Years Ago, Citing Death Toll

Article:

President Donald Trump has spoken publicly for the first time about the US airstrike that killed Iranian military leader Qassem Soleimani, stating that the general was "directly and indirectly responsible for the death of millions of people." In a series of tweets, Trump claimed that Soleimani was responsible for the deaths of thousands of Americans and was plotting to kill many more.

Trump also tied the situation in Iraq to the fallout from the strike, raising questions about stability in the region. He stated that the US has paid Iraq billions of dollars over the years and that the people of Iraq do not want to be dominated and controlled by Iran. The president also noted that Iran has gained more control over Iraq over the past 15 years, which has made the people of Iraq unhappy.

The airstrike, which was authorized by Trump, has left much of the world on edge, with Iran vowing revenge. The State Department has urged US citizens to leave Iraq immediately and has advised against approaching the US Embassy in Baghdad. The Pentagon confirmed that the strike was a "decisive defensive action to protect US personnel abroad."

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo defended the strike, stating that it "saved American lives." Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the supreme leader of Iran, called Soleimani's death "bitter" but vowed that life would be "more bitter for the murderers and criminals." Foreign Minister Javad Zarif called the strike against Soleimani an "act of international terrorism" and a "foolish escalation."

The move marked a significant escalation in Trump's widening confrontation with Iran and has sparked concerns about the potential for destabilizing consequences in the region.

Title: Katie Couric Accused of Deceptive Editing in Two Documentaries

Katie Couric, a renowned journalist and producer, is facing new accusations of deceptive editing in two documentaries. The allegations come just a week after she accepted blame for editing an interview in a different documentary in a way that misrepresented the views of pro-gun activists.

According to the Washington Free Beacon, Couric edited the documentary "Fed Up" to embarrass individuals who were interviewed, including Dr. David Allison, director of the Nutrition Obesity Research Center. Allison claimed that Couric edited his responses to make him appear uncertain and unprepared, which he believes is antithetical to the spirit of science and democratic dialogue.

In the documentary, Couric interviewed Allison about the issue of obesity and the food industry. Allison said he had a brief discussion with Couric about whether sugary drinks exacerbate America's obesity problem more than other foods. Couric reportedly questioned Allison about the science behind his claims, and he asked for a moment to "get his thoughts together" because she had specifically requested that all his answers be in layman's terms. However, the cameras continued rolling, and Allison was seen sitting silently for nearly 10 seconds before the documentary cut to the next interviewee.

Another example of alleged deceptive editing involves an interview with Lisa Gable, a spokeswoman for the Healthy Weight Commitment Foundation. Sources told the Free Beacon that Couric's voice was deceptively edited to embarrass Gable. In the documentary, Gable was asked about whether stores would consider removing food products from shelves. At one point, Couric can be heard saying Gable is avoiding the question, and Gable is seen sitting silently for around three seconds. However, the producer's voice was edited to make it seem like Gable's response was evasive.

The new accusations have sparked concerns about Couric's editing practices and whether she is intentionally trying to manipulate the narrative of the documentaries she produces. Couric has apologized for the editing mistakes in the past, but it remains to be seen how she will respond to these latest allegations.

**Tariff Tensions Escalate Between US and China, But Not a Trade War Yet**

The United States and China have engaged in a tit-for-tat exchange of tariff threats, with Beijing releasing a list of $50 billion worth of US products targeted with tariffs and the Trump administration responding with a similar list of Chinese high-tech imports. This move has sent the stock market into wild swings, with investors concerned about the potential for a trade war.

The list of Chinese products, which includes soybeans, pork, cranberries, whiskey, automobiles, airplanes, and plastic, is aimed at industries that do big business in China and dominate regions of the country that make up President Trump's political base. The tariffs, which would impose a 25% tax on the targeted products, are seen as a response to China's theft of American intellectual property and its trade surplus with the US.

While some economists warn of the risks of an escalating trade war, others believe that the US and China are simply engaging in a "weigh-in" before the big fight, with both sides gauging how far they can push each other without sparking a full-blown conflict.

The US tariffs, which require a monthslong comment and review process, are aimed at addressing the US trade deficit and intellectual property theft, while China's tariffs are seen as a response to the US imposing tariffs on 1,300 of its high-tech imports. The value of the US products targeted is virtually identical to the $50 billion in Chinese high-tech products identified for tariffs.

The US Chamber of Commerce has warned that a trade war could lead to higher prices for American consumers and lost jobs for American workers in affected industries. However, some experts believe that the US and China may be able to negotiate a resolution, with the US National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow saying that a negotiated resolution is more likely.

The US Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley has expressed concerns about the impact of the tariffs on American farmers and ranchers, who are already feeling the effects of retaliatory tariffs from China.

Title: Trump Calls for "Good Shutdown" in September to Fix "Mess" in Government

President Donald Trump expressed frustration with the government's legislative process on Tuesday, calling for a "good shutdown" in September to fix the "mess" in government. In a series of tweets, Trump stated that the reason for the plan negotiated between Republicans and Democrats is that they need 60 votes in the Senate, which are not there. He suggested that either electing more Republican Senators in 2018 or changing the rules to 51% would be necessary.

The comments appear to reflect Trump's frustration with the spending deal Congress is poised to approve this week, which would fund the government through September. The legislation represents the first major bipartisan legislation of Trump's presidency, but Democrats have argued that they won most of the battles surrounding the bill. The White House budget director, Mick Mulvaney, expressed frustration with the media's coverage of the deal, saying that the president's tweet was a "defensible position" and that the White House "completely destroyed" the narrative that they were not reasonable.

The spending deal does not include funding for Trump's proposed wall along the U.S.-Mexico border or language stripping federal money from so-called sanctuary cities, both of which the White House demanded at the outset of negotiations. The deal does, however, include increased military spending, which Trump touted as a "game-changer."

Title: Trump Discusses CIA Assessment of Jamal Khashoggi's Killing with CIA Chief and Secretary of State

Article:

President Donald Trump spoke with CIA Director Gina Haspel and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Saturday about the CIA's assessment of the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. According to a U.S. official familiar with the intelligence, the CIA has intelligence that substantiates an assessment that Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman ordered the killing. However, neither official indicated that there is direct evidence linking bin Salman to the killing, including on the day of the incident.

The CIA's assessment is based on an understanding of how Saudi Arabia operates, and a separate U.S. official described the confidence level as "high." The intelligence agencies' conclusion is likely to bolster efforts in Congress to further punish the close U.S. ally for the killing.

The Trump administration has already penalized 17 Saudi officials for their alleged role in the killing, but American lawmakers have called on the administration to curtail arms sales to Saudi Arabia or take other harsher punitive measures. Saudi Arabia's top diplomat has denied any involvement by the crown prince in the killing.

Vice President Mike Pence also commented on the matter, stating that the murder of Jamal Khashoggi was an atrocity and an affront to a free and independent press. He emphasized that the United States will "follow the facts" while trying to find a way to preserve a "strong and historic partnership" with Saudi Arabia.

The killing of Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist who lived in the United States and wrote for The Washington Post, occurred on October 2 at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul. Turkish and Saudi authorities have said he was killed inside the consulate by a team from the kingdom after he went there to get marriage documents.

Title: Trump Administration Rescinds Obama-Era Immigration Policy, Leaves DACA Program Intact

The Trump administration has rescinded a 2014 memo created by former President Barack Obama, which shielded millions of migrants from deportation. However, the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which allows undocumented immigrants who arrived in the United States as children to remain in the country, will remain in place.

Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly announced the decision to rescind the memo, which was challenged in court by 26 states and put on hold by federal courts. The memo, known as Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA), was never implemented.

The decision fulfills part of President Trump's campaign promise to overturn two of Obama's memos on illegal immigration. However, Kelly stated that the decision will not impact the DACA program, which has allowed nearly 800,000 undocumented immigrants who arrived in the United States as children to remain in the country.

Advocates for undocumented immigrants have expressed concerns that while the DACA program remains in place for now, it is vulnerable to being reversed in the future. The Trump administration's decision to rescind the parental program has also been met with criticism from some lawmakers.

Senator Tom Cotton, R-Ark., praised the decision, calling it "a deeply irresponsible policy from the start." Representative Don Beyer, D-Va., blasted the decision, noting that it came as Democrats and Republicans had put aside partisanship and gathered for the Congressional Baseball Game following the shooting of House Majority Whip Steve Scalise, R-La.

The need for comprehensive immigration reform giving undocumented immigrants a pathway to citizenship has never been more urgent, Beyer said.

Title: Romney Supports Raising Minimum Wage, Breaks with Fellow Republicans

Article:

Former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, has expressed support for increasing the minimum wage, diverging from many of his fellow Republicans who have opposed the idea. In an interview on "Morning Joe," Romney stated, "I think we ought to raise it. Because frankly, our party is all about more jobs and better pay."

This stance comes after Senate Republicans rejected a bill that would have increased the minimum wage to $10.10. However, Romney is not alone in his support for a minimum wage hike. Former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty and former Pennsylvania Senator Rick Santorum, both of whom also ran for the Republican nomination in 2012, have also expressed support for some increase in the minimum wage.

Romney also discussed his thoughts on the 2016 presidential election, stating that he is not running for president and believes the best prospects for the Republican Party's chances of winning the White House are with someone who has not run twice before, like himself. He mentioned several potential Republican candidates, including his 2012 running mate Representative Paul Ryan and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie.

Romney also criticized Hillary Clinton's record as Secretary of State, stating that her time in the position was not good for the United States abroad. He expressed concerns about her leadership capacity and the potential questions her record will raise about her ability to accomplish significant things on foreign soil.

In addition, Romney appeared to condone fundraising efforts by the National Republican Congressional Committee and National Republican Senatorial Committee that invoked the September 2012 attacks in Benghazi. He stated that without a GOP majority in the House, there would have been no investigations into Benghazi or the IRS, and that electing Republicans would allow for these kinds of investigations to occur.

Title: Nation Commemorates 18th Anniversary of 9/11 Attacks

The United States marked the 18th anniversary of the September 11 attacks on Wednesday, with tributes and ceremonies held across the country. The day began with moments of silence and the reading of the names of the almost 3,000 people who lost their lives in the attacks.

In New York City, the National September 11 Memorial & Museum held a ceremony where the names of the victims were solemnly read. Intermittent moments of silence marked the impact times of the planes, the time when each tower collapsed, and the moment when planes struck the Pentagon and a field in Shanksville, Pennsylvania.

The ceremony was attended by family members of the victims, including Mary Ann Marino, who lost her son, firefighter Kenneth Marino. "Eighteen years have not lessened our loss," she said.

In Washington, D.C., President Donald Trump spoke at the Pentagon, where 184 people were killed 18 years ago. He also led a brief remembrance on the South Lawn of the White House, joined by hundreds of guests, including 9/11 survivors and family members and current and former law enforcement personnel.

Trump blamed the Taliban for the cancellation of peace talks to try to end the war that started in Afghanistan shortly after the 9/11 attacks. He said U.S. forces have "hit them" harder than ever and warned that if the Taliban ever returns to the country, the U.S. will "go wherever they are and use power the likes of which the U.S. has never used before."

In Shanksville, Pennsylvania, Vice President Mike Pence lauded the heroes of United Airlines Flight 93, which crashed into a field after passengers fought with hijackers intent on crashing into the U.S. Capitol. The names of the 40 passengers and crew were read, and the Bells of Remembrance were rung.

Cities and towns across the nation marked the anniversary, with some events sparking controversy. In Michigan, an anti-Muslim event was canceled amid condemnation from politicians and organizations. The event, titled "9/11 Forgotten? Is Michigan Surrendering to Islam?", was set to host speakers addressing topics such as "How the interfaith movement is sabotaging America" and "How Islam is destroying America from within."

The 9/11 attacks, which occurred on September 11, 2001, resulted in the loss of nearly 3,000 lives and had a profound impact on the world. The anniversary is a time for Americans to remember and honor those who were lost, as well as to reflect on the ongoing efforts to prevent future attacks.

Title: Indiana Governor Mike Pence Defends "Religious Freedom" Law Amid Backlash

Indiana Governor Mike Pence has defended the state's new "Religious Freedom Restoration Act", which allows businesses to cite their religious beliefs as a legal defense against lawsuits. However, the law has sparked intense backlash, with critics arguing it could be used to discriminate against the lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) community.

Pence refused to answer at least six yes-or-no questions about whether the law legalizes discrimination against LGBT individuals, instead stating that the law is meant to protect the religious freedom of people of faith and families. He also declined to support adding protections based on sexual orientation to Indiana's anti-discrimination laws.

The law has triggered a national outcry, with the White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest calling Pence's decision "damage control mode". Tech companies, including Apple and Salesforce.com, have also spoken out against the law, with Apple CEO Tim Cook tweeting that the company is "deeply disappointed" in Indiana's decision.

The law has also led to a number of local businesses canceling plans to expand or invest in Indiana, including Angie's List, which was set to build a major facility in Indianapolis. The NCAA, NBA, WNBA, and NFL have also issued critical statements, while popular culture figures like Miley Cyrus and MC Hammer have weighed in on social media.

Pence has maintained that the law is not intended to discriminate against anyone, but rather to protect the religious freedom of people of faith. He pointed out that President Bill Clinton signed a similar law nationally, and that then-state Senator Barack Obama supported a similar law in Illinois. However, Indiana does not have a state law protecting against discrimination based on sexual orientation.

The law's chief legislative sponsor, state Senator Scott Schneider, has also agreed that the law would protect businesses that refuse to serve LGBT individuals. Pence has refused to comment on specific examples of situations where the law could be used to discriminate, such as a Christian baker refusing to make a wedding cake for a same-sex couple.

The backlash against the law has led to a number of local and national organizations calling for changes to the law or for Pence to repeal it. The law's opponents argue that it sends a harmful message and could lead to discrimination and harm for LGBT individuals.

Title: Candidates Face Scrutiny on Their Records on Racial Inequality as Democratic Primaries Move Forward

As the Democratic presidential primaries continue, candidates are shifting their focus towards wooing African American voters, a crucial demographic in the election. However, many candidates are facing scrutiny for their records on racial inequality, with some finding their rhetoric contradicting their performances.

Donald Trump, for instance, is touting his administration's efforts to reduce mass incarceration and create "opportunity zones," but his history of racial rhetoric and policies raises questions about his sincerity. Pete Buttigieg's record as mayor of South Bend, Indiana, has been criticized by African American leaders for its lack of progress on racial issues, while Amy Klobuchar's record as a prosecutor has been criticized for its racial bias. Mike Bloomberg's stop-and-frisk policies as mayor of New York City and his support for right-wing theories on the financial crisis have also been criticized.

African American voters are not easily fooled and have a clear agenda for change. They face structural inequality in unemployment rates, wages, jobs, schools, healthcare, housing, and criminal justice, among other areas. They want what most Americans want – equality and justice – and are looking for leaders who will take bold action to address these issues.

The Kerner Commission, established by President Lyndon Johnson in the 1960s, was a landmark effort to address the structural inequalities faced by African Americans. The commission's report warned of a "two societies, one black, one white – separate and unequal" and called for bold action to address the root causes of urban violence, including white racism and systemic inequality. The report's recommendations included new jobs, housing, and education opportunities, as well as an end to de facto segregation and greater police accountability.

Fifty-two years later, much has changed, but too much remains the same. Affirmative action has opened doors for some, but inequality has grown more extreme, and structural racism still pervades many areas of American life. As politicians campaign for African American votes, they will be judged on their willingness to accept the Kerner Report's challenge and take bold action to address the structural inequalities faced by African Americans.

Title: Job Creation Slows as Budget Uncertainty Looms

The job market in the United States showed signs of slowing down in November, with economists warning that a failure to agree on a plan to reduce the deficit by the end of the year could lead to a recession in the first half of 2013. The Congressional Budget Office and many private economists predict that more than $600 billion in government spending cuts and automatic tax increases will take effect in 2013, potentially pushing unemployment back up.

Despite businesses seeming to hire in spite of the uncertainty in Washington, experts warn that job growth could weaken early next year if a budget impasse is not resolved. Even if a short-term solution is reached, job growth remains below what is needed to push wages substantially higher or reduce the broadest measure of unemployment anytime soon.

The labor force shrank by 350,000 in November, with a significant number of workers remaining discouraged and dropping out of the job hunt. The labor participation rate, which represents the portion of the adult population that is either employed or actively looking for work, remains low by historical standards at 63.6%.

While job growth in November exceeded expectations, the Labor Department revised downward its figures for the preceding months. The manufacturing sector lost 7,000 jobs, and construction employment fell by 20,000, partly due to Hurricane Sandy's impact. Retailers added 53,000 jobs, but this may not persist in December.

The unemployment rate among workers aged 20-24 fell to 12.7% in November, and among 25-34-year-olds it fell to 7.9%. However, the unemployment rate among workers 55 and older remained steady at 5.8%. The Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan index of consumer confidence fell to 74.5 in early December, the lowest since August, due to concerns over the budget standoff.

Overall, the economy remains vulnerable, with a widely followed measure of consumer confidence showing a marked decline. While some sectors, such as retail, showed strength, others, like manufacturing, experienced weakness. The pace of job growth remains slow, and experts warn that a failure to agree on a budget plan could lead to a recession in the first half of 2013.

Title: Trump Renounces Birtherism, Claims Credit for Ending Controversy

Article:

In a highly anticipated event, Republican nominee Donald Trump announced on Friday morning that President Barack Obama was born in the United States. This statement comes after five years of questioning Obama's citizenship, which Trump had perpetuated through various media outlets, including television, press conferences, and social media.

Trump claimed credit for ending the birther controversy, stating that Hillary Clinton and her 2008 campaign started the issue, which he "finished" by continuing to question Obama's birthplace. He added that the country should now focus on making America strong and great again.

The event was billed as a campaign event, and Trump arrived 63 minutes late to the Trump International Hotel in Washington, D.C. The hotel, still under construction, is partially open for business, with rooms available for $895 a night. Trump's opening remarks were an advertisement for the hotel, which he claimed was finished under budget and ahead of schedule.

Trump then turned his attention to the Medal of Honor winners and former generals on stage, stating he has "very good chemistry" with them. He invited a series of Medal of Honor winners to speak, and the crowd erupted in chants of "USA!" when he returned to the lectern.

Trump spoke in a sleepy tone, discussing platitudes about improving the country and mistruths about the state of the country. He took no questions and offered no explanation for why he had changed his stance on the issue, despite Obama releasing his long-form birth certificate in 2011 and disclosing his birth announcement in 1961.

The birther controversy surrounding Obama's birthplace has been ongoing since 2004, with various conspiracy theories and misinformation spread through chain emails and message boards. While Trump did not start the controversy, he perpetuated it through his public statements and social media posts.

Title: House Armed Services Committee Report Concludes White House Failed to Provide Sufficient Security in Benghazi, Libya

The House Armed Services Committee has released a report concluding that the White House failed to provide sufficient security to defend the U.S. outpost in Benghazi, Libya, and that the administration quickly knew the violence was a terrorist attack. The report, released on [date], is the result of an investigation by the committee's Republican majority.

The report found that the White House "failed to comprehend or ignored the dramatically deteriorating security situation in Libya" and that U.S. personnel in Benghazi were "woefully vulnerable" in September 2012. The report also concluded that the Defense Department believed the violence was a terrorist attack "nearly from the outset."

The report's key findings include:

* The White House failed to comprehend or ignored the deteriorating security situation in Libya.
* U.S. personnel in Benghazi were woefully vulnerable in September 2012.
* The Defense Department believed the violence was a terrorist attack "nearly from the outset."
* There was no stand-down order issued by the administration to forces in Tripoli preparing to respond to the attack.

The report also agrees with the administration that during the attack, military assets were not positioned to make a difference in the response, and there was no stand-down order issued by the administration to forces in Tripoli preparing to respond.

Democrats on the committee have welcomed the report, stating that it brings an end to the politicization of the Benghazi controversy and that it is time to move forward and establish how to best protect U.S. citizens around the globe.

The report's findings are a significant development in the ongoing debate over the Obama administration's response to the Benghazi attack, which killed four Americans, including Ambassador Christopher Stevens. The report's conclusions are likely to be closely scrutinized by both sides of the political aisle, with some Republicans continuing to accuse the administration of covering up its response to the attack, while Democrats have welcomed the report's findings as a step towards moving forward.

Title: House Republicans and President Obama Still Far Apart on Budget Priorities

The meeting between President Barack Obama and House Republicans on Wednesday was part of the White House's "charm offensive" on Capitol Hill, aimed at bridging the partisan divide. However, despite the cordial atmosphere, the discussion did not yield significant progress on key issues, particularly those related to reducing the deficit.

House Speaker John Boehner thanked the president for coming but emphasized the remaining challenges on issues such as jobs, balancing the budget, and unlocking energy resources. Republicans reiterated their top priority of tackling federal spending and reining in record deficits, which Obama did not share.

Several Republicans expressed disappointment with the president's lack of substance in his answers, with Georgia Rep. Paul Broun calling his remarks "just a bunch of platitudes." Arkansas Rep. Tom Cotton noted that the federal government, like any business or family, needs to work towards a balanced budget.

House Majority Leader Eric Cantor suggested that the divide on fiscal issues could carry over to other issues, stating that if the president is unwilling to raise taxes, it may hinder progress. Some Republicans also questioned Obama's priorities, citing his meeting with his political arm, Organizing for Action, on the same day.

Despite the tense moments, the meeting was described as "affable" by Rep. Tom Cotton, and some members expressed a willingness to continue the dialogue. House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan praised the president, saying "he did himself some good."

The meeting was the second time Obama had traveled to the Capitol to discuss issues with House Republicans since his election, with some members lamenting the lack of communication between the White House and Congress.

Title: Lawmakers Introduce "Jobs" Bills Amid High Unemployment Rate

Article:

Lawmakers on Capitol Hill are introducing a slew of "jobs" bills in an effort to address the nation's high unemployment rate. According to the Labor Department, employers added only 80,000 jobs in June, leaving the unemployment rate unchanged at 8.2 percent. This has led to a surge in job-creation proposals, with about 90 bills introduced in the 18 months since the 112th Congress first met. This is a significant increase from the previous two-year congressional cycle and seven times more than the Congress before that.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Democrat, emphasized the need for Congress to focus on creating jobs and helping the middle class, rather than engaging in partisan politics. He highlighted a small-business tax cut designed to reward hiring and provide incentives for payroll growth as a key example of a "jobs" bill.

However, Republicans have criticized the Obama administration's job-creation policies, citing the recent employment report as evidence of their failure. House Speaker John A. Boehner, a Republican, argued that the president needs to work with Republicans to remove government obstacles to job creation.

Some of the "jobs" bills introduced by lawmakers may seem unrelated to job creation. For example, the National Strategic and Critical Minerals Production Act aims to streamline government regulations in the mining industry, while the Farm Dust Regulation Prevention Act seeks to exempt farm dust from Clean Air Act regulations. However, proponents of these bills argue that they will help preserve American jobs.

The debate over job-creation policies is often marked by partisan spin and disagreement over the number of jobs that would be preserved or created. Republicans have criticized the Obama administration's health care law, claiming it will force employers to lay off workers or close up shop. However, the president has argued that the law will lay a foundation for a stronger economy that will create jobs.

As lawmakers continue to introduce and debate "jobs" bills, it remains to be seen whether they will be able to find common ground and pass legislation that will effectively address the nation's unemployment crisis.

Title: Trump Wants to Reopen US Economy by Easter, Despite Experts' Concerns

President Donald Trump expressed his desire to have the US "opened up and just raring to go" by Easter, which falls on April 12, just 19 days away. This goal contradicts the advice of top public-health experts, such as Dr. Anthony Fauci, who are concerned that ending social-distancing measures too soon could exacerbate the coronavirus outbreak.

Fauci stated, "I can not see that all of a sudden, next week or two weeks from now, it's going to be over. I don't think there's a chance of that." He emphasized the importance of taking a cautious approach to combat the virus.

The World Health Organization (WHO) also warned that the US could become the new epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic, citing a "very large acceleration" in infections. The US had fewer than 100 confirmed cases on March 1, but by Tuesday afternoon, it had nearly 50,000.

Trump's call to reopen the economy goes against the advice of his own experts and warnings from governors on the front lines of the pandemic. Dr. Fauci reiterated, "I think we should do everything we possibly can do. I mean, in all sectors, because obviously, as I've said so many times, when you think you're maybe overreacting, you probably are not acting as forcefully as you should."

Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York implored Trump not to risk endangering lives by rushing to reopen the economy. Cuomo stated, "If you ask the American people to choose between public health and the economy, then it's no contest. No American is going to say, 'Accelerate the economy at the cost of human life.' Because no American is going to say how much a life is worth."

The Trump administration had previously announced new guidelines aimed at slowing the spread of the virus, including avoiding gatherings of 10 or more people, canceling nonessential travel, and not going out to bars and restaurants. These guidelines were in place for 15 days and were to be reassessed.
