The White House has been rallying students on college campuses in recent weeks, leading Republicans to accuse the President of exploiting the issue to fire up an important segment of his reelection campaign.

Mr. Obama stated that Congress has largely ignored his entreaties and that the issue should have been resolved weeks ago. He acknowledged that lawmakers in both parties are working on a solution, but emphasized that they have not done so yet and that pressure needs to be kept on them.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Democrat, expressed optimism that an agreement can still be reached before the deadline, stating that discussions over the past two days have been productive.

Title: Virginia Governor's Succession Plan Hit by New Scandal as Attorney General Admits to Blackface Incident

The succession plan for Virginia Governor Ralph Northam, already thrown into chaos by allegations against Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax, has hit another stumbling block. Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring, the third in line to the governorship, has admitted to wearing blackface in the 1980s. Herring apologized for his actions, calling them "inexcusable" and "insensitive."

Herring's admission comes as the Virginia Democratic Party grapples with a multi-layered race and sex scandal. The trouble began when a right-wing site unearthed a photo on Governor Northam's med-school yearbook page showing a man in blackface next to a man dressed as a Klansman. Northam initially admitted he was one of the men in the photo, but later backtracked, suggesting he wasn't either man.

Meanwhile, Lieutenant Governor Fairfax is facing allegations of sexual assault, which he denies. Fairfax has claimed to be the victim of a "smear" perpetrated by his political enemies, including Richmond Mayor Levar Stoney and possibly Governor Northam himself. Fairfax has also accused The Washington Post of being in on the conspiracy.

Fairfax's future was further thrown into doubt on Wednesday, when Dr. Vanessa Tyson, a professor at Scripps College in California, gave a lengthy statement detailing the allegations against him. According to Tyson, Fairfax kissed her and forced her to perform oral sex on him in 2004, despite her "obvious distress." Tyson said she suffered from deep humiliation and shame after the incident.

The situation is unclear, with both Northam and Fairfax going on the offensive. Northam is reportedly looking to hire a private investigator to find out how the photo got out, while Fairfax has accused his accuser of being a "smear" and has even used profanity to describe her. The Washington Post has not been able to corroborate the allegations against Fairfax.

The crisis has left the Virginia Democratic Party in disarray, with the fourth in line to the governorship being House Speaker Kirk Cox, a Republican. The situation is ongoing, and it remains unclear how it will play out.

Title: Obama's Relevance in Question as Republicans Take Control of Congress

Article:

Following the Republican takeover of Congress, President Barack Obama has expressed a desire to work with the new majority leader, Mitch McConnell, and Senate Republicans to advance America's business. However, the question remains whether Obama's presidency will be marked by cooperation or stagnation.

Despite the historic Republican victory, Obama's ability to shape policy and legislation will not be diminished solely due to the opposition party's control. As the commander-in-chief, he still holds significant power and influence. A notable example is Ronald Reagan, who faced similar circumstances in his sixth year in office and went on to achieve significant successes, including the INF Treaty and the 1986 Tax Reform Act.

However, Obama's own actions and ideology may hinder his ability to achieve significant bipartisan accomplishments. His signature policy achievement, the Affordable Care Act, has lost momentum and faces an uncertain future. Additionally, his reluctance to reach across the aisle and his inability to work with Republicans have been a hallmark of his presidency.

In foreign policy, Obama's diminished leadership role and lack of willingness to take a strong stance have led to a diminished America on the world stage. Unlike Reagan, who enjoyed a strong partnership with Mikhail Gorbachev, Obama's relationships with world leaders have been marked by a lack of cooperation and leadership.

To achieve his policy goals, Obama will likely rely on executive orders and unilateral actions, which could further divide the country. He may also attempt to shape the judiciary by appointing liberal judges, including a potential replacement for Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.

While Obama remains relevant, his ability to shape policy and achieve significant accomplishments is limited. His own radicalism and unwillingness to work with Republicans have led to a diminished presidency, and his legacy will likely be shaped by his actions in the courts rather than through bipartisan cooperation.

Title: Thousands of Protesters in Hong Kong Call on President Trump to "Liberate" the City

Article:

Thousands of protesters in Hong Kong gathered on Sunday, waving American flags and chanting the US national anthem as they marched to the US Consulate. The protesters, wearing black shirts and masks, carried posters that read "President Trump, please liberate Hong Kong" and sang "The Star-Spangled Banner" as they demonstrated. The event was organized by pro-democracy groups, who called on President Trump to support their fight against the Chinese government.

Defense Secretary Mark Esper urged Beijing to use "restraint" in its dealings with Hong Kong, a British colony returned to Chinese rule in 1997. Esper made the statement at a press conference in Paris on Saturday. The Sunday protests began peacefully but turned violent when police fired tear gas to disperse the crowds that converged on the city's Central District. The demonstrators smashed windows, vandalized a subway station, ignited fires in the street, and set up barricades.

The city has been in a state of turmoil throughout the summer, prompted by an extradition bill that would have allowed suspects in semi-autonomous Hong Kong to be sent to mainland China to face trial in courts controlled by the Communist Party. Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam last week announced she was formally withdrawing the bill, but it did little to discourage the protests, which have since turned into calls for more democratic reforms.

Title: Paul Ryan Emerges as Key Player in Washington's Budget Standoff

Paul Ryan, the Republican Representative from Wisconsin, has taken center stage in the ongoing budget standoff in Washington, successfully engaging President Barack Obama in a meeting at the White House. This development comes as a surprise, given the two politicians' history as political rivals. However, their past relationship, built on ideological differences rather than personal animosity, has allowed them to work together.

Ryan's involvement has helped shift the tone of the meeting, with both sides expressing optimism and a willingness to continue negotiations. The White House has acknowledged progress, but it remains unclear whether Ryan can push a deal over the finish line.

Ryan's ability to engage with Obama is a departure from the failed attempts by House Speaker John Boehner, who has been unable to reach a deal with the President. Ryan's relationship with Obama is built on a prior understanding, developed during the 2012 presidential election, where they were fierce competitors but not enemies.

Their past interactions have shown a mutual respect, with Ryan and Obama having a "preexisting condition" built on ideological differences rather than personal insults. Their relationship has been developing over the years, with their last public encounter being a lunch meeting in March, where they discussed the budget.

Ryan's involvement in the budget standoff has brought a new dynamic to the negotiations, with his expertise in fiscal matters as chairman of the House Budget Committee making him a key player. While it remains uncertain whether Ryan can push a deal through, his ability to engage with Obama has opened up new possibilities for progress.

Title: Romney's Etch A Sketch Moment: A Shift in Stances Ahead of Final Debate

The third and final presidential debate is just around the corner, and Mitt Romney is taking advantage of the opportunity to rebrand himself as a more moderate candidate. The Republican nominee has been accused of flip-flopping on several issues, including his stance on healthcare, immigration, and abortion. However, his campaign has hinted at a "reset" button, reminiscent of the Etch A Sketch toy, which allows users to erase and restart their drawings.

Romney has indeed made some significant changes to his positions, including supporting increased Pell Grant funding, acknowledging parts of the Affordable Care Act as worth keeping, and advocating for a pathway to legal status for young illegal immigrants. He has also tried to reassure voters that he will not lower taxes on the wealthy or be a crusader on abortion.

President Barack Obama has poked fun at Romney's shift, labeling it "Romnesia" and warning that the candidate will say anything to get elected. However, polls suggest that the move to the middle may be paying off, with Romney even or pulling ahead of the president in some polls.

Larry J. Sabato, director of the University of Virginia's Center for Politics, believes that Romney has more flexibility to maneuver than most presidential nominees and is taking advantage of it. Ford O'Connell, a Republican strategist, agrees, saying that Romney is trying to woo single-issue voters and narrow Obama's lead among key demographics.

Romney has also generated some doubt about his stance on the National Defense Authorization Act and his support for the individual health care mandate in Massachusetts. However, his vagueness on some issues has irritated some critics, who believe he is trying to avoid being pinned down on specific policies.

Michael F. Cannon, director of health policy studies at the Cato Institute, said that Romney's ambiguity is intentional, as he wants to avoid being held accountable for his actions. Frank Sharry, executive director of America's Voice, believes that Romney is trying to put lipstick on the pig, with his policies amounting to deportation for most undocumented immigrants, but his rhetoric suggesting otherwise.
